1 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


September 19, 2000, Tuesday


Yugoslavia's youth unite


BYLINE: Eve-Ann Prentice


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 1166 words


 

As Serbia's elections near, Eve-Ann Prentice meets a leading member of the anti-Milosevic movement

One of Slobodan Milosevic's chief opponents will not be out campaigning against the Yugoslav President during next weekend's presidential and parliamentary elections in Serbia.

Instead, Ivan Marovic, 26, will be settling down to a new life - as a soldier in the Yugoslav Army. One of the leading lights in the student-led resistance movement Otpor, the mechanical engineer was posted to Barr in Montenegro to begin his compulsory national service ten days ago. But he will almost certainly not prove an easy recruit for any Serbian drill-sergeant looking for unquestioning obedience. 

Sitting in a pavement cafe outside the central Belgrade headquarters of the Otpor movement recently, Marovic spoke to me, in near-perfect English, about the goals and tactics of the youth-based organisation that aims to overthrow the Serbian regime. The group has seen a phenomenal growth in the past year, from a few hundred members in December last year to 100,000 today, according to Marovic.

Blue-uniformed, armed police hovered uncomfortably close as he spoke. A huge banner with the organisation's symbol of a clenched fist billowed in the breeze as it hung from a first-floor window.

Otpor (meaning Resistance) is not a political party, yet it has galvanised huge numbers of anti-Milosevic Serbs. Though most of its supporters are still young, what started as a student protest movement in 1988 is attracting the unemployed and some pensioners. The movement is throwing its weight behind the main opposition candidate standing against Milosevic in Sunday's poll, Vojislav Kostunica.

Marovic spoke in a blisteringly hot Belgrade as trolley-buses thick with grime and seemingly held together with bits of twine carried those lucky enough to have jobs off to their workplaces. Bomb damage to factories after last year's Nato airstrikes, along with the effects of sanctions, have cost many Serbs their jobs.

It is against this background of daily grind that many young people of Serbia have united. The cafes seem as busy as ever, but a closer look reveals that many customers are lingering over a single coffee. Ill-paid university professors take second jobs driving trolley-buses and schoolteachers have been known to rummage in dustbins for food.

Many are worried that Serbia is on the brink of another war, this time against Montenegro, the only other republic, with Serbia, to make up federal Yugoslavia. Four other republics - Croatia, Slovenia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia - have seceded in the Balkan upheavals of the past decade.

President Milosevic earlier this year led moves to change the constitution to allow himself to be elected by the federal Parliament for two more terms, an act seen as being calculated to infuriate Montenegro's leaders, who have been straining at the leash since before last year's bombing campaign by Nato. Many think that they still have years of Milosevic's rule to come, along with unending international hostility.

Ivan Marovic knew in July that he would be called up by the Army this month, yet he claims that his absence from the political fray will make no difference to Otpor. "We have made sure that our organisation does not depend on one person," he says. "So whoever gets arrested or killed or goes over to join the Government does not hurt Otpor."

This philosophy has helped the group to cope with increasing harassment by the regime in the run-up to Sunday's elections. On September 4, plainclothes and uniformed police raided Otpor's Belgrade headquarters and carted off two computers, as well as thousands of T-shirts, posters and badges. "I keep the business cards only of people in the regime in our offices so that only they can be linked to us if the cards are seized," says Marovic.

On September 9, Marovic was given a rousing send-off to his year in the Army at a street party in Belgrade's main shopping street. The next day, more plainclothes police descended on Otpor's headquarters with the intention of carrying off more of the organisation's equipment - but this time their haul consisted of empty cardboard boxes. The police were also far rougher with the Otpor activists inside the headquarters building, slapping faces and pushing members about, Otpor said last week. A photographer had his camera seized when he was stopped while driving a car emblazoned with an Otpor sticker.

The organisation says 350 of its supporters have been arrested in recent months, albeit most of them briefly, and that 100 have been beaten up.

"Our main goal is to make the transition of our society into a true democracy, with political and economic stability. There are two conditions for this: the removal of the Milosevic regime and free and fair elections," says Marovic. "We encourage people to stand and fight for their rights, to be politically active."

Otpor espouses peaceful resistance, however: "There can be no change by violent methods," says Marovic. "Violent change would only give us a new Milosevic. Otpor is more a state of mind than an organisation as such."

But it is the young who seem to be more willing to risk the ire of the regime by campaigning against the Government of Milosevic, and Otpor's rise has helped to reveal a growing generation gap. Many of Otpor's young members are the children of active or tacit supporters of the ruling Socialist Party. This is because many older people still see socialism as an antidote to the fascism that blighted the Balkans during the Second World War, and partly because they are weary of conflict after a decade of civil strife and sanctions in the region. Older people also remember years of comparative wealth and ease in the 1970s and 1980s, when Yugoslavia was regarded with envy by the people from other socialist countries before the Berlin Wall fell in 1989.

"It is interesting that the young are not afraid," says Marovic. "The police have started searching our apartments, and since most of us live with our parents, it is our parents who are afraid."

Nenad Sitarica is a 22-year-old political science student and a core Otpor member in Belgrade. His father is a candidate for President Milosevic's Socialist Party in the elections. "There is a big generation gap," says Sitarica. "My father has been a member of the party since he was 16."

Many young educated Serbs have already made new lives abroad; others plan to go. Some have turned to the Orthodox Church, with a surge in young people becoming priests and nuns, to their parents' chagrin.

But Marovic will stay on when he completes his national service: "I considered living abroad, but I would feel defeated if I left. This country is worth fighting for. If you had a parent in a mental hospital, you would still visit him, you would not leave home."

Otpor's website has a section in English: www.otpor.net


LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

2 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


Anti-Milosevic opposition beset by more bickering


SECTION: News; D6


LENGTH: 601 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


In a setback to efforts to unseat Slobodan Milosevic, an opposition leader denounced rivals in the movement and said his followers would boycott joint rallies aimed at forcing the Yugoslav president to step down.

Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, accused another opposition group led by Zoran Djindjic of pushing the country to civil war by refusing offers of early elections to end the political crisis that followed the 78- day NATO bombing campaign.

It was the latest episode in a persistent rift between the opposition groups. The rift has long frustrated efforts to topple Milosevic, whose confrontational policies have dragged this country into four disastrous wars that have left Yugoslavia in economic ruin. 

Draskovic wants to accept the Milosevic government's offer of early elections this fall. Djindjic and his allies, by contrast, insist that Milosevic step down immediately and make way for a transitional government pending new elections under international supervision.

Draskovic, a former deputy prime minister, dismissed Djindjic's Democratic party as ''gentlemen who do not want elections, who do not seek a political agreement, who prefer to count rifles and dead Serbs instead of ballots.'' He made the comment in an interview with a provincial television station that was distributed yesterday by the independent news agency Beta.

In an interview published Saturday by the Italian newspaper La Repubblica, Draskovic warned that ''if there aren't elections, there will be a civil war.''

''We're very, very close,'' he said. ''And I'm against another war at all costs.''

Djindjic rejected Draskovic's accusations and hinted that Draskovic may not be serious in demanding that Milosevic go.

''We are not seeking co-operation with the Serbian Renewal Movement (alone) but with all those who want Milosevic to leave,'' he said in a statement carried by Beta.

''Those who want Milosevic to leave should tell the people so outright,'' Djindjic said. ''And if they don't want him to leave, they should say so as well.''

The rift between Draskovic and Djindjic has reared its head before. Three months of massive protests in 1996 and 1997 swayed Milosevic but did not topple him. Then, like now, rifts appeared in the opposition movement's leadership.

On Thursday, an estimated 150,000 people turned out here for the biggest anti-Milosevic rally in the capital in years.

Draskovic was jeered when he echoed the Milosevic government's call for early elections. He blamed the hostile reception on ''militant Djindjic activists'' and said his party would henceforth boycott rallies organized by the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition groups including Djindjic's Democrats.

''They will see how many supporters they have when Serbian Renewal Movement stops courting them and filling up the squares where they stage their rallies, because the Serbian Renewal Movement no longer has a reason to be there,'' Draskovic said.

He cautioned the opposition to be careful of making promises to the public that it cannot fulfill. During Thursday's rally, Djindjic gave Milosevic 15 days to resign or ''the whole of Serbia will rise up'' in street protests and a general strike will be called.

A comparatively small party, New Democracy, has appealed for unity among Milosevic's opponents. It said the three existing concepts for reform, a transitional government, political pressures and early elections ''are not mutually exclusive.''

That party was once allied with Milosevic but has turned to the opposition in recent years.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The New York Times


July 11, 1999, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Belgrade's Bitter People Shun Protests for Now


BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 


SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1182 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 10


During his 12 years in power, whenever Slobodan Milosevic has been on the ropes, most of the punches have been thrown here in the Serbian capital.

This is where the Serbian leader called out Yugoslav Army tanks and used tear gas eight years ago to put down a violent demonstration against state-controlled television, the key lever in his control of public opinion. It was here that the depth of urban middle-class revulsion with Mr. Milosevic's rule was shown to the world in three solid months of daily street demonstrations in the winter of 1996-97. 

But Belgrade, so far, has been a conspicuous wallflower in the growing anti-Milosevic movement that has found expression across Serbia in the last two weeks. This city has about a fifth of Serbia's population and about 40 percent of its educated middle-class, yet all the action has been in the boondocks.

With rallies in smaller cities across Serbia, the opposition movement has tapped frustration among restive army reservists, who are home from the lost war in Kosovo and, for the most part, unpaid for their trouble. Discontented Serbs also say they fear for their future in the collapsed postwar economy, are weary of international isolation and are shamed by crimes committed in their name in Kosovo.

While Belgrade's city council argued itself into paralysis this week over the question of Mr. Milosevic's resignation, city leaders in three cities -- Novi Sad, Nis and Sombor -- quickly approved resolutions demanding that he step down.

The delay in Belgrade's involvement in this season's round of anti-Milosevic demonstrations does not derive from any lack of ambient animus toward the Yugoslav President, who has been indicted as a war criminal and has lost four straight wars while turning once-prosperous Serbia into the basket-case economy of Eastern Europe.

On the streets here on Friday night, it was difficult to find a citizen of Belgrade, young or old, middle-class or poor, who did not believe the time had come for Mr. Milosevic to go.

"I would like to see him strung up and hanging in the center of town," said Ivan Tarla, 23, a film student at the University of Belgrade. "We are ready to go out into the street, but we need very clear goals."

The fractured opposition movement in Serbia is not planning demonstrations in Belgrade until late August precisely because it does not yet have a unified set of goals.

Mr. Milosevic, meanwhile, is attending to his main instrument of control -- the same state-controlled television that Belgraders demonstrated against en masse in 1991. He will rebuild the bombed television headquarters in the capital, officials say, before the bridges that NATO smashed all over Serbia.

So far, the largest single opposition party -- the only one that can guarantee the daily presence of tens of thousands of demonstrators on the streets of the capital for weeks on end -- has not yet joined the Alliance for Change, the coalition of smaller opposition parties that is organizing rallies against Mr. Milosevic outside Belgrade.

The Serbian Renewal Movement -- led by Vuk Draskovic, the self-proclaimed "king of the streets" and an on-again, off-again critic of the Milosevic regime -- is sitting on its hands for the moment.

Mr. Draskovic, who briefly served as a deputy minister in Mr. Milosevic's Government before being fired in the middle of the Kosovo war, has said the time is not yet ripe for demonstrations.

Polls indicate that in the aftermath of the Kosovo war, Mr. Draskovic's party gained strength and won the support of about 15 percent of Serbia's population, far more than any other opposition group. His party leads a coalition that runs city hall in Belgrade.

Probably more important, he controls a Belgrade television station, Studio B, a widely watched alternative to state television in the capital. Leaders of smaller opposition parties say they must gain better access to Studio B to whip up mass enthusiasm for demonstrations in Belgrade.

Mr. Draskovic's personal political ambitions seem to be keeping his party out of the streets. He holds a grudge against Zoran Djindjic, the key leader of the Alliance for Change. The bad blood grows out of Mr. Djindjic's boycott of an election two years ago, when Mr. Draskovic ran for President of Serbia. Badly needing those opposition votes, he finished a poor third.

His advisers say Mr. Draskovic has decided that the only way to force Mr. Milosevic from power is for a strong individual politician to rise above a decade of confused infighting among multiple small and ineffectual opposition parties and give Serbs one clear alternative. That alternative, in their view, is none other than Mr. Draskovic.

Leaders of the Alliance for Change, while resentful of what they say is Mr. Draskovic's self-involved brand of politics, do not dismiss his importance -- especially in street demonstrations.

"We need Mr. Draskovic's support," said Slobodan Vuksanovic, a senior strategist in the Alliance for Change. "We need him because of the number of people he can deliver and because of Studio B. Belgrade is the heart of Serbia in a political sense. Everything depends on the success of the demonstrations there."

Mr. Vuksanovic said that in Belgrade, unlike most of the rest of Serbia, the organizational structure of the ruling and opposition parties is strong and relatively well disciplined. To pull off a series of major demonstrations that is big enough not to be disrupted by Mr. Milosevic's police or by supporters of the ultra-nationalist Serbian Radical Party, he said, the Alliance for Change has no choice but to try to ally itself with Mr. Draskovic.

Successful rallies in the boondocks, then, are a way of convincing Mr. Draskovic and members of his Serbian Renewal Movement that if they stand on the sidelines for too long they may be left out altogether in divvying up power in a post-Milosevic Serbia.

There were signals this week that the strategy is beginning to work, as a surprisingly passionate anti-Milosevic movement bubbled up in the least likely of Serbian towns. In the southern city of Leskovac, long dominated by Mr. Milosevic's supporters, more than 20,000 people filled the streets on Monday. The protest was followed by smaller demonstrations throughout the week.

Startled and anxious to cash in on popular sentiment, the Serbian Renewal Movement decided on Wednesday to help locals in Leskovac organize their demonstrations.

Leaders of Mr. Draskovic's party conceded in Belgrade that they had underestimated grass-roots anger at the Milosevic regime. As for future rallies, they seemed to be opening a door that Mr. Draskovic, just two weeks ago, slammed shut.

"Vuk knows when the time comes," said Ognjen Pribicevic, a political adviser to Mr. Draskovic.

In Belgrade, it seems many people are ready.

"I will be the first in the streets because I have had enough," said Mira Angelic, 50, a lawyer. "Right now, there is no spark to start the fire. But I think it is a question of days and weeks. The spark eventually has to come from Belgrade."

The Independent (London)


April 16, 2000, Sunday


100,000-STRONG DEMO 'SHOWS MILOSEVIC WILL SOON BE GONE'


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 410 words


 

SERBIAN OPPOSITION leaders claimed yesterday that Friday night's anti -government rally was evidence that the pro-democracy movement was building the momentum to remove Slobodan Milosevic from power.

Seventeen opposition leaders, including Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, and his rival Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party, stood on the same platform and were cheered by the 100,000 people who packed Belgrade's Republic Square.

"Our lives are not lives any more after the last 10 years of Milosevic rule. The isolation we face makes us think that we live in a plague-infected country" said Mr Draskovic. 

The rally was the opposition's first joint protest since its leaders united behind a much-publicised accord in January to call for early free and fair elections.

Local elections are due this year and the crucial parliamentary elections next year.

"The opposition no longer has any choice. This rally cannot and must not be ignored," political analyst Srdjan Bogosavljevic told independent Belgrade radio B292.

The anti-Milosevic campaign has "achieved such a level of support that the opposition has no right to betray public expectations," he said.

Miroljub Labus, head of the anti-Milosevic G17 group, said that the rally had "sent a message both to the government and the opposition. The regime got a message that many people are absolutely dissatisfied with what is happening nowadays, and that they are expecting changes."

Aleksandar Vucic, Serbia's information minister, claimed he "heard nothing intelligent" from the opposition leaders.

"After the rally, I am convinced we will win in the coming elections," said Mr Vucic, of the ultra-nationalist Radical Party, which is allied with Milosevic's Socialists and the neo-communist JUL party, which is led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic.

Mrs Markovic, in turn, lambasted the opposition leaders as "monstrous advocates of violence and of complete war against political opponents".

A recent survey by the Belgrade Institute for Social Sciences showed that the united Serbian opposition would have 46 per cent of votes if the elections were held now.

The ruling coalition of the Socialists, JUL and the ultra-nationalists of Vojislav Seselj would obtain only 23 per cent of votes.

Almost 20 per cent of voters would be undecided, while a little under 12 per cent of voters would not go to the polls, the survey found.

Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


May 19, 2000 Friday Final Edition


Small Belgrade stations closed;
news read at city hall: Crowd demands that Milosevic commit suicide


SOURCE: Los Angeles Times


BYLINE: Paul Watson


SECTION: World; Pg. A16


LENGTH: 523 words


DATELINE: Belgrade


Forced off the air by state seizure of their studios, Belgrade's independent broadcasters were reduced Thursday to reading the nightly news from a balcony of City Hall.

The news anchors had to pause each time they read out Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's name Thursday night, however, as a crowd of about 10,000 demonstrators below demanded his head.

"Slobodan, save Serbia," the protesters chanted. "Kill yourself!" 

Serbian riot police fired tear gas and beat protesters for a second night in a row after some in the crowd set fire to garbage bins and threw rocks and Molotov cocktails at officers who blocked a march through the city.

At least 12 people were treated for minor injuries following the skirmishes, which lasted for more than an hour.

After months of anti-Milosevic protests, brief clashes with riot police have become more of a violent ritual than a sign of the long-awaited uprising that protesters repeatedly called for again Thursday night.

The balcony news readings included a statement issued by Serbia's interior ministry police, who said four officers had been injured, two of them seriously, in the first night of unrest Wednesday.

At least 60 injured protesters had gone to emergency rooms for treatment, the news reader also told the jeering crowd.

Opposition leaders told the crowd they would hold daily demonstrations until Milosevic gives in to their demand for early elections, but they have made that rallying cry before, only to call off protests as interest lagged.

The latest confrontation with Milosevic -- sparked by the Serbian government's seizure of Yugoslavia's main independent television and radio stations in the dead of night -- has failed to draw crowds even half as large as several previous protests.

A leading critic of Milosevic, Serbian Renewal Movement chief Vuk Draskovic, didn't attend Thursday's rally.

His main rival in the anti-Milosevic movement, Democratic party chief Zoran Djindjic, attended but didn't speak. Four minor opposition figures spoke.

Milosevic's increasing repression is "confirmation that we are in a state of emergency," said Vukasin Petrovic, a 24-year-old leader of the democracy movement called Otpor -- Resistance.

He accused Hadzi Dragan Antic, one of Milosevic's closest family friends and editor in chief of the state-run Politika publishing house, of "leading the war against" Otpor as head of a secret "crisis headquarters."

International condemnation of the Serbian government's seizure of independent broadcasters Studio B and Radio B2-92, including sharp words from the United States and European Union, fell on deaf ears in Milosevic's regime.

The government moved to silence the last independent broadcaster with a signal strong enough to reach Belgrade -- the capital of Yugoslavia and its dominant republic, Serbia -- by jamming Radio Pancevo's transmission from a nearby suburb.

Serbian Deputy Prime Minister Vojislav Seselj, who co-signed the decree authorizing Studio B's seizure, told a news conference Thursday that he hopes more independent broadcasters and print publications will be closed.

6 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


December 7, 2000 Thursday  
National Edition


Activists still watching Belgrade;
Movement that helped oust Milosevic says new regime not off hook


BYLINE: ANDREW GRAY, Reuters News Agency


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 740 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


The bulldozers are back, and this time they've got the Untouchables behind them. The excavation machines are symbols of the mass uprising that drove out Slobodan Milosevic on Oct. 5, clearing the way for a new Yugoslav government.

Now the student-based Otpor movement, which played a leading role in the anti-Milosevic campaign, has brought back the bulldozers, this time on giant black-and-white billboards and posters plastered all across the Yugoslav capital.  

The posters carry a warning for both the country's old and new guard: "We are watching you."

The message makes clear that Otpor has not thrown its lot in with the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, the political alliance that dominates the new federal government and backs new President Vojislav Kostunica.

"Our opinion is that those guys from DOS, they are all politicians from Milosevic's time. Some of them are politicians from Tito's time," said Otpor co-founder Dejan Randic, referring to Yugoslav post-war leader Marshal Josip Broz Tito.

"And we don't have any need to be connected in some kind of government."

The posters also tell members of Mr. Milosevic's long-ruling Socialists and their allies, many of whom still hold key state and business positions, that they are not off the hook.

Otpor, which is the Serbian word for resistance, has formed a group of lawyers and legal experts to gather evidence of corruption and crime committed under Mr. Milosevic by the bosses of factories, businesses and public authorities across the country.

Some Otpor activists liken the new group to the Untouchables led by Eliot Ness, who battled gangsters and enforced prohibition in 1920s Chicago.

Aleksandar Curcic, one of the lawyers in the group, which is formally named the Bureau for Enforcing the Truth, says there are many differences between the new team and the Untouchables, but notes one common factor: the potential to make dangerous enemies.

"You can only compare us in terms of the risk we are taking in the pursuit of justice," he said in an interview at Otpor's central Belgrade headquarters.

People in their teens and early 20s, wearing jeans and bomber jackets, hang around the two-room office. A pile of crumpled Otpor posters lies in a corner of a sparsely furnished room. A list of activists' mobile-phone numbers is posted on one wall.

The group of about 30 lawyers is in the early stages of collecting evidence, having started in the past couple of weeks.

About 40 people arrive every day, bearing tales of corruption and crime that went unpunished under Mr. Milosevic, Mr. Curcic said.

Their stories range from tales of fraud or financial mismanagement to beatings of pro-democracy campaigners.

The new group aims to banish the climate of fear that existed under Mr. Milosevic and his repressive state apparatus.

"Previously, there was a situation in which citizens were afraid of directly pointing fingers at criminals," said Mr. Curcic, who got to know the student activists because he defended them in court in the Milosevic era.

"Now is the time when citizens should point out these things," he said. "And it's much easier for citizens to do this with an organization in which they have confidence. Otpor is an organization like that."

Commentators agree Otpor gave a fresh and credible appeal to the anti-Milosevic movement when it emerged a couple of years ago, unsoiled by the squabbling and allegations of corruption associated with the former president's established opponents.

Now DOS leaders want a chance to go to work, and worry that Otpor's latest campaign could turn people against them as they are just getting started. But the activists are unrepentant.

"It was a people's revolution and the political parties are responsible for our future. And we wanted to say that there must be some kind of pressure group in this situation on both sides," explained Mr. Randic, an electronics student.

He said Otpor will broaden its activities, seeking to help end Yugoslavia's years of isolation by fostering links with neighbouring states, until recently considered the country's sworn enemies, and organizing student exchange programs.

The group, which recently won MTV's Free-Your-Mind award at a ceremony in Stockholm, has two more campaigns in the works. One will warn people against turning back to the Socialists and the other will urge young people to vote in the Dec. 23 elections in Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic.

The Irish Times


May 10, 2000


Protests held in Serbian leader's town


BYLINE: By GILLIAN SANDFORD


SECTION: CITY EDITION; WORLD NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 595 words


DATELINE: POZAREVAC


The home town of President Slobodan Milosevic was the focus of a major clampdown on opposition to his rule across Serbia yesterday.

Police arrested an opposition leader, journalists and members of the youth resistance movement and set up checkpoints on all roads in and out of Pozarevac - where the Yugoslav president grew up and has a home - to prevent opposition supporters and political leaders arriving for a major opposition rally.

But about 100 members of the youth resistance movement, Otpor, and other anti-Milosevic activists slipped past the cordon to interrupt a hastily convened counter-meeting set up by officials in Pozarevac's central square. 

By mid-afternoon, it was the scene of an extraordinary standoff, with the banner-waving anti-Milosevic protesters on one side and Socialist party officials from the city seeking to address 100 or so party stalwarts on the other.

A small group of men in black trousers, black leather jackets and sunglasses - the usual garb of men working as Milosevic family bodyguards - moved to within inches of the jeering protesters.

The demonstrators did not shift or back away, but continued distributing leaflets and brandishing their flags and placards.

One 23-year-old Otpor protester said: "We want to show our resistance to the system. Milosevic is afraid of the youth of Otpor. We have parents. We have relatives. We have so many people who know us and know we are not the terrorists which the regime calls us. We just want to live like ordinary people."

A hundred yards from the standoff, the Serbian Minister of the Interior, Mr Veljko Stoiljkovic, watched, as did several dozen young men wearing T-shirts with the Serbian national flag. It was as if they might be waiting for a signal.

Pozarevac is a haven for the Milosevic family and its enterprises. Several domestic and foreign journalists and cameramen, who had also slipped into the town through the police cordon, watched as the standoff continued. Every minute threatened to explode into violent confrontation, if either side made a wrong move.

The authorities had sought in every way to block the rally, held on Victory Day, which traditionally celebrates the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945. A lorry taking stage and sound equipment into the town was stopped en route shortly after midnight.

An opposition leader, Mr Nenad Canak from the League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina, was arrested early yesterday morning on his way from Novi Sad to Pozarevac.

In Belgrade, opposition leaders held an emergency meeting after coaches they had ordered to take them to the rally failed to turn up or were sent back to Belgrade by police at checkpoints.

The non-government radio station B292 and the Belgrade television station Studio B, controlled by the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, were taken off the air. Opposition leaders said they would hold a major demonstration in the capital within days to protest at yesterday's events.

The incident that created this crisis happened last week in Pozarevac, when three members of the Otpor movement became involved in a fracas with bodyguards of Mr Milosevic's son, Marko. They were arrested and held beyond the maximum legal detention period and seemed to have been beaten when they appeared before an investigating magistrate on Monday.

One, Mr Radoje Lukovic, had a 10 cm head wound, the other two were in bandages with bloodstained pads around their eyes, said their lawyer, Mr Borivoje Bokovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

They had been released, but yesterday they were arrested again.


LOAD-DATE: May 10, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times


8 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Age (Melbourne, Australia)


July 10, 1999 Saturday  
Late Edition


Revolution rumbles in Belgrade


BYLINE: GEOFF KITNEY, EUROPE CORRESPONDENT


SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 689 words


BERLIN, FRIDAY

The first stirrings of revolution that have begun in Serbia against President Slobodan Milosevic's leadership are raising hopes that the end of his reign is nigh. But there are also fears that the end will bring still more traumatic upheaval to the Balkans.

Serbian democrats are mobilising for a "velvet" revolution similar to those in other eastern European countries. But concern is growing that Mr Milosevic and his fanatical supporters will resist change with force and that Serbia's transition to democracy will come only after a "crimson" revolution - with the spilling of more blood. 

Grass-roots hostility to Mr Milosevic's leadership, which has inflicted a decade of conflict and misery on the people of the former Yugoslavia, is emerging across Serbia. The strength of the anti-Milosevic feeling and the speed with which it is emerging suggest that he is facing the prospect of a mass uprising. Brutal suppression may be the only means left open to him to keep his grip on power.

His 10-year rule of Yugoslavia has been characterised by his determination to maintain personal power.

The disastrous military adventures he launched in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo have greatly diminished his standing with the Serbian people. But Mr Milosevic has consolidated his grip by building a formidable state security structure. Most observers believe this agency will remain loyal to him.

Cautioning against hopes for his speedy demise, the NATO military commander, General Wesley Clark, said: "He still has his hand on the sinews of power in Serbia. He controls the army. He controls the police, including a very effective and brutal secret police network. He controls the media and he controls the economy and finances.

"I see that the opposition is fragmented and weak. It's been traumatised by a decade of President Milosevic's manoeuvring, dividing the opposition, suborning the opposition, and basically his campaign of covert terror against them." General Clark said it was difficult to "predict with assurance" that President Milosevic will be overthrown.

Alarming signs have emerged in the past few days that attempts to mobilise a peaceful push for change will bring a violent response from Mr Milosevic's supporters. Already Serbs have seen the first clashes between the two camps.

In the southern town of Prokuplje, where 4000 people marched in the streets, protesters clashed, trading punches and sending tensions soaring. A shot was fired over the crowd from the local headquarters of Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party.

In Leskovac, a stronghold of the Socialist Party where large protest rallies have confirmed the depth of anger, demonstrators attacked the home of the local party leader and Milosevic supporter, Mr Zivojin Stefanovic.

The Leskovac demonstrations are seen as important because they appear to have been a spontaneous action of local people. Most other recent demonstrations were organised by various opposition groups.

The spark for the Leskovac demonstrations came from a 31-year-old television technician without any history of political activism. Last Friday night Ivan Novkovic interrupted the televising of a basketball match to broadcast a recorded message accusing the party leader, Mr Stefanovic, of abusing his authority, appointing cronies to head local companies and destroying the local economy. Mr Novkovic was arrested and sentenced to 30 days' jail.

His action has created a scramble by Opposition parties to tap into the anti-Milosevic sentiment in his own political stronghold.

This has also highlighted the great weakness of the campaign to oust Mr Milosevic and the reason his position appears to be secure, at least for the time being: the Serbian opposition remains divided and leaderless.

Foreign observers believe the first real test of whether the anti-Milosevic movement can become a serious threat will come when Serbia's most respected political figure returns to Yugoslavia.

Former central bank governor Mr Dragoslav Avramovic, who has played a key role in the creation of the Alliance for Change movement in Serbia, may have the best chance of bringing together the divided nation.


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 2007

9 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


May 27, 2000


Tensions grow in run-up to Serbian elections
A low-intensity but determined battle is being fought out across Serbia as a youth-led opposition movement seeks to end the rule of Slobodan Milosevic. Gillian Sandford reports from Belgrade


SECTION: CITY EDITION; NEWS FEATURES; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 1124 words


The Serbian cartoonist Corax is famous for a caricature that he drew before the NATO bombing. It shows Slobodan Milosevic and his wife desperately hanging on to the minute-hand of a clock, trying to hold back time as the midnight hour approaches.

Amid all the sound and fury of recent weeks in Serbia, the hands of that clock have continued to move. The clock kept ticking when Serbia's government silenced and crippled leading non-government media. It kept ticking when armed police fired tear gas at protesters and besieged hundreds in Belgrade City Hall. It continues ticking as the authorities threaten a stringent antiterrorism law. 

In all the uncertainties of Serbia, as the regime and anti-Milosevic forces plan and strategise, the clock marks time towards one crucial event. According to the constitution, local and federal elections have to be held by the end of this month. That deadline has triggered the escalation in tension across Serbia.

The media provide a crucial battleground prior to the local elections in which Milosevic needs to reclaim a swathe of town halls that the opposition now holds; most importantly, he needs to wrench back the capital. Control of information is a major asset in this political fight.

When police stormed the Studio B building in Belgrade, silencing the leading opposition voice in the capital, they did so with a formal approval signed by Serbia's two deputy prime ministers who gave a series of reasons for taking over the station. Studio B is still broadcasting, but content is controlled by the regime.

The Studio B building housed all Serbia's leading non-state media: both non-government radio and the most popular newspaper in Yugoslavia, Blic. These are now operating but in a much constrained form.

Blic, with a previous circulation of 200,000, is now unable to find presses to print more than 75,000 - the state owns presses and controls paper supply. The Belgrade radio station, Index, is again broadcasting news, but police are yards away from their offices.

The Milosevic regime now has a far tighter grip on information. It possesses the only two country-wide television stations: Radio Television Serbia (RTS), widely viewed as the mouthpiece of the regime, and TV Politika. Studio B had the potential to reach much of Serbia, but it has now been neutralised as an opposition voice.

Veran Matic, spokesman for the independent media organisation ANEM, fears the next move of the regime will be to shut down opposition radio and TV outlets outside of the capital, following the Belgrade clampdown.

The editor of Blic, Veselin Simonovic, is sharply critical of the political opposition in Serbia, who, he says, ratcheted down the protests against the storming of the Studio B building and left journalists and youth activists from the resistance movement Otpor in the front line.

"Those in the front line are journalists and members of the youth resistance movement. That's not a normal situation," he said. "We accepted a risk all these years when we put out the paper, but being in the front line is not the job of journalists, it's the job of opposition political parties."

Journalists are exposed because of the lack of leadership from the country's divided political opposition, says Simonovic. He admires citizens in Belgrade who were willing to risk their safety to protest against the media clampdown but says: "I condemn the behaviour of the opposition, who, perhaps because of fear, perhaps because they can't find a unified position, succeeded in virtually stopping the protests."

The most popular anti-Milosevic force to emerge over recent weeks has been the student group Otpor(meaning "resistance"). According to insiders in Otpor, polling from Milosevic's own party now shows that Otpor far outstrips the ruling Socialist party in popularity. They say Otpor has 28 per cent of popular support and Milosevic has just 14 per cent.

The regime has publicly branded Otpor activists as traitors, terrorists and NATO agents, and is now threatening to introduce a stringent anti-terrorism law. Analysts say this could give the government the same powers it had during the martial law of the NATO bombing. Power to arrest and hold suspects indefinitely; power to clamp down on the press; it might also include the power to disarm civilians who hold guns.

Radical activists within Otpor and in the ranks of the political opposition are urging a campaign of civil disobedience that would be enacted across Serbia. Those town halls controlled by the opposition could use their power, they argue, to shut down bus services, close facilities and bring their communities to a standstill.

Otpor is seeking to recruit supporters from its home base, the universities, and is actively courting students who were previously apathetic or disillusioned with political protest. "Our aim is to radicalise and mobilise students," said Otpor activist Branko Ilic.

The regime has responded by curtailing the university year in a bid to curb activism. Only examination students with identity cards can now pass into their faculty buildings. Many Otpor activists want to move towards an immediate campaign of civil disobedience.

Zarko Korac, a Belgrade academic and leader of one of the smaller opposition parties, would support such a move, but says the larger parties who control the town halls across Serbia are concerned about the risk.

But Otpor has a second, long-term strategy outlined by an activist and young lawyer, Slobodan Homen. The Milosevic regime has always sought to exist within the letter of the law. He has deployed security forces - police and army - in the cause of defending the country and upholding the constitution.

People in Serbia expect to have the right to vote, although an increasing number of them are disillusioned with both the government and opposition and almost half tell pollsters they don't know or won't vote in elections.

Homen claims potential voters who say they are undecided or are not going to vote are almost all opposition supporters. Otpor will use its youngsters in towns and cities across Serbia to get that electorate out - and plead with them to give the opposition a chance.

That way, he believes, a peaceful transfer of power can be achieved, and if a Hague indictment needs to be finessed to help further a bloodless transfer, he says he would accept that.

"We are fighting for demands like free and fair elections - and with those demands we can gain the support of the police and the army, because we are defending the constitution.

Why is he so certain that the forces of security will back off? "It's very hard to explain to a soldier in a tank that he has to shoot people who are demanding elections," he says.


LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times


10 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


May 10, 2000


Protesters defy Milosevic in his home town;
Police arrest demonstrators and seal off Pozarevac in an attempt to prevent opposition rally


BYLINE: Gillian Sandford in Pozarevac, Serbia


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 728 words


Gillian Sandford in Pozarevac, Serbia

The home town of Slobodan Milosevic was the focus of a major clampdown on opposition to the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic across Serbia yesterday.

Police arrested an opposition leader, journalists and members of the youth resistance movement and set up checkpoints on all roads in and out of Pozarevac - where the Yugoslav president grew up and has a home - to prevent opposition supporters and political leaders arriving for a major opposition rally.

But around 100 members of the Youth Resistance Movement, Otpor, and other anti -Milosevic activists slipped past the cordon to interrupt a hastily convened counter-meeting set up by officials in Pozarevac's central square.

By mid-afternoon, it was the scene of an extraordinary stand-off, with the banner-waving anti-Milosevic protesters on one side and Socialist party officials from the city seeking to address 100 or so party stalwarts on the other. 

A small group of men in black trousers, black leather jackets and sunglasses - the usual garb of men working as Milosevic family bodyguards - moved to within inches of the jeering protesters.

The demonstrators did not shift or back away, but continued distributing leaflets and brandishing their flags and placards, bearing the clenched fist symbol of Otpor.

One 23-year-old Otpor protester said: 'We want to show our resistance to the system. Milosevic is afraid of the youth of Otpor. We have parents. We have relatives. We have so many people who know us and know we are not the terrorists which the regime calls us. We just want to live like ordinary people.'

A hundred yards from the stand-off, the Serbian minister of the interior, Veljko Stoiljkovic, watched, as did several dozen young men wearing T-shirts with the Serbian national flag. It was as if they might be waiting for a signal.

Pozarevac is a haven for the Milosevic family and its enterprises. Marko Milosevic runs the Madonna disco, which has the reputation as the hottest nightclub in the Balkans, a cybercafe and coffee shop called Passage in the town.

Many of President Milosevic's friends from childhood in Pozarevac have become significant figures in his regime. The interior minister is among this group, as was Zika Petrovic, the recently assassinated head of Yugoslav Airlines JAP, who was gunned down in Belgrade just over a week ago.

Several domestic and foreign journalists and cameramen, who had also slipped into the town through the police cordon, watched as the stand-off continued. Every minute threatened to explode into violent confrontation, if either side made a wrong move.

The authorities had sought in every way to block the rally, held on Victory Day, which traditionally celebrates the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945. A lorry taking stage and sound equipment into the town was stopped en route shortly after midnight yesterday, said Dra gan Curcija, an official from the opposition democratic party in Pozarevac.

An opposition leader, Nenad Canak from the League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina, was arrested early yesterday morning on his way from Novi Sad to Pozarevac.

In Belgrade, opposition leaders held an emergency meeting after coaches they had ordered to take them to the rally failed to turn up or were sent back to Belgrade by police at checkpoints.

The non-government radio station B292 and the Belgrade television station Studio B, controlled by the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, were taken off the air. Opposition leaders said they would hold a major demonstration in the capital within days to protest at yesterday's events.

The incident that sparked this crisis happened last week in Pozarevac, when three members of the Otpor movement became involved in a fracas with bodyguards of Milosevic's son Marko. They were arrested, held beyond the maximum legal detention period and appeared to have been beaten when they appeared before an investigating magistrate on Monday.

One, Radoje Lukovic, had a 10cm head wound, the other two were in bandages with bloodstained pads around their eyes, said their lawyer, Borivoje Bokovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

They had been released, but yesterday they were arrested again, with a freelance reporter for non-government media who works in Pozarevac and is a brother of one of the three.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


11 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


June 7, 2000, Wednesday, FINAL


Anti-Milosevic factions move closer to action


BYLINE: Scott Taylor


SECTION: News; A14


LENGTH: 759 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Atop a private terrace overlooking the Danube River and a picturesque Belgrade skyline, the leaders of Serbia's heretofore splintered opposition movements gather regularly to discuss a collective strategy.

The serene atmosphere of this secret club provides a surreal setting for the discussions of violence and civil disobedience which are being plotted over wine, slivovitz and barbecued pork.

Although the factions propose divergent policies, the consensus is a solitary goal: the immediate overthrow of President Slobodan Milosevic's regime.

The owner of this establishment is Jovan Mandic, a former power company executive who has already paid a heavy price for challenging ''the regime.'' 

In 1992, Mr. Mandic assisted anti-Milosevic demonstrators by ordering a power black-out of Belgrade during a 200,000-strong candlelight procession. For his actions, Mr. Mandic lost his top-level job and was beaten severely for 48 hours by the Yugoslav police.

Undeterred, Mr. Mandic has since dedicated his efforts to the ''removal of the communists,'' and he has tirelessly networked to co- ordinate the various Milosevic opponents into a unified voice. His private club is frequented only by invited ''intelligentsia'' and political activists. From these meetings, the strategies are developed that culminate in the organization of student demonstrations and widespread general strikes.

Until recently, Mr. Mandic's ''club'' had put its support behind the various registered political parties, but that is no longer the case.

''Among the population, these so-called opposition leaders have lost all credibility,'' said Mr. Mandic. ''It is time for a new movement and an entirely fresh leader.''

In pursuit of this objective, the club has openly embraced the creation of the new OTPOR (resistance) and helped to organize the recent mass demonstrations. As for a new leader, the club has chosen to support a political neophyte named Milan Protic, a charismatic 45-year-old university professor. Last week Mr. Protic and 100 influential signatories registered as an official political party, thereby creating the 16th such organization currently seeking a measure of popular support in Serbia. In an effort to gain a higher moral ground, the club has successfully enlisted the support of orthodox priests from Halkidiki, the Serbian religious region located in Greece.

On the other end of the spectrum, the club intends to establish the Protic movement as a ''serious resistance force'' in the forthcoming two weeks. ''There will probably be a rash of executions in the next 10-14 days,'' said one club member. ''Killing people is the only way to get the regime's attention.''

With their opposition showing the first signs of establishing a united front, Slobodan Milosevic's ruling Socialist Party could be facing a very tough time. The Yugoslav president is currently embattled on several fronts that are beyond his control and damaging to what is left of his popular support. One year after it was signed, several key terms of the Kosovo Peace Agreement with NATO have yet to even be partially adopted, making a mockery of Mr. Milosevic's claims of a ''victory.'' So far, NATO officials have refused to allow the Serbs any of the rights to enforce sovereignty over Kosovo as was outlined and agreed to in the peace proposal. The Kosovo Liberation Army has nominally been ''disarmed,'' albeit reconstituted as the Kosovo Protection Corps, yet Serbian military and border guards have still not been allowed back into (what is still officially recognized as) the Yugoslavian sovereign territory of Kosovo.

The second major factor affecting Mr. Milosevic is the tremendous strain put on his bankrupt treasury by the ongoing NATO sanctions.

In addition to problems with the economy and political unrest, the Milosevic regime was dealt another blow last week when Bulgaria announced it would open a separate diplomatic mission in Kosovo.

Despite all the mounting pressures, it will be necessary for the opposition movement to create the climate required for fundamental change. At this point, the option of an armed revolution is no longer being discounted. The club believes that the army (excluding the senior brass) would support a coup. When asked about the tragedy of Serbs killing Serbs in a civil war, Mr. Mandic replied, ''We would consider it to be Serbs versus communists.''

Scott Taylor is editor of Esprit de Corps magazine and author of Inat: Images of Serbia and the Kosovo Conflict.


LOAD-DATE: June 7, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

12 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


July 10, 1999 Saturday  
Early Edition


Milosevic may go but blood will spill;
* SERBIA


BYLINE: Geoff Kitney


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; International News; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 742 words


Despite growing popular anger, the Yugoslav Presidnet's lust for power, and lack of opposition unity, mean there could be more bloodshed to come, reports Herald Correspondent Geoff Kitney.

THE first stirrings of revolution in Serbia against the authoritarian leadership of President Slobodan Milosevic are raising hopes his brutal reign may be coming to an end. But there are fears the end will be the beginning of more traumatic upheaval to the Balkans.

As Serbian democrats mobilise in the hope of making a "velvet" revolution - similar to the peaceful transfer of power from Communist dictatorship to liberal democracy that occurred in other eastern European countries - there is growing concern Milosevic and his fanatical supporters will resist change with force, forcing the uprising instead to become a "crimson" revolution, stained with much blood. 

Grassroots hostility to Milosevic, who has inflicted conflict and misery on his people, is flourishing across Serbia.

Its strength and the speed with which it is emerging suggest he faces the real prospect of a mass uprising. But Milosevic is unlikely to go quietly. His 10-year rule of Yugoslavia has been characterised by a ferocious determination to maintain his personal power.

Disastrous military adventures he has launched in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo have greatly diminished his standing with the Serbian people. But Milosevic has built a formidable state security structure that most observers believe is likely to stay loyal.

Alarming signs have emerged in recent days that street protests will be met with violent resistance from Milosevic's supporters.

In the southern Serbian town of Prokuplje, where 4,000 people marched in the streets, anti- and pro- Milosevic demonstrators clashed, trading punches. Shots were fired into the air from the local headquarters of Milosevic's Socialist Party. In the city of Leskovac, a stronghold of the Socialist Party where large protest rallies have confirmed the depth of anger against Milosevic, demonstrators attacked the home of the local party leader and Milosevic ally, Zivojin Stefanovic.

Western observers see the Leskovac demonstrations as important because they appear to have been the spontaneous action of local people. Most other recent demonstrations were organised by opposition groups.

The spark for the demonstrations in Leskovac was the action of a 31-year-old television technician without any history of political activism.

Last Friday night Ivan Novkovic interrupted the televising of a basketball match to broadcast a recording of himself accusing Mr Stefanovic of abusing his authority, appointing cronies to head local companies and destroying the local economy.

Mr Novkovic was arrested and sentenced to 30 days' jail, but his action appears to have turned him into a local hero.

The incident created a scramble by opposition parties to try to tap into the anti-Milosevic sentiment in his own political stronghold.

But this has highlighted the great weakness of the campaign to oust Milosevic and why his position appears to be secure for the time being at least - the Serbian opposition remains divided and leaderless.

Foreign observers believe the first real test of whether the anti-Milosevic movement can combine and become a serious threat will come when the man regarded as Serbia's most respected political figure returns to Yugoslavia.

Dragoslav Avramovic, a former governor of the central bank who has played a key role in the creation of the Alliance for Change movement in Serbia, is regarded as the person who may have the best chance of bringing divided opposition parties together

under single leadership. He is due to return next week after receiving medical treatment in Switzerland.

But in a newspaper interview he warned that street protests against Milosevic would not lead very far without a united strategy for replacing him.

He warned that because of the war crimes charges Milosevic faces, he would be unlikely to give in to demands for his resignation.

Mr Avramovic said the only way Milosevic might agree to stand aside would be if he were given some form of guarantee he would not end up before the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Prospects the Western alliance might agree to such a guarantee seem remote. Whether Serbia's opposition leaders would be inclined to offer Milosevic such protection is also doubtful.

That leaves him with a very strong motive for retaining power, and using whatever means he has to.


LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Irish Times


August 4, 1999, CITY EDITION


Anti-Milosevic rally announced


BYLINE: (Guardian Service)


SECTION: WORLD NEWS; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 80 words


Belgrade - Opposition leaders in Yugoslavia have announced their first joint rally, a sign that the campaign to remove Mr Slobodan Milosevic as president is moving into its next phase. The demonstration was announced by Mr Mladjan Dinkic (35), leader of the Group 17 organisation of independent Yugoslav economists. He hopes to bring together the two main opposition figures, Mr Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement and Mr Zoran Djindjic of Serbia's Democratic party.

14 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 27, 1999, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


Can Serb Opposition Force Milosevic Out?


SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 6; Editorial Desk 


LENGTH: 151 words



To the Editor:

Re "U.S. Quietly Resuming Aid for Some Anti-Milosevic Groups" (news article, July 24): Recent news coverage of Serbia's opposition parties has revealed the rivalries and egos among established opposition leaders that may prevent real change. The opposition that President Slobodan Milosevic should really fear is a grass-roots movement, organized without public figures, political banners and television coverage. Such a movement might quietly gain momentum, and if Mr. Milosevic failed to detect it early he might have difficulty controlling it once it had grown. 

Giving money to the known opposition groups may put some pressure on Mr. Milosevic, but it avoids the hard work of finding movements that could actually fracture his regime.
 
MARK EDMOND CLARK
New York, July 25, 1999
 
The writer is a visiting professor of sociology at the University of Banja Luka.
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Letter


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


15 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


August 8, 2000


Opposition says Draskovic a spoiler


BYLINE: Julijana Mojsilovic in Belgrade


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages, Pg. 9


LENGTH: 445 words


 

Fifteen Serbian opposition parties yesterday chose the nationalist leader of the Democratic party of Serbia as their candidate to run in September against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

"We unanimously decided to name Vojislav Kostunica as our joint candidate," Dusan Mihajlovic, leader of the New Democracy party, said.

Party officials met in Belgrade to make their decision after crisis talks with the biggest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), which had nominated its own candidate on Sunday despite appeals not to risk splitting the opposition vote by going its own way. 

The SPO leader, Vuk Draskovic, said that he had not changed his mind about his candidate, the Belgrade mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic, who the rest of the opposition fear will split the anti-Milosevic vote in the September 24 election.

Mr Kostunica, chosen by the other parties because his nationalism reflects popular opinion in Serbia, yesterday abandoned his acceptance condition that Montenegro, Yugoslavia's smaller republic, would stop its boycott of the vote. The public was expecting him to run, he said.

A recent opinion poll gave Mr Kostunica greater popularity than President Milosevic, while the Belgrade mayor backed by Vuk Draskovic has not even appeared on pollsters' lists.

The Democratic party leader, Zoran Djindjic, said Mr Draskovic would not discuss a joint candidate.

Mr Mihajlovic said that Mr Draskovic's insistence on his own presidential runner meant that he could not join their candidate lists for local elections, also due September 24.

"We unanimously supported the idea of going together with SPO to all elections, but after the SPO came out with its separate presidential candidate, we decided that a coalition is impossible at one level if there is competition at another."

Mr Djindjic said Mr Kostu nica's advantage was that he could travel to Montenegro and Kosovo, whereas Mr Milosevic could not.

Montenegro's pro-western authorities have agreed to cooperate with the UN war crimes tribunal. It has indicted Mr Milosevic for war crimes committed by Serb forces last year in Kosovo before Nato bombing forced the withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from the province, which mainly ethnic Albanian .

"Our candidate can go everywhere," Mr Djindjic said. "And where can Mr Milosevic go? To his bunker. Well, let him win in his bunker; we will win in Serbia."

On the right, meanwhile, the ultra-nationalist Radical party has proposed Tomislav Nikolic, its vice-president and Yugoslav deputy prime minister, as its presidential candidate for September. Reuters

Leader comment, page 15


LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


16 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


July 20, 1999, Tuesday


MILOSEVIC CHIEF ATTACKS SPLIT OPPOSITION


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: MISHA SAVIC


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 525 words


Milosevic chief attacks split opposition

Misha Savic

in Belgrade

YUGOSLAV'S top general has labelled increasingly vocal opponents of President Slobodan Milosevic as traitors.

The accusation comes amid growing infighting on the part of opposition leaders seeking to oust Milosevic.

"Those who call for a forceful ouster of the legally elected authorities . . . cannot count on people's support," General Dragoljub Ojdanic, the army chief of staff, said in remarks published on Sunday by the pro-government daily Politika. 

The statement was his first since opposition leaders began organising anti-Milosevic rallies nearly three weeks ago, trying to capitalise on discontent spurred by the country's recent defeat by NATO and de-facto loss of Kosovo province to NATO troops and its ethnic Albanian majority.

Serbs regard Kosovo as the medieval birthplace of their state, though 90 percent of its present population is ethnic Albanian.

"It is the task of us all now to preserve the stability of the country because there are many sold souls, Western vassals, who want to take power by force and take the country into a new catastrophe," Gen Ojdanic said. "But they won't have any support from our people." The general is one of five top officials, including Milosevic, indicted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal for alleged atrocities in Kosovo.

Daily protests against Milosevic and his government have spread over much of Serbia, mostly organised by an opposition coalition known as Alliance for Change. But one prominent opposition politician has stayed out of the mainstream movement and yesterday launched his own, separate push to oust Milosevic.

Vuk Draskovic, head of Serbian Renewal Movement, spoke to a 15,000-strong crowd of supporters in the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, demanding Milosevic's resignation but at the same time distancing himself from other opposition leaders.

While outlining essentially the same demands as the rest of opposition, Mr Draskovic accused the other leaders of radicalism and of risking a civil war in Serbia.

Mr Draskovic has vacillated between alliance with the opposition and co-operation with Milosevic. After leading some of the strongest anti-Milosevic protests in the past, Mr Draskovic briefly served as deputy Yugoslav premier before he was fired for criticising the Government during the Kosovo conflict.

The traditionally fractured opposition in Serbia has failed in several past attempts to topple Milosevic.

Along with weeks of rallies by opposition supporters, there have been scattered protests by army reservists, called up during the 78-day NATO air-strike campaign and the escalated fighting against armed ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. The reservists demand to be paid for their service in Kosovo.

In the southern city of Nis, about 100 reservists demonstrated for a third consecutive day yesterday.

They later decided to suspend their protest and see if the army would deliver on its promise to pay them.

One of their representatives, Miodrag Stankovic, threatened "much more radical protests" if their demands were not met.

Associated Press


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


17 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Age (Melbourne, Australia)


May 1, 1999 Saturday  
Late Edition


The howl of the wolf;
BALKANS WAR - DISSENT


BYLINE: GEOFF KITNEY


SECTION: NEWS EXTRA; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 1600 words


IF HIS face gives the appearance of having been smashed repeatedly into a brick wall this is because it once was, on the orders of the man against whom he has just seriously reoffended. Having already been tortured by Slobodan Milosevic's special police, Vuk Draskovic will be feeling nervous about what retribution he might face this time for his rebelliousness.

Draskovic, the former Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister, has just been sacked by President Milosevic for offences that one hardline member of government described as treasonable. Is he brave or crazy? A bit of both, say those who know him.

Before Draskovic was sacked, NATO leaders saw hope in his conciliatory public statements. They thought Draskovic may be acting as a message carrier from Milosevic, putting out feelers for a political dialogue to resolve the conflict. 

When Milosevic killed this hope by dumping Draskovic they said it showed cracks were beginning to develop in the Serb leadership and that Draskovic's dissent was a symptom of Serbian people's growing weariness with the war.

But if NATO is now waiting to see a dissent movement form around Draskovic, and for this to help speed the end of the war, it is making yet another misjudgment about the internal affairs of Serbia.

"Draskovic's actions have created discussion of issues that were not being discussed previously. But Draskovic is too damaged to be a leader of any dissent movement and NATO's bombing campaign has made Milosevic stronger than he has ever been. I don't believe he is under any serious internal pressure to cave in to NATO's demands," one observer of Belgrade politics said.

The idea of a dissident movement emerging to challenge Milosevic's leadership is attractive to NATO. Without internal pressure there is no reason for Milosevic to negotiate.

The ball is in NATO's court, and, if it is also not prepared to compromise - which it insists it will not - its only option is the military one. And unless it is prepared to mount a ground force invasion - which it also insists it has no intention of doing - it is stuck with no alternative but to continue the air campaign.

But just as NATO's belief that Milosevic would agree to negotiate after the first few bombs fell proved to be wishful thinking so, it seems, is the idea of an internal uprising.

The spotlight that fell this week on Draskovic exposed the opposite of what NATO thought it saw: It revealed just how tragically threadbare are the opposition forces to Slobodan Milosevic in Serbia.

"The disastrous thing about the future outlook for politics in Belgrade is that Vuk Draskovic is probably the best alternative leader available. He is half mad, untrustworthy, has no consistent set of beliefs or objectives and is probably corrupt," said someone who once worked with him.

"I don't believe there is any prospect of Vuk being able to rally the people to challenge Milosevic. He might have been able to do that a few years ago, but he betrayed us and our hopes for democracy." There are a lot of pro-democracy, anti-Milosevic people in Belgrade who blame Draskovic as much as they blame Milosevic for the fact that their country is now at war with the free world.

In 1996, as leader of the largest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Party, Draskovic joined with other opposition figures to form the "Zajedno" (Together) anti-Milosevic coalition. The coalition contested local government elections and won sweeping victories.

Milosevic claimed the election results were rigged and attempted to annul them.

Belgraders took to the streets in protest, and for more than 80 successive days, they staged marches and rallies in the city centre. Crowds of 100,000 and more turned out. Draskovic led and his followers chanted "Vuk, Vuk, Vuk". It was a heady chant - Vuk means wolf in Serbo-Croatian.

But at one of these rallies, one of Draskovic's supporters saw something that dismayed her.

"The students had organised a rally at which they did not want to have any politicians speak. They wanted it to be a statement from the students, not a platform for the politicians to make speeches. Vuk and Danicsa (his wife) arrived. He wanted to speak, but was told this was not possible. Danicsa went crazy. `Who do you think you are stopping my husband speaking? He is much more important than any of you'."

"She told one of his bodyguards to push away the students, who were blocking his way, which they did very roughly, and he got up and spoke. I could see he wasn't really so different to Milosevic and she was like Mira Markovic."

Draskovic's party was committed to free enterprise, Westminster-style democracy, restoration of community values, and to taking Yugoslavia into the European mainstream, including aiming for membership of the European Union.

Draskovic was a monarchist who advocated the return of the Serbian royal family and a nationalist with a deep emotional attachment to Serb culture, but he strongly opposed the militaristic nationalism of Milosevic. This opposition landed him and Danicsa in jail in 1993 at the height of the war in Bosnia.

Both were tortured, and Danicsa was forced to watch as Vuk had his face repeatedly smashed into the wall of his cell. They were freed after they went on a hunger strike. Milosevic had feared they might become martyrs.

Despite its democratic platform, when the party took control of the Studio B television station in Belgrade, Draskovic fired all staff members who were not party supporters. Still, Studio B did become an alternative voice to the propaganda-filled Serbian state media.

The powerful political ambition of Draskovic and his wife that was revealed at the student rally in 1996 set him on a collision course with other key opposition figures who had joined with him to form Zajedno.

He fell out with Zoran Djindjic and Vesna Pesic, the other two most influential pro-democracy politicians, and the coalition fell apart.

The splintering of the opposition allowed Milosevic to play his opponents off against each other. When Milosevic switched from the presidency of Serbia to the presidency of Yugoslavia in 1997, the Opposition squabbled about who should oppose him in the presidential election. Draskovic ran and split the opposition vote, allowing Milosevic to win comfortably.

As Milosevic reasserted his political dominance Draskovic faded from prominence for a while, pursuing instead his other career as a writer. The chain-smoking former hope of the democracy movement turned instead to the security situation in Kosovo. Draskovic shared the prejudices of many Serbs against ethnic Albanians (prejudices reciprocated by the ethnic Albanians). One of his novels, a best-seller, depicts ethnic Albanian Muslims as criminals. He also wrote of the threat posed to Serbia by the population growth of ethnic Albanians and advocated a system of taxes to impose big penalties on couples with more than four children.

Draskovic publicly backed Milosevic's hard line against the ethnic Albanian separatists, a stand which further disillusioned his former supporters. Then in January this year, as NATO intensified it threats to bomb Serbia if Milosevic did not withdraw his forces from Kosovo and make a political deal with the ethnic Albanians giving Kosovo autonomy, Draskovic accepted an offer from Milosevic to join the Government.

He was appointed Deputy Prime Minister, a move that allowed Milosevic to prove Serbs were united behind him on his Kosovo strategy and to use Draskovic's links with the West to give the impression of being willing to maintain a dialogue about the future of Kosovo.

"There is not the slightest doubt that Vuk allowed himself to be used by Milosevic," said one diplomat. "He saw the chance to get the access to power that he had always wanted, decided that Serb solidarity over Kosovo was a good cover for his ambition, and he sold out for it."

So the politician who had been the great hope of Yugoslav democrats went and sat at the same Cabinet table as the brutal dictator who ordered his torture six years earlier and his former mortal political enemy, the ultra-nationalist leader of the Serb Radical Party, Vojislav Seselj. He seemed not to find this too uncomfortable.

I saw him in Belgrade just after the NATO bombing started. He and Danicsa were at one of the daily rallies in the main city square, in the company of the indicted Bosnian war crimes suspect Arkan and his wife.

Perhaps Draskovic's decision this week to warn that Serbia could not win the war with NATO, accuse the state media of lying to the Serb people, and suggest that the leadership would have to accept an armed international peacekeeping force in Kosovo, was an attempt to rescue some of his credibility.

Perhaps he believed he should try to position himself for the opportunities that might develop should Milosevic lead his country to complete collapse and total military defeat.

Given that it is now clear he was not speaking with any authority from Milosevic, and given that there is no evidence of any significant internal dissent, there seems to be no other logical explanation for saying things that virtually guaranteed he would be dismissed and putting himself at real physical risk.

But, the diplomat said, if that was his plan he was as deluded about his ambition as NATO was about his dissenting voice representing a serious challenge to Milosevic.

"There is no future with any of the current party leaders," he said. "The best the people can hope for is that the current crop are swept away by the war and a whole new generation replaces it. Until that happens I think the prospects for the Serb people are going to be bleak."


LOAD-DATE: July 25, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
