Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


July 19, 1999, Monday


KEY RIVAL JOINS ANTI-MILOSEVIC STREET RALLIES


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: DARIA SITO-SUCIC


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 464 words


Key rival joins

anti-Milosevic

street rallies

Daria Sito-Sucic

in Belgrade

KRAGUJEVAC: Thousands of Serbs demonstrated massive support for opposition leader Vuk Draskovic when they turned out yesterday for yet another anti-Milosevic rally.

The rally in Kragujevac, about 120km south of Belgrade, followed a massive protest rally against Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic on Friday.

That rally was organised by a coalition of opposition groups which Mr Draskovic has refused to join. 

Friday's rally, led by by former Belgrade mayor Zoran Djindjic, was also in Kragujevac and attracted about 10,000 people. Yesterday's rally, in the city's central square, was attended by about 15,000.

Mr Draskovic has refused to join forces with Mr Djindjic's coalition, called Alliance for Changes.

Yesterday's rally was the first organised by Mr Draskovic's party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, which had previously rejected street protests as a way to oust Milosevic.

"After all (the) misfortunes that have happened to this nation in the last 10 years, and especially after the Kosovo shame and pain, all reasons order the first man of this state, the President of Yugoslavia, to step down," Mr Draskovic told supporters.

"The SPO wants and demands this resignation."

Few policemen attended the rally, but reporters were stopped and briefly checked by a police patrol on a road leading to the city, which has a population of 170,000.

The rally began with the old Serbian national hymn, God Give Us Justice, sung by a church choir, after which a minute of silence was held "for all those who gave their lives in the latest unfortunate war".

The tribute was followed by protesters shouting: "Slobo, you have betrayed Kosovo", referring to the Belgrade troops' withdrawal and the ensuing Serb exodus.

Protesters waved Serbian and party flags, while a huge placard saying "One for all," with Mr Draskovic's photo, covered the first rows, as some demonstrators carried torches.

The protests came as the United Nations war crimes tribunal's appeals court said it could bring new charges against Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic for his role in Bosnia's 1992-95 war.

"I certainly expect that our ongoing investigations in Kosovo may lead to expanded charges against the persons who are currently indicted," tribunal chief prosecutor Louise Arbour said yesterday at the end of a three-day visit to Bosnia.

Milosevic and four associates already have been indicted for war crimes in Kosovo.

In Pristina, a KFOR spokesman said peacekeeping troops had discovered what appeared to be a mass grave. Thirty bodies were exhumed yesterday by soldiers from the Kosovo Liberation Army in the British sector north-east of Pristina.

Agence France-Presse

Additional reporting Reuters


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML

19 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


July 6, 1992


KING'S MEN HOLD ANTI-MILOSEVIC LINE


BYLINE: YIGAL CHAZAN IN BELGRADE


SECTION: FOREIGN; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 491 words


 

PIONEER PARK in central Belgrade has taken on the appearance of a film set for a low-budget Balkan war movie: men dressed in the uniforms of a king's army idle beside their khaki-coloured tanks, rousing martial music blares out of a loudspeaker and kitsch portraits of the Serbian royal family hang from trees.

For much of the last week, as Belgrade showed its ambivalence about supporting anti-government demonstrations, the 300 monarchists in the park - a mix of Serbian irregulars, peasants and factory workers - never faltered in their determination to see the fall of the authorities.

Most of them support the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) the main force behind Depos, an alliance of opposition parties and political associations calling for Serbia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, to go. 

The Depos rally outside parliament got off to a less than auspicious start eight days ago when only 60,000 people turned out to witness a spectacle of the heir to the Serbian throne and the Orthodox church's patriarch backing the alliance's demands. The organisers had predicted half a million.

With the capital's mood one of resignation, people trickled to the rally over the next few days, leaving speakers with little more than the Pioneer Park royalists as an audience.

But a final SPO rallying call brought 100,000 people - including republicans, nationalists and monarchists - marching through the streets and the procession has been repeated night after night, with new groups joining in.

At the weekend about 500 smartly dressed doctors and nurses headed for Belgrade television, seen as the president's main propaganda tool. Hundreds of heavily armed police, supported by armoured personnel carriers and fire engines with water cannon, waited for orders to intervene should the rally get out of hand.

Sitting outside his tent in Pioneer Park, Dragan Jokic, a student aged 24, from the Serbian copper mining town of Bor, said: "If Slobo doesn't leave, the UN will not lift its sanctions - that will be a disaster for Serbia." He predicted that even those who support the president will start turning against him. "When people haven't enough money to buy food they'll come to Belgrade in their millions."

Mr Milosevic has so far managed to stem discontent outside the capital by guaranteeing that the state will buy this year's harvest at higher than average prices, and ensuring that factory workers sacked because of lost orders continue to receive their pay.

While Depos knows that it has yet to win overwhelming support, it - like Dragan in the park - believes that soon the authorities will be hard pressed to offset the impact of sanctions.

"When the fuel runs out and we don't have enough chemicals to make the water clean for drinking, Milosevic will be in real trouble," said Ilija Radulovic, a senior SPO official. "Once the people start suffering they won't have time for his lies."


LOAD-DATE: May 7, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Guardian Newspapers Limited


20 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Contra Costa Times (California)


August 7, 2000 Monday FINAL EDITION


SERBIAN OPPOSITION FAILS TO UNITE;
THE CHIEF OPPOSITION PARTY IGNORES APPEALS TO SUPPORT
A COMMON CANDIDATE,
WHICH MAY LEAD TO VICTORY
FOR SLOBODAN MILOSEVIC


BYLINE: Aleksandar Vasovic


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A16


LENGTH: 397 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Serbia's largest opposition party Sunday nominated its own candidate to oppose Slobodan Milosevic in September elections, ignoring appeals to rally behind a common standard-bearer and bolstering chances the autocratic president will hold onto power.

The Serbian Renewal Movement nominated Belgrade's opposition mayor, Vojislav Mihailovic, to run for president of Yugoslavia. The movement had previously said it would boycott the Sept. 24 presidential and local elections. 

The country's other opposition groups have said they will support a common candidate to oust Milosevic, and the decision by the larger Serbian Renewal Movement will likely mean a split opposition vote and possibly victory for Milosevic.

In a statement released after a meeting of its ruling board on Sunday, the Serbian Renewal Movement demanded the other anti-Milosevic parties support Mihailovic.

"We hope that those parties will not boycott our presidential candidate, a candidate of the largest opposition party, or nominate someone else just to prevent his victory," the statement said.

The Serb opposition parties had scheduled negotiations for today on the candidate issue but the talks were called off, said Zoran Djinjic of the Democratic Party, the second-largest opposition group.

The rest of the opposition is expected to support Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the small, center-right Democratic Party of Serbia. Kostunica has not agreed yet to run.

Kostunica said Sunday he will accept the candidacy only if the pro-Western administration in Montenegro, which with much larger Serbia forms the Yugoslavian federation, participates in the balloting.

Although the Serbian Renewal Movement plans to take part in presidential and local elections, it has said it would participate in the parliamentary ballot only if the pro-Western Montenegrin parties do.

So far, the government of Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic has refused to take part in the elections, despite pressure from Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

U.S. officials fear Milosevic might use lack of cooperation as a pretext to try to oust Djukanovic and intervene militarily in Montenegro.

If the pro-Western parties abstain, Milosevic's supporters in Montenegro, who make up roughly half of that republic's 600,000 people, could secure a majority in the federal parliament.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP

21 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


October 7, 2000 Saturday  
Late Edition


Serbia's gloomy hero


BYLINE: Timothy Garton Ash, Timothy Garton Ash is a fellow of St Antony's College, Oxford University, and of the Hoover Institution, Stanford University.


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; News Review; Pg. 40


LENGTH: 1133 words


He's possibly even more nationalist than Milosevic, yet Vojislav Kostunica may yet be ...

VOJISLAV Kostunica is one of the gloomiest men I know. This may be an advantage for a new president of whatever remains of Yugoslavia. Even if the miracle happens and Slobodan Milosevic goes without bloodshed, gloom will still be in order.

A "new" Federal Republic of Yugoslavia will have a ruined economy, like Romania after 1989; a burden of guilt, like Germany after 1945; ubiquitous corruption, like Russia today; and still unresolved ethnic-territorial issues, like, well, old Yugoslavia.

Who is the leader upon whom such a heavy burden may fall? A large man, quiet-spoken, painstakingly analytical, Dr Vojislav Kostunica (pronounced Kosh-TOON-it-sa) talks more like an academic than a politician. Until 10 years ago, he was just that a politically engaged constitutional lawyer and political scientist. Now 56, he has been an active party politician only since the age of 45, when non-communist party politics became possible in 1989. 

The first time we met, at the time of the last great anti-Milosevic demonstrations, in 1996-97, he took me to an old-fashioned restaurant in central Belgrade and told me that he really believed in Yugoslavia. The original Yugoslavia, that is, the Serb-dominated unitary kingdom between the two world wars. (His father was an officer in its royal army.)

It was, he said, or should have been, an exercise in British-style nation-building under a constitutional monarchy. Look how the King had given his first son a Serb name, his second a Croatian name and his third a Slovenian one rather as British monarchs deliberately called their heir the Prince of Wales.

Most of the other nationalities of former Yugoslavia would find that a very rose-tinted view. But no, he didn't believe in the restoration of the monarchy. The pretender to the throne, Prince Alexander, barely speaks Serbian, he said. Now he believed in the need for "asymmetric federalism" as a solution for Kosovo, Montenegro and Vojvodina, and perhaps also for the Serb Republic in Bosnia.

And he explained to me at length his plans for the "regionalisation" of Yugoslavia. At rather boring length, I must say.

For Kostunica is a very serious man. Solid. Consistent. Knowledgeable and capable of sophisticated rational argument. Principled, too. But hardly a bundle of fun. Short on charisma. Nor is he a great believer in the politics of the street. That time, he told me how he saw unhappy echoes of 1968 in the street demonstrators cult of spontaneity, their belief in "the movement" as an end in itself.

This is the man whose future, and with it the future of all south-eastern Europe, now depends on his ability to lead a peaceful, inventive, effective movement of mass protest and civil disobedience.

In late 1998, we talked in the office of his tiny opposition party, the Democratic Party of Serbia. His spartan offices seemed virtually empty, as if a removals van was about to arrive. Under the harsh neon light, the talk was all of Kosovo, and how its future inside Serbia must be secured by constitutional, peaceful means. Ordinary, decent Serbians would be dismayed at what Milosevic was doing there, he said. In an election held under supervision of the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, Milosevic could be defeated. Fat chance, I thought.

A year later, after the war and the NATO bombing, which he criticised fiercely, the office seemed even more spartan and bare. Other opposition politicians clearly had plenty of money from somewhere and Belgrade gossip would soon tell you from where but not Serbia's Dr K.

This time, he was furious with the United States, and with Britain. "Blair! Cook!" he spat out the names with contempt.

But, he went on, "I know they are not the West. Fortunately, there is also Simon Jenkins [the London Times columnist who criticised the Kosovo war], Henry Kissinger [whom he clearly took to be another war critic], Noam Chomsky and Harold Pinter!"

So, as our papers say, a "moderate nationalist?" Well, what is a moderate nationalist? Some old Yugoslav hands, shocked by his strong support for the Bosnian and Kosovo Serbs, say he is as bad as Milosevic. Some even say he is more deeply nationalist than the post-communist opportunist Milosevic.

This is both true and completely false. It's true that he has been more seriously and consistently concerned about the fate of the Serbian nation than Milosevic. That is one of the reasons he was purged from Belgrade University in 1974.

In other, happier places and times he would be a conservative, romantic patriot, of the kind frequently encountered in the British Conservative Party (and it has some pretty rose-tinted views of the national past, too). In this unhappy place and time, he has said and done things he should regret: being photographed holding an automatic weapon among Kosovo Serbs, for example.

But I have no doubt that he is genuinely moderate and what matters is his moderation.

The difference between him and Milosevic is that between day and night. This is not just because Kostunica is supported by a coalition of less nationalist democrats. It's because he is himself, in his whole style and intellectual formation, profoundly committed to civilised, peaceful, constitutional means. And one lesson of Europe's terrible 20th century is that the means you embrace are as important as the ends. Perhaps more important.

This is a man who is passionate about the rule of law, who believes in elections, institutions, negotiations. He is also a man who, precisely because he is a Serbian patriot or nationalist sees that the only future for his country lies in a return to Europe. Whether he can become a popular leader of a peaceful, negotiated revolution, we shall see. But human beings can grow with a great challenge.

He made a fine beginning at the post-election victory rally last week. Addressing his "dear, brave fellow citizens, free people", he said: "We are fighting for democracy and democracy is based on truth, not on lies. The truth is that we have won this election."

Mentioning the support of Russia and the European Union but pointedly not the US he promised a country "in which only the will of the people and the law will be sacred". Then he addressed a skilful message to rank-and-file members of Milosevic's Socialist party: "We will not act as did your leaders: we will not hound people who have opposing opinions; we will not burst into other people's houses ... we will not remove the property of the people from the country."

After an equally dignified but conciliatory appeal to the police and army, he concluded, "We will defend the country, we will defend ourselves, because we have freed ourselves."

History makes the most unlikely heroes. Serbia's Dr K may yet be one.


LOAD-DATE: July 24, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

22 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


October 7, 2000 Saturday  
Late Edition


Local Serbs at loggerheads over who backed whom and when


BYLINE: Michelle Grattan


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; International News; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 273 words


As the people's revolution was triumphing in Yugoslavia, Serbs in Australia disputed how anti-Milosevic the local community has been. 

Mr Predrag Vucinic, who says he is the local representative of Mr Vojislav Kostunica's Democratic Party of Serbia, accused Serbs in Australia of failing previously to support the democratic movement.

But Mr George Marinkovic, founder and publisher of The Serbian Voice, a twice-weekly paper distributed throughout Australia, said this was "completely wrong".

Mr Vucinic, who came to Australia eight years ago and now lives in Canberra, said there were about 100,000 Serbs in Australia.

Serbian organisations had often demonstrated against the Western powers and even the Australian Government, but any demonstrations against Milosevic had been very small.

He said that when he had made anti-Milosevic statements on radio while living in Melbourne, many Serbs had called saying, "How can you say such things against our president?"

When he came to Australia, the Democratic party had given him permission to be its representative and try to establish a branch. "But because support was so strong for Milosevic I wasn't able to establish a successful branch here."

He predicted that many Serbs who had backed Milosevic would now try to say they had been supporters of the opposition.

Mr Marinkovic said local Serbs had demonstrated against Milosevic, he being one of them.

The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, yesterday said he would send a message to the Russian President, Mr Vladimir Putin, asking him "to exercise the undoubted influence he has on President Milosevic to urge a peaceful surrender of power and authority".


LOAD-DATE: July 24, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2000 John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd
All Rights Reserved


23 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 19, 1999, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Milosevic digs in as his foes' momentum slips away


BYLINE: Jack Kelley


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A


LENGTH: 913 words


DATELINE: KRAGUJEVAC, Yugoslavia


KRAGUJEVAC, Yugoslavia -- Despite protests and petitions calling
for the ouster of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, there
is a growing sense here that he will not be forced to resign anytime
soon -- if at all.

"It's looking bleaker every day," said Miroslav Djankovic, 44,
an unemployed autoworker. "There's a lot of hype but no clear
answer in sight."

The apathy was evident over the weekend when only 15,000 of the
168,000 people in this southern Serbian city showed up for the
first anti-Milosevic rally by Vuk Draskovic, the charismatic opposition
leader of the Serbian Renewal Party. Up to 50,000 people had been
expected.
 

Other protests in the Serbian cities of Leskovac and Kraljevo
also have fizzled despite repeated calls for large turnouts.

The reasons are clear: Serbia's already fragmented opposition
movement is growing further apart than ever, and Milosevic is
moving quickly to consolidate his power.

"Anyone who thinks this is the beginning of the end needs to
hold his tongue," independent political analyst Predrag Simic
said. "Let's be realistic: The opposition is too weak to take
advantage of the situation, and Milosevic is not going to step
down and feed the pigeons in the park."

To quell rising discontent, Milosevic on Sunday began paying thousands
of Yugoslav army reservists who have been protesting for back
wages. The soldiers, who had been seen by opposition leaders as
key to forcing Milosevic to resign, immediately called off their
demonstrations.

"The opposition movement has just lost its support," Gen. Dragoljub
Ojdanic, the army's chief of staff, said in an interview. "We're
confident now that our soldiers and police do not want to be part
of their civil war for change. They're placid now, and we expect
them to stay that way."

In a clear sign of support for Milosevic, Ojdanic also warned
in public remarks that opposition leaders who demand the president's
ouster are risking a "new catastrophe" and "cannot count on
people's support."

It was Ojdanic's first public statement since opposition leaders
began organizing anti-Milosevic rallies just over two weeks ago.

"It is the task of us all now to preserve the stability of the
country because there are many sold souls, Western vassals, who
want to take power by force and take the country into a new catastrophe.
But they won't have any support from our people," he said.

He appeared to be referring to Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic
and other opposition leaders who have been organizing near-daily
rallies against Milosevic.

Ojdanic also praised his troops for their "great contribution
in defending freedom, honor and dignity of our country in the
recent NATO aggression."

The general is one of five top government officials, including
Milosevic, indicted on war crimes charges by an international
tribunal in connection with atrocities against ethnic Albanians
in Kosovo.

At the same time, Milosevic aides said Sunday that the president
was rewriting election laws that would replace the current proportional
representation system, which tended to favor small opposition
parties, with a new, unspecified program that would favor larger
ones.

To exploit the change, his Socialist Party is expected to link
up with the Yugoslav Left Party headed by Milosevic's wife, Mira
Markovic, and with the Serbian Radical Party of ultra-nationalist
Vojislav Seselj to form a new, larger voting bloc. He then could
call for early elections in October that could shut out opposition
groups that now control many small Serbian towns, Draskovic aides
said.

"Milosevic, although under enormous pressure, intends to fight
for his presidency," Belgrade's VIP News Report quoted
Milosevic aides as saying. "The opposition and the people are
not going to win."

Draskovic, in an apparent attempt to court Milosevic's government,
told protesters this weekend that it was "not necessary" to
call for the Yugoslav president to step down immediately.

Instead, he said a transitional government should be set up under
Milosevic to end economic sanctions against the country. He also
urged protesters to "forgive" and "reconcile" with Milosevic
supporters.

Draskovic, who has shifted his alliances between the opposition
and Milosevic's government, then went on to blast other opposition
leaders in the umbrella group Alliance for Change.

The group, which blames Milosevic for the country's international
isolation and shattered economy, has spearheaded the demonstrations
and petitions across the country that have called for his ouster.
More protests are planned.

"We don't need daily rallies. We don't need petitions. We need
reconciliation," Draskovic told the stunned crowd. "Don't waste
your time with them. It is time to forgive."

Protesters at the weekend rally, many of whom arrived ready to
join a national uprising to oust Milosevic, walked out halfway
through Draskovic's speech, saying they were disillusioned. Several
were crying.

Others across the country echoed similar feelings Sunday. Many
said they no longer would participate in the protests because
it would do little good unless the opposition is united.

"Milosevic can sleep comfortably now," says Svetlana Maslarovic,
31, a Belgrade secretary. "He knows this is the greatest opportunity
we've had to overthrow him, and it looks like we're about to blow
it."


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, b/w, USA TODAY(Map); PHOTO, b/w, Sasa Stankovic, AFP; In Kragujevac: Youths demonstrate against Slobodan Milosevic. The rally Saturday had been expected to draw 50,000 people, but only 15,000 turned out.


Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


24 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 20, 1999, Friday, Late Edition - Final


TENS OF THOUSANDS CALL ON MILOSEVIC TO GIVE UP POWER


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1500 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 19


Tens of thousands of people gathered on a hot night in front of the Federal Parliament to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic, but they heard an extremely mixed set of messages from rival leaders of the democratic opposition here on how to get the job done.

A crowd of at least 50,000 people -- some estimates exceeded 100,000 -- represented the largest anti-Milosevic rally since NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, which forced Belgrade's troops out of Kosovo. 

But the opposition's rivalries and clashing strategies were also on display, with the drama of the night being the effort of Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest party in the opposition, to hijack a rally he had sworn he would not attend.

In a clumsy bit of political fakery booed by many in the crowd, Mr. Draskovic, who had withdrawn his name from the list of speakers, essentially crashed the rally, coming on stage surrounded by bodyguards, in response, he said, to the demands of his supporters in the crowd. His ploy was an almost exact re-creation of a sudden appearance by Mr. Milosevic at a rally on the same spot 10 years ago.

While Mr. Draskovic was almost forced by the size of the turnout to attend, he also criticized many of the ideas of other opposition leaders, saying that early elections under fair conditions were the only sensible way to change Serbia and finally oust Mr. Milosevic.

Mr. Draskovic commands more voters than any other opposition politician, up to 18 percent of the vote in recent polls, more than those who favor the parties of Mr. Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic, combined.

Opposition politicians had been wary of calling a rally in sophisticated Belgrade, where huge street protests against Mr. Milosevic in 1996 and 1997 failed to bring him down. But the numbers tonight were enough to give the opposition a lift, despite its divisions, showing the disgust of many people at their current isolation and poverty.

But the people are also disillusioned by the divisions among opposition leaders, they said, and those were on clear display.

The organizers of the rally -- the Serbian Orthodox Church and Group 17, a confederation of economists and professionals -- are calling for Mr. Milosevic to resign and appoint a transitional Government of experts to serve for a year and then organize new elections.

The leader of the Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, Mr. Draskovic's prime rival, called for Mr. Milosevic and the Government to resign within 15 days or face mass protests.

"If they are still there after 15 days then Serbia will go out into the streets, not only in Belgrade, but in all towns, in 50 towns on the same day," Mr. Djindjic said. "Everybody will go out into the streets with one single message -- we will stay here until you go. It's either Milosevic or Serbia, there can be no third solution. This time we will go to the end."

But Mr. Draskovic heaped scorn on the idea of a transitional government of experts -- "of people no one had heard of a week ago" -- and said that it was clear now that Mr. Milosevic would never agree to it. Mr. Draskovic also scoffed at the idea of a new Government formed in the streets, through civil unrest, saying: "It's dust in the eyes of the people."

Mr. Draskovic called for early elections in November, as Mr. Milosevic's spokesmen are themselves suggesting, in their own effort to divide the opposition, but then urged street pressure to insure early elections if Mr. Milosevic does not grant them. And he called on "all responsible leaders of the opposition" to support his ideas.

One speaker for the Alliance for Change called for a new demonstration in Belgrade on Aug. 28, while another, for the Group 17, called for a new demonstration here on Sept. 21.

Leaving the rally, Zoran Stankovic said: "The only real message is change. It's time for this Government to go." But he said Mr. Milosevic could only benefit "when the opposition leaders speak in so many voices."

One important political leader of the Alliance for Change coalition, Nenad Canak, leader of the League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina, said in an interview: "The rally was fine concerning the number of people and their energy. But it was not O.K. in terms of the absence of vision, of how to focus this energy in a serious way."

As the rally gathered, Government officials continued to float the idea of early Serbian elections, perhaps as early as the first week of November, creating further divisions among the opposition.

The Alliance for Change is not ready for elections and not especially eager for them, so the Government would be calling their bluff. Mr. Draskovic, however, favors early elections to capitalize on better polling numbers.

But new elections would not affect the position of Mr. Milosevic, whose single, four-year term as Yugoslav President runs through July 2001. While the opposition is calling for his resignation or removal, early elections may divert the population from that goal.

Normally elections for the Serbian parliament and municipalities would take place in 2001, while federal parliamentary elections would take place in 2000.

It would be difficult for the self-styled "democratic opposition" to oppose new elections, though its leaders would like any vote to be supervised by outside observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and would also like to see freer, more open news media, especially television.

"Elections are the best way to sober political drunks," Mr. Milosevic's party spokesman, Ivica Dacic, said today. "Our stand is that there are many more important things than elections. But if the other political parties say elections are necessary we are ready to go to elections. But they want to come to power without elections."

Vojislav Seselj, leader of the ultranationalist Radical Party that now helps rule both Serbia and Yugoslavia, said separately today that he favored early elections to resolve Serbia's post-Kosovo troubles. He said there was no agreement with other ruling parties to call them but there was a deal to hold them if the opposition wanted them.

"We are even going so far as to say, 'Let the opposition parties name a date for the elections and we will call them,' " he said. Mr. Seselj then, impishly, suggested that local elections come first -- since the opposition has its only power base in cities across Serbia won in local elections in 1996.

They took their seats only after street protests against election fraud forced Mr. Milosevic to back down -- while saving his own seat, of course.

Mr. Draskovic's power base is the city of Belgrade, with its powerful television station, Studio B. His rivals believe that he would do almost anything to retain the station.

So to divide the opposition further, Government officials leaked a story that Mr. Draskovic had met Mr. Milosevic secretly on Monday to discuss early elections and to agree not to speak at the rally. Mr. Draskovic angrily denied the entire story, as did his top aides, one of whom said "it would be idiotic" to have had such a meeting.

Draskovic aides suggested that the leak was from Mr. Djindjic. Whatever the truth, the leak succeeded in further poisoning the relationship, if that were possible, between Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Djindjic.

"Milosevic is a master political tactician," said one senior Alliance official sadly. "He's great at changing the subject and buying time."

Even so, early elections are a serious risk for Mr. Milosevic. The Government, whose support is weak after the loss of Kosovo, could lose its majority in the Serbian parliament if the opposition could ever mount a united, professional campaign. And there is reliably said to be a debate inside the Government about the wisdom of early elections.

Some senior Government officials expressed confidence privately today that they would win a majority or could create one, despite all their problems, while some senior opposition officials also believe, with despair, that Mr. Milosevic, his wife and Mr. Seselj could retain power in a coalition.

Waiting longer, until winter bites hard and the country is inevitably short of heat and electricity due to inefficiency, sanctions and NATO air strikes, could only harm the Government's standing.

The Government had made various efforts, both subtle and crude, to cut down the size of the rally. On Wednesday night, state television announced the arrest of a Montenegrin man possessing "a highly explosive device" with a timer and warned of other possible bombing attacks at "massive public gatherings," urging caution on citizens and on parents.

The Government ordered the payment of overdue pensions for today and moved the televising of a popular lottery program from Saturday night to tonight.

But the police did not interfere with what was a peaceful rally and were not much in evidence, though riot police were stationed in buildings should they have been needed.

  

http://www.nytimes.com

A1); Vuk Draskovic spoke at a rally he had sworn he would not attend. Tens of thousands attended an anti-Milosevic rally in Belgrade. Crowds urged Mr. Milosevic to resign and appoint a transitional Government. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)(pg. A10)

25 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


August 13, 1999, Friday


Milosevic consolidates power base in reshuffle


BYLINE: Eve-Ann Prentice


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 431 words


 

Belgrade keeps the hardliners, says Eve-Ann Prentice

Slobodan Milosevic bolstered the power of hard-liners in Yugoslavia yesterday in a government reshuffle, which came one week before a planned anti government rally in Belgrade.

It was said that President Milosevic had hoped to bring in politicians from across the board in an attempt to persuade the West that the new regime would be more democratic.

However, after six weeks of talks, opposition parties such as the Serbian Renewal Movement, led by Vuk Draskovic, have rejected an invitation to join the new Government. Instead, extra power has been given to the Serbian Radical Party, which is headed by the ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj, and the Yugoslav United Left, led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. Mr Seselj had vowed to leave the Government after Nato troops entered Kosovo in June. 

The new Government comes as plans are being finalised for what is expected to be a large anti-Milosevic protest in Belgrade next Thursday. The rally is being supported by the Serbian Orthodox Church, which this week renewed calls for the Yugoslav President's resignation, and by both main opposition groups, the Serbian Renewal Movement and the Alliance for Change.

One casualty of the reshuffle was Zoran Lilic, a Deputy Prime Minister and the Yugoslav President before Mr Milosevic took over the position two years ago.

The reshuffle was seen as a move by Mr Milosevic to reinforce his power base in the face of the growing demands for his resignation. Seven ministers were dismissed and twelve brought in, including five members of the Radical Party. All the new ministers, including those with the task of dealing with the outside world, are on a European Union list of more than 300 senior officials and businessmen barred from travelling to the West, as were the ministers they replace.

Mr Milosevic yesterday addressed the new Government, saying: "Our aim is to continue successfully with the process of current reforms, contribute to an accelerated pace of economic development and increase productivity and living standards." It had the opportunity of taking "some effective and brave steps" in the interest of all the population.

The Democratic Party described the new Government as "nothing new and nothing good". It added: "By this move, the regime has sent two messages. To the world it is saying: 'Forget about any co-operation with Yugoslavia.' And to its citizens it is saying they are facing a difficult winter and further impoverishment without heating and electricity."


LOAD-DATE: August 20, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Times Newspapers Limited


26 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 12, 1999, Monday, Late Edition - Final


U.S. Finds No One to Back Among Milosevic's Foes


BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 


SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1202 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11


Despite its clear desire to see President Slobodan Milosevic ousted, the Clinton Administration is finding it difficult to capitalize on the opportunity presented by the opposition protests that have bubbled up across Serbia.

The question of new leadership in Serbia is as troubling as it is important, not only because Mr. Milosevic has been indicted on charges of war crimes, Administration officials said, but also because without the participation of Serbia, it will be hard to build a stable Balkans. 

But for the moment, a wait-and-see attitude prevails in Washington, even though the Clinton Administration has made clear that it considers Mr. Milosevic an international outlaw who should be brought to justice.

The main problem, Administration officials acknowledge, is that they are wary of the current slate of opposition leaders who might succeed Mr. Milosevic.

Even if the Administration had a favorite, they concede, its ability to advance that person decisively is limited. Further, after 11 weeks of NATO bombing, even tacit support from Washington might only taint a successor's standing with the Serbian public.

Thus Administration officials say they are being careful not to back anyone in particular, and have instead decided to stick with their policy of simply trying to isolate Mr. Milosevic and generate hardship for his powerful circle of cronies.

The officials said they were disillusioned with the leaders who galvanized crowds in Belgrade against Mr. Milosevic in the winter of 1996-97.

One official said the Administration has written off as an "opportunist" Vuk Draskovic, one of the leaders of the 1996 street demonstrations, who then joined Mr. Milosevic in government and is now out of the government again.

Another leader of that period, Zoran Djindjic, who remained in opposition and hid in Montenegro during the Kosovo war, is not favored by Washington either, said a senior Administration official involved in trying to find some cohesion in the emerging anti-Milosevic movement. Officials say they believe that Mr. Djindjic lacks the necessary support and leadership skills to propel the movement forward.

"We shouldn't pick a winner," this official said, as he left for Europe with plans to meet some anti-Milosevic activists, whom he refused to identify. "The Europeans are making a dramatic mistake by picking Djindjic as their poster boy. He has very little support. We should let the people pick a winner."

In trying to foster an opposition to Mr. Milosevic, the Administration faces tough hurdles, some of which are an outgrowth of having just waged a war against Yugoslavia.

The United States no longer has an embassy in Belgrade, and has no plans for one, according to the State Department. This makes contact with opposition-party mayors in towns where the protests have sprung up almost impossible. Even with an embassy in 1996, American officials had trouble forging links to the opposition.

A still tougher hurdle is the unusual nature of the Milosevic regime. "Mr. Milosevic is an ultra-nationalist," said James R. Hooper, executive director of the Balkan Action Council, an independent group specializing in Balkans policy. "He's not a Communist like those in Eastern Europe who were held in power by the Soviet Union."

"Here the roots go very deep," he added. "Lots of Serbs have given real or passive support. There have been few regimes like this before."

The closest similarity could be made with fascist Italy or Nazi Germany, Mr. Hooper said.

Another uncertainty is the Yugoslav Army. Mr. Milosevic has repeatedly purged its ranks, leaving his ciphers at the top. But historically, the army has been a proud institution.

Disgruntled army reservists, talking darkly about the war in Kosovo and bitter about their lack of pay, took part in some of anti-Milosevic rallies last week, particularly in Leskovac, a longtime stronghold of the Yugoslav leader.

But what practical effect their participation would have in the coming months was difficult to judge. "The Yugoslav Army does not have a history of coups," a senior Administration official said.

The tactic most favored for encouraging the unrest appears to be isolating the Belgrade Government. With a little pressure here, a little pressure there, the hope is that Mr. Milosevic will asphyxiate.

The Administration is beginning to discuss how to help out some areas of Serbia where opposition party mayors are in power. Reconstruction aid has been ruled out for Serbia but humanitarian aid will be considered, President Clinton has said.

One way to make humanitarian aid set an example against Mr. Milosevic would be to organize the restoration of power at a hospital in a municipality where the opposition is in control, officials said.

Another isolation tactic is of symbolic importance. Much of Mr. Milosevic's standing with his own people was bolstered by the continual bustle of international figures who came to visit him, often on "last ditch" missions to warn against his policies, which would then be transformed on Serbian television into spectacles aggrandizing Mr. Milosevic.

Now, those visits have dried up. And he, his family and his inner circle are marooned inside Serbia. Mr. Milosevic rarely traveled anyway, but now there are few places he can go, without being arrested.

Of personal annoyance to his tight-knit family -- consisting of Mr. Milosevic, his wife, Mirjana Markovic, their son, Marko, daughter in law, Milica, and daughter, Marija -- was the recent refusal by the Greek Embassy in Belgrade to grant Marko Milosevic a visa for travel to Greece.

According to accounts in Belgrade, the young Mr. Milosevic, who carries a diplomatic passport, applied for a visa to Greece after the Kosovo war. After about 10 days, according to one account, the Greek Embassy returned the passport without explanation and without a visa.

About 300 of Mr. Milosevic's cronies, most of whom hold sizable bank accounts and property holdings abroad, are on a visa ban list created by the European Union before the NATO air strikes. Some of these people, including Bogoljub Karic, the owner of Serbian banks and a television station that toes the Milosevic political line, are getting restless.

Mr. Karic is reported to have been turned back at the Serbian border with Hungary and is known to be complaining around Belgrade that he is unable to tend to his investments in London.

Alongside its isolation strategy, the Administration is also trying to provide the Serbian opposition with some encouragement and role models for behavior. Mr. Clinton intends at the end of the month to attend a one-day jamboree planned for Sarajevo of 30 Western European and Balkan leaders.

It will be a day, Administration officials predict, of grand proclamations of a new dawn for the Balkans.

Absent there will be Slobodan Milosevic. Present will be Milo Djukanovic, President of Montenegro, the second-largest republic in Yugoslavia. It was Mr. Djukanovic who broke with Mr. Milosevic two years ago and received moral and financial support during the Kosovo war.

These days, he is the State Department's model of an opposition leader.        

http://www.nytimes.com

The Independent (London)


January 10, 2000, Monday


DRASKOVIC ACCUSED OF SPYING FOR FRANCE


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 12


LENGTH: 273 words


 

THE YUGOSLAV government has accused the opposition leader Vuk Draskovic of being a French spy and of wanting civil war. As Mr Draskovic prepared to host a strategy meeting for opponents of President Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav Information Minister, Goran Matic, also claimed that he was merely a puppet of the US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright. 

"Draskovic had several talks with the French intelligence service where he asked for money ... and in 1999 offered himself to co-operate with any foreign service for an adequate amount of money, ready to do what they expect from him," Mr Matic said. "We should not be surprised if the ... meeting brings an initiative to offer Nato a partnership. This would pardon the commanders and executors of the crimes committed during the aggression against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia." Mr Draskovic'saide, Predrag Simic, dismissed the allegations as "scandalous" and aimed at undermining today's meeting.

"The government is trying to divert attention from all the tragedies and disasters in our country for which they are responsible," he said.

Mr Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), is to lead 16 major opposition parties and groups, including the Alliance for Change, at the gathering, which will discuss how to force Mr Milosevic to call early elections.

SPO officials do not exclude the possibility of calling for joint mass protests, a strategy the party did not support when the Alliance started anti -Milosevic rallies last year. A spokesman for SPO, Ivan Kovacevic, said: "The time has come now for all forms of battle against the regime."

28 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 3, 2000, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Milosevic's grip on power not likely to loosen Opposition has little hope that elections will be fair


BYLINE: David J. Lynch


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9A


LENGTH: 1044 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- His usually quarrelsome political opponents
are uniting against him. There's even tantalizing talk of a U.S.-brokered
deal that could send him into exile.

But a little more than one year after NATO's war with Yugoslavia,
President Slobodan Milosevic's grip on power is as strong as ever.

He may have led his nation into three losing wars and earned indictment
as a war criminal, but Milosevic also has demonstrated an uncanny
instinct for political survival.
 

"After NATO airstrikes, Milosevic was weak and ready to fall,
but the opposition wasn't ready," political commentator Bratislav
Grubacic says. "Milosevic doesn't have a single idea to step
down. He is under no pressure internally."

At one level, Yugoslavia is little changed from before the war.
Electricity supplies have returned to normal. The cafes along
Belgrade's main pedestrian boulevard are full, and McDonald's
has even added a franchise to its local outlets.

That doesn't mean the Yugoslav leader lacks political problems.
Analysts say a student-led resistance movement called Otpor seems
especially to have spooked the regime. Likewise, polling by the
Medijum agency over the past year showed that 51%-59% of Serbs
want Milosevic to resign.

In a May survey, 62% of those queried said Serbia, which with
Montenegro makes up the Yugoslav federation, is heading in the
wrong direction.

It's not difficult to see why. Persistent gasoline shortages mean
that cars wait routinely in three-block-long lines to fill up
at the Jugopetrol filling station in the Novi Belgrade neighborhood.
Young people at soccer games serenade one another with chants
of "Slobo, save Serbia and kill yourself." Goran Pitic, a prominent
economist, reckons that after a decade of warfare and political
turmoil, it will take Yugoslavia perhaps two decades to build
its economic output back to what it was in 1989.

Reminders of the NATO-Yugoslavia war over the separatist province
of Kosovo linger in the devastated government buildings downtown
along Kneza Milosa, which locals have nicknamed the "street of
death."

Yugoslav Information Minister Goran Matic scoffs at the polls
as "foolish." He adds, "We'll see in the election."

This fall, Yugoslavia is scheduled to hold elections for municipal
and federal parliamentary offices. Opposition figures worry that
with the United States preoccupied by a presidential campaign,
Milosevic might crack down on dissent without fear of strong U.S.
response.

Prospects for a fair election are further clouded by:

* A proposed "anti-terrorism" law that would allow the
police to jail individuals for up to 30 days before charging them
with a crime.

* Ongoing strategy disputes within the habitually querulous
opposition.

* Indications that Montenegro's government, long at odds
with Milosevic, might boycott the parliamentary contests.

Several opposition parties are running on a united electoral ticket,
which enjoys a solid lead over Milosevic's ruling coalition in
major polls.

However, the largest single opposition party, the Serbian Renewal
Movement, which has about 10% support, has quit the ticket.

There is a widespread assumption that the real showdown won't
come until next year's elections for Serbian republic offices.

Vuk Draskovic, the Serbian Renewal Movement's charismatic leader,
says a fair political contest is impossible. The Yugoslav president
has tightened controls on universities and the independent press.
Milosevic wants to use rigged elections to legitimize his rule,
according to Draskovic.

A major opposition worry is the proposed anti-terrorism law, which
the regime says is needed to battle anti-Milosevic violence such
as the recent shootings of prominent political figures. Opposition
leaders say the measure's expansive police powers and broad definition
of "terrorism" could herald the rise of a police state.

Milan Protic, a U.S.-educated academic leading a small anti-Milosevic
party, says the opposition must contest the elections. "We are
limited to the democratic path," Protic says. "We can't get
into a power struggle; we do not have any power."

The political skirmishing is accompanied by a striking fatalism
on the opposition's part. With the prospect of being turned over
by his successor to war crimes prosecutors at the Hague, Netherlands,
almost no one thinks Milosevic can be dislodged peacefully:

* "There is absolutely no theoretical possibility that
Milosevic will lose power through elections," says Predrag Simic,
an adviser for Draskovic.

* "I can't imagine a normal way for him to go," says
Dragan Soc, Montenegro's justice minister. "He closed every door
for a peaceful solution. . . . My impression is his decision
is to rule even if the cost is his life."

* "I don't have any illusion that we can get rid of Milosevic
without casualties," says Cedomir Jovanovic of the Democratic
Party of Serbia.

Those who favor a regime change concede they essentially are waiting
for a military coup or a deal that would send Milosevic and his
powerful wife, Mira, into exile in return for immunity from war-crimes
prosecution.

Matic denounces such talk as "ridiculous propaganda . . .
clearly stupid." Officially, Washington says it won't bargain
with an indicted war criminal.

Milosevic and his opponents agree on one point: Both want to see
the U.S. policy of isolating Yugoslavia scrapped. A travel ban
keeps the regime's government and private supporters penned inside
Serbia. Financial sanctions bar Yugoslavia from accessing international
credit markets.

Some democracy activists say that by strangling the economy, sanctions
have eviscerated the pro-democracy middle-class and given Milosevic
an excuse for the many hardships of daily life.

Milosevic, meanwhile, is said to believe that any new U.S. administration
might rethink its Balkans policy.

"The (next) American administration -- it doesn't matter which
(political party) -- can't have a worse policy than this one,"
Matic says. "They bombed us for three months, eight years of
sanctions, made Nazis out of Serbs. What else can they do? Just
throw the atomic bomb?"


LOAD-DATE: July 03, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, B/W, USA TODAY (Map); PHOTO, B/W, Milos Bicanski, AFP; Pro-Slobo: A supporter of Slobodan Milosevic holds up a photo of the Yugoslav president during a rally June 7 in Podgorica, Montenegro.

29 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


July 19, 1999, Monday


KEY RIVAL JOINS ANTI-MILOSEVIC STREET RALLIES


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: DARIA SITO-SUCIC


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 469 words


Key rival joins

anti-Milosevic

street rallies

Daria Sito-Sucic

in Belgrade

KRAGUJEVAC: Thousands of Serbs demonstrated massive support for opposition leader Vuk Draskovic when they turned out yesterday for yet another anti-Milosevic rally.

The rally in Kragujevac, about 120km south of Belgrade, followed a huge protest rally against Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic on Friday.

That rally was organised by a coalition of opposition groups which Mr Draskovic has refused to join. 

Friday's rally, led by by former Belgrade mayor Zoran Djindjic, was also in Kragujevac and attracted about 10,000 people. Yesterday's rally, in the city's central square, was attended by about 15,000.

Mr Draskovic has refused to join forces with Mr Djindjic's coalition, called Alliance for Changes.

Yesterday's rally was the first organised by Mr Draskovic's party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, which had previously rejected street protests as a way to oust Milosevic.

"After all (the) misfortunes that have happened to this nation in the past 10 years, and especially after the Kosovo shame and pain, all reasons order the first man of this state, the President of Yugoslavia, to step down," Mr Draskovic told supporters. "The SPO wants and demands this resignation."

Few policemen attended the rally, but reporters were stopped and briefly checked by a police patrol on a road leading to the city, which has a population of 170,000.

In a clear sign of support for Milosevic, the head of the Yugoslav army warned in remarks published yesterday that opposition leaders who demanded the President's ouster were risking a "new catastrophe" and "cannot count on people's support".

The statement by General Dragoljub Ojdanic, the army's chief of staff, was his first since opposition leaders began organising anti-Milosevic rallies.

The general is one of five top government officials, including Milosevic, indicted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal in connection with atrocities against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

The protests came as the United Nations war crimes tribunal's appeals court said it could bring new charges against Milosevic for his role in Bosnia's 1992-95 war.

"I certainly expect that our ongoing investigations in Kosovo may lead to expanded charges against the persons who are currently indicted," tribunal chief prosecutor Louise Arbour said yesterday at the end of a three-day visit to Bosnia.

Milosevic and four associates already have been indicted for war crimes in Kosovo.

In Pristina, a KFOR spokesman said peacekeeping troops had discovered what appeared to be a mass grave. Thirty bodies were exhumed yesterday by soldiers from the Kosovo Liberation Army in the British sector north-east of Pristina.

Agence France-Presse

Additional reporting Reuters, AP


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


30 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


April 12, 1999, Monday, Final Edition


NATO Bombing Campaign Wounds Milosevic's Political Enemies


Michael Dobbs, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A19


LENGTH: 951 words


DATELINE: PANCEVO, Yugoslavia


 

Srdjan Mirkovic, a 39-year-old lawyer and democracy activist, was sworn in as mayor of this run-down industrial city in February 1997 as the result of a nationwide street uprising against Slobodan Milosevic, who was then president of Serbia. Every day for nearly three months, he had joined thousands of people in the streets of Pancevo, shouting anti-Milosevic slogans and accusing his government of election fraud.

Similar scenes took place all across Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic, after Milosevic supporters reacted to opposition election victories in dozens of towns and municipalities by announcing "corrected" results that kept power in the hands of the ruling Serbian Socialist Party. The street protests received worldwide coverage and were widely seen as a key moment in Yugoslavia's tortured transition from Communist dictatorship to a free-market democracy. 

Now, two years after he led the anti-Milosevic protests here, Mirkovic is organizing his fellow citizens to defend themselves in the event of NATO bombing attacks. The turbulent events of the winter of 1996-97 and the euphoria that swept Pancevo when it became clear that Milosevic had been forced to back down have been all but forgotten as residents focus their attention on a new enemy.

"Anybody in their right mind has to be against the bombing of our cities," Mirkovic said. "The longer this bombing continues, the stronger Milosevic becomes and the weaker the position of the political opposition."

Pancevo -- a city of 120,000 people that was a frontier post for the Austro-Hungarian Empire across the Danube River from Belgrade -- has been targeted by NATO bombs several times over the past two weeks. Targets have included a fertilizer factory, a light-aircraft plant and an important oil refinery, all situated close to residential areas. Local people say that two Pancevo residents -- 50-year-old Dusko Bogosavljev and 30-year-old Mirko Dimitrevic -- were killed during the attack on the refinery.

The deaths cast a pall over Pancevo. Mirkovic canceled nightly concerts he had organized to rally the population against the NATO attacks, and he is now advising residents to leave if they feel afraid. At the same time, he is warning of an "ecological catastrophe" if NATO bombs hit one of the large stockpiles of dangerous chemicals stored near the city.

Pancevo residents' nerves have been rattled further by a number of recent NATO bombing accidents, including one that heavily damaged the town of Aleksinac in central Serbia last Monday, killing at least 10 people. "That's the kind of mistake we are afraid of," said the mayor. "A similar mistake here could cause thousands of casualties."

Preoccupied with their own problems, few people here seem to have much time for the agony of the ethnic Albanian refugees who have fled Kosovo or gone into hiding in the mountains since the NATO airstrikes began on March 24. They have been driven from their homes by Serb-led army, police and paramilitary forces who seem determined to alter forever the ethnic makeup of Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians had outnumbered Serbs 9 to 1. The official news media here have depicted the exodus as being caused by the NATO bombing.

Even Pancevo residents with access to Western satellite channels, such as CNN and Britain's Sky News, cannot bring themselves to condemn their own government. The televised scenes of refugees fleeing Kosovo are "dreadful," said Snazena Sokolovic, who works at the oil refinery as a translator and was raised in Kosovo. She contended, however, that the situation there deteriorated sharply after NATO began its air offensive. "NATO is following a strange kind of logic," she said, "they say they want to stop the killing, but you don't stop killing by killing."

The ruling anti-Milosevic coalition in Pancevo has a 37-28 majority on the city council. But Mirkovic and other democracy activists fear their position will be much weakened if the war ends with a tightening of Yugoslavia's international isolation.

The world's preoccupation with the plight of the Kosovo refugees strikes many Pancevo residents as hypocritical, given the fact that much less world attention was paid a quarter-million ethnic Serbs when a Croatian army offensive drove them from the Krajina region of Croatia in the summer of 1995.

"Nobody is talking about the Serbian refugees from Croatia and Bosnia," said a Belgrade radio journalist who gave his name only as Dragan. "They are just talking about Albanian refugees; it is disgusting."

For now at least, anti-Milosevic forces in Pancevo have managed to remain relatively united. Mirkovic is a member of a moderately nationalist, republic-wide party known as the Serbian Renewal Movement, which governs here in a coalition with the pro-Western Democratic Party of Serbia. Across the republic, the political alliance that forced Milosevic to recognize the results of the local elections in Pancevo and other towns fell apart a few months later.

The leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, Vuk Draskovic, has now joined forces with Milosevic and was appointed a deputy prime minister in January. His longtime political rival, Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic, remains in opposition, but his standing has been severely undermined by the NATO offensive.

"The biggest loser in this war is my party," said Djindjic, who became mayor of Belgrade thanks to the opposition victory two years ago but was forced to resign within six months after a quarrel with Draskovic. "Our entire political identity is closely tied to Europe and America. For most people here, Europe has become identical with NATO, which is identical with bombs."


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)


August 8, 2000 Tuesday


3 CANDIDATES OPPOSE MILOSEVIC


SECTION: MAIN; Pg. 6A


LENGTH: 98 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


One day after the Serbian Renewal Movement put forward Belgrade Mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic, a coalition opposed to President Slobodan Milosevic nominated its own presidential candidate Monday. Most of Serbia's opposition parties joined in the endorsement of Vojislav Kostunica of the small center-right Serbian Democratic Party. "I said yes because of the public," Kostunica, 56, said after the nomination. "It's my moral duty to the opposition, and not my wish." The third anti-Milosevic candidate is Tomislav Nikolic of the Serbian Radical Party. The election is slated Sept. 24.

The Independent (London)


November 2, 2004, Tuesday


AFTER GEORGIA, A NEW TARGET FOR SERBIA'S STUDENT ACTIVISTS


BYLINE: VESNA PERIC ZIMONJIC IN BELGRADE An Otpor (Resistance) protester near Belgrade


SECTION: First Edition; FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 21


LENGTH: 238 words


 

THEY TOPPLED Slobodan Milosevic with mass demonstrations four years ago and helped in the downfall last year of the Georgian autocrat Eduard Shevardnadze.

Now, the hardliners in Ukraine are the latest target of the Serb student movement intent on exporting non-violent revolution. The Centre for Non-Violent Resistance, based in Belgrade, has been training activists in Ukraine who want to overthrow their own autocrats. It grew out of Otpor (Resistance) a pro-democracy, anti- Milosevic movement. "There's no exact recipe on how to export a revolution, but there are ways to help people who want changes," said Danijela Nenadic, a co-ordinator for the centre.

Ukraine faces isolation and falling living standards and all the wealth is concentrated in the hands of people close to President Leonid Kuchma, activists say. "The grievances of people in Ukraine were similar to ours four years ago," Ms Nenadic added.

Former Otpor activists acted as advisers in Georgia last year. They worked in Belarus as well, but are now banned from the country.

"We receive many calls from similar organisations as Otpor that want change of regime, but don't have the clear vision on how to do it," Sinisa Sikman, a trainer said. "We help them, but we insist on non-violent means." Last month, Ukraine barred Aleksandar Maric, a member of the centre and an adviser with the US-based democracy watchdog Freedom House.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 2004


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2004 Independent Print Ltd

The Independent (London)


November 2, 2004, Tuesday


THIRD TARGET FOR SERB REVOLUTIONARIES


BYLINE: VESNA PERIC ZIMONJIC IN BELGRADE Otpor members protest against the Yugoslav government in Belgrade AP


SECTION: Final Edition; FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 21


LENGTH: 177 words


 

THEY TOPPLED Slobodan Milosevic with mass demonstrations four years ago and helped in the downfall last year of the Georgian autocrat Eduard Shevardnadze.

Now, the hardliners in Ukraine are the latest target of the Serb student movement intent on exporting non-violent revolution. The Centre for Non-Violent Resistance, based in Belgrade, has been training activists in Ukraine who want to overthrow their own autocrats. It grew out of Otpor (Resistance) a pro-democracy, anti-Milosevic movement. "There's no exact recipe on how to export a revolution, but there are ways to help people who want changes," said Danijela Nenadic, a co-ordinator for the centre.

Ukraine faces isolation and falling living standards, and wealth is concentrated in the hands of people close to President Leonid Kuchma, activists say. "The grievances of people in Ukraine were similar to ours four years ago," Ms Nenadic added.

Last month, Ukraine barred Aleksandar Maric, a member of the centre and an adviser with the US-based democracy watchdog Freedom House.

34 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


July 13, 1999, FINAL


Opposition protesters clash with police


SECTION: News; A9


LENGTH: 175 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Protests around Serbia gained momentum yesterday, with some 7,000 protesters turning out in one western town to demand Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's resignation.

Anti-Milosevic activists appeared to get another boost when the Serbian Renewal Party of Vuk Draskovic said his party would begin street rallies in Serbia, the dominant republic of Yugoslavia. 

Mr. Draskovic, one of Serbia's best known opposition figures, had earlier said he preferred to go his own way and not join other opposition groups, a sign of the divisions that have hurt anti- Milosevic movements in the past.

He said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp., however, that he would hold his first rally Saturday in the central Serbian town of Kragujevac.

In Valjevo, 72 kilometres west of the capital, Belgrade, protesters broke through a glass door and briefly occupied part of the city administration building. Police arrived and there was some scuffling as they pushed the demonstrators out of the building.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.
