35 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 14, 1999, Wednesday, Final Edition


Key Figure Joins Drive To Topple Milosevic


William Booth, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 994 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, July 13


 

After sitting on the sidelines for weeks, Serbia's most powerful opposition leader, the charismatic and bombastic Vuk Draskovic, called on his supporters today to join him in "massive rallies all over Serbia" as part of the growing movement to force Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic from office.

The public pressure on Milosevic -- which has been building since he agreed last month to withdraw Serb-led government forces from Kosovo and let NATO peacekeepers in -- is entering a new, potentially explosive stage. Opposition figures are warning darkly of a possible bloody showdown or civil war, just as Milosevic's allies are heightening their rhetoric, calling government opponents and some media figures spies, traitors and lackeys of the CIA.

Draskovic, the self-styled "czar of the streets," who drew tens of thousands of people into central Belgrade 2 1/2 years ago to demonstrate against the Milosevic government, had avoided overtly supporting protest rallies led by other opposition figures in several Serbian towns and cities over the past two weeks. 

He said today that the wait-and-see period is over and that he is prepared to confront the Milosevic government with huge street protests beginning Saturday in the central city of Kragujevac.

Draskovic's participation adds a new dimension to the anti-Milosevic drive. His Serbian Renewal Movement, the second-largest party in Serbia after Milosevic's Socialist Party, controls the city government of Belgrade and, perhaps most importantly, operates an influential television station called Studio B.

In this tightly controlled society, a television station can be a crucial tool of repression or of revolution. Thus far, Studio B -- like the pro-Milosevic state-run television stations -- has provided little or no coverage of demonstrations organized by other opposition leaders, but it is expected to cover Draskovic's first rally in great and sympathetic detail. Since no other opposition figure has control of a television station, the broadcast propaganda war will be fought by only two combatants, Draskovic and Milosevic.

In the weeks before, during and immediately after the NATO bombardment of Yugoslavia, Draskovic offered mixed signals of his political intentions. He had served for a time as a deputy premier in the Milosevic government and was critical of the NATO air campaign, but he was forced to resign after declaring publicly that Milosevic had lied to the nation by claiming that government forces were winning the war in Kosovo, a province of Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic.

In an interview today, Draskovic vowed not to repeat his mistakes of years past, when he spoke in romantic terms of a return of the Serbian monarchy -- not to rule, but as a symbol of the state. This time, he said, he is going after the votes and voices not only of his core supporters, but also of those Serbs who have supported Milosevic.

Unlike other opposition leaders, Draskovic asserted that it is not productive to threaten Milosevic and his inner circle with arrest for alleged war crimes against ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo. He said that talking about revenge and arrests was a way to lose potential supporters who have sided with Milosevic and supported his nationalist policies for the past 10 years.

By calling for anti-government demonstrations, however, Draskovic is moving toward open conflict with the Yugoslav leader -- a maneuver that could backfire if Milosevic and his government were to respond by attempting to strip his party of power in Belgrade or to seize control of its television station.

Moreover, any effort to topple Milosevic could be handicapped by continued squabbling among opposition leaders. A ready illustration of this is the fact that the leader of the opposition Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, has also called for an anti-government demonstration in Kragujevac -- on the day before the Draskovic rally.

Even as they seek to play down their differences, Draskovic and Djindjic took shots at each other in separate interviews today. Djindjic said, nonetheless, that his party, along with other opposition groups, plans to stage up to 20 protest rallies around Serbia in coming weeks, culminating in a mass rally in Belgrade in August. Draskovic's plans also include large-scale street demonstrations in Belgrade.

Djindjic acknowledged that the public mistrusts all politicians and parties and simply wants someone to lead them toward change. "What we have had this last 10 years," Djindjic said, referring to a decade of Milosevic's rule in Serbia and Yugoslavia, "is a kind of sick political life. What the people want now most is something fresh, something that says, okay, here is the first step, and we will figure out the rest as we go."

In Belgrade today -- after they were blocked by police on Monday -- youthful members of the opposition group Alliance for Change began gathering signatures on a petition calling for Milosevic to step down. At a table set up on a main boulevard, thousands of people signed.

"This is my country, my city, and I think everyone should sign this paper," said Goran Djordjevic, an unemployed laborer. "I say what everyone should say, that things must change, and soon."

Support for the effort was not unanimous, however. One of the young signature collectors, Branimir Kuzmanovic, said that several men had ripped down their signs and flags and punched two of his colleagues. "But we did not want to incite them," he said. "There are all sorts of lunatics now, on the left and on the right." Kuzmanovic said he just wants "normal people" to sign the petition. Vuk Draskovic issues a public challenge to Milosevic. (Photo ran in an earlier edition) Belgrade residents sign a petition demanding the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. "I say what everyone should say, that things must change, and soon," said one of the thousands who came forward.


NAME: VUK DRASKOVIC


LOAD-DATE: July 14, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, ap/MIKICA PETROVIC; Photo, afp/SRDJAN SUKI


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


36 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


SEPTEMBER 22, 1999 Wednesday SF EDITION


UNITY ELUSIVE AS SERBS RALLY FOR CHANGE FEWER PROTESTED AGAINST MILOSEVIC THAN A MONTH AGO. THEY SEEMED UNSURE OF HOW TO DRIVE HIM FROM POWER.


BYLINE: Jeffrey Fleishman, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A02


LENGTH: 1072 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


Frustrated by high unemployment, inflation, years of political turmoil, and ruinous wars, tens of thousands of Serbs rallied last night in protests designed to topple President Slobodan Milosevic.

Across Yugoslavia, Serbs waved placards and chanted slogans, but the protests were lackluster compared with demonstrations of just a month ago, and Serbs seemed uncertain how to drive Milosevic and his cronies from power. Serbs are brimming with skepticism, and none of the disparate opposition leaders has yet captivated a nation in economic and social chaos.

"The protests are the last hope that something will change in this country," a law student, Tamara Draskovic, 22, said. "But I'm not very enthusiastic. We tried rallies two years ago, and failed. I'm disappointed that the opposition leaders are not united. . . . We can't change anything if we're fighting amongst ourselves." 

Protest organizers said daily demonstrations would continue until Milosevic stepped down.

Milosevic's grip on the government, media and police has been so strong since 1989 that, even amid four lost wars and widespread public anger, the Yugoslav leader has consistently crushed dissent. The big egos and political squabbles of opposition leaders have often helped him. Political analysts have said that Milosevic's regime was severely weakened by last spring's NATO bombings, but that bickering opposition politicians failed to seize the opportunity.

The main opposition movement, Alliance for Change, is headed by Zoran Djindjic, a former Belgrade mayor, and includes economists, professors and a former Yugoslav army general. The other major player, the Serbian Renewal Movement, is led by a charismatic writer, Vuk Draskovic. The two men were coalition partners three years ago, but they have become bitter enemies, and their animosities have left the opposition movement rudderless.

"It's a kind of perverse situation in which [Milosevic] is afraid of spontaneous protests from the people, but the people are afraid to do something," the general manager of the Belgrade Times news service, Bratislav Grubacic, said. "You have a complete stalemate. Nobody knows what to do. Nobody knows how to take power. They're hoping some miracle of God might help us: some lone assassin."

In a gloomy dusk, with rock music, whistles and anti-Milosevic posters, 20,000 gathered in the rain in Republic Square. Traffic stopped, and police watched intently as opposition leaders took microphones, and waxed fiery in the floodlights. Similar scenes unfolded in Nis, where 10,000 turned out, and in Novi Sad, where 7,000 braved the weather.

Organizers, who had hoped for much larger crowds, said rallies would be held in 30 cities and towns by the end of the week. Just a month ago, 100,000 people filled the streets of Belgrade.

Opposition leaders are hoping to rekindle revolutionary passion by adding a touch of political theater to future rallies. Some of them will feature "public trials in absentia" held for members of Milosevic's regime.

"This is only the beginning of a difficult struggle to free Serbia first from fear, then from the regime," Djindjic said at the rally, which was boycotted by Draskovic. "Only with persistent and long-lasting peaceful protests in the streets will we be able to topple the regime."

A lawyer, Goran Zoric, huddled under an umbrella as the Belgrade protest began. He watched people pass wearing paper masks with Milosevic's face crossed out. He did not expect to be moved by speeches and gestures. He just wanted to show his disdain for Milosevic.

"I'm not here as a member of any political party. I'm here as an unhappy citizen," Zoric said, rubbing rain off his beard. "It's hard to list all the mistakes Milosevic has made. We all feel endangered. . . . We've been robbed in all possible ways."

All Serbs have been battered by the collapsing economy. Unemployment is 50 percent. Hyperinflation is setting in. Grocery prices have soared by more than 20 percent in the last three weeks. And the United Nations is predicting that Yugoslavia's power plants will experience 30 percent to 50 percent shortages in electricity this winter. Humanitarian organizations are saying that many Serbs might freeze to death.

The bankrupt Yugoslav state can no longer pay pensioners. Instead, retired schoolteachers, mill workers and bus drivers are receiving coupons to cover future electricity bills. The move is a ruse, according to pensioners, who say they need real money to buy food and clothing.

"We're dealing with a regime right now whose priorities are not providing services to the people," said Stephen Tull, manager of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in Belgrade. "The urban poor population is really going to suffer this winter. You can see people digging through dumpsters all over Belgrade."

The hardships, along with the war in Kosovo and two months of NATO bombing, have embittered Serbs, but they have done little to cause hope for change. A recent poll found that only 10 percent of the population believed that the protests would bring new leadership. Forty-two percent said they expected Milosevic to remain in power.

"We understand that people are still a bit skeptical," said Alexander Djukic, who led 88 days of failed student protests against Milosevic in the winter of 1996. "Maybe they're a little disappointed with things. We made mistakes [in the earlier protests], but in the meantime we've lost so much as a people and a state. . . . At this point, political parties are not important."

Opposition organizers such as Djukic are baffled by how far Yugoslavia has drifted away from Europe and the West. The Yugoslav government now counts Libya as one of its biggest allies. And Serbian Vice Premier Vojislav Seselj recently expressed friendship with Iraq "for the heroic resistance of the Iraqi people for the independence of their land and against American hegemonism as our common enemy."

As rain fell harder at the rally, Branka Sandic held her husband's hand, and listened for words of courage, and demanded a better life.

"This is the desire for change," said Sandic, a pediatrician and mother of two, who earns $120 a month. "The people are exhausted by the economy. There's nothing in stores. We used to travel, and now we can't. . . . Now we're in a prison, a ghetto. Nobody in the world wants to take us in."


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PHOTO
A protester wears a mask with President Slobodan Milosevic's face crossed out.

37 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


May 12, 2000


'Father of the nation' opposes Serbian regime


BYLINE: By GILLIAN SANDFORD


SECTION: CITY EDITION; WORLD NEWS; Pg. 10


LENGTH: 427 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


A former Yugoslavia president, Mr Dobrica Cosic, whose nationalist ideas won him the title "the father of Slobodan Milosevic" has dramatically lent his support to radical young people in Serbia by joining the anti-Milosevic resistance movement Otpor.

Otpor - a youth and student-based activist movement - has been gaining support across Serbia since it became public in November last year. It claims to have at least 20,000 members and organises protests that provoke and challenge the regime. 

In recent days many leading regime officials, including the Serbian police chief, Mr Vlajko Stoiljkovic, have branded Otpor members as "terrorists" and "fascists".

Analysts say the decision of Mr Cosic (79) to join Otpor provides it with credibility and legitimacy because of his stature in the country. He is a renowned novelist and anti-fascist writer whose ideas have led many people to call him: "father of the Serbian nation."

Mr Cosic was sitting at one of his favourite restaurants in Belgrade on Tuesday morning when a student leader of Otpor, Mr Vukasin Petrovic (24), decided to approach him.

"I said, 'Good Morning'. He immediately began praising us, saying that we were doing a good job. 'You are the future of this country', he said to us. I asked him if he would like to join, and he said, 'Yes, with pleasure'," recalls Mr Petrovic.

Mr Cosic later told local journalists: "My decision to join Otpor is to offer human and moral support to those young people who are motivated by patriotism, democracy and civilised behaviour and who do not want to accept the system that exists at the moment, and a society without hope. I believe that the movement Otpor does not only oppose the present situation but also fights for a free, prosperous and humane society."

Mr Cosic was among the authors of a memorandum written by academics of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts in 1986. This was highly influential in fomenting nationalist thought.

"His nationalist ideas provided a climate of opinion that Milosevic could then manipulate," says Prof Srbijanka Turajlic, a member of the Otpor Council - a group of respected advisers to the youth movement. But she welcomed his membership of Otpor.

Many liberals will be uncomfortable with Mr Cosic's membership of Otpor, because of his close past links with Mr Milsoevic. He was president from June 1992 to June 1993, at the start of the Bosnian war when Mr Milosevic was President of Serbia and some believe Mr Cosic could have sought to exercise the authority vested in his office to try to prevent it.


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times


38 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE JOURNAL (Newcastle, UK)


August 7, 2000, Monday Edition 1


Serbian rivals split on election


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS, Pg. 40


LENGTH: 260 words


 
   YUGOSLAVIA: The largest opposition party yesterday nominated its own candidate to oppose Slobodan Milosevic in next month's elections, rejecting appeals to rally behind a common standard-bearer.

The Serbian Renewal Movement [SRM] said it had reversed an earlier decision to boycott the September 24 presidential and local elections, and nominated Belgrade's opposition mayor, Vojislav Mihailovic, to run for president. 

Such a move threatens to hand victory to Milosevic by further splintering the opposition, the rest of which has said it will nominate its own presidential candidate.

In a statement released after yesterday's meeting of its main board, the SRM demanded that the other anti-Milosevic parties support Mihailovic.

"We hope that those parties will not boycott our presidential candidate, a candidate of the largest opposition party, or nominate someone else just to prevent his victory," the statement said.

The rest of the Serbian opposition movement, however, is expected to support Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the small, centre-right Democratic Party of Serbia.

Negotiations on the issue between all opposition parties, scheduled for today, were later called off after Zoran Djinjic, who heads the second-largest opposition party, expressed doubts that any agreement could be reached.

"We had plenty of time for negotiations," Djinjic, head of the Democratic Party, said. "Our problem is that we were not able to unify goals with SRM."

Other opposition leaders have said the talks should be held as planned.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Newcastle Chronicle & Journal Ltd


39 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury (Australia)


October 7, 2000, Saturday


World joins in the jubilation 24 hours of revolution


BYLINE: HELEN McCABE


LENGTH: 1032 words


WHEN the tired young police officers discarded their riot shields and tear-gas cannons to join the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators the whole world cheered.

After 13 years of dictatorship the very foundations of Slobodan Milosevic's power was swept aside in the course of a day.

The movement began shortly after sunrise on Thursday morning when the military roadblocks were knocked over to allow the convoys of jubilant protesters from central Serbia to converge on the capital.

Every available road into Belgrade was choked with vehicles. People lined the streets with signs and flags to welcome the revolution. 

The atmosphere was likened to the world's longest wedding convoy.

Serbs of all ages -- the young, the old, the peasants, the academics all carried stickers with the message "A better Serbia".

At midday giant speakers were being erected in Republika Square and young street sellers were marketing badges with the clenched fist symbol of the student movement, Otpor.

As the excitement and sense of anticipation spread throughout the city, the crowd swelled to more than 200,000.

By early afternoon they were peacefully entertaining themselves with anti-

Milosevic songs in a celebration of the impending revolution.

Ironically, it was the pudgy Milosevic who first used mass rallies to propel himself to power in the mid-1980s when he was just another colourless Communist Party official.

Displaying the same political skill which has kept him one step ahead of his rivals and his enemies in the West, Milosevic inspired public demonstrations of support.

Backed by his wife, Mira Milosevic, he seduced his countrymen by repeatedly playing to their sense of nationalism and over-riding hatred of Croats and Moslems.

He unleashed in his people hatreds that would cost them hundreds of thousands of lives.

Mira was Slobodan's childhood sweetheart from their home town of Pozarevac, south-east of Belgrade.

They are described as the classic example of the "banality of evil"; a term first used to describe Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann.

"He was a small-town, ambitious, clever but essentially uninteresting Communist wannabe," said one who knew Mira.

"Without her he may have risen no higher than being head of a local post office Communist cell."

Today the treacherous couple have just about run out of options.

The running joke in Yugoslavia is that Mira would prefer to be shot than see out

her days in a rogue state where she may be denied her penchant for carefully coiffed wigs.

In fact, it is believed the pair would ideally prefer to retreat to Russia to live out the remainder of their lives.

However, the newly elected Kremlin president is not expected to ignore Western leaders who will react strongly against any country which offers to protect the indicted war criminal.

This leaves only China, Iraq, Libya and North Korea.

The American military is reportedly monitoring Yugoslav airspace for any unusual air traffic like a Falcon or DC-10 which have often been used by Milosevic.

Nato aircraft are believed to be under instructions to force any aircraft carrying the disgraced dictator to the ground.

However, after a lifetime surrounded by the tight-knit Serbian community, many observers predict life in a foreign land could be too much to bear for Milosevic.

Both his parents committed suicide and with the people of Serbia baying for blood this may ultimately be considered the couple's best option.

Although Thursday's demonstrations began peacefully by 2pm the crowd was restless.

Surrounded by thousands of police in riot gear the demonstrators began throwing rocks at the parliament and several hundred stormed into the rear of the 84-year-old building.

The police responded by firing tear gas into the crowd which retaliated by setting fire to the police cars.

But the violence was limited and short lived. The demonstrators sensed the reluctance and nervousness of the police to follow orders and put down the uprising.

A busload of special police in blue uniforms inched its way through the crowds, the police at times acknowledging the uprising with victory salutes.

Over the loud speaker the voice of an opposition spokesman could be heard above the noise of the crowd declaring victory over the parliament.

"We have the parliament building. It is ours. Long Live Serbia."

In the frenzy, the offices of Mrs Milosevic were ransacked and, as a political trophy, an expensive brown leather chair was carried out of the building and dumped into a bin.

Immediately afterwards, against a backdrop of thick acrid smoke, a lone protester climbed silently onto the plush upholstery and ceremoniously urinated over it.

At 4pm gunshots rang out through the centre of the city and ambulances were heard winding their way through the frenzied streets.

By this stage the world's leaders, who until now had been glued to the dramatic live coverage on television, were beginning to stir.

In Washington, President Bill Clinton declared the US stand "with those trying to get their country back".

British Prime Minister Tony Blair stepped out into the autumn sunshine in London and demanded Milosevic leave office.

"Your time is up. Go now. Don't wait until there has been more death and destruction," he said.

The crowd in Belgrade then turned its anger on the state-run Radio Television Serbia which had virtually ignored opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica during the lead-up to the September 24 election.

By nightfall it was in flames.

"This is the last time that Serbia and Yugoslavia will bleed for its freedom," said one protester. "Milosevic's main crime is that he did not listen to his people, and hid in his bunker. He ran politics as though he was the only person in Yugoslavia."

The extraordinary eruption of people power was the culmination of eight days of procrastination by Milosevic who refused to accept the outcome of the presidential election.

The government dominated federal election commission admitted that Milosevic's rival had won 48% of the vote to his 38% but it called for another poll because his challenger had fallen short of 50%.


LOAD-DATE: November 30, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: MER

40 of 348 DOCUMENTS


South Bend Tribune (Indiana)


December 24, 2000 Sunday Michigan Edition


Milosevic foes claim huge win in Serbia


BYLINE: By DUSAN STOJANOVIC; Associated Press Writer


SECTION: NATION; Pg. A9


LENGTH: 442 words


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia--Pro-democracy forces claimed sweeping victory Saturday in Serbia's parliamentary elections, declaring that they now have a mandate to remove the last vestiges of Slobodan Milosevic's regime in Yugoslavia's main republic.

The Democratic Opposition of Serbia, led by Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica, announced it had won about 64 percent of the vote, compared to about 13 percent for Milosevic's Socialists. The ultranationalist Radical Party trailed with about 8 percent in the elections in Serbia, the larger of two republics that make up Yugoslavia. 

The DOS claim was based on a count of about 40 percent of the votes. The Socialists confirmed the results, drawing some comfort from the fact that they will be the largest single party in the parliament because DOS is an 18-party coalition that many political observers expect to break up in the coming year.

"Those who did everything to make the Socialists disappear from the political scene were not right," Socialist Party general-secretary Zoran Andjelkovic said.

The biggest loser was the neo-communist Yugoslav Left Party of Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, which won less than 1 percent of the vote, the initial results showed.

Exit polls and unofficial returns also showed that the Serbian Renewal Movement led by Vuk Draskovic--for years the undisputed leader of the anti-Milosevic movement--won only 4 percent of the vote, not enough to make it into parliament. Draskovic's party had refused to join the Kostunica coalition.

If the election results hold, Serbia will have its first non-Socialist government in half a century, since World War II.

The Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a leading non-governmental monitoring group that conducted exit polls, predicted that in the 250-member parliament, Kostunica's coalition would take 176 seats, the Socialists 36, the Radicals 23 and--in the biggest surprise--15 seats would go to the Serbian Unity Party of indicted war crimes suspect Zeljko Raznatovic, who was assassinated in January.

Official returns were not expected until today.

The election afforded Kostunica the opportunity to complete the revolution set in motion when he defeated Milosevic for the federal presidency Sept. 24. Milosevic refused to accept the result and called for a runoff, triggering riots Oct. 5 that forced him to concede defeat.

Milosevic's allies continued to control the government of Serbia, which accounts for more than 90 percent of Yugoslavia's population of 10 million. The Serbian government also controls the key levers of power such as the judiciary and the 60,000-strong Serbian police.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: A voter gets help with casting her ballot Saturday in Kragujevac, Yugoslavia, during Serbia's parliamentary elections. For the first time, Serbs are casting their ballots into transparent boxes.    AP Photo/NEBOJSA RAUS

41 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


December 26, 1996, Thursday


Beatings fail to halt Belgrade protesters


BYLINE: Kirk Schork/Donald Forbes


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL; Page  6


LENGTH: 633 words


Belgrade - Undaunted by police beatings, opponents of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, took to the streets in protest again yesterday, following clashes on Christmas Eve between pro- and anti-Milosevic crowds.

Five were hospitalised, including one man who remained in a critical condition after being shot in the head during the disturbances by a supporter of Mr Milosevic's ruling Socialist party (SPS).

More than a month of street protests against Mr Milosevic had gone without violence until Tuesday, when the SPS arranged to bus supporters into Belgrade for a rally at the same time and place as the opposition.

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, said Tuesday's events let the genie of violence out of the bottle and marked "the beginning of civil war in Belgrade". 

The harder Mr Milosevic tries to shore up the credibility of his SPS as a party ruling Serbia by popular consent, the more events conspire to prove him wrong.

Another figleaf was peeled away when Mr Milosevic's party rallied only 40,000 supporters in Belgrade under police protection on Tuesday, after boasting it would mobilise half a million.

Snow, bitter temperatures, icy streets and the memory of Tuesday's running battles yesterday did little to dampen the students' enthusiasm, although their numbers were down substantially from the 200,000 who demonstrated on the previous day. In Serbia, Christmas is celebrated on 6 January.

Blowing whistles and horns and chanting anti-Milosevic slogans, protesters snaked through the centre of the city, drawing waves and cheers of support from many onlookers in office and residential blocks along the way.

Washington and Paris warned that they held Mr Milosevic responsible for Belgrade's street violence. The German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said any more violence would damage Serbia's efforts to reintegrate with Europe. Western governments spent much of the last year praising Mr Milosevic as a responsible world leader for his work in support of the Bosnian peace agreement.

Still firmly in control of all institutions of government, including state television, the army and police, Mr Milosevic shows no sign of surrendering power voluntarily.

Diplomats say Russia would probably block any effort by the UN Security Council to pressure Mr Milosevic by reimposing economic sanctions on Serbia, which were lifted earlier this year in the wake of the Bosnia peace deal.

His ability to use force now has been virtually vetoed by US-led Western threats of reprisals and also by hints of reluctance on the part of the security forces to get too involved.

Monitors listening to police radios during the clashes on Tuesday heard commanders ordering their men to use minimum force, even when they or SPS supporters were taking a beating from opposition activists of the Zajedno (Together) movement.

Like everyone else who works for the Serbian state, the police are paid only when the government can find the cash and therefore have less interest in preserving it. The army, which used tanks to save Mr Milosevic and quell anti-government protests that cost two lives in 1991, has stayed silently on the sidelines in 1996.

The idea that the SPS might ditch Mr Milosevic rests on the theory that the thousands of party members who hold every worthwhile job in the state apparatus and the economy have too much to lose to relinquish power.

Their wealth has been milked from the labour and looted from the bank accounts of ordinary Serbs, as Zajedno never tires of telling its supporters.

Out of power, they would be held accountable for the destruction of former Yugoslavia and the wars in Croatia and Bosnia, which have reduced Serbia's people to economic ruin.


LOAD-DATE: December 27, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1996 Independent Print Ltd


42 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury (Australia)


August 23, 1999, Monday


New setback in bid to unseat Milosevic


LENGTH: 207 words


Belgrade

SERBIA'S fractured opposition has suffered another setback with an opposition leader denouncing rivals in the movement.

Former deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic also said his followers would boycott joint rallies aimed at forcing President Slobodan Milosevic to resign. 

Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, accused another opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic, of pushing the country to civil war by refusing offers from Milosevic's supporters for early elections to end the political crisis resulting from the 78-day NATO bombing campaign.

The rift between Draskovic and Djindjic has long frustrated efforts to topple Milosevic, whose policies have dragged the country into four disastrous wars that have left Yugoslavia in economic ruin.

Draskovic wants to accept the Milosevic Government's offer of early elections with months.

Djindjic and his allies insist that Milosevic step down immediately and make way for a transitional government pending new elections under international supervision.

On Thursday, about 150,000 people turned in Belgrade for the biggest anti-Milosevic rally in the capital in years.

Draskovic was jeered when he mentioned the Government's call for early elections. AP

Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


43 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


October 7, 2000, Saturday


Power to the people


BYLINE: Helen McCabe


SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 33


LENGTH: 1221 words


Helen McCabe reports on Yugoslavia's revolution against 'the Butcher of the Balkans'

'This is the last time that Serbia and Yugoslavia will bleed for its freedom'

WHEN the tired young Serbian police officers discarded their riot shields and tear gas cannons to join the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators, the whole world cheered.

After 13 years of dictatorship, the very foundations of Slobodan Milosevic's power was swept aside in the course of a single day.

The movement began just after sunrise on Thursday morning when the military roadblocks were knocked over to allow the convoys of jubilant protesters from central Serbia to converge on the capital.

Every available road into Belgrade was choked with vehicles. People lined the streets with signs and flags to welcome the revolution. 

The atmosphere was likened to the world's longest wedding convoy.

Serbs of all ages -- the young, the old, the peasants, the academics -- all carried stickers with the message, "A better Serbia".

At noon the giant speakers were being erected in Republika Square and young street sellers were marketing badges with the clenched fist symbol of the student movement Otpor.

As the excitement and sense of anticipation spread throughout the city, the crowd swelled to more than 200,000.

By early afternoon they were peacefully entertaining themselves with anti-Milosevic songs in a celebration of the impending revolution.

Ironically, it was the pudgy Slobodan Milosevic who first used mass rallies to propel himself to power in the mid-1980s when he was just another colourless Communist Party official.

Displaying the same political skill which has kept him one step ahead of his rivals and his enemies in the West, Milosevic inspired public demonstrations of support.

Backed by his adored wife, Mira, he seduced his countrymen by repeatedly playing to their sense of nationalism and over-riding hatred of Croats and Muslims.

He unleashed in his people hatred that would cost hundreds of thousands of them their lives.

Mira was Slobodan's childhood sweetheart from their home town of Pozarevac, south-east of Belgrade.

They are described as the classic examples of the "banality of evil"; a term first used to describe Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann.

"He was a small-town, ambitious, clever but essentially uninteresting Communist wannabe," said one who knew Mira.

"Without her he may have risen no higher than being head of a local post office Communist cell."

Today, the treacherous couple have just about run out of options.

The running joke in Yugoslavia is that Mira would prefer to be shot than see out her days in a rogue state where she may be denied her penchant for carefully coiffed wigs.

In fact, it is believed the pair would ideally prefer to retreat to Russia to live out the remainder of their lives.

However, the newly elected Kremlin president is not expected to ignore Western leaders who will react strongly against any country which offers to protect the indicted war criminal.

This leaves only China, Iraq, Libya and North Korea.

The American military are reportedly monitoring Yugoslav airspace for any unusual air traffic like a Falcon or DC-10 which often have been used by Milosevic.

Nato aircraft are believed to be under instructions to force any aircraft carrying the disgraced dictator to the ground.

However, after a lifetime surrounded by the tight-knit Serbian community, many observers have predicted life in a foreign land could be too much to bear.

Both his parents committed suicide and, with the people of Serbia baying for blood, this may ultimately be considered their best option.

Although Thursday's demonstrations began peacefully, by 2pm the crowd was restless. Surrounded by thousands of police in riot gear, the demonstrators began throwing rocks at the parliament and several hundred stormed the rear of the 84-year-old building.

The police responded by firing tear gas into the crowd, who retaliated by setting fire to cars. But the violence was limited and short-lived. The demonstrators sensed the reluctance and nervousness of the police to follow orders and put down the uprising.

A busload of special police in blue uniforms inched their way through the crowds, at times acknowledging the uprising with victory salutes.

THROUGH a loudspeaker the voice of an opposition spokesman could be heard, above the noise of the crowd, declaring victory over the parliament.

"We have the parliament building. It is ours, long live Serbia."

In the frenzy, the offices of Mrs Milosevic were ransacked and, as a political trophy, an expensive brown leather chair was carried out of the building and dumped into a bin.

Immediately afterwards, against a backdrop of thick acrid smoke, a lone protester climbed silently on to the plush upholstery and ceremoniously urinated over it.

At 4pm, gunshots rang out through the centre of the city and a fleet of ambulances were heard winding their way through the streets.

By this stage the world's leaders, who until then had been glued to the dramatic live coverage on television, were beginning to stir.

In Washington, President Bill Clinton declared the US stood "with those trying to get their country back". British Prime Minister Tony Blair stepped out into the autumn sun in London and demanded Milosevic leave office.

"Your time is up. Go now. Don't wait until there has been more death and destruction," he said.

The crowd then turned its anger on the state-run Radio Television Serbia which had virtually ignored opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica during the lead-up to the September 24 election -- by nightfall it was in flames.

"This is the last time that Serbia and Yugoslavia will bleed for its freedom," said one protester.

"His main crime is that he did not listen to his people, and hid in his bunker. He ran politics as though he was the only person in Yugoslavia."

The extraordinary eruption of people power was the culmination of eight days of procrastination by Milosevic who refused to accept the outcome of the presidential election.

The government-dominated Federal Election Commission admitted that his rival had won 48 percent of the vote to his 38 percent but it called for another poll because his challenger had fallen short of 50 percent.

Public anger was fuelled by the suspicion of vote rigging, which observers estimated meant the real support for Kostunica was more like 52 percent.

The final straw was a decision by the constitutional court to declare the entire poll invalid, therefore raising the spectre of new elections at a time of Milosevic's choosing. Of course, he would have remained in power.

"All the court has to do now is determine that there have been no elections at all and the opposition invented them," said one opposition worker.

A poster reflected the universal anger at the court's decision: "It's no use: one plus one still make two."

But this time the anger was being channelled into a historic insurrection which was carried across Serbia in a wave of confidence and goodwill.

The president who put his country through three wars -- Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo -- today finds himself deserted not only by the rest of the world but also by his police force, his army, the propaganda unit he set up and, most importantly, by his people.


LOAD-DATE: December 4, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 2000 Nationwide News Pty Limited


44 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


December 24, 2000 Sunday Final Edition


Pro-democracy forces win big in Serbian vote: Ousted president's Socialists 'brought to their knees'


SOURCE: AP


SECTION: World; Pg. A4


LENGTH: 919 words


DATELINE: Belgrade, Yugoslavia


Pro-democracy forces claimed a sweeping victory Saturday in Serbia's parliamentary elections, declaring they now have a mandate to remove the last vestiges of Slobodan Milosevic's regime in Yugoslavia's main republic.

The Democratic Opposition of Serbia or DOS, led by Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica, announced it had won about 64 per cent of the vote, compared to about 13 per cent for Milosevic's Socialists. The ultranationalist Radical Party trailed with about eight per cent in the elections in Serbia, the larger of two republics that make up Yugoslavia.

"We declare triumphant victory," said DOS spokesperson Cedomir Jovanovic as coalition leaders uncorked champagne. "With the two-thirds majority in the parliament we will be able to change the character of this country." 

The DOS claim was based on a count of about 40 per cent of the votes. The Socialists confirmed the results, drawing some comfort from the fact that they will be the largest single party in the parliament because DOS is an 18-party coalition that many political observers expect to break up in the coming year.

"Those who did everything to make the Socialists disappear from the political scene were not right," Socialist Party general secretary Zoran Andjelkovic said. "I'm sure we'll have 20 per cent of the votes in the end and we'll be the strongest opposition party in the parliament."

The biggest loser was the neo-communist Yugoslav Left Party of Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, which won less than one per cent of the vote, the initial, unofficial results showed.

Exit polls and unofficial returns also showed that the Serbian Renewal Movement led by Vuk Draskovic -- for years the undisputed leader of the anti-Milosevic movement -- won only four per cent of the vote, not enough to make it into parliament. Draskovic's party had refused to join the Kostunica coalition.

The Centre for Free Elections and Democracy, a leading non-governmental monitoring group that conducted exit polls, predicted that in the 250-member parliament, Kostunica's coalition would take 177 seats, the Socialists 35, the Radicals 23 and -- in the biggest surprise -- 15 seats would go to the Serbian Unity Party of indicted war crimes suspect Zeljko Raznatovic, also known as Arkan, who was assassinated in Belgrade in January.

Official returns were not expected until Sunday.

"It's pretty clear we have won," said Zoran Djindjic, a Kostunica ally slated to become Serbia's first non-Communist prime minister since the Second World War. "We will win the elections, but a huge job comes afterward."

The apparent victory affords Kostunica the opportunity to complete the revolution set in motion when he defeated Milosevic for the federal presidency Sept. 24. Milosevic refused to accept the result and called for a runoff, triggering riots Oct. 5 that forced him to concede defeat.

Milosevic's allies continued to control the government of Serbia, which accounts for more than 90 per cent of Yugoslavia's population of 10 million. The Serbian government also controls the key levers of power such as the judiciary and the 60,000-strong Serbian police.

"Democratic reconstruction of Serbia and Yugoslavia will be completed after these elections," Kostunica said as he cast his ballot. "We are continuing what we began in September. I am convinced that the results will enable us to carry on with the work ... to rebuild the country."

Without a strong party to back him, Milosevic, who has been indicted by the UN war crimes tribunal, is now vulnerable to prosecution in Serbia for 13 years of rule that impoverished Yugoslavia and turned it into a pariah state.

"The elections show that people want a decisive showdown with the former regime," said pro-democracy leader Zarko Korac. "The Democratic Opposition of Serbia needs courage to do it."

Gradimir Nalic, a candidate for Serbia's new police minister, said, "There will be arrests, but only according to the law."

Initial reports indicated voter turnout was about 60 per cent, about 10 per cent less than in September's Yugoslav elections, according to poll watchers.

Marko Blagojevic, an official with the Centre for Free Elections and Democracy, said observers noticed no major irregularities. Monitors from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe also said the vote went smoothly. During Milosevic's era, irregularities were common.

A rare controversy at the polls was caused by invisible spray that was applied to the fingers of voters to prevent multiple voting. Many elderly voters refused to cast their ballots after rumours that the spray was radioactive and caused impotence, the centre said.

An hour after polls opened, Milosevic cast his ballot with his wife in the upscale Dedinje district in Belgrade, where he lives in a villa under heavy security.

Escorted by several bodyguards, the gloomy-looking Milosevic declined to comment, saying only, "I wish all a Happy New Year."

Ethnic Albanians in both Kosovo and in areas of southern Serbia bordering the province boycotted the vote. A great majority of them want independence, and consider the elections invalid.

In Kosovo's capital, Pristina, hundreds of ethnic Albanians demonstrated Saturday in front of UN headquarters to protest a decision by international officials to allow Kosovo Serbs to vote.

Kosovo was the only region in Serbia where the Socialist Party defeated pro-democrats. Kosovo Serbs traditionally have been supporters of Milosevic.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

45 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


March 19, 1991, Tuesday, Final Edition


Yugoslav Political Turmoil Broadens;
Collective Presidency Rejects Actions by Marxist Serbian Leader


Blaine Harden, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21


LENGTH: 856 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, March 18, 1991


Yugoslavia's central government began fighting back today against an attempt by Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic to disenfranchise the Yugoslav collective presidency, which commands the army and mediates disputes among this hybrid country's six constituent republics.

Speaking for the eight-member presidency, the republic of Macedonia's representative on the body, Vasily Tupurkovski, called Milosevic's action an "extremely serious" disruption of the decision-making power of the Yugoslav government and insisted that the Serbian leader's combative tactics would fail. "Nobody can legally block the work of the presidency," Tupurkovski said.

On Saturday, Milosevic declared that his Marxist government no longer recognizes the authority of the presidency and ordered the members from Serbia and three Serbian-dominated jurisdictions to quit, provoking a constitutional crisis. The only one of the four who refused to obey -- the representative from the Serbian province of Kosovo -- was fired today by the Serbian legislature, but Tupurkovski rejected that action, saying that only Kosovo's assembly had such authority. 

To pull Yugoslavia back from the brink of disintegration, Tupurkovski called for an urgent meeting of central government leaders and the heads of the six republics on Thursday. Serbian officials said they did not know if Milosevic or any representative of Serbia, the largest and most populous of the republics, would attend.

But even while defending the authority of the presidency, Tupurkovski acknowledged that it had no contact with leaders of the Yugoslav army in the previous 48 hours, and there is widespread concern here that the Serb-dominated military might support Milosevic in a countrywide martial-law crackdown. Milosevic's public dispute with the presidency erupted after he had failed repeatedly to induce the body to order the army to take "emergency measures" against anti-communist street protests in Serbia and separatist movements in other Yugoslav republics.

The Serbian leader's renegade action comes at a time when this patchwork country is splitting at the seams with ethnic tension. The northwestern republics of Croatia and Slovenia are threatening secession unless central-government control is fundamentally loosened, a prospect that Serbia had long opposed. The two republics, both led by strongly nationalistic, democratic governments, have stopped paying federal taxes and have mobilized large local militias as a defense against possible intervention by the army.

Today, the Yugoslav airline, JAT, announced that it has suspended all flights between Belgrade -- the capital of both Yugoslavia and Serbia -- and Zagreb, capital of Croatia. There also were reports of two large explosions in the Croatian town of Knin, where a well-armed Serbian minority, under the apparent control of Milosevic, has been skirmishing for months with Croatian police. Serbs in Knin announced an hour after Milosevic's attack on the presidency Saturday that they were "seceding" from Croatia.

Milosevic, 49, an authoritarian politician who blends militant Serbian nationalism with rigid communism, appears to have been backed into a corner by street protests and chaos in Serbia's state-controlled economy and seems to be trying to shore up his regime with appeals to ethnic sentiment.

The Yugoslav army is led by Serbian generals, some of whom are passionate supporters of Milosevic, and ethnic violence could provoke a military crackdown and thus force an end to the Serbian protests. Such conflict, particularly between Serbs and Croats, also would trigger an explosion of Serbian nationalism, which could prop up Milosevic's popular support as well.

Here in Belgrade, as the labyrinthine conflicts within the federal government ground on, the anti-Milosevic movement among students and intellectuals appeared to be gaining ground. Disaffected journalists from Politika, the largest Serbian daily and one that Milosevic controls, held an emotional rally to demand truth in Serbian journalism.

"We want our newspapers to stop spreading hatred in Serbia, to stop provoking confrontation across Yugoslavia," said Vladimir Stefanovic, a Politika reporter. "We have stooped to the lowest level in our history. We now want the managing director and chief editors to step down immediately."

Another newspaper, Borba, published an anti-Milosevic statement from a political group formed last year by Yugoslavia's prime minister, Ante Markovic. Journalists here described it as the most damning summation of Milosevic's impact on Serbia ever published.

"The personal regime of Slobodan Milosevic has entered into the final stage of its agony," the statement said. "Milosevic has attempted to blame Yugoslavia for all the failures and defects of his policies . . . [and is now trying] to annul the effect of the democratic breakthrough made during street demonstrations at which his policies were spontaneously rejected by the Serbian people. His policies contain all the paradoxes of his personality -- verbal commitment to Yugoslavia, while in fact he is trying to destroy it."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, MEMBERS OF SERBIAN LEGISLATURE RAISE THEIR HANDS IN VOTE TO DISMISS KOSOVO'S REPRESENTATIVE FROM YUGOSLAV PRESIDENCY. AP


TYPE: FOREIGN NEWS


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


46 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


July 19, 1999, Monday


MILOSEVIC FOES LABELLED AS TRAITORS


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Kragujevac


SECTION: Pg. 9


LENGTH: 721 words


 

YUGOSLAVIA'S top general branded opponents of President Slobodan Milosevic as traitors yesterday, amid growing in-fighting among opposition leaders seeking to oust the Yugoslav leader.

"Those who call for a forceful ouster of the legally elected authorities ... cannot count on the people's support," General Dragoljub Ojdanic, the army chief of staff, said in remarks published by the pro-government daily Politika.

The statement was his first since opposition leaders began organising anti -Milosevic rallies nearly three weeks ago, trying to capitalise on mounting discontent spurred by the country's defeat by NATO and the loss of Kosovo to NATO troops and its majority ethnic Albanians.

"It is the task of us all now to preserve the stability of the country because there are many sold souls, Western vassals, who want to take power by force and take the country into a new catastrophe," Gen Ojdanic said. "But they won't have any support from our people." 

The general is one of five top officials, including President Milosevic, indicted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal for alleged atrocities against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

Daily protests against Milosevic and his government have spread over much of Serbia.

One prominent opposition politician, Vuk Draskovic, has stayed out of the mainstream movement and on Saturday launched his own push to unseat President Milosevic. Mr Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, spoke to 15,000 supporters in the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, demanding Mr Milosevic's resignation but at the same time distancing himself from other opposition leaders, accusing them of risking civil war.

Mr Draskovic's speech was carefully calculated to unite Yugoslavs who want to topple Milosevic.

To appease Montenegro, he did not mention the Serbian monarchy; to attract disaffected members of Milosevic's Socialist Party, he stressed a revenge-free transition of government.

"Some people say that the time is coming when Milosevic and all the leaders of his regime must go to jail, that their children will spend day and night visiting their parents in jail. The Serbian Renewal Movement says no to that. We cannot rebuild this country on hate and revenge.

"Those types of statements come from people who have never felt the boot of this regime on their backs, nor have they seen their jails and basements. I was a target of that. Tens of thousands of our members have lost their jobs."

Mr Draskovic called on President Milosevic to resign. But adding "we should want more than that", he called for the establishment of a transition government leading to elections.

He stressed the importance of avoiding a civil war, "the greatest evil which exists", and said political change must come peacefully.

Immediately after the rally, one man was beaten unconscious as fighting broke out between youths of opposing political parties. Youths from the Renewal Movement said the fight broke out after a group of communists threw rocks and bottles at them.

Street scuffles are becoming common at political events.

Earlier this week, a group of opposition activists collecting signatures on a petition calling on Milosevic to resign were beaten by a gang of unidentified men.

The Serbian Renewal Movement, which represents a moderate nationalist wing of the Serbian opposition, draws inspiration from pre-communist iconography. Some of its leaders wear beards and moustaches in the fashion of pre-Second World War Yugoslavia.

Some in the crowd wore Serbian peasant hats, a nationalist symbol, and chanted "We want a king," referring to crown prince Tomislav Karadjordjevic, who lives in Britain.

The Renewal Movement chose for its first rally the anniversary of the death of the Second World War Serbian nationalist hero, Draza Mihailovic, who was killed by communists.

The more progressive wing of the opposition led by the Alliance for Change, a coalition of small parties, held a rally in Kragujevac on Thursday evening.

The Renewal Movement's rally, however, was much larger and better staged, with busloads of its supporters being brought in from neighbouring villages and towns.

"It was basically a slap in the face to the alliance," said a Serbian journalist who attended both rallies.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


47 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


October 9, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final


SHOWDOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA: FRIENDS IN NEED;
How Small Town Turned Out For Kostunica at a Key Time


BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 


SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1167 words


DATELINE: CACAK, Serbia, Oct. 8


Townspeople here cheered their mayor today in the street and paraded a yellow bulldozer around the main square for the television cameras in celebration of their part in the revolt in Belgrade that secured their election victory and forced Slobodan Milosevic from power.

People from Cacak, one of the most determinedly anti-Milosevic places in Serbia, were at the core of the tide of people who gathered in the capital, Belgrade, on Thursday and overran the federal Parliament and state television station. 

Velimir Ilic, the town's popular mayor and a well-known figure in the movement that opposed Mr. Milosevic, said two officers who were members of an elite police unit in Belgrade and two more in Cacak had helped to coordinate a mass defection of the police as the crowd, spearheaded by off-duty army paratroopers, rushed the Parliament building.

"It was a personal contribution from Cacak," said Mr. Ilic, 49, a broad-shouldered, energetic man who led 10,000 people from his town 60 miles north to Belgrade.

He was coughing badly -- he said he was still suffering from the canister of asphyxiating gas that a policeman shoved down the back of his track suit that day -- and said he had bruises on his arms and back from police batons.

On the table in his modest offices today, there was a huge basket of lilies from a local flower shop. The card read: "Thank you for everything you have done for us. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you."

Mr. Ilic, long a leading member of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement until he fell out with its leader, Vuk Draskovic, said he had always urged concrete action in opposing the Milosevic government.

But he said Mr. Draskovic and other opposition leaders had dismissed his "revolutionary ideas." But this time, he said, he headed for Belgrade determined to push for a confrontation.

"I was fed up with these long meetings," he said, "where there's just talking and nothing happens and Milosevic stays in power. I wanted to do something. At a rally here the day before, I told the crowd, 'It's victory or death.' We were fed up living in a Milosevic state. We were sick of watching state Radio Television Serbia, and we swore we would march to RTS even if we got killed."

He rallied a 12-mile-long column of cars and trucks and set off from Cacak at 7:30 in the morning for Belgrade. Among the workers, students and truck drivers, he had organized a core team of tough young men and, crucially, off-duty members of the police and the army, he said.

They took bulldozers and trucks to help break through police blockades and in case they needed to build their own barricades. For weapons they took three truckloads of stones, said Dragan Kovacevic, the regional chief of Mr. Ilic's New Serbia Party, who accompanied him at the head of the column.

Mr. Ilic said: "We established a team of young professionals, paratroopers from the Yugoslav Army and young policemen, and we coordinated this with the most elite units of the Interior Ministry Police in Belgrade. We got martial arts experts and professional boxers to join us. We even had plainclothes police coordinating with nearby towns."

The off-duty policemen used their walkie-talkies to give the demonstrators crucial warnings of police efforts to block the procession to Belgrade, he said.

That in itself caused problems, as some demonstrators accused them of being police informers. "I had to address the people several times and tell them, 'The police are with us,' " Mr. Ilic said.

On the march to Belgrade they tried to persuade the police to let them through and even join them. Once they were in central Belgrade, the paratroopers and tough young men -- along with members of Otpor, a student resistance movement, and even former paramilitaries in the crowd -- spearheaded the lunge for the Parliament building, he said.

That provoked a battle with the police, who fired tear gas and even opened fire on some demonstrators. That confrontation provided the stimulus and the huge crowd took on a life of its own, burning cars, Parliament and the television building, which had not been part of his plan, Mr. Ilic said.

But he said his personal agreement with two special policemen from Belgrade, and two from Cacak, had caused major elements of the police in the capital to join the side of the demonstrators. As several hundred thousand people converged in front of Parliament at 3 p.m. and started to clash with the police, his contacts refused orders to move against the demonstrators.

"At a certain moment they refused the orders of their superiors and were trying to persuade their colleagues too," Mr. Ilic said. He said a few influential men in the units had been on the anti-Milosevic side before the demonstration.

"They told us: 'Just keep on going. Sustain the pressure until 3:30 p.m., and then we'll get the order to charge and we'll refuse,' " he said, jumping half off his chair with excitement as he recounted the story.

In fact, Mr. Ilic said, he was scared all along that his agreement with the police was some kind of trap. He had developed contacts with those men during the last few months, but as the election campaign proceeded, he came under heavy police surveillance, including searches of visitors and of his bodyguards' homes.

Already last year, during the NATO bombing campaign, he had to go into hiding after protesting that the army had brought antiaircraft weaponry into the center of Cacak. He was accused by the government of being a traitor and undermining the country's "combat readiness."

He took to the hills in southwestern Serbia and hid for 43 days in the woods, and even once in a haystack. When he returned home at the end of the war, he was greeted as a hero by a crowd of some 20,000.

For the last month, he said, he has not slept in his house for fear of arrest. Then one of the special police in Belgrade invited him to stay with him for safety.

"I thought it was a set-up," he said, but he accepted. It proved to be an important test of trust. Another test was a warning his police contacts supplied of orders they had to move into the Kolubara coal mines against striking miners on Wednesday. They urged Mr. Ilic to gather a large number of demonstrators to rush to the support of the miners and push through the police barricades.

Mr. Ilic said he had not told other leaders of the democratic opposition of his contacts with the police and paratroopers or of his plans for the big rally in Belgrade.

But once the Milosevic opponents were inside Parliament, he introduced the Democratic Party leader, Zoran Djindjic, and the former army chief of staff, Momcilo Perisic, to the paratroopers. "I told them these men did it," he said.

And he warned that Mr. Milosevic remained a threat and his party could still fight back. "It is not finished," he said. "Milosevic is very dangerous. They are buying time and working intensively, and if they feel the moment is right, they could go on the attack."
  

http://www.nytimes.com

48 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


October 1, 1999, Friday


RIOT POLICE BREAK UP PROTESTS IN BELGRADE


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 16


LENGTH: 552 words


 

ONLY A FEW months ago, Belgrade residents rushed to central Milosa Velikog Street to view the damage to government buildings caused by Nato air raids, aimed at ending the Serbian crackdown in Kosovo.

In front of the same charred buildings on Wednesday night, thousands of city demonstrators ran into cordons of hundreds of police, who brutally halted an opposition march heading towards the villa of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

The police, in full riot gear, beat up 20 protesters, scattering the demonstration, and arrested 13 opposition activists during the night. 

It was the first police intervention in nine days of peaceful marches organised by the opposition grouping, the Alliance for Change.

Milan St Protic, a leader of the alliance, suggested to reporters yesterday that the police aggression showed that "Milosevic is nervous".

Senior members of the alliance vowed to continue staging regular peaceful protests and to avoid violence at all costs.

The marches, by tens of thousands of protesters, have been small compared with the mass anti-Milosevic demonstrations of 1996 and 1997. In the earlier unrest, the police - considered to be the President's "Praetorian guard" - waited for weeks before using force against protesters.

It remains a mystery why the police went to such lengths to stop the marchers this week when they were more than a mile away from Mr Milosevic's official residence at Dedinje. It is common knowledge here that he has not lived there since it was wrecked by Nato missiles in April. Many doubt that he lives in Belgrade at all.

Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, the biggest opposition party, which has stayed away from the protests so far, strongly condemned the police violence yesterday, saying the use of force showed that the regime was "virtually demanding a bloodbath in Serbia".

For months now, a public debate has been continuing over whether the crisis in Serbia will descend into civil war, or even end in the violent overthrow of Mr Milosevic, similar to the downfall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania a decade ago.

One side believes that Mr Milosevic will not hesitate to use force to quell the protests and stay in power - causing inevitable bloodshed. Others disagree, saying that growing poverty, combined with deep animosity towards the Yugoslavian leader and his powerful wife, Mira Markovic, could lead to events similar to those in Romania in 1989.

There is agreement on one point - that Mr Milosevic is not ready to go willingly.

Serbian official media described Wednesday's violence as an attack by "a group of hooligans; sympathisers of the alliance for Nato" against the police, who were carrying out their "regular duties".

The Interior Ministry issued a statement saying that "among the perpetrators were known criminals, drug addicts and hooligans who make trouble at sports events".

Meanwhile, the leaders of about 18 opposition parties, including the Serbian Renewal Movement and the rival Alliance for Change, held their first round -table talks aimed at agreeing conditions for any future elections in Serbia.

"This is a long process, but it can, step by step, lead to the final result - a joint stand by the opposition in Serbia," said Vuk Obradovic of the Alliance.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: A protester brandishing an opposition bulletin at riot police who used force to halt Wednesday's march in Belgrade Srdjan Suki/EPA


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


49 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


October 8, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


SHOWDOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA: THE OVERVIEW;
TAKING THE HELM, YUGOSLAV LEADER FACES BIG DIVISIONS


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER


SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 1364 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 7


Vojislav Kostunica, whose shoe-leather campaign and reputation for honesty made him the choice of a nation fed up with Slobodan Milosevic, was sworn in today as the new president of a deeply divided Yugoslavia.

Mr. Kostunica, a 56-year-old constitutional lawyer, won presidential elections on Sept. 24, but he was propelled into office by a popular revolt sparked by Mr. Milosevic's manipulation of the results. Hundreds of thousands of protesters overwhelmed Serbia this week, forcing an end to Mr. Milosevic's 13-year rule, which brought his shrinking country war, isolation and poverty. 

Looking pale and weary, Mr. Kostunica took the oath of office today before the newly elected federal Parliament, swearing to uphold Yugoslavia's "integrity, sovereignty and independence."

In a wandering acceptance speech, Mr. Kostunica praised the workings of Serbia's new democracy, where finally political differences might be worked out peacefully. "Today political parties are replacing one another in power," he said. "Everything is peaceful, and Yugoslavia and Serbia have joined the community of democratic nations."

But he got a swift foretaste today of the difficulties that he confronts. The scene at the 1970's-era conference center -- chosen as an alternative to the federal Parliament, which was burned in the revolt on Thursday -- was chaotic. Legislators, many of them accompanied by burly bodyguards, negotiated furiously about a future federal government, one result of a half-finished revolution that was bogging down in legal wrangling and political bargaining.

Among Mr. Kostunica's problems will be to guide a loose coalition of 18 disparate opposition parties that have never run anything larger than a city. But he must also work to maintain the very Yugoslav Federation over which he presides.

He must deal with the problem of restive Montenegro, which has moved a long way toward independence, and of internationally run Kosovo, whose largely Albanian population wants only to be free of any connection with Belgrade, no matter what foreign powers might think.

Mr. Kostunica's inauguration was delayed when his supporters, citing fraud in the presidential vote, disputed the number of parliamentary seats they were awarded, while members of Mr. Milosevic's coalition members fought to keep their Montenegrin allies on board and thus preserve their majority. The Montenegrins appeared to remain with Mr. Milosevic's coalition for now, but gave hints that they might soon switch to Mr. Kostunica.

The new president has floated the idea of a unity government of experts on the federal level that could include members of other parties that had backed Mr. Milosevic, like the Socialist People's Party from Montenegro, and even Mr. Milosevic's party itself.

In trying to gain a majority for his parliamentary allies, Mr. Kostunica has the complex task of trying to court both pro- and anti-Milosevic factions in Montenegro: the Montenegrin Socialists, and the Montenegrin president, whose boycott of the September elections left his party with no seats in the federal Parliament. Mr. Kostunica also knows that the Constitution, altered in a day by Mr. Milosevic in July, must be changed again to keep Montenegro inside Yugoslavia.

There remains great bitterness toward the Milosevic government, with Socialist Party headquarters being trashed in at least 20 cities across Serbia.

Today, at the Parliament, a student who belonged to the Otpor, or Resistance, movement and served in the army during the Kosovo war confronted two senior Milosevic men, Ljubisa Ristic and Goran Matic, for denouncing the movement as terrorist. "I'm a member of Otpor," said Filip Isajlovic. "I was in Kosovo last year. And I will never, ever forgive you for the words and names you called us."

Working out new relationships with the rest of Europe and the United States, which have welcomed Mr. Milosevic's downfall with full-throated delight, could be comparatively easy, despite questions over the extradition of Mr. Milosevic and other Serbs to The Hague on charges they committed war crimes in Kosovo and Bosnia. The West is eager to help Serbia with financial and other aid and has promised to begin lifting some sanctions against Yugoslavia -- though not the most damaging ones -- as early as Monday.

As the federal legislators gathered here this morning, there were reports by witnesses that Mr. Milosevic's son, Marko Milosevic, had flown on a Yugoslav Airlines flight to Moscow, YU-132, with his wife, Milica, and his son, Marko. His uncle, Borislav Milosevic, is Yugoslavia's ambassador to Moscow.

Ida Kovacevic, a stewardness on the plane, said in an interview after the flight returned here: "Marko came in as an ordinary passenger. He acted normally, and we acted normally. There was no special treatment." She confirmed that his wife and son were also aboard.

Belgraders noted gleefully today that in his resignation speech on Friday night, Mr. Milosevic said he wanted "to spend more time with my family, especially my grandson, Marko."

"He should go join them soon," said Vesna Mitic, standing today staring at the burned-out Parliament building where legislators can no longer meet.

But Meri Locani said: "I wouldn't even let him go to Russia. Why did he let all this happen? If people have a chance, they would hang him and his wife here in the square."

When she heard Mr. Milosevic's resignation speech, Mrs. Locani said, "I was so happy, as happy as I've ever been." She wiped at her eyes. She has a paraplegic daughter, Savina, 27, she said, adding: "I'd be the happiest person in the world if she could walk. But in the last few days I was so happy. It was almost as if she were walking."

But Mr. Milosevic remains here, with stated ambitions to continue in politics as the Socialist Party leader, which makes many uneasy. Aleksandar Tijanic, Mr. Milosevic's former spokesman who became a critic of his rule, said today: "As long as Milosevic remains on the Serbian political scene and shows a desire to be politically active, he represents a threat."

Mr. Milosevic "represents the political interests" of all those not in the democratic opposition, Mr. Tijanic said in an interview. But more important, "he's also the supreme commander of the net of paramilitaries, para-police and para-financial interests" that have thrived with and supported him and his wife, Mirjana Markovic.

"Milosevic can pull some strings," Mr. Tijanic said. "These cannot bring down the new government, but can keep it in constant instability and keep the public of Serbia in a constant state of tension."

One of Mr. Kostunica's main challenges, Mr. Tijanic said, is to enforce his authority over the opposition coalition and prevent any revolutionary bypassing of the law. "He should break down party interests in the coalition, because he won as the candidate of Serbian political opinion, and not as their candidate," he said.

The more powerful Serbian Parliament, which has supported Mr. Milosevic and whose members are not scheduled to face election until next year, is to meet on Monday. Maneuvering there with two parties that have been sometime allies of Mr. Milosevic could alter the face of the Serbian government, but exactly who will now control that legislature remains uncertain.

On Monday, the Serbian Parliament will recognize Mr. Kostunica, and may fire the Serbian Interior Minister, a key Milosevic ally, and abolish a draconian information law. But Mr. Kostunica and his allies must also begin to control the Serbian ministries that are now beholden to Mr. Milosevic and his coalition. The opposition is moving "minister by minister, institution by institution," trying to establish cooperation, a party leader said.

Both the Greek and Norwegian foreign ministers flew to Belgrade today for the hastily arranged inauguration ceremony.

The Greek minister, George Papandreou, and his government have tried to be intermediaries between Serbia and the rest of Europe, and between Mr. Kostunica and the Milosevic government. Mr. Papandreou said the end of Mr. Milosevic's rule ushers in "a new era in relations between Yugoslavia and Europe."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: October 8, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Vojislav Kostunica kissed the hand of Patriarch Pavle of the Serbian Orthodox Church in Belgrade yesterday. (Associated Press); A Belgrader peered yesterday into the Parliament building, which had been stormed and set afire by anti-Milosevic protesters on Thursday. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)(pg. 16)


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


50 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


September 27, 2000, Wednesday


Fragile coalition's challenge is to adhere


SOURCE: AP


BYLINE: * A correspondent in Belgrade


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 33


LENGTH: 425 words


THE opposition coalition that is claiming victory over President Slobodan Milosevic is an unlikely alliance that includes nationalists and ethnic minorities, labour unions and centre-right technocrats.

They came together for a common goal -- driving Mr Milosevic from office. If they succeed, it remains to be seen how long the coalition can hold together, given the monumental problems facing this country after a decade of civil strife and economic collapse. 

The 18 members of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia include some large, nationwide parties with branches in nearly every corner of the country. Others are small, almost shoestring operations with little more than a party banner, a fax machine and a resolve to bring about change.

National parties form the heart of the alliance. They include the centre-right Democratic Party and the moderately nationalist Democratic Party of Serbia, whose leader Vojislav Kostunica challenged Mr Milosevic in Sunday's election.

Other parties include the Movement for Democratic Serbia and the Democratic Alternative, both headed by defectors from Mr Milosevic, including former army chief General Momcilo Perisic.

Two parties represent the country's Muslim and ethnic Hungarian communities. Another -- New Democracy -- attracts the business community and technocrats.

The Democratic Opposition of Serbia has also forged alliances with independent labour unions and the popular, anti-Milosevic student organisation Otpor, or Resistance.

This disparate membership has raised concern that the alliance may not hold together if it does gain power.

For years, the opposition movement in Serbia, the larger of the two Yugoslav republics, had been plagued by personal rivalries and philosophical differences.

But last year's 78-day NATO bombing campaign against Yugoslavia changed all that. With the country in ruin and NATO-led peacekeepers in control of Kosovo province, the opposition decided it was time to move.

With strong encouragement from the US and Western European countries, opposition leaders began a series of meetings last year, which led to the alliance. When Mr Milosevic called early elections in July, the opposition was ready.

The next step was to find a candidate. Some of the best-known figures, including former Belgrade mayor Zoran Djindjic, were ruled out because long years in politics had left them with enemies.

Enter Mr Kostunica, a dour law professor. He was selected because public opinion polls showed he had fewer negatives than the others.


LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS
