51 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


September 27, 2000, Wednesday


Fragile coalition's challenge is to adhere


SOURCE: AP


BYLINE: * A correspondent in Belgrade


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 33


LENGTH: 425 words


THE opposition coalition that is claiming victory over President Slobodan Milosevic is an unlikely alliance that includes nationalists and ethnic minorities, labour unions and centre-right technocrats.

They came together for a common goal -- driving Mr Milosevic from office. If they succeed, it remains to be seen how long the coalition can hold together, given the monumental problems facing this country after a decade of civil strife and economic collapse. 

The 18 members of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia include some large, nationwide parties with branches in nearly every corner of the country. Others are small, almost shoestring operations with little more than a party banner, a fax machine and a resolve to bring about change.

National parties form the heart of the alliance. They include the centre-right Democratic Party and the moderately nationalist Democratic Party of Serbia, whose leader Vojislav Kostunica challenged Mr Milosevic in Sunday's election.

Other parties include the Movement for Democratic Serbia and the Democratic Alternative, both headed by defectors from Mr Milosevic, including former army chief General Momcilo Perisic.

Two parties represent the country's Muslim and ethnic Hungarian communities. Another -- New Democracy -- attracts the business community and technocrats.

The Democratic Opposition of Serbia has also forged alliances with independent labour unions and the popular, anti-Milosevic student organisation Otpor, or Resistance.

This disparate membership has raised concern that the alliance may not hold together if it does gain power.

For years, the opposition movement in Serbia, the larger of the two Yugoslav republics, had been plagued by personal rivalries and philosophical differences.

But last year's 78-day NATO bombing campaign against Yugoslavia changed all that. With the country in ruin and NATO-led peacekeepers in control of Kosovo province, the opposition decided it was time to move.

With strong encouragement from the US and Western European countries, opposition leaders began a series of meetings last year, which led to the alliance. When Mr Milosevic called early elections in July, the opposition was ready.

Enter Mr Kostunica, a dour law professor. He was selected because public opinion polls showed he had fewer negatives than the others.

JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 2000 Nationwide News Pty Limited


52 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


August 25, 1999 Wednesday Final Edition


MILOSEVIC RIVAL RAPS OPPOSITION BID FOR CIVIL WAR


BYLINE: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. C16


LENGTH: 276 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


A key opponent of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic insisted on early elections yesterday and criticized rivals for seeking civil war.

Elections are "the only realistic concept that could lead to the fall of this regime," Vuk Draskovic told a news conference. 

Draskovic blasted plans by other parties to organize an all-out uprising against Milosevic in the next two months, saying it could only lead to civil war and help Milosevic stay in power.

"The opposition must fight for conditions for democratic elections. We can demonstrate, but only to demand democratic elections."

His demand for early elections, rather than Milosevic's resignation and the formation of a transitional government has split Serbia's fractious opposition parties. Their failure to unite in the past has ruined other chances to oust Milosevic.

OPPOSITION UNITY

Draskovic's main rivals, Zoran Djindjic and his Alliance for Change, have spearheaded anti-Milosevic rallies throughout Serbia since June.

The issue of opposition unity was discussed yesterday in Montenegro between Djindjic, former general Vuk Obradovic and U.S. Balkan envoy James Dobbins.

A member of the opposition delegation, Vladan Batic, told Beta news agency the Serbs told Dobbins they would work to overcome divisions within the anti-Milosevic movement.

Djindjic rejected the idea of a Milosevic-organized election, saying the government would rig the vote. Milosevic's Socialist party last week indicated they would push for early elections as soon as November.

Yesterday, a group of Yugoslav army generals reiterated earlier warnings the army will intervene if there is violence.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Metroland Media Group Ltd


53 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Birmingham Post


September 30, 2000, Saturday


PUPILS JOIN PROTESTS AGAINST MILOSEVIC


SECTION: Pg. 7


LENGTH: 213 words


 

Thousands of pupils in Yugoslavia stayed away from school yesterday in the first wave of a nationwide blitz of strikes and protests aimed at forcing president Slobodan Milosevic to accept election defeat.

The school boycotts came in advance of a large demonstration planned for central Belgrade last night to launch a mass protest movement similar to those that helped strangle hard-line regimes across Eastern Europe in the past decade. 

More than 2,000 students waved anti-Milosevic banners and paralysed the centre of Nis, Serbia's third largest city. In one Nis high school only the principal was left inside as pupils poured onto the streets chanting: 'Save Serbia and kill yourself, Slobodan.'

'I know why you are not in school today. You refuse to accept injustice,' Nis Mayor Zoran Zivkovic told the pupils at a rally. He urged parents to join their youngsters on the streets.

Similar walkouts - joined by shopkeepers and others - were staged in several other cities, including the opposition strongholds of Cacak and Kragujevac.

'Serbia must stop in order to go forward,' an anti-Milosevic leader, Zoran Djindjic, told protesters.

'Children should not go to school, students should not go to university, theatres and cinemas should close.


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 2000 Midland Independent Newspapers plc


54 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


DECEMBER 1, 1996 Sunday D EDITION


150,000 STAGE LARGEST SERB PROTEST SO FAR MILOSEVIC'S OPPONENTS HAVE A LOT OF SUPPORT. WHAT THEY DON'T HAVE IS EXPERIENCE IN AUTHENTIC DEMOCRACY.


BYLINE: Tracy Wilkinson, LOS ANGELES TIMES, This article includes information from the Associated Press.


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A02


LENGTH: 878 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


Long black hair and beard flowing, Vuk Draskovic ascended the fourth-floor balcony, raised his arms to the sky, and pronounced his call for peaceful revolution to an adoring crowd below.

"Democratic Serbia will protest!" he cried. "In the streets, the schools, the universities, the factories, the theaters. . . ."

Draskovic is a leader of an opposition movement thrust suddenly into the international spotlight as the first serious challenge in years to Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic. For the last 13 days, the opposition has led huge demonstrations against Milosevic's moves to undo its recent victories at the polls. 

Yesterday's demonstrations were the biggest since Milosevic came to power in 1987. An estimated 150,000 people marched through the capital, aiming eggs and firecrackers at city hall and state TV. The rally began when about 15,000 students took to the streets, and it grew throughout the day.

"This is the fight for democracy and our future," said Milica Panic, 23, a law student, as she joined a long column of marching youths. "It is not just a fight for election results."

Yet as products of Serbian politics, the principal leaders of this fledgling opposition have little training in authentic democracy and, in the past, have voiced the same strident nationalism that fueled the bloody disintegration of the former Yugoslavia. Their experience and background raise questions about their ability to sustain the anti-Milosevic movement and to govern should they ever gain power.

Zoran Djindjic, president of the Democratic Party, who is quickly emerging as the most capable opposition leader, campaigned on behalf of the political party of indicted war crimes suspect Radovan Karadzic during September elections in neighboring Bosnia. And Draskovic formed a paramilitary army in 1991 to battle independence-seeking Croats. He and Djindjic have renounced violence, but their statements over the years have been contradictory.

The daily protests have been large and impressive. Tens of thousands marched through Belgrade again Friday, chanting "Let's go, all out attack!" and pelting Milosevic's office building with red paint and eggs. The opposition coalition, known as Zajedno (Together), announced that it would launch labor strikes starting tomorrow in an effort to widen the movement to include unions and workers.

So far, the protests have been dominated by students, pensioners and middle-class professionals. For the opposition to have a significant impact on Milosevic's leftist authoritarian regime, it must attract blue-collar support, analysts said.

Few observers here expect the opposition to succeed in toppling Milosevic, who is seen by the West as a guarantor of last year's Bosnia peace accord. He retains control over a loyal, 80,000-member police force and almost all media. But his decision to annul opposition victories in municipal elections Nov. 17, which triggered the protests, has seriously damaged his international credibility.

If opposition parties eventually do gain some local power, diplomats fear a period of instability and municipal chaos. The opposition - largely inexperienced and unskilled in the ways of municipal management - would face a hostile federal government that will make running the cities a nightmare.

The federal government still would control state coffers and such crucial resources as heating oil. Diplomats say one reason Milosevic is so adamant against sharing power is that such an arrangement would give foes a better view of rampant corruption that his cronies engage in through state-favored companies.

The Zajedno coalition's mandate would be limited politically as well. The ultranationalist Radical Party and Milosevic's Socialists would continue to control large blocs at the federal and local level.

It is also questionable whether the coalition could remain united.

Where Draskovic, 50, is an emotional symbol and a charismatic firebrand, Djindjic, 44, is a handsome, brainy pragmatist. Political and personality clashes have marked their relations.

Born at the end of World War II to partisans who had fought the German occupation, Draskovic was one of the first proponents of a Greater Serbia, the idea of uniting Serbs throughout the Balkans in a single state. Milosevic mastered the concept and used it as motivation for wars in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina.

Draskovic came to reject war, however, was branded a traitor by Bosnian Serbs, and was jailed and badly beaten by Milosevic's security forces in 1993.

Although the current protests appear to have given him a renewed focus, he has a reputation for flip-flopping on issues.

Djindjic, whose apparent victory in the Belgrade mayoral race this month was annulled by Milosevic, studied in Germany with Marxist intellectuals in the 1970s, landed in legal trouble back home in Yugoslavia because of his student activism, and then rose to the leadership of the Democratic Party.

Unlike Draskovic, Djindjic has had conflicts with Milosevic involving what he regarded as Milosevic's abandonment of Serbs in Croatia and Bosnia. He maintained ties to Karadzic and the Bosnian Serbs throughout the war, and he was a frequent guest in Karadzic's Bosnian headquarters of Pale.


LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1996 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC 
All Rights Reserved


55 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


September 22, 2000, Friday


DEFIANT KOSTUNICA VOWS TO FIGHT 'UNTIL LAST SERB';
 YUGOSLAV ELECTION: WITH CLENCHED FISTS AND SHOUTS OF 'SAVE US FROM THIS MADHOUSE' 150,000 OPPOSITION SUPPORTERS THRONG DOWNTOWN BELGRADE WO DECKS OF EIGHTEEN POINT INDY MODERN SET ON TWENTY POINT LEADING TWO DECKS OF EIGHTEEN POINT XYZ


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 505 words


 

IN A massive show of defiance of President Slobodan Milosevic, more than 150,000 people filled a downtown square of the Yugoslav capital, Belgrade, on Wednesday night to show their support for the opposition presidential candidate, Vojislav Kostunica.

The final pre-election rally for Mr Kostunica, of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS), was notable for his down-to-earth words that struck a chord with many. "I am an ordinary man, like most of you. I don't want to change the world. My intention is to change this country with you," he told the cheering audience. 

"We all want to live in an average country, where everything is average. Nothing like the past decade that brought us wars, refugees, isolation, sanctions, criminal Nato bombing. We want a state where the authorities will be afraid of the people, and where people will not be afraid of the regime, poverty and violence."

Their hands clenched into fists, the symbol of the popular student movement Otpor (Resistance), thousands responded with "Save Serbia from this madhouse, Kostunica". Many people wore Otpor shirts or others that said: "We're stronger" or "There's a way out". Women's groups gave away aprons with the inscription "It's time to clean up Serbia". Many people carried simple flyers that said "He's (Milosevic is) done".

Mr Kostunica described Yugoslavia as being "a hostage of a single man". "If I were this man, I'd step down, but Milosevic does not want to do so." To the crowd that booed whenever Mr Milosevic's name was mentioned, he added: "Our credo is people. Their credo is power. Power at all costs, until the last Serb."

Veterans of many anti-Milosevic protests could not recall such a civilised and dignified rally for the past decade. Pensioners had brought their grandchildren, young couples came with their babies. The police maintained a low-key presence and traffic was blocked from the streets around the parliament building.

Mr Kostunica had his only chance to appear on state controlled Radio Television of Serbia (RTS) on Wednesday. Under the electoral law, he was allocated a one-hour slot. He walked from the few hundred yards from RTS to the rally. Witnesses said the building echoed with the applause of the employees, who cheered Mr Kostunica as he left. "Something like that has never happened before," an RTS employee said.

As the crowds peacefully dispersed after the rally, Ivana Stajic, 20, a Belgrade student said: "I hope Kostunica wins. For years now, I have known only Milosevic. I don't know what it feels like to start the day without thinking of him and the problems he brought us."

However, some expressed doubts. "It doesn't matter if Kostunica wins here... Many outside Serbia support Milosevic... he suits many," one middle- aged man said.

Opinion surveys show Mr Kostunica holding a significant lead against Mr Milosevic. Fears are mounting that the President would not concede a loss and could try to stay in power by rigging the vote or imposing martial law.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: An estimated 150,000 opposition supporters join an anti-Milosevic rally in Belgrade on Wednesday night EPA

56 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


August 20, 1999, FINAL


Frustrated Serbs vent their anger: Huge anti-Milosevic rally biggest since 1997


BYLINE: William Branigin


SECTION: News; A5


LENGTH: 317 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- In a massive outpouring of opposition sentiment, masses of Serbs took to the streets of this capital last night to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic and call for democratic change in Yugoslavia.

Ignoring the government's last-minute political manoeuvers and veiled warnings of violence aimed at limiting attendance, the crowd clogged a vast area in front of the Yugoslav federal parliament building, waved opposition party flags and chanted slogans against Mr. Milosevic. 

Estimates of the size of the crowd varied wildly, from a low of at ''least 50,000'' to a high of ''more than 150,000.''

The rally, the largest anti-Milosevic demonstration here since a series of protests against alleged election fraud in late 1996 and early 1997, proceeded peacefully despite tense moments shortly after it started when a tear gas grenade exploded in the crowd and briefly scattered protesters.

''Red bandits!'' yelled angry demonstrators after the tear gas exploded, a reference to the communist origins of Milosevic's ruling Socialist Party of Serbia.

Speaker after speaker called for the resignation of Mr. Milosevic, who has held power for the past decade, first as president of Serbia and since 1997 as president of the Yugoslav federation. Serbia is the dominant republic in the federation, which also includes Montenegro.

Among the speakers was Vuk Draskovic, the mercurial leader of the largest opposition party, who earlier had cancelled his speech at the rally in a dispute over the appearance of a rival politician. His change of heart apparently reflected the size of the gathering. Although the crowd exceeded organizers' expectations, it was unclear where the protest movement goes from here. The opposition remains badly divided, and Mr. Milosevic has survived previous attempts to force him out during his 10 years in power.

57 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)


September 24, 2000, Sunday, FINAL


***** New Story*****


BYLINE: Southam Newspapers


SECTION: News; A5


LENGTH: 655 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


Serbs go to the polls today to chose a president and a new parliament, but the tension palpable on the streets of the Yugoslav capital in the hours leading up to the vote has revealed the nation's uncertainty about the election and the future.

Yugoslavs appear to be wrestling with the question: ''Are we about to elect a president or descend into violence and war?''

''I'm scared a little bit,'' acknowledged Vukasin Petrovic, an activist with the Otpor (Resistance) movement, ''because I can't predict what will happen in the next days. There are so many options (as to what can happen). . . . I must wait, and that kills me.'' 

Analysts and voters say the elections are the most crucial Yugoslavia has faced in more than a decade.

About seven million voters will pass judgment on the tumultuous 13-year regime of President Slobodan Milosevic, a Communist leader who won power in 1987 and rode successfully into the post-communist era on a wave of nationalism and war.

Public opinion suggests Milosevic will lose the election to Vojislav Kostunica, a previously obscure academic who leads the incumbent in the polls by six to 20 percentage points.

Kostunica, leader of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia alliance, is favoured to win in a fair fight. But the tension galvanizing Yugoslavia -- from the Adriatic coast of Montenegro to the ethnic Hungarian villages in the north Serbian province of Vojvodina -- hinges on the widespread fear Milosevic will attempt to steal the election and defend the theft with the might of the Yugoslav army and the federation's paramilitary police force.

Since opposition supporters are expected to take to the streets en masse if the government rigs the vote, many Serbs fear the election will end in tears.

''There will be blood,'' said Aleks Milutinovic, 33, a Belgrade journalist. ''That's my prediction. The government will steal the election, the opposition will protest and the police will crack down hard. Milosevic has shown a willingness to unleash his attack dogs at the first sign of protest. This worked in the past, and it will work again.''

But anything can happen. Here are some possibilities:

- Milosevic will win by stealing votes in Montenegro and Kosovo, declare victory and use the armed forces to back him up. The likely result: protests and violence across Yugoslavia.

- Milosevic will lose, concede defeat but invoke the nation's old constitution and remain in office until next summer. Likely result: protests by the outraged opposition. But if Milosevic is successful, such a stalling technique will buy the Balkan strongman sufficient time to regroup and fortify his position.

- None of the four presidential candidates will win an outright majority, forcing a second round in October or November. Result: Milosevic gains time to plan a comeback; but opposition candidates of the Serbian Renewal Movement and Serbian Radical Party could back Kostunica in a second round, burying Milosevic in an opposition landslide.

- Milosevic will lose the presidential elections, concede defeat but steal local elections and retain power by controlling parliament and the cities. Result: Milosevic could persevere by holding the legislative reins of government. But loss of the presidency would diminish the strongman in the eyes of his constituents and likely mark the beginning of his demise.

Tensions in anti-Milosevic Montenegro have created fears there will be a post-election conflict in this independence-minded Yugoslav republic. Late last week, a Montenegrin policeman, loyal to the republic's anti-Milosevic government, was shot and killed by a pro-Serb Yugoslav government soldier just outside of the capital of Podgorica.

Similar incidents could trigger violence between Montenegro and Serbia -- Yugoslavia's last two republics -- giving Milosevic the pretext to declare martial law, annul the elections and remain in power.


LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: CP Color Photo: Serbs fear Milosevic's reaction to election

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

58 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


September 23, 2000, Saturday


TENSIONS RISE ON EVE OF CRUCIAL YUGOSLAV POLL


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 13


LENGTH: 712 words


 

A TENSE mood of uncertainty hangs over Yugoslavia as voters prepare to cast their ballots in tomorrow's presidential elections. Although polls show President Slobodan Milosevic trailing opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica by 7-10 percentage points, analysts expect the regime to rely on massive electoral fraud for a victory.

The talk in Belgrade's cafes last night revolved around what might happen when, tomorrow night, the regime and the Democratic Opposition of Serbia both declare victory.

The Yugoslav army commander, General Nebojsa Pavkovic, has warned that his troops will prevent any violent attempt to take over the government from the streets - the opposition has urged its supporters to take to the streets to celebrate its expected victory. 

Opposition supporters are acutely aware that the Milosevic regime cannot afford to concede defeat, and know he will not hesitate to crush protests with a show of force. The country is teetering on the brink of a violent confrontation between Mr Milosevic's supporters and backers of Mr Kostunica.

Polls show that Mr Milosevic is running a deficit of 800,000 votes to avoid a run-off with Mr Kostunica. The president can, in theory, steal up to 200,000 votes without raising any eyebrows, but anything over that will require massive election fraud, according to election analysts.

Nobody doubts Mr Milosevic's determination to stay in power, primarily because he has been indicted for war crimes by the War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. The only question is how far Mr Milosevic will go to defend his internationally ostracised regime.

"Police will launch a massive attack on opposition supporters to snuff out the potential of a anti-Milosevic movement," said Darko, a 27-year-old news editor at a Belgrade TV station. His view is the most widespread. Dozens of protesters were treated for serious injuries last September and in May, when local protests threatened to turn into mass movements against the regime.

"If something big happens, it won't be in Belgrade. A violent uprising is most likely to begin in southern cities like Nis or Kraljevo where people are poorer and more disillusioned, and where the regime has never unleashed a large show of force," said an opposition strategist.

Others speculate that the election will never happen. "Milosevic will at the last moment create a crisis, either in Kosovo or Montenegro, in order to avoid an election in which he is certain to be humiliated," said Boyan, 38, a taxi driver who has fought in four nationalist wars for the Milosevic regime.

Local observers say Mr Milosevic miscalculated when he scheduled early elections in July. He was so confident of his popularity that he changed the Yugoslav constitution so that the president would be elected by popular vote instead of by federal parliament.

Though he has been in power for 12 years, Mr Milosevic has only faced two elections. In 1990 and 1992, in early elections, he was the candidate for the office of the president of Serbia and won 65 and 53 per cent of the vote, respectively.

Now he has the support of less than 30 per cent of the voting public. He assumed that a divided opposition would lead him to victory, but Mr Kostunica unexpectedly emerged from the shadows to undermine the political formulas that have kept Mr Milosevic in power.

Regardless of what happens tomorrow, Mr Kostunica has profoundly affected Yugoslavia's political landscape. His soft-spoken manner contrasts sharply with the bombastic style favoured by Serbia's opposition leaders over the past decade. The country has had enough of sound and fury politics and wants a candidate it can trust. Mr Kostunica's campaign slogan promises just that: "Who is the candidate you can look straight in the eye?"

For the past decade Mr Milosevic has relied on the egoistic squabbles within the opposition to remain in power.

Mr Kostunica undermined that predictable formula; 19 parties backed him, while one opposition party, led by Vuk Draskovic, fielded its own candidate. Mr Draskovic's party is widely viewed as being in collusion with Mr Milosevic and has plummeted in popularity. The result has been a more clear definition of opposition to the president.


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 2000 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


59 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


July 9, 1999, Friday


SERB LEADERS FLINCH IN FACE OF PROTESTS


BYLINE: Steve Crawshaw In Prokuplje


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 16


LENGTH: 664 words


 

VIOLENT CLASHES between Milosevic loyalists and supporters of the democratic Serb opposition were narrowly averted last night when the ruling Serb Socialist party apparently lost its nerve.

Party bosses had scheduled a demonstration at the same time and place as the anti-Milosevic opposition. Many expected violence - on the last occasion of such a deliberate double-booking, one man was killed. Yesterday however, in the face of growing anger, the Socialists backed down.

They started to erect a stage for their rival meeting yesterday afternoon. But the hostility of the crowd was so strong that they finally gave up and left the pieces lying uselessly on the ground just a few metres from the stage that the opposition successfully erected. 

During the demonstration, a local Socialist Party boss fired gun shots from his office balcony, causing brief panic among the thousands who had gathered in the central square. However, the meeting went off peacefully. Supporters of Slobodan Milosevic unfurled a banner from a balcony demanding "Traitors Leave Toplica" (the region surrounding Prokuplje) but they were booed off the balcony.

It was the usually self-confident Milosevic supporters who seemed frightened. An old man inside the locked Socialist Party Headquarters told The Independent that the demonstration was "absolute barbarism".

There were scuffles between supporters and opponents of the regime, but there were no injuries.

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic Party, received a much warmer welcome in Prokuplje than he had at the hands of the Kosovo Serbs in Gracanica earlier in the day. He called for a peaceful solution to Serbia's problems, saying: "There are not so many Serbs that we can fight and kill each other".

All over the country, signs of resistance are multiplying - though the protests have not yet reached critical mass.

Resistance to the regime is taking different forms. In the industrial town of Nis down the road from Prokuplje, people lined up at trestle tables to sign demands for Mr Milosevic's resignation.

The campaign is organised under the slogan, "Many Reasons - But One Demand: Resignation". Each signatory gives not just their name but address and ID number. These serve not just to show that the signatories are real, but also that people are not afraid. Most of the planned signing points in Nis were dismantled after the police threatened arrests. But outside a shopping mall in the city centre, organisers stayed put, daring the police to do their worst. In other towns, the gathering of signatures was banned.

Vuk Draskovic's Serb Renewal Movement (SPO) - formerly a pillar of the opposition - has hesitated between supporting the protests and remaining loyal to Mr Milosevic. Mr Draskovic has conspicuously avoided calling for the resignation of the Yugoslav leader.

But in Leskovac, the local SPO leadership tried on Wednesday to take charge of protests against the regime. Interestingly, the protests dwindled after the SPO became involved. Scepticism of politicians of all stripes runs deep in Serbia today. And tension remains high in the only other remaining Yugoslav republic, Montenegro.

The pro-western Montenegrin government fears proposals by Belgrade to form a federal police force, which could overrule Montenegro's own force. The Montenegrin interior ministry said such preparations were "yet another bid to destabilise the general situation in the republic".

During the Nato bombing, government buildings in the Montenegrin capital, Podgorica, were protected by armed police against a threatened coup by army units loyal to Belgrade. Belgrade was publicly furious at Montenegro's refusal to offer support to Serbia.

The Serb media are split in their reporting of the current situation. The independent tabloid Blic devoted most of yesterday's front page to news about the opposition protest. The pro government Politika by contrast remained silent.


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Kosovo Serbs demonstrate outside Gracanica monastery yesterday, where opposition leader Zoran Djindjic spoke in public AP; Vuk Draskovic: Cautious


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


60 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


December 26, 1996, Thursday, Final Edition


Protesters Dash Through Belgrade Snow; Anti-Milosevic Crowd Celebrates Government's Failed Attempt to End Marches


John Pomfret, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A37


LENGTH: 985 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Dec. 25


 

Defying police beatings, tough words from President Slobodan Milosevic and harsh weather, hundreds of thousands of opposition supporters packed the snowy streets of the capital today in a boisterous 36th day of protests against Milosevic's nine-year rule.

Tooting kazoos and whistles, lobbing firecrackers and chanting slogans, approximately 200,000 people formed a line that snaked through central Belgrade partly to demand democracy and partly to celebrate what many here believe to be a significant victory over Milosevic's supporters the night before.

The peaceful demonstration today was a blunt reminder that Milosevic's attempts Tuesday night to use his Socialist backers to smash the month-long wave of opposition protests failed. Socialist Party officials said they expected 500,000 Milosevic loyalists to converge on Belgrade Tuesday and scare off the opposition. But far fewer than 100,000 showed up, and it was Milosevic's boosters who were forced to flee the capital instead. In all, about 100 people were injured in street clashes between supporters of the opposition and Milosevic's loyalists and riot police. 

The fighting erupted when Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia organized a pro-government demonstration at the same time and in the same place where the opposition demonstration was to be staged. It was the first attempt by the Socialists to demonstrate for Milosevic since the opposition began marching in the capital more than a month ago to protest the government's annulment of Nov. 17 municipal voting. The opposition won elections in 14 out of 19 cities, including Belgrade, the capital.

"The whole world can see that Serbia is the last bastion in Europe for this kind of government," said Vesna Pesic, an opposition leader. "It is as if seven years ago the Berlin Wall did not fall. It is as if Serbia is an island in Europe where democracy has not reached."

Leaders of the opposition coalition, Together, said today they would continue protesting until Milosevic restores the election results.

In a joint news conference today, Pesic and another opposition leader dismissed signs of disagreement in their movement and said they still wish for discussions with Milosevic and other Socialists as long as the government first recognizes Together's electoral victories.

"We will accept dialogue on condition that he accepts the law," said Zoran Djindjic, president of the Democratic Party and the main strategist of the Together movement.

Earlier, Vuk Draskovic, another opposition leader, ruled out any talks with Milosevic following Tuesday's clashes. One Democratic Party official said Draskovic's statement "was an emotional overreaction."

The opposition statements appeared to be attempts to calm Western fears that Tuesday's violence threatened chances of a peaceful settlement of Serbia's biggest political crisis since 1991, when war came to the Balkans at what is widely held to be Milosevic's instigation.

It is unclear how the unpredictable Serbian president will respond to the continued protests or to the growing threat to his rule. In coming days, he will have several chances to defuse the situation and meet opposition demands.

In a statement read on state television late tonight, police warned that all rallies must be organized in accordance with regulations, the Associated Press reported. One of those rules is that rallies cannot be held in city centers.

In the important industrial city of Nis, 140 miles south of Belgrade, where Together says Milosevic's party stole an opposition victory, the local election commission began meeting today following a court decision ordering the panel to re-count ballots in 26 polling stations.

On Friday, the 55-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe is expected to issue its recommendations based on a visit to Belgrade last week by an OSCE delegation, which came at Milosevic's invitation to look into allegations of vote rigging.

Today, Djindjic and Pesic set out terms for a possible compromise with Milosevic. The pair said they would agree to new municipal elections quickly as long as Milosevic recognized their victories.

Djindjic and Pesic also stressed that they wanted equal access to Serbia's electronic media, which are dominated by the Socialists. An estimated 80 percent of Serbia's 10 million people rely on state-run TV Serbia for their news.

Tonight, the state-run TV news called the pro-Milosevic demonstration a "glorious" and "magnificent" rally of the "forces of peace and progress." In rhetoric filled with references to "foreign plots," "terrorism" and "Western schemes to destabilize Serbia," TV Serbia aired an unusually strong dose of pro-Milosevic programming.

If the opposition is installed in city halls throughout Serbia, especially in Belgrade, it would be in a strong position to affect the outcome of any subsequent elections. Under Serbian law, municipal governments are responsible for holding elections.

An air of defiance filled the crowd of protesters today. Ivanka Miljacki, a retired architect, said she was marching for her son and daughter. They emigrated to the United States because "they saw no hope for people like them who aren't good at stealing and manipulation and all the other damnable skills needed to survive here," she said.

Miljacki said she stayed with the crowd Tuesday even though riot police charged waving batons. "I was protected by big gentlemen," she said. "We felt secure in our numbers."

Djordje Ristic, 19, a civil engineering student, walked with a placard taken from a Socialist demonstrator. The placard read: "We don't want foreign flags." State-run media have said the presence of American and German flags among the protesters proved that the West funds the opposition.

"We are a democratic gathering, so even their posters are welcome," Ristic said with a wide grin.


LOAD-DATE: December 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

61 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 11, 1999, Wednesday, Final Edition


Church Leaders Ask Milosevic to Resign; Bishops Unite Behind Latest Appeal


William Branigin, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A15


LENGTH: 688 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Aug. 10


 

The influential Serbian Orthodox Church called on Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic today to resign in favor of a transitional government that would pave the way for early elections.

After a six-hour meeting, the church's bishops, including some who have supported the Milosevic government, agreed to appeal directly to him as well as to Serbian President Milan Milutinovic to step down. Those resignations would relieve "accumulated internal spiritual, moral, social and socio-economic problems . . . and the growing international isolation of the country," a senior bishop said.

The church's governing body, known as the Holy Synod and headed by Patriarch Pavle, asked Milosevic to resign in June, and the government responded by branding church leaders "traitors." Today's decision represented a significantly broader appeal by practically the entire church hierarchy. 

But the conference of bishops decided that Patriarch Pavle should not accept an invitation by political opposition groups to speak at a planned rally against Milosevic in the capital Aug. 19, according to Bishop Artemije, the church's top cleric in the Serbian province of Kosovo and one of the most outspoken opponents of Milosevic in the Holy Synod.

Artemije laid out the church's position in a statement he read on a local television station in southern Serbian city of Nis.

"We appeal to the presidents of Serbia and Yugoslavia . . . to immediately make way for other figures to take over the helm of state and take the people out of the cul-de-sac in which they have been driven," Artemije said. Milosevic's term expires in 2001, and Milutinovic's is up in 2002. Serbia is the dominant republic in the Yugoslav federation.

The statement also strongly criticized international sanctions against Yugoslavia and the failure of an international peacekeeping force in Kosovo to stop attacks by ethnic Albanians on Serbs living there in retaliation for atrocities committed by Serb-led forces.

The church's call for a new government came on the same day that a Yugoslav general who was dismissed as army chief of staff last year by Milosevic said he is forming a new political movement aimed at removing the Yugoslav leader.

Momcilo Perisic said his new group, the Movement for Democratic Serbia, would seek to unite Milosevic opponents and work to bring about new elections. The movement will enter an opposition scene in which various political parties, alliances and ad hoc groups are working, so far without much cohesion, toward many of the same goals.

The political future of Perisic, 55, has been the subject of intense interest here since he spoke out publicly against Milosevic for the first time late last month. Since then, he has come under sharp criticism from the government and the pro-Milosevic military leadership, which has accused him of taking the side of NATO in its air offensive against Yugoslavia.

With Milosevic entrenched in power and the political opposition in disarray, many people here have been looking to Perisic in the hope that he can provide some sort of alternative leadership and draw support for the anti-Milosevic forces from the military.

In an interview, the lean, chain-smoking former three-star general lashed out not only at the Milosevic government but also at the Clinton administration, NATO, ethnic Albanian "terrorists" in Kosovo and the fractious political opposition.

Perisic said he was fired by Milosevic as chief of staff last November in part because he opposed using military force in Kosovo, favoring "democratic means" to deal with ethnic Albanian separatists there. But he said that once engaged, the army never should have withdrawn from the province.

He said he had no knowledge of any atrocities committed in Kosovo by Serbian or Yugoslav forces but was sure that "if there were any" the army did not commit them. In addition to Yugoslav army troops, Serbian Interior Ministry police and paramilitary groups were active in Kosovo.

Although he criticized the NATO bombing campaign, Perisic said he wants to secure Western help to rebuild Yugoslavia.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


62 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 8, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Trouble in the Backyard


BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 


SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1172 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 7


More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav President is surfacing across much of Serbia.

Hostility toward Mr. Milosevic, bubbling up this week on the streets of the most unlikely of towns, has raised expectations among opposition politicians that Mr. Milosevic's survival in power might now be measured not in years, but in months. 

What has particularly raised eyebrows among political analysts -- who are beginning to doubt that opposition parties are capable of harnessing the anger -- is the surprise eruption of large and violent protests in the southern Serbian city of Leskovac, a long-time stronghold of the Milosevic regime.

There, without the help of any political party, but with the participation of army reservists who fought in the lost war in Kosovo, more than 20,000 people marched on Monday night calling for Mr. Milosevic to resign. On Tuesday, about 2,000 people charged the local police station, demanding the release of the local television technician who had organized Monday's rally.

The police responded with tear gas and by beating demonstrators with nightsticks. The crowd retreated and later attacked the home of a local political boss who belongs to the Yugoslav Left, a hard-line Communist party headed by Mr. Milosevic's wife. They smashed windows in the house and destroyed its front gate, a police official there said by phone.

"If Milosevic is in trouble in Leskovac, then he is really in trouble," said Aleksa Djilas, a historian and political analyst in Belgrade who is not affiliated with the opposition groups trying to force the Yugoslav leader from office. "It is like a Kennedy being in trouble in Boston. This is the beginning of the end. I don't know when the end will happen, but it will be months, not years."

The presence of Yugoslav Army reservists in demonstrations in Leskovac is a wild-card element which, if repeated in towns and cities across Serbia, could tip the scales against Mr. Milosevic more quickly than opposition leaders had expected.

Since the end of the Kosovo war in early June, hundreds of reservists have intermittently blocked roads and bridges in central and southern Serbia, demanding their overdue pay for service during the 11-week war in Kosovo.

The survival skills of Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicted on war crimes charges, should not be underestimated. Although he has lost four wars this decade while presiding over the implosion of the economy, he remains a shrewd politician. He has weathered eruptions of mass unhappiness in Serbia before, most recently in the winter of 1996-97, when three months of daily demonstrations all but paralyzed Belgrade.

The two major tools in his survival kit are an enormous state police apparatus, which is still believed to be loyal, and state television, which is the primary source of information for most of the country.

There is a consensus among opposition leaders that Mr. Milosevic cannot afford politically to use his police to arrest, injure or kill large numbers of Serbs. As Zoran Djindjic, a key opposition leader, said at a rally on Tuesday night in the western Serbian town of Uzice, "If there are a lot of us, they will not use force."

Instead, they expect Mr. Milosevic to do what he has done in the past: deploy his police and his large party apparatus to harass, intimidate and try to buy off the opposition. For instance, to disrupt an opposition rally planned for Thursday night in Prokuplje, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party has called its own rally at the same place and time. He tried the same tactic two years ago in Belgrade, without much success in igniting street violence.

That leaves television, which is doing what it has done so effectively throughout Mr. Milosevic's 12 years in power. It ignores or distorts all the news that is bad for Mr. Milosevic and his family, while vilifying their rivals and critics as corrupt anti-Serbian traitors.

There has been almost no television coverage, for instance, of this week's trouble in Leskovac or of three large opposition rallies in Serbia in the past week. But there has been plenty of television footage of Mr. Milosevic handing out medals to war heroes and promoting the image of a country on the mend. These moments have been private ones engineered for television rather than public appearances that might draw protesters.

As they have been for years, opposition leaders in Serbia are divided about how to best plug into popular discontent, which is rooted both in anger about the lost war in Kosovo and fear stirred by the collapsing economy.

The Serbian Renewal Movement, led by the charismatic Vuk Draskovic, had insisted since the war in Kosovo ended that the time was not right for street demonstrations. As recently as Monday, Mr. Draskovic told a news conference that he is a "legalist" who wants to press for reform from within the system.

The stunning news from Leskovac, which is controlled by Mr. Milosevic's Socialists but where the Serbian Renewal Movement is the main opposition group, appears to have forced the hand of Mr. Draskovic. His party announced today that it would take charge of a rally in Leskovac on Thursday night.

A senior adviser in the party, Ognjen Privbicevic, offered this explanation for Mr. Draskovic's sudden and seemingly opportunistic change of strategies.

"Vuk has such a good nose for these things," Mr. Privbicevic said. "Things are changing so quickly here. Nothing is predictable. This is the first rule."

Milan Bozic, the Deputy Mayor of Belgrade and a top leader in the Serbian Renewal Movement, said that all political parties in Serbia have underestimated both the depth of popular anti-Milosevic feeling and its power to bring people to the streets.

"All of sudden, it looks as though frustration over Milosevic is much more deeply embedded into the national consciousness than we expected," Mr. Bozic said.

Mr. Djindjic, a key leader of the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition groups, and a rival of Mr. Draskovic, delivered a rousing -- if vague -- speech on Tuesday that envisioned simultaneous daily rallies in towns across the country as well as a general strike.

Mr. Djindjic said he expected the Serbian Orthodox Church, which last month demanded that Mr. Milosevic resign and which has since been bitterly condemned on state television, will soon join the opposition and ring church bells across the country to call Serbs out on the nationwide general strike.

The timing and the planning for that strike are not yet clear, said Milan Protic, also a leader of the Alliance for Change. He said the opposition movement has not yet sat down with church leaders to ask for their help.

The Milosevic regime appears to fear the involvement of the church in politics. Politika, its main newspaper, today condemned church leaders for making peace in Kosovo with "terrorist" Albanian leaders and warned the church to avoid the "murky waters" of politics.
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: The strength of anti-Milosevic protests in Leskovac has surprised even the leader's opponents. Yesterday a peaceful crowd urged his resignation. (Associated Press)(pg. A8)
 
Map of Yugoslavia showing location of Leskovac: Leskovac, once a Milosevic bulwark, now seethes with unrest. (pg. A8)

The New York Times


July 5, 1999, Monday, Late Edition - Final


CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: OPPOSITION;
Key Foe, Back From Exile, Dares Milosevic to Jail Him


BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 


SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 756 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 4


A key figure in the Serbian opposition movement who fled during the war with NATO returned this evening and dared President Slobodan Milosevic to arrest him.

Zoran Djindjic, a central figure in the opposition alliance that two years ago staged the largest and most sustained street demonstrations ever held against Mr. Milosevic, is facing up to 20 years in prison for avoiding military service during the Kosovo war. 

"I do not believe Milosevic can take the risk to arrest me and provoke protests around Serbia," Mr. Djindjic said at the Belgrade airport, adding that he would appear in court here this week to defend his decision to flee the country.

Mr. Djindjic, 46, a philosopher and former Mayor of Belgrade who was educated in Germany, fled the capital in early May after he said he had received information that paramilitary thugs were planning to kill him. Shortly before he left, a prominent opposition journalist, Slavko Curuvija, was shot dead in the street after being accused on state television of being a traitor. The Government news media and pro-Milosevic politicians made the same charge against Mr. Djindjic.

At the airport, Mr. Djindjic told reporters he had flown into Belgrade on Montenegrin Airlines, rather than drive through Serbia in a private car, so that Mr. Milosevic's police could not arrest him away from the glare of television cameras. He arrived from Montenegro, the small, independence-minded republic that with Serbia makes up Yugoslavia.

Mr. Djindjic said he believed that the opposition movement here had only a matter of months to force Mr. Milosevic from power before world attention wandered away from the Balkans.

"We have not too much time," Mr. Djindjic said. "If we have Mr. Milosevic in power after six months, it will be too late. The attention of the international community will focus on us maybe three or four months more."

The Serbian Orthodox Church has called for Mr. Milosevic's resignation, but it was not clear today how many of its priests had used their pulpits to preach on that theme. Serbian opposition parties are almost unanimous in wanting Mr. Milosevic replaced but are bitterly divided over almost everything else.

Besides the threat of being imprisoned by courts that Mr. Milosevic controls, Mr. Djindjic is facing daunting political problems inside the fractured opposition movement.

He has been criticized by other opposition leaders for fleeing the country at a time of national crisis. Some of that criticism has come from inside his own Democratic Party, which he helped found and of which is president.

A number of political analysts here say his standing as an opposition leader has been weakened by his decision not to stay with the people of Serbia as they were being bombed.

Mr. Djindjic said today that he had been of more use to the opposition movement and to the future of Serbia by getting out of the country and lobbying European governments to give aid to individual cities where opposition to Mr. Milosevic was strong.

The United States and many European countries have said that until Mr. Milosevic is removed from power, they will give only relief assistance to Serbia but will not help rebuild roads and bridges.

Mr. Djindjic must also deal with the refusal of Vuk Draskovic, leader of the largest single opposition party, to join with smaller opposition parties in the Alliance for Change, an umbrella group that is staging anti-Milosevic rallies around the country.

Mr. Draskovic, who accuses Mr. Djindjic of cowardice for fleeing during the war, has said that the time is not right for street demonstrations and that he wants to work from "within the system" to force Mr. Milosevic from power.

Asked if the opposition can succeed without Mr. Draskovic, a flamboyant politician who has proven able to bring tens of thousands of people into the streets, Mr. Djindjic said popular disgust with Mr. Milosevic did not depend on the personality of anyone in the opposition.

"I think the feeling of the people is that they want change," Mr. Djindjic said. "They cannot accept compromise. Those parties that cannot accept that should leave the political scene."

Mr. Djindjic said it was not he who was taking a risk by returning to Serbia, but rather Mr. Milosevic who, by staying on in power, risked his life.

"The best solution for him would to go to The Hague," Mr. Djindjic said, referring to the International War Crimes Tribunal that meets there. "He is very clever. Maybe he can explain himself -- I don't know."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Zoran Djindjic, a Serbian opposition leader, greeted supporters after arriving at Belgrade's airport. (Reuters)

64 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


September 26, 2000, Tuesday, 0 South Pinellas Edition


Milosevic out, opponent declares


SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 1016 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


 

With official vote results lacking, the Yugoslav leader gives no sign he will concede.

Moving to pre-empt President Slobodan Milosevic, the chief opposition candidate in Sunday's Yugoslav presidential vote declared victory Monday, and tens of thousands of his supporters held a huge party in Belgrade to celebrate.

With his bold declaration, made in the absence of official voting results, Vojislav Kostunica appeared to be trying to demonstrate enough self-confidence and public support to force Milosevic to concede defeat. The opposition contends that despite widespread fraud and voter intimidation by the government, Kostunica carried the day on Sunday. Unofficial results gave him 55 percent to Milosevic's 35 percent. 

Kostunica said at a news conference Monday that if Milosevic challenges his claim, the opposition movement will "defend our victory by peaceful means, and we will protest for as long as it takes. We will fight in democratic ways. The truth is our strongest weapon. We don't want to provoke internal tensions."

The European Union, the United States and other Western nations threw their weight behind the opposition, declaring that any claims of victory by the government would not be credible and calling on Milosevic to step aside.

The Western powers view him as having directed a decade of ethnic warfare in the Balkan region and say he must leave if they are to lift economic and political sanctions on Yugoslavia. Milosevic has been indicted as a war criminal by an international tribunal in The Hague.

Kostunica made his victory announcement in a vacuum of reliable information about the actual results. Government election authorities have so far released only early figures, showing Milosevic in the lead. In any case, the opposition has declared itself unwilling to believe any official vote count, saying the numbers will be manipulated by the government to deny what they contend was a clear win by Kostunica.

Two other opposition parties that fielded presidential candidates, the Serbian Radical Party and the Serbian Renewal Movement, both credited Kostunica with victory.

Milosevic, who has not appeared in public since he visited a polling station Sunday morning, gave no sign Monday that he is prepared to concede the election and resign. At the same time, police and other security forces under his control did little to obstruct the opposition rallies.

Monday night in Belgrade - capital of both Yugoslavia and its dominant republic, Serbia - Kostunica supporters rallied in force, shouting such slogans as "Save Serbia, kill yourself, Slobodan!" Similar rallies were reported in many cities around Yugoslavia.

At the Belgrade gathering, famed Yugoslav folk singer and dissident Djordje Balasevic made his first appearance in two years, having withdrawn from public performances to protest Milosevic's policies. No rallies were organized by the government Monday, after only a few hundred Milosevic supporters attended a Belgrade rock concert Sunday and suffered the taunts of participants in a larger Kostunica rally.

The government appeared to be grappling through much of the day for a credible accounting of the election results, which analysts here think Milosevic had expected to win handily.

"We are encountering a wall of silence," said Sinisa Nikolic, an opposition member of the Federal Election Commission. "We are sitting here and asking what to do. We have no access to where computer results are being calculated."

Given Milosevic's tight control of the military and police, as well as his frequent use of repression to silence dissent, he retains the option of insisting that the vote was really in his favor and then cracking down on opponents.

He also could claim that a second round of balloting is needed because no candidate attained a majority of all votes cast Sunday. If he does, a runoff between the two top vote-getters - presumably Milosevic and Kostunica - would be held Oct. 8. But such a vote would hold new risks for Milosevic, because his opponents in Montenegro - Serbia's Western-oriented partner in the Yugoslav federation - who orchestrated a massive boycott of Sunday's vote within the republic, have said they would vote for Kostunica in a second round.

Legally speaking, Milosevic could concede defeat but remain in office until the middle of next year, to finish his current term.

At a Belgrade news conference Monday, Gorica Gajevic, a senior official of the ruling Socialist Party, said that with more than a third of the vote counted, Milosevic had won at least 45 percent. She added that she expected his vote tally to surpass 50 percent, ensuring a first-round victory. Gajevic also said she expects the Socialists to capture a majority of both houses of Parliament.

But another official in the ruling coalition, Ljubisa Ristic, conceded the party had suffered a major defeat in municipal elections that coincided with the presidential vote. Opposition leaders agreed, saying, for example, that the opposition had won 105 of 110 local assembly seats in Belgrade and 68 of 70 seats in Cacak, while in Novi Sad, Milosevic's Socialists won 11 of 90 seats.

Zoran Djindic, a leader of the 18-party coalition that backed Kostunica, said results from 60 percent of polling stations indicated Kostunica had won 55 percent of the vote, compared to Milosevic's 35 to 37 percent.

The opposition's claims of victory were based on tallies submitted by its election monitors, who stood by as government members of local election committees counted ballots throughout the country after the polls closed late Sunday.

"In essence, we won everywhere," said Dragisa Djokovic, who heads Kostunica's Democratic Party offices in Mitrovica.

Under Yugoslav law, the Federal Electoral Commission, which is stacked with Milosevic supporters, is responsible for verifying the local counting and declaring a winner. Officials on the commission refused to tell reporters why pro-Milosevic members of the body were in the Parliament building Monday, hours after police ejected the two opposition members.


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

65 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


August 25, 1999, Wednesday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION


OPPONENT OF MILOSEVIC INSISTS ON EARLY ELECTIONS;
HE ALSO ACCUSES OTHER RIVALS OF SEEKING A CIVIL WAR


BYLINE: The Associated Press


SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A10


LENGTH: 511 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


 

A key opponent of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic insisted Tuesday on early elections and accused opposition rivals of seeking a civil war.

Elections are "the only realistic concept that could lead to the fall of this regime," Vuk Draskovic said in a news conference. "I am sure Milosevic would lose such a vote." 

Draskovic also criticized plans by other opposition parties to organize an all-out uprising against Milosevic in the next two months. He said such a move could only lead to civil war and help Milosevic stay in power.

But Draskovic could not offer a clear strategy on how to force the autocratic Milosevic into organizing a democratic election, which would have to include loosening the reins on state-run media and allowing international election monitors into the country.

"We can either count rifles or ballots," Draskovic said. "The opposition must fight for conditions for democratic elections. We can demonstrate, but only to demand democratic elections."

His demand for early elections rather than Milosevic's resignation and the formation of a transitional government has split Serbia's fractious opposition parties. Their failure to unite in the past has ruined other chances to oust Milosevic.

Draskovic's main rivals, Zoran Djindjic and his Alliance for Change, have spearheaded anti-Milosevic rallies throughout Serbia since June.

In a major show of discontent, about 150,000 people attended an opposition rally Thursday in the capital of Belgrade. The crowd jeered Draskovic, who proposed an early ballot.

The issue of opposition unity was discussed Tuesday in Montenegro by Djindjic, former Gen. Vuk Obradovic, and James Dobbins, the U.S. Balkan envoy.

A member of the opposition delegation, Vladan Batic, told the news agency Beta that the Serbs told Dobbins they would work to overcome divisions within the anti-Milosevic movement.

Draskovic, once the most charismatic of all opposition leaders, lost much of his support when he joined Milosevic's government earlier this year. He was dismissed in May for urging a compromise with the West during NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia.

The rival Alliance for Change has gained strength since NATO took over Serbia's Kosovo province in June.

On Monday, Djindjic said his group planned to increase pressure on Milosevic by organizing more protests and dismissed Draskovic's accusations that the protests could lead to civil war in Serbia.

Djindjic said Milosevic must resign or Serbia would plunge into chaos, hunger and political disintegration. He rejected the idea of a Milosevic-organized election, saying the government would rig the vote.

Some opposition officials worry that Milosevic wants to lure the opposition into early elections before he loses any more popular support and that Draskovic is helping him. Milosevic's ruling Socialists indicated last week that they would push for early elections as soon as November.

On Tuesday, a group of Yugoslav army generals repeated earlier warnings that the army would intervene if violence erupted.


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1999 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


66 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


OCTOBER 13, 1999 Wednesday SF EDITION


AFTER SERB OPPOSITION LEADER'S CRASH, SUSPICIONS OF A PLOT VUK DRASKOVIC LIVED, BUT FOUR OTHERS WERE KILLED LAST WEEK. MANY BLAME BELGRADE AND SEE SIGNS THAT MILOSEVIC IS GROWING MORE NERVOUS.


BYLINE: Lori Montgomery, KNIGHT RIDDER NEWS SERVICE


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A04


LENGTH: 760 words


DATELINE: LAZAREVAC, Yugoslavia


On a lonely road south of Belgrade, a truck loaded with sand plowed into a convoy carrying Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic and four others to a Sunday picnic last week.

Only Draskovic survived.

The driver of the truck has vanished, and the truck's tag number that could trace ownership has been wiped from official rolls. Witnesses are scared, and few Yugoslavs seem to harbor any doubt that the fiery Oct. 3 crash was an attempt to assassinate Draskovic, the strongest rival to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. 

With thousands flooding the streets nightly for anti-Milosevic rallies, Belgrade is abuzz with speculation that the crash means the president is nervous. Political observers are anxious to see whether Draskovic's brush with death will push him to join the rallies, a so-far ineffectual campaign to topple Milosevic.

"We hope Vuk will now wholeheartedly join the opposition, but we'll see about that," said Milan Protic, a leader of the Alliance for Change, which is staging the rallies. "He's obviously under a lot of pressure - from all sides."

Draskovic, 52, is the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party in Yugoslavia, but his differences with other opposition leaders for years have hindered their efforts to oust Milosevic.

In the latest dispute, the Alliance for Change has taken to the streets since late September in a bid to remove the Yugoslav president and hold elections. Milosevic is considered vulnerable since an 11-week NATO air war devastated Yugoslavia last spring and forced him to cede control of the Serbian province of Kosovo to international peacekeepers.

The powerful and charismatic Draskovic has stayed away from the protests. He wants the opposition to push for elections while Milosevic is still in office. But in recent weeks, Draskovic began sending signals that he was ready to join forces with the Alliance for Change.

In the Oct. 3 crash, Draskovic and a group that consisted of his brother-in-law Veselin Boskovic and three bodyguards had set off from Belgrade for a picnic and political event. Boskovic drove Draskovic in an Audi sedan. The three bodyguards followed in a BMW.

According to officials in the Serbian Renewal Movement, as the cars neared the village of Lazarevac, about 40 miles south of Belgrade, a large green truck swerved out of the oncoming lane and sideswiped the Audi. Boskovic died of a broken neck. Draskovic, knocked unconscious by the erupting air bag, suffered minor injuries.

The truck then smashed head-on into the BMW and burst into flames. The bodyguards died instantly. The driver of the truck had vanished when police arrived minutes later.

Since then, police have produced no information about the truck. The serial number is visible on its charred chassis, but police have not found the owner. The tag number - Belgrade 994-704 - is the only one missing from a long sequence of tag numbers in the registry of vehicles.

"That police couldn't find the tag, the owner or the driver even after finding the chassis number is totally unbelievable," said Serbian Renewal Movement attorney Borivoje Borovic, who is conducting an independent inquiry. "Obviously, they don't want to get involved in this investigation in a meaningful way."

While police have been questioning dozens of residents of Lazarevac, they have not interviewed Draskovic.

The only substantive statement of any kind from police headquarters has been the assertion that Draskovic's convoy was speeding, which Draskovic denies. Authorities have referred the case to a local court in Lazarevac, which is treating it as a routine traffic accident.

Draskovic, officials in his party, and other opposition leaders quickly called the incident an assassination attempt.

No one has gone so far as to accuse Milosevic directly, however, and the regime has denied involvement. But in the tidy homes and shops that line the highway near the crash site, there is little doubt that someone powerful was involved.

According to witnesses in Lazarevac, a new-looking green truck similar to the one involved in the crash was parked alongside the road at least four hours before the crash, which occurred shortly after noon. They said four men and a red Volkswagen Golf with no tags were there, too.

"People are afraid to talk about it now, but we all know about it," said Milos, 38, a Draskovic supporter who lives nearby and who is among the few people willing to talk in Lazarevac. "This is a police state. People are afraid of what might happen."


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Belgrade police prevent a protest march through the capital's district of Banovo Brdo yesterday. Serbia's key opposition alliance yesterday dismissed Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's latest accusations and announced new tactics for his ouster. (DARKO VOJINOVIC, Associated Press)
