The Globe and Mail (Canada)


May 10, 2013 Friday


A new life for Tropical Heat and its star


BYLINE: GEOFF PEVERE, Special to The Globe and Mail


SECTION: THE GLOBE REVIEW; REVIEW; Pg. R3


LENGTH: 525 words


Slaughter Nick for President

Directed and written by Rob Stewart, Liza Vespi and Marc Vespi

Classification: PG

**½

Right around the same time the heavy-metal band Anvil was about to be rediscovered, and Swedish filmmaker Malik Bendjelloul started searching for Sugar Man, the 47-year-old Canadian actor Rob Stewart embarked on his own odyssey of belated, documentary-boosted pop-culture reclamation.  

According to Stewart, who co-directs, co-produces and is the subject of Slaughter Nick for President, the Brampton, Ont.-based, largely unemployed actor was living in his parents' suburban basement when he heard the news: Tropical Heat (a.k.a. Sweating Bullets), the Canadian-made Magnum P.I. via Baywatch meets Miami Vice detective show he'd appeared in back in the early nineties, was an object of high cult enthusiasm in Serbia. Not only that, but Serbia's top dissident punk band, Atheist Rap, had scored its biggest and most socially galvanizing hit with a catchy little high-velocity number called Slaughteru Nietzsche - commonly translated as Nick Slaughter, Serbia Hails You. The song was not only popular throughout the country, it had attained anthemic status as the soundtrack to the anti-Milosevic movement of the 1990s.

Slaughter Nick for President tracks Stewart's journey from his parents' basement to Serbia in 2008 where he is confronted by the fact of a celebrity status he never knew he had. From his arrival at the airport, where he is greeted by one of the former leaders of the student uprising, ushered through a flash-bulbing mob and into a limo, Stewart is delivered a universe away from that Brampton basement. Throughout Serbia, he's so popular people call his name on the streets, approach him to sign Tropical Heat DVD collections, compel him to appear in daft TV commercials, and generally tell him how this late-night surf detective show helped them dream of freedom.

It's over the course of these discussions that Nick Slaughter for President acquires its heart and heft. As the music of Rodriguez did for the South African anti-apartheid movement, the antics of the pony-tailed beach P.I. Nick Slaughter came to represent a kind of freedom and hope to young Serbians opting for democracy, the point where one of the country's more ubiquitous anti-authoritarian graffiti tags gave this movie its title: "Slaughter Nick for President." Naturally, our boy from Brampton is flabbergasted. But he's also happy. Exceedingly so. Indeed, from the movie's beginning, Stewart's voiceover keeps telling us that this was one of the greatest experiences of his life and, while undoubtedly true, it also prevents the movie from taking on either the final emotional K.O. of Anvil: The Story of Anvil or the slow-reveal dead-or-alive mystery that drives Searching for Sugar Man. But what it does share with both is a sense of wonder at the sheer stubborn weirdness of the human drive for galvanizing symbols of liberation and release from tyranny, and how one culture's trash can become another's rallying cry for action. In this case, Tropical Heat caused a splash, sustaining a wave of revolt behind a charge of "Surf's up!"


LOAD-DATE: May 10, 2013


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2013 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved


68 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


September 22, 1999, Wednesday, Final Edition


Anti-Milosevic Rallies Fizzle In Yugoslavia; Low Turnouts Place Focus On Fragmented Opposition


Daniel Williams, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A25


LENGTH: 766 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Sept. 21


 

Nationwide anti-government rallies in Yugoslavia fizzled tonight, attracting only a modest turnout and underscoring how the opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic has been weakened by divisions within its leadership.

In Belgrade, the main event among rallies in 20 cities, no more than 20,000 people showed up, far fewer than the estimated 100,000 who packed the main square on Aug. 19 to demand Milosevic's ouster.

In Novi Sad, 5,000 turned out, half the total for a summertime rally. Turnout in other cities also was low. In Leskovac, for example, where 20,000 people showed up for an anti-Milosevic protest more than a month ago, only 1,000 came today. 

The light turnouts bolstered Milosevic, who in early summer seemed to close to being removed from power in the aftermath of the NATO air campaign against Yugoslavia and withdrawal of government forces from Kosovo, a province of Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic. In July and August, army reservists protested lack of pay, and anti-government demonstrations were well attended even in rural Milosevic strongholds. Tonight, protesters marched listlessly, passing people in cafes who seemed uninterested in the goings-on.

"Rally? What rally?" asked Goran Matic, a cabinet minister in Milosevic's government. "This was an attempt of a rally. It only shows definitely and forever that the policy supported and financed by NATO countries has been defeated."

The results were a blow to Alliance for Change, a coalition led by political activist Zoran Djindjic. Djindjic has been battling Vuk Draskovic, who heads the Serbian Renewal Movement, for leadership in the fight against Milosevic.

The two have differed over the strategy for unseating the government. Djindjic wants Milosevic's immediate resignation, followed by an interim government before new elections. Draskovic favors early elections that would eliminate the need for an interim government.

In recent weeks, analysts here argued that unless the rivalry between the two is resolved, street protests would quickly lose fervor. Draskovic and his followers boycotted today's protests. Draskovic had threatened to boycott the August demonstration in Belgrade, but showed up after gauging the size of the crowd and deciding it was prudent to make an appearance.

Djindjic put on a brave face. "Even if 5 million people had shown up, it would not have finished the job. It's only the beginning and it's now or never," he told reporters. In a dig at Draskovic, he added, "For those waiting, I don't know what they're waiting for."

Djindjic called on followers to hold daily protests. The Alliance for Change also plans strikes and sit-ins, and student groups also plan demonstrations.

Draskovic supporters struck an uncompromising stance. "As we expected, the rally didn't succeed. Their idea didn't succeed," said Ognjen Pribicevic, an adviser to Draskovic, a former government minister who was ousted by Milosevic during the NATO air campaign.

In Belgrade's Republic Square, under a light rain, protesters shouted "Slobo, Go!" and "Let's go on the attack!" In conversation, they expressed both a desperation for change and skepticism that it would occur.

"I'm here because it's my civic and patriotic duty. I'm here to bring meaning to my life and my children. We're living like rats because of his criminal activities," said Zorana Suvakovic, 48, an unlikely protester. She is a journalist at the government newspaper, Politika.

"I think 10 million people would have to come to get rid of him, and maybe that wouldn't even help."

Jelena Vudukovic, 47, a clerk at a tourist agency, said people fear demonstrations might lead to violence. "People are afraid to show dissatisfaction. We don't want blood on the streets," he said.

Miroslav Bejovic, 36, a telegraph office worker said that after August he promised himself never to come to an anti-government rally again. He showed up tonight, reasoning that protest is an "existential question."

"But I've lost faith."

Few police were on the street in Belgrade, although plainclothes men reported to each other on the mood of the crowd through walkie-talkies.

In Novi Sad, to the theme song from "Star Wars," politicians promised to storm the local parliament building. But after heated speeches filled with attacks on Milosevic as a criminal and liar, the march on the parliament building petered out in silence while plainclothes police watched nervously from inside.

A protester in Belgrade puts his tongue through a hole in a picture of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


69 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


OCTOBER 26, 1999 Tuesday SF EDITION


MILOSEVIC AND FRIENDS CALCULATING STRENGTHS / OPPOSITION LEADERS AND FOES OF THE YUGOSLAV PRESIDENT / ARE FEELING THE EFFECTS OF HIS EFFORTS TO END DISSENSION.


BYLINE: Lori Montgomery, KNIGHT RIDDER NEWS SERVICE


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A10


LENGTH: 725 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


As thousands rally nightly to demand his resignation, Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic and his allies are conducting an increasingly public campaign of intimidation, police harassment and economic blackmail against opposition leaders.

Across Serbia, authorities loyal to the Milosevic regime have arrested some supporters of the pro-democracy Alliance for Change, threatened others with violence or fired them from state-controlled jobs, and closed privately owned shops and restaurants.

Recently, the campaign seemed to enter an ominous new phase as Milosevic's powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, launched a fierce rhetorical attack against Alliance for Change leader Zoran Djindjic, branding him a traitorous puppet of the West and a NATO spy. Meanwhile, the commander of the Yugoslav army vowed to defend the country against "various internal enemies." And a bomb exploded at the home of an opposition leader in the eastern town of Valjevo. 

Coming shortly after a suspected assassin plowed a truck loaded with sand into a car carrying opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, the latest developments sent shock waves across Belgrade intellectual circles.

Djindjic has accused the government of plotting his murder. Another key figure in the opposition movement has taken to wearing body armor under a heavy jacket when he appears at rallies or goes out to dinner.

"Don't say anything," the flak-vested dissident pleaded, as he scanned the sidewalk outside a fashionable Belgrade restaurant. "If they find out, I'm afraid they'll start aiming for my head."

Dissidents, journalists, and other observers of the Milosevic regime believe Milosevic is testing strategies to defuse calls for his resignation and for free and fair elections. Aware that a majority of Serbs would throw him out of office if given the chance to vote, analysts say Milosevic is disturbed that opposition factions have coalesced around a plan to begin a push Oct. 28 for early elections.

For now, Milosevic and his supporters appear to be carefully targeting movement leaders - in Belgrade and smaller communities - as a way of intimidating others to stay home and keep their mouths shut. If that doesn't work, dissident leaders fear the regime may unleash a police crackdown against the marchers who have gathered nightly in towns across Serbia for the last 31 days.

"I think the night of long knives is waiting for us," said Cedomir Jovanovic, a top Alliance for Change organizer. "They're waiting for the opportunity to use extreme violence in such a way as to horrify Serbian citizens" into submission.

One of the most wanted men in Serbia, Jovanovic, 28, is familiar with the regime's tactics. For the last two months, he has been sleeping in different apartments and switching cars during the day to avoid arrest by state security.

Charged this month with accepting cash from foreign intelligence agents and plotting to destroy the constitutional system, Jovanovic hides under a baseball cap and appears in public escorted by a cadre of marchers. Asked what would happen if police found him, Jovanovic, a movie buff, replied: "Midnight Express," a film that depicts vicious conditions in a Turkish prison.

The situation outside Belgrade is even bleaker. Take Leskovac, a southern Serbian town controlled by Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) where spontaneous protests erupted about a month after international peacekeeping forces entered Kosovo on July 12.

The issue in Leskovac - ground zero of this year's anti-Milosevic movement - was fury over the number of local men sent to fight in Kosovo. Nearly 70 percent of fighting-age males were mobilized in Leskovac, 20 miles from the Kosovo border. More than 80 died, though authorities admit to only 57.

On July 1, Ivan Novkovic, a technician at the SPS-controlled TV station, broadcast a diatribe against local SPS leaders during a championship basketball game between Yugoslavia and Germany. Four days later, 20,000 people - the largest crowd ever to assemble in the town of 80,000 - turned out to demonstrate against local leaders.

After the rally, Novkovic and two other rally speakers were imprisoned for nearly a month each. One of the speakers, Bratislav Stamenkovic, was fired from his job as a municipal development engineer. Earlier this month, Novkovic also was fired.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC 
All Rights Reserved


70 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


December 26, 1996, Thursday, THREE STAR Edition


BELGRADE PROTESTS PEACEFUL ON DAY AFTER STREET CLASHES


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7A


LENGTH: 555 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


 

Undaunted by police beatings the day before, thousands of opponents of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic protested in Belgrade on Wednesday.

Despite falling snow and frigid temperatures, the demonstrators marched peacefully through the city after street battles Tuesday when surging pro- and anti-Milosevic crowds clashed and police waded in to separate the groups.

Wednesday was the 36th successive day of what have become ritual protests with carnival-like overtones. Blowing whistles and trumpets and chanting anti-Milosevic slogans, the marchers snaked through central Belgrade, drawing waves and cheers of support from onlookers. 

Snowballs and firecrackers were thrown along the route, but there was no repeat of Tuesday's violence or massive police presence.

One local radio station put the size of the anti-government crowd at 100,000 people, about half the number the "Together" coalition fielded the day before.

Police, in a statement read on state television late Wednesday night, warned that all rallies must be organized in accordance with regulations. One of those is that rallies cannot be held in the center of cities.

The demonstrations began after Milosevic and his ruling party used its lock on government power to overturn opposition victories in Nov. 17 municipal elections in several cities and towns, including Belgrade.

For more than a month, the daily protests passed off without serious incident, but Milosevic's Socialist Party brought supporters into Belgrade Tuesday for a rally at the same time and place as the opposition.

Opposition leaders denounced the move as a blatant provocation, and Belgrade's emergency medical center treated 58 people for injuries in the ensuing clashes. One man was in critical condition after a Milosevic supporter shot him in the head.

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, said the clashes had let the genie of violence out of the bottle and marked "the beginning of civil war in Belgrade."

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic Party, said, "We have information that Mr. Milosevic yesterday reached a decision to ban rallying and that the state services are now getting ready to implement it."

Milosevic all but programmed Tuesday's street battle by urging gove rnment supporters to rally at the same site where the opposition has been protesting regularly since his annulment of opposition victories in the Nov. 17 elections.

Milosevic's supporters and opponents clashed repeatedly and police weighed in with batons against the president's detractors.

Montenegro Backs Off

In a sign that Milosevic's grip on power may be weakening, the prime minister of Montenegro - Serbia's junior partner in the Yugoslav federation - warned Wednesday that his republic would take steps to protect itself from further international isolation resulting from Milosevic's policies.

The leadership of Montenegro has been sympathetic to the Serbian opposition since the protests began.

Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic said Wednesday that Montenegro was prepared to conduct its own foreign policy if Serbia did not work harder to rejoin the world's nations, the Fonet independent news agency reported.

The United States and France said they held Milosevic responsible for Belgrade's street violence.


LOAD-DATE: December 26, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; Photo by Agence France-Presse - Opposition leaders Vuk Draskovic (left) and Zoran Djindjic wave to supporters during another march by 100,000 or so demonstrators Wednesday in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

71 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 23, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Fewer at Anti-Milosevic Rallies, but Leaders Vow to Continue


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 559 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 22


Street protests intended to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia appeared to falter on their second day today, giving some comfort to a Government deeply shaken by the loss of Kosovo.

Some 7,000 people turned out in fine weather for the rally here in the capital, compared with 20,000 on Tuesday. In Nis, about 8,000 gathered, compared with 20,000; in Kragujevac 5,000 attended, half of Tuesday's total. In Novi Sad, 5,000 came, compared with 7,000. 

Officials of the Alliance for Change, a loose coalition of opposition parties dominated by the Democratic Party of Zoran Djindjic, insisted tonight that the rallies and the campaign to oust Mr. Milosevic would continue.

The 88-day-long protests of the winter of 1996-97 also started small, they said, and built slowly to large numbers.

But the starting time for Thursday's rally was moved up two hours, to 4 P.M., to catch people in town before they head home, and some officials said there were already discussions of how to play down the importance of the rallies in order not to discredit the Alliance.

Mr. Djindjic, speaking at the Belgrade rally tonight, said somewhat plaintively, "We are being asked whether the people have any more energy" for the protests after 10 years of hardship and war under Mr. Milosevic.

Loss of energy "is natural," he said. "But if the people don't find this energy we are doomed. This is the last battle, not just for our generation, but for our children and grandchildren. We have no other option but to be here every day, rain or sun."

Alliance officials said later that they might move more quickly to announce an alternative, transitional Government, to be headed by the respected former Central Bank governor, Dragoslav Avramovic, 79, or move to more confrontational tactics, like a general strike or road blockages. Another possibility, they said, might be an agreement by opposition-controlled cities to stop recognizing the authority of Mr. Milosevic's Government.

They also seemed, in comments tonight, to be moving closer to the idea of using the rallies to press for early elections under fair conditions. This is the route favored by the largest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, which has dissociated itself from the rallies in the hope that they will fail.

The Movement's leader, Vuk Draskovic, has said that if the opposition parties can agree on conditions for a free and fair ballot, he will join the protests in order to press Mr. Milosevic to call elections. The Alliance, however, has insisted that Mr. Milosevic resign first.

Tonight, Mr. Djindjic said that Mr. Milosevic would steal any election unless forced, by mass street demonstrations, to organize a truly fair vote. And Mr. Avramovic, in his speech, said that he would try to reach an agreement with other opposition parties on demands for free and fair elections and the country's democratization.

Mr. Avramovic is clearly trying to unite the opposition, understanding that without Mr. Draskovic, however disliked he may be by the Alliance, the effort is likely to fail.

There is a continuing "round table" among opposition parties as they try to agree on conditions for a fair election. Mr. Djindjic boycotted 1997 elections as unfair, acting against American advice, while Mr. Draskovic took part, lending them legitimacy.        

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


72 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times


June 29, 1992, Monday


Serb leader warns West of 'Vietnam quagmire'


BYLINE: From Tim Judah and Dessa Trevisan in Belgrade


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 815 words


RADOVAN Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, has never minced his words. He said at the weekend: ''If there is armed intervention over Sarajevo, Bosnia will turn into a new Vietnam. This is not an ideological but a civil war. We shall fight to the death.'' As he spoke, his men were withdrawing artillery and tanks from around the besieged city's airport.

With Croat forces rampaging across Bosnia, Serb forces in retreat and Serbia on the international rack, to fight the world to keep an airport would be a foolhardy gesture at best. Taking the threat of military intervention seriously, the demoralised Bosnian Serb forces are turning to saving what they can. 

Bosnian Croat forces, backed by Croatia, are moving in a pincer movement to cut the republic in two. They are also thrusting across the frontier near Dubrovnik to wreak revenge on Trebinje, where Serb troops besieging the Adriatic ports have their headquarters.

Diplomats in Belgrade say the fear is that Croatia has been egging the Bosnians on to provoke the Serbs precisely to trigger a full-scale military intervention. If that happens, then Zagreb would seize the opportunity to drive Serbs from the UN-protected enclaves in Croatia and a bloody new cycle of vengeance and ''ethnic cleansing'' would begin.

In Belgrade, official Serbia has been quiet about the impending threat of intrvention. President Milosevic insists that he is appalled by the shelling of Sarajevo, that Serbia has no territorial designs on Bosnia, and that his country is the victim of an ''international media conspiracy''. But the war that Mr Milosevic and his allies be-

gan a year ago has run out of control and opposition to Mr Milosevic is mounting. All the best-laid Serbian plans are on the brink of disaster. Greater Croatia may yet arise from the ashes of greater Serbia.

As anti-Milosevic sentiments grew, Crown Prince Alexander, the pretender to the throne of Serbia, yesterday addressed more than 60,000 people at an opposition rally in central Belgrade. Blowing kisses to the crowds, he yelled at the top of his voice: ''I am with you.'' Alexander Karadjordjevic, hitherto a British businessman, had returned to Serbia on Saturday as the opposition marshals its forces in a last-ditch effort to secure President Milosevic's resignation. But officials at yesterday's rally admitted disappointment at the turnout.

Crown Prince Alexander who, because of international sanctions, was forced to return via Timisoara in Romania, visited striking Belgrade University students soon after arrival and urged them to keep up their protest against Mr Milosevic ''until the end''. The students gave him a rapturous welcome, chanting in unison: ''We want the king!''

The rally, which was held on Vidovdan, the day on which Serbs commemorate their defeat at the hands of the Ottoman Turks in 1389, was blessed by the country's Orthodox patriarch. The church, a traditional ally of government, has made its opposition to President Milosevic's government explicit, and yesterday the patriarch appealed for Serbs to resolve their differences without resort to civil war.

The demonstration was organised by a new coalition, the Democratic Movement for Serbia, but the most important speaker was Vuk Draskovic, leader of the main opposition party. He called on the army and police to ''join the Serbian people'' and appealed to Mr Milosevic to go, saying that, if he did not, ''Serbia will be a corpse; people will pick at us''. Mr Draskovic said that a resolution of the present troubles could be found only if all Serbia's political movements thrashed out the foundations of a transitional coalition government through round-table talks.

The country is rapidly waking up to the fact that fresh trainloads of Serbian refugees will soon be coming from Croatia and Bosnia. It is also clear that, having bequeathed the Bosnian Serbs vast amounts of weaponry from the former federal army, they are now no longer at the beck and call of the Serbian president. Faced with military defeat, they will continue to fight rather than lay down their arms to save Mr Milosevic or to have sanctions lifted from Serbia.

Even if Mr Milosevic bows to the protests, his immediate departure would no longer be enough for Serbs to extricate themselves successfully from the present predicament. A new Serbo-Croat war cannot be excluded. War in the south in Kosovo is also on the agenda. Having brutally repressed the autonomy previously granted to the two million Albanians who live in the province, no peaceful accommodation with Serbia is possible; but not even the most liberal Serbian opposition politicians can contemplate conceding Kosovo's independence or union with Albania.

Mr Milosevic's options are diminishing. Allies are deserting him and he has begun to resort to eccentric suggestions such as confederation with Greece.


LOAD-DATE: June 30, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Newspapers Limited


73 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 20, 1999, Friday, Final Edition


150,000 Serbs Rally Against Milosevic; Opposition in Belgrade Calls for Yugoslav President to Quit


William Branigin, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1122 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Aug. 19


 

In a massive outpouring of opposition sentiment, more than 150,000 Serbs took to the streets of this capital tonight to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic and call for democratic change in Yugoslavia.

Ignoring last-minute political maneuvers by the government and veiled warnings of violence aimed at limiting attendance, the crowd clogged a vast area in front of the Yugoslav federal parliament building, waved opposition party flags and chanted slogans against Milosevic.

The rally, the largest anti-Milosevic demonstration in Belgrade since a series of protests against alleged election fraud in late 1996 and early 1997, went ahead peacefully despite some tense moments shortly after it started when a tear-gas grenade exploded in the crowd and briefly scattered protesters. They quickly regrouped, however, and there were no further incidents or reports of injuries. 

Under a half moon on a clear, warm night, speaker after speaker called for the resignation of Milosevic, who has held power here for the past decade, first as president of Serbia and since 1997 as president of the Yugoslav federation. Serbia is the dominant republic in the federation, which also includes Montenegro.

Among the speakers was Vuk Draskovic, the mercurial leader of the largest opposition party, who had had a change of heart after earlier canceling his speech in a dispute over the appearance of a rival politician.

The demonstration was widely anticipated here as a barometer of the public's attitude toward Milosevic in the aftermath of his disastrous policy in Serbia's southern province of Kosovo, which led to a 78-day NATO bombing campaign, the withdrawal of Serbian forces and the deployment of a NATO-led peacekeeping force.

Although the crowd exceeded organizers' expectations, it was unclear where the protest movement will go from here. The opposition remains fragmented, and Milosevic has survived previous attempts to force him out.

In their speeches tonight, opposition leaders vowed to keep pressuring Milosevic to step down.

"The people are getting ahead of their leaders," said accountant Radisa Lejic, 45, referring to opposition politicians whose squabbling had threatened to reduce the turnout. "This is the last minute for something to be done, and if we don't do it, then who else can?"

The government-controlled television network, however, called the rally "a failure in every sense." It said the event was ordered by the opposition's "NATO bosses" and that Draskovic had shown up "to fulfill a promise" to Robert S. Gelbard, the State Department official who oversees U.S. Balkans policy.

"Slobo odlazi," literally "Slobo go away," the crowd frequently chanted, holding up a three-finger gesture of Serbian patriotism based on the Holy Trinity of the Serbian Orthodox Church.

"Red bandits!" yelled angry demonstrators after the tear gas exploded, a reference to the communist origins of Milosevic's ruling Socialist Party.

"We want to go back to Europe, where we were before communism and neo-communism," said Bishop Artemije, an influential Serbian Orthodox cleric representing Kosovo, in a message read for him from the stage.

In another message to the crowd, Aleksandar Karadjordjevic, the London-based crown prince of Yugoslavia, urged opposition parties to stay out of any coalition with Milosevic, adding that "the salvation of Serbia depends on this moment." Royalist supporters lit Roman candles and sang the Serbian royal anthem.

"Milosevic, look at this square," said Zoran Djindjic, a leader of the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition parties. "This is where your citizens are. These are citizens who don't want you. Go away before we remove you."

If Milosevic does not resign in 15 days, he said, demonstrations will be held across Serbia until he does. "Now it's us or them," Djindjic said. "It's Milosevic or Serbia. There is no third way."

Draskovic, who heads the Serbian Renewal Movement, sounded a more conciliatory note. He criticized other opposition leaders' demands for a transitional government, saying that "we cannot make a government in the streets," and he called for new elections by the end of November whether Milosevic presides over them or not. He thus appeared to be accepting offers by Milosevic's coalition to hold elections by then in what is seen as an attempt by Milosevic to ease the pressures for his resignation.

Many supporters of other parties booed the bearded firebrand as he delivered his oration, reflecting the ongoing divisions within the anti-Milosevic camp.

Draskovic and other speakers criticized the presence of NATO-led troops in Kosovo, where they said that Serbs who are supposed to be under the force's protection are being kidnapped and killed by ethnic Albanians. Most of Kosovo's prewar Serbian population has fled the province over the past two months.

In an apparent attempt to limit the rally's turnout, authorities canceled a number of buses and trains into Belgrade from Serbian cities and warned that "unknown" perpetrators could try to plant explosives at large public gatherings.

On the eve of the rally, Milosevic's Socialist Party also floated the idea of holding early elections, possibly by November. Spokesmen for the party and its coalition partners said they were "ready" for new elections any time and challenged opposition parties to name a date.

The move appeared to reflect a calculation that the opposition parties may be too deeply divided to win -- and that the situation can only get worse for Milosevic the longer he waits to take action. The government especially dreads the onset of winter, when the country is expected to face a heating crisis because of a shortage of electricity.

Political analysts also see the offer of early elections as a ploy to buy time so Milosevic can further undermine the opposition and defuse pressure on him to resign. Opposition parties are split on conditions for new elections, with some insisting that they should be held only after Milosevic steps down and once changes are made to election and media laws that favor his government.

According to a recent poll by Belgrade's Partner agency, opposition groups have been gaining in popularity, but are still far from receiving majority support. If an election were held today, the poll of 1,000 citizens in 32 municipalities said, Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement would get 18.1 percent of the vote, and the rival Alliance for Change would receive 14.8 percent. The three parties in Milosevic's ruling coalition would get a total of 24 percent, the poll indicated. Nearly 30 percent of those polled were either undecided or would boycott the election.


LOAD-DATE: August 20, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

74 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE AUSTRALIAN


December 30, 1996, Monday


Riot police hold back anti-Milosevic hordes 


SOURCE: Reuters


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 634 words


SERBIA'S opposition movement planned fresh demonstrations yesterday, unbowed by bitter cold, snow and police pressure on the mass marches that have been disrupting the capital, Belgrade, for six weeks.

Twenty thousand people took to the streets in two separate protests on Saturday, one of them tolerated by police but the other swiftly blocked, although without bloodshed that marred protests earlier in the week.

The President, Mr Milosevic, has riot police shunting protesters off the streets, where they had snarled traffic, into pedestrian areas to hold rallies while he considers his response to rising international pressure for democratic reform. 

The turnout on Saturday paled beside peak numbers of more than 200,000 in the daily tide of demonstrations since November 19 against alleged election fraud by Mr Milosevic's long-ruling Socialist Party.

Demonstrators' ranks were no doubt thinned by an onset of snow-blown sub-zero temperatures coupled with police pressure.

But protesters have taken heart from an fact-finding mission by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, a pan-European security forum, that confirmed their complaints of rigging in municipal elections last month and urged Mr Milosevic to restore opposition victories in 15 of Serbia's biggest towns, including Belgrade.

The mission's findings have yet to be adopted by the OSCE, although most of its western members, including the United States, have led international condemnation of Mr Milosevic's refusal to admit his election defeats.

They have also blamed him for the violence on December 24 when the Socialist Party tried to stage a demonstration at the same time and place as Zajedno's daily protests, which previously were peaceful and good-humoured.

The report, which was expected after mission members said they had found blatant examples of election rigging, gave Mr Milosevic an exit route from the crisis.

Diplomats said one of his options was to turn over the disputed towns but quickly order fresh municipal elections to restore Socialist Party rule, now facing its biggest threat in half a century of unbroken power.

But Zajedno could well boycott a new election without free access to the Yugoslav news media.

Mr Milosevic's alternative is to defy the judgment by the OSCE that the opposition won.

The cost of doing this would be increased isolation abroad, at a time when Serbia has been campaigning for much-needed Western economic aid after the formal end of war-related international sanctions, and the risk of the street protests in Belgrade spiralling out of control.

In Belgrade on Saturday 10,000 opposition supporters marched, shouting "Slobo murderer", after the funeral of an activist who died in the riot on Christmas Eve. Thousands turned out for the funeral, also attended by the main leaders of the Together group, Mr Vuk Draskovic, Mr Zoran Djindjic and Ms Vesna Pesic. Police did not interfere.

But police showed less patience with 10,000 students who tried to surge down a major city street after nightfall, swiftly diverting them into a pedestrian mall and trapping them there for an hour before they dispersed.

Mr Draskovic said Predrag Starcevic, 39, was trampled to death in the December 24 violence by a crowd trying to flee a police charge.

Fifty people were injured in a melee between Zajedno and Socialist Party supporters. The Government then banned street marches. Another 29 were hurt on Friday when uniformed and plainclothes police assaulted Zajedno activists, witnesses said.

Mr Draskovic urged protesters on Saturday to shun violence but warned, "There is a line beyond which a man no longer puts up with (State) humiliation and terror. Milosevic is trying to take citizens across that line to provoke bloodshed."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1996 Nationwide News Pty Limited

The Bismarck Tribune


June 4, 1993 Friday


LENGTH: 643 words


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) Ä Serbia's prosecutor general called for a ban on the largest opposition party Thursday, signaling a possible crackdown on President Slobodan Milosevic's political foes. The order against the Serbian Renewal Movement came a day after its leader, Vuk Draskovic, and his wife, Danica, were badly beaten in police custody. They were arrested late Tuesday during a protest in Belgrade that was brutally suppressed by police. Rioting exploded hours after Milosevic's Socialist Party and its extreme nationalist allies in the Radical Party ousted Yugoslav President Dobrica Cosic, a more moderate Serb nationalist, in a no-confidence vote.  

Milosevic's Serbia has helped to fuel the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina as part of his vision of a ""Greater Serbia'' uniting Serbs in the former Yugoslavia. Hard-line nationalists opposed Cosic's efforts to end the war, but Serbia's opposition wants it to end so U.N. sanctions punishing Belgrade for its role in the violence will be lifted. Serbia's constitutional court would have to approve a ban on the party. But the mere threat was held over the opposition movement's head to keep it in check. Draskovic had a broken left arm, facial injuries, was dragging one leg and appeared barely conscious at police headquarters Wednesday, said Cedomir Efendic, a party colleague who was detained with Draskovic and saw him after the beating. The party leadership said in a statement that the Draskovics ""were physically tortured and their lives are in jeopardy.'' Senior party official Veselin Pavicevic appealed to the world to take action against Milosevic's ""fascist'' regime. Draskovic's attorney found the opposition leader and his wife in Belgrade's central jail late Thursday. The attorney, Borivoje Borovic, did not see his clients, but told the Tanjug news agency that the head of the prison had insisted they be examined by doctors. There was no word on Draskovic's condition. Draskovic is expected to go before magistrates today to decide whether he remains in custody, Borovic said. In a statement carried by Tanjug, the prosecutor general's office accused Draskovic's party of inciting Tuesday's unrest and said it should be banned for organizing the protest and anti-Milosevic demonstrations in March 1991 and June 1992. The statement also said the party repeatedly had demanded the violent overthrow of existing authorities. ""The party crudely abused the constitutional freedom of political activity,'' the statement said. Vladimir Gajic, general secretary of Draskovic's party, dismissed the prosecutor's charges as ""ridiculous.'' ""It's an attempt to introduce the crime of mere thought,'' he said. Gajic said the party has demanded the resignation of the government, but not its violent overthrow. He added that the opposition had expected to be banned if further unrest followed Tuesday's riots, in which a police officer was killed and more than 30 people were injured. But leaders did not call for more demonstrations, and a strong police presence kept the streets quiet. Leaders of Serbia's fractured opposition have feared a crackdown since it became clear Monday that Milosevic, who had recently adopted a more moderate stance, had allied with extreme nationalists who threaten his power. In unusually direct criticism, Russia's Foreign Ministry said Thursday that the removal of Cosic and the crackdown on demonstrators ""worry us as evidence of mounting tension within the country, and of the development of anti-democratic trends.'' But the fact that Draskovic, the best-known Serbian opposition leader and a recent guest of President Clinton, could be detained and severely beaten seemed intended to underline the authorities' power to act as they please. The reliable Borba daily said dozens of the 121 people arrested during the protest were given 60-day jail terms Wednesday.

76 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


SEPTEMBER 27, 1999 Monday SF EDITION


ANTI-MILOSEVIC PROTEST HEATS UP IN BELGRADE UP TO 50,000 MARCHED YESTERDAY. ORGANIZERS SAY THE FLAGGING MOVEMENT IS REGAINING STRENGTH.


BYLINE: Branimir Pipal, REUTERS


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A03


LENGTH: 439 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


Up to 50,000 people took to the streets of Belgrade yesterday as protests demanding the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic seemed to gather strength.

On the sixth day of antigovernment demonstrations, the protesters marched through the capital chanting "Slobo Go" and "Red Bandits" as they passed government buildings.

About 40,000 demonstrators also rallied Saturday evening in Belgrade. 

The growing number of protesters over the weekend injected new life into a campaign that had seemed in danger of running out of steam after a slow start last week.

"More and more people are coming," said opposition leader Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party. "We hope the trend will continue," he told Radio Index.

The opposition group Alliance for Change launched the rallies in towns across Serbia, the dominant Yugoslav republic, on Tuesday. The organization has vowed to continue with the daily demonstrations as long as necessary.

Protesters blame Milosevic for Serbia's growing economic hardships and isolation after a decade of Balkan bloodshed, including NATO's 11-week air war against Yugoslavia to stop Belgrade's repression of ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo.

Even though the weekend rallies attracted bigger crowds than those of previous days, the turnout still only represented a fraction of Belgrade's population of two million. And antigovernment rallies elsewhere in the politically isolated Balkan republic were much smaller.

But opposition activists were increasingly upbeat, saying they were on the right track. "This has clearly gained momentum," Alliance coordinator Vladan Batic said.

Drawing parallels with successful street protests in 1996, which only gradually gained momentum to peak at more than 200,000 in Belgrade, activists hope that the new drive will develop in a similar way.

Djindjic has set a target of two million protesters across Serbia, saying this would show that people want change.

The Alliance for Change, representing one wing of the divided opposition, wants Milosevic to resign and the establishment of a transitional government, followed by free elections.

Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, who helped organize big crowds during 88 days of protests in 1996-97, has refused to take part.

Police have kept a low profile, but government officials have ridiculed and condemned the protests, branding opposition leaders as "traitors" and "NATO lackeys."

The Tanjug state news agency, in a commentary, described the street protests as a "total fiasco" and dismissed the Alliance for Change as an instrument of the West.

The New York Times


November 16, 2001 Friday  
Late Edition - Final


World Briefing Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic's Son Charged


BYLINE: Reuters


SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Foreign Desk; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 83 words


The son of former President Slobodan Milosevic was charged with threatening to cut up a political opponent with a power saw.  

The indictment against Marko Milosevic said that in March 2000 he and six associates ordered Zoran Milovanovic to identify the leaders of the anti-Milosevic Otpor student movement and that Mr. Milosevic then switched on the saw and made his threat. He fled the country after his father was ousted and has been reported to be in Russia or another former Soviet republic.

78 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


August 5, 1999 Thursday


Church throws weight behind Serb opposition Orthodox clerics to sponsor anti-Milosevic rally amid calls for political co-operation


BYLINE: COLIN McINTYRE Reuters News Agency; REUT


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A16


LENGTH: 572 words


DATELINE: Belgrade


Serbia's influential Orthodox Church has emerged as a key player in the growing movement to topple President Slobodan Milosevic as it seeks to unite the country's divided political opposition.

The church, which until recently had largely remained outside politics, is sponsoring a rally in Belgrade this month that organizers hope will bring out the masses and haul feuding opposition leaders together under one banner.

To ensure that party rivalry is kept to a minimum, the G17 group of independent economists behind the Aug. 19 protest is urging participants to leave party emblems at home and to bring Serbian flags if they want to wave something. 

By putting the rally under the umbrella of the Orthodox Church, G17's energetic 35-year-old co-ordinator, Mladjan Dinkic, has overcome the rivalry of the two main opposition leaders. Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party and Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Party (SPO) have each refused to support any initiative organized by the other.

According to opposition officials, both leaders have promised to attend the rally in front of the Yugoslav parliament. It would be the first antigovernment demonstration in the capital since the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's 11-week bombardment of Yugoslavia, although protests have been going on elsewhere for the past month.

Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Djindjic, whose party is part of the Alliance for Change umbrella group, worked together three years ago during weeks of student and opposition protests over election fraud. The demonstrations rocked Mr. Milosevic's regime to its core.

But relations between the two plunged when Mr. Draskovic stood in 1997 general elections boycotted by the Alliance for Change, and eventually joined the government, although he was sacked in January for appearing to question its Kosovo policies.

The Orthodox Church began emerging in the political arena last year when the spiritual leader of the ethnic Serb minority in Kosovo, Bishop Artemije, joined moderate Serbs in condemning the repression of ethnic Albanians by Serb forces.

"Kosovo was lost in February last year when Milosevic's regime started solving the Kosovo problem by force. That's when we lost Kosovo," Bishop Artemije told a recent rally in the town of Valjevo.

In an unprecedented move, the church's Holy Synod came out in June with a call for Mr. Milosevic and his regime to step down, and for a national unity government to replace it.

Work on creating such a government of experts, which would rule for a year to prepare free elections and economic reforms, has been going on for some time by the anonymous but influential G17 group of economists, politicians, church leaders and intellectuals.

But while nobody questions the good intentions of those involved in the project, the problem remains that until Mr. Milosevic steps down (and he shows no sign of doing that) or they find a constitutional way to remove him, their plan is just a piece of paper.

"They are putting the cart before the horse," one local analyst said. "The big question is not a transitional government, it is getting rid of Milosevic."

While the Aug. 19 rally could bring out a huge crowd that would increase the pressure on Mr. Milosevic, analysts doubt whether it could achieve the "critical mass" that might persuade the embattled leader to quit.

"The only thing the regime is really afraid of is desperately hungry people coming onto the streets," one analyst said.


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1999 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved


79 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


Serb opposition parties unite to oust Milosevic


SECTION: News; B8


LENGTH: 277 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


Serbia's fractious medley of opposition parties agreed to leave their differences behind yesterday and join a united front aimed at ousting Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic from power, one party leader reported after a six-hour political meeting.

''All the participants except Momcilo Perisic signed the agreement,'' said Vladan Batic, a co-ordinator of the Alliance for Change coalition, one of the two key partners in the newly unified opposition. 

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the country's main opposition force, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), had called the talks with a plea for squabbling to end among Serbia's many anti-Milosevic factions.

Fourteen of the country's 15 opposition parties agreed to adopt the joint strategy, Batic reported, with Perisic - a former Yugoslav army chief-of-staff - standing out as the only dissident.

Draskovic said ''we are all satisfied'' with the outcome.

They approved documents aimed at concentrating opposition efforts on forcing Milosevic to call early national and regional elections by April, which they hope he will lose.

A joint call was also to be made to the European Union and the United States to lift sanctions against Yugoslavia if Milosevic agrees to the election demands, and to respect UN resolutions on Kosovo.

Parties represented in the meeting included Kosovo Serbs, Momcilo Trajkovic and Bishop Artemije, who opposed Milosevic's policy in the strife- torn southern province. Also present were representatives of Serbia's Muslim and ethnic Hungarian minorities.

''If the opposition does not agree now it will show it is not ready to take over power,'' Trajkovic said.

The Globe and Mail (Canada)


November 16, 2001 Friday  
National Edition


Son of Milosevic faces charges over chainsaw


BYLINE: Reuters News Agency


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A15


LENGTH: 297 words


DATELINE: POZAREVAC, YUGOSLAVIA


The son of ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic was charged yesterday with threatening to hack up a resistance activist with a chainsaw and throw the parts into a river.  

The indictment, the first official charges issued against the unpopular Marko Milosevic, said he and six associates ordered Zoran Milovanovic to identify the leaders and publishers of the Otpor anti-Milosevic student movement in March, 2000.

Marko Milosevic switched on the saw and "threatened to cut him up and throw him into the Morava River," says the indictment by the Pozarevac district public prosecutor.

Once described by the United States as one of the richest and most violent members of the Serbian mafia, Marko Milosevic fled the country on a false passport after an uprising ousted his father last year.

Known for his bleached haircut and flashy lifestyle, the former race driver has since been reported to be hiding out in Russia or in another former Soviet republic.

His father is awaiting trial in The Hague on war-crimes charges.

Marko Milosevic ran a business empire in Pozarevac.

His holdings included an amusement park called Bambiland and the Madona nightclub.

His many critics in Serbia say Marko Milosevic was involved in shady and lucrative cigarette and oil dealings during his father's turbulent rule, allegations he has denied.

Accusations have flown between his associates and activists.

At one stage, protesters who complained that they had been assaulted found themselves accused of attempted murder, prompting large demonstrations.

Criminal charges have been filed before against Marko Milosevic over separate incidents.

This, however, was the first official indictment.

Given his uncertain whereabouts, it is not clear how the authorities will proceed with the case.

81 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


April 15, 2000


Opposition leaders unite for major anti-Milosevic rally


BYLINE: By GILLIAN SANDFORD


SECTION: CITY EDITION; WORLD NEWS; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 553 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


More than 100,000 demonstrators filled Republic Square in central Belgrade yesterday in a major rally against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

It was the first protest by all parties in the Serbian opposition to take place in the capital since August last year and a crucial litmus test of support.

The high turnout will be a major boost to the beleaguered opposition leaders. Analysts have long said that because Belgrade is the intellectual and political centre of the country, it must provide the impetus for change. 

The rally saw the leader of the Democratic Party, Mr Zoran Djindjic, and his long-time rival, Mr Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, sharing a stage together and calling for free and fair elections in Yugoslavia at all levels: local, republic and federal.

"The regime are the traitors," said Mr Draskovic. "They have betrayed everyone. They have made one million citizens beggars.

"Our flag is not in Kosovo any more," he said. After the rally, Mr Slobodan Vuksanovic, a key official of the Democratic Party, said: "The atmosphere was terrific. There was a very good turnout and we can say it was very successful. It was just one more proof that people are strongly supporting change and want the opposition to be the tool by which change is brought about."

Sixteen leaders of different opposition parties spoke during the rally, which lasted for more than three hours.

"It is very important that so many people are here. It's a message to the opposition leaders that they have to stop their eternal bickering," said one doctor who attended.

"The number of people is absolutely terrific. The result is that probably people will have more optimism and faith in democratic forces here. But this has to be just the first of many rallies," said Mr Velko Popovic, a journalist and member of the Social Democratic Youth.

Police kept a low profile during the rally. A helicopter hovered overhead for a while and small groups of police stood some distance away, but offered no provocation.

Youths from the students' resistance organisation, Otpor, had walked to the rally, starting the previous day from the northern city of Novi Sad.

Protesters blocked key roads in the centre of the capital for the rally in which youngsters waved flags of support from the main opposition parties and shouted: "Red Gang, Red Gang" - an anti-communist slogan.

The state-controlled television Politika was running a major movie marathon, showing films such as American Beauty. Many interpreted this as an attempt to keep people at home.

Journalists from Spain attempting to enter the country the day before the rally were held at Belgrade airport and not allowed entry, despite having valid papers.

Four Japanese, one Canadian, a German and two American journalists were also reported by an independent radio station to have been refused entry. Local radio reported that a number of opposition supporters who were coming to the capital by coach had been stopped by police who insisted on carrying out technical inspections of their vehicles, in an effort to delay them.

The only non-government television station, Studio B, which sought to carry the rally, was subject to heavy jamming and lost transmission totally when its transmitter suffered an unexpected power failure.


LOAD-DATE: April 15, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times


82 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


December 30, 1996, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Military officials may be joining anti-Milosevic side


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A


LENGTH: 442 words


Thousands of anti-government demonstrators in Belgrade, Yugoslavia,
defied a police ban Sunday amid signs that military officials
were joining the protest movement against President Slobodan Milosevic.
Protesters have gathered daily in Belgrade since Milosevic overturned
the results of municipal elections won Nov. 17 by the opposition.

An open letter from military officials in six towns in southern
and southeastern Serbia was read to the Belgrade demonstrators. 
The authenticity of the military letter could not be confirmed.
But the army, a traditional bastion of support for Milosevic,
has not issued any denials.

The letter said Milosevic was responsible for the wars in Croatia
and Bosnia and the humiliation of Yugoslav troops. Milosevic sent
the army to back Serb rebellions in the former Yugoslav republics.
After four years of war, Serbs failed in their goal of uniting
all Serb-held lands.

HEBRON TALKS: Within days of an expected deal on a partial
Israeli withdrawal from Hebron, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu said 450 Jewish settlers living among 130,000 Palestinians
would remain forever in the West Bank town under Israeli control.
"We are there, and we are there to stay forever, for all time,"
he said.

Amid the tough public talk, a final accord wasn't expected until
the return today of U.S. Mideast envoy Dennis Ross.

Hebron is the last of seven occupied West Bank cities Israel agreed
to give self-rule to under an agreement signed in 1995. The Palestinians
took over much of the Gaza Strip in 1994. -- Judith Colp Rubin
in Tel Aviv, Israel

PERU HOSTAGES: Leftist Tupac Amaru rebels appeared to soften
their demands in a hostage situation about to enter its third
week. The leftist guerrillas, holding 83 captives in the Lima,
Peru, residence of the Japanese ambassador, have stopped making
their key demand that hundreds of fellow rebels be freed from
prison. And they haven't repeated threats to execute hostages.
The rebels released 20 hostages Saturday, after Fujimori sent
a Cabinet minister to initiate direct talks with the rebels despite
his policy of not negotiating with terrorists.

CHECHNYA DEAL: The last Russian combat unit withdrew from
Chechnya under a peace deal between Moscow and separatist leaders,
Russia's Itar-Tass news agency said. Under the Aug. 31 accord,
Moscow promised to withdraw its forces, sent to Chechnya in 1994
to quell the southern region's independence bid. The rebels agreed
to postpone for five years a decision on Chechnya's political
status. But they've made little secret that they still want independence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

83 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


October 1, 1999, Friday


RIOT POLICE BREAK UP PROTESTS IN BELGRADE


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 16


LENGTH: 564 words


 

POLICE IN the Yugoslavian capital Belgrade last night continued with a second wave of crackdowns against anti President Milosevic protesters, widening their raids to include the offices of an outspoken independent newspaper.

Last night, as protesters took the streets for the 10th day in a row, police waded in with batons and arrested 21 demonstrators. Early this morning, police sealed off the offices of the Glas Javnosti newspaper and banned it for 15 days. They then sealed off the headquarters of the anti-Milosevic alliance. 

The latest moves followed Wednesday night's clashes. In front of the Nato -bombed government buildings in Milosa Velikog Street thousands of demonstrators ran into cordons of hundreds of police, who brutally halted an opposition march heading towards the villa of President Milosevic.

The police, in full riot gear, beat up 20 protesters, scattering the demonstration, and arrested 13 opposition activists during the night. It was the first police intervention in nine days of peaceful marches organised by the opposition grouping, the Alliance for Change.

Milan St Protic, a leader of the alliance, suggested that the police aggression showed that "Milosevic is nervous". Senior members of the alliance vowed to continue staging regular peaceful protests and to avoid violence at all costs.

The marches, by tens of thousands of protesters, have been small compared with the mass anti-Milosevic demonstrations of 1996 and 1997. In the earlier unrest, the police - considered to be the President's "Praetorian guard" - waited for weeks before using force against protesters. It remains a mystery why the police went to such lengths to stop the marchers this week when they were more than a mile away from Mr Milosevic's official residence at Dedinje. It is common knowledge here that he has not lived there since it was wrecked by Nato missiles in April. Many doubt that he lives in Belgrade at all.

Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, the biggest opposition party, which has stayed away from the protests so far, strongly condemned the police violence saying the use of force showed that the regime was "virtually demanding a bloodbath in Serbia".

For months now, a public debate has been continuing over whether the crisis in Serbia will descend into civil war, or even end in the violent overthrow of President Milosevic, similar to the downfall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania a decade ago.

One side believes that Mr Milosevic will not hesitate to use force to quell the protests and stay in power, causing inevitable bloodshed.

Others say that growing poverty, combined with deep animosity towards the Yugoslavian leader and his powerful wife, Mira Markovic, could lead to events similar to those in Romania in 1989. There is agreement that Mr Milosevic is not ready to go willingly.

Meanwhile, the leaders of about 18 opposition parties held their first round -table talks aimed at agreeing conditions for any future elections in Serbia. The Serbian official media described Wednesday's violence as an attack by "a group of hooligans; sympathisers of the alliance for Nato" against the police, who were carrying out their "regular duties". The Interior Ministry issued a statement saying that "among the perpetrators were known criminals, drug addicts and hooligans who make trouble at sports events".


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: A woman trying to stop her husband being beaten by police at a rally in Belgrade by demonstrators opposed to President Milosevic AP


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


84 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


October 1, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Milosevic's Worst Nightmare


BYLINE: By Timothy Garton Ash; Timothy Garton Ash, a fellow at St. Antony's College, Oxford, and at the Hoover Institution, is author of the forthcoming "History of the Present."


SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk


LENGTH: 896 words


DATELINE: OXFORD, England


Vojislav Kostunica is one of the gloomiest men I know. This may be an advantage for a new president of whatever remains of Yugoslavia.

Even if the miracle happens and Slobodan Milosevic, who is denying that Mr. Kostunica won an absolute majority in the presidential election and insisting on a runoff, goes without bloodshed, gloom will still be in order. A new federal republic of Yugoslavia will have a ruined economy, like Romania after 1989; a burden of guilt, like Germany after 1945; ubiquitous corruption, like Russia today; and still unresolved ethnic-territorial issues, like, well, old Yugoslavia. 

Who is the man upon whom such a heavy burden may fall, if he becomes president? Large, gray-suited, quiet-spoken, painstakingly analytical, Mr. Kostunica talks more like an academic than a politician. Indeed, until 10 years ago, he was just that -- a constitutional lawyer and a political scientist. Now 56, he has been an active party politician only since 1989, when non-Communist party politics became possible.

The first time we met, in 1997, during the last great anti-Milosevic demonstrations, he took me to an old-fashioned restaurant in central Belgrade and told me he really believed in the original Yugoslavia -- that is, the Serb-dominated unitary kingdom that existed between the two world wars. (His father was an officer in its royal army.) It was, he said, or at least should have been, an exercise in nation-building under a British-style constitutional monarchy. Look how the king had given his first son a Serbian name, his second a Croatian name and his third a Slovenian one -- rather as British monarchs deliberately called their heir the Prince of Wales. Croats, Slovenes and Bosnians would find that a rose-tinted view of the past.

But for today, he explained at great length, a new Yugoslavia needed what he called asymmetric federalism -- with different rights and powers for the different component parts -- as a solution for Kosovo, Montenegro and Vojvodina, and perhaps also for the Serb republic in Bosnia.

Vojislav Kostunica is a very serious man. Solid. Consistent. Knowledgeable and capable of sophisticated rational argument. Principled, too. But hardly a bundle of fun. Short on charisma.

Nor is he a great believer in the politics of the street. During the 1997 protests, he told me that he was wary of the demonstrators' cult of spontaneity, their belief in "the movement" as an end in itself. Yet his own future, and with it that of all southeastern Europe, now depends on his ability to lead a peaceful, inventive, effective movement of mass protest and civil disobedience.

In late 1998, we met in the spartan office of his tiny opposition party, the Democratic Party of Serbia. His talk was all of Kosovo and how its future inside Serbia must be secured by constitutional, peaceful means. Ordinary, decent Serbians would be dismayed at what Mr. Milosevic was doing there, he said. In an election held under international supervision, Mr. Milosevic could be defeated. Fat chance, I thought.

A year later, after the war and the NATO bombing, which he criticized fiercely, the office seemed even more spartan and bare. This time, he was furious with the United States and Britain. TonyBlair! Robin Cook! He spat out the names of the British prime minister and foreign minister with contempt. "But," he added, "I know they are not the West." The West was also Henry Kissinger, whom he took to be a critic of the Kosovo war, and Noam Chomsky and Harold Pinter.

So is Mr. Kostunica a "moderate nationalist," as some newspapers are calling him? What exactly is a moderate nationalist? Some old Yugoslav hands, shocked by his strong support for the Bosnian and Kosovo Serbs, say he's as bad as Slobodan Milosevic. Some even say he's more deeply nationalist than Mr. Milosevic, the post-Communist opportunist.

This is both true and completely false. It's true that Mr. Kostunica has been more seriously and consistently concerned about the fate of the Serbian nation than Mr. Milosevic. In other, happier places and times he would be a conservative, romantic patriot of the kind frequently encountered in the British Conservative Party (and they have some pretty rose-tinted views of the national past, too). In this unhappy place and time, he has said and done things he should regret: being photographed holding an automatic weapon among Kosovo Serbs, for example, whatever his explanation for the incident is.

But I have no doubt that he is genuinely moderate -- and what matters is his moderation. It is not just that he is supported by a coalition of democrats who are less nationalist than he is. He is himself, in his style and intellectual formation, profoundly committed to using civilized, peaceful, constitutional means. And one lesson of Europe's terrible 20th century is that the means you embrace are quite as important as the ends. Perhaps more important.

This is a man who is passionate about the rule of law. Who believes in elections, institutions, negotiations. And he sees that the only future for his country lies in a return to Europe.

Whether Mr. Kostunica gets a chance to show if he has it in him to become a popular leader of a peaceful, negotiated revolution, we shall see. But human beings can grow with a great challenge. History makes the most unlikely heroes. He may yet be one.  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Op-Ed


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


85 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


September 14, 2000


Leading article: A result tailored to order: Milosevic prepares to defraud the voters


SECTION: Guardian Leader Pages, Pg. 23


LENGTH: 411 words


 

A flurry of high-level meetings this week in New York, Washington and Zagreb has served to underscore the west's impotence in the face of mounting evidence that Slobodan Milosevic will perpetrate a massive fraud in Yugoslavia's September 24 presidential election. US officials said that Mr Milosevic was making "substantial preparations" to rig the poll. The EU admitted it was "worried". Speakers at the Balkan stability pact summit in Croatia, warning that the stakes could not be higher, urged Serbs to "vote wisely". But they all know the truth in this context of Stalin's remark, recycled by the EU's Chris Patten, that "it's not who votes that matters, it's who counts". And while the diplomats deliberately toned down their remarks for fear of inflaming Serb nationalist opinion, they also know that if Mr Milosevic succeeds in his fraud and suppresses any resulting domestic protests with his usual ruthless efficiency, there is precious little Nato's political masters can or will do about it. 

It is not all gloom. Opinion polls currently suggest a victory (in a fair fight) for the leading anti-Milosevic candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, behind whom most opposition parties have coalesced. Resistance groups like Otpor, the student movement, would-be election monitors like the non-governmental Centre for Free Elections, human rights advocates like Natasa Kandic, and independent media bravely lead the way in defying state and judicial persecution, police torture and worse. "He's finished!" has become the rallying slogan for those who would be rid of this appalling man. But in his first campaign appearance, in Djerdap on Tuesday, Mr Milosevic made brutally plain what he thought of them. The nation's choice was between "heroes and traitors" in Nato's pay.

Among the "heroic" steps Mr Milosevic has in store are said to be up to 1m ghost votes, a modern version of Gogol's dead souls, which will supposedly be cast for him in Montenegro (despite an official poll boycott) and Kosovo; forged ballots, personation, and doctored electoral rolls; no independent verification; media censorship and blanket propaganda; and the intimidation of state employees, pensioners and public housing tenants. And if he still looks like losing, he may yet manufacture a military crisis with Montenegro's pro-western leadership. All this the west, lacking a firm, coherent Balkan strategy, is powerless to prevent. Better have some more meetings.


LOAD-DATE: September 14, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


86 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


May 27, 2000, Saturday


STUDENTS TAKE TO THE STREETS IN PROTEST AT LATEST SERB CRACKDOWN


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 16


LENGTH: 506 words


 

THOUSANDS OF Serbian students took to the streets yesterday to protest at a government crackdown on universities in an attempt to stave off a campus revolt.

The Serbian Education Minister, fearing mounting anti-Milosevic discontent might foment student unrest when the opposition is stepping up protests in major cities, had banned all gatherings at universities. The order served notice that the summer term was to end immediately, a week early, and students would be allowed to enter universities only to sit their exams. 

Various student associations have threatened to call for a general university strike in line with civil disobedience plans of several opposition parties campaigning for an end to the rule of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic. As thousands flooded to the main square in front of a university building yesterday, busloads of riot police drove up and parked in nearby streets.

The students spelled out their list of demands, including one to the authorities to enable a "peaceful transition of power". They asked all those "responsible for Serbia's demise to leave". The students also called on all citizens to start non-violent resistance, and urged the opposition to "by personal example, give impetus to a wide national rebellion against state terrorism".

The government has accused the broadly popular student movement Otpor (Resistance), which was joined last week by prominent university professors and personalities, of terrorism, fascism and betraying the national interest.

Milosevic supporters say Otpor is linked with Nato countries involved in the 11-week bombing campaign against Serbia last year. Every day, 20 to 40 Otpor members of all ages from across Serbia are taken in for questioning, an Otpor source told The Independent.

Last Tuesday, masked men attacked Belgrade University students on a sit- in protest at a city-centre building. Security guards of an unknown origin were posted yesterday at university buildings, checking that only registered students were entering. It was impossible to establish whether they were police or security firms linked to the regime. "This is the end of the autonomy of the university as we knew it," said Marija Bogdanovic, former dean of Belgrade School of Philosophy.The Serbian opposition plans another anti-Milosevic rally this afternoon, following last week's closure of the popular independent Studio B radio and TV. But the opposition is being increasingly criticised for its perceived mild approach to Mr Milosevic.

For days, rumours were circulating in Belgrade that Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the main opposition Serbian Renewal Party (SPO), had been in contact with Mr Milosevic's socialists, seeking a deal.

The SPO runs Belgrade at the local level and controlled the now-silenced Studio B. Mr Draskovic's adviser, Ognjen Pribicevic, was forced to publicly denounce the rumours.

Without mentioning Mr Draskovic by name, smaller opposition parties criticised what they called his "moderate approach".


LOAD-DATE: May 30, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Independent Print Ltd

Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


July 26, 1999, Monday


ARMY URGED TO BACK PEOPLE


SOURCE: QNP


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 131 words


Army urged to back people

NIS, Yugoslavia: Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic yesterday warned the armed forces not to interfere in the country's political affairs, as 25,000 people in Serbia's third largest city called on President Slobodan Milosevic to step down. 

"These days, generals warn that the army and the police will defend the regime with all their power," Mr Draskovic told more than 25,000 protesters.

"Generals have nothing to do in internal political discussions."

His statement came after General Nebojsa Pavkovic, commander of Yugoslavia's Third Army, issued a stern warning to anti-Milosevic movements.

Gen Pavkovic said the President had the army's "unreserved support" and would prevent any attempt to overthrow his regime.

Agence France-Presse

JOURNAL-CODE: CML

88 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


April 2, 1999, Friday


LETTER: SERBIA'S OBSESSION


BYLINE: Asad Yawar


SECTION: COMMENT; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 281 words


 

Sir: The assertion by many "democratic" Serbians that there will be no real peace and stability in the region unless Serbia embarks on the road to democracy is, unfortunately, specious.

In Serbia's free, multi-party and largely fair elections of 1990, the two main Serbian nationalist parties (of which Milosevic's SPS was one) polled 63 per cent of the vote; two years later, at the height of the war in Bosnia, where Serbian forces had displaced over two million Muslims and Croats in under six months - and went on to kill at least 200,000 Bosnians - Milosevic polled 56 per cent in Serbia's presidential election, hardly the record of a dictator. 

The sad truth is that no candidate who espoused the admirable values of democracy and a liberalised economy came close to capturing the Serbian public's imagination. That is why, even during the anti-Milosevic demonstrations of 1996 and 1997, the person presented by Serbia's "democrats" as the answer to their country's problems was the ultra-nationalist Vuk Draskovic; members of his Serbian Renewal Movement were actively involved in atrocities in both Croatia and Bosnia, and Draskovic himself now serves in Milosevic's government as Deputy Prime Minister.

Serbia's political culture has been built on what the independent Serbian journalist Stojan Cerovic called "the constant, obsessive theme of building a Greater Serbia". This involves "purifying" Serbia by "cleansing" it of non -Orthodox people and "extending" Serbia so that it mirrors the nationalist ideal of encompassing Bosnia, Croatia, Kosovo and the Sandzak, something which can only be accomplished by genocide.

ASAD YAWAR

Wembley, Middlesex


LOAD-DATE: April 6, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


89 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


November 16, 2001 Friday Final EDITION


Milosevic son charged over power saw threat: U.S. described him as violent mobster


SOURCE: Reuters


SECTION: NEWS, Pg. D20


LENGTH: 316 words


DATELINE: POZAREVAC, Yugoslavia


POZAREVAC, Yugoslavia, -- The son of ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic was charged yesterday with threatening to hack up a resistance activist with a power saw and throw the parts into a river.

The indictment, the first official charges issued against the unpopular Marko Milosevic, said he and six associates ordered Zoran Milovanovic to identify the leaders and publishers of the "Otpor" anti-Milosevic student movement in March 2000. 

"(Marko) switched on the power saw and threatened to cut him up and throw him into the Morava River," the indictment by the Pozarevac District Public Prosecutor said.

Once described by the United States as one of the richest and most violent members of the Serbian mafia, Marko Milosevic fled the country on a false passport after a mass uprising ousted his father last year.

Renowned for his bleached haircut and flashy lifestyle, the former racing car driver has since been reported to be hiding out in Russia or another former Soviet republic. His father is awaiting trial in The Hague on war crimes charges.

Marko Milosevic ran a small business empire in Pozarevac, which his parents see as their hometown, including an amusement park called "Bambiland" and the "Madona" nightclub.

His many critics in Serbia say Marko Milosevic was involved in lucrative and shady cigarette and oil dealings during his father's turbulent rule, allegations he has denied.

Accusations have flown to and fro between his associates and activists with whom they clashed. At one stage, protesters who complained they had been assaulted found themselves accused of attempted murder, prompting large demonstrations.

Criminal charges have been filed against Marko Milosevic before over separate incidents, but this was the first official indictment. Given his uncertain location, it was not clear how the authorities would proceed with the case.
