90 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


June 6, 2005


Young democracy guerrillas join forces: From Belgrade to Baku, activists gather to swap notes on how to topple dictators


BYLINE: Ian Traynor in Tirana


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages, Pg. 16


LENGTH: 1195 words


 

Razi Nurullayev was seized by the Azerbaijani police three weeks ago near his home in Baku, dragged away and jailed for five days for being a democratic nuisance. A week earlier, on a main street in Minsk, Yauhen Afnagel and 100 other young Belarus democracy guerrillas staged a political stunt. They demonstrated for half an hour, holding pictures of a "disappeared" opposition politician and then ran for cover before President Alexander Lukashenko's police could arrest them.

In Uzbekistan, meanwhile, a few dozen Tashkent students switched their lights off together in a synchronised show of defiance last week - a small gesture of protest, but risky and daring given the murderous regime of President Islam Karimov; and perhaps the start of something bigger. 

The activists involved in all three incidents linked up in Albania yesterday to form a transnational network of young democracy fighters - a student international aimed at toppling dictators.

Rotten regimes

Mr Nurullayev, Mr Afnagel and one of the Uzbek student organisers who cannot be named for their own security were among hundreds of young revolutionaries who gathered in Tirana at the weekend to celebrate the downfall of several rotten regimes and plot the overthrow of current dictatorships.

"This is the first time something like this has happened - it's great," said Ivan Marovic from Belgrade, a veteran of the Serbian Otpor youth movement that helped bring down Slobodan Milosevic five years ago.

The activists danced, drank and then got up in the morning for earnest arguments about "knowledge proliferation", "flash mobs", Foucault, the value of logos and corporate branding, political marketing, the meaning of politics and how to maximise subversive impact.

"We mocked the power as much as possible," said Alina Shpak from Kiev, explaining her Pora movement's triumph in unseating the old Kuchma regime in last winter's Orange Revolution. "You can't be afraid of someone you're laughing at."

From the Chinese frontier to the borders of the EU, the vast post-Soviet space has been in the grip of revolutionary fervour over the past few years - a second wave of democratisation after the 1989-91 revolutions symbolised by the fall of the Berlin Wall.

Young veterans and strategists of the Orange, Rose and Cedar revolutions in Ukraine, Georgia and Lebanon, as well as of the anti-Milosevic uprising, were joined in Tirana by Albanian youngsters organised to fight everything from illegal Italian waste dumping to corruption and violence against women. Alongside them were student leaders hoping to emulate the success of their peers against the daunting dictatorships in Belarus, Azerbaijan and in Uzbekistan, where President Karimov has just demonstrated his ruthlessness by massacring hundreds.

"We all consider your chains our own," declared the Albanian youth leader, Erion Veliaj, 25. "We hope you all reach a non-genetically modified democracy."

If the revolutionary class of 1989 comprised middle-aged dissidents and intellectuals graduating from underground bookclubs to the barricades, the class of the new millennium is a revolutionary vanguard that is media savvy.

Their tools are the internet chatroom and the text message, the logo and brand recognition, the eye-catching flyer and pithy sloganeering. These outfits are non-hierarchical, decentralised, nominally leaderless and organised with militaristic precision.

"Our idea was to use corporate branding in politics," said Mr Marovic of Serbia's Otpor, which has become the model for parallel movements across the region.

"The movement has to have a marketing department. We took Coca-Cola as our model."

As well as acting as an ambassador, training revolutionaries in other countries, he is also developing a computer game - A Force More Powerful -with programmers in the US. You win by outwitting and toppling regimes through techniques of non-violent guerrilla activism.

If the gathering in Tirana seemed like a student campus, the talent and determination of the young organisers were obvious. Aided by western support, advice and funds, they have chalked up a series of stunning victories - three in four years - in Serbia in 2000, Georgia in 2003 and Ukraine in 2004. Other young protesters have taken part in mass action in places such as Kyrgyzstan.

Controversy has raged over the precise role of the west, and the US in particular, in financing and directing the revolutionaries for "regime change".

While the Serbs and the Ukrainians, for example, benefited from US support and money, the Uzbeks and Azerbaijanis are bitter about the lack of American backing in the face of formidable repression. "The US was pushing for regime change and was ready to invest millions of dollars," Mr Marovic said of the Serbian scenario. "The funds were there."

Double standards

Others accused Washington of double standards for singling out Belarus and the regime of Alexander Lukashenko as a target for overthrowing while tolerating the Karimov and Aliyev regimes in Uzbekistan and Azerbaijan because the first is useful to the US military in Afghanistan and the second is crucial to American oil interests in the Caspian basin.

"The Americans don't want a revolution in Azerbaijan after 13 years of dictatorship," Mr Nurullayev said. Last month he met the US ambassador in Baku to plead for help for his organisation, Yokh, which means "no".

He has not heard back from the US embassy.

Yokh is a new movement of 100 activists, styled on Serbia's Otpor, Ukraine's Pora, and Georgia's Kmara.

"We can't go on the streets and hand out our flyers. It's too dangerous," said Mr Nurullayev.

But Baku is a windy city. Yokh has just had a million flyers printed, declaring: "No to corruption, No to dictatorship." They will be dumped at high spots in the city at night to be picked up by the gusts and scattered across Baku.

In Tashkent, too, the lights-off action last week was a first tentative step by the democracy guerrillas to challenge Mr Karimov, fight the fear and mobilise the young.

The Tirana gathering heard about the launch of Bolga (The Hammer), a small group of Uzbek students at home and in the diaspora inspired by the Georgians and the Ukrainians.

Bolga's organisers declare: "What is our task? To take actions to disperse fear and silence in our society.

"What is our goal? To hold free elections, create a free society.

"What is the Bolga movement? It is a democratic and leaderless movement of Uzbek youth. We throw away the trash of totalitarianism from our minds. We are street cleaners, so we wear orange clothes."

Energised by their first networking experience, the youth leaders declared themselves all for one and one for all, aping the Nato treaty's stipulation that an attack on one organisation will be taken as an attack on all of them. There was a touch of the evangelising of the born-again congregation.

"Turn to your neighbour, look them in the eye and say to them, 'You are not alone,'" Mr Veliaj urged the gathering. A common declaration adopted yesterday stated that "each fight is our fight".


LOAD-DATE: June 6, 2005


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2005 Guardian Newspapers Limited


91 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


January 13, 2000


Milosevic's rivals try to bury feuds Anti-Milosevic Serbs bury their feuds


BYLINE: Jackie Rowlands in Belgrade


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 733 words


Jackie Rowlands in Belgrade

The Serbian opposition will be celebrating Orthodox new year tonight in a greater state of harmony than at any stage since the end of the Nato bombing campaign.

Rival opposition parties are encouraging their supporters to come together at an open-air New Year's Eve party organised by the students' resistance movement in Republic Square in Belgrade, the scene of ultimately doomed protests last year against the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic.

The hitherto feuding opposition is congratulating itself on the signing of a 'historic agreement' earlier this week in which 15 political parties adopted a joint strategy aimed at securing early presidential, parliamentary and local elections in Serbia.

At their festivities the students are to name their men and women of 1999, and more than a few opposition leaders will doubtless be hoping to find their names on the list. 

'We, the leaders of the democratic opposition, decided to once again demand from Milosevic and both Yugoslav and Serbian parliaments to agree to call early elections by the end of April.' said a spokesman for the controversial and charismatic opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic.

The demand for elections was accompanied by a threat of renewed anti -government protests starting in March.

The action plan was the initiative of Mr Draskovic, who is trying to assume the role of overall leader of the Serbian opposition. He appears to believe that his moment has come after the failure of his rival, Zoran Djindjic, to galvanise public support during a countrywide protest campaign last summer.

The decision by all the main opposition parties to support the strategy indicates a new pragmatism and a tacit admission that opposition disunity has alienated the people of Serbia.

Beyond the demand for elections, Mr Draskovic's blueprint outlines a strategy for rehabilitating Serbia internationally. It contains proposals for the lifting of sanctions against Belgrade once the authorities agree to elections and for the readmission of Serbia into the Organisation for Security and Co -operation in Europe.

To avoid accusations of selling out to the west, the opposition also calls for Serbian troops to be allowed to return to Kosovo.

Mr Draskovic is adopting a softly softly approach to political change rather than the top-to-bottom shake-out advocated by some of his younger opposition rivals. Notably absent from his blueprint is the demand for the immediate removal of President Milosevic.

Mr Draskovic is meanwhile courting disaffected members of Mr Milosevic's ruling Socialist party of Serbia, who are alarmed at the growing influence in government of the president's wife, Mira Markovic, and her associates.

Serbian sceptics argue that Mr Draskovic is not interested in reforming a system which benefits the ruling elite, but merely in changing who is at the top. Political analysts believe he may be seeking an exit strategy for Mr Milosevic which would allow the Serbian leader to retreat from power without facing prosecution on war crimes charges by the international criminal tribunal in the Hague.

Mr Milosevic, however, shows no signs of wanting a way out.

'Sloba and Mira have learnt that it is possible to rule without popular support,' said Bratislav Grubacic, a Belgrade-based political analyst.

The authorities have made it clear that presidential and parliamentary elections are not on the table.

'There is no parliamentary crisis in Serbia to give a reason for calling early elections,' said Ivica Dacic, the Socialist party spokesman, adding that elections were needed only at the local level, in towns and cities where opposition parties controlled local councils.

The government is widely expected to call local elections in the spring, capitalising on recent changes to the voting system which should favour the Socialists and their allies.

In a sign that the display of opposition unity is rustling government feathers, the authorities have started a campaign to discredit Mr Draskovic. The federal information minister, Goran Matic, showed journalists a videotape in which an alleged spy claimed to have put Mr Draskovic in contact with the French secret services.

Mr Draskovic, who already claims to have been the victim of a state-sponsored assassination plot, has rejected these allegations.


LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


92 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 23, 1999, Monday, Late Edition - Final


Serbs' Other Political Couple: Vuk and Danica Draskovic


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 2371 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 22


Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, and his influential wife, Danica, find themselves at a political crossroads, suddenly less radical than many of their supporters, their commitment to the ouster of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia called into question.

Having built a reputation as fierce and combative leaders of the opposition to Mr. Milosevic and his powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, the Draskovics now have money, power, position and a lot to lose -- making them much like the tightly knit Milosevics themselves, whom they detest but to whom they are often compared. 

The Draskovics control Belgrade, its many business opportunities and its powerful television station, Studio B -- all at the sufferance of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party.

And their efforts to find a peaceful way to oust Mr. Milosevic, to negotiate with him for new elections while trying to subvert him, has confused some of their followers and helped keep the opposition divided.

That was glaringly evident at a large anti-Milosevic rally on Thursday in Belgrade, which drew up to 100,000 people. When Mr. Draskovic realized how many had shown up, he felt compelled to crash the rally he had refused to attend.

The bearded Mr. Draskovic is normally a compelling orator, a kind of rock star.

But his speech, calling for early elections and not Mr. Milosevic's immediate removal, was too moderate for the crowd, marking a strange new episode in his career.

The Draskovics' desire for political power and dominance among the varied opposition leaders has led them to make various deals with the authorities while holding to the idea of fundamental democratic change. As they alternate between opposition and cooperation -- what critics call opportunism -- more people ask whether they have any other real aim beyond power. Tonight on Studio B, Mr. Draskovic defended his caution, saying it would be easy to call for civil war. "I am Milosevic's opponent, but I am also opposed to a single head rolling," he said. "I don't want people to get killed because of Milosevic."

But many disappointed despisers of Mr. Milosevic say the Draskovics have become afraid of revolutionary disorder, corrupted and coopted, more interested in replacing the leader at the top than in destroying his system of crony capitalism and special favors.

Some suggest that they are so driven by an intense personal hatred for their erstwhile coalition partner of only three years ago, the Democratic Party leader, Zoran Djindjic -- an animosity fully reciprocated -- that the fight for supremacy within the opposition has overshadowed the fight against Mr. Milosevic.

Such charges infuriate Vuk and Danica Draskovic, now 53 and 54 respectively. In a recent, four-hour interview at their comfortable home, Ms. Draskovic said bitterly: "Who led the demonstrations in 1991? And '93? And '96? Who led the fight in the streets? Who went to jail?"

But each time it has been Ms. Draskovic, a former judge forced to resign in 1973 by the Communists for refusing to jail a jobless man, who has pushed her husband, the orator and mover of crowds, to act boldly.

In late 1996, during enormous street protests that ultimately forced Mr. Milosevic to grant the democratic opposition their victories in local elections, Ms. Draskovic was captured on television urging protesters to take clubs and march on Dedinje, where Mr. Milosevic lives, and to seize power from the thieves who had stolen the elections.

Asked whether it was time now -- after the loss of Kosovo -- to urge people to take clubs to Dedinje again, Ms. Draskovic answered immediately, "Yes, it's always time."

Mr. Draskovic said nearly as quickly: "No. No one wants a civil war."

It is a tension that has defined their relationship, which is strong and mutually dependent, between the smart, aggressive daughter of a Chetnik -- a monarchist guerrilla during Nazi occupation -- and the son of a proud Partisan, a fighter with the victorious Communist Tito.

They were law students in 1968, the year of student upheavals throughout Europe, when they first met and dated, and took part in protests here against social injustice, inequality and "the red bourgeoisie," the party bureaucracy.

Tito promised reforms, exhilarating Mr. Draskovic and the others, who danced and shouted, "Tito we love you!"

But Danica Boskovic, Mr. Draskovic remembered in a 1990 interview with On magazine, was utterly contemptuous of the half-Croatian Tito and of their faith in him, and she exploded when Vuk tried to pull her into the celebratory kolo, or dance.

"What kolo?" she demanded. "That bandit, that Ustashe" -- a Croatian fascist. "He's cheated us and fooled us just to get us to calm down. I thought you were smarter than that."

Vuk said: "Don't speak that way about Comrade Tito. Get into the kolo." And Danica said: "Choose: him or me."

"Of course I chose Tito," Vuk said, "and I seem to remember I pushed her away."

A week later, Tito reneged and called the students counterrevolutionaries. "I repented," Vuk said, "and for four years I tried to exchange one word with Danica, in vain. She would not see me for four years."

It's a true story, Danica said, laughing. Why did she relent? "Vuk changed," she said. "He left the party."

But when is confusing. Communist Party membership was a necessary ticket for employment in journalism, and he worked for the Tanjug press agency from 1969 until 1978, when he was yanked from Lusaka, Zambia, for making up a border war.

He said that charge was nonsense, that he had had ideological troubles, but he then worked for the official trade union newspaper in Belgrade. He said he had given up on the party, but actually he was expelled from it in 1982, when he published the fiercely nationalist novel "Knife."

The novel reopened many of the nationalist and religious issues that Tito had suppressed but which helped break apart the country, with so much bloodshed, after his death.

Combined with Mr. Draskovic's deep and mythic Serbian nationalism -- "I'm a victim of my metaphors," he said as he expressed his love for the dead multiethnic Yugoslavia -- his wife's anti-Communist credentials have given their Serbian Renewal Party a considerable reach into provincial Serbia, where the more citified intellectuals of the Democratic Party do less well.

Her fury at the expropriations and hypocrisies of Communism have helped drive her toward action, she says, and without question helped him toward political prominence.

He was arrested by Mr. Milosevic's Serbian government for the first time in March 1991, after a huge opposition demonstration against the unrelenting propaganda of the state television, which the protesters called "TV Bastille."

Policemen and demonstrators clashed, and as the marchers faltered, Danica, standing with Vuk on the balcony of the National Theater, yelled at him: "What are you waiting for? Shout, 'Forward!' "

He did. One policeman and one student died, and he was arrested for a few days, but he had earned his reputation as "king of the streets."

On June 1, 1993, there was a street riot in Belgrade after Mr. Milosevic -- then President of Serbia, one of the republics making up the Yugoslavia -- engineered the sudden impeachment of the federal President, the nationalist writer Dobrica Cosic.

Mr. Draskovic led a march through Belgrade. But it was Ms. Draskovic who called on protesters to storm the federal Parliament. She was filmed on state television saying, "We should get inside, beat up the police and bust up the whole building" and asking demonstrators, "Where are your guns and your bombs?"

The couple were arrested about 1:30 A.M., and both were beaten badly by the police. Ms. Draskovic was beaten by the chief of the city's police, Rade Markovic -- now Director of State Security -- and she is said to have behaved impressively, cursing the police and the Government with blood pouring from her mouth.

Mr. Draskovic, in a separate cell, reacted differently. He wrote a letter, later published in a newspaper, full of pathos to Ms. Markovic, Mr. Milosevic's powerful wife, begging her to free Danica.

"Danica and I have no children," he wrote. "To me, she is my wife and my child and my whole family. While she is in jail, my entire family is in jail. Help her, esteemed Ms. Markovic, and you will have helped me, too. I would be endlessly grateful to you, as long as I live."

The Draskovics were in jail or prison hospitals for some 40 days before they were freed on July 9, flown to Paris by Danielle Mitterrand, the wife of the French President at the time.

But there are persistent reports that Mr. Draskovic wrote a second letter from jail, promising Mr. Milosevic that if his wife was released, the street demonstrations would stop and his party would "disarm."

The couple deny that there was any unpublished letter, but there is no question that Mr. Draskovic moved into more conventional politics and showed an increasing willingness to deal with the authorities to get a share of power and, it is said, money.

There were already signs of that a year before. In the local elections of 1992, a democratic coalition including his party won the upscale Belgrade municipality of Savski Venac, a district covering Dedinje, a wealthy area with many embassies and official houses. At the inaugural session of the local legislature, Mr. Draskovic struck a deal with Mr. Milosevic's Socialists and dropped a coalition partner.

Ms. Draskovic's brother Veselin Boskovic took over the department that managed municipal "construction grounds" -- in other words, he controlled building permits and vacant city land. Accusations of graft and corruption, including cash bribes for building permits, were so plentiful that he was forced to step down, despite denials, in part because Mr. Milosevic's party kept a dossier on him.

But after the opposition won Belgrade in the 1996 elections, Mr. Boskovic was given responsibility for the same department -- only for all of Belgrade. Again, there have been numerous accusations of bribery and graft, of payoffs for permits, which he and Ms. Draskovic have denied.

Mr. Draskovic's chief of security, a former bodyguard who was a member of a short-lived Serb Volunteer Guard that Mr. Draskovic sent to Croatia to fight in 1991 when that republic seceded from Yugoslavia, was also appointed manager of the large Tasmajdan Sports Center in downtown Belgrade. There, as with parking lots, tickets are paid for in cash.

Roksanda Nincic, a political reporter for the liberal Vreme magazine, says one of Mr. Draskovic's problems "is that he's organized a corrupt government that hasn't put Danica's family in influential places so much as in places where cash flows."

Ms. Draskovic has another brother and six sisters, and in the interview, she listed all of them and their professions to refute persistent allegations that she had granted them or their husbands leases for lucrative shops in good locations.

But Mr. Milosevic's Socialists -- who keep Mr. Draskovic in power in Belgrade by not voting against him in the city council -- are widely believed to have the means to harass and prosecute Mr. Boskovic and other party and family favorites, a stick they use, Draskovic rivals say, to keep Mr. and Ms. Draskovic in line.

The Draskovics also see control of Studio B, the Belgrade television station, as vital to any relatively fair election campaign -- another reason, some suggest, that he is not eager to defy Mr. Milosevic too fiercely.

It also helps explain why Mr. Draskovic agreed to take part in the 1997 Serbian elections, which Mr. Djindjic and most of the other opposition parties boycotted, against American advice, as unfair because of a lack of truly independent news media and outside electoral observers.

The election was credible only because Mr. Draskovic took part.

But as he moved more fully into conventional politics, his wife was perceived as too visible and influential. Like Hillary Clinton, she pulled back from the open play of politics -- a decision her husband announced.

Even today, he is defensive on the topic. "She has influenced me more than you think but less than normal," he said. "She influences me most when her stand is close to mine, but not if we are opposed."

She is fiercer than he is about himself, it seems. In the interview, she remembered being infuriated by reading, on her second day in jail in 1993, a newspaper citing Mr. Djindjic.

"He said we got what we deserved," she said bitterly.

When Mr. Draskovic agreed later to go into the Zajedno coalition with Mr. Djindjic in 1996, "we were very close to divorce," he said.

She said, a touch sarcastically, "He said, 'I must save Serbia, I must save my people.' And what happened?"

"You were right," Mr. Draskovic said. "Zajedno was a big mistake."

Early this year, Mr. Draskovic shocked more of his supporters when he went into Mr. Milosevic's federal Cabinet as a deputy prime minister, citing the crisis in Kosovo and the need for national unity, while saying he remained, at heart, in opposition, working to change the system from the inside.

He became the acceptable face for the Government, its spokesman to the West, yet he also criticized Mr. Milosevic and his wife for manipulating Serbian patriotism for narrow political goals. That finally got him dismissed before the war in Kosovo ended, allowing him to revive his opposition credentials.

Now he is accused of making another deal with a desperate Mr. Milosevic, favoring early elections in November. Mr. Draskovic denies any deal and says elections are the only way forward. But what he defines as pragmatic politics, aimed at power, is increasingly seen as opportunism.

Yet his rivals have no clearer notion of how to oust Mr. Milosevic, other than hoping to do it in the streets.

In the 1990 interview, Mr. Draskovic mentioned that in a preface to his book "Where Are You Going, Serbia?" he was compared to a rooster in a famous Ivo Andric short story. The rooster is killed not because it sings badly, but because it crows too early.

"That's why it ends up in the pot," Mr. Draskovic said. "And that, I guess, is my destiny."

NAME: Vuk Draskovic; Danica Draskovic


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

A1); Vuk Draskovic was kissed by his wife, Danica, after leaving a Belgrade hospital in July 1993. The couple were arrested for anti-government demonstrations in June, and he went on a hunger strike in jail. (Associated Press)(pg. A9)

Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


August 11, 1999, Wednesday


MILOSEVIC PRESSURE GROWS


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: KATARINA SUBASIC


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 152 words


Milosevic pressure grows

Katarina Subasic

in Belgrade

YUGOSLAV President Slobodan Milosevic was under growing pressure yesterday as two main Serbian opposition leaders agreed to join an anti-regime rally in Belgrade and a former army chief of staff founded a new opposition party.

Vuk Draskovic and Zoran Djindjic, leaders of the Serbian Renewal Movement and Democratic Party, said they would join an anti-Milosevic rally in Belgrade on August 19. 

They were speaking after meeting with the Serb Orthodox Church's chief, Patriarch Pavle.

It was initiated by a group of economists, the G-17, which has put forward a Stability Pact for Serbia which calls for a transitional government to replace Mr Milosevic's regime.

The rally will be the first in which Mr Draskovic and Mr Djindjic have taken part since their previous opposition coalition Zajedno (Together) split in 1997.

Agence France-Presse

Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


August 21, 1999, Saturday


THOUSANDS TELL MILOSEVIC TO QUIT


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: TOM HUNDLEY


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 32


LENGTH: 500 words


Thousands tell Milosevic to quit

Tom Hundley

in Belgrade

MORE than 100,000 Serbs turned out on a warm August evening to vent their frustration with Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, the man who has led their country to military defeat, economic ruin and international isolation.

Zoran Djindjic, one of leading figures in Serbia's fractious opposition, issued an ultimatum to Milosevic: resign within 15 days or face daily demonstrations and prolonged nationwide strikes.

"This time we will carry on until the end," Mr Djindjic told the protesters. "Either he goes or we do." 

Police kept a low profile, and the rally outside the Yugoslav parliament building remained peaceful. There were some tense moments, however, when a tear-gas grenade tossed into the densely packed crowd nearly caused a stampede.

The rally was organised by a newly formed group of independent economists who aim to create a transitional government of experts that would repair the economy, normalise relations with the West and prepare the country for internationally supervised elections.

"It's time for Milosevic to go," said Milovan Pavlovic, a 71-year-old retired mechanic from southern Serbia, who travelled by bus to Belgrade to take part in the demonstration. He said he was disappointed by the turnout.

"I was hoping for two or three million. These are dark days for Serbia and we will probably need a miracle to get rid of Milosevic."

Opposition leaders had said they wanted to hold off on rallies in Belgrade until they had developed a clear strategy for ousting Milosevic. Yesterday's demonstration was the first in the capital since the winter of 1996-97, when nearly three months of daily street protests against Milosevic ultimately failed because opposition leaders began bickering with each other.

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party, is the most charismatic, erratic and perhaps mistrusted figure in the anti-Milosevic camp. Two days before the Belgrade rally he withdrew as a speaker without explanation.

There were reports in the Belgrade media _ denied by Mr Draskovic _ of a secret meeting between him and Milosevic.

But halfway through yesterday's rally, he suddenly and dramatically strode up to the speaker's platform, touching off a brief scuffle between his bodyguards and those of arch-rival Mr Djindjic.

His theatrical appearance touched off loud jeers and cries of "traitor," which were quickly drowned out by ecstatic chants of "Vuk, Vuk" from supporters.

A key opposition figure who kept his promise to stay away from the rally was General Momcilo Perisic, a former army chief of staff who leads the newly formed Movement for a Democratic Serbia.

General Perisic, who was fired by Milosevic more than a year ago, is seen as a reluctant politician who has taken up the cause as a patriotic duty. He said he would not address the Belgrade rally because "the goals of the meeting are not clear" .

Knight-Ridder/Tribune


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


95 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


August 8, 2000 Tuesday


Candidate chosen to take on Milosevic


SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; WORLD REPORT; Pg. A11


LENGTH: 90 words


DATELINE: Belgrade


Fifteen Serbian opposition parties formally chose Vojislav Kostunica yesterday to be their presidential candidate against Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. Party representatives met in Belgrade to make their final decision after crisis talks with the biggest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, which nominated Belgrade Mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic as its own, rival candidate on Sunday. With two opposition candidates in the running, many fear they could end up splitting the anti-Milosevic vote in the Sept. 24 election. Reuters

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

96 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Observer


May 28, 2000


Defiant anti-Milosevic protesters rally as Belgrade clamps down: Earlier edition (2 star)


BYLINE: by Gillian Sandford, Belgrade


SECTION: Observer News Pages; Pg. 22


LENGTH: 384 words


PROTESTERS were rallying in Belgrade's Republic Square last night as the Serbian government threatened to introduce a stringent anti-terrorism law.

The rally was a crucial test of credibility for Serbia's political opposition, which has drawn fierce criticism for lacking leadership during the country's escalating crisis.

In the past week, the regime of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic has ratcheted up the tension, arresting activists from the student-based resistance movement Otpor and brand ing its members 'terrorists', 'traitors' and 'agents of Nato'. In the wake of growing activism from the wider student body, it closed universities on Friday - making campuses no-go zones for all but those entering faculty buildings to take examinations. 

Details of the anti-terrorism law have not been released, but analysts fear it may allow indefinite detention, arbitrary closure of non-state media and the disarming of citizens who hold guns; effectively introducing a state of emergency.

The regime will not be drawn on introducing the law, but top Socialist Party member Nikola Sainovic said last week: 'The Socialist Party believes we will be successful in the fight against terrorism and against Nato.

'The work of Otpor has a violent character, disrupts public peace and order and the security of the country - and these activities will be prevented,' he said.

Otpor activist Slobodan Homen responds that it is Otpor's non-violent character that gives it popularity and strength.

According to Otpor insiders, polling from Milosevic's own party shows that Otpor outstrips the ruling Socialist Party in popularity. They say that Otpor has 28 per cent of popular support and Milose vic only 14 per cent. The stakes were high for the opposition yesterday. The number of protesters attending and the performance of speakers was crucial to bolstering credibility.

Homen says that Otpor activists do not want power. 'We don't want to be members of parliament. We just want to get rid of the regime.' Homen says that Otpor has delivered an unequivocal message to the opposition: 'We are ready for a campaign of civil disobedience. We can stop exams in the faculties and we can organise.

'If you are not willing to take appropriate steps, we will do it alone.'


LOAD-DATE: May 30, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


97 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


August 19, 1999, Thursday, Edition 1


'SLOBO GO AWAY,' SERB SOCCER FANS URGE MILOSEVIC


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 526 words


BELGRADE (AP) - Yugoslav fans chanted calls for President
Slobodan Milosevic to resign during a soccer match between
Yugoslavia and Croatia yesterday, one day before a major
anti-government rally in Belgrade.

During a 45-minute break due to a power outage, Belgrade fans shouted slogans such as ''Slobo, go away,'' ''Slobo, Saddam,'' and ''Slobo, you sold Kosovo. '' Many also chanted ''The rally is tomorrow,'' referring to today's protest, which organizers hope will attract more than 100,000 people. 

It was the first game between the national teams of the former wartime enemies since Croatia became the second Yugoslav republic to break away when the federation began to disintegrate eight years ago. The qualifying match for next year's European championship ended in a 0-0 tie.

In an effort to blunt the rally's impact, Milosevic's Socialist party offered yesterday to hold early elections, The offer fell far short, however, of opposition demands that Milosevic step down and allow a transitional government before any elections.

''We believe that there are more important things on the nation's agenda than the elections, but if the opposition wants that, so be it,'' Ivica Dacic, a Socialist party spokesperson, said. ''We are ready.''

Elections are technically scheduled for 2001. Milan Bozic, of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, said his party would agree to early elections, but only under international control. Democratic party deputy Ljiljana Lucic said early elections would be just another attempt at vote fraud.

And another opposition leader fled Belgrade yesterday for Montenegro, the rebellious province whose government opposes Milosevic. Vesna Pesic, of the Civic Alliance of Serbia, fled one day after Milosevic's prosecutor demanded her investigation for allegedly calling for the toppling of his regime.

Waves of anti-Milosevic protests began in Serbia, the dominant Yugoslavia republic, after the 78-day NATO air campaign left the country badly damaged, impoverished, isolated and without control over the southern province Kosovo. The air campaign aimed to force Milosevic to accept a peace plan for the separatist province.

Yesterday, 20,000 people rallied in the country's third-largest city, Nis, chanting: ''Resignations, resignations!'' Similar rallies in Belgrade in 1996- 97 pushed Milosevic to make concessions. He later took advantage of power struggles among opposition leaders to backpedal on the deals.

Opposition leaders have still been unable to forge a common front. One key player, Vuk Draskovic, who in the past has led the largest anti-Milosevic protests, will not attend today's rally.

U.S. State Department spokesperson James Rubin said U.S. officials have met with opposition leaders and encouraged unity to hasten Milosevic's departure. The U.S. has financed Yugoslav groups which promote pluralism, but Rubin denied any U.S. role in today's planned protests.

He said most Serbs now oppose Milosevic. One poll published yesterday said more than 70 per cent want him out of office. Rubin added opposition sentiment has spread to the military.


LOAD-DATE: August 20, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: YUGOSLAV FOES:
Opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, left, and President Slobodan Milosevic.


Copyright 1999 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


98 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


April 15, 2000, Saturday


70,000 JOIN PROTEST AT MILOSEVIC'S REGIME


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 19


LENGTH: 157 words


 

UP TO 70,000 people were expected to turn out for a massive anti- government rally in Belgrade last night despite strenuous efforts by the Milosevic regime to lure them away.

In a novel bid to distract disillusioned Serbs, one of the official television stations screened a marathon of pirated copies of Oscar blockbusters yesterday including American Beauty and The World is not Enough. For days, Politika TV had called on its viewers "to stay indoors on Friday".

But from midday, huge groups of opposition sympathisers marched through the streets of the capital chanting anti-Milosevic slogans, headed for Republic Square. Police presence was visible.

The rally was organised by the united opposition parties under the motto "Stop the terror; free elections in Serbia". All the opposition leaders were expected to speak, including Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement and Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Independent Print Ltd


99 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


July 13, 1999, Tuesday


AFTERMATH OF WAR: DRASKOVIC BACKS NEW PROTESTS


BYLINE: Steve Crawshaw In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 352 words


 

ONE OF Serbia's leading political players yesterday threw his weight behind the opposition protests that are daily weakening the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.

Vuk Draskovic, the charismatic leader of the Serb Renewal Movement (SPO), announced that his party would back opposition demonstrations beginning this weekend. Mr Draskovic claimed that this would bring large crowds on to the streets for the first time since the huge demonstrations that came close to unseating Mr Milosevic two years ago. 

Yesterday 7,000 protesters turned out in the western Yugoslav town of Valjevo to demand Mr Milosevic's resignation. Some protesters broke through a glass door and briefly occupied part of the city's administration building.

Mr Draskovic's new support for the anti-Milosevic campaign is just the latest in a series of zigzags that have made him one of the most unpredictable figures on the Serb political stage.

His former allies in the opposition are now wary of him, at best.

Two years ago, he was one of the main leaders of the opposition. Later, he switched sides and became Mr Milosevic's deputy prime minister. During the Nato bombing campaign, Mr Draskovic's criticisms of Belgrade's dishonesty led to his "half sacking" from the government - though members of his party have continued to serve as ministers.

Fence-sitting has in recent weeks been his trademark. Only a few days ago, SPO members of the Belgrade city council refused even to debate a call for Mr Milosevic's resignation put forward by the other main opposition party, the Democratic Party. Mr Draskovic argued that it was "not yet" time for Mr Milosevic to go.

It is unclear whether Mr Draskovic's latest intervention will transform the opposition protests into something more immediately threatening to Mr Milosevic.

So far, there has only been nationwide smouldering, not a political blaze.

The popular disillusion with politicians of all kinds is so strong that the involvement of political parties has recently proven a dampener rather than an encouragement to come out on the streets.


LOAD-DATE: July 14, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Draskovic: Unpredictable


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


100 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Bath Chronicle


November 17, 1999


Serb demo blow


SECTION: News, Pg.6


LENGTH: 164 words


 

The largest opposition party in Serbia has urged a rival pro-democracy group to stop its dwindling street protests which have failed to unseat Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

The Serbian Renewal Movement, led by Vuk Draskovic, said demonstrations for early free and fair elections in Serbia - a demand supported by all opposition parties in the country - might be organised instead. 

It remains unclear, however, whether even a united opposition call for demonstrations could attract many Serbs to the streets to defy Milosevic's powerful police, which have used violence against the protesters more than once.

Opposition supporters have been disappointed in their leaders' bickering.

After nearly two-months, the anti-Milosevic street protests led by the Alliance for Change have collapsed, as only few hundred people appear for the daily marches and rallies. The group has nevertheless refused to cancel them, saying they keep the pressure on Milosevic.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1999 Bristol United Press


101 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


August 20, 1999, Friday


100,000 Serbs gather to call for Milosevic's removal


BYLINE: Eve-Ann Prentice in Belgrade


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 384 words


 

Opposition leaders in Yugoslavia last night called on Serbian refugees from Kosovo to lead a march on President Milosevic's home in Belgrade on August 28.

The plans for the march were revealed at a huge protest rally in Belgrade attended by well over 100,000 people from across Serbia. Mr Milosevic was also given until September 21 to agree to a transitional government or face popular insurrection on the streets. The deadline was set by Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democratic Party. 

Last night's gathering marked a crucial turning point in the wave of anti-Milosevic protests that have swept the country since the end of the Nato bombing campaign in June. Many in towns outside Belgrade had dwindled to almost nothing and Mr Milosevic had been counting on a low turnout last night.

Vuk Draskovic, the other main opposition leader in Yugoslavia, was booed and jeered to taunts of "betrayal" after he unexpectedly decided to speak to the crowd.

Mr Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, had announced earlier this week that he would not take part in the rally after days of squabbling with Mr Djindjic about how to remove Mr Milosevic from power.

In unprecedented scenes, the crowd drowned out Mr Draskovic's attempts to speak after he had leapt on to the rostrum and taken the microphone. The jeers indicated that the crowd now sees Mr Draskovic as a covert Milosevic ally.

Teargas was thrown by unknown protagonists just after the opening of the rally. But although some protesters dispersed, the massive rally continued.

"This is where new Serbia is being born," Mr Djindjic told the crowd. "Our proposal is to give (Mr Milosevic) a few days to make up his mind. If he does not accept a transitional government the whole of Serbia will go on the streets."

Vladan Batic, a founder of the umbrella Alliance for Change, then announced the plan for the march on Mr Milosevic's home in the leafy, up-market Dedinje area of Belgrade. "I call on our brothers from Kosovo to lead a march on Dedinje in ten days' time," he said.

The opposition leaders also said that signatures calling for the installation of a transitional government would be collected at the Serbian Orthodox church patriarchate in Belgrade in the run-up to the September deadline.


LOAD-DATE: August 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Times Newspapers Limited


102 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 18, 1999, Wednesday, Final Edition


Serbian Opposition Split On Eve of Public Protest


William Branigin, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A10


LENGTH: 510 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Aug. 17


 

Vuk Draskovic, the leader of Serbia's largest opposition party, said today that he will not appear at a major rally scheduled here Thursday to demand the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

Planning for the demonstration, seen as a test of opposition strength, has been plagued by disarray in the ranks of anti-Milosevic forces, as well as by intensified counterattacks by the government. Draskovic's refusal to participate was the latest sign of internal squabbling that has raised questions about whether anyone can provide an alternative to Milosevic and channel the popular discontent that has surfaced over the past few weeks across Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic. 

"August 19th will show whether Serbs prefer to lick ice cream or change the regime," said Darko Brocic, a pollster here.

Draskovic said he will send another leader of his Serbian Renewal Movement to the rally. The official explanation for this from the man whose fiery oratory earned him the title "czar of the streets" was that his replacement, Spasoje Krunic, is a better public speaker.

Other opposition figures said that Draskovic dropped out because a rival coalition of small opposition parties, the Alliance for Change, insisted on naming Velimir Ilic, mayor of the central Serbian city of Cacak, as one of its speakers. Ilic split with Draskovic a few years ago and formed his own party.

For his part, Ilic also did not seem enthusiastic about the rally. He said it was "organized too soon" and was likely to be "yet another wasting of the people's energy." At the same time, he likened Draskovic to "a spoiled baby" and said that "until someone deprives Draskovic of a microphone, there will be no democratic changes in Serbia."

The rally is being organized by the Group of 17, an association of independent economists. Their platform calls for Milosevic's resignation; for a transitional government run by people currently outside the political system; and for national elections within six months. Organizers said the demonstration will set a deadline for Milosevic's resignation and call for escalating protests if he refuses. In a formal notification to Belgrade police, they said they expect more than 100,000 people to attend.

Thus far, the struggle between Milosevic and the opposition has been mainly a war of words, with each side accusing the other of being "terrorists" and seeking to foment civil war. Milosevic supporters also have accused the opposition of acting as surrogates for NATO, which waged a 78-day bombing campaign against Yugoslavia this spring, and of organizing the demonstration in honor of President Clinton's birthday, which falls on Thursday.

Serbian Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic called the Alliance for Change "a terrorist organization" after one of its leaders, Vesna Pesic, told a crowd that the "Romanian scenario" would be used to get rid of Milosevic if necessary--a reference to the execution of Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife following the 1989 uprising there.


LOAD-DATE: August 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


103 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Irish Times


July 18, 2008 Friday


Happy days in Novi Sad


SECTION: THE TICKET; Music Features; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 1033 words


What began eight years ago as a post-war, anti-Milosevic music event has evolved into Serbia's biggest music festival, and one of Europe's best, writes Jim Carroll

IT BEGAN as an act of defiance.

Back in 2000, three students decided to hold a music festival in the northern Serbian city of Novi Sad. It was a year after Nato forces had bombed the city and a few months before that year's presidential election. The organisers decided it was time to make a protest about the political situation, so they booked some bands. 

To avoid drawing undue attention from the authorities, that inaugural EXIT gathering was not billed as an anti-Slobodan Milosevic protest, but the intent was clear to all. A festival with a slogan of "EXIT out of 10 years of madness" was never just going to be about hedonism.

Over the course of three months, a huge number of bands and performers played on various stages in the city, while audiences were encouraged by activists from the Otpor youth movement to think about how the political system could be used to end the Milosevic era. The September election was the first step in that process, and EXIT went on to become an annual gathering for Serbian youth.

There's still sedition of a kind in the air at EXIT. "Rebellion is the only thing that keeps you alive," proclaims a festival-site poster. The poster, however, is not calling for the removal of an unpopular politician; rather, it is advertising a brand of footwear.

Such branding is just one sign of how much has changed around these parts. Car manufacturers, beer brands and telecom companies were not around for the first EXIT, but they're making up for lost time now by seeking to attach their logos to every available space.After all, this is where their target audience are. The numbers in attendance are testament to EXIT's position as one of the biggest festivals in Europe. This year, more than 50,000 people came through the gates every night.

At least half of the audience came from overseas, with research last year indicating that there were 52 different nationalities present. Organisers estimate at least 8,000 travelled from Britain this year and say there were about 500 advance weekend ticket sales from Ireland.

These visitors are usually jaded by the same old festival fare on offer at home and are keen to experience something completely different abroad. The trick for EXIT in the coming years will be to continue to appeal to them, while also ensuring that the increasing corporate buy-in doesn't change the festival. The local economy is also a significant stakeholder in the event. Besides the annual financial boost for local pockets, festival tourism means longer-term gains as fans go away with positive impressions of Serbia and spread the word. And it's hard not to be impressed by what's on offer in Novi Sad because EXIT really is a festival with lots of the wow factor.

For a start, there's the venue, a true star in the proceedings. The magnificent medieval Petrovaradin fortress overlooks the Danube, and the city and is easily one of the most striking festival sites in Europe.

The fortress provided a strategic stronghold against Turkish and Austrian invaders throughout its history, but few of them can have been as raucous or as good-natured as the EXITgoers who take it over four nights every July. There are about two dozen stages located in every nook and cranny of the site. You simply follow the hordes as they climb up steps onto walls or walk through tunnels to get from stage to stage. Just when you think you've got to every single stage on the site, you find another one situated where you least expect it.

Whatever about the two main stages where the bigger acts perform, it's the smaller stages which provide the most surprises. These cater for all musical tastes, from Latin, reggae and indie rock to happy hardcore, live electronica, cheesy trance and a couple of dozen metal/punk bands making the fiercest, angriest racket imaginable. In their midst, you'll find exciting bands such as Vrelo, Orkestra del Sol and the Pannonia All Stars doing their thing. It's not all music, though. In keeping with EXIT's political roots, there are dozens of stalls vociferously advocating an assortment of causes. You'll be handed anti-vivisection and anti-trafficking leaflets, along with more on vegetarianism, gay rights, women's refuges, recycling, why Serbia needs to be in the EU and the importance of keeping Novi Sad a Nazi-free zone. There is also someone attempting to promote the benefits of yoga, but there are few takers.

While the bulk of the acts and DJs on the smaller stages may not be household names beyond the Balkans, EXIT does still draw the big names. This year, Manu Chao caused road-blocks around the main stage when he and his band performed last Saturday night.

Others who rose to the occasion included The Gossip (whose new material sounds fantastic), the excellent Gogol Bordello (a sort of homecoming for the New York gypsy punk band), Ministry (the industrial metal band playing one of their final shows ever), The Hives and a rejuvenated Paul Weller, complete with a blistering make-over for Eton Rifles.

Some, though, did not fare quite so well. Pharrell Williams from NERD had sound issues which led him to petulantly fling his microphone at some poor, unfortunate roadie. Both Primal Scream and The Streets also failed to sizzle or connect with the audience, while Roni Size and Reprazent seemed a tad lost on that big stage. Festival headliners the Sex Pistols may have drawn a big crowd, but a muddy sound and pretty tired renditions of the classics meant people began to stream away from the stage after about three songs. Over on the dance stage, it was Audion's subtle, sexy, tweaked house, Francois K's masterclass in mood-setting, the sleazy electro of Claude VonStroke, a live set from Booka Shade and an epic set from Swedish house producer Axwell which took all the plaudits.

As the thousands left the site in the early hours of Monday morning, the last thing they saw was a reminder about next year. In July 2009, EXIT will celebrate its 10th anniversary. That really should be the greatest rock'n'rave weekend of the year.

www.exitfest.org


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 The Irish Times
All Rights Reserved


104 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Irish Times


July 18, 2008 Friday


Happy days in Novi Sad


SECTION: THE TICKET; Music Features; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 1033 words


What began eight years ago as a post-war, anti-Milosevic music event has evolved into Serbia's biggest music festival, and one of Europe's best, writes Jim Carroll

IT BEGAN as an act of defiance.

Back in 2000, three students decided to hold a music festival in the northern Serbian city of Novi Sad. It was a year after Nato forces had bombed the city and a few months before that year's presidential election. The organisers decided it was time to make a protest about the political situation, so they booked some bands. 

To avoid drawing undue attention from the authorities, that inaugural EXIT gathering was not billed as an anti-Slobodan Milosevic protest, but the intent was clear to all. A festival with a slogan of "EXIT out of 10 years of madness" was never just going to be about hedonism.

Over the course of three months, a huge number of bands and performers played on various stages in the city, while audiences were encouraged by activists from the Otpor youth movement to think about how the political system could be used to end the Milosevic era. The September election was the first step in that process, and EXIT went on to become an annual gathering for Serbian youth.

Such branding is just one sign of how much has changed around these parts. The local economy is also a significant stakeholder in the event. Besides the annual financial boost for local pockets, festival tourism means longer-term gains as fans go away with positive impressions of Serbia and spread the word. And it's hard not to be impressed by what's on offer in Novi Sad because EXIT really is a festival with lots of the wow factor.

For a start, there's the venue, a true star in the proceedings. The magnificent medieval Petrovaradin fortress overlooks the Danube, and the city and is easily one of the most striking festival sites in Europe.

The fortress provided a strategic stronghold against Turkish and Austrian invaders throughout its history, but few of them can have been as raucous or as good-natured as the EXITgoers who take it over four nights every July. There are about two dozen stages located in every nook and cranny of the site. You simply follow the hordes as they climb up steps onto walls or walk through tunnels to get from stage to stage. Just when you think you've got to every single stage on the site, you find another one situated where you least expect it.

These cater for all musical tastes, from Latin, reggae and indie rock to happy hardcore, live electronica, cheesy trance and a couple of dozen metal/punk bands making the fiercest, angriest racket imaginable. In their midst, you'll find exciting bands such as Vrelo, Orkestra del Sol and the Pannonia All Stars doing their thing. It's not all music, though. In keeping with EXIT's political roots, there are dozens of stalls vociferously advocating an assortment of causes. You'll be handed anti-vivisection and anti-trafficking leaflets, along with more on vegetarianism, gay rights, women's refuges, recycling, why Serbia needs to be in the EU and the importance of keeping Novi Sad a Nazi-free zone. There is also someone attempting to promote the benefits of yoga, but there are few takers.

While the bulk of the acts and DJs on the smaller stages may not be household names beyond the Balkans, EXIT does still draw the big names. This year, Manu Chao caused road-blocks around the main stage when he and his band performed last Saturday night.

Others who rose to the occasion included The Gossip (whose new material sounds fantastic), the excellent Gogol Bordello (a sort of homecoming for the New York gypsy punk band), Ministry (the industrial metal band playing one of their final shows ever), The Hives and a rejuvenated Paul Weller, complete with a blistering make-over for Eton Rifles.

Some, though, did not fare quite so well. Pharrell Williams from NERD had sound issues which led him to petulantly fling his microphone at some poor, unfortunate roadie. Both Primal Scream and The Streets also failed to sizzle or connect with the audience, while Roni Size and Reprazent seemed a tad lost on that big stage. Festival headliners the Sex Pistols may have drawn a big crowd, but a muddy sound and pretty tired renditions of the classics meant people began to stream away from the stage after about three songs. Over on the dance stage, it was Audion's subtle, sexy, tweaked house, Francois K's masterclass in mood-setting, the sleazy electro of Claude VonStroke, a live set from Booka Shade and an epic set from Swedish house producer Axwell which took all the plaudits.

As the thousands left the site in the early hours of Monday morning, the last thing they saw was a reminder about next year. In July 2009, EXIT will celebrate its 10th anniversary. That really should be the greatest rock'n'rave weekend of the year.

www.exitfest.org

105 of 348 DOCUMENTS



BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


September 12, 2006 Tuesday


American, Serbian asked to leave Maldives deny fomenting unrest


LENGTH: 780 words


Text of report by Sri Lankan-based Maldivian Minivan News website on 12 September

Two foreign nationals were asked to leave the Maldives at the weekend, after officials accused them of "undermining the national unity" of the country.

But the men, an American and a Serbian, told Minivan News that they were simply on holiday in the Maldives and dismissed government allegations of wrongdoing. 

They said that they had been "politely asked" to leave the Maldives by the authorities but stressed that they had not broken any laws and were not charged with any offence.

The men - both experts in non-violent resistance techniques - had been visiting Addu Atoll. They said that whilst on holiday they had "exchanged ideas" with opposition activists about how to conduct peaceful protests.

"I am from a country which was in a similar situation to the Maldives," said the Serbian man, who asked not to be named. "I wasn't a member of OTPOR [anti-Milosevic movement], but I did work closely with them."

"All over the world people are trying to figure out how to change their societies peacefully and without conflict... [ellipsis as published] and that can be a difficult thing to do," added the American man.

"In most countries - India, Nepal, Sri Lanka - it's normal for citizens to talk about the problems they face. But in some countries you are not allowed to talk about your problems. So these people need to learn how to work in an atmosphere of fear and how to bring that fear down."

"If you can reduce fear on both side, then people can come to an agreement," the American said.

Controller of Immigration and prominent DRP [ruling party] Majlis [parliament] member Ibrahim Shafiu told Haveeru [Daily] that the decision to ask the men to leave was taken because he had received reports alleging that the men had been briefing a gathering of youngsters in Addu on ''how to face the security forces and continue the recent acts of violence in the atoll''.

"We questioned them after bringing them to Immigrations," Shafiu said. "They agreed that they had met groups of young people and given them such information. A condition for granting a tourist visa is that they could be expelled from the country if they did, or were suspected of doing, anything to undermine national and religious unity in the Maldives,'' he added.

Shafiu claimed that the men would not be subject to a full investigation "so as not to waste time".

But the American denied the allegations: "We never did anything to bring instability into the country. We didn't break any laws. We are not members of OTPOR. We were not deported. We just exchanged ideas with people. A government official explained to us that Maldives is 'a democracy'. Yet, after that meeting we were constantly photographed and then we were politely asked to leave. The government said they were worried we were undermining the stability of the country but they didn't explain how.''

"The situation in the Maldives is very similar to the situation in Serbia before the fall of Milosevic," said the Serb. "We were not advising the people of Addu of anything. But we did exchange ideas with them. I spoke about Serbia, and how we managed to change things through non-violent means."

The Serb added: "I said: we wouldn't have referred to the police as 'Golhaa Force' ["Golhaabo" is a nickname for President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom] because the police are not the guilty ones. They are just doing their job. In Serbia, we did not go after our countrymen, our neighbours or our brothers. Instead, we talked to the police."

"In Serbia, we never threw rocks at the police. It would have been the wrong thing to do. It's very important not to do that. Why, people may ask: 1) Because you'll lose - the police have all the weapons and training to fight violently; 2) It causes an increase in fear on both sides and makes a solution more difficult; and 3) the general public will not hear your political message, instead they'll just see the violence," the Serb continued.

"If one puts themselves in the position of the police, and you see a crowd running towards you throwing stones, you are likely to respond with violence," added the American.

"In Serbia, by acting peacefully we changed the behaviour of the police. The police realized that the people didn't want to fight with them - they only wanted things to change. The Serbian police were a very, very aggressive security force but they changed," said the Serb.

"In Maldives we saw that the people in the opposition had the energy and foresight to use non-violent methods. They are very patriotic and very proud of their country," said the American.

Source: Minivan News website, Colombo, in English 0000 gmt 12 Sep 06


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 2006


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript



Copyright 2006 British Broadcasting Corporation
All Rights Reserved


106 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


August 21, 1999, Saturday


OPPOSITION IN SERBIA TOLD TO STOP BICKERING


BYLINE: Rupert Cornwell


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 344 words


 

AFTER THURSDAY'S massive protest rally against Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's opposition leaders are under stronger pressure than ever to set aside their differences and topple the Yugoslav President.

The Belgrade march, which attracted as many as 150,000 people from every section of the opposition, demonstrated the strengths and weaknesses of the movement: the size of the hostility to Mr Milosevic and the jealous rivalries of his opponents, which may yet keep him in power.

Yesterday, the government- controlled press did its best to play down the event, relegating coverage to the inside pages, with headlines such as that in the newspaper Politika, which proclaimed a "failed pro-Nato rally" attended by no more than 25,000 demonstrators. 

"One can't tell who is more disappointed, the organisers, the participants or the Nato bosses and mentors," said the state television station.

But the government's anti-Nato card seems to be losing some of its potency, and the main leaders of the rally were delighted with the turnout at the largest anti-Milosevic protest since 1997. They stepped up their demands for his speedy and unconditional resignation.

But the splits in the opposition are starting to show. While Zoran Djindjic demanded Mr Milosevic's immediate replacement, his bitter rival, the quixotic Vuk Draskovic, urged early elections as the best way out of the deadlock. But the former deputy prime minister of Yugoslavia was widely booed for his pains. "Treason, Treason," chanted sections of the crowd, mindful of Mr Draskovic's long history of zigzagging between the opposition and Mr Milosevic, and fearful that any election would be simply rigged by the present regime.

Meanwhile Nato governments are becoming daily more impatient at the squabbling. Yesterday it was the turn of Joschka Fischer, the German Foreign Minister, to warn that the Serb opposition must unite. "All the democratic forces in Serbia must continue down the path they've started," he said. "The door to Europe is open for a democratic Serbia."


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


107 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


July 29, 1999, Thursday


Opposition agitates for army to oust Milosevic


SOURCE: * AP


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 210 words


* A correspondent in Belgrade

A TOP Serbian opposition leader facing military trial for draft dodging has warned that the movement to oust President Slobodan Milosevic would accelerate if he were convicted.

Zoran Djindjic also appealed to Yugoslav army commanders to abandon their pledges to protect the Yugoslav President and try to oust him, saying the country's very survival is threatened. 

Mr Djindjic, who is leading popular protests against Mr Milosevic, was due to be summoned to appear before a Belgrade military court yesterday for pre-trial investigation, his lawyers said.

The allegations that he avoided compulsory army service during the NATO air campaign carry a maximum sentence of 20 years' jail.

Mr Djindjic's Alliance for Change coalition has been staging regular anti-Milosevic rallies for the past month.

The protests reflect growing Serb discontent with Mr Milosevic's policies, which many blame for a destroyed economy, international isolation, NATO's bombing campaign and the de facto loss of Kosovo province.

The 46-year-old politician fled Serbia during the air campaign fearing his life was in danger. His lawyers say he never received a call-up notice. Nearly 30,000 other men face similar draft-dodging charges.
