LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


108 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


November 26, 2004


Analysis: US campaign behind the turmoil in Kiev


BYLINE: Ian Traynor


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages, Pg. 17


LENGTH: 1151 words


 

With their websites and stickers, their pranks and slogans aimed at banishing widespread fear of a corrupt regime, the democracy guerrillas of the Ukrainian Pora youth movement have already notched up a famous victory - whatever the outcome of the dangerous stand-off in Kiev.

Ukraine, traditionally passive in its politics, has been mobilised by the young democracy activists and will never be the same again.

But while the gains of the orange-bedecked "chestnut revolution" are Ukraine's, the campaign is an American creation, a sophisticated and brilliantly conceived exercise in western branding and mass marketing that, in four countries in four years, has been used to try to salvage rigged elections and topple unsavoury regimes.

Funded and organised by the US government, deploying US consultancies, pollsters, diplomats, the two big American parties and US non-government organisations, the campaign was first used in Europe in Belgrade in 2000 to beat Slobodan Milosevic at the ballot box. 

Richard Miles, the US ambassador in Belgrade, played a key role. And by last year, as US ambassador in Tbilisi, he repeated the trick in Georgia, coaching Mikhail Saakashvili in how to bring down Eduard Shevardnadze.

Ten months after the success in Belgrade, the US ambassador in Minsk, Michael Kozak, a veteran of similar operations in central America, notably in Nicaragua, organised a near identical campaign to try to defeat the Belarus hardman, Alexander Lukashenko.

That one failed. "There will be no Kostunica in Belarus," the Belarus president declared, referring to the victory in Belgrade.

But experience gained in Serbia, Georgia and Belarus has been invaluable in plotting to beat the regime of Leonid Kuchma in Kiev.

The operation - engineering democracy through the ballot box and civil disobedience - is now so slick that the methods have matured into a template for winning other people's elections.

In the centre of Belgrade, there is a dingy office staffed by computer-literate youngsters who call themselves the Centre for Non-violent Resistance. If you want to know how to beat a regime that controls the mass media, the judges, the courts, the security apparatus and the voting stations, the young Belgrade activists are for hire.

They emerged from the anti-Milosevic student movement, Otpor, meaning resistance. The catchy, single- word branding is important. In Georgia last year, the parallel student movement was Khmara. In Belarus, it was Zubr. In Ukraine, it is Pora, meaning high time. Otpor also had a potent, simple slogan that appeared everywhere in Serbia in 2000 - the two words " gotov je", meaning "he's finished", a reference to Milosevic. A logo of a black-and-white clenched fist completed the masterful marketing.

In Ukraine, the equivalent is a ticking clock, also signalling that the Kuchma regime's days are numbered.

Stickers, spray paint and websites are the young activists' weapons. Irony and street comedy mocking the regime have been hugely successful in puncturing public fear and enraging the powerful.

Last year, before becoming president in Georgia, the US-educated Mr Saakashvili travelled from Tbilisi to Belgrade to be coached in the techniques of mass defiance. In Belarus, the US embassy organised the dispatch of young opposition leaders to the Baltic, where they met up with Serbs travelling from Belgrade. In Serbia's case, given the hostile environment in Belgrade, the Americans organised the overthrow from neighbouring Hungary - Budapest and Szeged.

In recent weeks, several Serbs travelled to the Ukraine. Indeed, one of the leaders from Belgrade, Aleksandar Maric, was turned away at the border.

The Democratic party's National Democratic Institute, the Republican party's International Republican Institute, the US state department and USAid are the main agencies involved in these grassroots campaigns as well as the Freedom House NGO and billionaire George Soros's open society institute.

US pollsters and professional consultants are hired to organise focus groups and use psephological data to plot strategy.

The usually fractious oppositions have to be united behind a single candidate if there is to be any chance of unseating the regime. That leader is selected on pragmatic and objective grounds, even if he or she is anti-American.

In Serbia, US pollsters Penn, Schoen and Berland Associates discovered that the assassinated pro-western opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic, was reviled at home and had no chance of beating Milosevic fairly in an election. He was persuaded to take a back seat to the anti-western Vojislav Kostunica, who is now Serbian prime minister.

In Belarus, US officials ordered opposition parties to unite behind the dour, elderly trade unionist, Vladimir Goncharik, because he appealed to much of the Lukashenko constituency.

Officially, the US government spent $ 41m (£21.7m) organising and funding the year-long operation to get rid of Milosevic from October 1999. In Ukraine, the figure is said to be around $ 14m.

Apart from the student movement and the united opposition, the other key element in the democracy template is what is known as the "parallel vote tabulation", a counter to the election-rigging tricks beloved of disreputable regimes.

There are professional outside election monitors from bodies such as the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, but the Ukrainian poll, like its predecessors, also featured thousands of local election monitors trained and paid by western groups.

Freedom House and the Democratic party's NDI helped fund and organise the "largest civil regional election monitoring effort" in Ukraine, involving more than 1,000 trained observers. They also organised exit polls. On Sunday night those polls gave Mr Yushchenko an 11-point lead and set the agenda for much of what has followed.

The exit polls are seen as critical because they seize the initiative in the propaganda battle with the regime, invariably appearing first, receiving wide media coverage and putting the onus on the authorities to respond.

The final stage in the US template concerns how to react when the incumbent tries to steal a lost election.

In Belarus, President Lukashenko won, so the response was minimal. In Belgrade, Tbilisi, and now Kiev, where the authorities initially tried to cling to power, the advice was to stay cool but determined and to organise mass displays of civil disobedience, which must remain peaceful but risk provoking the regime into violent suppression.

If the events in Kiev vindicate the US in its strategies for helping other people win elections and take power from anti-democratic regimes, it is certain to try to repeat the exercise elsewhere in the post-Soviet world.

The places to watch are Moldova and the authoritarian countries of central Asia.


LOAD-DATE: November 26, 2004


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2004 Guardian Newspapers Limited


109 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 21, 1999, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


Anti-Milosevic Rallies to Begin Tonight in Belgrade


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 3; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1174 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 20


The leader of a group of opposition parties that will try to bring down President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia in a series of rallies and demonstrations beginning on Tuesday says the outcome is really up to the Serbian people now.

"This is poker with all the cards on the table," the leader, Zoran Djindjic, said in an interview today. "We don't have any choice. We have to try to remove Milosevic by the end of the year, and do it with people on the streets. We believe that the people are stronger than Milosevic. But it depends on the people of Serbia now, and I don't know what their reaction will be." 

Mr. Djindjic's Democratic Party and the smaller opposition parties in the Alliance for Change have made plans for simultaneous rallies beginning on Tuesday evening in 32 Serbian cities and towns. They have also tried to organize daytime events. Party workers will hand out material from kiosks and canvass local citizens with petitions. Daily mock trials of Government officials will be presented on accusations of having failed the people or of being corrupt.

It has been a summer of intermittent rallies and disputes within the broader opposition. The largest of the parties, the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic, will not take part in the new demonstrations.

But the Alliance politicians said it was time, as Mr. Djindjic (pronounced JIN-jitch) said last month, at the biggest opposition rally to date, "to go to the end."

The rally on Tuesday in Belgrade, the capital, will be in the Square of the Republic, which will look full with 10,000 to 15,000 people, not in front of the Parliament, where the rally last month drew an estimated 100,000.

Rally posters show Mr. Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic, with big red X's over their faces and with the slogan, "The people choose." That is an echo of a 1945 slogan that said, "We want no king, we want Tito -- the people choose."

Mr. Djindjic, appearing to use the time-honored tactic of lowering expectations, said he expected that the rallies would start slowly and peak. Depending on the turnout, by the beginning of next month the Alliance plans to concentrate on activities like traffic blockades, some form of a general strike and announcing an alternative shadow Government, to be led by a former Central Bank governor, Dragoslav Avramovic.

The opposition-run local governments of the main cities may then make declarations of no confidence in the Government and refuse to obey it, Mr. Djindjic suggested. Or the opposition could on its own hold informal elections.

"But by the end of October, Milosevic will respond in some way," Mr. Djindjic said, "with violence or counterdemonstrations or new elections or his resignation," although Mr. Djindjic said he had no great hopes for an easy or quick resignation.

Mr. Draskovic, the other main opposition leader, has been pushing for early elections, and he is widely expected to wait to see how the rallies fare before committing himself. If the turnouts are large, he will have little choice but to join in some fashion. If they are small, he is most likely to declare himself the leader of the opposition and urge the others to unite behind him.

On Sunday, Mr. Draskovic said that he would join protests if the opposition could agree on conditions for free, fair and early elections and if Mr. Milosevic refused to schedule them. But it is not clear that Mr. Milosevic feels the need to have early elections, in view of their risks to him, and he is also waiting to see what turnouts the Alliance produces.

So is the United States, which is backing Mr. Djindjic's efforts -- with more moral support than tangible help. A senior Administration official said in a telephone interview: "We'll see if these demonstrations go well, if they have a progression, plateau or even decline. Then they can decide what comes next. They have four or five weeks to mobilize people and see where that takes them."

If there is a decline, he said, "then the Administration may have to change its tune" and accept early elections with Mr. Milosevic still in power.

Mr. Djindjic and Alliance officials are encouraged by opinion polls that indicate that two-thirds of Serbs are unhappy with the Government, half believe that the political system is growing worse, and nearly 40 percent have no confidence in Mr. Milosevic.

But the polls, released last week by the Center for Studying Alternatives, a research institute, indicate deep and abiding insecurity and fear of chaos and civil war. The Government is exploiting such fears through its propaganda, accusing the Alliance of acting as NATO's cat's paw, of being in the pay of the United States and trying to finish what the bombing started.

More than 90 percent of the respondents in a random sample of 1,600 Serbs said they feared a lowering of their already poor living standards. Nearly as many said they feared new inflation and unemployment. Eighty percent said they feared civil war, and 70 percent mentioned hunger. When asked whether they favored change even at the price of violence, many respondents demanded that the word violence be scratched out, pollsters said. Still, about a third said they wanted change at any price.

The point of the demonstrations is to turn those concerns into collective action, to mobilize Serbs who fear for their future and to give them confidence, Mr. Djindjic said. If the rallies build and the Alliance can achieve as many as two million signatures on petitions, he added, he expects the Government to begin to crumble.

Mr. Djindjic said 30 people associated with the Government and its business interests had approached his party about making contributions as a sort of bet on the future. They also want help in having their names removed from a European Union ban on visas and travel for 300 notables from the present administration.

A senior aide to Mr. Djindjic, Cedomir Jovanovic, said today, "Milosevic's power will disappear the day he no longer controls the levers of power, when the police understand that there's no one behind their backs but a little group of thieves, and in front of them are the people."

But some party officials are also concerned that they are attempting too much and opening too many fronts, that they have to deal with the conflict with Mr. Draskovic, as well as internal conflicts about strategy in the party and the Alliance.

The party's 5,000 active participants are already working 12 hours a day, officials said, and the canvassing that Mr. Djindjic plans will take even more out of them.

Still, it is party-building work -- obtaining signatures and telephone numbers -- of the kind that the opposition has rarely done, and it should help in elections should they come about.

As for himself, Mr. Djindjic stepped back from an earlier pledge to quit as party leader if Mr. Milosevic was still in power on Jan. 1, 2000. But if this new effort to unseat Mr. Milosevic fails, Mr. Djindjic said, he will step down as a "lightning rod" for criticism.  

http://www.nytimes.com

110 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)


July 28, 1999, FINAL


Serb warns Milosevic not to prosecute him for evading conscription


BYLINE: The Associated Press


SECTION: News; A5


LENGTH: 257 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


A Serb opposition leader accused of evading conscription during the NATO air campaign warned Tuesday that the movement to oust Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic would accelerate if he is convicted.

Zoran Djindjic appealed to army commanders to abandon their pledges to protect Milosevic and try to oust him, saying the country's survival is threatened. 

Djindjic, who is leading popular protests against Milosevic, has been summoned to appear before a Belgrade military court today for pretrial investigation, his lawyers said.

The allegations that he avoided compulsory army service during the NATO bombing could lead to convictions that carry a maximum sentence of 20 years. If he is convicted and imprisoned, ''it would be a very wrong decision . . . which would accelerate and radicalize the protests,'' Djindjic said.

Djindjic's Alliance for Change coalition has been holding anti-Milosevic rallies for the past month. The protests reflect growing Serb discontentment with Milosevic's policies, which many blame for a destroyed economy, the NATO bombing and the de facto loss of Kosovo. Djindjic, 46, called the allegations part of an attempt by Milosevic to divert public anger by painting opposition leaders as traitors.

He fled Serbia to the more liberal Yugoslav republic of Montenegro during the air campaign, which began March 24. He said his life was threatened because of his opposition to Milosevic. His lawyers said he never received a notice of conscription. Nearly 30,000 others face similar charges.

111 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE AUSTRALIAN


January 3, 1997, Friday


Serbs cook up a ploy to annoy 


SOURCE: AFP


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 7


LENGTH: 393 words


BELGRADE: Serbian opposition leaders conscripted pots, pans, drums and foghorns into their latest protest in a switch of tactics designed to keep the pressure on authorities in Belgrade to accept their wins in local elections.

The tactic was aimed chiefly at protesting against the pro-government coverage of the opposition movement churned out by Serbia's State-run media.

After 44 straight days of street protests, culminating in a giant New Year's Eve party in Belgrade that brought out 200,000 people, opposition supporters were told instead to stay at home. 

This time they were asked to create a racket, specifically to use pots and pans and anything metal they could lay their hands on to drown out the main evening news program on State television.

But 10,000 students, who have marched in the vanguard of the six-week anti-Milosevic protests, took to the streets of the capital anyway late on Wednesday, defying bitter cold as well as a ban on demonstrations.

They were soon joined by thousands more citizens, but riot police -out in force last week -could not be seen on the streets.

Earlier that day the speaker of Montenegro's parliament, Mr Marovic, called on Belgrade to respect the findings of a team of international mediators from the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, who have called on the Serbian President, Mr Milosevic, to recognise the results of the November 17 municipal elections.

Belgrade is expected to give its response by today to the OSCE team, which has urged it to accept the gains made by the opposition Together coalition.

Opposition candidates won 13 of Serbia's biggest towns and nine districts in Belgrade, but the results were cancelled by authorities, triggering the huge daily street protests.

Mr Marovic said acknowledgement of the OSCE report would be "a first step to overcoming the crisis in Belgrade and Serbia". Montenegro and Serbia are the republics that make up federal Yugoslavia.

Mr Marovic said federal Yugoslavia "must not face renewed isolation . . . democracy is the path to follow to reintegrate it into the international community". In a short televised new year message, Mr Milosevic spoke briefly of the country's "external and internal difficulties" but did not refer directly to the protests. He promised 1997 would be a "year of reform". AFP

112 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


November 26, 2003, Wednesday


GEORGIAN OPPOSITION COPIED SERBS' BLOODLESS REVOLUTION


BYLINE: LEONARD DOYLE FOREIGN EDITOR


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 13


LENGTH: 601 words


 

GEORGIA'S PARLIAMENT set 4 January as the date for new presidential elections yesterday, after the bloodless "rose revolution" that saw President Eduard Shevardnadze's departure at the weekend.

The election date was agreed after Georgia's highest court invalidated the elections which saw the ruling party try to hold on to power by brazenly stuffing ballot boxes and changing voter lists in plain sight of foreign election monitors. Members of the legislature gathered in the parliament building, the epicentre of the country's recent protests, and overwhelmingly decided to press ahead with the elections. 

"We should stand side by side independent of nationalities, independent of political interests," said parliamentary speaker and interim President Nino Budrzhanadze. "Today we are starting a new era." A vase of red roses stood on the speaker's lectern, a reminder of the flowers many of the protesters carried.

Before the parliament convened, Mikhail Saakashvili, another opposition leader and the expected successor to Mr Shevardnadze, warned of the risk of civil war if the new elections do not proceed as planned. "If this session doesn't set new elections, Georgia will find itself in a state of civil war," the American-educated former justice minister said in a televised statement.

Mr Saakashvili has warned that there remains a potential for violence. Concern is growing that Adzharia, an autonomous province in southwestern Georgia on the Black Sea led by his opponent, Aslan Abashidze may now seek independence from Georgia.

Mr Abashidze warned yesterday that Adzharia was breaking off relations with the capital, Tbilisi, until a new president was elected. Train and air service were cut and regional security forces sealed the borders with the rest of the country. Mr Abashidze said his region would boycott the parliament.

The country's interim leaders have vowed to bring political stability to the country as quickly as possible. "I'm going to do everything to maintain stability and peace in the country," Ms Burdzhanadze said.

Georgia's new power brokers are following in the footsteps of the opposition movement which deposed Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, in October 2000 after a similar popular uprising.

Opposition leaders went to Belgrade to learn the lessons of their revolution and then arranged for their Serbian counterparts to travel to Tbilisi. All last summer members of Serbia's opposition organisation Otpor (Resistance) slipped into Georgia to run training courses in civil disobedience for thousands of students.

Financed by the George Soros foundation, they organised the mostly student opposition under the slogan Kmara! (Enough!) which was modelled on the Serbian anti-Milosevic slogan "You're cooked!"

The US government also funded courses for the opposition parties in techniques for building independent democratic institutions in the country. As Ivane Merabishvili, general secretary of the National Movement party that led the revolt told the Washington Post's Peter Baker: "All the demonstrators knew the tactics of the revolution in Belgrade by heart. Everyone knew what to do. This was a copy of that revolution, only louder."

Georgia's new rulers now face a struggle to rebuild their poverty- stricken country. Political sabotage, corruption, separatist threats and an economic quagmire threaten to drag the country down. One of the first tasks will be to restore relations with the IMF, the EU and other aid donors who walked away from the country because of systemic corruption and mismanagement.


LOAD-DATE: November 26, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2003 Independent Print Ltd


113 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


March 7, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


Raid Temporarily Cuts Off Anti-Milosevic TV Station in Belgrade


BYLINE: AP 


SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 536 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 6


Men in camouflage uniforms today raided the transmission center of the main nongovernment television station here, Studio B. Senior government officials intensified legal action against it.

Two employees were badly beaten in the morning raid on the Torlak transmission station, Studio B executives said. 

Five assailants who were wearing police uniforms stormed the compound, tied up and beat the two workers and tore transmitter cables, causing Studio B to go off the air temporarily. Hours after the raid, Telecommunications Minister Ivan Markovic ordered Studio B to pay in eight days $850,000 for the use of its frequencies or face legal action.

This evening, a court fined the station $40,000 in a libel suit filed by a police officer.

The City Council owns the station, and it is controlled by the Serbian Renewal Movement of an opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic.

"The latest attack on Studio B is the attack on all free, independent and alternative media in Serbia," said the chief of the station, Dragan Kojadinovic. "This is the action that is meant to leave all of us without Studio B."

Mr. Kojadinovic said the station did not have the money to pay for using its frequencies.

Mr. Kojadinovic was fined $20,000 in the case.

The police officer, Branko Djuric, was accused on a Studio B program of involvement in a vehicular accident in October in which Mr. Draskovic was injured.

Mr. Draskovic has said the crash was an assassination attempt disguised as an accident.

The judge rejected Studio B's defense that it could not be held responsible for comments made by guests on live programs.

Mr. Kojadinovic met tonight with major opposition leaders in Serbia, accusing President Slobodan Milosevic's government of the "most brutal action" in its crackdown against the station.

A statement issued after the meeting called for an end to all pressure and threatened street protests if it continued.

In their own statement, the police denied that they had been involved in the raid and accused Studio B of "another malicious and incorrect report fabricated in that media house."

Pictures from the Torlak center, broadcast on the Studio B evening news, showed bloodstains on the floor of the transmission station.

The two workers who were attacked were taken to a hospital for treatment. One had his head bandaged.

Mr. Kojadinovic said: "The five attackers arrived in a police jeep with the siren howling. The workers believed that they came for an inspection and opened the gate, after which the beating began."

The transmissions were temporarily interrupted to 400,000 viewers and one million radio listeners. Another independent outlet, B2-92 radio, which broadcasts on a Studio B frequency, was also cut off. Some equipment also was confiscated.

The chief technician of Studio B, Dusan Markovic, said the attackers were obviously extremely skilled and able to distinguish which "cables belonged to independent media." Several state-run stations also have equipment and transmitters at the site.

The government may be trying to crack down on major independent news media ahead of local and federal elections this year. Studio B has broadcast programs that criticized Mr. Milosevic.  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


114 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


April 27, 1999, FINAL


Yugoslavia's man of courage speaks out


BYLINE: Maj.-Gen. Lewis MacKenzie


SECTION: News; A6


LENGTH: 608 words


Yugoslavia's Deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic is receiving a good deal of press after indicating in an interview with Studio B, the most liberal of the Belgrade TV stations, that Yugoslavia should accept an armed UN peacekeeping force in Kosovo once the bombing stops. This is the first time that any member of the Yugoslav government has made such a statement, at least in public.

Mr. Draskovic is probably the best-recognized if not the best-known Serb outside of Yugoslavia, except for President Slobodan Milosevic. Mention to anyone the anti-Milosevic protest marches of 1996 in downtown Belgrade and the image of a tall, athletically built, bearded marcher in the front ranks comes to mind. 

That person was -- and is -- Vuk Draskovic. He has been the president of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the major opposition party in Serbia, since 1990. Like so many politicians in the Balkans that buck the system, he has been imprisoned numerous times since 1991 due to his anti-war and anti-regime activities.

Born in 1946, he graduated as a lawyer in 1968. He is the author of several novels and for a period was a journalist for the Tanjug press agency.

Vuk, as he likes to be called, has a strong following, particularly in Belgrade, and as a result President Milosevic opted to appoint him deputy prime minister instead of leaving him in prison.

Realistically, he has little influence in the decision-making process; however, he can generate a good deal of media attention with his views.

I had two long meetings with Mr. Draskovic while I was in Belgrade three weeks ago. On camera, of course, he was keeping to the party line. But off the record, Mr. Draskovic is refreshingly honest and objective. Quite frankly, he probably is not cut out to be a politician and has been thrust into the fray by circumstances.

To my surprise, we agreed about almost everything that has to be done to bring the war to a conclusion.

A ceasefire is essential before any political negotiations take place. A temporary, fixed-time ceasefire would be acceptable. Confidence-building measures should be implemented immediately. Reconciliation protocol would be developed by the international community and refugees would return to Kosovo. Yugoslavia would welcome Partners for Peace status within NATO, as was discussed at Rambouillet.

Anyone within Yugoslavia, including Serbs and Kosovo Albanians, suspected of committing war crimes should be charged and tried.

On the key issue of an international force in Kosovo, Mr. Draskovic agreed that the best solution is a UN-led mission made up of troops from countries outside the conflict. He actually went one step further and suggested that Kosovo be declared a UN protectorate for a period of perhaps three years.

Mr. Draskovic is accepting considerable risk with his statements of the past 24 hours. He is no fool and might well be of the opinion that his security is somewhat guaranteed by his popular following.

If he were to be murdered, as an outspoken Belgrade newspaper editor was just more than one month ago, it could well spark a popular uprising in Belgrade. The West has to be careful not to cosy up too obviously to Mr. Draskovic as that would only alienate him even more from Mr. Milosevic. And that's not a comfortable position for anyone in the middle of a war where the rules for internal security are, to put it mildly, a bit loose.

Maj.-Gen. Lewis MacKenzie, now retired, commanded UN troops during the siege of Sarajevo in the Bosnian civil war of 1992. His column, A Soldier's View, will appear in the Citizen for the duration of Operation Allied Force.


LOAD-DATE: April 27, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Black & White Photo: The Associated Press / Yugoslav Deputy Premier Vuk Draskovic said last night in Belgrade that his government was ready to accept a peace deal calling for a UN presence that would include troops from NATO countries if necessary. Draskovic, said he believed he was expressing the views of President Slobodan Milosevic, who has rejected all proposals for foreign troops.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

115 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


April 27, 1999, FINAL


A voice of reason rings out in a dangerous age: Yugoslavian deputy prime minister Vuk Draskovic is putting forth sensible ideas to bring peace to his country, and risking his life doing it.


BYLINE: Lewis MacKenzie


SECTION: Editorial; A13


LENGTH: 584 words


Yugoslavia's deputy prime minister Vuk Draskovic is receiving a good deal of press after indicating in an interview with Studio B, the most liberal of the Belgrade TV stations, that Yugoslavia should accept an armed United Nations peacekeeping force in Kosovo once the bombing stops.

This is the first time that any member of the Yugoslav government has made such a statement, at least in public.

Draskovic is probably the best-recognized if not the best-known Serb outside of Yugoslavia, except for President Slobodan Milosevic. Mention to anyone the anti-Milosevic protest marches of 1996 in downtown Belgrade and the image of a tall, athletically built, bearded marcher in the front ranks comes to mind. 

That person was Vuk Draskovic. He has been the president of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the major opposition party in Serbia since 1990.

Like so many politicians in the Balkans who back the system, he has been imprisoned numerous times since 1991 due to his anti-war and anti-regime activities.

Born in 1946, he graduated as a lawyer in 1968. He is the author of several novels and for a period was a journalist for the Tanjug press agency.

Vuk, as he likes to be called, has a strong following, particularly in Belgrade. As a result, Milosevic opted to appoint him deputy prime minister instead of leaving him in prison.

Realistically, he has little influence in the decision-making process; however, he can generate a good deal of media attention to his views.

I had two long meetings with Draskovic while I was in Belgrade three weeks ago. On camera, of course, he was keeping to the party line. But off the record, Draskovic is refreshingly honest and objective.

Quite frankly, he probably is not cut out to be a politician and has been thrust into the fray by circumstances.

To my surprise we agreed about everything that has to be done to bring the war to a conclusion.

A ceasefire is essential before any political negotiations take place. A temporary, fixed-time ceasefire would be acceptable. Confidence-building measures should be implemented immediately.

Reconciliation protocol would be developed by the international community and refugees would return to Kosovo. Yugoslavia would welcome Partners for Peace status within NATO, as was discussed at Rambouillet.

Anyone within Yugoslavia, including Serbs and Kosovo Albanians who are suspected of committing war crimes, should be charged and tried.

On the key issue of an international force in Kosovo, Draskovic agreed that the best solution is a UN-led mission made up of troops from countries outside the conflict.

He actually went one step further and suggested that Kosovo be declared a UN protectorate for a period of perhaps three years.

Draskovic is accepting considerable risk by his statements of the past 24 hours. He is no fool and might well be of the opinion that his security is somewhat guaranteed by his popular following.

If he were to be murdered, as an outspoken Belgrade newspaper editor was just over a month ago, it could well spark a popular uprising in Belgrade. The West has to be careful not to cosy up too obviously to Draskovic as that would only alienate him even more from Milosevic.

And that is not a comfortable position for anyone in the middle of a war where the rules for internal security are, to put it mildly, a bit loose.

Maj.- Gen. Lewis MacKenzie, now retired, commanded UN troops during the siege of Sarajevo in the Bosnian civil war of 1992.


LOAD-DATE: April 27, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Photo: Vadim Ghirda, Associated Press / VUK DRASKOVIC: His moderate proposals could stand him in bad stead with the extremists in Serbia.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

116 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


April 2, 2001


Milosevic behind bars


SECTION: CITY EDITION; EDITORIAL PAGE; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 551 words


The arrest of Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade yesterday on charges of corruption and abuse of office is welcome indeed as a confirmation that the young Serbian democracy is coming to terms with the recent disastrous past of its country. Milosevic's party and collaborators in the military and security forces turned the last decade into a cauldron of oppression and war for the nations of ex-Yugoslavia and surrounding states, simultaneously enriching themselves. His arrest on these charges should be recognised by the international community which has put such pressure on Serbia to come to terms with Milosevic as a first step on the road to making him account for his crimes against humanity at the war crimes tribunals in The Hague. 

Milosevic's decision to turn Yugoslavia's disintegration to his political advantage by asserting Serb nationalism against its former constituent nations enabled him to mobilise its surviving security apparatus and enrich himself in the process. These latter crimes are the one with which the new Serbian government is now coming to terms. Their painful realisation of how much damage they had sustained and time lost has been brought home by normalising relations with the rest of the world since last autumn's dramatic events which removed Milosevic from power. They have simultaneously had to come to terms with international pressure to bring Milosevic and others charged with war crimes at The Hague to justice in that city. Inevitably such pressure has been controversial within the anti-Milosevic movement. The new president of what remains of the Yugoslav federation, Mr Vojislav Kostunica, has opposed the efforts to bring Milosevic before The Hague tribunal on grounds of his State's law and sovereignty.

Younger members of the government are more willing to contemplate that possibility after he has faced trial for corruption in Belgrade. He should be tried on both counts. But the timing of that outcome will depend on how the evolution of Serbian democracy is orchestrated with international pressure to bring Milosevic to The Hague, for example by denying it aid for reconstruction. Yesterday's positive reaction from American and European leaders appears to take account of these realities. It is to be hoped there will not be premature action to force the Serb government to go further than they are politically capable of doing, despite the pressing need to validate the trial process in The Hague. Milosevic's first and last opportunist resort to Serb nationalism occurred in Kosovo. The fallout from that crisis is still with us there and in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, for the last two weeks have tested the European Union's new crisis management apparatus to its limits. On balance it has succeeded in finding a war to support the Macedonian government's military campaign against Albanian rebels in the Tetovo region and maintain pressure on them to organise a political dialogue on minority rights capable of forestalling the rebels' appeal while keeping the moderate Albanian parties in the coalition. That tentative success is a great relief to surrounding states and the wider Europe of which the Balkans must increasingly be recognised as a constituent part. This achievement very much remains to be consolidated.


LOAD-DATE: April 3, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2001 The Irish Times


117 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE BRISTOL POST


May 22, 1999


Earthmother


SECTION: Features, Pg.31


LENGTH: 398 words


 

The Kosovo crisis

HOW many times does it need to be said? This war is mad and should be stopped. Violence is escalating in Kosovo and Serbia. Back home we are fed Orwellian propaganda. Remember the 1984 Newsspeak slogan: War is Peace? 

Djorde e-mailed from Nis in Serbia: "I counted 18 explosions in the city. Help, this is past normal reasoning! People are mad with fear. Please, send this message somewhere! Help."

If I was in charge now, I'd stop the bombing and indict Milosevic, Clinton and Blair as war criminals. All three count as deranged abusers in my books.

There are complex reasons for war - but we are only getting the heart- squeeze version. Rather than scenes of carnage, we are shown pictures of Blair looking sorrowfully at an Albanian refugee. It doesn't make sense. If the West really cares, why didn't we support anti-Milosevic democratic movements?

Why are we spending billions on murdering innocent civilians and giving less than one percent for refugee relief? But we only get the Biggles version: Milosevic is a Hitler. Please don't dilute the significance of the Second World War.

If Milosevic is committing genocide then genocide is happening all over the world. There are at least 140 armed conflicts in the globe with catastrophic numbers of refugees fleeing for their lives. The world is in crisis and it's time to look for new solutions.

Might is Right is an outmoded, crude and brutal way to deal with conflict. It stems from the primitive belief that there are only two positions: top-dog or under-dog, powerful or powerless. Come on, use your imagination! There is another way. Forget that hoary old idea that you don't reward a bully. Prison research shows that educational and work opportunities work best in keeping bullies out of trouble.

Wouldn't it have been better to take up Milosevic's pre-war offer of Kosovan autonomy and send in tons of aid and international human rights workers? All conflict stems from scarcity of resources, be it battlezone, workplace or home. If you think someone is getting more than you, you want to claw it back.

The fact is there is enough to go round - if only we could use our rational faculties to share it out more fairly. Isn't it better to reform the unequal political and economic situation that produces scarcity, rather than wait until it gets to the point of war?


LOAD-DATE: May 25, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1999 Bristol United Press


118 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


January 29, 1997, Wednesday


Kosovo endgame


BYLINE: Leader


SECTION: Pg. 16


LENGTH: 324 words


 

WATCH out for another Balkan explosion in the obscure province of Kosovo, the region from where in 1989 Slobodan Milosevic, then the Stalinist president of all Yugoslavia, launched his Serbian nationalist drive. On the battlefield of Kosovo Polje, where Serbs suffered a catastrophic defeat under swords of the Turks 600 years ago, Milosevic cried for a Greater Serbia and triggered wars in Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia which dismembered the Yugoslav federation. 

With his authority now waning in rump Serbia, as opposition to his totalitarian, economically disastrous rule grows, Milosevic is again playing the Kosovo card, hoping to tap raw Serbian pride.

In Kosovo, ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs nine to one. For all Serbs, Kosovo is holy ground, a symbol of the eternal threat by the Islamic hordes to people spawned by the Christian Orthodox book (with Marx's works thrown in later).

The Albanians have therefore been historically subjugated, and continue to be repressed. But suddenly -in parallel with the prolonged anti-Milosevic demonstrations being led in Belgrade by the Zajedno opposition coalition - the underground Albanian independence movement in Kosovo has acquired new energy.

There have been several attacks on Serb security police and the Serb rector of Pristina University in Kosovo was critically injured in a car bombing this month.

In a subtle twist of state propaganda, Zajedno, which is no more sympathetic than Milosevic's Socialist Party to the Albanians, has been accused of fomenting the Kosovo unrest. Analysts believe Milosevic will use this as a pretext for declaring a state of emergency, arguing that national security is threatened, and crack down harshly on both Zajedno and Kosovo's Albanian majority.

Such trouble in Kosovo could be the signal for a violent endgame to the Yugoslav/Serbia crisis which Milosevic began all those years ago in pursuit of absolute power.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1997 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


119 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


September 22, 1999, Wednesday


TENS OF THOUSANDS JOIN ANTI-MILOSEVIC RALLIES


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 15


LENGTH: 725 words


 

FROM the northern city of Novi Sad to Leskovac in the south Serbs took to the streets last night to demand the resignation of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

Yugoslavia's opposition movement, the Alliance for Change, held rallies in 20 of Yugoslavia's largest cities and vowed to continue demonstrating every day at 6pm until Mr Milosevic resigns.

The rally drew moderate crowds in most cities, but Alliance leaders are convinced the crowds will grow in size.

The biggest rally was at Republic Square in Belgrade, drawing tens of thousands of citizens under a persistent drizzle. In the same spot where Serbs once demonstrated against NATO's bombing, opposition leaders blamed Mr Milosevic for the country's woes and vowed to topple his "criminal regime". 

The Holy Synod of the Serbian Orthodox Church issued a statement over the weekend calling on Serbs to put aside individual and party interests for the good of the nation.

"What are a few bruises to secure our nation's future?" asked Kristina Peric, an opposition leader from Valjevo.

The principal speaker, Zoran Djindjic, the president of the Democratic Party, told the crowd it was time for action.

"We all know that we're not here just to talk, but to discuss what to do.

"Let's do what everyone knows must be done. That man crouching in his bunker knows what's coming. This is not fun and games. We have a difficult job. We can't gather on squares for the next 100 years."

After Mr Djindjic's speech, the crowd marched to Radio Television Serbia then to the offices of Politika, the state run newspaper.

The march followed the same path as in 1996 and 1997 when Belgrade residents demonstrated for three months after Milosevic overturned municipal election results.

The crowd steadily grew in size as the demonstrators wound through Belgrade's streets chanting "Thieves" and "It has begun."

The Alliance for Change had been preparing for yesterday's protest all summer, organising dozens of rallies after NATO ended its 78-day bombing campaign of Yugoslavia.

Efforts to unite Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement and the Alliance for Change collapsed last month at a Belgrade rally. Mr Draskovic wants to go to elections under the Milosevic government while the Alliance is demanding that Mr Milosevic resign, and then have elections under a transition government.

The Alliance, a coalition of 35 political organisations, last week elected the extremely popular Dragoslav Avramovic to head an eventual transition government.

As the former head of the Yugoslav National Bank, Mr Avramovic, now in his 80s, stopped hyper-inflation in 1993 by pegging the Yugoslav dinar to the Deutschmark.

Yugoslavia's politically jaded citizens are no longer easily goaded to demonstrate despite Milosevic's abysmal standing.

Several large demonstrations since 1991 failed to produce results. But Alliance leaders say this time will be different. "Last time, we didn't take the final step," said Alliance co-ordinator Vladan Batic. "This time, we're going all the way."

The Alliance is hoping that economic frustration and the looming winter will get people out in larger numbers.

The country's shattered infrastructure and economic isolation have left citizens with the lowest salaries in Europe.

Belgrade's Institute for Foreign Trade noted that Yugoslavia's economy has returned to an agrarian economy similar to 1945.

While some are sceptical that the Alliance can by itself topple Mr Milosevic in the immediate future, others say that anything can happen. Mr Draskovic said his party would also take to the streets if the Milosevic government does not call early elections.

"I am optimistic we will have massive support on the streets.

My impression is that we've reached the bottom line. They will come out because they have nothing left," said Milan Protic, a historian and president of the Defence political group.

"People speak of fatigue, but I think that will eventually contribute to this movement.

We're facing winter with a shortage of electricity. These objective problems will bring Milosevic to the end."

Opposition leaders agree this is a last opportunity. "Every morning you should splash cold water on your face and say 'We can't pass up this opportunity'," said Mr Djindjic last night.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


120 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


September 7, 1999


Milosevic's top ally reported to be under house arrest in Belgrade


BYLINE: Gillian Sandford in Belgrade


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 669 words


Gillian Sandford in Belgrade

Serbia's president, Milan Milutinovic, is said to be under house arrest and to have fallen out of favour with his long-time political ally, the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, according to an opposition spokesman - a report the government denies.

Mr Milutinovic, a member of Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia, has been indicted for war crimes by the Hague tribunal in connection with events in Kosovo this year. Before he was Serbian president, he was the Yugoslav foreign minister and Yugoslav ambassador to Greece.

The reports of his confinement come at a time when many of Mr Milosevic's circle are rumoured to be increasingly concerned about their future - either because they are sought by the Hague tribunal or because they are blocked from leaving the country while they remain on a list of 300 Yugoslav officials unable to travel to European Union countries. 

Mr Milutinovic is also on the list. Ironically, he fought his presidential election campaign on the internationalist slogan: 'Serbia and the world.'

The concerns about Mr Milutinovic were first voiced on Friday by a leading official in the New Democracy party, Zarko Jokanovic. He said: 'There are indications that the Serbian president, Milan Milutinovic, is under house arrest, that he is prevented from performing his duties, that he has fallen into disfavour with the ruling family and that his life is threatened."

Mr Jokanovic called for the creation of an independent commission to investigate whether Mr Milutinovic was capable of carrying out his constitutional duties.

Mr Milutinovic has not been prominent in public life for several weeks. A fortnight ago the Belgrade press reported that he was in hospital with high blood pressure.

It is difficult to confirm exactly what, if anything, has happened to him. The government has dismissed the reports, and Serbia's deputy information minister, Radmila Vasic, said Mr Jokanovic was speaking 'absolute rubbish".

She added: 'Milutinovic works daily and there are no problems with his work."

But the rumours of his confinement surfaced again at the weekend. Nebojsa Covic, president of the Democratic Alternative, said: 'This has to be checked, but there are indications that this is true and that some other people from the same party are in a similar situation." He did not say who the other people were.

The claims come at a time when President Milosevic appears to have ridden out the wave of opposition protests that swept towns across the country in the summer, when thousands gathered, calling for him to resign.

Some opposition leaders are seeking to regroup and regain the momentum they lost after a disastrous demonstration in Belgrade on August 19, when their bitter rivalries burst into the open at what was to have been a major show of anti-Milosevic defiance.

The umbrella opposition movement Alliance for Change has scheduled another rally in Belgrade for September 21, which it says will herald widespread protests, including strike action aimed at toppling the Milosevic regime.

But the alliance's failure to capitalise on events earlier this summer has left its credibility low, and it is not certain that the new protests will be widely supported.

According to an independent poll by the Partnership agency in mid-August, the alliance is a small group which is supported by only 14.8% of Serbs.

If it were to unite with the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic, it would be far better placed. But Mr Draskovic is blamed by many in the alliance for sabotaging the August 19 rally, so that a reunion seems unlikely.

Spokesmen for Mr Milosevic's party and for Mr Draskovic are talking about the possibility of early elections. Commentators say that even if elections were held soon, they do not expect a shift in the balance of power.

According to the Partnership poll, Mr Draskovic's party would win 18% of the vote, and the governing coalition would win 24%.


LOAD-DATE: September 7, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Guardian Newspapers Limited


121 of 348 DOCUMENTS


San Jose Mercury News (California)


October 13, 1999 Wednesday MORNING FINAL EDITION


FEW SERBS FIND CRASH ACCIDENTAL FOUR DIED WHEN TRUCK HIT OPPOSITION PARTY CONVOY


BYLINE: LORI MONTGOMERY, Mercury News Berlin Bureau


SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 4A


LENGTH: 770 words


DATELINE: LAZAREVAC, Yugoslavia


On a lonely road south of Belgrade, a truck loaded with sand plowed into a convoy carrying Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic and four others to a Sunday picnic last week.

Only Draskovic survived.

Since then, the driver of the killer truck has vanished and the truck's license number has been wiped from official rolls. Witnesses are scared, and few harbor any doubt that the fiery Oct. 3 crash was an attempt to assassinate Draskovic, the strongest rival to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. 

With thousands flooding the streets nightly for anti-Milosevic rallies, Belgrade is abuzz with speculation that the attack means the strongman is nervous. Political observers are anxious to see whether Draskovic's brush with death will push him to join the rallies, setting an explosive charge under a so-far-ineffectual campaign to topple Milosevic.

"We hope Vuk will now wholeheartedly join the opposition, but we'll see about that," said Milan Protic, a leader of the Alliance for Change, which is staging daily rallies calling for Milosevic's ouster. "He's obviously under a lot of pressure -- from all sides."

Not a united front

Draskovic, 52, is the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), the largest opposition party in Yugoslavia, but his divisions with other opposition leaders for years have hindered Milosevic's ouster.

In the latest dispute, the Alliance for Change has taken to the streets since late September, trying to force Milosevic to resign and clear the way for early elections. Milosevic is considered vulnerable since an 11-week NATO air war devastated Yugoslavia last spring and forced him to cede control of the Serbian province of Kosovo to international peacekeepers.

The powerful and charismatic Draskovic has stayed away from the protests. He wants the opposition to push for elections while Milosevic is still in office. But in recent weeks, Draskovic began sending signals that he was ready to join forces with the Alliance for Change.

A few days before the crash, Studio B television, which Draskovic controls, began broadcasting the rallies -- including shots of police beating marchers headed for Milosevic's wealthy Belgrade neighborhood. Then Draskovic attended an opposition round-table meeting where the feuding factions finally began to resolve their differences.

A few days later, Draskovic and an entourage including his brother-in-law Veselin Boskovic and at least three bodyguards set off from Belgrade for a picnic and political event. Boskovic drove Draskovic in an Audi sedan. The three bodyguards followed in a BMW.

According to SPO officials, as the convoy neared the village of Lazarevac, 40 miles south of Belgrade, a large green truck swerved out of the oncoming lane and sideswiped the Audi. Boskovic died of a broken neck. Draskovic, knocked unconscious by the erupting air bag, suffered minor injuries.

The truck then smashed head-on into the BMW and burst into flames. The bodyguards died instantly. The driver of the truck had vanished when police arrived minutes later.

Since then, police have produced no information about the truck. The serial number is visible on its charred chassis, but they haven't found the owner. The license number -- Belgrade 994-704 -- is the only one missing from a long sequence of numbers in the registry.

"That police couldn't find the tag, the owner or the driver even after finding the chassis number is totally unbelievable," said SPO attorney Borivoje Borovic, who is conducting an independent inquiry. "Obviously, they don't want to get involved in this investigation in a meaningful way."

More curious, while police have been questioning -- and intimidating -- dozens of residents of Lazarevac, they have not interviewed Draskovic, the only surviving witness.

The only substantive statement of any kind from police headquarters has been the assertion that Draskovic's convoy was speeding, which Draskovic denies. Authorities have referred the case to a local court in Lazarevac, which is treating it as a routine accident.

Begging to differ

Draskovic, SPO officials and other opposition leaders quickly denied that.

"It is an assassination attempt. Those who organized it should consider what will happen to them," Draskovic told Studio B. "By the grace of God, Iwas the only one left alive."

"The elimination of political adversaries by staging car accidents is a method already seen in these parts," said a New Democracy party statement. "The perpetrators are obviously in big trouble as they will resort even to murder in order to accomplish their dark objectives."


LOAD-DATE: October 25, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, background, follows his mourning cousins during the funeral Oct. 5 of his brother-in-law Veselin Boskovic, who was killed Oct. 3.

122 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


September 5, 2000, Tuesday, FINAL


Vote marks 'new beginning' for Yugoslavia: Milosevic's opponent pledges to 'stop decline' of Serbs


BYLINE: John Nadler


SECTION: News; A6


LENGTH: 916 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


BELGRADE -- Amid fears of war and election fraud, Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the newly founded Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) alliance, officially kicked off his campaign to replace Slobodan Milosevic as Yugoslavia's president by promising to ''stop the decline of the (Serb) state and nation.''

He made the pledge in Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital, late last week during a brief party convention that introduced the DOS's platform and candidates for parliamentary and presidential elections Sept. 24.

''This is a new beginning for us,'' university professor Marija Bogdanovic said afterwards. ''I cried listening to his speech.'' 

The opposition has reason to be hopeful. Mr. Kostunica, a popular figure in Serb politics, is leading the largest anti-Milosevic movement to be assembled in Serbia in years. With Yugoslavia on the verge of war and economic collapse, Mr. Milosevic's days in power should be numbered.

But Yugoslavia is split between those who think the election will usher in a new leader and and a new beginning, and those who argue the vote can only strengthen Mr. Milosevic, who has artfully and brutally fended off challengers since coming to power a dozen years ago.

Despite Mr. Milosevic's iron rule, many of his opponents say they have a winning formula and candidate. In his keynote convention speech, Mr. Kostunica, a straight-taking law professor, reached out to voters with a 10-point platform for getting Serbia back on track. The DOS, echoing U. S. Republican party rhetoric from the 1990s, calls the platform its ''Contract with Serbia.''

The platform points include promises for ''honest'' government, economic development, renewed ties with the West and an end to trade sanctions, anti-crime initiatives, a peaceful resolution of the crisis in Montenegro, and ''fair wages for honest work.''

Mr. Kostunica's more dynamic promises include bringing stability to Kosovo, assurances DOS's candidates will not try to profit from elected office, and not to seek revenge against political opponents should the DOS win.

Revenge is a sensitive issue, especially among pro-government bureaucrats fearful a change in regime will lead to their ouster and persecution.

''During the last 10 years, they (the Milosevic regime) have created another artificial face of Serbia and unfortunately the world believes this image,'' Mr. Kostunica said. ''We will present the true face of Serbia.''

Cheering conventioneers appeared to be impressed by Mr. Kostunica's words and style. Clearly, Mr. Kostunica, an obscure opposition figure until his recent ascendency to the top of DOS, walks and talks differently than other Serb politicians.

The DOS leader has a reputation for being a nationalist and a conservative. But he has so far refused to use reactionary rhetoric to appeal to Serbian hardliners in the way that other opposition leaders -- such as Vuk Draskovic, the now diminished leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) in hiding in Montenegro after a recent assassination attempt, and Vojislav Seselj, the reactionary leader of the Serbian Radical Party (SRS) -- have done.

Mr. Kostunica's strongest attributes appear to be a reputation for honesty and a squeaky-clean record.

Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Seselj have both cut deals with Mr. Milosevic for personal and political gain. Mr. Seselj's Radicals are a cornerstone of Mr. Milosevic's parliamentary coalition, and Mr. Draskovic abandoned his leadership of student protests three years ago to become a deputy prime minister in the Milosevic government.

Mr. Draskovic has refused to stand behind Mr. Kostunica in a united front against Mr. Milosevic as both the SPO and SRS run their own candidates for president.

But even with the concern that opposition votes will be divided on election day, Mr. Kostunica's supporters are optimistic.

''I think we'll be successful,'' declared DOS parliamentary candidate Jeljko Ciric. ''I wouldn't be involved otherwise.''

Public opinion polls predict a DOS victory. According to an editor for the Belgrade newsmagazine NIN, Mr. Kostunica now enjoys about 35-per-cent support in Yugoslavia, compared to 24 per cent for Mr. Milosevic. Poll data released in July put Mr. Kostunica's approval rating at 42 per cent, and Mr. Milosevic's at 28 per cent.

NIN puts support for Mr. Draskovic's SPO in the single digits (eight per cent), but has no idea how much support the Radicals enjoy due to SRS leader Mr. Seselj's order that supporters not co-operate with pollsters.

Top officials in Yugoslavia's ruling coalition formally declared Mr. Milosevic's candidacy for re-election Sunday, submitting the results of a petition drive intended to show off his support and counter the polls showing the president trailing Mr. Kostunica.

The petition drive reportedly collected nearly 1.6 million signatures supporting the president even though only 25,000 are required for a candidate.

''This clearly shows people's support for Milosevic's policies of defending national sovereignty, resistance against aggressors, of reconstruction and development,'' said Gorica Gajevic, the secretary general of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS).

But Mr. Ciric predicts Mr. Kostunica will triumph on a second ballot, which will be required if there is no clear majority winner on the first ballot.

''Kostunica will win, '' said Mr. Ciric, ''if Milosevic doesn't create a crisis in Montenegro or Kosovo, or if he doesn't cheat.''


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

123 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The New York Times


October 14, 2002 Monday  
Late Edition - Final


Low Turnout Invalidates the Results of Serbia's Election


BYLINE: By DANIEL SIMPSON


SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 664 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 13


Weary of political infighting and unsure of which reformist faction to support, more than half the Serbian electorate did not vote in today's presidential election, rendering the result invalid.

Under legislation dating from Slobodan Milosevic's autocratic rule in the 1990's, if less than 50 percent of the voters turn out, the election must be held again within two months.

Just 45.4 percent ventured into heavy rain to cast their ballots today, ignoring warnings from both presidential candidates that a failed election would only drag out the political instability that is holding back Serbia's economic recovery.

Serbia's current president, Milan Milutinovic, has been indicted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague, where Mr. Milosevic is on trial, and is widely expected to surrender once his term expires at the end of this year. 

Preliminary results from today's vote showed that Vojislav Kostunica, a conservative nationalist who replaced Mr. Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia, easily defeated Miroljub Labus, a pro-Western liberal and architect of the government's economic reform program.

Mr. Kostunica, who is seeking a new job before the Yugoslav federation grouping Serbia and Montenegro is abolished, won 66.7 percent of the vote against 31.3 percent for Mr. Labus, according to Belgrade's Center for Free Elections and Democracy, which monitored the ballot.

Both men are veterans of the disparate alliance of reformers that ousted Mr. Milosevic two years ago but they represent two rival factions that quickly emerged from the anti-Milosevic movement.

A bitter power struggle between the two camps -- one led by Mr. Kostunica, the other by the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic -- has brought reforms to a standstill and alienated voters desperate for living standards to improve.

"Serbs are tired of political squabbling," said Jovan Maric, a psychiatrist and prominent commentator on social issues. "These elections were a slap in the face for Djindjic. They have sent a signal to the government that it needs to do something dramatic to make people's lives better."

Apart from the state broadcaster RTS and a couple of small independent channels, television networks did not broadcast special election programs tonight, reflecting a widespread lack of interest in the vote.

Many observers fear that politicians will now devote their attention to electioneering rather than the economic and political reforms Serbia needs to recover from a decade of wars, international isolation and impoverishment under Mr. Milosevic.

But if the campaign is as contentious as this one has been, it could prove just as difficult to motivate the electorate in two months.

"People don't see anything to vote for and neither candidate gave them much of an incentive," one Western diplomat said. "After Labus lost the first round, there were only two conceivable outcomes in the runoff -- a Kostunica victory and a failed election. Both just mean further political uncertainty."

Although Mr. Labus said he had not yet decided whether to run again, he is unlikely to have Mr. Djindjic's backing after today's result.

Mr. Kostunica, who is Serbia's most popular politician, is demanding that a general election be held as soon as possible in the hope of gaining control of Parliament.

As Serbian president, he would be better placed to persuade some of the 17 parties in Mr. Djindjic's coalition to join his camp and rob the government of its majority. Political survival for Mr. Djindjic, who is personally unpopular with voters, largely depends on his ability to thwart Mr. Kostunica's ambitions.

Unless these two men can reconcile their differences or one of them wins, their power struggle will continue to dictate post-Milosevic politics.

"The problems with our politicians is vanity," said Radmilo Kljajic, a columnist for Serbia's leading daily newspaper, Politika. "The government did not actually implement changes, but tried to hang onto power using Milosevic's laws."


URL: http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: October 14, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Voters in Belgrade cast their ballots yesterday in Serbia's presidential election, but there were not enough votes cast for the results to be valid. (Associated Press)

124 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 23, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


U.S. Anti-Milosevic Plan Faces Major Test at Polls


BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ


SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 5; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 1224 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22


After more than seven years opposing President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia on the battlefield and in the negotiating room, the Clinton administration is making one last stand against him -- among the voters.

In a high-profile strategy that began a year ago, the administration has helped finance an opposition movement that is backing Vojislav Kostunica in his campaign to unseat Mr. Milosevic from the Yugoslav presidency in voting on Sunday. 

Even if, as almost everyone expects, Mr. Milosevic simply declares himself the victor, Washington is hoping that angry voters will take to the streets in a way that eventually drives him from office, much as Ferdinand E. Marcos was ousted in the Philippines in 1986.

The strategy largely reflects the thinking of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who has made democracy a centerpiece of her tenure and has cast Mr. Milosevic as her most bitter enemy.

But the plan, which has ranged from bringing fractious opposition leaders here to meet Dr. Albright in her seventh-floor suite at the State Department to pumping million of dollars into voter education groups and the independent media, has its risks.

For one thing, Mr. Kostunica is a Serbian nationalist who does not necessarily support the NATO presence in Kosovo. Without an official American presence in Serbia, it is difficult to gauge how much of the $25 million spent on the opposition over the last year has been fruitfully used. In fact, the blatant American campaign against Mr. Milosevic has given him a powerful theme for his campaign.

The administration officials who devised the strategy said they believed that Mr. Milosevic, regardless of the vote tallies, would manipulate the results and declare victory. In the best case, the officials said, they hoped that opposition protests would eventually lead Mr. Milosevic's all-important army and security forces to turn against him.

"The people of Yugoslavia are standing up," said James C. O'Brien, special adviser to President Clinton and Dr. Albright on democracy in the Balkans. "They believe it's time for change. There is the potential for seismic change in Yugoslavia."

The administration, Mr. O'Brien suggested, hopes that the elections will provide a "crucial moment, like the Berlin Wall falling." But he said Washington would settle for a "tide turning."

The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, noted recently that "people power" spelled the end in Manila in 1986 and that the same movement could occur now in Belgrade.

Other officials acknowledged, however, that it was unclear how motivated the opposition would be to protest, whether it could rouse a weary population to rally in great numbers and whether the security forces would turn against Mr. Milosevic.

To encourage opposition activities in Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, the United States has spent $25 million in the last year, according to Donald L. Pressley, the assistant administrator at the United States Agency for International Development. Nearly half of the money, $11 million, was spent on helping unions, media organizations and civic associations, Mr. Pressley said.

Two groups here, the National Democratic Institute and the International Republican Institute, were allocated $4 million to help groups in Serbia campaign door to door and to develop other get-out-the-vote techniques, Mr. Pressley said. Much of the remaining money went to Serbian cities like Nis and Novi Sad, which are run by independent mayors.

Because American officials are barred from Serbia, a satellite embassy, under the direction of Ambassador William Montgomery, was established in Budapest in the summer to be the fulcrum for the effort to build democracy in Serbia. From Budapest, conferences have been organized in southern Hungary to bring Serbians together with turnout experts from Central Europe.

The Agency for International Development has given contracts to establish nongovernmental organizations like Freedom House and the German Marshall Fund, which give grants to Central European groups that have access to Serbia, Mr. Pressley said.

Thus, O.K. 98, a group that helped unseat Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar in Slovakia in 1998, is working alongside Serbian groups in door-to-door canvassing, he said.

In Serbia, there have been complaints that some of the foreign activity enriches individuals with cash, cell phones and faxes. Mr. Pressley said that $1.5 million of the $25 million effort was earmarked for audits and that A.I.D.'s Budapest operation for Serbia included an auditor.

Administration officials, following their usual policy, refused to confirm or deny the existence of covert operations in Yugoslavia.

One main reason for optimism in the administration is that officials apparently believe that their carefully devised effort to build democracy has helped magnify interest in the opposition candidate, Mr. Kostunica.

Rarely in more than seven years of dealing with Mr. Milosevic has the Clinton administration sounded so upbeat. Nor have officials been so willing to advertise their policy. One official said this week that he had to warn about too much euphoria inside the State Department.

The administration has had little to do with Mr. Kostunica, a law professor who has maintained a fierce independence from American policy and who has said that if he came to power he would not send Mr. Milosevic to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague. The tribunal indicted Mr. Milosevic last year for what it said were crimes committed by his security forces in Kosovo.

Dr. Albright has watched enthusiastically as more than a dozen parties in Serbia's famously fractured opposition decided to back Mr. Kostunica. Administration officials are also upbeat because, they say, they believe that Mr. Milosevic miscalculated by suddenly calling the elections in July, making this his first direct electoral test since 1992.

The unanswered question in the strategy is what happens after the vote. In his 13 years in power, Mr. Milosevic has repeatedly shown his ability to maneuver, manipulating allies and rivals to maintain his grip.

Some administration officials said they believed that if Mr. Milosevic did not lose by a wide margin and, therefore, did not resort to extensive fraud, there would be a less compelling case for protest.

Other officials argue that ordinary people, buffeted by a bad economy and accepting of official propaganda that the opposition is backed by foreign interests, lack the passion for an enduring show of protest.

Other questions concern whether the police and soldiers are prepared to use large-scale force against fellow Serbs. If they are, that raises a question about how much the administration should encourage protest.

"Is this going to be like 1956?" asked one senior administration official, recalling the Western hints to the Hungarians that help would be on the way if the Soviet Union quashed the uprising.

In the last several days, Bratislav Grubacic, a Serbian journalist who is widely read in the Western diplomatic community, has warned that Mr. Milosevic will attempt to stay in power at any cost. "The bigger danger for the Serbs," Mr. Grubacic wrote, "is that the authorities could apply repressive measures such as those in Beijing's Tiananmen Square."  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
