The Scotsman


October 6, 1999, Wednesday


DRASKOVIC ACCIDENT MAY UNITE YUGOSLAV OPPOSITION


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 14


LENGTH: 571 words


 

HUNDREDS of mourners yesterday laid to rest Veselin Boskovic, the brother-in -law of Yugoslavia's most popular opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic.

Mr Boskovic was killed in a catastrophic car accident on Sunday afternoon, which Mr Draskovic survived - and claims was an assassination attempt.

"It wasn't you who they wanted to kill, but me," Mr Draskovic said before hundreds of mourners at yesterday's funeral. "God, hasn't it been enough? Hasn't enough blood been spilled?" 

Three of Mr Draskovic's bodyguards were killed along with Mr Boskovic in Sunday's crash. The word "killers" was heard repeatedly between sobs at the Topcider cemetery near Belgrade.

Representatives from rival opposition parties turned out to pay their respects to Mr Boskovic. Vuk Obradovic, a retired general and president of the Social Democratic party attended the funeral, as did representatives from other opposition parties.

If Mr Draskovic's claim of an assassination attempt turns out to be correct, the deaths of his entourage could serve as a final catalyst to unify Yugoslavia's opposition and invigorate efforts to unseat the president, Slobodan Milosevic.

Details of Mr Draskovic's accident continue to baffle the public. A large truck filled with several tonnes of sand crossed into the oncoming lane of traffic and hit two cars.

Mr Draskovic's car, driven by Mr Boskovic, flipped on its roof and landed on an embankment.

The car carrying Mr Draskovic's three bodyguards burst into flames when it collided head-on with the truck. The truck's driver disappeared from the scene and police have not been able to identify its owner.

An investigator told Mr Draskovic's lawyer on Monday that the driver had been caught. But at a press conference later that day, Mr Draskovic's spokesman, Ivan Kovacevic, said that police still had no driver, that the truck's licence plates were missing, and that the owner still had not been identified.

The alleged assassination attempt occurred at a critical juncture in Yugoslavia's growing opposition movement.

Mr Milosevic has benefited from a divided opposition since 1997, but especially so after NATO's 78-day bombing campaign ended in June.

Last week, though, a representative from Mr Draskovic's party met with opposition rivals for the first time in more than two years.

Opposition parties discussed conditions for fair elections and agreed to continue discussions in one week. Leaders characterised the meeting as "very productive and positive".

Mr Draskovic and his rivals had stopped bickering publicly, while the Draskovic-controlled Belgrade television station, Studio B, has begun giving prominent coverage to the nightly protest marches led by his rivals.

In recent days, Studio B's signal has been interfered with during news broadcasts while state television has called the anti-Milosevic protesters "hooligans".

Analysts agree the protest movement will falter without the eventual participation of Mr Draskovic's party. Mr Draskovic was also under increasing pressure from his constituents to get involved in street protests, once police began beating demonstrators last week.

Opposition leaders are withholding judgment about the car crash until further evidence is collected, but many in the opposition strongly suspect it was indeed an attempt on Mr Draskovic's life, with the aim of derailing a gradually uniting opposition.


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


126 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


June 17, 1999, Thursday


KIND WORDS OF SUPPORT WILL NOT BE ENOUGH TO TOPPLE THE SERB TYRANT


BYLINE: Tim Luckhurst


SECTION: Pg. 6


LENGTH: 1230 words


 

"WE will do all we can to help you, but it's up to you to get rid of the regime." So said the US state department special envoy, Bob Gelbard, at the meeting of Yugoslav opposition leaders assembled in Montenegro last weekend.

Mr Gelbard was a surprise arrival. He came accompanied by Milan Panic, the US pharmaceuticals magnate who defected to the West in 1956 while representing Yugoslavia in an international cycling event in the Netherlands. Mr Panic was appointed Yugoslav federal prime minister by Slobodan Milosevic in July 1992 when the Serb leader was keen to present a western friendly image to the international community. He rapidly showed true independence of mind, famously telling Mr Milosevic to "shut up" during international peace talks on Bosnia and then standing against him for the Serbian presidency in December 1992.

Mr Panic's presence at Mr Gelbard's side gives grounds for cautious optimism about western diplomatic strategy towards the Yugoslav opposition. The emigre millionaire might have won the 1992 election if he had not been badly let down by the West. He ran neck and neck with Mr Milosevic in the opinion polls. But his appeal to the Yugoslav electorate was based on a promise to end international sanctions against the country. It was a commitment he could deliver only with US and British help. 

The West kept the sanctions in place and Mr Milosevic was able to portray his opponent as a weakling who cosied up to Serbia's enemies without winning anything in return.

Mr Panic's experience was not unique. Zoran Djindjic, the western-educated liberal intellectual who also attended the Montenegro gathering, has had equally bitter experience of Western betrayal when he most desperately needed help. Mr Djindjic was one of the leaders of the Zajedno opposition alliance which brought Mr Milosevic to the brink of defeat during the "whistling revolution" which followed his government's decision to annul election results which had handed the opposition major victories in local elections held in late 1996.

Between December of that year and February 1997, Mr Djindjic, together with the mercurial Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, brought tens of thousands of protesters on to the streets of Belgrade and Nis to demand recognition of the election results, democratic reform, economic liberalisation and the end of the Milosevic era.

The Zajedno movement generated huge support and soon created the impression that power was inexorably draining away from the Milosevic regime. A counter rally organised by the Serbian Socialist Party was a disaster, attracting only a tiny fraction of the numbers brought onto the streets by the Zajedno leaders, and providing graphic evidence that Mr Milosevic no longer spoke for his people.

What happened next must still scare the leaders who met Mr Gelbard in Montenegro.

Instead of backing the opposition to the hilt, western ambassadors backed away from their initial enthusiasm for the protesters and encouraged them to compromise with the Milosevic authorities. Zajedno collapsed amid much internal squabbling.

Had Mr Panic won in 1992 the disasters which followed in Bosnia might not have happened. If Zajedno had triumphed in 1997 the war in Kosovo might well have been avoided. Lack of clear and determined western support was one of the key factors which undermined both of these chances to build a more liberal Serbia. Mr Panic and Mr Djindjic will have made this point to Bob Gelbard. That he travelled to the meeting uninvited and with Mr Panic at his side may be taken as an indication that the United States at least has learned the lesson.

The crucial test now is how well it has learned it and how many of its allies Washington can bring with it.

Western doubts about the Yugoslav opposition are not without foundation.

 Anti-Milosevic coalitions have broken up time and time again as individual party leaders have sought personal advantage by doing deals with the Belgrade government. Vuk Draskovic, who did not attend the meeting in Montenegro, has swung like a yoyo between fierce hostility to the Yugoslav president and ministerial office in his government. NATO governments are entitled to wonder if, this time, the opposition can work together to achieve change. The answer must be a tentative yes.

KFOR troops had barely crossed the Kosovo border when Mr Gelbard travelled to Montenegro, carefully avoiding the attentions of Yugoslav secret police as he went. The timing of his mission was right and so was the membership of the gathering he attended. Milo Djukanovic, the 37-year-old democratically elected president of Montenegro, heads the only remaining republic of Federal Yugoslavia beyond Serbia.

He has stood out against Mr Milosevic throughout the NATO air campaign and retains the enthusiastic support of his people. Zoran Djindjic speaks for a small but significant body of sophisticated urban Serbs.

Milan Panic brings the promise of western aid to reconstruct Serbia and renewed membership of the world community.

With real backing from NATO these men can form the nucleus of a credible challenge to Mr Milosevic. But they will need a lot more than kind words. Mr Milosevic retains the certain loyalty of his paramilitary police, though he may not be so confident about the army. As an indicted war criminal he has nowhere to flee. But he has wriggled out of crisis after crisis in his long and bloody career.

He is a rat in a trap and will fight like one.

How can NATO best promote a convincing opposition challenge? There must be a concrete promise of money for reconstruction and development.

Mr Milosevic's media machine must be challenged by the use of radio and television broadcasts into Serbia. Those who he might order to turn their weapons on opposition protesters must be convinced that this time he really cannot survive. The ringing condemnation issued by the Serbian Orthodox church must be exploited for all it is worth.

Above all, the West must be resolute. Mr Milosevic is facing his biggest ever challenge. His economy is in ruins. The sacred heartland of Kosovo is in the hands of NATO and the KLA. His people are hurting.

He will appeal to his traditional supporters on the grounds that those who wish to replace him are pro-Western traitors working in cahoots with those who have bombed Serbia.

This may work for a while. But it will not feed people or heat their homes when the harsh Balkan winter sets in. Nor will it accommodate the thousands of Serbian refugees now fleeing Kosovo.

Having found the resolve to pursue the war to a successful conclusion, NATO must demonstrate a similar commitment to winning the peace. That means active support for the opposition, including a commitment to use force again if Mr Milosevic turns his guns against his own people in a last ditch attempt to escape the fate which ended the career of his former neighbour and ideological soul-mate Nicolae Ceausescu.

Slobodan Milosevic is not invincible. He has been brought to the brink before and can be pushed over it this time. Mr Gelbard was right to say that the primary impetus for change must come from within Serbia.

But it cannot come from Serbs alone. The West must understand that with Mr Milosevic still in power, victory in Kosovo is no victory at all.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


127 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


AUGUST 7, 2000 Monday SF EDITION


NEWS IN BRIEF


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A02


LENGTH: 948 words


IN THE NATION United cancels 120 more flights in Chicago

United Airlines canceled at least 120 flights at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport yesterday, a day after canceling 150 flights there because of a pilot shortage. The airline blamed the cancellations on pilots who have refused to work overtime since their contract expired in April. The union has denied there is an organized effort to refuse overtime work.

Lawyers want history of SLA barred at trial

Attorneys for former Symbionese Liberation Army fugitive Sara Jane Olson asked a California state appeals court last week to bar evidence about the radical group's violent history at Olson's trial in Los Angeles. Superior Court Judge James Ideman ruled earlier this year that prosecutors could discuss the entire history of the SLA when Olson goes on trial in January. She is charged with attempting to kill Los Angeles police officers in 1975; pipe bombs used in the attempt did not detonate. 

Florida coastal fishing to get more restrictions

The federal government will further restrict fishing off much of the Florida coast beginning this fall to try to protect migratory species such as tuna, swordfish and shark in the overfished region. The National Marine Fisheries Service ban on open-water longline fishing, a method used by about 450 commercial boats in the region, could cut some fishermen's revenues by 10 percent, the government estimated over the weekend.

Gunman surrenders after deputy is killed

In Port Angeles, Wash., a gunman suspected of killing a sheriff's deputy surrendered yesterday to police officers who were negotiating with him and firing tear gas into his house in an attempt to end the day-old standoff. Thomas M. Roberts, 53, who has a history of mental problems, was taken into custody after walking out of the house. Wallace E. "Wally" Davis, 48 - a sheriff's deputy, writer and father of three, with a fourth child due in February - died after he was shot when he responded to a report of a disturbance at the suspect's house on Saturday.

Hurricane Alberto still far from land

Hurricane Alberto, the first of the Atlantic hurricane season, kept moving westward yesterday while remaining far from land, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said. Alberto, with maximum sustained winds of about 80 m.p.h. and occasionally higher gusts, was about 1,600 miles east of the Windward Islands in the Caribbean Sea.

5 killed after truck goes wrong way on highway

The driver of a pickup truck traveling the wrong direction on a Fort Worth, Texas, highway smashed into several vehicles Saturday night. Five people, including the pickup driver, were killed. Six others were injured. The pickup driver was apparently fleeing another wreck moments before the fatal crash on Highway 121, police said.

IN THE WORLD Serbian opposition candidate to face Milosevic

Serbia's largest opposition party yesterday nominated its own candidate to oppose Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic in September elections, ignoring appeals from other opposition groups to rally behind a common candidate. The Serbian Renewal Movement nominated Belgrade Mayor Vojislav Mihailovic. The movement, which had said it would boycott the elections, demanded that the other anti-Milosevic parties support Mihailovic.

7 U.N. workers, 5 others killed in Afghanistan

Gunmen in Afghanistan shot and killed 12 people, including seven Afghans working for the United Nations' mine-clearing agency, in western Herat province, the organization said yesterday. The aid workers were killed near Kotal-e-Subzak early Saturday, the organization said. Officials of the Taliban militia that controls 90 percent of Afghanistan and the opposition traded accusations over who carried out the killings.

Poland OKs development near Auschwitz

The Polish Interior Ministry has lifted a ban placed by local authorities on a visitors' center, cafeteria and parking lot near the former Nazi death camp near Auschwitz, developer Janusz Marszalek said yesterday. He said the ministry ordered the governor to reconsider his decision, saying it was based on the incorrect premise that a snack bar, shops and a parking lot already on the camp site would remain.

Hiroshima marks 55th anniversary of bombing

The tolling of a bell yesterday marked the day 55 years ago when the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan. Sixty seconds of silent prayer in Peace Memorial Park in Hiroshima began at 8:15 a.m., the moment the bomb dropped on Aug. 6, 1945, killing about 140,000 people. Three days later, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Nagasaki, killing 70,000 people. Japan surrendered on Aug. 15, 1945, ending World War II.

Mudslide in Swiss Alps kills three hikers

A mudslide buried a group of mostly American hikers in the Swiss Alps yesterday, killing two of the tourists and their guide, police said. The victims were among about 20 walkers on a mountain trek from the First Grindelwald mountain to the Grosse Scheidegg peak in Switzerland's Berner Oberland region. The two tourists had not been identified.

Gunmen steal $11.1 million in Paraguay

Gunmen in military-style uniforms in Asuncion, Paraguay, stole $11.1 million as guards were about to load the money onto a plane headed for New York on Friday night. It was the country's biggest robbery ever, authorities said Saturday. The money was from several private banks.

Militant injured in explosion in Gaza City

A member of a militant Islamic group was injured in Gaza City yesterday when a bomb he was making exploded, Palestinian police said. "Interrogation is under way to determine his affiliation," a police official said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

All Rights Reserved


128 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 18, 1999, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


Main Foe of Milosevic Pulls Out of Big Rally Plan


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1169 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Aug. 17


In a severe blow to the effort to oust President Slobodan Milosevic, the leader of the largest opposition party and an influential former army general withdrew today from a major anti-Milosevic rally scheduled for Thursday.

Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement and the opposition's best orator, said today that he would not take part in the rally because of the actions and behavior of the Alliance for Change, which is effectively led by his rival, Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democracy Party. 

Momcilo Perisic, whom Mr. Milosevic fired as army chief of staff last November, also pulled out, saying he did not support a transitional government of experts, one of the aims of the rally, but rather favored early elections for a new government.

The rally, the first one in the capital, Belgrade, since Yugoslav troops pulled out of Kosovo, has been seen as a high point of a summer of waxing and waning protests against Mr. Milosevic. The rally and the turnout for it will be judged by all the players here as a test of anti-Milosevic sentiment, and the Government has been attacking its organizers for various shortcomings -- including doing NATO's bidding and choosing to hold the rally on President Clinton's birthday.

The Government has also attacked Mr. Perisic with extraordinary fervor, labeling the former general, who is slight in stature, "a small weakling," an "unrealized male" and "General Clark's orderly," a reference to Gen. Wesley Clark, the NATO commander.

The Government, having tried to consolidate itself around the parties of Mr. Milosevic, his wife, Mirjana Markovic, and the ultranationalist politician Vojislav Seselj, is generally anxious about sentiment in Belgrade, however pleased it may be about a continually divided opposition.

Today's developments will weaken the opposition and make it seem less credible to ordinary Serbs.

The night before the rally, on Wednesday, there will be be a large crowd at the first soccer match between Yugoslavia and Croatia since the collapse of Tito's Yugoslavia.

While the crowd is likely to shout anti-Government slogans, the Government fears something more serious. There are rumors, reported in the Belgrade press, that the ruling parties have bought or secured a third of the seats -- up to 20,000 -- for their members.

Some officials feel that if Yugoslavia, which boasts a strong team, beats Croatia, the sense of good feeling may carry over to the Thursday rally. Or vice versa.

The bitter and visceral rivalry between Mr. Djindjic on one side and Mr. Draskovic and his powerful wife, Danica, on the other, has bedeviled and infuriated American diplomats trying to finish the war against Serbia with Mr. Milosevic's ouster.

A senior American diplomat, Robert S. Gelbard, met in Serbia's sister republic of Montenegro with all key Yugoslav opposition leaders to plan strategy and provide advice and encouragement -- if not the millions of dollars that Mr. Milosevic's propaganda asserts.

But the visibility of American diplomats advising the domestic opposition on the ouster of the elected Yugoslav President has been a gift to Mr. Milosevic's propaganda machine, making it easy to tar the opposition as traitors or dupes of the nation that just bombed Belgrade and is overseeing the exodus of Serbs from Kosovo.

The issues involved in Mr. Draskovic's decision today not to speak at the rally were personal, symbolic and substantive, his aides said. First, he disapproved of a change in the lineup of speakers for the rally that came just two hours after the list was issued. The new lineup included Vesna Pesic, the former Civic Alliance leader, and Velimir Ilic, Mayor of Cacak. Mr. Draskovic would not accept Mr. Ilic, his former deputy who joined with Mr. Djindjic.

Early this morning, Mr. Draskovic decided that he would not speak. Instead, his party's speaker will be a much less compelling figure, Spasoje Krunic, the chairman of Belgrade's executive council. Mr. Draskovic did, however, call on his supporters to come to Belgrade and take part in the rally.

At a news conference today, Mr. Draskovic said, "I cannot accept many, many stupid ideas of irresponsible people."

He also said the rally was too late and should have been held at the end of June.

But there were also substantive issues involved. Mr. Djindjic, the Alliance for Change generally and the Clinton Administration want Mr. Milosevic to resign as a first step and want him to be delivered, perhaps within six months, to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. They want a transitional government of experts to serve for a year to prepare for new elections.

Mr. Draskovic wonders how they intend to force Mr. Milosevic's resignation without violence, unrest and even "civil war," and he has proposed either new, internationally supervised elections to replace Mr. Milosevic, or a transitional government, to be negotiated with the Government now in place, that would render Mr. Milosevic a figurehead.

But Mr. Draskovic says he now believes that Mr. Milosevic will never agree to a transitional government and that the time for such an idea is past.

Mr. Draskovic's ideas are also vague, but he says he believes that Mr. Milosevic can be pushed or seduced to resign, presumably with some promise of immunity for his family and his assets.

Mr. Perisic, who has started his own movement, is trying to induce members of the army, the police and current Government to leave the Milosevic circle. He agrees with the Alliance that Mr. Milosevic is not trustworthy and must be forced or persuaded to resign as a first step, said his spokesman, Boris Karajicic, a former student resistance leader. But Mr. Perisic wants early elections.

Mr. Perisic's views are closer to Mr. Draskovic's, and they both seem to want a more constitutional process than what the Alliance favors.

Last week, Ms. Pesic, former leader of the Civic Alliance, even suggested that if Mr. Milosevic remained in office, "the Romanian model, if need be," could not be ruled out. The Romanian dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, and his wife were overthrown and murdered in 1989.

Milosevic supporters immediately seized on Ms. Pesic's comments and the Serbian Prime Minister, Mirko Marjanovic, called the Alliance for Change, commonly disparaged as "the Alliance for NATO," a "terrorist organization."

Today, according to state television, a prosecutor asked the police to examine evidence that Ms. Pesic is guilty of a felony charge for inciting and "an attack on the constitutional system."

That is another reason Mr. Draskovic found her inclusion in the list of speakers unfortunate, aides say.

Alliance officials say Mr. Draskovic, who joined the Yugoslav Government in January but was fired during the war, is doing Mr. Milosevic's bidding. They say Mr. Draskovic, whose party controls Belgrade and its influential television station, Studio B, with the support of Mr. Milosevic's party, is being pressured by the Government.

        

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: August 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


129 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 24, 1997, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Milosevic Trades Top Serbian Post for Yugoslav Presidency


BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 623 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 23


Slobodan Milosevic switched jobs today, dropping his title of President of Serbia and emerging as President of the Yugoslav federation after a swearing-in ceremony in the federal Parliament.

Intent on prolonging his 10-year rule but barred by the Constitution from serving again as President of Serbia, Mr. Milosevic maneuvered to take the Yugoslav presidency, until now a figurehead job. 

After intense bargaining with leaders in Montenegro, which with Serbia makes up what is left of Yugoslavia, Mr. Milosevic managed last week to push through a majority vote in Parliament for his appointment as federal President.

Accompanied by his wife, Mira Markovic, Mr. Milosevic pledged in a brief speech to Parliament to rule over "a peaceful, independent, just and developed country."

But since the war that Mr. Milosevic presided over and that led to the breakup of Yugoslavia, the Serbian economy has declined sharply and has become largely criminalized. The opposition movement that protested in the streets of Belgrade against Mr. Milosevic last winter has faded, its principal leaders caught up with intramural political jockeying and the students who organized the demonstrations drained of energy.

Only several hundred anti-Milosevic protesters appeared outside the federal Parliament today and were pushed aside before Mr. Milosevic entered. Several thousand university students, in a rare demonstration since the winter, were prevented from going to Parliament by a police cordon.

Mr. Milosevic's supporters gathered outside Parliament, chanting their fealty to Mr. Milosevic and yelling "Red Gangsters!" to the opposition protesters.

In the early 1990's, as President of Serbia, Mr. Milosevic promised to bring standards of living equivalent to those in Sweden and to build fast rail links that would integrate Serbia in Europe.

But instead the economy crashed under the weight of war, and the Dayton peace settlement has failed to improve the material well-being of Serbs.

Mr. Milosevic has refused to allow any meaningful privatization of the nationalized economy, unemployment hovers around 40 percent and the average wage has dropped to one-third its prewar value. Many Serbs say they believe that the economy is run for the direct interests of Mr. Milosevic and a few cronies.

Elections for the Serbian presidency scheduled for Sept. 21 are likely to be boycotted by the opposition parties, according to Slobodan Vuksanovic, spokesman for the Democratic Party. The opposition is upset that Mr. Milosevic's party, the Socialist Party of Serbia, has changed the boundaries of election districts to favor its candidates.

The only declared candidate so far for the vacant Serbian presidency is the ultranationalist Vojislav Seselj, whose Serbian Radical Party provided many of the most violent Serbian paramilitary fighters in the Bosnian war. Mr. Seselj, who brandished a gun in front of the Serbian Parliament to scare away students several years ago, was among the first to line up and congratulate Mr. Milosevic after his swearing in today.

Mr. Milosevic has not yet announced a candidate from his own party for his old job and appears to be favoring Mr. Seselj's candidacy. In his latest nationalistic action, Mr. Seselj, who is the Mayor of Zemun, a municipality of Belgrade, ordered the eviction of two Croatian families from their homes last week.

By having Mr. Seselj as President of Serbia, Mr. Milosevic could count on a faithful ally to control the powerful Serbian secret police. In an indication of how isolated Mr. Milosevic has remained after the war, the first telegram of congratulations read on state-run television today came from President Fidel Castro of Cuba.

      


LOAD-DATE: July 24, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company


130 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


August 18, 1999, Wednesday


Milosevic's hold on power grows


BYLINE: Eve-Ann Prentice


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 813 words


 

Feuding rivals aid yet another escape act, says Eve-Ann Prentice

A SIGN by one of the bridges linking old and new Belgrade proudly announces the presence of a restaurant called the Argument. It seems to symbolise what is happening in Yugoslavia as the summer unfolds.

For although the restaurant's name really means "debate" in English, rational discussion is almost absent among the myriad pro- and anti-government groups squabbling over where the country goes from here.

Two months after the end of Nato's bombing campaign, President Milosevic is still at the helm, buoyed by deep splits in the opposition, widespread popular resentment of the West, and the availability of food. 

An anti-Milosevic rally to be held in Belgrade tomorrow has long been billed as a potentially crucial point in the build-up of opposition. But plans for the protest were in disarray yesterday after Vuk Draskovic, one of the two main opposition leaders, announced that he would not address the gathering. His decision followed days of wrangling about who should speak and in what order. "There have been so many problems concerning the organisation of the rally," said a spokesman for Mr Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement. "Another official will speak in his place."

The other main opposition group is the umbrella Alliance for Change led by Zoran Djindjic, the Democratic Party leader. Mr Djindjic and Mr Draskovic are now deeply antagonistic towards one another, even though once allies. Mr Djindjic generally receives support from entrepreneurial Serbs, especially those who would like to do business abroad, while Mr Draskovic has a more mystical air which appeals to the Serbian Orthodox psyche.

Many ordinary Serbs are dismayed that the two cannot put aside their differences and present a united front. "Do they think they are organising another Woodstock on Thursday?" said a group of Belgrade students yesterday. Young and old are pessimistic about the future, fearing a cash and power-starved winter. But although they grumble about the Milosevic regime, ordinary Serbs are often even more scathing about the West and feel unfairly vilified. The perceived failure of Kfor to protect Kosovo's Serbs from Albanians has added to the sense of Serbs standing alone against the world - and may have boosted Mr Milosevic's support.

The West hopes that tightening the sanctions screw on Serbia will increase the chances of a popular insurrection against Mr Milosevic, but the evidence here seems to be that this policy is having the opposite effect.

Public anger at the regime was probably at its height in the first month after the Kosovo campaign, when tens of thousands of conscripted troops came home and the extent of the debacle became clear to people with little or no access to outside information. This was especially true in southern and central towns which provided most troops for Kosovo.

Tens of thousands joined organised and spontaneous anti-government rallies in towns such as Cacak, Valjevo, Krusevac and Leskovac. Today, these rallies usually attract no more than a few hundred. In Leskovac this week, even those at the heart of the dwindling protest meetings admitted that villagers in the area would almost certainly vote for Mr Milosevic in an election.

Nonetheless, the Government is clearly uneasy about tomorrow's protest, which opposition leaders had hoped would attract more than 100,000 people before Mr Draskovic's decision not to speak.

Mr Milosevic, meanwhile, seems to be using his proven tactic of carrot and stick. The carrot is the regime's occasional deliberate indulgence. Police have tended to stand back at protest meetings, and they increasingly turn a blind eye to black marketeering. Petrol is openly available from hundreds of roadside entrepreneurs selling it for about DM5 (about Pounds 1.78) a litre from plastic bottles, while garages stand largely deserted.

Although there is genuine hunger among hundreds of thousands of near-destitute refugees from Croatia and Bosnia, let alone Kosovo, most Serbs are kept blissfully ignorant of these woes and they have enough money for now to buy food.

But the threat of force is never far away. In Valjevo yesterday, Bogoljub Arsenijevic, a self-proclaimed opposition figure, was arrested and beaten up, his colleagues said. He had recently joined forces with

an opposition movement called the Movement for Democratic Serbia, founded by a former Army Chief of Staff, Momcilo Perisic.

State newspapers and television are launching vehement attacks on opposition leaders, accusing them of trying to generate unrest.

Tomorrow's protest takes place on President Clinton's birthday. The following day Mr Milosevic celebrates his 58th birthday. Despite the West's wishes, no clear signs have emerged to indicate that it will be his last in power.


LOAD-DATE: August 20, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Times Newspapers Limited


131 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


March 17, 2000, Friday


WAR-WEARY SERBS STRUGGLE IN THE GRIP OF MILOSEVIC TIGHTENS;
 BALKAN AFTERMATH CRITICAL MEDIA SHUT DOWN, OPPOSITION IMPOTENT AND LIVING STANDARDS AT NEW LOWS - A NATION DESPAIRS OF CHANGING THE REGIME


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic In Belgrade


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 798 words


 

"TEN YEARS ago, before everything that happened here, we had a life," recalled Ljiljana Nonin. "We planned our holidays, went to the Croatian seaside every year, to Spain, bought furniture. We could plan and manage."

Now the family struggles to survive on pounds 70 a month. "It's so hard to survive," Mrs Nonin said. "You don't know what to buy for lunch or how to pay the electricity. Bills come and you put them aside. You have to eat to survive." 

Nine months after the Nato bombardment ended, Serbia is a depressed and depressing place. The regime is slowly squeezing the life out of its people and the opposition parties seem powerless to offer any way out.

The independent media are being shut down one by one. Kosovo is boiling with tension, while Montenegro looks likely to become the next target of Slobodan Milosevic, Yugoslavia's President. Caught in the middle, 7.5 million confused Serbs, such as Ljiljana Nonin, struggle to survive in an impoverished state where only farms, electricity plants and some small businesses manage to keep going.

Teachers have been on strike for seven weeks now, demanding to be paid. Long lines of pensioners in shabby clothes gather around the entrances to supermarkets. They queue for hours to buy two litres of cooking oil, sugar, some meat - if it eventually arrives. Some days they have to go home empty-handed.

"There is not a simple or a single word that could describe how we live now," said Mrs Nonin, a middle-aged Belgrade woman. "Ordinary people are depressed, desperate and more frightened than ever."

The Nonins live in a small apartment in downtown Belgrade. They used to enjoy a comfortable life. Mrs Nonin used to have a well-paid job as a secretary in the federal meteorological service. She left her job eight years ago to look after her son, who had leukaemia. The boy died in 1994 after an unsuccessful bone-marrow transplant in Italy.

Besides living through the hell of losing a son, Mrs Nonin remembers the nightmare of travelling abroad. With an air-traffic embargo in force, she had to travel with her son via Budapest. Obtaining an Italian visa for the trip was a story in itself. Western countries introduced visas for Yugoslav citizens in 1991 when the wars that accompanied the disintegration of the former Yugoslavia first broke out.

Yet despite the scale of the discontent voiced by the ordinary people, there is no credible opposition to turn to.

The Alliance for Change started anti-Milosevic rallies just days after Nato air raids ended last June. Protests around the country were lively for more than a month, but fizzled out. Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) decided not to join. Finally, in January, the biggest opposition parties joined forces but a proper unified movement has not materialised.

Vladimir Goati, a political analyst, says the Serbian opposition "is running around in circles". "In the meantime, the remnants of civil society and independent media are paying a high price."

Some analysts believe the days of mass rallies against Mr Milosevic are over and that he could be removed from power only through free and fair elections. But fair elections have not been held in this country since 1990. Rigging elections is a speciality of the regime. Another is not recognising election results.

Meanwhile, the total isolation of the country is helping Mr Milosevic do whatever he wants. The regime has in fact divided its people into "patriots", who support it, and "traitors", those who sympathise with opposition parties. The opposition is accused of being "the extended hand of the Nato aggressors", and of trying to instigate a civil war.

But it is the regime itself that is preparing for further aggression, according to Slobodan Vucetic, one of the leading critics of Mr Milosevic. For years, Mr Vucetic was a supreme court judge who paid for his criticism of the regime when he was sacked last December.

"This regime lacks any rational approach when faced with economic and social meltdown," Mr Vucetic said. "It is now in a great panic and will not hesitate to use force against its own people just to stay in power. This regime is nowhere near the democratisation that would offer the only solution to our crisis."

And no matter what hardships people face, few analysts are predicting a revolution.

"I went to all the protests in Belgrade for years now: 1991, 1992, 1993, 1996..." Mrs Nonin said. "But I see that fewer and fewer people are willing to turn out... It's hard to understand their passivity. They live awful lives, yet they sit and wait for someone else to do something. Maybe it's fear, maybe they are cowards. I deplore that attitude, because if we do nothing, how can we expect things to change?"


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: A Serb pensioner shouting anti-government slogans at a rally in; Belgrade in October AP/Darko Vojinovic)


Copyright 2000 Independent Print Ltd


132 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Guardian Weekly


September 6, 2000


Serbia's opposition tries to rally voters


BYLINE: Christophe Chatelot in Belgrade


SECTION: LE MONDE; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 839 words


HIGHLIGHT: Anti-Milosevic coalition hopes to oust Belgrade's strongman in coming elections


"Hold your nose and vote for the opposition" is the message that many Serbian civil rights activists are putting across to voters in the run-up to Yugoslavia's presidential elections on September 24.

"We have to forget the opposition's futile divisions if we want to kick out Slobodan Milosevic as president of the Yugoslav Federation," says Otpor (Resistance), a militant student organisation.

By putting his four-year term of office to the test of universal suffrage by changing the constitution last month (earlier, federation presidents had been elected by MPs), Belgrade's strongman has suddenly begun to look vulnerable.

Independent observers agree that the key to the election will be the turn-out. "If a lot of people bother to vote, then the regime will have to rig the results massively to ensure victory for Milosevic, and in that case no one knows how the population will react," says Marko Blagojevic, head of the Centre for Free Elections and Democracy (Cesid). 

"Every single ballot paper will count. People have to be convinced that it will be their vote that tips the balance in favour of the democratic opposition candidate," says Blagojevic.

The students of Otpor are the most zealous of the opposition campaigners. For weeks they have been trying to motivate voters who have been turned off by the opposition's infighting, worn down by 10 years of economic crisis, traumatised by last year's Nato bombings, and brain-washed by official propaganda.

But there has been no massive mobilisation against the regime. "No one expected Milosevic's constitutional coup on July 24 or, for that matter, September elections," says Dukasin Petrovic, one of the Otpor leaders. "The opposition is not ready, whereas the regime is already up and running."

The national media constantly hammer home the propaganda of Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) and of the ultranationalist Radical party, whose candidate is Tomislav Nikolic. The Serbian prime minister, Mirko Marjanovic, sees the election as "a referendum: are you in favour of Milosevic, development, peace and freedom, or do you want the country to be turned into a Western colony?"

Voja Janetic, a media expert, says: "The regime is putting across a two-pronged message: we must resist foreign aggression and the new world order imposed by the United States. The Serbs, behind Milosevic, are the defenders of the free world."

The opposition has opted for a minimal campaign. "People are fed up with politics. Three weeks will be enough," says Vojislav Kostunica, the 56-year-old candidate of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS), a coalition of 18 parties.

Does this mean that the DOS does not really have its heart in its election campaign? It claims that Milosevic is poised to break the rules that he has himself defined.

As regards the general elections in Serbia and Montenegro, which will take place the same day as the Serbian local elections and the presidential election, the dice seem heavily loaded.

"The federal general election is a foregone conclusion: it'll be won by the regime," says Predrag Simic, who works as an international relations adviser to Vuk Draskovic, president of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), one of the main opposition parties.

That is why the opposition has been concentrating on the presidential election. Opinion polls, though not very reliable, show that Kostunica is in with a chance. After Draskovic sprang a surprise by withdrawing from the race, he was replaced as SPO candidate by Vojislav Mihajlovic, the colourless mayor of Belgrade.

Mihajlovic's many detractors claim that his only asset is his name -- his grandfather was Dragoslav Mihajlovic, leader of the Chetnik Serbian nationalist movement during the second world war, who was executed by Tito's partisans in 1946.

That view is shared by many in the SPO. They suspect that Draskovic, whose popularity is on the wane, may have wanted to scupper the chances of an opposition victory by refusing to back a single opposition candidate. While Kostunica may lack charisma, he does have a solid reputation for being a brilliant and honest intellectual who remains faithful to his ideas.

"People are so fed up that any opposition candidate could beat Milosevic in the second round of a fair election," says one foreign observer.

Milosevic could simply call off the election if the ratings are too disastrous for him in September; or he could rig the poll on a massive scale and bank on the population being too resigned to do anything; or there could be a re-run of the huge demonstrations of the winter of 1996-97, when the regime had to admit defeat in most large cities.

If Milosevic loses the election, his coalition will still control the federal and Serbian parliaments as well as the Serbian presidency. "There's an odd atmosphere," says Milan Samardzic, an Otpor activist. "We tell ourselves that we have a chance of winning, while at the same time knowing full well that Milosevic can't lose." August 24


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, Vojislav Kostunica has been chosen by 18 opposition parties to run against Milosevic, Goran Tomasevic


Copyright 2000 Guardian Publication, Ltd.


133 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


July 5, 1999 Monday Final Edition


SERB CHURCH'S SIGNALS MIXED;
STANCE ON OUSTING MILOSEVIC UNCERTAIN


BYLINE: BLAINE HARDEN, CARLOTTA GALL, N. Y. TIMES NEWS SERVICE


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. B11


LENGTH: 1444 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


A handful of black-robed, full-bearded Serb Orthodox priests bobbed on the edges of a noisy crowd that assembled last week in the Serb town of Cacak to demand that President Slobodan Milosevic resign.

One of them, the Rev. Stojan Stokic, a village priest who had driven more than 150 miles for the rally, showed off the same pious fury, the same political passion that characterized many Roman Catholic priests in Poland who more than a decade ago helped the Solidarity movement topple communism.

To see and hear Stokic was to believe that something fundamental is changing in the soul of the Serbian Orthodox Church, which grabbed international attention last month by coming out ahead of Serb opposition parties and calling on Milosevic to step down.

But Stokic, who said he would preach his anti-Milosevic politics in his parish, is still an exception.

The Orthodox Church is both bound by and responsible for the notion that wherever Serbs live and bury their dead should be part of Serbia. 

This is the church that 10 years ago welcomed Milosevic's violent nationalist land grab in the collapsing Yugoslavia and whose most senior bishops travelled in the war zones of Croatia and Bosnia, blessing Serb forces shelling towns like Sarajevo.

Even though its head, Patriarch Pavle, said last week in Kosovo that the Serb leader's policies are criminal, the church continues to send mixed signals about what its priests should do in toppling a president who is indicted as a war criminal.

Stokic said the war in Kosovo, where Serbs committed atrocities against Albanians before losing control of territory his church regards as sacred to Serbs, had changed everything.

"I am so ashamed and I am feeling guilty," he said. "Milosevic never mentions that Albanians were killed. He is only president of the police. It isn't the job of the Orthodox Church to speak about politics. But now in this terrible time, we must speak out against this man."

But Bishop Atanasije, vicar of the patriarchy in Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital, and a cleric who often speaks for Pavle, said in an interview: "The church is not a political body. If the church has called for Slobodan Milosevic to resign, it is not because the church is involved in politics, it is out of her own pastoral care for the people of this country."

Taking pains to deny news stories that parish priests around Serbia have been instructed to use Sunday's services as the beginning of a campaign to teach Serbs about atrocities committed in their name in Kosovo, the bishop said, "Those reports have nothing to do with reality."

It is enough that the church hierarchy has spoken publicly, he said, adding that in local parishes, priests should stick to the Gospel.

"There is no need for the priests to speak out," said Atanasije, drawing a clear distinction between what the Serbian Orthodox Church is willing to do here and what the Catholic Church did in Poland.

"The Roman Catholic Church is allowed to use any means in order to achieve a good goal," the bishop said. "The Orthodox Church must always use evangelical means. We cannot say to the people rise up and throw off your government. We cannot use evil means to overcome evil. We can say obey the statutes of the law. That's it."

In the decade during which Milosevic has been fomenting ethnic war in Yugoslavia, the Serbian Orthodox Church has frequently criticized him and called for his resignation.

In 1992, shortly after the start of the Croatian war, Pavle accused Milosevic of making Serbs "victims of communist tyranny" and called for the creation of a government of national salvation. The patriarch in 1997 led a procession of more than 100,000 people into central Belgrade and lent his support to months of demonstrations during which opposition parties demanded that the president step down.

ATROCITIES

But until the patriarch began speaking recently of the "evil" he has seen in Kosovo, the focus of church criticism has not been that Milosevic's government committed atrocities in trying to create a new Serb empire, but that it has been unsuccessful in building that larger state.

"We blame Milosevic not for trying to defend the nation, but for failing," said Atanasije.

Despite its recent statements about Kosovo, Atanasije said the church is not rethinking the support that many of its senior priests, including the patriarch himself, gave in blessing Bosnian Serb forces whose leaders have now been indicted for war crimes.

One priest, the Rev. Filaret Micovic, photographed in Bosnia atop a tank while brandishing a Kalashnikov rifle, was recently promoted to bishop.

"I don't see anything strange about the presence of a priest among his troops," Atanasije said.

This continuing stream of conflicting messages -- the embrace of nationalist aspirations but the rejection of Milosevic's savage means of realizing them -- grows out of the pivotal role that the church has played for nearly seven centuries in gestating and defending the idea of what it means to be a Serb.

"Being a Serb and being Orthodox mean the same thing," said Mirko Djordjevic, a retired literature professor and the author of a new book about the church and its ties to Milosevic. "Our church itself has generated nationalism."

Under centuries of Ottoman occupation, when the state of Serbia ceased to exist, it was the church and its myth-making senior clerics who kept the fires of Serb nationalism burning, and made honoured saints of Serb warriors. Prince Lazar, who led Serb forces against the Turks in the glorious lost battle of Kosovo in 1389, was reputed by the same church that made him a saint to have said: "It is better to die in battle than to live in shame."

The hold on many Serbs of what the church has always described as a glorious national past has encouraged Serbs to hope for another Great Serbia.

In realizing the church's long-held dream that all Serbs should live in the same state, the rise of Milosevic in the late 1980s was the best news the Serbian Orthodox Church had heard for decades, Djordjevic said.

"The church believed Milosevic was the messiah who had come to smile on all Serbs," he said.

Later in Bosnia, the bishops openly supported Radovan Karadzic, blessing his war to lop off part of that former Yugoslav republic and fuse it to Serbia. Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs during the 1992-1995 war, has been indicted for war crimes.

After decades of Tito's communism, during which the church was repressed and controlled by the government and some of its vast properties were confiscated, Milosevic allowed the church to reclaim its role in Serb society. Priests appeared on state-controlled television. He pledged to allow religious education in schools and to return church property, promises later broken.

But Christian holidays have again become public celebrations in Serbia and the church in 1989 was allowed to elect a patriarch, Pavle, who is from Kosovo, without government interference. As Yugoslavia unravelled and wars began in the early 1990s, Serb paramilitary leaders -- many of them responsible for atrocities and wholesale campaigns of theft in Croatia and Bosnia -- invoked the church as their inspiration for defending Serbs.

WAR CRIMINAL

The warlord Zeljko Raznjatovic, who is known as Arkan and has been indicted as a war criminal, said publicly that his "supreme commander" was Pavle. Before Arkan's indictment by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Netherlands, but after worldwide publicity about the brutality and greed of his paramilitary fighters, Orthodox priests officiated at his lavish and very public wedding in Belgrade.

Djordjevic, regarded as a leading expert on the Serbian church, says Pavle has been "shocked" by the evidence of atrocities that he has seen in Kosovo since the 11-week war with NATO ended in early June.

That shock has resulted in what Djordjevic describes as a new direction for the church, with the patriarch and Bishop Artemije, the most senior representative of the church in Kosovo, speaking openly of "evil" done by Serbs against Albanians.

Artemije took part Friday in a U.N.-sponsored meeting with the leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army, Hashim Thaci, and other Albanian leaders. They signed a joint statement condemning war crimes and crimes against humanity committed against Albanians in Kosovo.

Artemije has long opposed Milosevic but has not often been heard inside Yugoslavia. Shortly after the NATO bombing began, he made a proclamation to be read in every church in Kosovo, criticizing what he called "pogroms" against the Albanians. It condemned the burning of houses and attacking of people.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: 1. photo by The Associated Press; The banner above reads Down with Milosevic. More than 5,000 people, some of them in the background, gathered in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia, to demand the resignation of the president.; 2. map; 3. photo by Dragan Antonic, Reuters; The Serbian Orthodox Church continues to send mixed signals about what its priests should do to topple Slobodan Milosevic.


TYPE: Special Report


Copyright 1999 Metroland Media Group Ltd


134 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


June 11, 1999


Spinning out the conflict


BYLINE: ??


SECTION: Guardian Leader Pages; Pg. 21


LENGTH: 596 words


With a million refugees and a devastated Kosovo, the argument will not die away quickly. We need to look with scepticism on the conclusion that Nato has achieved a 'victory". It might be illuminating for Simon Hoggart (June 9) to comment on his conclusions in six months' time. 

What the bombing has achieved has been a rapid acceleration of existing horrors - and the UK has a particular responsibility, given the single-minded belligerence of its prime minister. Was there an alternative? Certainly not an easy, bloodless answer to Milosevic's brutalities. Milosevic could only have been restrained, at best and only in part, by world opinion backed by various economic and political sanctions (UN agreed), and by the encouragement of the extensive anti-Milosevic sentiment inside Serbia. Milosevic's evil practices would not have ended, but with aid workers, UN observers and journalists in Kosovo, the atrocities might have been restrained.

It is a melancholy conclusion, for the world is rum bling with wars and the threats of war. More violence is usually not the answer. Prof John Saville

University of Hull

Henry Porter (G2, June 9) is right to attack the anti-war movement for the poverty of its arguments and its refusal to support the Kosovans. But he is wrong to assert that this is part of a collapse of the left. There were many on the socialist left who focused on the central issue, the attempt to wipe out the Kosovans as a people. We tried to ensure that practical support and solidarity was delivered through campaigns like Workers Aid for Kosova and Trade Unions for Kosova. This work will not stop because the immediate war may have ended.

We also insisted on the right of Kosovo to independence, something supported by neither Nato nor the crude 'anti-imperialists'. Will Nato now support the right of Kosovo to self-determination or wind up at war with the KLA? Whatever they do it will certainly be determined by the interests of the western ruling class. But it was possible to give support to the Kosavans without putting any trust or confidence in Nato. Patrick Murphy

Alliance for Workers Liberty

No Serbs have been so effectively silenced, politically neutered, disenfranchised, as those of us who have opposed the Nato aggression. We have had no means of dissenting through the democratic process. Parliament was not allowed to determine whether we should go to war or how to end it. Those few courageous MPs who opposed the bombing were not permitted to test the feeling of either the parliamentary Labour party or parliament through votes.

Is it not gratuitous to condemn Milosevic for acting as a dictator when, in Britain, a cabal of politicians can implicate all of us in an unwarranted act of carnage without our consent? Prof Vic Allen

Keighley, W Yorks

You will be surprised to know, judging from your letter writers, that all the frontline states of Albania, Bosnia/Hercegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, FYR Macedonia, Romania, and Slovenia fully support Nato strategy. The ranks of the retired military, diplomats and politicians, the professional leftists and, heaven help us, thespians and playwrights who questioned the continuing prosecution of Nato's aims would do well to dwell on the view of those closest to the conflict. They believe it would certainly have created a far worse situation than we presently face and we should not weaken in our resolve to see it through to the end. Peter Robinson

Director, Trades Union

Committee for European and Transatlantic Understanding


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Guardian Newspapers Limited


135 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 4, 1999, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE SERBIAN ORTHODOX;
Church of Milosevic's Rise Now Sends Mixed Message


BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN with CARLOTTA GALL 


SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1703 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 3


A handful of black-robed, full-bearded Serbian Orthodox priests bobbed on the edges of a noisy crowd that assembled this week in the Serbian town of Cacak to demand that President Slobodan Milosevic resign.

One of them, Father Stojan Stokic, a village priest who had driven more than 150 miles for the rally, showed off the same pious fury, the same political passion that characterized many Roman Catholic priests in Poland who more than a decade ago helped the Solidarity movement topple Communism. 

To see and hear Father Stojan was to believe that something fundamental is changing in the soul of the Serbian Orthodox Church, which grabbed international attention last month by coming out ahead of Serbian opposition parties and calling on Mr. Milosevic to step down.

But Father Stojan, who said he will preach his anti-Milosevic politics in his parish this Sunday morning, is still an exception.

The Orthodox Church is both bound by and responsible for the notion that wherever Serbs live and bury their dead should be part of Serbia.

This is the church that 10 years ago welcomed Mr. Milosevic's violent nationalist land grab in the collapsing Yugoslavia, the church whose most senior bishops traveled in the war zones of Croatia and Bosnia, blessing Serbian forces shelling towns like Sarajevo.

Even though its head, Patriarch Pavle, said this week in Kosovo that the Serbian leader's policies are criminal, the church continues to send mixed signals about what its priests should do about toppling a President who is indicted as a war criminal.

Father Stojan said the war in Kosovo, where Serbs committed atrocities against Albanians before losing control of territory his church regards as sacred to Serbs, has changed everything.

"I am so ashamed and I am feeling guilty," he said. "Milosevic never mentions that Albanians were killed. He is only president of the police. It isn't the job of the Orthodox Church to speak about politics. But now in this terrible time, we must speak out against this man."

But Bishop Atanasije, vicar of the patriarchy in Belgrade and a cleric who often speaks for Patriarch Pavle, said in an interview: "The church is not a political body. If the church has called for Slobodan Milosevic to resign, it is not because the church is involved in politics, it is out of her own pastoral care for the people of this country."

Taking pains to deny news stories that parish priests around Serbia have been instructed to use this Sunday's services as the beginning of a campaign to teach Serbs about atrocities committed in their name in Kosovo, Bishop Atanasije said, "Those reports have nothing to do with reality."

It is enough that the church hierarchy has spoken publicly, he said, adding that in local parishes, priests should stick to the Gospel.

"There is no need for the priests to speak out," said Bishop Atanasije, drawing a clear distinction between what the Serbian Orthodox Church is willing to do here and what the Catholic Church did in Poland.

"The Roman Catholic Church is allowed to use any means in order to achieve a good goal," the bishop said. "The Orthodox Church must always use evangelical means. We cannot say to the people rise up and throw off your Government. We cannot use evil means to overcome evil. We can say obey the statutes of the law. That's it."

In the decade during which Mr. Milosevic has been fomenting ethnic war in Yugoslavia, the Serbian Orthodox Church has frequently criticized him and called for his resignation. In 1992, shortly after the start of the Croatian war, Patriarch Pavle accused Mr. Milosevic of making Serbs "victims of Communist tyranny" and called for the creation of a government of national salvation. The Patriarch in 1997 led a procession of more than 100,000 people into central Belgrade and lent his support to months of demonstrations during which opposition parties demanded that the President step down.

But until the Patriarch began speaking recently of the "evil" he has seen in Kosovo, the focus of church criticism has not been that Mr. Milosevic's Government committed atrocities in trying to create a new Serbian empire, but that it has been unsuccessful in building that larger state.

"We blame Milosevic not for trying to defend the nation, but for failing," said Bishop Atanasije.

Despite its recent statements about Kosovo, Bishop Atanasije said the church is not rethinking the support that many of its senior priests, including the Patriarch himself, gave in blessing Bosnian Serbian forces whose leaders have now been indicted for war crimes.

One priest, Father Filaret Micovic, photographed in Bosnia atop a tank while brandishing a Kalashnikov rifle, was recently promoted to bishop.

"I don't see anything strange about the presence of a priest among his troops," Bishop Atanasije said.

This continuing stream of conflicting messages -- the embrace of nationalist aspirations but the rejection of Mr. Milosevic's savage means of realizing them -- grows out of the pivotal role that the church has played for nearly seven centuries in gestating and defending the idea of what it means to be a Serb.

"Being a Serb and being Orthodox mean the same thing," said Mirko Djordjevic, a retired literature professor and the author of a new book about the church and its ties to Mr. Milosevic. "Our church itself has generated nationalism."

Under centuries of Ottoman occupation, when the state of Serbia ceased to exist, it was the church and its myth-making senior clerics who kept the fires of Serbian nationalism burning, and made honored saints of Serbian warriors. Prince Lazar, who led Serbian forces against the Turks in the glorious lost battle of Kosovo in 1389, was reputed by the same church that made him a saint to have said: "It is better to die in battle than to live in shame."

The hold on many Serbs of what the church has always described as a glorious national past has encouraged Serbs to hope for another Great Serbia.

In realizing the church's long-held dream that all Serbs should live in the same state, the rise of Mr. Milosevic in the late 1980's was the best news the Serbian Orthodox Church had heard for decades, Mr. Djordjevic said.

"The church believed Milosevic was the Messiah who had come to smile on all Serbs," he said.

Later in Bosnia, the bishops openly supported Radovan Karadzic, blessing his war to lop off part of that former Yugoslav republic and fuse it to Serbia. Mr. Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs during the 1992-1995 war, has been indicted for war crimes.

After decades of Tito's Communism, during which the church was repressed and controlled by the Government and some of its vast properties were confiscated, Mr. Milosevic allowed the church to reclaim its role in Serbian society. Priests appeared on state-controlled television. He pledged to allow religious education in schools and to return church property, promises later broken.

But Christian holidays have again become public celebrations in Serbia and the church in 1989 was allowed to elect a patriarch, Pavle, who is from Kosovo, without Government interference. As Yugoslavia unraveled and wars began in the early 1990's, Serbian paramilitary leaders -- many of them responsible for atrocities and wholesale campaigns of theft in Croatia and Bosnia -- invoked the church as their inspiration for defending Serbs.

The warlord Zeljko Raznjatovic, who is known as Arkan and has been indicted as a war criminal, said publicly that his "supreme commander" was Patriarch Pavle. Before Arkan's indictment by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague but after worldwide publicity about the brutality and greed of his paramilitary fighters, Orthodox priests officiated at his lavish and very public wedding in Belgrade.

Mr. Djordjevic, regarded as a leading expert on the Serbian Church, says Patriarch Pavle has been "shocked" by the evidence of atrocities that he has seen in Kosovo since the 11-week war with NATO ended in early June.

That shock has resulted in what Mr. Djordjevic describes as a new direction for the Serbian Church, with the Patriarch and Bishop Artemije, the most senior representative of the church in Kosovo, speaking openly of "evil" done by Serbs against Albanians.

Bishop Artemije took part on Friday in a United Nations-sponsored meeting with the leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army, Hashim Thaci, and other Albanian leaders. They signed a joint statement condemning war crimes and crimes against humanity committed against Albanians in Kosovo.

Bishop Artemije has long opposed Mr. Milosevic but has not often been heard inside Serbia. Shortly after the NATO bombing began, he made a proclamation to be read in every church in Kosovo, criticizing what he called "pogroms" against the Albanians. It condemned the burning of houses and attacking of people.

"We read it in our church," said Father Sava, an assistant to Bishop Artemije and one of the most outspoken liberal priests in the church. Father Sava admitted that many priests may have chosen not to follow suit.

"It was brave, because of the secret police," the priest said. "And you know we have no free media. Bishop Artemije was then attacked by Serbian state media and called a madman."

The Orthodox Church is not a monolith, he explained, and priests do not have to obey the Patriarch, as members of the Roman Catholic Church have to obey the Pope.

"We are not unified," Father Sava said. "People can have their own political understanding. There are a lot of deluded people in the church as well."

In Belgrade on Friday, Bishop Atanasije insisted on steering an interview away from the matter of the church's new openness about atrocities committed by Serbs and toward what he described as foreigners' refusal to give equal time to the abuse of Serbs by other ethnic groups across Yugoslavia.

"Westerners tend to close their eyes when the suffering of Serbs is concerned," the bishop said, emphasizing an abiding tradition in the Orthodox Church that sees Serbs as victims of foreign manipulation. "What was done in Kosovo, of course, was evil. But the next question that has to be asked is who committed evil. The Serbs were not the only actors."
  http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: Patriarch Pavle has called Slobodan Milosevic's policies criminal. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. 1); By Orthodox Church tradition, wherever Serbs live and bury their dead should be part of Serbia. At a Serbian Orthodox monastery in Pec, Kosovo, Marica Miric, 85, mourned last week at the grave of her daughter. Serbs in the city of Pec at a liturgy for St. Vitus's Day, which marks the Serbs' epic battle in 1389 against Ottoman Turks at Kosovo Polje. (Photographs by Associated Press)(pg. 4)

136 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


October 14, 2002 Monday Final Edition


Lack of votes cast renders Serbian election invalid: Result drags out political instability


SOURCE: New York Times


BYLINE: Daniel Simpson


SECTION: World; Pg. A5


LENGTH: 438 words


DATELINE: Belgrade, Yugoslavia


Weary of political infighting and unsure of which reformist faction to support, more than half the Serbian electorate did not vote in Sunday's presidential election, rendering the result invalid.

Under legislation dating from Slobodan Milosevic's autocratic rule in the 1990s, if less than 50 per cent of the voters turn out, the election must be held again within two months.

Just 45.4 per cent ventured into rain to cast ballots Sunday, ignoring warnings from both presidential candidates that a failed election would only drag out the political instability that is holding back Serbia's economic recovery. 

Serbia's current president, Milan Milutinovic, has been indicted by the UN war crimes tribunal at The Hague, where Milosevic is on trial, and is widely expected to surrender once his term expires at the end of this year.

Preliminary results from the vote showed Vojislav Kostunica, a conservative nationalist who replaced Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia, easily defeated Miroljub Labus, a pro-western liberal and architect of the government's economic reforms.

Kostunica, who is seeking a new job before the Yugoslav federation grouping Serbia and Montenegro is abolished, won 66.7 per cent of the vote against 31.3 per cent for Labus, according to Belgrade's Centre for Free Elections and Democracy, which monitored the ballot.

Both are veterans of the disparate alliance of reformers that ousted Milosevic two years ago, but they represent two rival factions that quickly emerged from the anti-Milosevic movement.

A bitter power struggle between the two camps -- one led by Kostunica, the other by the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic -- has brought reforms to a standstill and alienated voters.

"Serbs are tired of political squabbling," said Jovan Maric, a psychiatrist and prominent commentator on social issues.

"They have sent a signal to the government that it needs to do something dramatic to make people's lives better."

Many observers fear politicians will now devote their attention to electioneering rather than the economic and political reforms Serbia needs to recover from a decade of wars, isolation and impoverishment under Milosevic. But if the campaign is as contentious as this one, it could prove just as difficult to motivate the electorate in two months.

"People don't see anything to vote for and neither candidate gave them much of an incentive," one western diplomat said.

"After Labus lost the first round, there were only two conceivable outcomes in the runoff -- a Kostunica victory and a failed election. Both just mean further political uncertainty."


LOAD-DATE: October 14, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Colour Photo: Reuters; Presidential candidate Miroljub Labus casts his ballot Sunday in Serbian presidential elections.


TYPE: News

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

137 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


June 5, 1992, Friday, VALLEY; CAPITAL EDITION


BOSNIA-HERCEGOVINA; Serbian president must quit to stop war, opposition says


BYLINE: KITTY MCKINSEY; SOUTHAM NEWS


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2


DATELINE: BELGRADE


Serbian opposition leaders Thursday called on President Slobodan Milosevic to resign after he said he would do just that if the United Nations ended the economic blockade of his republic.

In an interview with a British television company, Milosevic said Wednesday he would "absolutely" resign if it would end sanctions imposed last weekend to punish Serbia for perceived aggression in the war in Bosnia-Hercegovina.

"I really don't know whether he said it seriously," said Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, but it is clear "Serbia's salvation depends on his resignation." 

Vojislav Kostunica, vice-president of the Democratic Party, agreed Milosevic's resignation would hasten the end of the war in Bosnia and lead to greater democracy in Serbia. But he said "it is not a serious offer."

Others questioned whether Milosevic's resignation -- real or not -- would achieve an end to the sanctions.

"It's a good trick," said Jurij Bajec, a former close associate and now critic of Milosevic.

"But the sanctions could not be lifted just because he resigned because then the world would admit that they really wanted to get rid of him and not to end the war in Bosnia," Bajec said.

Meanwhile, Serbs of all political persuasions said innocent people would soon be paying a high price for measures that would have no effect on Milosevic.

The sanctions include a trade and oil embargo and a ban on flights in and out of Yugoslavia, comprising only Serbia and tiny Montenegro.

Even UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has admitted Milosevic has limited influence over Serbian irregulars fighting Muslims and Croats in Bosnia.

"You can bet Milosevic is doing everything he can to end the war in Bosnia because his own head is on the line now," said Bajec.

Kostunica, from the Democratic Party, said Milosevic is being bombarded by international and domestic calls for his resignation. In an extraordinary move, the Serbian Orthodox church last week called on him to step down.

"This must represent a serious psychological problem for Milosevic," said Kostunica.

However, many Serbs said the West's intense opposition to Milosevic may even strengthen his position by rallying compatriots to his side.

"All these rumors about military intervention are bringing us closer to unification because we are an irrational, emotional people," said Danko Djunic, managing director of the independent Economics Institute.

Opposition leaders could only rally about 35,000 people in Belgrade, a city of approximately 1.7 million, for an anti-Milosevic rally on Sunday.

"To say we are frustrated is an understatement," admitted Milan Komnenic, vice-president of the Serbian Renewal Movement. He was speaking of the opposition's failure to mould widespread dissatisfaction with the Serbian economic and political situation into a force that could topple Milosevic.

Milosevic, a former Communist leader, was democratically elected in December 1990 as a socialist.


LOAD-DATE: June 5, 1992


LENGTH: 502 words


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

138 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


October 15, 2002 Tuesday Final Edition


Low voter turnout invalidates results


SOURCE: New York Times News Service


BYLINE: Daniel Simpson


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. D08


LENGTH: 650 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


Weary of political infighting and unsure of which reformist faction to support, over half the Serbian electorate did not vote in Sunday's presidential election, rendering the result invalid.

Under legislation dating from Slobodan Milosevic's autocratic rule in the 1990s, if less than 50 per cent of the voters turn out, the election must be held again within two months.

Just 45.4 per cent cast their ballots Sunday, ignoring warnings from both presidential candidates that a failed election would only drag out the political instability that is holding back Serbia's economic recovery. 

Serbia's current president, Milan Milutinovic, has been indicted by the UN war crimes tribunal at The Hague, Netherlands, where Milosevic is on trial, and is widely expected to surrender once his term expires at year's end.

Preliminary voter results showed that Vojislav Kostunica, a conservative nationalist who replaced Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia, easily defeated Miroljub Labus, a pro-Western liberal and architect of the government's economic reform program.

Kostunica, who is seeking a new job before the Yugoslav federation grouping Serbia and Montenegro is abolished, won 66.7 per cent of the vote against 31.3 per cent for Labus, according to Belgrade's Center for Free Elections and Democracy, which monitored the ballot.

Both men are veterans of the disparate alliance of reformers that ousted Milosevic two years ago, but represent two rival factions that quickly emerged from the anti-Milosevic movement.

A bitter power struggle between the two camps -- one led by Kostunica, the other by Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic -- has halted reforms and alienated voters desperate for living standards to improve.

"Serbs are tired of political squabbling," said Jovan Maric, a psychiatrist and prominent commentator on social issues. "These elections were a slap in the face for Djindjic. They have sent a signal to the government that it needs to do something dramatic to make people's lives better."

Apart from the state broadcaster RTS and a couple of small independent channels, television networks did not broadcast special election programs Sunday night, reflecting a widespread lack of interest in the vote.

Many observers fear that politicians will now devote their attention to electioneering rather than the reforms Serbia needs to recover from a decade of wars, international isolation and impoverishment under Milosevic.

But if the campaign is as contentious as this one has been, it could prove just as difficult to motivate the electorate in two months.

"People don't see anything to vote for and neither candidate gave them much of an incentive," one Western diplomat said. "After Labus lost the first round, there were only two conceivable outcomes in the runoff -- a Kostunica victory and a failed election. Both just mean further political uncertainty."

Although Labus said he had not yet decided whether to run again, he is unlikely to have Djindjic's backing after Sunday's result.

Kostunica, who is Serbia's most popular politician, is demanding that a general election be held as soon as possible in the hope of gaining control of Parliament.

As Serbian president, he would be better placed to persuade some of the 17 parties in Djindjic's coalition to join his camp and rob the government of its majority. Political survival for Djindjic, who is personally unpopular with voters, largely depends on his ability to thwart Kostunica's ambitions.

Unless these two men can reconcile their differences or one of them wins, their power struggle will continue to dictate post-Milosevic politics.

"The problem with our politicians is vanity," said Radmilo Kljajic, a columnist for Serbia's leading daily newspaper, Politika.

"The government did not actually implement changes, but tried to hang onto power using Milosevic's laws."


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Kostadin Kamenov, the Associated Press; An election official at a polling station waits for the electorate to vote in the Serbian election. Low turnout means a runoff must be held within two months.


TYPE: News
