139 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


March 16, 2000


Search for a safe harbour;
Jonathan Steele One year on and Kosovo still suffers from the tragic consequences of unresolved conflict


SECTION: Guardian Leader Pages; Pg. 23


LENGTH: 1179 words


Father Sava Janjic is one of the bravest Serbs left in Kosovo. A soft-spoken figure whose scholarly appearance masks passionately held views, his rare quality is his willingness to acknowledge the crimes done to Albanians by the Milosevic regime.

Yet as sits in the high-ceilinged refectory of the monastery of Gracanica, he has little to feel cheerful about. A leader of the Serb National Council in Kosovo, he became the articulate voice of those Serbs who felt they should cooperate with the United Nations administration when it arrived in the territory in June. 

Now he feels let down and under pressure. Kfor, the international peace force, is failing to protect Serbs enough to give them freedom of movement beyond their prison enclaves, let alone create conditions for those who left Kosovo to want to come home. In the northern city of Mitrovice which has been effectively partitioned, pro-Milosevic Serbs boast that their success in keeping Albanians out shows a tough line is the only solution. Father Sava senses Slobodan Milosevic's support in Kosovo is growing and that the hard -liners who denounce Kfor as nothing more than an occupation force are gaining strength. The trouble in Mitrovice is not just a battle between Serbs and Albanians but a struggle for the allegiance of Kosovo's Serbs.

Amid his many disappointments Father Sava's regrets the lack of support which he and his boss, Bishop Artemije, Kosovo's senior Orthodox clergyman, have had from opposition politicians in Belgrade. At a recent meeting, the two clerics asked the anti-Milosevic politicians to sign a joint declaration which would stress two points. First, that it was not an act of treason for Kosovo's Serbs to work with the United Nations. Second, that 'injustices' had been inflicted on Albanians. Although this was deliberately softer than the clergymen's usual formulation 'crimes', even this was too much for Belgrade's opposition.

Had it been signed, the statement would have had far-ranging political benefits. Father Sava and Bishop Artemije are convinced that unless more Serbs acknowledge that the atrocities done in their name are the prime cause of the hatred which bedevils Kosovo today, tolerance will take a long time to grow.

It is easy to see that Serbs cannot readily accept that their side bears the greater guilt. What is more depressing is the way this escape from the facts is beginning to creep into western public discourse on Kosovo's shaky peace. Allan Little's recent BBC2 programme, Moral Combat, was only the latest example of the tendency to say a plague on both houses - with the danger that the international community will wash its hands and withdraw from Kosovo, as Milosevic is no doubt calculating. Little produced an excellent discussion of the conflict among western politicians and military strategists over the conduct of the war, but he put it into a surprisingly one-dimensional framework which gave no political context beyond the tendentious claim that from the very beginning the Kosovo Liberation Army aimed at provoking a Nato intervention. If that was so, how come the KLA's man at Rambouillet did most to anger the Americans and endanger the talks? And what happened to the consensus among all who reported on Kosovo in 1998, including Allan Little, that the KLA was one of the least centralised and disparate guerrilla movements of recent times, with minimal overall leadership and no clear strategy?

The notion of 'balance', in which a suffering Albanian family is juxtaposed with a suffering Serb family, culminated in the programme's final line that 'the oppressed, now liberated, have become the oppressors', which created a false moral and historical equivalence. Is there really no difference between a state-machine whose security forces use arson, artillery, and cold-blooded murder on a mass scale against people still in their homes, and the hot -blooded revenge-seeking of bereaved people returning to destroyed villages and burning the houses of their Serb neighbours, usually after the Serbs had already left?

Now we have moved to a second post-war stage, where crime in Kosovo is random, opportunistic, urban and largely done by professional criminals who want to make money out of Serb flats rather than by former refugees in the countryside. It is the inevitable consequence of a law and order vacuum, for which the international community is mainly to blame for failing to provide the police it promised. Take away the police from London or Berlin, and see how quickly the crime rate would soar.

This is not to deny that the current violence against Serbs in Kosovo takes place in a vindictive atmosphere where most Albanians, regrettably, think ethnically. Moderate Albanian opinion keeps quiet and witnesses to repression do not come forward. Far from restraining them, parents encourage their children to stone Serb buses when they pass through Albanian areas under Kfor escort. The Albanian press does not feel able or willing to report fairly, let alone critically, on what is being done to Serbs.

This is where Father Sava comes back in. Albanians would start to differentiate and not lump all Serbs together as evil-doers if they felt more Serbs were able to accept the truth about what happened in 1998 and 1999, and even show some sense of collective responsibility. Albanians would also relax if more Serbs did not go on behaving, as those in Mitrovice do, as though the Serbs can still win the war and get Kfor to withdraw.

For western governments the message is clear. The ambiguity of UN resolution 1244 which left Kosovo's final status obscure has become a liability. It gives false encouragement to Serbs and real anxiety to Albanians. What is needed is a forthright statement by the western powers, and preferably the security council as a whole, that Kosovo will never return to Serb rule. This would help the cowardly opposition in Belgrade to break free of the nationalist cancer. They could correctly argue that it was Milosevic who lost Kosovo, and then go on to develop a modern political and economic agenda no longer distorted by territorial self-delusion.

For Albanians such a declaration would provide a reason to stop seeing every Serb in Kosovo as a potential fifth columnist. In exchange for an international commitment that Kosovo's return to Serb rule is off the table for ever, the leaders of the various Kosovo Albanian parties should be urged to agree to a formal statement that the territory will remain legally part of Yugoslavia, though under international protection, for three or five more years. In that period Milosevic might finally leave power or Yugoslavia, with the help of Montenegro, might dissolve - leaving Kosovo independent by default.

There are hard choices ahead for Serbs, Albanians, and the international community, but to trivialise Kosovo's current troubles as an endless Balkan cycle of violence does no service to anyone.

Find a special report on the Guardian network at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/ kosovo


LOAD-DATE: March 15, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


140 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


November 10, 1999, FINAL


Serb police attack anti-Milosevic protesters


SECTION: News; A12


LENGTH: 248 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Police armed with batons and backed by armoured vehicles waded into more than 2,000 anti-government demonstrators marching on parliament yesterday. Student leaders said about 50 people were injured. 

Deputies loyal to President Slobodan Milosevic, meanwhile, unexpectedly agreed to consider opposition demands for early elections legislation. But the lawmakers also moved to take over Serbian municipalities governed by the opposition.

Some wounded demonstrators were left lying motionless on the pavement. Others fled, shouting: ''Slobodan to The Hague!'' referring to the UN tribunal that has charged Mr. Milosevic with war crimes.

The official Serbian television station accused the students of provoking the crackdown, and showed footage of the demonstrators throwing objects at police. It said the police action was justified and professional.

The student organization Otpor, or Resistance, told the Beta news agency that 50 people were injured.

In parliament, which is dominated by Mr. Milosevic's allies, the deputies' offer to discuss early general elections provided no guarantee that the elections would be approved. Elections are scheduled for the end of 2000.

A decision by the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party, to walk out of the legislature further diminished chances of such an agreement between Mr. Milosevic's neo-communists and ultranationalists. The parliament decided to discuss the matter today.


LOAD-DATE: November 10, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

141 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


The Milosevic question: Serbs debating Yugoslavia's future with an intensity that's increasing


SECTION: News; A1 / FRONT


LENGTH: 888 words


DATELINE: PROKUPLJE, Yugoslavia


Protesters demanding the resignation of Slobodan Milosevic stoned his party's headquarters here yesterday after a supporter of the Yugoslav president fired gunshots into the air to disrupt the rally.

A scheduled counter-demonstration by government supporters failed to materialize, and police did not interfere with the rally by about 4,000 demonstrators, the latest in a series of protests that have seen tens of thousands of people out in the streets demanding that Milosevic step down.

''We will chase him out, '' said Goran Svilanovic, a top figure in the Alliance for Change, an umbrella group of opposition parties that organized the rally and other anti- Milosevic protests.

Opposition parties are trying to capitalize on the growing discontent among Serbs against Milosevic over the loss of historic Kosovo province after a widely destructive 78-day bombing campaign by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. 

''They put shame on us, killing and burning in our name,'' Svilanovic said, referring to atrocities committed by Milosevic's forces against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

Historian Milan Protic, another Alliance activist, said: ''Too much evil has been done for them to be forgiven. It is too little to just demand that they leave. We must make them leave.''

For the planned counter-demonstration, only about two dozen Milosevic supporters, mostly elderly, showed up and traded insults with the protesters in Prokuplje, a town of about 20,000 about 190 kilometres south of Belgrade.

One protester was slightly injured in a shoving match with government supporters. Some of the counter-demonstrators hung a banner on a nearby roof calling the protesters ''traitors.''

A Milosevic supporter came out of an office of the ruling Socialist Party and fired several gunshots into the air. No one was injured, but protesters began to throw stones at the building until their leaders appealed for calm.

Police did not intervene.

With memories of the NATO bombing still fresh, Milosevic has sought to portray his opponents as traitors and pawns in a Western plot to destabilize Yugoslavia. The accusations, pushed by state-run media, have made it difficult for opposition parties to advocate Western-style democracy and reforms.

Elsewhere, the Socialist Party blasted the top anti-Milosevic leader and head of the Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, as ''an unofficial spokesman for NATO and Albanian separatists.''

Djindjic, who has visited NATO countries recently to drum up support, returned to Yugoslavia last week despite a military court's decision to investigate him on allegations that he dodged military service during the Kosovo conflict. Serbia's state-run media have branded him a traitor who sided with NATO and Albanian separatists in Kosovo, Serbia's southern province.

Djindjic and other Milosevic opponents have been emboldened by the size and spontaneity of recent protests in several Serbian cities. Djindjic has said daily demonstrations could build a broad enough base for a general strike aimed at ousting Milosevic.

Djindjic spent part of yesterday in Kosovo, seeking the support of Serbian Orthodox Church leaders and meeting with Western officials involved in the peacekeeping operation.

But he got a hostile reception from Serbs in Gracanica, a village near Pristina, the province's capital. The crowd chanted pro-Milosevic slogans, shouted that Djindjic and his colleagues were ''thieves'' and kicked and pushed journalists and camera operators covering the disturbance.

The protesters ''were sent to make trouble, by Milosevic, of course,'' Djindjic said after the riot was put down by soldiers attached to NATO's peace-implementation force. ''It was a joke by Milosevic - one of his last jokes.''

Serbia's Orthodox Church, already the source of outspoken attacks on Milosevic, formally added its weight to the Alliance campaign. Bishop Vladika Artemije of Raska and Prizren and the Alliance set out their common aims in a statement after yesterday's meeting. ''We jointly declare that the only way toward the salvation of Serbia and of Kosovo and Metohija (the Serb designation for the province) is in the urgent and thorough transformation of Serbia into a democratic country,'' the statement said.

Djindjic, a former mayor of Belgrade whose fluency in foreign languages has made him a focal point of the opposition movement for international media, said he hopes Serbs in Kosovo will realize that ditching Milosevic would help them live in safety and peace.

''Some problems in Kosovo cannot be solved if Serbia does not become democratic. Only with a democratic Serbia can Serbs remain in Kosovo,'' Djindjic said.

In the month since NATO's occupation of Kosovo, demonstrations and anti-government rallies have erupted across Serbia. The northern Serb city of Novi Sad, battered during NATO's air war, has been the scene of incessant anti-Milosevic protests and marches.

The common folk are not the only ones who have caught the virus. Even more devastating to Milosevic's political future has been the participation of Yugoslav army soldiers in protest rallies and a recent insurrection by reporters and editors in the state's media machine over the government's determination to set news policy.

Southam News contributed to this report


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

142 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


June 15, 1992, Monday, Final Edition


Serbs Cooperating in Sarajevo, Leader of Peace Keepers Says


Blaine Harden, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1


LENGTH: 1036 words


DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia, June 14, 1992


After weeks of frustration and failure in international efforts to break the siege of Sarajevo, the commander of the U.N. peace-keeping mission said here today that he now is receiving tangible cooperation from Serb forces who surround the city.

"We have confirmed that the Serbian leaders are committed to opening the airport. Things are moving in the right direction," said Brig. Gen. Lew MacKenzie, the Canadian commander of the U.N. peace-keeping operation here.

The most immediate threat to opening the airport and lifting the siege now appears to be coming not from Serb forces, but from the primarily Muslim defenders of the city. 

They have mounted a major offensive, using artillery and infantry, to reclaim a downtown neighborhood called Grbavica. At the cost of many casualties, the Muslims appear to have surrounded and sealed off a Serb fighting unit in the neighborhood.

The two sides separately signed a new cease-fire, to go into effect at 6 a.m. Monday, that will test whether the Muslim side is prepared to give up its relative advantage in Grbavica for the sake of opening the airport and feeding the city.

"It will be a great tragedy if they continue the offensive," said MacKenzie. He said a cease-fire will have to hold before more U.N. forces are brought into Sarajevo, the airport is opened and food can reach hungry people.

After a spectacular Saturday night of rocket attacks and street fighting near the city center, there was a noticeable decline today in fighting in and around Sarajevo.

Serb fighters allowed U.N. technicians access to Sarajevo airport, where they began assessing how quickly it can be opened to international relief flights.

"The blockade will be lifted in four days," a banner headline in the Sarajevo daily newspaper Oslobodzenje announced. But MacKenzie said in an interview that if "everything goes right" it will take at least eight or nine days to open the airport.

Still, the news lifted spirits in a city short of food, water, electricity and hope. A few cafes opened to eager customers, and many residents defied sporadic sniper fire to walk the streets in search of food.

About 50,000 tons of relief food and medical supplies are waiting at nearby Zagreb airport for an airlift to relieve the food shortage. The capital of Bosnia-Herzegovina has been under siege by the Serbs for 10 weeks. In several sealed-off neighborhoods, residents are believed to be starving.

About five tons of food and medicine arrived in Sarajevo by road on Saturday night, with another 95 tons of French aid waiting 30 miles outside Sarajevo for Serbian clearance.

U.N. officers held meetings today with Serb commanders on the removal of antiaircraft guns and missile systems to a distance of at least six miles from the airport. Serb and Bosnian leaders signed a deal nine days ago that commits them to giving the United Nations sole control of Sarajevo airport.

Meetings were also held this weekend on a plan for both the Serb and Bosnian sides to move their artillery into locations where they can be monitored by the United Nations.

"We discussed the concentration of the guns. The term 'goodwill' has to be used," said MacKenzie, who met on Saturday for two hours with the political leader of Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, and the commander of most Serb military units in Bosnia, Gen. Ratko Mladic.

In another signal that the Serbs may be changing what had been an overtly hostile attitude toward U.N. peace keepers, a captain was sent this weekend as a liaison officer to live in the U.N. mission headquarters in Sarajevo. In turn, two U.N. officers were sent as live-in observers to the main Serb military barracks on the edge of the city.

U.N. sources said the level of Serb cooperation here is a result of mounting international and domestic pressure on the Belgrade regime of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic.

Milosevic, despite his repeated denials, is said by Western governments to have been responsible for starting the ethnic war in Bosnia, and he is thought to exercise considerable control over Serb fighters here.

In Belgrade, the Serbian capital, Milosevic's problems are growing daily. U.N. economic sanctions against Serb-dominated Yugoslavia, imposed two weeks ago, are gutting the economy. Big state-owned factories have been idled, foreign companies such as the McDonald's fast-food chain are closing, and superhighways have emptied. Gasoline, spare parts and some basic foods are short, and hyper-inflation has made it difficult for many pensioners to afford food.

At the same time, Serbia's fractious domestic political opposition has united under an umbrella group that is calling for Milosevic's immediate resignation.

Street demonstrations in Belgrade today drew thousands of people, who marched on the Serbian assembly and on Milosevic's office.

Many of the pillars of the once-docile Serbian establishment have been drawn into the dump-Milosevic movement. They include a circle of senior Serbian writers and academics, as well as the Serbian Orthodox Church.

The exiled head of a Serbian royal family, Crown Prince Michael, also has joined the opposition. His appeal to Serbian traditionalists is being used by the umbrella group to siphon off Milosevic's appeal to nationalism.

Serbian Patriarch Pavle, the normally nonpolitical leader of the Orthodox Church, led one of today's demonstrations. He warned that Serbia faces civil war unless the government surrenders power quickly. "Our greatest enemy is domestic Serbian evil," he told the crowd.

The anti-Milosevic demonstrations came despite threats from radical Serbian nationalist groups to use force to stop street demonstrations. Milosevic's regime has backed a number of criminals who lead paramilitary groups that fought in Bosnia and in the former Yugoslav republic of Croatia. The return of many of these fighters to Belgrade has sparked widespread fear among Western governments that murder and assassinations could be used to stop the anti-Milosevic movement.

The U.S. government on Saturday ordered all American citizens to leave Serbia and its small ally Montenegro. It also announced a sharp reduction in staff at its embassy in Belgrade.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: FOREIGN NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post


143 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


August 21, 1999, Saturday


Unexpected promise


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 622 words


 

Beforehand, many suggested that it would not happen or, if it did, that it would not amount to much. But, in the end, Wednesday's opposition rally in Belgrade, to demand the resignation of President Milosevic of Yugoslavia, turned out to be a night to remember. The crowd of up to 100,000 people that assembled outside the Federal Parliament building was the largest anti-Milosevic gathering since before Nato's air war for Kosovo. Although he had said earlier that he would not bother to attend, the charismatic Vuk Draskovic, leader of the largest opposition party and hero of earlier mass protest rallies in 1996, did after all turn up at the last minute, drawing criticism from the government-controlled television network that he was "fulfilling a promise" to the hated United States. Support for the protest came from abroad, too, in the shape of a message from the London-based Prince Alexander Karadjordjevic, pretender to the Serbian throne, urging opposition parties to keep out of any coalition with Mr Milosevic. Seen inside and outside Serbia as a barometer of the public's attitude to Milosevic - after his disastrous policy in the southern province of Kosovo which triggered the Nato bombing campaign - there are elements of both bad and good news in the outcome of the rally. 

The bad news is the publicly voiced discord that keeps opposition leaders at each other's throat rather than working towards the same goals. Zoran Djindjic, who heads the Democratic Party, demanded, to cheers from the crowd, that Mr Milosevic and his Government resign within 15 days or face mass protests. The Serbian Orthodox Church and Group 17, an alliance of economists and technocrats, want a transitional government of experts to rule for a year, after Mr Milosevic resigns and before new elections can be held. But, when the bearded Mr Draskovic - a bitter personal rival of Mr Djindjic - made his dramatic appearance, he poured cold water on these plans. His competing agenda was less radical: moving forward elections due next year to November. The same suggestion had already been made this week by Mr Milosevic's aides; moreover, the mercurial Mr Draskovic, who had moved briefly from opposition to government before being sacked in April for speaking out against the war, is viewed in some quarters as an opportunist. The jeers of "traitor!" that greeted his proposal may, therefore, have indicated no more than suspicion about whether he could be moving back into the Government's orbit; they may, however, suggest a darker truth. Some opposition members turned against Mr Milosevic simply because he lost Kosovo, the terrain they called the Serb heartland, and not because of the atrocities perpetrated there in the name of his twisted brand of nationalism; the hostile reception given to Mr Draskovic raises worrying questions about how far even Serb opposition activists still are from confronting the hard truths they will need to learn if they are to fashion a real democracy. More immediately, the clash also left unclear where the movement's divided leadership can take it next. Even the next rally date was in dispute: Group 17 wanted September 21, Mr Djindjic August 28.

Yet the sheer size and energy of the turnout gives reason for hope that Mr Milosevic's grip on Serbia is, at last, weakening. Organisers had been scared of calling protesters out in sophisticated but weary Belgrade, whose people had learnt the hard way in 1996 that mass rallies, however enthusiastic, can fail to produce political change. Yet hope triumphed over experience, and tens of thousands turned out again. Despite the weakness of the Opposition's split leadership, there is real strength in the movement's grassroots.


LOAD-DATE: August 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Times Newspapers Limited


144 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Daily Telegraph (LONDON)


March 17, 2006 Friday


Nation divided as Milosevic coffin goes on display in Belgrade museum


BYLINE: Kate Connolly in Belgrade


SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 305 words


THOUSANDS queued to pay their last respects to the Serbian dicatator Slobodan Milosevic yesterday as his coffin was displayed in Belgrade.

It arrived at a city museum in a silver van and will lie in state on a red carpet until the end of today, against the wishes of the director of the museum, built to honour another Yugoslav leader, Tito. 

"They have turned my museum into a funeral parlour,'' said the director, Ljiljana Cetinic. "I most strongly protest as a director and a citizen of this country,'' she added.

The vocal opposition to Milosevic's welcome home, especially from those who consider him a traitor and his return an embarrassment, grew in volume. But a stream of mainly elderly people visited the closed coffin, bowing their heads at the remains of their former hero or kissing his portrait.

Outside those waiting in the snow clutched flowers and candles and denounced as "murderers'' his United Nations jailers in The Hague, where he died last weekend.

A rally protesting against the funeral in Milosevic's birthplace, Pozarevac, tomorrow will take place at the same time in Belgrade. Anti-Milosevic campaigners, including those who aided his overthrow in 2000, issued invitations to a "springtime is early'' demonstration by text message.

Ivan Marovic, 32, a founding member of Odpor, the student movement that played a key role in toppling Milosevic, said he feared that Serbia still had to confront his legacy. "We have not begun to deal with what he did to us and to others and we desperately need to,'' he said.

"It is a difficult job and will take a decade, but unless we do it there will be no guarantee that another person like Milosevic will not take his place.''

Only one newspaper, the pro-western Danas, has reflected on his crimes, running a picture spread entitled: "The darkest years of Serbian history''.

INTERNATIONAL   A3-14
 
Taiwan Quake Toll Mounts As Search Efforts Continue
The death toll from Tuesday's earthquake in Taiwan has risen past 2,000, with another 6,500 people injured and 2,300 believed still trapped in the rubble, the Government said. Hundreds of thousands are homeless and many communities in north and central Taiwan are still without power.   A6
 
China Leaders Affirm Overhaul
A four-day meeting of the Communist Party's top leaders reaffirmed a commitment to reorganizing state-owned enterprises and making them globally competitive. The Central Committee also gave Vice President Hu Jintao, above, a new position as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission, strengthening the impression that he is President Jiang Zemin's choice as successor.   A12 


Israeli Visits Nazi Camp
Prime Minister Ehud Barak, visiting Germany, toured the site of the Sachsenhausen death camp with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder.   A3
 
Heightened Alarm Over Hamas
Two bombs that exploded prematurely in Israel and Jordan's arrest of three Hamas leaders renewed attention on threats posed by the militant Islamic movement.   A7
 
Tension in Timor Delays Aid
Concerns about security are delaying the start of an aid program to help East Timorese refugees in urgent need of food, shelter and medical care, aid workers said.   A4
 
Objections to U.N. Intervention
Secretary General Kofi Annan's call for more active intervention by the United Nations when civilian populations are at risk is meeting resistance in the General Assembly.   A5
 
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said Congress's unwillingness to pay arrears to the United Nations had hampered Administration efforts to sway the organization.   A13
 
Anti-Milosevic Protests Falter
Street protests intended to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia appeared to falter on their second day.   A11
 
Bank Official Testifies
The chairman of the Bank of New York said suspicious activity in accounts at the core of the Russian money-laundering inquiry had not been stopped because the accounts were held by the husband of a highly regarded bank officer.   A8
 
World Briefing   A14
 
NATIONAL   A18-25
 
U.S. Accuses Big Tobacco Of Conspiracy on Smoking
The Justice Department closed a criminal investigation of the tobacco industry and instead filed a civil lawsuit accusing the largest cigarette companies of conspiring since the 1950's to defraud and mislead the public about the health effects of smoking. The suit seeks to recover billions that the Government spent on smoking-related health care.   A1
 
Espionage Inquiry Widened
Attorney General Janet Reno and the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, left, have ordered Federal agents to broaden their investigation into evidence of Chinese nuclear espionage, moving beyond scrutiny of Wen Ho Lee, a scientist fired from Los Alamos National Laboratory.   A1
 
Deal to Delay New Fighter
Congressional negotiators said they had sketched out a deal to delay for a year the Air Force's $70 billion F-22 fighter jet program.   A24
 
Assessing Year 2000 Risk
The United States is largely prepared for Year 2000 computer problems, although concerns remain in some areas, a Senate panel said.   A22
 
McCain Assails Buchanan
Senator John McCain denounced Patrick J. Buchanan's views of World War II and called on Republicans to bid him farewell.   A24
 
An Internet Scheme
Investigators said a Portuguese hacker and an Australian pornography company had devised a scheme to hold hostage Internet users who were tricked into visiting pornography sites. The only escape was to quit the Net or turn off the computer.   A1
 
Sweepstakes Lawsuit
Florida's Attorney General filed a suit accusing Publishers Clearing House of deceptive practices.   A18
 
S.E.C. Complaint Against Miami
The City of Miami was accused by Federal regulators of defrauding its bondholders by deliberately concealing a 1995 financial crisis.   A18
 
Muscular Dystrophy Research
Scientists said they had made bone marrow cells turn into muscle, causing mice with the disease to produce correctly working muscle cells.   A19

Shania Twain and the Dixie Chicks were big winners at the Country Music Association Awards.   A22
 
NEW YORK/REGION   B1-14
 
Art Exhibit Incites Mayor To Warn Brooklyn Museum
Mayor Giuliani threatened to cut off city subsidies to the Brooklyn Museum of Art unless it canceled the opening next week of a British exhibition that features, among other works, a portrait of the Virgin Mary stained with a clump of elephant dung. The city gives the museum nearly one-third of its $23 million annual budget.   A1
 
State Budget Criticized
A number of fiscal experts said that despite a continuing economic boom that has left most states in their best financial shape in decades, New York's new budget actually worsens the state's long-term outlook.   B1
 
City Hailed for Traffic Safety
New York will share honors with Mendota, Ill., population 7,100, as a recipient of an A.A.A. award for traffic safety based on pedestrian fatalities, seat belt use, biking accidents and drunken driving.   B1
 
Deadly Street Attack by Group
Two men were shot to death and two others were seriously wounded when they were attacked by as many as 12 men on a relatively quiet side street in the East 20's in Manhattan, the police said.   B3

More than 20 Muslim cadets from the Middle East resigned from the State University of New York's Maritime College in the Bronx, saying they had been subjected to demeaning treatment and, in two cases, physical attack by other cadets.   B4

About 1.2 million people in northern New Jersey were urged to boil their tap water for a fifth straight day because of persistent flood-related problems at two major treatment plants.   B5

Federal prosecutors in Manhattan obtained a seizure warrant for one of the two Egon Schiele paintings that a New York court had just authorized to be returned to Austria. The painting, "Portrait of Wally," which was stolen by the Nazis, is now the subject of an ownership dispute.   E2

Interval Research, a pioneering Silicon Valley laboratory, is undergoing a major change of direction as a result of fundamental differences between David E. Liddle, the computer scientist who founded it seven years ago, and Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder who financed it.   C1

146 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 18, 1999, Sunday, Final Edition


Milosevic Foe Takes New Tack; Draskovic Calls For Revenge-Free Ouster of President


William Booth, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 974 words


DATELINE: KRAGUJEVAC, Yugoslavia, July 17


 

Serbia's most powerful opposition figure brought tens of thousands of frustrated citizens into the streets of this economically shattered city tonight in the largest protest thus far against the continued rule of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

Vuk Draskovic -- the charismatic leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement which sponsored the rally -- used the occasion to demonstrate his latest strategy for toppling the Milosevic government. Instead of trying to arouse the crowd with rhetoric about sending Milosevic to face an international tribunal on war crimes charges, Draskovic declared that the opposition should say "no to revenge" and added: "I will personally guarantee that Milosevic does not go to jail."

The new tactic could be a dicey one. Many Serbs would like to see Milosevic pay for the misery and global isolation he has brought them through four losing wars, but at least as many fear the internal strife this could cause -- not to mention the national shame of seeing their leader tried in a U.N.-sponsored court most view as rigged against them. 

"Serbia has to avoid the danger of a civil war," Draskovic said, warning that there are "forces in favor of civil war" in which Serb would fight against Serb and provide just the kind of excuse for "NATO troops [to] come in" -- as they have in Serbia's southern province of Kosovo.

Draskovic, a bearded populist who spent four months in prison for his attacks on the Milosevic government in the early 1990s, now appears to be reaching out to some members of the government to assure them that while Milosevic must go, some of them can hold on to their positions and perks. In effect, he appears to be trying to create an opportunity for Milosevic to step down with dignity and as little chaos as possible.

"We have to get out of this big disaster as peacefully as possible," Draskovic told the cheering crowd. To do this, he declared, sloganeering and demonstrations are not enough. Serbs do not need to shout at each other, he said, but to listen quietly.

The organizational power of Draskovic and his party, which controls the Belgrade city government, was in evidence here at the first anti-Milosevic rally he has called since the end of the Kosovo conflict -- the latest military debacle for the Serbs in 10 years of Milosevic-instigated wars among the ruins of the old Yugoslav federation.

There has been a number of other protest rallies around Serbia in the last two weeks, organized by smaller opposition parties and ad hoc groups, but they paled in comparison with the sophistication of the show put on by Draskovic -- who called himself the "czar of the streets" earlier in the decade, when he led hundreds of thousands of people in protests against government manipulation of election returns.

Today's rally looked like a rock concert. A large stage was erected near the central square, complete with theatrical lighting and towering sound speakers that blasted out music loud enough to induce a headache. Then, triumphantly, Draskovic arrived amid a small contingent of supporters and bodyguards who parted the crowd as they escorted the opposition leader to the stage.

It is hard to estimate the exact size of crowds at Serbian rallies. Police do not give numbers, and organizers often exaggerate attendance. Draskovic's party controls a Belgrade television station called Studio B, which reported that 50,000 people attended. That seemed a little high to foreign observers, who estimated the crowd at about half that number -- which still made it the largest postwar anti-Milosevic rally thus far.

Whether Draskovic and his new message will resonate with the exhausted and economically ruined residents of this central Serbian city of 200,000 remains to be seen.

"Kragujevac is a dying city," sighed Ratko Jovanovic, a municipal employee who is helping coordinate the massive influx of displaced Serbs here from war-ravaged Kosovo. The large industrial plants in the city's Zastava Complex, which made Yugo cars as well as trucks, spare parts and munitions, was hit hard by NATO bombs. Jovanovic estimates that 60,000 citizens here are out of work.

The only facilities still operating in Kragujevac produce milk, meat, canned goods and alcohol. "Everything else is dead," Jovanovic said. He said the city's heating plants must be rebuilt to keep people from freezing this winter but that there is no money available; the city budget is 5 percent of what it was a decade ago. Mostly, Jovanovic said, "we need food."

Draskovic told the crowd that what this war-weary land needs now is to create a transitional government in Belgrade composed of respected experts, then to seek an immediate end of international economic sanctions and a massive infusion of foreign aid and investment -- something the United States and other NATO countries have said they oppose so long as Milosevic remains in power. Draskovic also called for a return to Kosovo of the tens of thousands of Serbs who fled the province after the war and for speedy national elections conducted to European standards of fairness.

Zoran Spasic and his wife Vesna stood in the crowd with their 5-year-old daughter. Vesna Spasic is an unemployed lawyer; her husband is a salesman selling off the remaining spare parts from the Zastava Complex.

Like many Serbs, the Spasics said they just want to see an end to the Milosevic regime and the beginning of something positive, something that would help their people emerge from the ruin and waste of the last decade and reintegrate them into Europe.

Asked what they would do if they had to choose between violent change and no change at all, Zoran Spasic thought for a moment and asked: "Can we have change without violence?" His wife said, "We have had wars. Too many wars. We don't want any more."


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


147 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


Milosevic losing friends among Serbs


BYLINE: BLAINE HARDEN


SECTION: News; B1 / BREAK


LENGTH: 1072 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav president is surfacing across much of Serbia.

Hostility toward Milosevic, bubbling up this week on the streets of the most unlikely of towns, has raised expectations among opposition politicians that Milosevic's survival in power might now be measured not in years, but in months.

What has particularly raised eyebrows among political analysts, who are beginning to doubt if opposition parties can keep up with grass-roots anger, is the surprise eruption of large and violent protests in the large southern Serb city of Leskovac, a longtime stronghold of the Milosevic regime.

There, without the help of any political party, but with the active involvement of army reservists who fought in the lost war in Kosovo, more than 20,000 people marched on Monday night calling for Milosevic to resign. On Tuesday, about 2, 000 people charged the local police station, demanding the release of the local TV technician who organized Monday's rally. 

Police responded with tear gas and by beating demonstrators with nightsticks. Demonstrators retreated and later attacked the home of a local political boss who belongs to the Yugoslav Left, a hard-line Communist party headed by Milosevic's wife. They smashed windows in the house and destroyed its front gate, a police official there said by phone.

''If Milosevic is in trouble in Leskovac, then he is really in trouble,'' said Aleksa Djilas, a historian and political analyst in Belgrade who is not affiliated with the opposition groups trying to force the Yugoslav leader from office. ''It is like a Kennedy being in trouble in Boston. This is the beginning of the end. I don't know when the end will happen, but it will be months, not years.''

The muscular involvement of Yugoslav army reservists in demonstrations in Leskovac is a wild-card element that, if repeated in towns and cities across Serbia, could tip the scales against Milosevic much more quickly than opposition leaders had expected.

Since the end of the Kosovo war in early June, hundreds of reservists have intermittently blocked roads and bridges in central and southern Serbia, demanding pay for their service during the 11-week war in Kosovo.

The survival skills of Milosevic, who has been indicted on war- crimes charges, should not be underestimated. Although he has lost four wars this decade while presiding over the implosion of the economy, he remains a shrewd politician. He has weathered eruptions of mass unhappiness in Serbia before, most recently in the winter of 1996-97, when three months of daily demonstrations all but paralyzed Belgrade.

The two major tools in his survival kit are an enormous state police apparatus, which is still believed to be loyal, and state television, which is the primary source of information for most of the country.

There is a consensus among opposition leaders that Milosevic cannot afford politically to use the police to arrest, injure or kill large numbers of Serbs. As Zoran Djindjic, a key opposition leader, said in a rally on Tuesday night in the southwest town of Uzice, ''If there are a lot of us, they will not use force.''

Instead, they expect Milosevic to do what he has done in the past, deploy his police and his large party apparatus to harass, intimidate and try to buy off the opposition. For instance, to disrupt an opposition rally planned for tonight in the southern town of Prokuplje, Milosevic's Socialist Party has called its own rally at the same place and time. He tried the same tactic two years ago in Belgrade, without much success in igniting street violence.

That leaves television, which is doing what it has done so effectively throughout Milosevic's 12 years in power. It ignores or distorts all the news that is bad for Milosevic and his family, while vilifying their rivals and critics as corrupt, anti-Serb traitors. There has been almost no TV coverage, for instance, of this week's trouble in Leskovac or of three large opposition rallies in Serbia in the past week.

As they have been for years, opposition leaders in Serbia are divided about how best to plug into popular discontent, which is rooted both in anger about the lost war in Kosovo and fear of the collapsing economy.

The Serbian Renewal Movement, led by the charismatic Vuk Draskovic, had insisted since the war in Kosovo ended that the time was not right for street demonstrations. Draskovic, as recently as Monday, told a news conference that he is a ''legalist'' who wants to press for reform from within the system.

The stunning news from Leskovac, which is controlled by Milosevic's Socialists but where the Serbian Renewal Movement is the main opposition group, appears to have forced the hand of Draskovic. His party announced yesterday that it will take charge of a rally in Leskovac tonight.

Milan Bozic, the deputy mayor of Belgrade and a top leader in the Serbian Renewal Movement, said that all political parties in Serbia have underestimated both the depth of popular anti-Milosevic feeling and its power to bring people to the streets.

''All of sudden, it looks as though frustration over Milosevic is much more deeply embedded into the national consciousness than we expected, '' Bozic said.

Djindjic, a key leader of the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition groups, and a rival of Draskovic, delivered a rousing, if vague, speech on Tuesday that envisioned simultaneous daily rallies in towns across the country as well as a general strike.

Djindjic said he expects the Serbian Orthodox Church, which last month demanded that Milosevic resign and which has since been bitterly condemned on state television, will soon join the opposition and ring church bells across the country to call Serbs out on the nationwide general strike.

The timing and the planning for that strike are not yet clear, according to Milan Protic, also a leader of the Alliance for Change. He said the opposition movement has not yet sat down with church leaders to ask for their help.

The Milosevic regime appears to fear the involvement of the church in politics. Politika, its main newspaper, Wednesday published an angry commentary that condemned church leaders for making peace in Kosovo with ''terrorist'' Albanian leaders and warned the church to avoid the ''murky waters'' of politics.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Photo: DAVID BRAUCHLI, AP / French police officers protect ethnic Albanian women from flying stones thrown by Serbs hoping to keep them from going home to Mitrovica.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

148 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


July 16, 1999, Friday


THUGS BEAT UP ANTI-MILOSEVIC DEMONSTRATORS


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 11


LENGTH: 729 words


 

YESTERDAY was a bad day for democracy in Belgrade. A group of nine opposition activists were gathering signatures calling on the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, to resign, when they were attacked and savagely beaten by unidentified thugs.

Shortly after the attack, Serbia's parliament voted to keep in effect decrees giving police broad authority to harass and persecute anti-government protesters.

For the past two weeks, opposition parties have been gathering signatures across Serbia, calling on President Milosevic to resign. Despite constant harassment by the authorities, the petition drive has gathered hundreds of thousands of signatures so far. 

The campaign began in Belgrade last Monday at 29 points across the city. Yesterday, in front of a crowded business centre in the new part of town, New Belgrade, Aleksander Spasic, a 49-year-old economist, was one of nine people, four men and five women, manning a petition table.

The group had already gathered 93 signatures in half an hour when they were savagely set upon by ten men. The attackers all looked alike, with crew cuts and wearing blue jump suits, white T-shirts and white tennis shoes, Mr Spasic said.

"There were about 20 people around our table, signing petitions and talking to us. This band of ten large men pushed their way through the crowd and began to beat us. They even punched a woman who was signing a petition. I was pushed back against a kiosk and repeatedly punched. My glasses fell off, then someone said, 'Forget the old man'."

Slobodan Djordjevic was even more severely beaten. The 27-year-old unemployed economist was first punched, then repeatedly kicked on the ground by the group of men. He later received numerous stitches on his mouth and under his ear and was examined for possible head trauma.

Mr Spasic said that before leaving some of the attackers called the opposition members "traitors" and shouted: "Who's paying you?"

"I think it might have ended worse, but a throng of people, mostly women, began shouting at the men, calling them 'bandits' and 'criminals'," said Mr Spasic. "In the 15 minutes following the attack, we gathered another 70 signatures. Then at the hospital, doctors and nurses signed our petition."

The activists said the attackers knew exactly who they were after. When the police arrived 15 minutes later, the activists expected help. Instead, the police told them they had no right to be there and told them to leave immediately.

"They weren't at all interested in the fact that a group of innocent people had just been beaten," said Dragan Kopcalic of the Democratic Party. The activists refused to leave, but the police came back with a captain who ordered them to leave under threat of arrest.

An hour after the attack, Serbia's parliament voted to indefinitely retain 16 decrees that give police the authority to search citizens at will and require citizens to receive police approval for public gatherings.

The vote was a strong indication that the government intends to crack down on an opposition movement which is quickly gathering momentum.

Around 8,000 people gathered in a central square in Kragujevac yesterday where leaders of the Alliance for Change denounced Mr Milosevic and appealed for an end to damaging opposition splits.

Tomorrow, the Serbian Renewal Movement led by Vuk Draskovic will stage its first protest in the same town, an industrial centre badly hit by NATO's air campaign.

Yesterday's attack in Belgrade was the most violent in a series of government intimidation tactics. Police interrogated an opposition activist, Marko Durisic, earlier in the week. In Nis, petitioners were harassed by police before being driven out of the public market by the security forces.

"This is obviously an organised attempt to harass and intimidate those who don't support this regime," said Ljiljana Lucic, vice-president of the Democratic Party, one of the organisers of the petition drive.

Activists have gathered 13,000 signatures so far at the site of yesterday's attack, and Mr Djordjevic will not be intimidated. "Am I scared? Of course, but we have to push forward. This is an anti-human regime that stands against civilisation, and there is nothing you can do but be brave. This government has nothing left to offer but violence. We'll be out again tomorrow."


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


149 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


Milosevic to get run for his money: But Yugoslav leader is not above creating havoc to ensure he retains presidency, power


BYLINE: JOHN NADLER


SECTION: News; B8


LENGTH: 1453 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


The newly founded Democratic Opposition of Serbia alliance has reason to be hopeful it can unseat the Yugoslav president.

Amid fears of war and election fraud, Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the newly founded Democratic Opposition of Serbia alliance, officially kicked off his campaign to replace Slobodan Milosevic as Yugoslavia's president by promising to ''stop the decline of the (Serb) state and nation.''

He made the pledge here in the Yugoslav capital late last week during a brief party convention that introduced the DOS's platform and candidates for parliamentary and presidential elections set for Sept. 24.

''This is a new beginning for us, '' university professor Marija Bogdanovic said afterward. ''I cried listening to his speech.'' 

The opposition has reason to be hopeful. Kostunica, a popular figure in Serb politics, is leading the largest anti-Milosevic movement to be assembled in Serbia in years. With Yugoslavia on the verge of war and economic collapse, Milosevic's days in power should be numbered.

But Yugoslavia is split between those who think the election will usher in a new leader and a new beginning and those who argue the vote can only strengthen Milosevic, who has artfully and brutally fended off every challenge to his leadership since coming to power a dozen years ago.

Despite Milosevic's iron rule, many of his opponents say they now have a winning formula and candidate. In his keynote convention speech, Kostunica, a straight-taking law professor, reached out to voters with a 10-point platform for getting Serbia back on track. The DOS, echoing U.S. Republican Party rhetoric from the 1990s, calls the platform its ''Contract with Serbia.''

The platform points include promises for ''honest'' government, economic development, renewed ties with the West (and an end to trade sanctions), anti- crime initiatives, a peaceful resolution of the crisis in Montenegro, and ''fair wages for honest work.''

Kostunica's more dynamic promises include bringing stability to Kosovo, assurances DOS's candidates will not try to profit from elected office, and not to seek vengeance against political opponents should the DOS win.

Revenge is a sensitive issue, especially among pro-government bureaucrats fearful a change in regime will lead to their ouster and persecution.

''I give my word there will not be revenge against people who do not support us,'' Kostunica declared before thousands of delegates. ''No one should fear.''

With the slogan ''We will win, everyone will benefit,'' Kostunica and the DOS appear to be offering change at the expense of no one but Milosevic and his legacy.

''During the last 10 years, they (the Milosevic regime) have created another artificial face of Serbia, and unfortunately the world believes this image,'' Kostunica said. ''We will present the true face of Serbia.''

Cheering conventioneers appeared to be impressed by Kostunica's words and style. Clearly, Kostunica, an obscure opposition figure until his recent ascendency to the top spot of the DOS, walks and talks differently than Serb politicians of the past and present.

The DOS leader has a reputation for being a nationalist and a conservative. In fact, Kostunica owes his current stature to editors at Milosevic-controlled state TV who liked and aired his criticisms of NATO and the UN over the Kosovo crisis.

won't appeal to serb hard-liners

But Kostunica has thus far refused to use reactionary rhetoric to appeal to Serb hard-liners in the way that other opposition leaders - such as Vuk Draskovic, the now diminished leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) who is in hiding in Montenegro after a recent assassination attempt, and Vojislav Seselj, the reactionary leader of the Serbian Radical Party (SRS) - have done in the past.

Rhetoric aside, Kostunica's strongest attributes appear to be a reputation for honesty and a squeaky-clean record.

Draskovic and Seselj have both cut deals with Milosevic for personal and political gain. Seselj's Radicals are a cornerstone of Milosevic's parliamentary coalition, and Draskovic abandoned his leadership of student protests three years ago to become a deputy prime minister in the Milosevic government.

Draskovic has refused to stand behind Kostunica in a united front against Milosevic as both the SPO and SRS run their own candidates for president.

But even with the concern that opposition votes will be divided on election day, Kostunica's supporters are optimistic. ''I think we'll be successful,'' declared DOS parliamentary candidate Jeljko Ciric. ''I wouldn't be involved otherwise.''

Opinion polls predict a DOS victory. According to an editor for the Belgrade newsmagazine NIN, Kostunica now enjoys about 35-per-cent support in Yugoslavia, compared with 24 per cent for Milosevic. Poll data released in July put Kostunica's approval rating at 42 per cent, and Milosevic's at 28 per cent.

NIN puts support for Draskovic's SPO in the single digits (8 per cent), but has no idea how much support the Radicals enjoy due to SRS leader Seselj's order that supporters not co-operate with pollsters.

Top officials in Yugoslavia's ruling coalition formally declared Milosevic's candidacy for re-election Sunday, submitting the results of a petition drive intended to show off his support and counter the polls showing the president trailing Kostunica.

1.6 million sign petition

The petition drive reportedly collected nearly 1.6 million signatures supporting the president even though only 25,000 are required for a candidate. ''This clearly shows people's support for Milosevic's policies of defending national sovereignty, resistance against aggressors, of reconstruction and development,'' said Gorica Gajevic, the secretary-general of Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS).

But Ciric predicts Kostunica will triumph on a second ballot, which will be required if there is no clear majority winner on the first ballot.

''Kostunica will win,'' Ciric said, ''if Milosevic doesn't create a crisis in Montenegro or Kosovo, or if he doesn't cheat.''

But there are signs Milosevic may try both ploys if faced with defeat. ''Now that Milosevic is indicted as a war criminal (by the UN), he cannot lose and retire,'' said Belgrade journalist Svetlana Djurdjevic. ''He has to win.''

According to analysts, the pro-Milosevic Yugoslav army is fueling tensions daily with Montenegro's republican police force and many Serbs and Montenegrins consider war to be inevitable.

The government has also forbidden international monitors from scrutinizing the vote, a clear indication that Milosevic is setting the stage for election fraud, critics say.

''If (Milosevic) thinks he's going to lose he could provoke something in Montenegro and persuade people that it wouldn't be convenient to change the chief at this moment,'' said Marko Blagojevic, a board member of the Centre for Free Elections and Democracy (CeSID), a domestic election-watch organization that wants to place monitors at every polling station in the country.

But a study of past victories reveals the Yugoslav president may have a system for cheating already ironed out. ''We looked at government records of the last election,'' he said, ''and found that in (the Kosovo village of) Junik there was 100-per- cent support for the SPS candidate.

''Junik is completely Albanian. No Serbs lived there. And Kosovar Albanians have boycotted every election for the past 10 years.

''So it's impossible to believe an Albanian village voted unanimously for a Serb leader and the SPS without a single vote for another candidate.''

This year, Montenegro is boycotting the election, and CeSID is concerned Milosevic may try to win by stuffing imaginary ballot boxes in Montenegro and, incredibly enough, in NATO-occupied Kosovo.

''This is the fear,'' Blagojevic admitted. The SPS has further stoked these fears by loudly announcing Milosevic will campaign in both Kosovo and Montenegro.

There is also the possibility Milosevic will win fair and square. Milosevic controls the media, and the hearts of many beleaguered Serbs who cannot conceive of another leader. ''Many people are afraid of change,'' said DOS supporter Bogdanovic. ''They think change will only be worse.''

And the past squabbles and betrayals of the Serb opposition have disillusioned scores of voters who may vote for Milosevic by default.

Even supporters with blind faith in Kostunica's ability to win do not believe victory will come easily.

''I don't think Milosevic will give power away without troubles,'' admitted Bogdanovic. ''But I think the people want change. And I think the people have the strength to make it.''


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
