The New York Times


August 28, 1999, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


An Anti-Milosevic Leader Tries for a Comeback


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 1573 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 27


Zoran Djindjic has been refining his plans, and there have been a lot of them, but he now seems ready to roll the dice to try to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

At 47, Mr. Djindjic, the urbane and telegenic leader of the Democratic Party, appears to think it is his last chance to rid the country of Mr. Milosevic and his Government. 

Huge street protests in the winter of 1996-97 petered out after 88 days with Mr. Milosevic in power, but Mr. Djindjic vows that this time he is prepared "to go to the end," though he can be vague about what that means exactly. In an interview, he said he would lead demonstrations, beginning with a Belgrade rally on Sept. 21, until Mr. Milosevic resigned.

Asked if that meant that his only options were victory, arrest or exile, Mr. Djindjic shrugged. Later, he said that "if Serbia enters the new century with Mr. Milosevic at its head," he will retire from politics.

Mr. Milosevic must be gone "by the end of October or early November," Mr. Djindjic said. But he recognizes that Mr. Milosevic may not be gone, and that his strategy may have to be revised.

"If ordinary people are not ready to take the risk, we will lose," he said. "But if they are not ready to be on the streets, I'll be ready and try to lead them there."

Known for his pragmatism and modern sensibility, Mr. Djindjic, with less to lose, now seems more radical than his rival within the opposition, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement. That has made him more attractive to Washington, which had long mistrusted the German-educated Mr. Djindjic as being "too European."

"We have different interests," he said of Mr. Draskovic in his much-improved English. "Draskovic doesn't want to change the system. He wants to maintain the privileges of the Government but to change its membership. I want to change the character of the Government itself."

While Mr. Draskovic has been plumping lately for early elections under freer conditions, possibly on Nov. 7, and Mr. Milosevic's aides have themselves been suggesting an early vote, Mr. Djindjic says free elections will not be possible while Mr. Milosevic is President.

Still, in the interview Mr. Djindjic said clearly for the first time that his party and the larger opposition coalition, the Alliance for Change, would have to take part in early elections, even with Mr. Milosevic in power -- that they could not credibly boycott the vote, as they did in 1997.

But he said they would try to organize the election as "a referendum on Milosevic," running slates of candidates that did not include party leaders but would be headed by respected non-politicians like Drago slav Avramovic, the former Central Bank head who brought down Yugoslavia's hyperinflation in 1994, and Momcilo Perisic, who was fired by Mr. Milosevic in November as army chief of staff.

After meeting with American officials, Mr. Djindjic said he had assurances that these men would agree to lead such a slate.

"We'd say O.K. to elections, but have two million in the streets to wait for the results as a kind of electoral control," he said. He would hope that street pressure and the imploding of the Government would cause Mr. Milosevic to step down, so that "truly free elections" could then take place with all party leaders running.

Mr. Djindjic said he hoped to step up street pressure slowly but surely, giving the Government no pretext for a crackdown. Under enough pressure, "I believe Milosevic and his wife will leave if they see they have lost," Mr. Djindjic said. "I don't believe they are brave enough to fight to the end."

Others, pointing to Mr. Milosevic's indictment on war crimes charges, say that the couple has little alternative but to try to preserve their positions, and that they would not trust promises of safety from cronies, let alone opposition figures.

Mr. Djindjic, trained as a philosopher, said the fate of the Milosevics was not his concern.

"Milosevic is not a criminal, but a logical consequence of a part of our history," he said. "Milosevic is a cause of our problems, but he is also, in an important sense, a consequence of them. But if Milosevic remains in power, and the effort to democratize fails, there will be a further period of state disintegration."

But few see many signs of serious cracks in the Government, and some analysts regard Mr. Djindjic's new radicalism in part as an effort to compensate for having fled Serbia during the war over Kosovo.

"Djindjic is simply trying to find his way back to political life," said Milan Milosevic, a respected political analyst who is not related to the President.

"I think the opposition has totally overestimated the possibility of revolution in Serbia because of the loss of Kosovo," Mr. Milosevic said. "Djindjic has no chance as a revolutionary, but all this has helped him to survive politically. And by choosing this more radical path, he has rallied his troops around him."

Mr. Djindjic portrays himself as contemporary, thoughtful and sophisticated. He sees Serbia's other major political figures -- President Milosevic, Mr. Draskovic and Voji slav Seselj, the Radical Party leader and coalition partner of Mr. Milosevic -- as "antimodern," with their concentration on primitive Communism, traditionalism and nationalism.

Insights like that have made him an attractive candidate to the urban educated voters in Serbia who want closer ties to Europe and the rest of the world, especially after the fiasco of the war with NATO.

Though his rally speeches are improved and popular, he is not a natural rabble-rouser like Mr. Draskovic. In a way he is trying to ride popular discontent as much as to lead it.

At the moment, Serbs may be angry, but they are not especially enamored of the opposition leaders. Asked in an opinion poll published on Thursday in Nin magazine which opposition leader "will lead us out of the crisis," 68 percent of Serbian respondents said "none," while another 20 percent were undecided.

Some 4 percent chose Mr. Draskovic, 2.5 percent chose Mr. Avramovic and 2 percent Mr. Perisic. Only 1.5 percent chose Mr. Djindjic.

Even if the unknown margin of error in the poll was large, the conclusions are fairly vivid.

Part of the problem is that "all opposition leaders are fascinated with the masses," said Mr. Milosevic the political analyst. Although they only pulled 10 percent of any city's population into summertime rallies, "they see 10,000 people in front of them and they imagine it's a million."

And they never do the kind of serious local political organizing that President Milosevic's party has always done, and in fact refined since it transformed itself from the Communist Party.

Ivan Radovanovic, an independent journalist, called Mr. Djindjic "a strange mixture of pragmatism and hysteria, and you never know which will prevail." Mr. Djindjic, he said, "seems wholly pragmatic, and then something tips him over and he's capable of overthrowing his plans. And Vuk Draskovic drives him crazy."

It was Mr. Djindjic who was most responsible for the breakup of the opposition coalition, called Zajedno, when he went back on his promise to back Mr. Draskovic in his 1997 presidential campaign and instead boycotted the elections, Mr. Radovanovic said. He noted that in 1993 Mr. Djindjic negotiated his own coalition deal with President Milosevic, pulling out only at the end, although four from his party joined the Cabinet.

After the 1996-97 protests, "Djindjic was spoken of as a Serbian Vaclav Havel and he thought he could run the opposition," Mr. Milosevic said. "But he had big problems with Draskovic, who saw himself as the king of the streets" and who, once betrayed, engineered Mr. Djindjic's ouster as Mayor of Belgrade.

Because of that and the 1997 election boycott, Mr. Djindjic "for two years has been out of the game and in crisis, and his party has been in crisis, too," Mr. Milosevic said.

He made matters worse by fleeing the country during NATO's bombing campaign, his life under threat. Government propaganda took full advantage and called him a coward, a traitor and a tool of NATO, charges that Mr. Draskovic's party echoes, though less crudely.

But as Mr. Djindjic, the Alliance for Change and Mr. Draskovic have explored one strategy after another, the summer has been wasted in disputes and a now-dead plan for a transitional government of experts that President Milosevic would never have accepted.

And the period after the capitulation in Kosovo -- when the Milosevic Government was rocked on its heels and seemed extremely shaky, with the army and police unsure -- was not exploited, even though the opposition probably could have united those angry with President Milosevic for prosecuting the war and those angry with him for losing it.

Now, with the Serbs nearly expelled from Kosovo under NATO eyes, it is easier for Mr. Milosevic to argue that the war was worth fighting, given the consequences.

"The opposition never seems to anticipate anything," Mr. Radovanovic said. "They only react to Milosevic and to events, and to the insults of each other."

Now President Milosevic's suggestion of early elections has further divided the opposition. But despite all the confusion and the skepticism, Mr. Djindjic is steeling himself.

"I believe that this is the last opportunity to get rid of Milosevic," he said. "It's not just the last chance for me, but for us as a country."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: August 28, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: The Yugoslav opposition figure Zoran Djindjic, right, mingled with farmers this week at a traditional music festival in Guca. Mr. Djindjic vows that he is prepared "to go to the end" to oust President Slobodan Milosevic. (Agence France-Presse)


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


151 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


November 30, 1996, Saturday, Final Edition


Yugoslav Workers Cool to Opposition; One Union Boss Offers Lukewarm Support to Anti-Milosevic Coalition


John Pomfret, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 819 words


DATELINE: KRAGUJEVAC, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29


 

Zoran Nedeljkovic is known as "the bear" around Kragujevac and the massive Red Flag weapons factory where he has toiled since high school. With a bulldog mug suggesting Harvey Keitel minus a few teeth and the gruff manner of Yugoslavia's working class, he plays and looks the part. Especially these days.

As the leader of one of the biggest branches of Yugoslavia's main trade union, Nedeljkovic is the only major union boss to back the most sustained protests ever against Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic's government. Nedeljkovic has broken with the state-led leadership of the Association of Autonomous Unions of Serbia, which has condemned the demonstrations, because he believes Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia should recognize opposition electoral victories in 15 of Yugoslavia's 18 cities and hand over power in those towns. 

But the 39-year-old union boss is no Lech Walesa. His support for the opposition, a coalition of five parties that call themselves Together, is as qualified as it is courageous. He opposes the idea of a general strike to oust Milosevic. He did not allow any officers of his union shop to contest seats in the local election against the Socialists. And, he says, he wants to keep the goals of his union -- "secure jobs, a good wage and an eight-hour working day" -- separate from politics.

Nedeljkovic's measured encouragement illustrates a significant problem facing Serbia's Together coalition as its protesters marked a 12th straight day of anti-government demonstrations in Belgrade, Nis, Kragujevac and other cities around the country: Any attempt to oust the Serbian president, or at least force him to recognize election results, needs the wholehearted assistance of Yugoslavia's working class. But so far the only support Together can obtain from Serbia's workers is the lukewarm endorsement of one major union chief, Nedeljkovic.

If the movement does not gain more support, opposition officials acknowledged, their challenge to Milosevic probably will fizzle.

"Students and white collar protesters cannot do it alone," said one opposition leader. "While damage will have been done to Milosevic, he will survive."

Kragujevac once was the apex of Serb industry. It is the headquarters of the Red Flag group of companies, which made the Yugo car, trucks and tens of thousands of AK-47 automatic rifles at its flagship factory and Nedeljkovic's employer: Red Flag Special Products.

Today, of the 11,000 workers employed at the Yugo factory, perhaps 15 percent are working. Their average salary is $ 20 a month. Things are only slightly better for the 2,500 workers at the truck plant. Red Flag Special Products, however, has done the best.

"The bear" is a cautious warrior. Like many in his union, he wants changes in Yugoslavia but does not know if Together is capable of delivering. "Our aim is to prove that the Socialists can be beaten," he said. "I really hope that I'm on the right side."

Nedeljkovic became union chief in this town 140 miles south of Belgrade in 1994 in an election that the Socialists attempted unsuccessfully to rig, he said. Both his father and grandfather had worked at the weapons plant. Those roots, he said, helped him win.

On Aug. 19, Nedeljkovic led his workers on strike in one of the most significant labor actions in Yugoslavia in years. They had not been paid for several months. Nedeljkovic broke with union leaders in Belgrade and had his men walk out.

The strike lasted two months. An envoy of Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, came to see Nedeljkovic, who said he was offered a vice presidency in Markovic's Yugoslav United Left organization -- a successor of the former ruling communist party that is now allied with her husband's Socialist Party. The tactic is a normal one for the Milosevics, who have sought to co-opt troublemakers by buying them off.

"But we're on opposite sides," Nedeljkovic said. "I told them to get lost."

In the end, Red Flag's workers won back pay and benefits, appointment of union representatives to Red Flag's executive board and a new factory manager, approved by the union. They went back to work Oct. 19.

Discontent with the Socialist Party is high in Kragujevac. The town's mayor, Zivorad Nesic, recently has been implicated in a scam to build a private shopping mall with government money. A local independent newspaper also alleged that Nesic used money from an urban redevelopment fund to bankroll his campaign.

In local elections Nov. 17, Together crushed Milosevic's Socialists, but the local election commission, also controlled by Milosevic, did not recognize the results and ordered a new election, held Wednesday.

Unlike in Belgrade and the southern Serbian city of Nis, the opposition participated in Wednesday's vote. Opposition officials said today that the results were the same. Together took 61 percent of the city council's seats.


LOAD-DATE: December 01, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1996 The Washington Post


152 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


March 13, 2003, Thursday


Zoran Djindjic


SECTION: Features; 34


LENGTH: 1253 words


 

Zoran Djindjic, Prime Minister of the Republic of Serbia since January 2001, was born on August 1, 1952. He was assassinated in Belgrade on March 12, 2003, aged 50.

Dissident voice in Tito's Yugoslavia who emerged as the pragmatic leader of a new Serbian state

Prime Minister of Serbia since January 2001, Zoran Djindjic had made his name in the West as "the West's man" in post- Milosevic Yugoslavia. In many ways he resembled such contemporaries as Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and Gerhard Schroder, in that he seemed to be above all else a pragmatist who had no great visions but was prepared, like Bismarck, to float and steer upon the river of time.

But it was not always so, and his political outlook evolved with the great changes that affected his country. To his supporters this was sensible and productive realism, to his opponents it was opportunism. 

Zoran Djindjic was born in the Bosnian village of Bosanski Samac in 1952, the son of a Yugoslav army officer. He showed early political awareness when he tried to collect signatures protesting against a new law that made Marshal Tito President of Yugoslavia for life. Although punished for this indiscretion he went on to complete a philosophy degree at Belgrade University, only to run foul of the authorities once again when, in 1974, together with like-minded students from Croatia and Slovenia, he attempted to found a non-communist student movement. For this he and his would-be colleagues were sentenced to one year's imprisonment.

On his release Djindjic left for West Germany to read for a doctorate. He studied under Jurgen Habermas at the University of Frankfurt when that institution was still associated with the student protest movement. It was said that Djindjic became interested in extreme organisations such as the Baader-Meinhof Gang and the Red Army Faction.

Djindjic received his doctorate from the University of Konstanz in 1979. His thesis was entitled Marx's critical social theory and problems of justification.

In it he developed an epistemological basis for Marx's theory that a crisis is necessary in society for the old order to be swept away and a new one created.

Djindjic wrote a few years later that he had gone to Frankfurt because he believed that was the only place where he would find the new intellectual nourishment which would enable Marxism to adapt to and thrive in the new realities of Yugoslavia, realities that Djindjic seemed to think were already too liberal and too bourgeois. Yet, even when he was a student in Germany, Djindjic had been involved with the class enemy, selling textile machines and making clothes.

Back in Yugoslavia, Djindjic abandoned commerce to teach philosophy in the universities of Novi Sad and Belgrade. But within a few years he was fully engaged in politics. In 1979 he was one of the youngest participants in a summer school on the island of Korcula run by the Praxis group of critical, Marxist intellectuals.

As the final vestiges of the communist monopoly of power disappeared, Djindjic became one of the founders of the Democratic Party, and two years later, in 1990, he became its chairman and in 1994 its president. He was elected to the Serbian parliament in 1990.

Djindjic then moved his supposedly centrist party closer to Serbian nationalism.

In 1994, when the Bosnian Serbs were ordered by the Western powers to end the bombardment of Sarajevo, Djindjic showed, as he said, "solidarity with the Bosnian Serbs" by going to the Bosnian Serb capital, Pale, and partaking of a roasted ox with Radovan Karadjic. Djindjic also had occasional meetings with the notorious Arkan, Zeljko Raznatovic, who led one of the groups of irregulars fighting in Bosnia.

Yet when Serbian nationalism was defeated and the Dayton accord signed in 1995 Djindjic sought a new tack, one which brought him into direct opposition to President Milosevic. He played a major role in bring about Zajedno (Together), an alliance of three anti-Milosevic parties. At the end of 1996 the alliance secured notable victories in local elections in a number of key Serbian cities, including Belgrade.

Though Milosevic initially tried to discount the elections, his hand was forced by massive public protests and by Western pressure, and in February 1997 Djindjic became the first non-communist Mayor of Belgrade since 1945. The Zajedno alliance did not last long. By the summer its constituent parties were squabbling, and in September Djindjic was forced from his mayoral office after having been accused of "incompetence" by his erstwhile ally, Vuk Draskovic.

Djindjic now performed another about-face and abandoned the more vociferous nationalists. In December 1996 he had told the German magazine Der Spiegel that he was "the horse which the West should back", and after his removal from Belgrade town hall he concentrated on gathering round him a group of experts who could help to reconstruct a Serbian economy battered by years of war and sanctions.

Only in the West, he argued, could the requisite expertise and capital be found.

This did not mean that he condoned Nato action against Serbia in 1999, but once that had ended he pushed hard for Serbia's re-integration into the Western world.

He therefore became an even more determined opponent of Milosevic and played a significant role in his removal, by liaising with vital state institutions and military leaders in October 2000.

At the end of that year Djindjic was at the head of a new coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, which secured an easy victory in the Serbian parliamentary elections in December. Djindjic assumed office as Prime Minister of Serbia in January 2001.

As prime minister Djindjic continued his pro-Western line but it was one which brought him into frequent conflict with the then President of Yugoslavia, Vojislav Kostunica. Their differences were never greater than over the question of whether Milosevic should be extradited to face the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague, and it was Djindjic who sanctioned Milosevic's extradition in June 2001.

The following day an international donors' conference in Brussels offered Yugoslavia $ 1.28 billion in grants and loans.

Djindjic was universally recognised as a powerful intellect and an organiser of prodigious talents. But as with many politicians of his generation there was always doubt as to what, if any, were his core beliefs, and he never enjoyed the popular support accorded to his fellow- intellectual and opponent, Kostunica.

In the Serbian presidential elections of 2002 Djindjic chose to back Miroslav Labus rather than run himself. Nevertheless, to many Serbs Djindjic remained what one British newspaper had called him after the fall of Milosevic: "the shadow kingmaker".

Only last month Djindjic survived what may have been another attempt on his life, when a truck suddenly swerved out of its lane towards a convoy of cars, one of which was carrying him. At the time observers believed the near-miss might have been linked to his Government's attempts to stamp out organised crime.

In February, too, Serbia formally joined a loose federation with Montenegro.

Djindjic had also announced recently that Serbia would support a breakaway Serbian mini-state in Kosovo if the West prevented Serbian troops from returning there to guarantee the rights of the ethnic minority.

Djindjic is survived by his wife Ruzica, a lawyer, and by a son and a daughter.


LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2003 Times Newspapers Limited


153 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 8, 1999, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Clashes feared at protests today


BYLINE: Jack Kelley


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2A


LENGTH: 417 words


DATELINE: LESKOVAC, Yugoslavia


LESKOVAC, Yugoslavia -- Thousands of angry Serbs, including many
soldiers who fought in Kosovo, demonstrated here for a third straight
night Wednesday to demand that Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic
resign immediately or risk being ousted by angry mobs.

"We are ready to go to the end, to civil war and even bloodshed,
to get changes," said Nesic Dobrosav, director of the Committee
for Human Rights.

"We're expecting the worst. Neither side is going to give in
without a fight."
 

Tens of thousands were expected to demonstrate today in the southern
Serbian town of Prokuplje, near Kosovo's provincial border.

In Washington, State Department spokesman James Foley said, "Milosevic's
days are numbered. (But) it's impossible to predict how many numbers
there are in those days."

In a sign that the pro-Milosevic forces intend to fight back,
the president's ruling Socialist Party called its own rally at
the same place and time in Prokuplje, raising the prospect of
clashes.

At the same time, a top opposition leader urged Serb citizens
to hold daily protests in their cities and towns until Milosevic
steps down.

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the Democratic Party, said Serbia's
opposition groups soon might call for a nationwide strike to show
their dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav leader.

"Every day we must be in the streets until (Milosevic) resigns,"
Djindjic said. "The whole of Serbia should be in a state of civil
disobedience."

Zoran Zivkovic, the mayor of Nis, Serbia's third-largest city,
said anti-Milosevic momentum is "sweeping Serbia" and cannot
be stopped.

"This is a people's movement and they're angry," he said.

Nowhere have the protests been as strong as in Leskovac, a city
of 170,000 about 150 miles south of Belgrade. The demonstrations
were sparked this week after a television engineer, Ivan Novkovic,
went on the air to demand the dismissal of local officials from
Milosevic's party. In answer to his call, 20,000 people demonstrated
Monday in a town that had been considered a Milosevic stronghold.

Novkovic was jailed for calling the protest. On Tuesday, 1,500
people clashed with anti-riot police to demand his release. Demonstrators
rushed to a house belonging to a local Milosevic ally, smashing
its windows and breaking down a fence.

"If I could, I'd skin Milosevic alive, slowly," said Zivko Lalic,
a Serbian refugee from Kosovo now living here. "There's no going
back. We want him out."


LOAD-DATE: July 08, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, B/W, USA TODAY (Map)


Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


154 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


August 20, 1999, Friday


Besieged Milosevic offers election


SOURCE: * AP, AFP, Reuters


BYLINE: * Correspondents in Belgrade  and Nis


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 7


LENGTH: 388 words


SERBIAN President Slobodan Milosevic is reported to have offered to hold early elections in the face of resounding calls demanding he step down.

Mr Milosevic's offer on Wednesday appeared to be a last-minute concession to try to defuse Yugoslavia's political crisis and deflate an anti-Government rally planned for yesterday in Belgrade.

The Serbian parliament, dominated by Mr Milosevic's regime, is expected to decide on an election date next month, according to sources close to his Socialist Party and the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic, independent news agency Beta reported. 

However, opposition leaders say they would only agree to Mr Milosevic's offer to hold early elections if the vote is monitored by international observers. Elections are technically scheduled for 2001.

"We believe that there are more important things on the nation's agenda than the elections but, if the opposition wants that, so be it," said Ivica Dacic, a spokesman for the Socialist Party.

On Wednesday, 20,000 people rallied in the country's third-largest city of Nis, chanting "resignations, resignations," Beta said.

The rally came on the eve of a protest in the Yugoslav capital, Belgrade, the first since the start of the anti-Milosevic campaign in late June.

"It is Belgrade's turn to show whether it is for change," the mayor of Nis, Zoran Zivkovic of the Democratic Party, told protesters.

Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party, said he expected 200,000 people at the rally in Belgrade.

Opposition activists acknowledge that it will not be easy to persuade Mr Milosevic to step aside, especially since rows between political leaders have caused widespread disillusion among ordinary Serbs.

US officials yesterday urged the opposition to work tog-

ether to speed Mr Milosevic's ouster.

"The more unified they act, the quicker the chances are that Milosevic will leave the scene, and the quicker therefore that the people of Yugoslavia and Serbia will be able to live the life they deserve to," State Department spokesman James Rubin said.

Most opposition leaders say the President's resignation is a precondition for any reform. They say Mr Milosevic, who has been indicted by a UN court for war crimes in Kosovo, is too isolated to lead Yugoslavia out of its unprecedented crisis.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


155 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 5, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


Challenging Mr. Milosevic


SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 


LENGTH: 577 words


Slobodan Milosevic is running for another term as Yugoslavia's president in an unfair election that he will most likely win by any means necessary. Nevertheless, the opposition should run against him. No one believes that Mr. Milosevic will leave office simply because voters tell him to. But if the opposition can unite on a single presidential candidate for the elections, in late September, it can at least revitalize its popular support and shake some of the apathy that is paralyzing Serbia.

The opposition will certainly run candidates in local elections. Anti-Milosevic candidates won in more than 30 municipalities in 1996, although protesters had to occupy the streets for months in order to get Mr. Milosevic to recognize the victories. These local officials give the opposition control of some funds and broadcast media, in addition to political stature and a base for organizing. The posts are crucial to keep. The opposition should also run candidates in the federal Parliament to reduce Mr. Milosevic's near-total control. 

Mr. Milosevic has taken no chances with his own re-election. Recently he has shut down many of the remaining independent media in Serbia, and has been intimidating opposition politicians and independent activists through violence and abuse of the courts. His ubiquitous propaganda allows him to remain the most popular politician in Serbia. But he is helped by a petty and ineffectual opposition. Polls, however, show that if the opposition united around a single candidate, that person could win. Even if there is little chance the winner would be allowed to take office, this would energize the opposition.

This weekend there is a convention of the Serbian Renewal Movement, whose leader, Vuk Draskovic, is the main obstacle to a united opposition. Mr. Draskovic has in the past cut deals with Mr. Milosevic and sabotaged opposition unity, acts that should disqualify him as a candidate this time.

Mr. Draskovic has said that his party will not participate in the elections if Milo Djukanovic, the president of Serbia's tiny sister republic of Montenegro, stays out as well. But Mr. Djukanovic, who has led his republic in a mutiny against the Yugoslav president, has a better reason for boycotting. He is already under the constant threat of attack from the Yugoslav army stationed in Montenegro -- an attack that Washington fears may come soon. The presidential election will be staged with new rules that are part of a recent constitutional coup by Mr. Milosevic, which greatly reduced Montenegro's influence in the presidential election and over all.

If the opposition does contest the election and Mr. Milosevic wins, countries such as Russia, Greece and Italy should not use his "victory" as a pretext to improve their relations with Serbia. They well know he keeps power through repression. Nor should Mr. Milosevic look forward to a change in American policy if Gov. George W. Bush becomes president. The Republican platform says there should be no negotiations with indicted war criminals such as Mr. Milosevic, and that Washington should seek their arrest, trial and imprisonment.

Contesting Mr. Milosevic for the presidency requires opposition unity. Democratic opposition parties were able to beat Vladimir Meciar in Slovakia and Franjo Tudjman's party in Croatia only when they overcame their internal squabbles. Mr. Milosevic is more malignant, but that only makes unity even more necessary.  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Editorial


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


156 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Straits Times (Singapore)


Mere military action inadequate


May 15, 1999


Louise Branson in Washington


THE Clinton administration is deeply divided over Kosovo -albeit behind the scenes. Nato bombing has not forced President Slobodan Milosevic to cave in as expected. US officials are desperate to find a way out.

On Thursday, there were signs of movement. President Bill Clinton, after days of near-silence, delivered an impassioned speech about the importance of prevailing in Kosovo. He evoked gruesome examples of the atrocities allegedly being carried out by Serb forces. The clear hint was that he was preparing American opinion for a possible ground intervention. 

That would be a major, and welcome, development -an admission that bombing alone is a failure.

But it would not be enough. Nato -led by the Americans who are needed for any solution -- should have the imagination, the guts and the determination to go further. It is quite clear to anyone who has even casually studied the Balkans these past few years that there is one root cause of instability in the region. His name is Slobodan Milosevic.

This evil dictator deliberately stirred nationalism to bring himself to power in 1987. Since then, he has gathered all reins of power in his own hands.

Even his top aides are rarely briefed on his negotiations. Over the years, he has become steadily more repressive. On the many occasions his people have come out in demonstrations against him, he has turned his police on them or stirred more war and trouble to distract attention.

The Nato bombing has only strengthened his grip on power. Even anti-Milosevic liberals are out in the streets protesting the bombing. "I am against Milosevic, but I am not against my country," said one, summing up the sentiment.

For the broad Serb public, long fed nationalistic propaganda, the bombing has confirmed a historical sense of victimisation -first at the hands of the Turks, then the Nazis, now Nato. It has also facilitated a national denial: as victims, they do not have to take responsibility or even own up to the Kosovo horrors.

The Serb dictator, meanwhile, has taken advantage of the Kosovo distraction to increase his tyrannical hold at home. He has fired dozens of Belgrade university professors who refused to sign a pledge of allegiance to his government, for example. And he has shut down or taken over the last few non-government media outlets.

While support for Mr Milosevic in Serbia is a mile wide, however, it is an inch thick. It could easily crumble if Serbs were given a way out, shown a path to the Europe they had keenly wanted to join in the late 1980s and early 1990s when they saw themselves as part of a democratic wave sweeping across Eastern and Central Europe.

The first step to achieve this would be to get rid of Mr Milosevic. Nato should do that by declaring him a war criminal. To suggest that it does not have enough evidence to send him to the Hague is nonsense.

The real reason the US in particular is holding back is it thinks it needs him to be a "guarantor" of peace. But that is a cave-in: setting the stage for him to stir more trouble in, say, his multi-ethnic northern province of Vojvodina or among his Muslims in the Sandzak region as soon as he again needs to distract his people's attention to keep his grip on them.

Nato needs to go further than a Hague indictment, though. Serbs are in no psychological state after 12 years of Mr Milosevic to pick up the physical or psychological pieces on their own. What they need is a Marshall Plan and an allied takeover of the kind that occurred in Germany and Japan after World War II.

A high-publicity Nuremberg-style trial of Mr Milosevic and his chief lieutenants would help Serbs face and come to terms with the terrible things that have been committed by some of them and in their name. The institutions needed to build democracy from the ground up could also be installed.

Harvard historian Daniel Goldhagen, who wrote "Hitler's Willing Executioners: Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust", has already launched that idea, publishing a manifesto in which he said that Serbia should "be placed in receivership".

Others have taken up the theme. Mr Thomas Schwartz, another American historian, commented that "when Germany was totally defeated, it provided opportunity. You could be physically there, controlling the flow of information and using war-crime trials to show the Germans that atrocities were done in their name". Without something similar in Serbia, he said, "we can look forward to more trouble in Serbia".

"What reminds me of Germany is the comparison to the end of World War I," he added. "Then, the Germans had this powerful sense of being victims. There was a deep resentment that Hitler was able to exploit. It will be the same in Serbia when Nato bombing stops."

Particularly if the eventual settlement in Kosovo is an unsatisfactory peace deal that leaves Mr Milosevic in power -after, perhaps, caving in to Nato following a ground intervention in Kosovo. (The writer, a Straits Times correspondent based in Washington, reported on Yugoslavian issues and development from Belgrade from 1990-1996.)


SECTION: Commentary Analysis; Pg. 62


LENGTH: 852 words


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Straits Times Press Limited


157 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Straits Times (Singapore)


Mere military action inadequate


May 15, 1999


Louise Branson in Washington


THE Clinton administration is deeply divided over Kosovo -albeit behind the scenes. Nato bombing has not forced President Slobodan Milosevic to cave in as expected. US officials are desperate to find a way out.

On Thursday, there were signs of movement. President Bill Clinton, after days of near-silence, delivered an impassioned speech about the importance of prevailing in Kosovo. He evoked gruesome examples of the atrocities allegedly being carried out by Serb forces. The clear hint was that he was preparing American opinion for a possible ground intervention. 

That would be a major, and welcome, development -an admission that bombing alone is a failure.

But it would not be enough. Nato -led by the Americans who are needed for any solution -- should have the imagination, the guts and the determination to go further. It is quite clear to anyone who has even casually studied the Balkans these past few years that there is one root cause of instability in the region. His name is Slobodan Milosevic.

And he has shut down or taken over the last few non-government media outlets.

(The writer, a Straits Times correspondent based in Washington, reported on Yugoslavian issues and development from Belgrade from 1990-1996.)


SECTION: Commentary Analysis; Pg. 62

LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1999

Copyright 1999 The Straits Times Press Limited


158 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


August 10, 1999, FINAL


Orthodox Church to join mass anti-Milosevic rally


SECTION: News; A6


LENGTH: 299 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


BELGRADE -- The head of Serbia's influential Orthodox Church and the country's main opposition leaders agreed on Monday to join a mass anti- government rally in Belgrade on Aug. 19.

''I'm very optimistic,'' Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democratic Party said when asked if Serbia's often-divided opposition could finally join forces to oust Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. He said the rally would be the first joint step.

The synod of the Orthodox Church, which in the past has tended to stay out of politics, called at a meeting in June for Milosevic to quit.

Djindjic spoke to reporters after a two-hour meeting that opposition leaders and a group of independent economists had with Patriarch Pavle and other Church dignitaries.

In the first reaction to the meeting, the Yugoslav state news agency Tanjug, which often reflects the government position, accused the Serb opposition of pressing the Church to take up an unconstitutional role.

The ultra- nationalist Radical Party, a long-time Milosevic ally, accused ''certain minor political groupings'' of trying to provoke a break within the Serbian Orthodox Church, Tanjug reported.

The Party said the Church had never been nor should be anyone's party outlet and it expected the Church to remain outside the political struggle.

Church leaders earlier met former Yugoslav army chief General Momcilo Perisic, sacked by Milosevic last November after he questioned the president's Kosovo policy.

Perisic was reported by opposition sources to have founded a new opposition movement on Sunday to add to the growing pressure on Milosevic.

''The Church is the only institution in Serbia with credibility now, and it has pledged to take an active role in the forthcoming political process,'' Djindjic said.


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Photo: Patriarch Pavle

CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved


159 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


March 13, 2003 Thursday Final Edition


Slain leader stood for reform: Helped oust dictator. As prime minister, Djindjic worked to bring Serbia into the European mainstream


SOURCE: AP


BYLINE: KATARINA KRATOVAC


SECTION: News; Pg. A4


LENGTH: 583 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


In Serbia's darkest hours, Zoran Djindjic stood up to the Balkans' worst dictator and single-handedly engineered Slobodan Milosevic's extradition to the United Nations war crimes tribunal.

Once the autocratic ruler was toppled, Serbia's prime minister spearheaded democratic reforms meant to pull the republic - long ostracized by the world - back into Europe's mainstream.

Two bullets fired yesterday ended the life and aspirations of Djindjic, the man who personified Serbia's hopes for a better future. 

Supporters pronounced Djindjic their country's "own Kennedy," after the admired and assassinated U.S. president.

Born Aug. 1, 1952, to the family of a Yugoslav army officer in Bosanski Samac in neighbouring Bosnia - then part of the former Yugoslavia's six-state communist federation - Djindjic was raised and educated in Belgrade. He studied in the philosophy department of the capital's university, then a hotbed of liberal opposition to Tito's communist government.

In 1977, he left to earn a doctorate in philosophy at Heidelberg, Germany. His academic career continued abroad, mostly at German universities.

A passionate anti-communist, Djindjic joined the Democratic party in its founding days and took over its helm in 1994. Milosevic's autocratic rule had already plunged the country into a series of ethnic wars that wreaked Europe's worst carnage since the Second World War.

In 1997, with the Zajedno (Together) coalition, Djindjic led three months of anti-Milosevic protests that daily challenged the dictator's police on Belgrade streets and caught the attention of freedom-fighters the world over.

In 1999, Djindjic succeeded in uniting Serbia's fledgling pro-democracy movement and propelled the rise of Vojislav Kostunica in a popular uprising that swept Milosevic from power in October 2000. After Kostunica succeeded Milosevic as Yugoslavia's president, Djindjic emerged as the second-most-powerful man in the country.

Djindjic's pro-Western government worked hard to bring the country into Europe's mainstream. For many Serbs, joining the European Union - and the promise of Western investment, open borders and free trade - was seen as the only way out of their misery of 60-per-cent joblessness and staggering inflation.

But once in the prime minister's office, Djindjic accused Kostunica of nationalist rhetoric, pessimism and lack of determination to carry out changes after Milosevic's ouster.

Kostunica countered by saying Djindjic sought to turn Serbia into a "Colombia-style" mafia state, and he criticized the prime minister's suave public image, entourage of bodyguards and upscale lifestyle.

Djindjic was aware his pro-western stance led to shaky popularity in Serbia, where strong nationalism still prevails and where many believe the West is anti-Serb. But he calmly pledged to continue on his reform path, and he declared an open war on the rampant organized crime that had engulfed the region.

Kostunica and Djindjic finally split, with Djindjic outmanoeuvring Kostunica when what remained of Yugoslavia was transformed last month into a new, loose union renamed Serbia and Montenegro.

Djindjic's term was due to expire in 2004. It was not immediately clear who might succeed him.

Despite their bitter animosity, Kostunica yesterday deplored Djindjic's assassination, saying that while they disagreed on many issues, the shots that took Djindjic's life were "proof that terrorism must be condemned and fought relentlessly, everywhere."


LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: PETAR KUJUNDZIC, REUTERS; In this September 1999 photo, Zoran Djindjic sits in front of a police cordon during a protest march against Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade. Djindjic played a key role in ousting Milosevic.


TYPE: Crime


Copyright 2003 CanWest Interactive, a division of
CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved


160 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


March 9, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION


50,000 in Serbia denounce Milosevic


BYLINE: AP


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A3


LENGTH: 316 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


 
   BELGRADE (AP) - Tens of thousands of people massed in Serbia's capital today to denounce President Slobodan Milosevic for the long war over Croatia's secession from Yugoslavia and the crumbling economy.

Chanting "Slobo, Hitler" and "Slobo, Saddam," they defied a government warning the rally could bring a repeat of violence that erupted a year ago today when police and army tanks moved against 200,000 anti-Milosevic protesters. Two people died, scores were hurt and hundreds arrested during four days of unrest.

Today's demonstration ended after three hours with no incidents reported. Reporters estimated about 50,000 people gathered on St. Sava's plateau for the rally.

Milosevic's renamed Communists won multiparty elections in Serbia two years ago and still enjoy sizeable support.

But opposition has been growing over the civil war's human toll as well as runaway inflation and a 20 per cent unemployment rate. Other Serbs are angry over the U.N.-sponsored truce in Croatia, accusing Milosevic of abandoning ethnic Serbs in that republic.

"Hunger is knocking on the door of Serbia," Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement and Milosevic's chief rival, told the rally. "Our Serbia must become . . . a state of the future not of the past, a construction site, not a barracks."

The 15 opposition parties that called the demonstration called for new elections, a new constitution, freedom of the press and fundamental economic changes.

Belgrade television says 579,000 people have signed a petition demanding Milosevic's resignation.

Camouflage-clad riot police patrolled downtown, but few officers were visible near the demonstration. Three jeeps manned by police wearing flak jackets guarded Milosevic's house several kilometres from the rally.

Although the Belgrade rally was much smaller than last year, organizers said they were satisfied.


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Reuter photo: Holding up flowers and making the Serbian three-finger sign, thousands of people gather in Belgrade today to call for the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic.Yugoslavia; demonstration


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


161 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


October 6, 2000, Friday, FINAL C


The unlikely leader of a stunning uprising: With an almost Gandhi-esque appeal for peaceful resistance, opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history.


BYLINE: Eve Ann Prentice


SECTION: News; A9


LENGTH: 1047 words


Vojislav Kostunica cuts an unlikely figure as hero and prospective saviour of Yugoslavia. While despairing Serbs and Western leaders looked the other way in search of a Balkan braveheart to rise up and cut the chains that have kept Slobodan Milosevic in power for the past decade, the quietly spoken rival for the presidency slipped under the ropes and felled him at the ballot box.

On Thursday, hundreds of thousands of people swarmed through the capital to demand Milosevic accept his apparent electoral defeat by Kostunica in the Sept. 24 election. The uprising developed with stunning speed, swelling as security forces showed little willingness to battle the largest anti-Milosevic protest ever. 

Soon after the end of the NATO bombing campaign last year, many war and sanctions-weary Serbs looked high and low for someone to lead them against the regime. The political options were bleak: the maverick fence-sitter Vuk Draskovic and his Serbian Renewal Movement on one hand, and the Democratic party leader Zoran Djindjic on the other. Djindjic's error was to leave Belgrade at the height of the bombing; it was seen as an act of cowardice by ordinary Serbs who had no choice but to stay put.

To make matters worse, Djindjic and Draskovic proved repeatedly that they could not put personal differences aside and present a united opposition.

A series of opposition rallies around Serbia in the weeks that followed the Alliance campaign were little more than Sunday outings for the curious and a chance for the two opposition groups to squabble. The only exceptions came when protests were organized by two independent rebels: Ivan Novkovic, a renegade television weatherman in the southern town of Leskovac, and Bogoljub ''Maki'' Arsenijevic, an artist from the central town of Valjevo. However, while these two would-be revolutionaries galvanized people in their home towns, they were never serious contenders for the post of president.

During this time, Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history. It came when Milosevic decided to call early elections and Kostunica was chosen to head a multi-party democratic opposition. Whereas the West had been less than accurate in reading the Balkan mentality, Kostunica had read the runes well.

He knew that many Serbs had become wary of firebrand politics and paramilitary adventurism. His message has been an almost Gandhi-esque appeal to peaceful resistance.

So who is the man who now seems to have achieved what would have looked impossible even three months ago -- levering Milosevic from power? And will he meet the West's expectations?

Vojislav Kostunica, a married man with no children, was nominated as the candidate of 18 parties and one trade union that form the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS). Born to an old Belgrade family in 1944, he graduated from the Belgrade School of Law in 1966 and went on to obtain a master's degree in 1970 and doctorate in 1974.

In 1970 he was appointed assistant lecturer at the Belgrade School of Law, but was expelled in 1974 during a political purge of Belgrade University, because of his opposition to communism.

From 1974 until 1981, he worked at the Institute of Social Sciences. He moved on to become director of the Institute for Philosophy and Social Theory. Until recently, his main claim to fame was as a bookish academic and author of papers on constitutional law, political theory and political philosophy. Kostunica has also worked as editor-in-chief of several specialized journals dedicated to law and philosophy, such as the Archive for Legal and Social Sciences, Philosophical Studies, Philosophy and Society and Theoria.

During the '80s, while Milosevic was climbing the greasy pole to supreme power, Kostunica turned his legal skills to human rights and was especially active in the board for the freedom of thought and speech, where he was highly regarded. It was around this time that he became involved in politics, becoming a founder of the Democratic party in 1989. He has been president of the separate Democratic party of Serbia since it was founded in 1992 and was a member of the Serbian parliament from 1990 until 1997, when his party boycotted the elections due to the ''lack of regular electoral conditions.''

Western leaders, however, have been nonplussed. Although senior European Union, American and even Russian politicians have been swift to call on Milosevic to hand power to Kostunica, the lawyer has not always been flavour of the month, especially in Washington.

Kostunica has consistently proclaimed that he would not hand Milosevic over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and he was a vigorous critic of the NATO bombardment. This has been seized on by some as proof that he is no different from other war-zealous Balkan leaders.

Kostunica has been described in some U.S. state department background briefings as an old- fashioned Serb nationalist, a sort of ''Seselj in coat-tails'' -- a reference to Milosevic's erstwhile ally, Vojislav Seselj, the ultra-nationalist leader of the Serbian Radical party.

This is where East and West divide. Opponents of the Milosevic regime see nothing wrong in criticizing the NATO campaign, for the bombing affected nearly everyone. While they may be anti-Milosevic, they believe their political destiny should be decided from within.

''Kostunica is a good patriot. He is educated, a peaceful man and no threat to anyone,'' says Srdjan Stojanovic, an independent Serbian journalist who lives in London. ''He is a calm, even boring speaker, but he insists on following legal procedures. That is what our country needs.''

Nikola Barovic, a noted Serbian human rights lawyer, agrees. ''He is a very good lawyer and has a high regard for fair play. Because he is very strict and correct, I think he will do all he can to help keep things peaceful,'' he says.

And an expatriate Serb points out: ''He is a politician of impeccable democratic credentials, keen intelligence and high personal integrity. He has not compromised himself either by making deals with Milosevic, unlike Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, or by being too subservient to the West like, say, Zoran Djindjic. His consistency and perseverance has finally paid off.''


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: CP Color Photo: Darko Vojinovic, Associated Press / CLAIMING VICTORY: Dr. Vojislav Kostunica, who is claiming he is the new president of Yugoslavia, speaks to about 400,000 opposition supporters from the balcony of city hall Thursday in Belgrade.; Color Photo: (Slobodan) Milosevic

162 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


October 6, 2000, Friday, FINAL


An unlikely hero for democracy: With an almost Gandhi-esque appeal for peaceful resistance, opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history.


BYLINE: Eve Ann Prentice


SECTION: News; A9


LENGTH: 1047 words


Vojislav Kostunica cuts an unlikely figure as hero and prospective saviour of Yugoslavia. While despairing Serbs and Western leaders looked the other way in search of a Balkan braveheart to rise up and cut the chains that have kept Slobodan Milosevic in power for the past decade, the quietly spoken rival for the presidency slipped under the ropes and felled him at the ballot box.

On Thursday, hundreds of thousands of people swarmed through the capital to demand Milosevic accept his apparent electoral defeat by Kostunica in the Sept. 24 election. The uprising developed with stunning speed, swelling as security forces showed little willingness to battle the largest anti-Milosevic protest ever. 

Soon after the end of the NATO bombing campaign last year, many war and sanctions-weary Serbs looked high and low for someone to lead them against the regime. The political options were bleak: the maverick fence-sitter Vuk Draskovic and his Serbian Renewal Movement on one hand, and the Democratic party leader Zoran Djindjic on the other. Djindjic's error was to leave Belgrade at the height of the bombing; it was seen as an act of cowardice by ordinary Serbs who had no choice but to stay put.

To make matters worse, Djindjic and Draskovic proved repeatedly that they could not put personal differences aside and present a united opposition.

A series of opposition rallies around Serbia in the weeks that followed the Alliance campaign were little more than Sunday outings for the curious and a chance for the two opposition groups to squabble. The only exceptions came when protests were organized by two independent rebels: Ivan Novkovic, a renegade television weatherman in the southern town of Leskovac, and Bogoljub ''Maki'' Arsenijevic, an artist from the central town of Valjevo. However, while these two would-be revolutionaries galvanized people in their home towns, they were never serious contenders for the post of president.

During this time, Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history. It came when Milosevic decided to call early elections and Kostunica was chosen to head a multi-party democratic opposition. Whereas the West had been less than accurate in reading the Balkan mentality, Kostunica had read the runes well.

He knew that many Serbs had become wary of firebrand politics and paramilitary adventurism. His message has been an almost Gandhi-esque appeal to peaceful resistance.

So who is the man who now seems to have achieved what would have looked impossible even three months ago -- levering Milosevic from power? And will he meet the West's expectations?

Vojislav Kostunica, a married man with no children, was nominated as the candidate of 18 parties and one trade union that form the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS). Born to an old Belgrade family in 1944, he graduated from the Belgrade School of Law in 1966 and went on to obtain a master's degree in 1970 and doctorate in 1974.

In 1970 he was appointed assistant lecturer at the Belgrade School of Law, but was expelled in 1974 during a political purge of Belgrade University, because of his opposition to communism.

From 1974 until 1981, he worked at the Institute of Social Sciences. He moved on to become director of the Institute for Philosophy and Social Theory. Until recently, his main claim to fame was as a bookish academic and author of papers on constitutional law, political theory and political philosophy. Kostunica has also worked as editor-in-chief of several specialized journals dedicated to law and philosophy, such as the Archive for Legal and Social Sciences, Philosophical Studies, Philosophy and Society and Theoria.

During the '80s, while Milosevic was climbing the greasy pole to supreme power, Kostunica turned his legal skills to human rights and was especially active in the board for the freedom of thought and speech, where he was highly regarded. It was around this time that he became involved in politics, becoming a founder of the Democratic party in 1989. He has been president of the separate Democratic party of Serbia since it was founded in 1992 and was a member of the Serbian parliament from 1990 until 1997, when his party boycotted the elections due to the ''lack of regular electoral conditions.''

Western leaders, however, have been nonplussed. Although senior European Union, American and even Russian politicians have been swift to call on Milosevic to hand power to Kostunica, the lawyer has not always been flavour of the month, especially in Washington.

Kostunica has consistently proclaimed that he would not hand Milosevic over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and he was a vigorous critic of the NATO bombardment. This has been seized on by some as proof that he is no different from other war-zealous Balkan leaders.

Kostunica has been described in some U.S. state department background briefings as an old- fashioned Serb nationalist, a sort of ''Seselj in coat-tails'' -- a reference to Milosevic's erstwhile ally, Vojislav Seselj, the ultra-nationalist leader of the Serbian Radical party.

This is where East and West divide. Opponents of the Milosevic regime see nothing wrong in criticizing the NATO campaign, for the bombing affected nearly everyone. While they may be anti-Milosevic, they believe their political destiny should be decided from within.

''Kostunica is a good patriot. He is educated, a peaceful man and no threat to anyone,'' says Srdjan Stojanovic, an independent Serbian journalist who lives in London. ''He is a calm, even boring speaker, but he insists on following legal procedures. That is what our country needs.''

Nikola Barovic, a noted Serbian human rights lawyer, agrees. ''He is a very good lawyer and has a high regard for fair play. Because he is very strict and correct, I think he will do all he can to help keep things peaceful,'' he says.

And an expatriate Serb points out: ''He is a politician of impeccable democratic credentials, keen intelligence and high personal integrity. He has not compromised himself either by making deals with Milosevic, unlike Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, or by being too subservient to the West like, say, Zoran Djindjic. His consistency and perseverance has finally paid off.''


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: CP Color Photo: Darko Vojinovic, Associated Press / SERB SAVIOUR: Democratic Opposition of Serbia leader Vojislav Kostunica and his wife Zorica Radovic leave city hall in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, Thursday.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

163 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Advertiser


April 28, 1999, Wednesday


KOSOVO SURPRISE; A role for NATO


BYLINE: By GEORGE JAHN in Belgrade


LENGTH: 502 words


A MAN considered a mouthpiece for Yugoslav President Slobodan

Milosevic has suddenly upstaged him with a bold suggestion that troops

from NATO countries could play a role in Kosovo.

Deputy Premier Vuk Draskovic said yesterday Yugoslavia would accept a

UN peacekeeping force for Kosovo that could include soldiers from NATO

countries.

What's more, said Mr Draskovic, both Mr Milosevic and Russian special

envoy Mr Viktor Chernomyrdin shared his views in separate

conversations with each of them. 

Such a stance by Mr Milosevic would mark a huge concession by the

Yugoslav leader.

Mr Milosevic has steadfastly rejected the concept of any foreign armed

forces in Kosovo as part of a peace settlement.

And he has ruled out any presence in Kosovo of "aggressor countries"

his term for NATO nations. The US and its NATO allies continue to

insist on a strong NATO-led force in Kosovo as part of any peace

accord.

But if Mr Milosevic, Mr Draskovic and Moscow are indeed of one mind,

and Mr Milosevic is using his deputy leader to voice a new stand on

Kosovo, then the two sides are more in tune with each other than at

any time since the NATO airstrikes began on March 24.

Still, Mr Draskovic has a track record of unpredictability.

His comments could mean less a change in thinking by the Yugoslav

regime and more an attempt to distance himself from Mr Milosevic and

position himself as a possible alternative for the Yugoslav

leadership.

When he joined Mr Milosevic's Government last year, the flamboyant

former opposition leader was accused of selling out by the

anti-Milosevic movement.

For many, he turned into Mr Milosevic's moderate voice once he joined

the Government. When Mr Milosevic sounded tough, Mr Draskovic was

conciliatory on Kosovo during the two rounds of talks in France that

ended in failure and led to the NATO air strikes.

After the start of the air campaign, Mr Draskovic's language was

passionately pro-Serb but low-key compared with others in the

Milosevic camp. He broke that mould on Monday when, in an interview

with Studio B his party's television station the bearded firebrand

suddenly condemned both the leadership and its propaganda campaign.

The comments aroused immediate attention.

Inside Serbia, some now applaud Mr Draskovic for shattering the image

nurtured by State media of a people determined to fight to the last

rather than bend to NATO.

For the second time in less than a week, NATO yesterday blasted a

high-rise building described as the "nerve centre" of Mr Milosevic's

ruling machine.

A huge explosion shook the 23-storey Usce Centre building, which

houses offices of Mr Milosevic's socialist party and offices of

several broadcast stations.

Earlier, the Red Cross was finally allowed to see the three US

soldiers captured by Yugoslav forces last month.

And the UN relief agency said it had credible evidence that Serb

forces were using Kosovo refugees as human shields to help protect

them from NATO airstrikes.


LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: ADV


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


164 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


December 28, 1996, Saturday, FIVE STAR LIFT Edition


A WHIFF OF A GARLIC REVOLUTION


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 33


LENGTH: 410 words


 

Czechoslovakia deposed its communists in a Velvet Revolution. Serbia's political opposition may be in the middle of a garlic revolution. Despite an eruption of violence on Tuesday that claimed the life of a protester, well-armed riot police and wintry weather, tens of thousands of students and opposition members took to the streets on Thursday and again on Friday. 

Many students carried strings of garlic to ward off "communist vampires, " a humorous but pointed message. The regime's opponents have given no indication that they plan to desist: "We will march . . . until they fulfill our demands," said student leader Cedomir Jovanovic. Those demands have begun to include the resignation of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic. That outcome, which once seemed completely implausible, no longer looks impossible.

Unable to tolerate even the mildest dissent, Mr. Milosevic has no one but himself to blame. He tossed out the results of local elections when they were not to his liking. He then escalated the situation, and ruled out a possibility of compromise, by using the courts to ratify his illegal action.

Throughout this crisis, Mr. Milosevic has seemed bewildered that people, denied a voice within the system, would take their peaceful protests outside, to the streets. But instead of intimidating his rivals into silence, his increasingly severe reactions have pushed Mr. Milosevic into the corner.

Finally this week, Mr. Milosevic was reduced to borrowing a page from Nicolae Ceaucescu's crude book on crowd control; he bused in rural supporters to provoke conflict with peaceful protesters. As expected, violence broke out: 58 people were injured, and the anti-Milosevic movement now has its first martyr - Predrag Starcevic, who died of beatings inflicted by Milosevic supporters.

Mr. Milosevic may end up regretting that move because his supporters may have had their eyes opened. Dependent on government propaganda, they reportedly were astonished to see how widespread opposition to the regime is and how the opponents are not just the thugs and hooligans portrayed on government TV.

The United States and the West are largely observers to this process. But they can keep the pressure on Mr. Milosevic by reimposing sanctions should he engage in a violent crackdown. Even his friends - Montenegro and Russia - are rushing to put distance between them. Mr. Milosevic's power just might wither in the light of a new day.


LOAD-DATE: December 28, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


TYPE: EDITORIAL


Copyright 1996 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


165 of 348 DOCUMENTS


San Jose Mercury News (California)


October 22, 1999 Friday MORNING FINAL EDITION


MILOSEVIC BACKERS TURNING UP TERROR ON RIVALS FACTIONS PLAN PUSH FOR EARLY ELECTIONS


BYLINE: LORI MONTGOMERY, Mercury News Berlin Bureau


SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 17A


LENGTH: 886 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


As thousands rally nightly to demand his resignation, allies of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic are conducting an increasingly public campaign of intimidation, police harassment and economic blackmail against opposition leaders.

Across Serbia, authorities loyal to the Milosevic government have arrested some supporters of the pro-democracy Alliance for Change, threatened others with violence or fired them from state-controlled jobs and closed privately owned shops and restaurants.

This week, the campaign seemed to enter an ominous new phase as Milosevic's powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, launched a fierce rhetorical attack against Alliance for Change leader Zoran Djindjic, branding him a traitorous "puppet" of the West and a NATO spy. Meanwhile, the commander of the Yugoslav army vowed to defend the country against "various internal enemies." And a bomb exploded at the home of an opposition leader in the eastern town of Valjevo. 

Increasing animosity

Coming just two weeks after a suspected assassination attempt in which a truck loaded with sand plowed into a car carrying opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, the latest developments sent shock waves across Belgrade intellectual circles.

Dissidents, journalists and other observers of the Milosevic government believe that Milosevic is nervously testing strategies to defuse calls for his resignation and for free and fair elections. Well-aware that a majority of Serbs would throw him out of office if given the chance to vote, analysts say Milosevic is disturbed by indications that opposition factions have coalesced around a plan to begin a coordinated push Thursday for early elections.

For now, Milosevic and his supporters appear to be carefully targeting movement leaders in Belgrade and smaller communities as a way of intimidating others to stay home and keep their mouths shut. If that doesn't work, dissident leaders fear, the government may unleash a brutal police crackdown against the marchers who have gathered nightly in towns across Serbia for the past month.

"I think the night of long knives is waiting for us," said CedomirJovanovic, a top Alliance for Change organizer. "They're waiting for the opportunity to use extreme violence in such a way as to horrify Serbian citizens" into submission.

Moving constantly

One of the most wanted men in Serbia, Jovanovic, 28, is familiar with the regime's tactics. For the past two months, he has been sleeping in different apartments and switching cars during the day to avoid arrest by state security agents.

Charged earlier this month with accepting cash from foreign intelligence agents and plotting to destroy the constitutional system, Jovanovic hides under disguises and appears in public escorted by a cadre of marchers. Asked what would happen if police found him, Jovanovic, a movie buff, replied: "Midnight Express," a film that depicts vicious conditions in a Turkish prison.

Djindjic said he is under constant police surveillance. His motorcades have been searched repeatedly in recent days. Citing police and state security sources, Djindjic said his apartment building, its entrance and elevator and the surrounding streets have been photographed, his bodyguards have been quizzed about their weapons and the home of a friend has been filmed from a helicopter "as if it were an enemy military object."

On another front, the printing house that publishes Alliance for Change posters and bulletins was hauled into court this week on 44 charges of printing a publication that is not officially registered. If convicted, ABC Grafika could face fines that would halt publication of independent news media such as Vreme, NIN and Glas Javnosti, as well as Alliance for Change documents.

The situation outside Belgrade is even bleaker. Take Leskovac, a southern Serbian town controlled by Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) where spontaneous protests erupted about a month after international peacekeeping forces entered Kosovo on July 12.

The issue in Leskovac -- ground zero of this year's anti-Milosevic movement -- was fury over the huge number of local men sent to fight in Kosovo. Nearly 70 percent of fighting-age men were mobilized in Leskovac, barely 20 miles from the Kosovo border. More than 80 of them died, though authorities admit to only 57.

On July 1, Ivan Novkovic, a technician at the SPS-controlled TV station, broadcast a diatribe against local SPS leaders during a championship basketball game between Yugoslavia and Germany. Four days later, 20,000 people -- the largest crowd ever to assemble in the town of 80,000 -- turned out to protest against local leaders.

After the rally, Novkovic and two other rally speakers were imprisoned for nearly a month. One of the speakers, Bratislav Stamenkovic, was fired from his job as a municipal development engineer. Last week, Novkovic also was fired.

The number of marchers in Leskovac has dwindled to 300, as those who take to the streets find themselves photographed and their jobs threatened by their employers -- all supporters of Milosevic's party.

"We have a lot of work to do and we have a very dangerous rival," said Stamenkovic, who spent 25 days in prison. "The end is very close. But I'm afraid there will be a lot of wounded and dead before this is over."


LOAD-DATE: October 25, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
