166 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


August 21, 1999, Saturday


THOUSANDS TELL MILOSEVIC TO QUIT


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: TOM HUNDLEY


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 32


LENGTH: 511 words


Thousands tell Milosevic to quit

Tom Hundley

in Belgrade

MORE than 100,000 Serbs turned out on a warm August evening to vent their frustration with Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, the man who has led their country to military defeat, economic ruin and international isolation.

Zoran Djindjic, one of leading figures in Serbia's fractious opposition, issued an ultimatum to Milosevic: resign within 15 days or face daily demonstrations and prolonged nationwide strikes.

"This time we will carry on until the end," Mr Djindjic told the protesters. "Either he goes or we do." 

Police kept a low profile, and the rally outside the Yugoslav parliament building remained peaceful. There were some tense moments, however, when a tear-gas grenade tossed into the densely packed crowd nearly caused a stampede.

The rally was organised by a newly formed group of independent economists who aim to create a transitional government of experts that would repair the economy, normalise relations with the West and prepare the country for internationally supervised elections.

"It's time for Milosevic to go," said Milovan Pavlovic, a 71-year-old retired mechanic from southern Serbia, who travelled by bus to Belgrade to take part in the demonstration. He said he was disappointed by the turnout.

"I was hoping for two or three million. These are dark days for Serbia and we will probably need a miracle to get rid of Milosevic."

Yesterday's demonstration was the first in the capital since the winter of 1996-97, when nearly three months of daily street protests against Milosevic ultimately failed because opposition leaders began bickering with each other.

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party, is the most charismatic, erratic and perhaps mistrusted figure in the anti-Milosevic camp. Two days before the Belgrade rally he withdrew as a speaker without explanation.

There were reports in the Belgrade media _ denied by Mr Draskovic _ of a secret meeting between him and Milosevic.

But halfway through yesterday's rally, he suddenly and dramatically strode up to the speaker's platform, touching off a brief scuffle between his bodyguards and those of arch-rival Mr Djindjic.

His theatrical appearance touched off loud jeers and cries of "traitor," which were quickly drowned out by ecstatic chants of "Vuk, Vuk" from supporters.

Russia yesterday threatened to withdraw its troops from the Kosovo peacekeeping force, complaining that it did not want to be associated with an operation that it believed NATO was mismanaging.

"If KFOR activities take on a certain character, then Russia's association with such activities will not be possible," the Interfax news agency quoted defence and foreign ministry officials as saying.

The officials said the KFOR force was not abiding by United Nations resolutions, a reference to provisions calling for the protection of Serbs and the disarming of ethnic Albanian fighters from the Kosovo Liberation Army.

Knight-Ridder/Tribune

Additional reporting AFP


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


167 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury (Australia)


October 5, 1999, Tuesday


Road murder bid, Draskovic alleges


LENGTH: 370 words


Belgrade

PROMINENT Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic has alleged he was the victim of an assassination attempt in a car crash yesterday.

Four of his team died in the crash, which followed the car he was in swerving off the road to avoid hitting a truck.

The car in which Draskovic's security team was travelling hit the truck head-on, one of Draskovic's advisers said. 

Draskovic, president of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), told Studio B television that the crash was an "obvious assassination attempt".

"We are talking about an obvious assassination attempt and, with God's will, everybody was killed but myself," he said. "Let those who carried it out reflect well on what will happen to them."

The alleged assassination attempt came as mass demonstrations against the regime of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic took place throughout Serbia for the 13th consecutive day, bringing tens of thousands of people on to the streets.

Draskovic was slightly injured in the accident, near Lazarevac, 40km south of Belgrade, his party said.

Killed were his security chief, two other members of the security team and his brother-in-law, an official in the Belgrade municipality.

"The truck suddenly, without any reason . . . switched to our side of the road and it was clear to me that it had intended to kill me," Draskovic said.

Borivoje Borovic, a lawyer and member of the SPO's directorate, said the road was straight and not slippery, with good visibility. "The truck driver disappeared," he added.

An investigating magistrate said the truck had been on the wrong side of the road at the time of the collision "for reasons yet unknown".

At an anti-Milosevic rally organised by the opposition coalition Alliance for Change, a minute's silence was held in honour of the killed SPO officials.

Because of a disagreement over strategy, the SPO does not participate in the alliance's daily protests aimed at ousting Milosevic.

As the mass protests continued, police cordons restricted a march by 15,000 people through the centre of Belgrade.

Police directed the crowd back to a square where the demonstration had started. There were no reports of violent incidents.

AFP


LOAD-DATE: March 8, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: MER


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


168 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


August 21, 1999, Saturday


MILOSEVIC BOOSTED BY OPPOSITION BICKERING


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 11


LENGTH: 758 words


 

AFTER Thursday's anti-government rally in Belgrade, Serbia's opposition was left nursing a political hangover yesterday.

Opposition analysts gave the rally mixed reviews. The good news was the impressive size of the crowd in this politically jaded city. The bad news is that the opposition showed itself to be as split as ever. 

State television gave prominent coverage to the tossing of a teargas canister into the crowd at the start of the protest as well as on-stage scuffling between rival parties' security guards.

A newscaster claimed the demonstration was planned weeks ago by the US envoy to the Balkans, Robert Gelbard.

The government's daily paper, Politika, buried news of the rally and estimated crowd size at only 25,000.

The crowd of 150,000 was considered a strong showing for Belgrade. While the capital is firmly controlled by the opposition, as are all of Serbia's larger towns, citizens have grown weary of demonstrating against the president, Slobodan Milosevic, for ten years with nothing to show for it.

"The size of the crowd was a good sign. It was clearly an expression of disappointment with the government," said Dragoljub Micunovic, president of the Democratic Centre and a federal MP.

Citizens also took advantage of every opportunity to chant anti-Milosevic epithets.

But the sobering news was the old rivalries exposed at the podium. One group is planning simultaneous protests across Serbia in a bid to force out Mr Milosevic, while the other will press for early elections.

Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement wants to negotiate internationally monitored elections with the Milosevic government.

That proposal was jeered at the rally, but recent polls indicate Mr Draskovic is Serbia's most popular leader, with 18 per cent support.

Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party received a 13.7 per cent approval rating, while his wife's United Yugoslav Left received a 2.5 per cent rating.

The Alliance for Change, the Serbian Orthodox Church and a group of economists and professionals called G17 are sticking with the Stability Pact for Serbia, a document demanding the resignation of Mr Milosevic followed by a year-long transition government of experts.

The idea is to set politics aside temporarily to pull Serbia out of its economic isolation.

Zoran Djindjic, president of the Democratic Party and key alliance member, gave Mr Milosevic an ultimatum: "Either resign in 15 days or we'll remove you. It's either him or us. There is no middle ground."

Mr Djindjic and his allies will lead protests in "50 cities and towns" across Serbia, accompanied by strikes and civil disobedience, until Mr Milosevic agrees to bow out.

Mr Djindjic drew wild cheers in cosmopolitan Belgrade, but he is an urban candidate with scant support among farmers and factory workers. His party received a 10 per cent showing in recent polls, just trailing Milosevic's Socialists.

Mr Djindjic's party is by far the strongest in Alliance for Change. But without Mr Draskovic's support, analysts say the alliance's civil disobedience campaign will not be much of a threat. Yet Mr Djindjic is betting that deep and mounting economic frustration will pull Serbs on to the streets.

The alliance feels that fair elections are not possible with Mr Milosevic at the helm.Mr Draskovic, on the other hand, knows fair elections could put him in power. But he set conditions for early elections: state media must be open to the opposition, and voting must be monitored by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe.

Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party recently announced it would go to elections if that is what the opposition wants, but whether it would meet Mr Draskovic's demands remains unknown.

Serbia's and Yugoslavia's ruling coalition is made up of Vojislav Seselj's Radical nationalists, and the parties of Mr Milosevic and his wife. Polling data suggests only a united opposition could beat that coalition.

Mr Djindjic's street protests could quickly turn violent, as the Alliance for Change has been branded "a terrorist organisation" by state media and government leaders.

Adding to the uncertainty are rumours that many in Mr Milosevic's ranks are thinking of turning against him.

"In private conversation, powerful people in the Socialist Party are expressing their dissatisfaction," said Mr Micunovic. "That has never happened before. There is a consensus that something has to happen to move us past this point, but everyone disagrees about what it is."


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


169 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


August 21, 1999, Saturday


MILOSEVIC BOOSTED BY OPPOSITION BICKERING


BYLINE: Alex Todorovic In Belgrade


SECTION: Pg. 11


LENGTH: 758 words


 

AFTER Thursday's anti-government rally in Belgrade, Serbia's opposition was left nursing a political hangover yesterday.

Opposition analysts gave the rally mixed reviews. The good news was the impressive size of the crowd in this politically jaded city. The bad news is that the opposition showed itself to be as split as ever. 

State television gave prominent coverage to the tossing of a teargas canister into the crowd at the start of the protest as well as on-stage scuffling between rival parties' security guards.

A newscaster claimed the demonstration was planned weeks ago by the US envoy to the Balkans, Robert Gelbard.

The government's daily paper, Politika, buried news of the rally and estimated crowd size at only 25,000.

The crowd of 150,000 was considered a strong showing for Belgrade. While the capital is firmly controlled by the opposition, as are all of Serbia's larger towns, citizens have grown weary of demonstrating against the president, Slobodan Milosevic, for ten years with nothing to show for it.

"The size of the crowd was a good sign. It was clearly an expression of disappointment with the government," said Dragoljub Micunovic, president of the Democratic Centre and a federal MP.

Citizens also took advantage of every opportunity to chant anti-Milosevic epithets.

But the sobering news was the old rivalries exposed at the podium. One group is planning simultaneous protests across Serbia in a bid to force out Mr Milosevic, while the other will press for early elections.

Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement wants to negotiate internationally monitored elections with the Milosevic government.

That proposal was jeered at the rally, but recent polls indicate Mr Draskovic is Serbia's most popular leader, with 18 per cent support.

Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party received a 13.7 per cent approval rating, while his wife's United Yugoslav Left received a 2.5 per cent rating.

The Alliance for Change, the Serbian Orthodox Church and a group of economists and professionals called G17 are sticking with the Stability Pact for Serbia, a document demanding the resignation of Mr Milosevic followed by a year-long transition government of experts.

The idea is to set politics aside temporarily to pull Serbia out of its economic isolation.

Zoran Djindjic, president of the Democratic Party and key alliance member, gave Mr Milosevic an ultimatum: "Either resign in 15 days or we'll remove you. It's either him or us. There is no middle ground."

Mr Djindjic and his allies will lead protests in "50 cities and towns" across Serbia, accompanied by strikes and civil disobedience, until Mr Milosevic agrees to bow out.

Mr Djindjic drew wild cheers in cosmopolitan Belgrade, but he is an urban candidate with scant support among farmers and factory workers. His party received a 10 per cent showing in recent polls, just trailing Milosevic's Socialists.

Mr Djindjic's party is by far the strongest in Alliance for Change. But without Mr Draskovic's support, analysts say the alliance's civil disobedience campaign will not be much of a threat. Yet Mr Djindjic is betting that deep and mounting economic frustration will pull Serbs on to the streets.

The alliance feels that fair elections are not possible with Mr Milosevic at the helm.Mr Draskovic, on the other hand, knows fair elections could put him in power. But he set conditions for early elections: state media must be open to the opposition, and voting must be monitored by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe.

Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party recently announced it would go to elections if that is what the opposition wants, but whether it would meet Mr Draskovic's demands remains unknown.

Serbia's and Yugoslavia's ruling coalition is made up of Vojislav Seselj's Radical nationalists, and the parties of Mr Milosevic and his wife. Polling data suggests only a united opposition could beat that coalition.

Mr Djindjic's street protests could quickly turn violent, as the Alliance for Change has been branded "a terrorist organisation" by state media and government leaders.

Adding to the uncertainty are rumours that many in Mr Milosevic's ranks are thinking of turning against him.

"In private conversation, powerful people in the Socialist Party are expressing their dissatisfaction," said Mr Micunovic. "That has never happened before. There is a consensus that something has to happen to move us past this point, but everyone disagrees about what it is."


LOAD-DATE: September 10, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


170 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


April 03, 1999, FINAL


NATO's folly in the Balkans: The western alliance erred by applying the Bosnian model to Yugoslavia and strategically backing the Serbs into a blind alley, an academic observer argues.


BYLINE: Lenard J. Cohen


SECTION: Editorial; A19


LENGTH: 1447 words


As the NATO alliance presses its bombing campaign against Slobodan Milosevic's military machine in Yugoslavia, an intense propaganda war is also raging.

In a televised address to the Serbian people March 25, U.S. President Bill Clinton claimed that the United States and its allies "have no quarrel with the Serbian people." He identified Milosevic as the culprit responsible for the diminished and isolated position of Serbia and for forcing Serbia's sons to fight in a "senseless conflict."

U.S. Secretary of State Madeline Albright reinforced that, "Americans do not hate Serbs." She added that the Serb people have not been "accurately informed" about the Kosovo peace settlement based on the Rambouillet accords; an agreement that would help build democracy for every ethnic group in Kosovo. Serbian leaders, she warned, must accept the peace plan and allow the deployment in Kosovo of a NATO-led peace implementation force. 

Such sentiments offered cold comfort to most Serbs, who regard Kosovo as the cradle of their cultural identity, and who dread the prospect of Albanian political hegemony in the region. But even more catastrophic for the Serbian people is the idea that Kosovo could be occupied by an external military force.

A majority of Serbs staunchly oppose Milosevic's authoritarian regime. However, the majority (including the weak and divided domestic opposition) strongly resent foreign dictates regarding which political values and models they should espouse, when and how Serbs should depose their political leaders and how Serbia should respond to an internal secessionist movement.

In this context, Clinton's explanation that the Kosovar Albanians insisted on the deployment of NATO peacekeeping forces in Kosovo only heightens Serbian paranoia, while the president's claim those troops would not constitute "some occupying force" is viewed as sheer deceit.

It is true NATO leaders conducted seemingly endless negotiations with Milosevic and promised to maintain Yugoslavia's current borders. But the key provision of the plan presented to the Serbian regime -- that was offered on a take-it or leave-it-and-be-bombed basis -- included the presence of a 28, 000-strong NATO force on Yugoslav territory.

During the Rambouillet and Paris negotiations more than 1,200 civilian "verification monitors" were already present in Kosovo, and the fighting had diminished compared to the earlier period or what has followed since the current NATO bombing campaign. Expanding such a civilian force, protected by NATO troops in Macedonia, might have provided a more acceptable alternative for implementing a negotiated political agreement for Kosovo.

A European protection force with OSCE monitors could have been another viable option. But NATO rejected such plans, preferring instead the Bosnian model of peace enforcement, where a large NATO- led military force "protects" a comprehensive civilian implementation program.

But Kosovo is not Bosnia, not to mention part of a sovereign country. Uncompromisingly employing a cookie-cutter approach to resolve conflicts within each complex Balkan sub-region is hopelessly misguided. And, as now is tragically evident in Kosovo, can even make a bad situation worse.

There is certainly a "moral imperative" to relieving humanitarian disasters and preventing atrocities, such as those resulting from the brutal struggle between Yugoslav security forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army. But the present oxymoronic NATO policy of "humanitarian bombing" is hardly the way to deliver short-term emergency assistance.

Increasing numbers of Albanians have now become refugees and targets of Serbian anger. Even anti-Milosevic Serbs are now deeply offended by the resolve of the international community to bomb their country to force acceptance of a NATO-led peacekeeping protectorate on their soil. Ironically, the same young Serbs who became politically conscious in anti-Milosevic protests now vent their frustration in opposition to NATO.

If the goal of the international community is to alleviate both Albanian and Serb suffering in Kosovo, preserve the Yugoslav borders, and repair Serb-Albanian relations, the bombing campaign of Serbia in order to politically target Milosevic is clearly the wrong way to go about it. Some advocates of NATO's aerial assault are now calling for direct " forced entry" by NATO ground troops, or foreign arming of the Kosovar Albanians. Such proposals would only serve to broaden the conflict and compound NATO's original misguided approach.

The dream of most Albanians in Kosovo is to achieve political independence. This includes eventual union with Albania proper, and with other Albanian populations in neighbouring states. That yearning has now intensified.

Indeed, the core of Serbian opposition to the take-it-or-leave-it peace settlement is the fear that the Rambouillet accords and the presence of NATO troops in Kosovo would encourage Kosovar Albanian separation and state-building dreams.

Many of Yugoslavia's neighbours, such as fragile Macedonia (at least its 65-70 per cent non- Albanian citizens), Greece and Bulgaria exhibit similar angst with respect to the destabilizing potential of such "greater" Albanian aspirations.

A publicly stated goal of NATO bombing is to force Serb acceptance of the present peace settlement signed by the Albanian side in Paris. But the alliance's unspoken agenda is to emulate the Dayton model used for Bosnia and Herzegovina; that is, the creation of another international protectorate in the Balkans.

Such a NATO-run entity is viewed not only as a way to unseat Milosevic and blunt Serbian "aggression," but also a means to prevent the formation of a large ethnic Albanian state. Today NATO is ostensibly bombing the Serbs to protect Kosovo's Albanians. Tomorrow alliance forces will likely be required to deter state-building efforts by the Kosovo Liberation Army and other militant Albanians.

NATO's political and military leaders have studiously avoided raising any other alternatives, such as peacefully negotiating border changes or partition of the countries in the area, for fear that any territorial reconfiguration -- for example, of Kosovo or Macedonia -- would encourage similar initiatives in ethnically segmented Bosnia and Herzegovina. By "degrading" Milosevic's military, NATO hopes to clear the way for the alliance to shape the political future of southeastern Europe.

But what is termed military force serving diplomacy is essentially force serving problematic political goals. After Dayton and the experience of the past few years in Bosnia, NATO has developed a template for what it considers to be the proper political architecture and behaviour for people in Europe's less stable regions. The result of such a policy will encourage the incremental expansion of a very expensive and protracted chain of protectorates throughout the Balkans.

As NATO moves ahead with its latest Balkan venture, the citizens and policy-makers in NATO states could profitably ask themselves some serious questions regarding current alliance strategy.

For example, do we really want to establish a network of expensive and long-term protectorates in southeastern Europe? Can such military-backed protectorates really foster "self-sustaining" multiethnic states and democratic self-governance? Should NATO bomb all countries where armed separatist movements have engendered a brutal response from incumbent state leaders who belong to the dominant ethnic group? Should we attack foreign countries if they are unwilling to grant international officials working in protectorates near imperiatorial powers to induce what they consider to be acceptable patterns of political behaviour?

Such issues will remain pertinent beyond the political life of Slobodan Milosevic and the current bombing campaign.

At this point, it would be prudent to suspend the bombing of Yugoslavia (as part of a mutual ceasefire), and to take another look at whether the proposed Kosovo peace settlement can effectively address not only the "Serbian question," but also the "Albanian question" in southeastern Europe.

For better or worse, Slobodan Milosevic is now fully aware that NATO threats are credible. However, the broader interests of the countries in the alliance require consideration of alternatives to bombing as a methodology for negotiating Balkan stability, and to the proliferation of NATO-backed international protectorates in the region.

Lenard J. Cohen is professor of political science at Simon Fraser University. He is currently writing a book on Slobodan Milosevic and Serbian politics.


LOAD-DATE: April 4, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Photo: Nexhat Cocaj, Reuters / GHOST TOWN: The village of Prizen in southern Kosovo is consumed by flames set by Serbian forces. The ethnic Albanian residents were expelled on March 27. This photo was given to Reuters news agency at the Albanian border by an amateur photographer from the village.

171 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


July 8, 1999, Thursday


Anti-Milosevic  fervour spreads


SOURCE: * AFP, Reuters


BYLINE: * Correspondents in Belgrade and Uzice


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 284 words


DEMANDS for Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to quit have spread to Serbia's second and third-largest cities, with protesters at one rally in the south of the province clashing with police.

Students in Nis said on Tuesday the people had to choose between Serbia or Mr Milosevic, and the city council of Novi Sad accused the President of "catastrophic foreign and domestic policy". 

In the southern Serbian town of Uzice, former Belgrade mayor Zoran Djindjic led an anti-government rally to warn of civil war if Mr Milosevic stays, while in Leskovac about 1500 people clashed with riot police following the jailing of a television engineer who had interrupted broadcasts to call for an opposition protest.

Some protesters attacked the house of a local official of Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party, smashing windows and breaking down the fence in protest at the 30-day sentence for Ivan Novkovic.

Mr Djindjic, the head of the Serbian Democratic Party, told about 5000 people in Uzice that Serbia was heading for a civil war unless Mr Milosevic went.

Speaking in public for the first time since fleeing Serbia in fear for his life six weeks ago, Mr Djindjic called in his Uzice speech for people to have courage and push for change.

"Every day, in every town, we have to get out in the streets" until Mr Milosevic is dismissed, Mr Djindjic said, describing him as "the worst and the most incapable leader the world has ever seen".

Mr Djindjic urged the people to "transform" their dissatisfaction to "a general people's movement aimed at freeing the Serbian people from slavery".

"You should be ready, it will be a long summer but it will be followed by freedom," he said.

LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


172 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


June 28, 1999


Kosovo: After the war: Opposition: Milosevic faces showdown rally;
Protest turnout could make or break moves to oust president


BYLINE: RORY CARROLL IN BELGRADE


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages; Pg. 12


LENGTH: 443 words


Yugoslavia's opposition leaders are preparing for tomorrow's mass rally against Slobodan Milosevic, a showdown that could make or break efforts to dislodge the president.

Demonstrators will be bussed from Belgrade to the central Serbian town of Cacak, where a crowd of up to 25,000 will try to launch a campaign of country -wide street protests calling for Mr Milosevic's resignation and free elections.

Failure to mobilise high attendance could further undermine opposition unity, consolidating the shaky regime. 

The mayor of Cacak, Velimir Ilic, is expected to come out of hiding to speak. He is wanted on criminal charges for organising an anti-government rally during the war in Kosovo.

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the Democratic party and a potential challenger to Mr Milosevic, is expected to return from his tour of Europe. He claimed at the weekend that Mr Milosevic had been offered asylum in China if ousted, so he could avoid prosecution by the war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

The Alliance for Change, an umbrella group of 30 opposition parties, chose Cacak as a hotbed of anti-Milosevic sentiment. Hopes of joining forces with 3,000 soldiers protesting about unpaid wages in nearby towns faded yesterday when the reservists melted away after a general toured their blockades handing out cash.

The rally will breach a ban on protests, in force despite last week's decision to lift the state of war. Alliance leaders said they were prepared to go to jail.

Their morale was boosted at Saturday's Yugoslav football cup final when Red Star Belgrade's stadium resounded to the chants: 'Slobo resign', and 'Slobo, you sold Kosovo'.

But opposition rifts have undermined their chances of tapping such hostility. Vuk Draskovic, popular head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, will not attend the rally.

Ljubodrag Stojadinovic, who headed the army press office, said Mr Milosevic was unlikely to send in police. 'It's hard to believe there'll be enough people there to shake him. People are fed up, but things are returning to normal. They don't want violence or revolution. Elections in the autumn are the most likely next step.'

No one questioned in Belgrade's streets planned to attend. 'You expect me to drive down there for three hours so I can shout about Slobo and achieve precisely nothing? No thanks,' said one man.

The Serbian Orthodox church is understood to have chosen Thursday as the day to speak out about Serb atrocities in Kosovo. Its head, Patriarch Pavle, has returned from the province shocked by what he saw. He has instructed priests to relay the message that the country needs to atone.


LOAD-DATE: June 29, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Guardian Newspapers Limited


173 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


June 28, 1999


Milosevic faces showdown rally;
Opposition Protest turnout could make or break moves to oust president


BYLINE: Rory Carroll in Belgrade


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages; Pg. 12


LENGTH: 447 words


Rory Carroll in Belgrade

Yugoslavia's opposition leaders are preparing for tomorrow's mass rally against Slobodan Milosevic, a showdown that could make or break efforts to dislodge the president.

Demonstrators will be bussed from Belgrade to the central Serbian town of Cacak, where a crowd of up to 25,000 will try to launch a campaign of country -wide street protests calling for Mr Milosevic's resignation and free elections.

Failure to mobilise high attendance could further undermine opposition unity, consolidating the shaky regime. 

The mayor of Cacak, Velimir Ilic, is expected to come out of hiding to speak. He is wanted on criminal charges for organising an anti-government rally during the war in Kosovo.

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the Democratic party and a potential challenger to Mr Milosevic, is expected to return from his tour of Europe. He claimed at the weekend that Mr Milosevic had been offered asylum in China if ousted, so he could avoid prosecution by the war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

The Alliance for Change, an umbrella group of 30 opposition parties, chose Cacak as a hotbed of anti-Milosevic sentiment. Hopes of joining forces with 3,000 soldiers protesting about unpaid wages in nearby towns faded yesterday when the reservists melted away after a general toured their blockades handing out cash.

The rally will breach a ban on protests, in force despite last week's decision to lift the state of war. Alliance leaders said they were prepared to go to jail.

Their morale was boosted at Saturday's Yugoslav football cup final when Red Star Belgrade's stadium resounded to the chants: 'Slobo resign', and 'Slobo, you sold Kosovo'.

But opposition rifts have undermined their chances of tapping such hostility. Vuk Draskovic, popular head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, will not attend the rally.

Ljubodrag Stojadinovic, who headed the army press office, said Mr Milosevic was unlikely to send in police. 'It's hard to believe there'll be enough people there to shake him. People are fed up, but things are returning to normal. They don't want violence or revolution. Elections in the autumn is the most likely next step.'

No one questioned in Belgrade's streets planned to attend. 'You expect me to drive down there for three hours so I can shout about Slobo and achieve precisely nothing? No thanks,' said one man.

The Serbian Orthodox church is understood to have chosen Thursday as the day to speak out about Serb atrocities in Kosovo. Its head, Patriarch Pavle, has returned from the province shocked by what he saw. He has instructed priests to relay the message that the country needs to atone.

174 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


June 3, 1993, Thursday


Belgrade tense after police beat Draskovic; The Serbian capital could descend into a 'whirlpool of violence' says Marcus Tanner


BYLINE: MARCUS TANNER


SECTION: EUROPEAN NEWS PAGE; Page 10 


LENGTH: 792 words


A TENSE calm returned to the streets of Belgrade yesterday after police arrested and severely beat the leader of Serbia's largest opposition movement, following a riot outside the Yugoslav parliament in which one policeman was killed.

An Interior Ministry statement said Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, was arrested after he assaulted a policeman in a struggle outside the parliament between police and several thousand protesters.

Mr Draskovic's wife, Danica, who was arrested but allowed one telephone call, said she watched as police dragged her husband around a courtyard of Belgrade's main police station by his feet after his arrest.

The opposition leader was admitted to hospital overnight for facial surgery after his ordeal in the police station. A doctor who treated him said Mr Draskovic suffered head fractures, lost some teeth, could not speak or stand up and appeared to be suffering from internal bleeding. Although doctors protested he was not fit to move, the police dragged Mr Draskovic out of his bed and took him back to prison as soon as the operation was over. 

The police arrested Mr Draskovic at 1am yesterday after enraged demonstrators, shouting slogans against the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, attempted to storm the parliament. Tempers are running high among Serbia's impoverished population, and for some the beating-up of a deputy from Mr Draskovic's party inside the parliament by a member of the ultra-nationalist Radical Party was the final straw.

Riot police flooded the city centre, fired rounds of tear gas and repeatedly baton-charged the crowd, which hurled stones at the parliament and smashed windows and streetlamps. One policeman was hit and died yesterday of brain injuries. Dozens of demonstrators were injured. The police made more than 120 arrests. Mr and Mrs Draskovic called on the youthful crowd to disperse and stage a peaceful protest the following day. They retired to party headquarters.

But there was to be no protest. In the early hours of the morning, riot police surrounded the headquarters building and a posse of 40 moved in. The Draskovics were led away in handcuffs. Police lined the entrance to the building. Eye-witnesses said they gave him a savage beating as he ran the gauntlet from the building to a waiting police van.

Staff at Mr Draskovic's headquarters said the police arrested 30 party officials at the same time. ''The police were armed to the teeth with machine guns, pistols, gas masks and wore flak-jackets - they looked like real dogs of war,'' said Blagica Stojanovic, a party spokeswoman. ''When we demanded to see their warrants they just laughed. They said they belonged to the Special Intervention Brigade and did not need warrants.''

Mr Draskovic, 47, has long been a thorn in the side of Mr Milosevic and his ruling Serbian Socialist Party. While Serbia's other opposition hummed and hawed about the brutal war in Croatia and Bosnia, the charismatic writer-turned-politician focused his considerable wit on Serbia's leaders and Mr Milosevic in particular, calling them bandits and thugs who dragged Serbia's name through the mud.

Vuk Draskovic started in politics in the mid-eighties as a nationalist opponent of Communist rule. He espoused a Greater Serbia under a restored monarchy. His was a nave Balkan dream of a democratic land of prosperous peasants, jolly priests, wise kings. With his long hair, hypnotic eyes and richly timbred voice, he looked like a Serbian Rasputin. He loved to doodle maps of Serbia's future borders and to muse about a great future federation of Eastern Orthodox countries stretching from Belgrade to Moscow. He was inconsistent on most points and consistent only in voicing ribald contempt for Mr Milosevic. Loathed by many Serbs as a traitor, he had a core of dedicated followers in Belgrade and in the Serbian countryside, who regarded him as little less than a messiah.

After the failure of a big anti-Milosevic demonstration in Belgrade which he led in March 1991, he became a marginalised figure. But Mr Milosevic never forgot or forgave his most trenchant critic. His opposition to the war in Bosnia and Croatia made him dangerous, and there was always the fear in government circles that he might one day act as a catalyst for a future revolt.

Recently he appeared embittered, accusing Western countries of propping up Mr Milosevic and of giving in to him in Bosnia. He foresaw Serbia's descent into a whirlpool of violence. At his last press conference he said more protests would soon shake Serbia and they would end in bloodshed.

At the time he was accused of inciting a civil war. In retrospect he was just prophetic.

(Photographs omitted)


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1993 Independent Print Ltd

Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


December 26, 1996, Thursday


FIFTEEN HURT AS BELGRADE RALLIES ERUPT


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: GRESTE P


LENGTH: 954 words


KEYWORD-HIT

Fifteen hurt

as Belgrade

rallies erupt

By PETER GRESTE in Belgrade FIFTEEN people were injured,

one by gunfire, in Belgrade yesterday during rival rallies by

supporters and opponents

of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic.

Two of the injured were in serious condition, according to the

state-controlled Tanjug news agency and the independent agency Beta.

An Opposition supporter, named as Ivica Lazovic, was in a ""very

serious condition" after being operated on at an emergency clinic,

Beta said.

Independent radio B-92 said Lazovic was hit when a Milosevic

supporter fired a gun at a group of demonstrators who were jeering at

him not far from the headquarters of the Opposition Serbian Renewal

Movement. 

Another man suffered a broken leg during the rallies, estimated at

about 200,000 Opposition protesters and 100,000 pro-Milosevic

supporters.

Anti-government protesters will rally in Belgrade today, defying

President Milosevic.

Thousands were expected to protest in the capital, fired by their

success in facing down a rally organised by President Milosevic to

intimidate them.

The autocratic ruler ferried in some 40,000 backers from outside

the capital, a much lower figure than expected.

Rival groups of pro and anti-Milosevic demonstrators fought running

battles with wooden clubs and iron bars, as the two camps converged on

the city centre for mass rallies.

One man was shot in the head by a supporter of the ruling Socialist

Party (SPS) and badly injured.

It was the first violence after more than a month of street

protests by students and the Zajedno (Together) Opposition

coalition against alleged election fraud by ruling Socialists.

A fact-finding team of the pan-European organisation, the OSCE, had

concluded that the results of the November

17 elections had been modified to give the socialists an edge in

14 districts

Results of the local election results in which the opposition

Together coalition won 15 out of 18 towns and cities, including

Belgrade, were scrapped.

The fact-finding team had concluded that the local polls were

modified in 14 districts of Serbia's biggest cities to the detriment of

the opposition and in favour of Mr Milosevic's

Socialist Party.

Former Spanish prime minister Felipe Gonzalez headed the OSCE

mission.

He held several meetings with the opposition and Serbian

authorities, and said his impression that there had been an ""electoral

problem" had been confirmed.

It was alleged that the Serbian opposition

parties were victims of "a legal plot."

Mr Milosevic, making his first public appearance since the crisis

over the disputed municipal election results

, told supporters no one would be allowed to destabilise Serbia.

""A strong Serbia is not to the liking of many powers outside our

country," he said.

""That is why, together with the fifth column they have formed

here, they have tried to destabilise our country."

Diplomats said the relatively small turnout for Mr Milosevic had

encourage Opposition supporters to join what is expected to be a record

march.

""Milosevic has scored an own-goal," said one Western diplomat who

declined to be named.

""He only had one chance at his demonstration and he blew it.

""Now all his people have gone home and I don't think they'll come

back in a hurry."

""I reckon this will only give the Zajedno

supporters the shot of adrenalin they need to get back on the

streets."

State television's evening national news bulletin only showed

pictures of the pro-Milosevic demonstration as the participants drove

home on board hundreds of comandeered buses.

Many said they had been given the day off work in state-run

factories and ordered to come to Belgrade, and were completely unaware

of the Opposition

protests.

""Who are they?" inquired one elderly SPS supporter when she saw a

group of students marching through the city.

""I had no idea there was anybody unhappy with our president."

Zajedno leader Zoran Djindjic told supporters: ""Milosevic has

clearly turned full circle and has gone back to provoking disturbances.

""Belgrade was quiet until he brought his supporters here. The

minute they came, the shooting began."

Western states condemned Mr Milosevic's

decision to stage his rally at the same time and place as the

regular Zajedno rallies.

The United States said it held Mr Milosevic responsible for the

violent actions

of loyalist demonstrators.

""The US holds the Serbian Government and its President, Slobodan

Milosevic

, responsible for the violent actions

of the demonstrators," acting Secretary of State Strobe Talbott

said in a statement.

Mr Talbott said the top US diplomat in Belgrade, Richard Miles, had

met Serbian Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic to urge the Serbian

Government to avoid further violence.

""We have given a similar message to the Opposition," he said.

Mr Talbott placed the responsibility for the violent flareup on the

Government.

""Rather than making a goodwill effort

to resolve the political crisis caused by the annulment of

Oppostion victories in the November 17 elections, the Serbian

authorities have flagrantly and provocatively chosen to heighten

tensions by bringing thousands of people into Belgrade to confront the

peaceful demonstrations by the Opposition," he said.

France also blamed Mr Milosevic for provoking the clashes, while

Germany expressed grave concern at the lack of dialogue between the two

sides.

Reuter

CLUB-wielding Opposition supporters beat a supporter of the Socialist

Party of

Serbia in Belgrade during massive protests yesterday.

A MILOSEVIC supporter brandishes a pistol during clashes with

Opposition supporters.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1996 Nationwide News Pty Limited


176 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


August 18, 1999, Wednesday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION


KEY MILOSEVIC FOE SAYS HE'LL SKIP MAJOR PROTEST;
GENERAL WARNS THAT THE ARMY WILL INTERVENE IF THURSDAY RALLY IS VIOLENT


BYLINE: The Associated Press


SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A5


LENGTH: 330 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


 

Two days before a major anti-government rally in Belgrade, a key protest leader said he would not attend, and a top general warned the army would intervene in case of violence.

The surprise announcement Tuesday by opposition leader Vuk Draskovic was a blow to attempts to form a united front to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic. Draskovic has led the biggest protests against the president. 

The protest rally Thursday in Belgrade would be the first major gathering in the capital since weeks of anti-government protests in 1996-97. It is expected to be a test of the public's discontent with Milosevic, and its readiness to trust opposition leaders.

The economic and political crisis in Serbia, already deep after years of international isolation and wars, has intensified since the NATO bombing, which ended in June. Serbs increasingly blame Milosevic's policies for the worsening situation in the country.

Milosevic's government has toughened its position lately toward the growing opposition movement, and harsh oral attacks against opposition leaders have appeared daily in the state-run media.

Belgrade police Tuesday arrested and beat up an anti-government activist, Bogoljub Arsenijevic, from central Serbia. He went into hiding after leading thousands of rock-throwing followers in a raid on a government building in his native Valjevo.

Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic told the newspaper Glas on Tuesday that "the army has to stand between the divided people to prevent civil war."

"The army will not stand against people, but (against) all those telling various stories, those who want to come to power illegitimately," Pavkovic said.

Draskovic led protests in 1991 and afterward spent several days in jail. He was also one of the leaders of weeks anti-Milosevic demonstrations in 1996-97.

But he later moved closer to Milosevic and served as deputy premier in the Yugoslav government before being sacked during the NATO bombing.


LOAD-DATE: August 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: PHOTO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Photo - Activist Bogoljub Arsenijevic is arrested by police in Valjevo, Yugoslavia, on Tuesday. Arsenijevic had gone into hiding after leading a raid on a government building.

177 of 348 DOCUMENTS



BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


September 12, 2006 Tuesday


Montenegrin press review for Tuesday 12 September 06


LENGTH: 745 words


VIJESTI

Roundup of main news

The headline, "They were preparing to set Malesija on fire", covers half of the daily's front-page and refers to a report on yesterday's press conference organized by the Montenegrin police. The police officials discussed the recent arrest of a group of Albanians who are accused of preparing terrorist actions. According to the report, they also presented a number of seized rifles, anti-tank rocket launchers, mines and other explosive devices

Under the headline, "Milo is a bit tired", the daily carries news agency reports about Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic saying that he is considering plans to withdraw from political life. 

Another report analyses the election results and says that many unionists and some pro-independence voters have decided to support the Movement for Change, or PZP, while it appears that some of the unionist voters actually voted for the ruling coalition. The report adds that about 40,000 unionist voters abstained from voting. The paper carries a report on the OSCE monitoring mission saying that the elections were mostly democratic. However, the OSCE observers warn that the elections were marred by new restrictive regulations and certain vote-buying incidents, particularly those in the northern Montenegrin town of Berane.

Another report says that an Egyptian Navy delegation has arrived in Tivat, Montenegrin coastal town, and visited surplus Montenegrin Navy ships.

POBJEDA

Roundup of main news

The main front-page headline, "The people of Montenegro can be proud of such elections", introduces a report on the OSCE monitoring mission saying that the Montenegrin elections were in line with the Council of Europe and OSCE standards.

Another prominent headline, "Opposition says that the people failed", refers to a report on initial reactions to the election results. The report quotes political analyst Dusan Janjic as saying that the Socialist People's Party, or SNP, might not survive the most recent defeat and that its leader Predrag Bulatovic is finding it increasingly difficult to manage such an outmoded party. Anther political expert, Vladimir Goati, says that the success of the PZP is the greatest election surprise but that this party needs to set up a serious infrastructure as soon as possible.

The remaining prominent headline, "'Eagle's Flight' operation conducted right on time", refers to a report on the arrest of the group of Albanians accused of preparing terrorist attacks.

DAN

Roundup of main news

The largest front-page headline, "Djukanovic: I am leaving", refers to news agency reports on Prime Minister Djukanovic saying that he is growing tired of the political life.

Under the headline, "Bulatovic: America was offering me the post of leader", the daily carries a report on former Montenegrin President Momir Bulatovic presenting his new book in Kragujevac, city in Serbia. Bulatovic commented about recent political events and said that the USA had offered him to lead the anti-Milosevic opposition in 1996.

The daily also carries several reports on the election results and points out that the villagers of Vir near Niksic, town in central Montenegro, overwhelmingly voted for the ruling coalition, despite the fact that a depot explosion recently practically destroyed their village.

REPUBLIKA

Roundup of main news

Another report on the election results dominates the front page of the daily and says that this was a clear victory of the Democratic Party of Socialists - Social Democratic Party, or DPS-SDP, coalition. According to the report, the SNP is, following a decade of rivalry, no longer the main opponent of the ruling parties. While the PZP did not manage to recruit a significant number of the ruling coalition voters, the report adds, it managed to convince moderate unionists to support them, while the Serbian List took over the pro-union hardliners. The SNP now has only two options - to become a European party or to disappear, the report concludes.

Elsewhere, the daily quotes the DPS and SDP spokesmen as saying that their voters did not support the PZP and that this movement managed to recruit only former opposition supporters.

In another report, Ferhat Dinosa, chairman of the Democratic Union of Albanians, or DUA, says that the recent arrest of the group of Albanians in Malesija is not an action aimed against all the Albanians. The report adds that, according to rumours, Dinosa was one of the group's targets.

Source: Montenegrin press review in Serbian 12 Sep 06


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 2006


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

178 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Washington Post


December 11, 2000, Monday, Final Edition


U.S. Advice Guided Milosevic Opposition; Political Consultants Helped Yugoslav Opposition Topple Authoritarian Leader


Michael Dobbs , Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 2919 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


 

In a softly lit conference room, American pollster Doug Schoen flashed the results of an in-depth opinion poll of 840 Serbian voters onto an overhead projection screen, sketching a strategy for toppling Europe's last remaining communist-era ruler.

His message, delivered to leaders of Serbia's traditionally fractious opposition, was simple and powerful. Slobodan Milosevic--survivor of four lost wars, two major street uprisings, 78 days of NATO bombing and a decade of international sanctions--was "completely vulnerable" to a well-organized electoral challenge. The key, the poll results showed, was opposition unity.

Held in a luxury hotel in Budapest, the Hungarian capital, in October 1999, the closed-door briefing by Schoen, a Democrat, turned out to be a seminal event, pointing the way to the electoral revolution that brought down Milosevic a year later. It also marked the start of an extraordinary U.S. effort to unseat a foreign head of state, not through covert action of the kind the CIA once employed in such places as Iran and Guatemala, but by modern election campaign techniques. 

While the broad outlines of the $ 41 million U.S. democracy-building campaign in Serbia are public knowledge, interviews with dozens of key players, both here and in the United States, suggest it was much more extensive and sophisticated than previously reported.

In the 12 months following the strategy session, U.S.-funded consultants played a crucial role behind the scenes in virtually every facet of the anti-Milosevic drive, running tracking polls, training thousands of opposition activists and helping to organize a vitally important parallel vote count. U.S. taxpayers paid for 5,000 cans of spray paint used by student activists to scrawl anti-Milosevic graffiti on walls across Serbia, and 2.5 million stickers with the slogan "He's Finished," which became the revolution's catchphrase.

Regarded by many as Eastern Europe's last great democratic upheaval, Milosevic's overthrow may also go down in history as the first poll-driven, focus group-tested revolution. Behind the seeming spontaneity of the street uprising that forced Milosevic to respect the results of a hotly contested presidential election on Sept. 24 was a carefully researched strategy put together by Serbian democracy activists with the active assistance of Western advisers and pollsters.

In the long run, many people here say, Milosevic's overthrow was inevitable, if only because of the economic and military disasters that befell Serbia during his 13 years in power, first as head of Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic, and then as head of Yugoslavia itself. But there was nothing inevitable about the timing or the manner of his departure.

"Without American support, it would have been much more difficult," said Slobodan Homen, a student leader who traveled to Budapest and other European capitals dozens of times to meet with U.S. officials and private democracy consultants. "There would have been a revolution anyway, but the assistance helped us avoid bloodshed."

"The foreign support was critical," agreed Milan Stevanovic, who oversaw the marketing and message development campaign for the opposition coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia. "In the past, we did what we intuitively thought we should do. This was the first campaign where our strategy was based on real scientific research."

Had Yugoslavia been a totalitarian state like Iraq or North Korea, the strategy would have stood little chance. But while Milosevic ran a repressive police state, he was never a dictator in the style of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. His authority depended on a veil of popular legitimacy. It was this constitutional facade that gave Serbian opposition leaders, and their Western backers, an all-important opening.

A Unified Opposition

The fall of 1999 was a difficult time for the Serbian opposition. Although Milosevic had long been unpopular, he appeared to have had some success in tapping into the upsurge of patriotic feeling caused by the Kosovo war a few months before. The 59-year-old Yugoslav president was seeking to depict himself as the rebuilder of the country following NATO bombing raids. Attempts by some opposition parties to topple Milosevic through street protests were getting nowhere.

Milosevic's strongest political card was the disarray and ineffectiveness of his opponents. The opposition consisted of nearly two dozen political parties, some of whose leaders were barely on speaking terms with one another. While the opposition politicians recognized the need for unity in theory, in practice they were deeply divided, both on the tactics to use against Milosevic and the question of who should succeed him.

It was against this background that 20 opposition leaders accepted an invitation from the Washington-based National Democratic Institute (NDI) in October 1999 to a seminar at the Marriott Hotel in Budapest, overlooking the Danube River. The key item on the agenda: an opinion poll commissioned by the U.S. polling firm Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates.

The poll reported that Milosevic had a 70 percent unfavorable rating among Serbian voters. But it also showed that the big names in the opposition--men such as Zoran Djindjic and Vuk Draskovic--were burdened with negative poll ratings almost as high as Milosevic's.

Among the candidates best placed to challenge Milosevic, the poll suggested, was a moderate Serbian nationalist named Vojislav Kostunica, who had a favorable rating of 49 percent and an unfavorable rating of only 29 percent.

Schoen, who had provided polling advice to former Yugoslav prime minister Milan Panic during his unsuccessful 1992 campaign to depose Milosevic, drew several conclusions from these and other findings of the poll.

First, Serbian voters were receptive to simple anti-Milosevic messages focusing on the terrible economic situation. Second, they wanted change to come through the ballot box, not demonstrations. Finally, and most important, only a united opposition had a chance of deposing Milosevic. "If you take one word from this conference," Schoen told the delegates, "I urge it to be unity."

The unity message did not catch on immediately with Serbian opposition leaders. "They had seen Milosevic rise before," recalled Debra Alexander, who was in charge of the National Democratic Institute polling operation. "There was a sense they were going up against insuperable odds."

In the following months, however, the opposition politicians came to believe the polling evidence and shape a strategy for defeating Milosevic with the help of the Western consultants. Djindjic, leader of the largest, best-organized opposition party, agreed to set aside his presidential ambitions in favor of a less polarizing candidate and serve as coalition campaign manager.

Things moved into high gear in July, when Milosevic called elections. For the first time in Serbian political history, Western advertising techniques were used to test political messages. The messages were tested in a similar way to soft drinks or chewing gum, according to Srdan Bogosavljevic, head of the Strategic Marketing firm, which ran a series of focus groups on behalf of the opposition coalition and the Otpor student resistance movement with financial support from Western democracy groups.

"We approached the process with a brand to sell and a brand to beat," said Bogosavljevic, one of Serbia's best known pollsters. "The brand to sell was Kostunica. The brand to beat was Milosevic."

According to Stevanovic, the coalition marketing expert, every word of the opposition's one-minute and five-minute core political messages used by opposition spokesmen across the country was discussed with U.S. consultants and tested by opinion poll. Coalition candidates running for the Yugoslav parliament and tens of thousands of local government positions received extensive training on how to stay "on message," answer journalists' questions and rebut the arguments of Milosevic supporters.

Visa restrictions imposed by the Milosevic government made it impossible for the U.S. consultants to travel to Serbia, so they organized a series of "train the trainers" sessions in Hungary and Montenegro. The trainers then went back to Serbia to spread the word.

Kostunica's selection as the opposition presidential candidate in August was shaped, in large measure, by the opinion polls. "The polls showed that Kostunica could defeat Milosevic in the easiest possible way," recalled Dusan Mihajlovic, leader of the New Democracy party, one of 18 political parties that made up the coalition. Part of Kostunica's appeal, the polls showed, was that he was widely perceived as anti-American. Because he was an outspoken critic of the NATO bombing of Serbia, it was difficult for the Milosevic government to label him a Western stooge or a traitor to Serbian interests.

Kostunica was also the one opposition leader strongly opposed to accepting U.S. campaign assistance. "I was against it, never got any myself, and thought it was unnecessary," he said in an interview.

To many opposition activists, Kostunica's denials ring a little hollow. While it is true that his own party, the Democratic Party of Serbia, rejected anything that smacked of U.S. aid, his presidential campaign benefited enormously from the advice and financial support the opposition coalition received from abroad, and particularly from the United States.

Lessons in Resistance

The U.S. democracy-building effort in Serbia was a curious mixture of secrecy and openness. In principle, it was an overt operation, funded by congressional appropriations of around $ 10 million for fiscal 1999 and $ 31 million for 2000.

Some Americans involved in the anti-Milosevic effort said they were aware of CIA activity at the fringes of the campaign, but had trouble finding out what the agency was up to. Whatever it was, they concluded it was not particularly effective. The lead role was taken by the State Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development, the government's foreign assistance agency, which channeled the funds through commercial contractors and nonprofit groups such as NDI and its Republican counterpart, the International Republican Institute (IRI).

While NDI worked closely with Serbian opposition parties, IRI focused its attention on Otpor, which served as the revolution's ideological and organizational backbone. In March, IRI paid for two dozen Otpor leaders to attend a seminar on nonviolent resistance at the Hilton Hotel in Budapest, a few hundreds yards along the Danube from the NDI-favored Marriott.

During the seminar, the Serbian students received training in such matters as how to organize a strike, how to communicate with symbols, how to overcome fear and how to undermine the authority of a dictatorial regime. The principal lecturer was retired U.S. Army Col. Robert Helvey, who has made a study of nonviolent resistance methods around the world, including those used in modern-day Burma and the civil rights struggle in the American South.

"What was most amazing to us was to discover that what we were trying to do spontaneously in Serbia was supported by a whole nonviolent system that we knew nothing about," said Srdja Popovic, a former biology student. "This was the first time we thought about this in a systematic, scientific way. We said to ourselves, 'We will go back and apply this.' "

Helvey, who served two tours in Vietnam, introduced the Otpor activists to the ideas of American theoretician Gene Sharpe, whom he describes as "the Clausewitz of the nonviolence movement," referring to the renowned Prussian military strategist. Six months later, Popovic can recite Helvey's lectures almost word for word, beginning with the dictum, "Removing the authority of the ruler is the most important element in nonviolent struggle."

"Those Serbs really impressed me," Helvey said in an interview from his West Virginia home. "They were very bright, very committed."

Back in Serbia, Otpor activists set about undermining Milosevic's authority by all means available. Rather than simply daubing slogans on walls, they used a wide range of sophisticated public relations techniques, including polling, leafleting and paid advertising. "The poll results were very important," recalled Ivo Andric, a marketing student at Belgrade University. "At every moment, we knew what to say to the people."

The poll results pointed to a paradox that went to the heart of Milosevic's grip on power. On one hand, the Yugoslav president was detested by 70 percent of the electorate. On the other, a majority of Serbs believed he would continue to remain in power, even after an election. To topple Milosevic, opposition leaders first had to convince their fellow Serbs that he could be overthrown.

At a brainstorming session last July, Otpor activist Srdjan Milivojevic murmured the words "Gotov je," or "He's finished."

"We realized immediately that it summed up our entire campaign," said Dejan Randjic, who ran the Otpor marketing operation. "It was very simple, very powerful. It focused on Milosevic, but did not even mention him by name."

Over the next three months, millions of "Gotov je" stickers were printed on 80 tons of imported adhesive paper--paid for by USAID and delivered by the Washington-based Ronco Consulting Corp.--and plastered all over Serbia on walls, inside elevators and across Milosevic's campaign posters. Printed in black and white and accompanied by Otpor's clenched-fist emblem, they became the symbol of the revolution.

A Fair Vote Count

Had Yugoslav border officials been paying attention last summer, they would have observed an extraordinary increase in the number of Serbian students visiting a revered Serbian shrine in southern Hungary. "Making a pilgrimage to Saint Andrija" became the favorite excuse for opposition activists en route to another U.S.-funded program, this one in the Hungarian town of Szeged, just 10 minutes' drive from the Serbian border.

Its purpose was to train election observers. "We set up mock polling stations with ballot boxes and went through the balloting process in detail with them," recalled John Anelli of the Republican institute, describing what became a key component in Milosevic's downfall. "We trained about 400 election monitors who went back to Serbia and trained another 15,000 monitors."

Without a massive monitoring operation, and an equally massive parallel vote count organized by the Serbian Center for Free Elections and Democracy, this fall's effort to unseat Milosevic would almost certainly have failed. Opposition parties suspected him of stealing previous elections, most notably in 1997, but were unable to offer conclusive proof. This time, they made sure they had the means to detect election fraud.

Drawing on their experience of elections in such places as Indonesia and Mozambique, IRI consultants simulated vote-counting scams and ballot-stuffing techniques. "They trained us to spot fraud and react quickly," said Goran Rapoti, an opposition election monitor from the town of Backa Palanka, who attended the seminar. "It was really useful."

The United States paid for the training in Szeged and the second level of training back in Serbia. By Election Day, the opposition parties were able to place at least two trained monitors at every polling station in the country. Each monitor received about $ 5 in Western-provided money, a significant sum in a country where the average monthly wage is less than $ 30.

"Without the monitors, Milosevic's people would have stolen the elections again," said Alexander Trkulja, the coalition campaign manager in Backa Palanka. "They are masters in stealing elections."

An iron rule for both the coalition and Otpor was never to talk about Western financial or logistical support. To have done so would have played straight into the hands of the Milosevic propaganda machine, which routinely depicted opposition leaders as "traitors" or "NATO lackeys."

"It was dangerous to be connected publicly with the American authorities," said Randjic, the Otpor activist, recalling a 12-hour police interrogation in which he was grilled about his "Washington controllers."

Even today, nearly two months after Milosevic's fall, the topic is sensitive. Although the U.S. effort was clearly aimed at Milosevic, the Clinton administration prefers to depict it as a neutral democracy-building operation. "Our job was to level the playing field," said Paul Rowland, head of the Democratic institute's Serbia program. "We worked with parties that wanted to make Serbia a genuine democracy."

Serbian opposition leaders, meanwhile, view the U.S. support as atonement for past mistakes. They note that for many years U.S. officials treated the Yugoslav president as the linchpin of America's Balkan diplomacy, an indispensable interlocutor for Bosnia peace negotiator Richard C. Holbrooke and other high-level emissaries. Far from undermining Milosevic's grip on power, U.S. policy had actually served to strengthen it, they contend.

"In the past, we had the impression that the West was supporting Milosevic," said Homen, a 28-year-old lawyer who served as Otpor's intermediary with Western diplomats and aid organizations. "This was the first time that we felt that Western governments were actually trying to get rid of Milosevic."


LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Map, The Washington Post
