179 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


July 1, 1992


BELGRADE TRIES TO BEAT SANCTIONS;
Anti-Milosevic campaign runs out of steam


BYLINE: YIGAL CHAZAN IN BELGRADE


SECTION: FOREIGN; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 619 words


 

THE Yugoslav government will today introduce a package of economic measures to combat spiralling inflation caused by the imposition of United Nations sanctions, which are rapidly bringing the country to its knees.

But leading Belgrade economists hold out little hope for the strategy, claiming the federation's industrial and commercial decline is virtually irreversible.

The main plank of the government's anti-inflation plan, in the face of price rises which exceeded 100 per cent last month, is the devaluation of the Yugoslav dinar. The cost of many basic foodstuffs will be frozen and salaries adjusted so that the highest will be only three times greater than the minimum wage. 

The influential Belgrade weekly, Ekonomska Politika, poured scorn on the measures, saying they will result in Yugoslavia becoming a command economy by the end of the year.

The magazine concluded the package would have little chance of succeeding if the UN sanctions are not lifted within weeks. It predicts that a sustained trade blockade will trigger mass unemployment, with nearly one million people likely to lose their jobs, and warns that "the social collapse will then be total".

Serbia's opposition parties have used the deteriorating economy as a main theme in their campaign to force the resignation of the republic's president, Slobodan Milosevic. But their tactic has so far had minimal impact since the majority of the population perceives UN sanctions as directed at them rather than their leader.

State-controlled television has reinforced this impression, highlighting the security council's vacillation about approving airlifts of humanitarian aid to Serbian parts of Bosnia as evidence of alleged UN hostility towards the Serb nation.

By shifting attention to what they call the "inhumanity" of sanctions, the Belgrade authorities have been able to take the sting out of an anti-government demonstration in the Serbian capital, now into its fourth day.

Some 100,000 people turned out on the opening day of the rally, but the crowds have now dwindled to no more than 3,000 diehards. The poor attendances have bitterly disappointed the protest organisers, the Serbian Democratic Movement (Depos) - an alliance of opposition parties spearheading calls for the resignation of Mr Milosevic and the formation of a government of "national salvation".

With the apparent failure of the demonstration, it is unlikely that the president regards Depos as a serious threat to his leadership. He has even been emboldened to offer to hold presidential elections, knowing his success would be virtually secured by his monopoly of the media.

Depos is unimpressed by the gesture. But while its campaign has suffered an early blow, it is determined to continue calling for Mr Milosevic to stand down. "Our expectations have not been met, but the door has nevertheless been opened a crack," the alliance's spokesman, Vladeta Jankovic, said.

Political analysts in Belgrade believe the odds are heavily stacked against Depos achieving its aims peacefully. They warn that radical members may lose patience with the "softly softly" approach.

The presence of militant ultra-nationalists and monarchists at the Belgrade rally suggests there is no shortage of people within Depos who are prepared to resort to violence. Depos leaders are aware of the militant factions within their ranks and take care to avoid inciting the hotheads. But the organisation may be tempted to become more aggressive if it fails to muster more support - a move which many believe would increase the prospect of civil war in Serbia.

Leader comment, letters, page 18; Precision and indecision, page 19


LOAD-DATE: May 7, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Guardian Newspapers Limited


180 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Guardian Weekly


April 5, 2000


Search for a safe harbour


BYLINE: Jonathan Steele


SECTION: COMMENT[ANALYSIS] Pg. 14


LENGTH: 770 words


HIGHLIGHT: Jonathan Steele One year on and Kosovo still suffers from the tragic consequences of unresolved conflict


Father Sava Janjic is one of the bravest Serbs left in Kosovo. A soft-spoken figure whose scholarly appearance masks passionately held views, his rare quality is his willingness to acknowledge the crimes done to Albanians by the Milosevic regime.

Yet as he sits in the refectory of the monastery of Gracanica, he has little to feel cheerful about. A leader of the Serbian National Council in Kosovo, he became the voice of Serbs who felt they should cooperate with the United Nations administration when it arrived in June.

Now he feels let down and under pressure. K-For, the international peace-keeping force, is failing to protect Serbs enough to give them freedom of movement beyond their prison enclaves, let alone create conditions for those who left Kosovo to want to come home. In the northern city of Mitrovice pro-Milosevic Serbs boast that their success in keeping Albanians out shows that a tough line is the only solution. Father Sava senses Slobodan Milosevic's support in Kosovo is growing and that the hardliners who denounce K-For as nothing more than an occupation force are gaining strength. The trouble in Mitrovice is not just a battle between Serbs and Albanians but a struggle for the allegiance of Kosovo's Serbs.

Father Sava regrets the lack of support that he and his boss, Bishop Artemije, Kosovo's senior Orthodox clergyman, have had from opposition politicians in Belgrade. At a recent meeting the two men asked the anti-Milosevic politicians to sign a joint declaration that would stress two points: that it was not an act of treason for Kosovo's Serbs to work with the UN, and that "injustices" had been inflicted on Albanians. This was too much for Belgrade's opposition.

Had it been signed, the statement would have had far-ranging benefits. The clerics are convinced that unless more Serbs acknowledge that the atrocities done in their name are the prime cause of the hatred that bedevils Kosovo today, tolerance will take a long time to grow.

It is easy to see that Serbs cannot readily accept that their side bears the greater guilt. What is more depressing is the way this escape from the facts is beginning to creep into Western discourse on Kosovo.

Allan Little's recent BBC2 programme, Moral Combat, was only the latest example of the tendency to say a plague on both houses. The notion of "balance" made little distinction between a state-machine whose security forces use arson, artillery, and cold-blooded murder on a mass scale against people still in their homes, and the revenge-seeking of bereaved people returning to destroyed villages and burning the houses of their Serbian neighbours.

Now we have moved to a second post-war stage, where crime in Kosovo is random, opportunistic, urban and largely carried out by professional criminals who want to make money. It is the inevitable consequence of a law and order vacuum, for which the international community is mainly to blame for failing to provide the police it promised. Take away the police from London or Berlin, and see how quickly the crime rate would soar.

This is not to deny that the current violence against Serbs in Kosovo takes place in a vindictive atmosphere where most Albanians think ethnically. Far from restraining them, parents encourage their children to stone Serbian buses when they pass through Albanian areas under K-For escort. The Albanian press does not report fairly on what is being done to Serbs.

This is where Father Sava comes back in. Albanians would start to differentiate and not lump all Serbs together as evil-doers if they felt more Serbs were able to accept the truth about what happened in 1998 and 1999. Albanians would also relax if more Serbs did not go on behaving as though the Serbs can still win the war and get K-For to withdraw.

The ambiguity of UN resolution 1244, which left Kosovo's final status obscure, has become a liability. It gives false encouragement to Serbs and real anxiety to Albanians. What is needed is a forthright statement by the Western powers that Kosovo will never return to Serbian rule.

For Albanians such a declaration would provide a reason to stop seeing every Serb in Kosovo as a potential fifth columnist. In exchange for such an international commitment, the leaders of the various Kosovo Albanian parties should be urged to agree to a formal statement that the territory will remain legally part of Yugoslavia, though under international protection, for three or five more years. In that period Milosevic might finally leave power or Yugoslavia might dissolve -- leaving Kosovo independent by default.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Illustration, no caption


Copyright 2000 Guardian Publication, Ltd.


181 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 31, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final


U.S. Urging Milosevic Opponents to Unite for September Vote


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 3; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 855 words


DATELINE: PRAGUE, July 30


American officials are putting strong pressure on the president of Montenegro and the leader of Serbia's largest opposition party to take part in Yugoslav elections called in September, according to Yugoslav politicians and Western officials.

The American officials argue that a united opposition in Serbia, together with voters in Montenegro, Serbia's increasingly independent partner in the Yugoslav federation, would have a good chance of defeating President Slobodan Milosevic in the presidential and parliamentary elections he has called for Sept. 24. 

Mr. Milosevic and his allies have begun a new wave of repression and altered the Constitution to create direct elections for his position -- which he otherwise would have to relinquish next July.

The only time the opposition triumphed in past elections was when it united for municipal elections in 1996, winning in Belgrade and dozens of other cities. Mr. Milosevic initially refused to recognize the victories, setting off three months of protests.

If the coming elections are manipulated or stolen, as expected, the Americans argue, the opposition will have another rallying cry for anti-Milosevic demonstrations. But a boycott provides no chance to beat Mr. Milosevic, they say, and a divided opposition has almost no chance to win.

In late 1997, Milo Djukanovic broke with Mr. Milosevic and won the presidency in Montenegro. He has allied himself with the West, but is refusing to take part in the September elections, arguing that the constitutional changes were made without consultation with Montenegro and aim to reduce its influence.

Mr. Djukanovic's officials say that to take part in the elections would only ratify Mr. Milosevic's constitutional coup and legitimize the likely outcome -- a Milosevic victory, fair or otherwise.

The changes to the Constitution have also removed previous requirements for a minimum turnout of half the eligible voters -- apparently to blunt any opposition boycott or the effect of widespread apathy among a generally depressed electorate.

Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the largest single opposition party in Serbia, the Serbian Renewal Movement, says he will not take part in federal elections if Mr. Djukanovic will not. Mr. Draskovic also argues that the elections cannot be free and fair -- with attacks on opposition politicians, the judiciary, student protesters and government pressure on independent news media.

The rest of Serbia's political opposition, largely grouped into the Alliance for Change, says it will take part, and is urging Mr. Draskovic to follow suit.

Mr. Draskovic is almost sure to take part in the local elections, where his party has many seats and privileges to defend. A boycott of the elections would cause a revolt in his own party, Draskovic aides admit.

A likely opposition presidential candidate is Vojislav Kostunica, a moderate nationalist who is considered free of corruption or of cooptation by the West -- distinguishing him from Mr. Draskovic or his great rival, Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party.

In May, the government took over the Belgrade television station Mr. Draskovic controlled, Studio B, and prevented the independent radio station, B2-92, and two others from broadcasting in Belgrade.

The government has been regularly suing the independent news media under a tough information law passed in October 1998 and has also restricted newsprint to major independent publications, particularly Blic, a popular tabloid whose circulation has been reduced by nearly half.

And last week, in a trial that produced outrage domestically and internationally, a Serbian journalist, Miroslav Filipovic, was convicted by a military court in Nis on charges of espionage and sentenced to seven years in prison.

Mr. Filipovic, who works for the independent Belgrade publication Danas, Agence France-Presse and a London-based Internet site called the Institute for War and Peace Reporting, wrote a number of articles that annoyed the government, including one that cited an internal Yugoslav Army report on unhappiness and remorse over the brutal tactics used against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo -- tactics that caused Mr. Milosevic and four top aides to be indicted by an international tribunal on charges of war crimes.

Unusually for a suspected spy, Mr. Filipovic signed his name to his articles, and no evidence was presented to indicate that he had secret contacts with any foreigner or intelligence agency.

The government has also accused other independent journalists in Serbia of being spies and working on the orders of the Central Intelligence Agency or the same NATO countries that bombed Serbia last year, but in no case has provided evidence.

While those forms of pressure are hardly new in Serbia, they are increasing and indicate pre-election nervousness in the Milosevic camp.

"Milosevic is very shaky and obviously very concerned about these elections," said Ognjen Pribicevic, a Draskovic aide. "His worry is not just because of the opposition, but because the situation in Serbia is disintegrating in every sense, economically and politically."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Slobodan Milosevic's constitutional coup could extend his term. (Associated Press)      


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


182 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Observer


September 17, 2000


Milosevic fights dirty to survive: The opposition has its best chance in a decade to oust the Yugoslav hard man


BYLINE: Gillian Sandford Belgrade and agencies


SECTION: Observer News Pages, Pg. 23


LENGTH: 695 words


 

PRESIDENT Slobodan Milosevic is fighting for his political survival as he enters the last week of a vicious presidential campaign tainted by intimidation and haunted by fears of electoral fraud.

Faced for the first time in a decade by an opposition united behind a single candidate, Milosevic is trailing in every opinion poll. But observers fear his defeat, which would bring a political sea change in Yugoslavia, would be followed by repression and bloodshed.

Tensions rose on Friday, when a gang of men in civilian clothes stormed the Belgrade offices of the get-out-and-vote campaign. 

They entered the office of the group, known as Vreme Je (It Is Time), locking the youngsters working there in a room and taking computers, documents and other equipment.

The Vreme Je workers were offloaded from a van at Belgrade police station, said opposition politician Gaso Knezavic.

Last weekend police moved on the headquarters of the student-based resistance group Otpor, roughing-up a small group of youngsters.

The regime refuses to allow observers from allegedly hostile countries and organisations to monitor the elections. Opposition activists in Serbia have been taken to police stations for 'informative talks'.

Last week the regime campaign switched into high gear. Milosevic made two rare personal appearances. Last Tuesday he opened a new hydro-electric dam and on Friday the Zastava car plant in Kragujevac. His speech was plastered across the front of the state newspaper, Politika, and dominated state television news, which played on the regime's campaign theme: reconstruction. 'This generation really has something to leave to the generation to come - a 10-year-old resistance to violence, strongly expressed national solidarity and courageous ability to cope in difficult times,' he said.

Veselin Simonevic, editor of the popular non-government newspaper Blic , says this time it won't wash. 'In the short and long term, Milosevic is a loser. He is finished.'

Last summer, when Milosevic changed the constitution and made the position of president directly electable, it seemed a brilliant ruse, enabling him to hold power for a further two terms. He believed egocentric opposition leaders would continue wars of vanity 'in this he miscalculated', says Simonevic.

According to opinion polls, the politician most people would vote for as a presidential candidate was the leader of one of the smaller parties, Dr Vojislav Kostunica.

His candidacy has turned the presidential poll into a serious race for high stakes.

In two weeks Kostunica has criss-crossed the country, drumming up support from eastern border towns to the west, and even made a dangerous trip to Kosovo, when the Nato-led protection force had to intervene with riot squads to separate warring pro and anti-Milosevic Serbs.

Kostunica aims to mobilise disillusioned voters. He offers what many say they seek: 'changes' and 'a normal life'. Analysts say if Milosevic were defeated 'it would destroy the decade-long myth of invincibility'.

'Milosevic did not count on Kostunica,' says Simonevic. 'He counted that the leaders of the opposition parties, who always struggle between themselves, will do so again and that he would win.

'Many citizens are not for Milosevic and have not been for a long time,' he says, but explains that the opposition split the anti-Milosevic vote. This time this is not happening. 'This is why Kostunica has a real chance.'

Every opinion poll published shows Kostunica ahead of Milosevic. The least optimistic showed Milosevic with 26 per cent and Kostunica with 29 per cent. But other polls have shown the opposition contender steaming ahead. This would force a second round of voting - between Milosevic and Kostunica.

Former Socialist Party member Milovan Drecun, who recently formed his own opposition party, asserts there will be voting fraud.

'Milosevic wants to win the poll with 2.5 million votes in the first round,' says Drecun. No second round is planned.'

LINKS

www.spo.org.yu/index-en.htm For Serbian Renewal movement www.sps.org.yu/index-ne.htm for Socialist Party of Serbia

The Washington Post


January 16, 1997, Thursday, Final Edition


Past, Present and Future at Odds As Serbs Try to Read Milosevic


Jonathan C. Randal, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A25


LENGTH: 1019 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Jan. 15


 

Despite his most disastrous two months in a decade-long reign, Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic still casts such a long shadow that his political opponents cannot quite believe they are on the verge of their first big success.

Eight weeks after Milosevic's courts overturned opposition electoral victories in 14 Serbian cities and towns -- and one day after government electoral commissions restored those victories in Belgrade and another key city -- Serbs are still trying to sort out perceived skulduggery by Milosevic, his Socialist Party and its partners in Serbia's ruling coalition.

Conspiracy is so ingrained in Serbia's political heritage that the leaders of the opposition coalition known as Together have voiced suspicions that Milosevic, long the master manipulator, may yet deprive them of their victories despite serious, if ambiguous, signs that he is giving in.

Even as they call for Milosevic's resignation at daily demonstrations, opposition leaders say they do not really believe that gaining power in all the disputed cities and towns would force him from office. And many Serbs refuse to count Milosevic out in future elections despite the creaking and groaning of what long appeared to be a perfectly oiled political machine. 

"He's still a stemwinding orator, a clever demagogue," a foreign observer said, "even if right now his reputation as the great communicator has suffered for having failed to communicate in the past two months."

Remarked a longtime Milosevic associate: "Back in 1990, Milosevic was God in the eyes of the Serbian Academy of Sciences, the Orthodox Church, the army, the police, indeed 90 percent of Serbia's population. Now he's just president of Serbia."

Given the impenetrably confusing developments of the past 24 hours, it is easy to understand why both sides in the crisis are casting about for signs of what is to come. For example:

Alarm bells began ringing soon after the electoral reversal in Belgrade, with a reported threat by Branislav Ivkovic, the city's sacked Socialist Party boss, to challenge the decision.

In fact, no official complaint questioning that decision was filed today, and the deadline for appeals was to have expired at noon Thursday. Or so it was initially thought -- until the electoral commission announced late today that its official letters of notification to politicians affected by Tuesday's ruling would not be delivered until Thursday morning, thus delaying the 48-hour challenge period.

Informed sources said the delay was caused by a frantic, time-consuming but eventually successful search for an ironclad judicial precedent allowing an administrative body such as the electoral commission to overrule a court decision.

Even before this latest twist, leery Serbs seized on the Belgrade electoral commission's ruling that 10 of the city's 110 council seats remained in doubt as proof that even if Milosevic could not deny Together its 60-seat council majority, he was determined to delay the winners from taking up their duties.

Further anxiety was caused when Belgrade University's governing council -- made up of faculty, university officials and government-appointed representatives -- voted in a secret ballot to reject student demands that the university's rector be replaced.

Early in the seven-hour council session, a majority of its members had voted to accept a catalogue of demands from the university's students, who have formed the backbone of the daily anti-Milosevic demonstrations. Among the demands, which two government deputy prime ministers had promised would be honored, was the removal of the rector, Dragutin Veliskovic. But another vote was held, and the students' friends on the council persuaded only 25 of its 76 members to vote for Veliskovic's ouster.

The rector asserted that the first vote was on whether to consider his case, not to approve his dismissal. Student leader Cedomir Andic remarked, "We are confused, and they [the council] are hypocritical."

In Novi Belgrade, across the Danube River from the old city, council seats in eight boroughs were awarded to outgoing Socialists despite a finding by observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe that the opposition had won them.

Opposition representatives were reduced to protesting outside the premises where the Socialists assumed office. Nonetheless, Vuk Draskovic, one of Together's three co-leaders, told followers at a downtown demonstration that they were "closer than ever to having our victory recognized."

A court deciding who should govern the central town of Smederevska Palanka ruled in favor of the Socialists, the Associated Press reported. The court recognized the Socialists' victory in a runoff election that the opposition had boycotted after insisting that the original results that gave control of the town be respected.

All but overlooked in the recent turmoil were purges underway in Socialist Party ranks as Milosevic seeks to dilute responsibility for mishandling the crisis. But no matter how many party stalwarts are sacrificed, diplomats and analysts insist, Milosevic stands to lose face in Serbia's macho politics if Together assumes power in Belgrade and wins back the other disputed municipalities.

Dismayed Milosevic supporters are worried enough to talk openly of what one termed "saving Milosevic from himself," and friend and foe alike have expressed amazement at his vacillation.

Immediately after the disputed elections, which were held Nov. 17, Milosevic initially signaled his willingness to accept Together's victories. He said at the time that multi-party politics involves the risk of losing elections and wrote the lost municipalities off as headaches for an opposition movement that he likened to a "jumbo jet without a pilot."

Within days, however, Serbian courts annulled voting results in the 14 localities the opposition had won, citing irregularities. The daily anti-Milosevic demonstrations ensued, and the president has been virtually silent ever since, making just a handful of public appearances.


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, afp, Uncertainty in Serbia: Riot police confront demonstrators in Belgrade before an opposition rally. One day after Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic made a major concession to his political opponents, opposition leaders remained cautious about how the republic's crisis would evolve. Above the crowd at the latest of daily anti-Milosevic rallies in Belgrade, a man flashes the three-fingered Serb salute.


Copyright 1997 The Washington Post


184 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


May 1, 1999 Saturday  
Late Edition


Loose cannon


BYLINE: Geoff Kitney


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; News Review; Pg. 39


LENGTH: 1166 words


Vuk Draskovic is an erratic political animal. His challenge to Slobodan Milosevic was the latest episode in a strange career, writes Geoff Kitney.

IF his face gives the appearance of having been smashed repeatedly into a brick wall this is because it once was, on the orders of the man against whom he has just seriously reoffended. Having in the past been savagely tortured by Slobodan Milosevic's special police, Vuk Draskovic will be understandably nervous about what he faces this time for his rebelliousness.

So is the man who has just been sacked by Europe's most feared political tyrant for what were described by one hard-line member of the government as "treasonable" offences brave or crazy? A bit of both, say those who know him and have watched his erratic and self-destructive course through the minefield of Belgrade politics.

And what does his latest, reckless political adventure say about what is happening at the top of Serbian politics as Milosevic leads his nation towards a sixth week of war and ever deepening misery. 

NATO leaders, desperate to find a way of forcing Milosevic's capitulation and an end to the humanitarian disaster that has followed their attempt to bomb him into submission, saw hope in Draskovic's conciliatory public statements.

Until he was sacked, they had thought he might be acting as a message carrier from Milosevic, putting out feelers for dialogue.

When Milosevic killed this hope by dumping Draskovic from his Cabinet they said it showed cracks were showing in the Serb leadership, and that Draskovic's dissent was the beginning of a challenge to Milosevic's iron grip.

But if NATO is waiting to see a dissent movement form around Draskovic and for this to speed the end of the war, it is making yet another misjudgment.

Without internal pressure there is no reason for Milosevic to negotiate. The ball is in NATO's court and if it, too, is not prepared to compromise, its only option is the military one. And unless it is prepared to mount a ground-force invasion, it has no alternative but to continue the bombing. That means a long, slow, grinding military campaign that can do little to stop the persecution, execution and expulsion of the ethnic Albanians the NATO military action was intended to protect.

The spotlight that fell this week on Draskovic exposed the opposite of what NATO thought it saw: it revealed just how tragically threadbare are the opposition forces to Milosevic in Serbia.

"The disastrous thing . . . is that Vuk Draskovic is probably the best alternative leader available. He is half-mad, untrustworthy, has no consistent set of beliefs or objectives and is probably corrupt," said someone who once worked with him. "I don't believe there is any prospect of Vuk being able to rally the people to challenge Milosevic. He might have been able to do that a few years ago but he betrayed us and our hopes for democracy."

In 1996, as leader of the largest opposition party - the Serbian Renewal Party - Draskovic and other opposition figures formed the Zajedno (Together) anti-Milosevic coalition, which won sweeping victories in local government elections.

Milosevic tried to annul the results, claiming they had been rigged. For more than 80 days Belgraders staged protest marches and rallies in the city centre. Crowds of 100,000 and more turned out, with Draskovic in the lead and his followers chanting "Vuk, Vuk, Vuk". It was a heady chant - Vuk means wolf in Serbo-Croatian.

But at one of these rallies, one of Draskovic's supporters saw something that dismayed her and convinced her that he was a Vuk in someone else's clothing.

The students had organised a rally at which they did not want to have any politicians speak. When Draskovic and his wife, Danicsa, were told this Danicsa shouted abuse, and their bodyguards roughly shoved students aside so that Draskovic could speak.

Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Party had a platform committed to free enterprise, Westminster-style democracy, restoration of community values and to taking Yugoslavia into the European mainstream, including aiming for membership of the European Union.

Draskovic strongly opposed the militaristic nationalism of Milosevic, which landed him and Danicsa in jail in 1993 at the height of the war in Bosnia.

Both were tortured, and Danicsa was forced to watch as Vuk had his face repeatedly smashed into the stone wall of his cell. They were freed after they went on a hunger strike and Milosevic feared they might become opposition martyrs.

The commitment of the Serbian Renewal Party to its democratic platform had its limitations. When the party took control of the Studio B television station in Belgrade, Draskovic fired all staff who were not party supporters. Nevertheless, Studio B did support the democracy movement and became an alternative to the propaganda-filled Serbian state media.

Draskovic fell out with Zoran Djindjic and Vesna Pesic, the two other most influential pro-demo- cracy politicians, and the coalition fell apart. This let Milosevic play his opponents off against each other and left pro-democracy supporters increasingly disillusioned.

In presidential elections in 1997, the opposition squabbled over who should oppose Milosevic. Draskovic insisted on running, splitting the opposition vote and allowing Milosevic to win comfortably.

As Milosevic reasserted his political dominance, the chain-smoking, big-drinking Draskovic faded from prominence for a while, pursuing his other career as a writer.

Draskovic publicly backed Milosevic's hard line against the ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo, further disillusioning his former supporters. Then this January, as NATO intensified its threats to bomb Serbia if Milosevic did not withdraw his forces from Kosovo and allow it autonomy, Draskovic accepted an offer to join the Government.

He was appointed Deputy Prime Minister, allowing Milosevic to tell the world that all Serbs were united behind him on Kosovo and to use Draskovic's links with the West to give the impression of being willing to maintain a dialogue.

The politician who had been the great hope of Yugoslav democrats did not seem to find it too uncomfortable sitting at the same Cabinet table as the brutal dictator who had ordered his torture six years earlier, and his former mortal political enemy, the ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj.

Perhaps Draskovic's decision this week to warn that Serbia could not win the war with NATO, to accuse the state media of lying and to suggest that the leadership would have to accept an armed international peacekeeping force in Kosovo was an attempt to rescue some credibility. Perhaps he was trying to position himself for possible opportunities should Milosevic lead his country to complete collapse.

Given that it is now clear he was speaking without Milosevic's authority and that there is no evidence of any significant internal dissent, there seems no other logical explanation for saying things that virtually guaranteed he would be dismissed and

placed at real physical risk.


LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: ILLUS: Wolf man . . . the Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister, Vuk Draskovic, speaking to journalists in Belgrade on Tuesday, a day before he was dismissed.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

185 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


March 24, 2001


Cauldron of the Balkans will be key test for EU


BYLINE: By PAUL GILLESPIE


SECTION: CITY EDITION; WORLD NEWS; WORLD VIEW; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 993 words


"I am afraid that the tension between the two ethnic groups will increase. Every time one side acts, the other reacts".

This observation by the mayor of Tetovo yesterday captures exactly why the escalation of violence this week in that region of Macedonia is so worrying.

Its use by the National Liberation Army (a branch of the Kosovo Liberation Army) was designed to provoke such a reaction. Such a polarisation could destroy Macedonia's sensitive balance between Albanians - about one-third of the two million population - and the majority Slavs. Since gaining independence from Yugoslavia a coalition of parties representing both groups has made substantial progress in developing the country and reversing discrimination against the Albanian minority. 

Violence tests the integrity of that fragile relationship by exposing partisan actions and reactions. Thus the moderate Albanian parties have been complaining they have not been consulted about the government's military response. Every casualty provokes a debate. It is precisely this polarisation that turns to the advantage of the N/KLA, which up to now has been rebuffed by most Albanian parties and voters.

Its support of a greater Albania is regarded by informed observers as quite unrealistic, not least because few Kosovan or Macedonian Albanians want to unite with Albania proper, a much less developed country. But its plan for an independent Kosovo, to include Macedonian Albanians, remains much more active, despite its isolation politically in Kosovo and the greater difficulty in putting the plan forward following the anti-Milosevic revolution in Yugoslavia.

That has led European governments to re-emphasise support for the principle of territorial integrity for Yugoslavia/Kosovo and for Macedonia. But the legacy of the Kosovo war hangs over this latest Balkan crisis in Macedonia. The KLA was created, after all, by the NATO coalition that ran the war. There remain disagreements between the US government - more tolerant of independence for Kosovo - and the Europeans, who reject it.

The Bush administration has not clarified its policy on the matter; it is unwilling to commit extra troops - and probably wants to reduce it - or to endanger the existing US complement in Kfor by policing the boundary zone between Kosovo and Macedonia more robustly.

As a result, movement of fighters has been made easier. So has the drug smuggling and human trafficking for which the area has become notorious. Such interests have more to gain from conflict than relative peace.

One way or another it falls to the European Union to manage this crisis politically. Its message to the Macedonian government and Kosovan leaders in recent days has been that politics must accompany military responses to the KLA provocations. Hence the initiatives to include the moderate Albanian parties in Macedonia's national security committee and EU pressure to open a political dialogue capable of delivering reforms for the Albanian minority.

In Kosovo this week an EU delegation made it clear to political leaders that continued development aid depends on renouncing violence and deepening political dialogue. As the Commissioner for External Relations, Chris Patten, put it: "Violence in Macedonia will wreck any effort to rebuild the economy in Kosovo."

The same message came from the EU summit it Stockholm yesterday, where the Macedonian President, Mr Boris Trajkowski, met its leaders. The tone was set earlier in the week by the German Chancellor, Mr Gerhard Shroder, who said the Macedonian government would have to be more careful with Albanian rights. The German weekly, Die Zeit, went further, calling for the south Balkans to be declared an EU protectorate.

German experts are pessimistic that the EU's long-term development strategy is capable of withstanding the strain of these events. Such comment is eerily reminiscent of warnings over the last decade about the importance of avoiding conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina and then Kosovo, because of the complexity of their histories, politics and multicultural societies.

On that benchmark Macedonia is the real cauldron of the south Balkans. In his fine history of the region Misha Glenny points out that it "was and is the crossroads of the Balkan peninsula". It "was Europe's most enduring and complex multi cultural region". When the process of fragmentation in the Balkans began, "the potential for violence in this region was greater than anywhere else".*

He was writing about the 1880s-1900s, which culminated in the two Balkan wars of 1912 and 1913 involving Greek, Serb, Bulgarians and Montenegrins against the retreating Ottoman empire. Some 200,000 combatants (excluding civilians) were killed in a ghastly prefiguration of the first World War, egged on by the imperial powers which funded and armed those involved, with the greatest devastation inflicted on Macedonia.

The 20th century's successive waves of violence to some extent simplified Macedonia's complex multiculturalism; but the grave destabilising potential for its neighbours, were it to unravel, is so historically determined that it would be very difficult to contain.

Speaking in Dublin earlier this month Mr Patten said the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy "is about projecting stability" and that "a key test is its ability to prevent conflict".

That makes this crisis its first real challenge, since it was supplemented last with a more elaborate political-military apparatus.

A common, rather than a single foreign policy, he said, is well-fitted for the post-imperial task of incorporating the Balkan region into Europe through stabilisation and accession agreements, with the long-term perspective of joining the EU. Those carrots and sticks are put powerfully to the test in Macedonia.

*Misha Glenny, The Balkans 1814-1999, Nationalsim, War and the Great Powers, London, 1999.

pgillespie(at)irish-times.ie


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2001 The Irish Times


186 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Daily Telegraph (LONDON)


May 27, 2006 Saturday


FESTIVAL GUIDE


BYLINE: Andrew Perry


SECTION: ART; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 899 words


1. Rock in Rio

Lisbon, Portugal

May 26-27, June 2-4

Second outing for Portuguese sibling of famous Brazilian festival. Two huge stages, plus an electronic tent, set in Bela Vista Park, beside Lisbon airport. Also includes a snowboard piste. 100,000 people expected per day. Price: One day ?53; two days ?90

Airport: Lisbon Portela 

Acts: Santana, Jamiroquai, Corinne Bailey Rae, Guns N' Roses, Shakira, the Darkness, Roger Waters, Anastacia, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Sting

www.rockinrio-lisboa.sapo.pt

2. Roskilde

Copenhagen, Denmark

June 29-July 2

Long-running, Glastonbury-esque, legendarily well-organised bonanza. Political motivations represented across spoken-word stages; all profits go to "humanitarian and cultural purposes''. This year: "Act Against Slavery''.

Price: ?180 weekend ticket; all one-day tickets sold out

Airport: Copenhagen Kastrup

Acts: Arctic Monkeys, Bob Dylan, Franz Ferdinand, Goldfrapp, Kaiser Chiefs, Morrissey, the Streets, the Strokes, Kanye West, Placebo, Rufus Wainwright, Sigur Rós

www.roskilde-festival.dk

3. Montreux Jazz

Montreux, Switzerland

June 30-July 15

Sixteen-day concert series, across three indoor theatres, plus free events, aftershow parties, and boat/train rides featuring live music, all amid jaw-dropping scenery.

Price: varies, per concert

Airport: Geneva

Acts: BB King, Chick Corea, Gnarls Barkley, Herbie Hancock, Ornette Coleman, Sean Paul, Terry Callier, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, and Iggy & the Stooges

www.montreuxjazz.com

4. Exit

Novi Sad, Serbia

July 6-9

Knees-up in Petrovaradin Fortress, overlooking the Danube. Has its origins in anti-Milosevic resistance movements: first went public the year he was ousted. Runs from 8pm to 8am, starring hundreds of DJs - house music was the soundtrack of the Serbians' liberation.

Price: ?66.75, plus ?6.75 service charge

Airport: Belgrade

Acts: Morrissey, Franz Ferdinand, the Cardigans, Billy Idol, Pet Shop Boys, Kelis, HIM, Suzanne Vega. DJs include Derrick May, Junkie XL, Jeff Mills, Dave Clarke, Nick Warren

www.exitfest.org

5. Oxegen

Punchestown Racecourse, Co Kildare, Ireland

July 8-9

60,000-capacity, full-tilt, rock/dance bash. Previously known as Witness. Features many of the bands performing at Scotland's T In the Park over the same weekend.

Price: eBay only; all tickets sold out in 12 hours

Airport: Dublin

Acts: the Who, Arctic Monkeys, James Brown, Primal Scream, Eels, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Richard Ashcroft, Ben Harper, Kaiser Chiefs, Paul Weller, Franz Ferdinand, Placebo, Goldfrapp

www.oxegen.ie

6. Paléo Festival Nyon Nyon, Switzerland

July 18-23

Started in 1977 as a folk festival, renamed in '85 after a famous racehorse. Now includes jazz, world, electronic, alternative rock, even classical. Run by a non-profit-making cultural organisation. The bucolic setting includes wooded creeks and hidden cafés.

Price: from ?39 for a day ticket, up to ?188 for the full six days

Airport: Geneva International

Acts: Ben Harper, Pixies, Depeche Mode, Dandy Warhols, Gogol Bordello, the Who, Tracey Chapman, Amadou & Mariam, Placebo, Feeder, Joseph Arthur

www.paleo.ch

7. Nice Jazz

Nice, France

July 19-26

Halfway between Montreux and a rock festival, with eight evenings of music across three outdoor stages in idyllically leafy Cimiez Park, formerly a Roman amphitheatre - "where audiences and olive trees swing together''.

Price: eight-day pass ?179, three-day pass ?90, per night in advance ?35

Airport: Nice Côte D'Azur International

Acts: Erykah Badu, George Clinton, Suzanne Vega, Kanye West, Salif Keita, Incognito, Joe Jackson, Randy Newman, John Butler Trio

www.nicejazzfest.com

8. Benicassim

Nr Valencia, Spain

July 20-23

Sunshine (and hefty British contingent) virtually guaranteed.

There are famously amazing facilities backstage (including swimming pool), while fans can enjoy the nearby beach, two go-kart tracks, and discotheque open until sunrise.

Price: ?152 four days, ?70 one day

Airport: Valencia (92 km)

Acts: Scissor Sisters, Depeche Mode, Pixies, the Strokes, Franz Ferdinand, Morrissey, Madness, Babyshambles, Beth Orton, Coldcut, Echo & the Bunnymen, Futureheads, Ordinary Boys

www.fiberfib.com

9. Basowiszcza

Gródek, Poland

21-22 July

Known locally as the Belarussian Woodstock, it's definitely one for the more intrepid festival-goer, but the effort should be rewarded by a magnificent setting in the Borak forest, and by the unfamiliar local festival customs.

Price: Free

Airport: Warsaw Frederic Chopin, then 100 miles by train to Bialystok

Acts: Basowiszcza means literally "Young Belarus Music Festival''. Staged and funded by the Polish Cultural Programme since 1990, it showcases Belarussian rock acts banned from playing in their homeland. Hence the line-up remains hush-hush until the weekend itself, but it's likely to include NRM, Neurodubel, Ulis, Krambambula and Palac.

www.basowiszcza.org

10. Sziget

Budapest, Hungary

August 9-16

Takes place on the beautiful, wooded Obudai Island in the middle of the Danube, close to the city centre. Mobile showers and a nearby hotel swimming pool come free of charge - river skinny-dipping is firmly discouraged. Extra-musical activities range from paintball to chess.

Price: ?120 full eight-day camping ticket; ?99 without camping

Airport: Budapest Ferihegy

Acts: Radiohead, Robert Plant, Scissor Sisters, Franz Ferdinand, Coldcut, Cradle of Filth, the Exploited, Femi Kuti, Ministry, the Orb, Placebo, Roger Sanchez, Rasmus, Mylo, DJ Storm, Sick of It All, Therapy?

www.sziget.hu

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

187 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


April 15, 2002, Monday


OBITUARY: VLAJKO STOJILJKOVIC;
 POLICE CHIEF AND LOYAL FRIEND TO MILOSEVIC


BYLINE: Vesna Peric Zimonjic Stojiljkovic: 'defender of Serbia'


SECTION: OBITUARIES; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 967 words


 

VLAJKO STOJILJKOVIC, Interior Minister of Serbia until 2000, belonged to the closest circle of the former Serbian president Slobodan Milosevic. He was known for his endless loyalty to Milosevic and his cruelty towards all who opposed him. Yet, faced with possible extradition to the international tribunal in The Hague, to be charged with war crimes in Kosovo in 1999, he chose to kill himself instead of joining his friend on trial. It remains unclear whether Milosevic will view this as an act of bravery or betrayal.

Born in 1937, Stojiljkovic graduated from Belgrade Law School and more or less made his career in Pozarevac, Milosevic's hometown, some 100km east of Belgrade. He was not a popular figure, and even his comrades in Milosevic's Socialist Party viewed Stojiljkovic as rigid, and not too bright. 

For many years, he was the head of the Pozarevac police, chief of police of the eastern Serbian region and ran one of the biggest prisons in Serbia, Zabela, situated on the outskirts of Pozarevac. There were a few short intervals in his police career when he headed Serbian or Yugoslav chambers of commerce in the early 1990s. As Milosevic's trusted friend, Stojiljkovic was appointed Interior Minister in 1997. He resigned from the post after Milosevic fell from power in 2000.

The two spent a lot of time together in Pozarevac, where the Milosevic family resided at weekends and holidays. Vlajko and "Sloba" would play chess together, or go fishing on the banks of the Danube. It was under Stojiljkovic's scrutiny that Milosevic's son Marko developed a business empire in Pozarevac and became the notorious lord of the town. Milosevic junior fled the country after his father's fall from power.

It was also under Stojiljkovic's lead that the Serbian police turned into a brutal force, with the special aim of fighting rebellious ethnic Albanians in Kosovo province. The police became an efficient tool against the opponents of Milosevic's regime in the period that preceded his fall from power. Both were viewed by Stojiljkovic with hatred.

Excessive force was the trademark of his career as minister in charge of police. He demanded total obedience and was rigid in planning and executing actions. The Serbian police force did whatever it wanted in the southern province of Kosovo from 1998 onwards, when the armed rebellion of ethnic Albanians and their Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) started. Any resistance was branded "terrorism" by Milosevic's regime. In the 11 weeks of Nato air raids against Serbia in 1999, the actions of the Serbian police against ethnic Albanians looked like an open manhunt. Some former top officials say today that it was Stojiljkovic who insisted on harsh measures against "terrorists" in Kosovo, "to teach them a lesson for good".

The actions of the Serbian security forces in the province left at least 10,000 ethnic Albanians dead. The bodies of victims of mass executions were transferred to Serbia proper at the time of Nato air raids, in refrigerator trucks that were later dumped into rivers. Further, 800,000 ethnic Albanians were forced to leave their homes and seek shelter in neighbouring Albania and Macedonia. Stojiljkovic always described these reports as "fabrications".

Two years ago, when the Serbian opposition joined ranks to topple Milosevic in the elections, Stojiljkovic used the forces at his disposal to quell rebellion at home. Activists in the student movement Otpor (Resistance) were arrested and severely beaten by the police, street protests were met with disproportionate and unnecessary force. Cordons of anti-riot police in places around Serbia where anti-Milosevic protests were being held became a commonplace. As did being beaten.

Stojiljkovic allowed the Serbian mafia to flourish and several assassinations or assassination attempts against Milosevic's opponents took place. Vaults that were at the disposal of the notorious security service held more than 500kg of cocaine, ready to be sold in the streets of Serbia. As police minister, Stojiljkovic must have known about all these things. He was in charge of both branches of the ministry - dealing with public security and the secret service.

But all this became history on 5 October 2000, when a popular uprising swept Milosevic from power. Seeing that several hundred thousand people, from all over Serbia, had taken to the streets of Belgrade in the biggest ever anti- Milosevic protest, the Serbian police became practical; they decided to disobey orders and not to shoot at the protesters.

But Stojiljkovic had other ideas. Witnesses say he was unaware that the protests were on such a large scale. He gave orders from his cabinet, over the phone, contacting the most important police generals. One of his ideas was that police helicopters should be used to drop toxic chemicals to disperse protesters in front of the federal parliament building. The chopper crews decided not carry out the order. By the end of the dramatic day, Milosevic was ousted. People who know Stojiljkovic say that he could not believe it, on that day, or for months afterwards.

Stojiljkovic chose the entrance of the federal parliament building in which to shoot himself last Thursday. As an MP of Milosevic's party, he was leaving parliament after a new law allowing further extraditions to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague had just been passed. In his suicide note, he said that the Serbian police were honourable men and that "the defenders of the country" who fought against "terrorism and Nato" should not be extradited to the tribunal, as they were heroes. He believed himself to be one of them.

Vlajko Stojiljkovic, politician: born Mala Krsna, Yugoslavia 1937; Serbian Interior Minister 1997-2000; died Belgrade 13 April 2002.


LOAD-DATE: April 15, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2002 Independent Print Ltd


188 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


September 21, 1999, Tuesday, Final Edition


Infighting Weakens Milosevic Foes; Demonstrations Planned Today in 20 Serbian Cities


Daniel Williams, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 960 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Sept. 20


 

Opposition infighting and confusion over competing strategies have markedly slowed the drive to topple Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic since a series of mass rallies spawned by the Kosovo war put his government on the defensive over the summer.

One sign of Milosevic's belief in his survival emerged last week, when his spokesman withdrew an offer of early elections that had been extended as a way to defuse what appeared to be a swelling wave of criticism. The shift was seen as a sign that Milosevic believes he can ride out the postwar discontent without concessions to the political opposition, which is demanding a change in leadership for Yugoslavia and its dominant republic, Serbia.

A portion of the opposition will try to regain momentum with rallies on Tuesday in 20 cities, including Belgrade, the Yugoslav and Serbian capital. 

The turnout and fervor exhibited will be seen as a gauge of public stamina, which many observers think has been sapped.

The war-weary country, with Kosovo effectively cut off, seems ripe for rebellion. Displaced people crowd shelters and complain of government indifference. International trade sanctions have exacerbated deep economic problems. Prices are rising, fuel is in short supply, and jobs are scarce. Reconstruction after the war has been limited to patchwork repair of roads, bridges and housing. Without foreign help and a reopening to world trade, recovery is impossible, economists say.

But for people hoping for quick change, opposition wrangling is an unwelcome diversion. Polls show that few expect Milosevic's exit soon, and some fear violence. Washington, eager for Milosevic's ouster, is quietly lobbying for opposition unity but has gotten nowhere.

"Our opposition is awful," said Aleksa Djilas, an independent political observer. "It's the main reason Milosevic is still in power."

"They want us to go out into the streets, but I don't feel like putting my head out to be hit to benefit politicians who just stand for themselves," said Dragan Savic, an auto repairman who took part in early demonstrations but plans to stay home from now on. "I have enough problems just to survive."

Many analysts agree that before a credible challenge to Milosevic can be mounted, one key opposition rivalry must be resolved--that between Zoran Djindjic and Vuk Draskovic. Djindjic heads the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition parties that wants Milosevic to resign in favor of a government of economic experts that would form an interim administration pending new elections. The alliance is spearheading Tuesday's rallies.

Draskovic leads the Serbian Renewal Movement, which alternately has opposed Milosevic and formed part of his ruling coalition. Draskovic wants immediate elections without the government of experts as an interim step and is staying away from Tuesday's demonstrations.

Djindjic, a butch-cut philosopher and former student activist, and Draskovic, a bearded novelist, despise each other. The pair appeared on the same platform in August, during the last big anti-Milosevic rally in Belgrade. Since then, they have been at each other's throats.

Aides to Djindjic criticize Draskovic for alleged corruption in the Belgrade city government he controls and for cozying up to Milosevic. Draskovic's associates fault Djindjic for everything from speaking broken English to a lack of patriotism for fleeing Serbia during the Kosovo war.

Djindjic says the demonstrations are the first in a series of protests, sit-ins and road blockades meant to undermine Milosevic. "The goal is to show that he cannot govern," Djindjic said in an interview.

Djindjic and his alliance back Dragoslav Avramovic, a former head of the Central Bank, as their candidate to head a post-Milosevic government. Avramovic worked wonders in pulling Yugoslavia out of hyperinflation in the early 1990s and is widely regarded as the country's most popular politician. But even Avramovic, 77, has doubts about his candidacy.

"Every morning I wake up and wonder, do I need this?" he said the other day.

Tuesday's turnout will be scrutinized as a measure of Djindjic's ability to draw a crowd. A light turnout will inevitably bring calls for Djindjic to bow to Draskovic.

Draskovic's followers insist that Djindjic is unelectable and that only the Serbian Renewal Movement is capable of taking on Milosevic. Last week, a delegation of Draskovic's aides traveled to Montenegro--Serbia's disaffected partner in the Yugoslav federation--to try to persuade U.S. State Department officials to support his early election plan. According to American officials, Washington was noncommittal and stressed the importance of opposition unity.

"Only Draskovic can win; he's got the charisma and the party," said an aide in a typical partisan evaluation. If Djindjic falters, Draskovic will call his followers into the streets with the aim of forcing elections, to be conducted under strict rules, including international supervision.

The divisions and stumbling do not mean Milosevic has let down his guard. On the contrary, he spares little effort to undermine the opposition. Last Friday, the Yugoslav government opened a new barge-supported bridge across the Danube River in Novi Sad at the same time that Alliance for Change had scheduled a convention in the city. Novi Sad's bridges were destroyed by NATO aircraft during the war, and residents have had to use ferries to cross the river.

Workers at the site said they were ordered to open the span to pedestrian traffic early, even though railings were not yet in place and seams in the concrete roadbed were still being filled with tar. "They wanted to attract the public away from alliance's rally," said one worker.


LOAD-DATE: September 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


189 of 348 DOCUMENTS


DAILY MAIL (London)


July 8, 1999


Step down now or risk a civil war, Milosevic warned


SECTION: Pg. 18


LENGTH: 382 words


 

SLOBODAN Milosevic was warned to step down or risk a bloody civil war last night as protests escalated across Serbia.

In areas once considered the heartland of support for the Yugoslav president, tens of thousands took to the streets.

A petition calling for his removal has now collected more than 100,000 signatures, opposition leaders said. 

It was signed by 3,000 on its first day in Serbia's largest southern city, Nis.

In the bitter aftermath of the ill-fated campaign of ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, an 11-week war against Nato and Milosevic's ludicrous claims of victory, anger against the dictator had simmered rather than boiled over.

But growing demonstrations banned by the government have shown the public mood changing to frustration and mounting anger through the past week.

In Leskovac, 180 miles south of the capital Belgrade, more than 10,000 people took to the streets over the past three days to chant anti-Milosevic slogans.

Several people were injured as protesters demanding the release of a local television engineer clashed with baton-wielding police.

Thirty-one-year-old Ivan Novkovic interrupted a broadcast of a basketball match between Yugoslavia and France on Monday to call on Milosevic to resign and for people to take to the streets if he did not.

For his troubles he was jailed for 30 days.

By mid-afternoon yesterday there were reports that sections of the crowd many of them bitter former Army reservists who had served in Kosovo were armed.

In a separate protest organised by the Alliance for Change an umbrella group of opposition parties 6,000 people in the central industrial city of Uzice heard Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic declare: 'The time is now right for Serbia to rid itself of Milosevic and his party.' The rising star of the opposition movement later warned that the growing tide of 'people power is unstoppable'.

He feared the government might resort to violence, saying: 'There is a danger of civil war here and now.' His planned visit to Kosovo today is only likely to heighten tensions.

The potential for violence escalated yesterday when police said they would halt an antigovernment demonstration in Prokuplje, 20 miles from Nis, while allowing a pro-Milosevic rally to go ahead.


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1999 Associated Newspapers Ltd.


190 of 348 DOCUMENTS


DAILY MAIL (London)


July 8, 1999


Step down now or risk a civil war, Milosevic warned


SECTION: Pg. 18


LENGTH: 383 words


 

SLOBODAN Milosevic was warned to step down or risk a bloody civil war last night as protests escalated across Serbia.

In areas once considered the heartland of support for the Yugoslav president, tens of thousands took to the streets.

A petition calling for his removal has now collected more than 100,000 signatures, opposition leaders said. 

It was signed by 3,000 on its first day in Serbia's largest southern city, Nis.

In the bitter aftermath of the ill-fated campaign of ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, an 11-week war against Nato and Milosevic's ludicrous claims of victory, anger against the dictator had simmered rather than boiled over.

But growing demonstrations banned by the government have shown the public mood changing to frustration and mounting anger through the past week.

In Leskovac, 180 miles south of the capital Belgrade, more than 10,000 people took to the streets over the past three days to chant anti-Milosevic slogans.

Several people were injured as protesters demanding the release of a local television engineer clashed with baton-wielding police.

Thirty-one-year-old Ivan Novkovic interrupted a broadcast of a basketball match between Yugoslavia and France on Monday to call on Milosevic to resign and for people to take to the streets if he did not.

For his troubles he was jailed for 30 days.
