The potential for violence escalated yesterday when police said they would halt an antigovernment demonstration in Prokuplje, 20 miles from Nis, while allowing a pro-Milosevic rally to go ahead.


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1999 Associated Newspapers Ltd.


191 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


October 02, 1997, Thursday, Final Edition


Yugoslav Riot Police Quell 2 Anti-Government Protests


Lee Hockstader, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A19


LENGTH: 428 words


DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia, Oct. 1


 

Riot police loyal to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic attacked thousands of anti-government street protesters in separate demonstrations today, signaling that the Balkan strongman remains firmly in control despite recent electoral setbacks.

In one incident, hundreds of police fired tear gas and swung clubs to break up a protest by several thousand ethnic Albanian students in Serbia's southern province of Kosovo. The Albanians, who represent about 90 percent of the population in Kosovo but only a minority overall in Yugoslavia, were demanding the right to an Albanian-language education. 

In the other incident, several hundred riot police attacked thousands of marchers in Belgrade who were protesting the firing of Mayor Zoran Djindjic and the removal of editors of the capital's only independent television station.

The United States and its European allies protested the use of excessive force in both incidents.

In elections last month in Serbia, which makes up most of what is left of the former Yugoslavia, candidates loyal to Milosevic lost ground to radical nationalist opponents running for the republic's parliament and presidency. But the authoritarian Milosevic, who only last winter was reeling from weeks of street protests, remains firmly in control of the police, as he demonstrated today.

In response to the police attack in the Kosovo capital, Pristina, leaders of the Albanian students called off planned daily demonstrations late today. They said they will pursue their campaign for Albanian-language instruction at Pristina University by less confrontational means.

The Reuter news agency, reporting from Pristina, said the students appeared surprised by the firmness of the police crackdown after the government promised Western diplomats it would not use force.

In Belgrade, the protests were triggered by Tuesday's vote by the city assembly to fire Djindjic and replace the management board of the independent Studio B television station, which backed him.

Djindjic called today for fresh demonstrations against Milosevic. But the vote to oust the mayor was inspired equally by his former ally in an anti-Milosevic coalition, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement. Draskovic is angry with Djindjic for leading a drive to boycott last month's Serbian elections, in which Draskovic ran for president.

It was unclear whether, after the tough police response today, Djindjic's supporters again would take to the streets to back him in what has become an internecine struggle between Milosevic's foes.


LOAD-DATE: October 02, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Map, dave cook


Copyright 1997 The Washington Post


192 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


September 30, 2000, Saturday, Edition 1


STRIKES GATHER STEAM AGAINST MILOSEVIC


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 809 words


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP-Reuters) - Darkening movie houses,
blocking roads and shutting shops, tens of thousands of Yugoslavs
heeded opposition calls yesterday for countrywide strikes aimed
at forcing President Slobodan Milosevic to accept election defeat
and step down.

Even as opposition leaders explained the campaign to about 25,000 supporters in Belgrade's main square, students rallied in the country's south, shopkeepers shuttered their doors in the east and television workers cut off transmissions in the north.

"Cease your work, come out and stay on the streets, so that this country will find its path to future," opposition leader Zoran Djindjic told the Belgrade crowd. "Serbia must stop for us to unload Milosevic out of a seat he no longer has a right to." Serbia and the smaller Montenegro make up Yugoslavia. 

The opposition called the protests to pressure Milosevic to admit that challenger Vojislav Kostunica won last Sunday's election. Milosevic admits he finished second, but his government says no candidate won a majority so an Oct. 8 run-off is necessary.

The actors' guild declared a strike, and most theatre and cinema owners said they would shut down. Several roads were blocked in northern and southern parts of Serbia and over 7,000 coal miners stopped work in Kolubara, 40 kilometres south of Belgrade.

Two protests, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening, attracted a total of 50,000 people to Belgrade's main Republic Square.

Police briefly blocked one of three main bridges over the Sava River, trying to prevent people and a column of about 100 taxi drivers from joining the evening protest in the capital.

Outside Belgrade, thousands of high school students shunned classes in Nis, Serbia's third largest city, and spilled into the streets, some jumping out of first floor classroom windows in their haste to attend the protest.

Waving anti-Milosevic banners, they chanted: "Save Serbia and kill yourself, Slobodan," while taxi drivers blockaded adjoining streets.

"I know why you are not in school today," Mayor Zoran Zivkovic told the students in Nis. "You refuse to accept injustice!"

The Yugoslav opposition plans more protests today and tomorrow and civil disobedience backed by a general strike threat to crank up pressure on Milosevic to quit.

"We will continue with the rallies over the weekend and start a general strike on Monday to grind Serbia to a standstill," Djindjic said yesterday.

Walkouts, joined by shopkeepers and company employees, were staged in a dozen other cities and towns. Southern Valjevo was completely blocked and thousands protested in Kraljevo. In Novi Sad, state television employees stopped work.

A main highway in western Serbia was blocked for one hour by some 60 cabbies as a "warning."

Also yesterday, Serbia's opposition lodged an official complaint with the Federal Election Commission, providing their own tally that showed Kostunica beat Milosevic 51.34 per cent to 36.22 per cent in Sunday's vote.

If the commission fails to respond to their complaint, the opposition plans to press the case in the country's constitutional court.

The opposition said it would dispatch delegations to army headquarters, the interior ministry and Serbian state television with documents proving their election victory.

An opposition member of the commission, Nebojsa Bakarac, told reporters that Milosevic had falsified more than 100,000 votes from polling places that never opened in Albanian-populated towns in Kosovo and that there was proof of ballots "cast" by dead voters.

Kostunica urged an independent recount of the ballots, appealing "especially to neighbouring Greece."

"It is more than necessary to count the votes again and examine the entire balloting material," Kostunica said in a letter made available to the media yesterday.

Greece, a NATO member with close cultural and religious ties to Serbia, has suggested the opposition consider the possibility of taking part in the run- off if international election observers are allowed. Bakarac, the commission's opposition member, rejected Greece's initiative, saying the opposition would not bargain with Milosevic on a run-off: "The truth is the truth and it's not negotiable."

U.S. Defence Secretary William Cohen has praised the growing anti-Milosevic movement, and noted, without giving specifics, that American forces were " prepared for contingencies."

Many foreign countries, including Canada and the United States, have promised to lift sanctions if Kostunica's victory is respected.

Croatia yesterday added its voice to those countries recognizing Kostunica's victory, calling it a "vote for democracy."

Milosevic and his backers have made it clear they will defy pressure to cede power after 13 turbulent years.


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2000


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: AP PHOTO
MILOSEVIC'S GOTTA GO:
Protesters in Belgrade shout their opposition to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic at rallies yesterday. Thousands heeded opposition calls for nationwide strikes.


Copyright 2000 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


193 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


December 8, 1997, Monday


Milosevic benefits from Serbian apathy at the polling booths


BYLINE: Andrew Gumbel


SECTION: NEWS; Page  11


LENGTH: 426 words


Serbians voted to elect a president yesterday, for the second time in three months. But widespread apathy suggested little prospect of reaching the 50 per cent turnout needed to validate the results. Andrew Gumbel in Belgrade reports on an impasse that can only benefit Slobodan Milosevic. 

Everybody knew this was going to be a lacklustre campaign. But last Tuesday the whole country was made to realise what pathetic, puerile stuff its prospective future leaders were made of. Vojislav Seselj, the frontrunner in September's inconclusive poll and a notorious hardline nationalist, held a live television debate with one of his biggest rivals, the erstwhile anti-Milosevic campaigner Vuk Draskovic.

At first Mr Seselj, who has a track record of making verbal and physical threats on the small screen, surprised everyone by playing the mature politician, doing his best to sound sweetly reasonable about the depressed economy, the backlog of unpaid pensions and state salaries, and the thorny political question of autonomy for the Albanian-majority province of Kosovo.

But then Mr Draskovic accused Mr Seselj of being a bad Serb with a suspiciously high proportion of Croatian blood. Mr Seselj looked flustered at first, then threw the same accusation back in Mr Draskovic's face. Since the two men have close family ties, the insults soon became downright personal. What was supposed to be a debate about the country's future turned into a racist slanging match.

The truth is, both men are a severe embarrassment - Mr Seselj because of his rabid political opinions and his tendency to have his opponents beaten up, Mr Draskovic because his claim to represent the democratic opposition that spent last winter marching against the Milosevic regime looks more tenuous every day. Most of the moderates in his party have walked out on him. The rest of the pro-democracy movement are boycotting the election.

That leaves just one other leading contender, the Yugoslav Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic, who is a Milosevic man through and through. But he is also endlessly bland, a poor campaigner and a man with a past as a scourge of anti- establishment intellectuals under Tito.

The most likely scenario is another inquorate election, and another round of voting next spring. Without a president, Serbia cannot form a government. The power vacuum leaves just one man with a real job, Mr Milosevic. Although his post as Yugoslav federal president is largely honorary, no one is in a position to challenge his supremacy.


LOAD-DATE: December 08, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1997 Independent Print Ltd


194 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times


December 18, 1993, Saturday


Serbia voters enticed by visions of glorious future


BYLINE: From Tim Judah in Belgrade


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 578 words


SERBIA goes to the polls tomorrow in an election that may be remembered as the one that sealed its wartime pyrrhic victory. A de facto greater Serbia now stretches from the Romanian border to the Adriatic, but it is an impoverished pariah state and is likely to remain so for years to come. Nobody dares to tell the voters, though. 

Serbia's politicians are spinning dreams, luring the electorate with promises of a strong and wealthy United States of Serbia while the economy crumbles. Inflation will probably top 100,000 per cent for this month alone. One Belgrade magazine has coined a phrase for this: making reference to Japanese tidal waves, it talks of an ''inflationary tsunami''.

As misery engulfs the country, the ruling Socialists promise that peace is imminent and sanctions will soon be lifted. There is no evidence of either. More extraordinary is the violent lurch to the right by the mainstream opposition.

During the summer Vuk Draskovic, the Leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, was brutally beaten by police and then detained after a demonstration in Belgrade. Appeals on his behalf came from London and across Europe and he was flown to France for medical treatment. There will be red faces in Europe on Monday if Mr Draskovic comes within a hair's breadth of power.

Mr Draskovic promised tens of thousands in a rally in Belgrade on Wednesday that all the Serb-held territories in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina were part of Serbia and so were Sarajevo and Mostar. Both towns remain to be conquered by Serb forces. He also promised to rip up any peace deals made by Slobodan Milosevic, the Serb President.

It had been assumed that Mr Milosevic's Socialists would retain their grip on power, but this is no longer regarded as certain. The surge of support for extreme nationalists in Russia has encouraged the Serbian opposition. So has last Sunday's victory by an anti-Milosevic candidate in Krajina, the Serb-held enclave in Croatia.

Mr Milosevic is not standing for re-election and his marked lack of support for the Socialists in the campaign leads some to believe he has written them off. There are rumours in Belgrade that he will announce a union of Serbia and Serb-held lands in Croatia and Bosnia, but time is running out for such a move to have an electoral impact.

Some believe that Mr Milosevic is preparing for a period of cohabitation where he continues to rule but confounds the West by presenting it with a democratically elected opposition Government, which makes him look like a moderate on the national question. All sorts of coalitions are also being touted, most of them inherently unstable.

One of the more grotesque, but likely possible combinations, is a Socialist-dominated Government propped up by a new party led by Zeljko Raznjatovic, better known by his nom de guerre: Arkan. The leader of the Tigers during fighting in Bosnia and Croatia is high on most lists of alleged war criminals and is also wanted by the Swedish, German, Dutch and Belgian police. It is alleged that before the war Arkan was a Yugoslav secret service assassin and a bank robber.

So, Serbs go to the polls tomorrow to celebrate their pyrrhic victory. At the beginning of the war Serbs complained that their fate was always to be winners in war and losers in peace. It is something they believe profoundly and it looks as though it is true once more. Unfortunately it is not a vote winner. More fool Serbia.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1993 Times Newspapers Limited


195 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


May 14, 1999, Friday


OBJECTIVE ONE: GET MILOSEVIC


BYLINE: Louise Branson


SECTION: Pg. 21


LENGTH: 951 words


 

THE Clinton administration is deeply divided over Kosovo - albeit behind the scenes. It doesn't know what to do. NATO bombing has not forced Slobodan Milosevic to cave in as expected.

American officials are desperate to find a way out.

Yesterday, there were signs of movement. President Clinton, after days of near-silence, delivered an impassioned speech about the importance of prevailing in Kosovo. He evoked gruesome examples of the atrocities allegedly being carried out by Serb forces. The clear hint was that he was preparing American opinion for a possible ground intervention. As he was speaking, more army and navy reservists were being called up. 

That would be a major, and welcome, development, an admission that bombing alone is a failure. Until now, Clinton had seemed paralysed by polls indicating his country could not take too many American soldiers returning in body-bags.

But it would not be enough.

NATO - led by the Americans, who are needed for any solution - should have the imagination, the guts and the determination to go further. It is quite clear to anyone who has even casually studied the Balkans these past few years that there is one root cause of instability in the region. His name is Slobodan Milosevic.

With the skills of Machiavelli, this evil dictator deliberately stirred nationalism to bring himself to power in 1987. Since then, he has gathered all reins of power in his own hands. He has only a small coterie of advisers whom he constantly changes, setting one against the other to sow fear and distrust.

Nobody is allowed to come close to challenging his power. Even his top aides are rarely briefed on his negotiations.

Over the years, he has become steadily more repressive. He controls the media which broadcasts a diet of lies and propaganda. On the many occasions his people have come out in demonstrations against him - waving posters comparing him to Saddam Hussein - he has turned his police on them or stirred more war and trouble to distract attention. The NATO bombing has only strengthened his grip on power.

Even anti-Milosevic liberals are out in the streets protesting the bombing. "I am against Milosevic, but I am not against my country," said one, summing up the sentiment.

For the broad Serb public, long fed nationalistic propaganda, the bombing has confirmed a historical sense of victimisation - first at the hands of the Turks, then the Nazis, now NATO. It has also facilitated a national denial: as victims, they do not have to take responsibility or even own up to the Kosovo horrors.

The Serb dictator, meanwhile, has taken advantage of the Kosovo distraction to increase his tyrannical hold at home. He has dismissed dozens of Belgrade university professors who refused to sign a pledge of allegiance to his government, for example. And he has shut down or taken over the last few non -government media outlets - including the wonderful B92 student radio in Belgrade which used to produce spunky reports that told his repression like it was.

While support for Milosevic in Serbia is a mile wide, however, it is an inch thick. It could easily crumble if Serbs were given a way out, shown a path to the Europe they had keenly wanted to join in the late Eighties and early Nineties, when they saw themselves as part of a democratic wave sweeping across Eastern and Central Europe.

The first step to achieve this would be to get rid of Milosevic. NATO should do that by declaring him a war criminal. To suggest that it does not have enough evidence to send him to the Hague is nonsense. The real reason the United States in particular is holding back is because it thinks, as at Dayton, it needs him to be a "guarantor" of peace. But that is a cave-in: setting the stage for him to stir more trouble in, say, his multi-ethnic northern province of Vojvodina or amongst his Muslims in the Sandzak region as soon as he again needs to distract his people's attention to keep his grip on them.

NATO needs to go further than a Hague indictment, though. Serbs are in no state after 12 years of Milosevic to pick up the physical or psychological pieces on their own. What they need is a Marshall Plan and an allied takeover of the kind that occurred in Germany and Japan after the Second World War. A high-publicity Nuremberg-style trial of Milosevic and his chief lieutenants would help Serbs face and come to terms with the terrible things that have been committed by some of them and in their name. The institutions needed to build democracy from the ground up could also be installed.

Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, a Harvard historian who wrote Hitler's Willing Executioners: Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust has already launched that idea, publishing a manifesto in which he said that Serbia should "be placed in receivership." Others have taken up the theme. Thomas Alan Schwartz, another American historian, commented that "when Germany was totally defeated, it provided opportunity. You could be physically there, controlling the flow of information and using war-crime trials to show the Germans that atrocities were done in their name." Without something similar, he said, we can look forward to more trouble in Serbia.

"What reminds me of Germany is the comparison to the end of World War One," he added. "Then, the Germans had this powerful sense of being victims. There was a deep resentment that Hitler was able to exploit.

It will be the same in Serbia when NATO bombing stops."

Particularly if the eventual settlement in Kosovo is an unsatisfactory peace deal that leaves Milosevic in power - after, perhaps, caving in to NATO following a ground intervention in Kosovo.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


196 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


June 26, 1997, Thursday, DAILY EDITION


Ordinary Serbs bear cost of rebuilding the country's economy


BYLINE: ANTHONY ROBINSON; Anthony Robinson is a writer with the Financial Times, where this column first appeared.


SECTION: SECTION 1; News; GUEST COLUMN; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 805 words


 

"Welcome to Kragujevac: home of the Yugo," reads a battered sign at the entrance of the city that used to be the Turin of Yugoslavia and is now a symbol of Serbia's gutted economy.

Before the disintegration of Yugoslavia, the Crna Zastava (Red Flag) car plants in this city 130 kilometres south of Belgrade turned out up to 220,000 cars a year. The ubiquitous Yugo model briefly competed with other cheap imports in Europe and the U.S.

Today, Zastava is hard pressed to produce 10,000 cars a year. Last year thousands of workers went on strike and in November Veroljub Stevanovic, the managing director sacked in 1992, was elected mayor for the opposition Zajedno movement. His was one of many opposition election victories whose attempted annulment by Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's president, sparked three months of nationwide demonstrations. 

The disintegration of former Yugoslavia and four years of trade sanctions against Serbia severed access to markets, raw materials and components, dealing a near-lethal blow to dozens of plants like Zastava.

Trade sanctions were lifted last year in return for Serbian compliance with the Dayton peace agreements, which ended the war in Bosnia. But financial sanctions that bar Serbia from membership in the International Monetary Fund and access to international capital markets remain in force.

The collapse of Zastava has created huge social problems for the one-company town. "Over 70,000 are waiting for a job, another 30,000 are on enforced 'vacation' and the population is swollen with 5,000 Serb refugees," Stevanovic says. "This city has the greatest social problems in Europe." The mayor believes Zastava could be revived, but only with foreign investment and new management to replace the party hacks put in when anti-Milosevic dissidents like him were sacked.

"Executives from Hyundai, Renault and Fiat itself have all looked around recently. We know there are too many workers and there will have to be retrenchments. But the real problem is that the communists are still in power -- and that is simply not attractive to anyone," Stevanovic says.

Only 50 km from Belgrade, in the steel town of Smederevo, life is significantly different. The steel complex was always a heavy loss maker. But it received much investment in the early 1980s, although the plant was closed when sanctions were imposed in 1992.

Yet unlike Kragujevac with its opposition mayor, Smederevo's managers smoothly switched allegiance from the Communist party to Milosevic. With this level of political support, workers at Smederevo continued to receive their pay during the four years until it reopened last year. The plant is expected to produce 1.2 million tonnes of steel products this year, mostly for export.

The export drive reflects both depressed domestic demand and the government's need for hard currency.

Serbia's trade deficit was more than US$ 1 billion last year and rising. "The problem is that Serbia's biggest exporters are also its biggest importers. The more they produce the bigger the deficit," worries Goran Pitic, head of research at Belgrade's Economics Institute. Danica Popovic, at the rival Centre for Economic Studies, adds: "There is no economic strategy and that means there is no direction at the micro level at all. The people that run plants like Smederevo and Zastava are apparatchiks, not managers."

Popovic is skeptical of the government's new-found belief in privatization, noting that 96% of the country's assets are still in state hands. But about 35% of economic output is produced by the private sector, she says.

Serbian industry is still working at only 36% capacity against 73% in 1989. Serbia has survived by consuming its capital, including the estimated US$ 4 billion in effect stolen from private hard currency accounts in 1991.

The economic cost of Milosovic's failed attempt to create a Greater Serbia is borne by ordinary Serbs whose average annual income has fallen by more than 50% to about US$ 1,500 since 1990. But while Serbia has stagnated in isolation, other former Yugoslav republics, especially Slovenia and Croatia, have forged ahead with economic stabilization and privatization. They have created strong, convertible currencies backed by growing foreign currency reserves and attracted foreign investment.

Serbia's best hopes for economic recovery lie in restoring economic and trade links with these independent states.

Even under the most optimistic assumptions, however, Serbia faces a struggle to rebuild its economy. It will no longer receive a share of Slovenia's export revenues or the hard currency tourist receipts of Croatia, both of which helped to sustain it in the days of federal Yugoslavia. And as long as Milosevic remains in control, it will also be hamstrung by financial sanctions.


LOAD-DATE: June 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1997 Financial Post Ltd.


197 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


June 26, 1997, Thursday, DAILY EDITION


Ordinary Serbs bear cost of rebuilding the country's economy


BYLINE: Anthony Robinson


SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 17, Guest Column


LENGTH: 809 words


''Welcome to Kragujevac: home of the Yugo,'' reads a battered sign at the entrance of the city that used to be the Turin of Yugoslavia and is now a symbol of Serbia's gutted economy.

Before the disintegration of Yugoslavia, the Crna Zastava (Red Flag) car plants in this city 130 kilometres south of Belgrade turned out up to 220,000 cars a year. The ubiquitous Yugo model briefly competed with other cheap imports in Europe and the U.S.

Today, Zastava is hard pressed to produce 10,000 cars a year. Last year thousands of workers went on strike and in November Veroljub Stevanovic, the managing director sacked in 1992, was elected mayor for the opposition Zajedno movement. His was one of many opposition election victories whose attempted annulment by Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's president, sparked three months of nationwide demonstrations. 

The disintegration of former Yugoslavia and four years of trade sanctions against Serbia severed access to markets, raw materials and components, dealing a near-lethal blow to dozens of plants like Zastava.

Trade sanctions were lifted last year in return for Serbian compliance with the Dayton peace agreements, which ended the war in Bosnia. But financial sanctions that bar Serbia from membership in the International Monetary Fund and access to international capital markets remain in force.

The collapse of Zastava has created huge social problems for the one-company town. ''Over 70,000 are waiting for a job, another 30,000 are on enforced 'vacation' and the population is swollen with 5,000 Serb refugees,'' Stevanovic says. ''This city has the greatest social problems in Europe.'' The mayor believes Zastava could be revived, but only with foreign investment and new management to replace the party hacks put in when anti-Milosevic dissidents like him were sacked.

''Executives from Hyundai, Renault and Fiat itself have all looked around recently. We know there are too many workers and there will have to be retrenchments. But the real problem is that the communists are still in power -- and that is simply not attractive to anyone,'' Stevanovic says.

Only 50 km from Belgrade, in the steel town of Smederevo, life is significantly different. The steel complex was always a heavy loss maker. But it received much investment in the early 1980s, although the plant was closed when sanctions were imposed in 1992.

Yet unlike Kragujevac with its opposition mayor, Smederevo's managers smoothly switched allegiance from the Communist party to Milosevic. With this level of political support, workers at Smederevo continued to receive their pay during the four years until it reopened last year. The plant is expected to produce 1.2 million tonnes of steel products this year, mostly for export.

The export drive reflects both depressed domestic demand and the government's need for hard currency.

Serbia's trade deficit was more than US$1 billion last year and rising. ''The problem is that Serbia's biggest exporters are also its biggest importers. The more they produce the bigger the deficit,'' worries Goran Pitic, head of research at Belgrade's Economics Institute. Danica Popovic, at the rival Centre for Economic Studies, adds: ''There is no economic strategy and that means there is no direction at the micro level at all. The people that run plants like Smederevo and Zastava are apparatchiks, not managers.''

Popovic is skeptical of the government's new-found belief in privatization, noting that 96% of the country's assets are still in state hands. But about 35% of economic output is produced by the private sector, she says.

Serbian industry is still working at only 36% capacity against 73% in 1989. Serbia has survived by consuming its capital, including the estimated US$4 billion in effect stolen from private hard currency accounts in 1991.

The economic cost of Milosovic's failed attempt to create a Greater Serbia is borne by ordinary Serbs whose average annual income has fallen by more than 50% to about US$1,500 since 1990. But while Serbia has stagnated in isolation, other former Yugoslav republics, especially Slovenia and Croatia, have forged ahead with economic stabilization and privatization. They have created strong, convertible currencies backed by growing foreign currency reserves and attracted foreign investment.

Serbia's best hopes for economic recovery lie in restoring economic and trade links with these independent states.

Even under the most optimistic assumptions, however, Serbia faces a struggle to rebuild its economy. It will no longer receive a share of Slovenia's export revenues or the hard currency tourist receipts of Croatia, both of which helped to sustain it in the days of federal Yugoslavia. And as long as Milosevic remains in control, it will also be hamstrung by financial sanctions.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Column


Copyright 1997 Financial Post Ltd.


198 of 348 DOCUMENTS


San Jose Mercury News (California)


July 4, 1999 Sunday MORNING FINAL EDITION


RESENTMENT OF MILOSEVIC GROWING AMONG SERBS


BYLINE: JEFFREY FLEISHMAN, Knight Ridder News Service


SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 17A


LENGTH: 964 words


DATELINE: LAPLJE SELO, Yugoslavia


The wheat is ready for harvest, but the combines are out of gas and the Serb farmers are scared to work the fields. They sit in the shade of a cherry tree, cursing war and drinking homemade brandy until their wives collect them.

Just beyond them, NATO troops patrol narrow roads. Returning ethnic Albanian refugees seek revenge for years of Serb oppression. There seems to be no safe place. And the men are angry that the Kosovo land their families have farmed for generations is suddenly in jeopardy. 

The brandy stops flowing and words grow more bitter when someone mentions Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. The Serb farmers of Laplje Selo, like increasing numbers of people in their country, despise him. They blame Milosevic for plundering a country and twisting Serb nationalism into a sin that triggered NATO airstrikes and saddled a bankrupt Yugoslavia with $40 billion worth of ruin.

"A crook," one farmer says.

"Evil," another says.

Disdain sweeps country

Disdain for Milosevic is sweeping Yugoslavia. Elderly Serbs surviving on pensions of $22 a month marched against Milosevic last week in Belgrade. Tens of thousands of others -- including underpaid soldiers -- joined anti-Milosevic rallies in Cacak and other cities, demanding his resignation. The Serbian Orthodox Church has called for him to step down. Crown Prince Alexander, heir to Yugoslavia's exiled monarchy, described Milosevic as a "monster" who "must go, for the sake of Yugoslavia."

The surge of opposition is reminiscent of 1996, when students and intellectuals protested Milosevic's corrupt government and militant nationalism that was tugging Yugoslavia further away from Europe.

Milosevic outlasted his detractors, dividing opposition leaders and strengthening his power. Some diplomats predict Milosevic will escape defeat again, but many Serbs say their president has shamed them for the last time.

"He's the traitor to Serb nationalism," said Momcilo Trajkovic, president of the Serbian Democratic Movement, a small opposition party founded by Trajkovic in his hometown.

In a stunning reversal of fortune, the Serbs, who once controlled Kosovo with paramilitary police, are increasingly vulnerable to ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the population. The Serbs of Laplje Selo don't like the odds.

Across Kosovo, ethnic Albanians are looting and burning Serb homes. Serbs are winding up dead on roadsides. More than 80,000 of Kosovo's 200,000 Serbs have fled.

Most of Laplje Selo's 2,000 residents are staying put, though many farmers have sent their wives and children away until tensions ease. And a few village leaders, such as the baker, Stojan Nedeljkovic, are packing cars and tractors with furniture and clothes, just in case.

Remaining in the village is difficult, as farmers such as Zika Jovic can't sell summer squash and other vegetables because ethnic Albanians are boycotting Serb products.

'We're scared'

"No one wants our cheese, bread or vegetables," Jovic said. "We have to give it to the cows to eat. I have to sell eggs to buy cigarettes, but now I can't even go to the market.

"We're scared. We're like prisoners. Milosevic promised so much. But we have nothing. There's not even room for us in Serbia if we leave Kosovo. The wars Milosevic started in Bosnia and Croatia have already flooded the country with Serb refugees."

West of the Kosovo capital of Pristina, where the land flattens, Laplje Selo is marked by the silver domes of St. Sveta Petka church. The cemetery is wild with weeds and shiny with black granite markers, some bearing the names -- as folklore has it -- of those cursed to die young because their parents once sold land to Albanians.

Centuries ago, Serbs battled the Turks for this land. Then came the Germans. And last summer, 200 village men grabbed rifles and formed night patrols to protect 1,500 acres of wheat from guerrillas in the Kosovo Liberation Army. They feared the KLA might torch the fields.

Down the road at the village's co-operative farm office, the combines needed gasoline. War disrupted supplies, and farmers say Albanians are selling to Serbs at highly inflated prices.

Momcilo Trajkovic, the president of the Serbian Democratic Movement, said: "I feel the anger of Albanians. But now there is a tragedy against the Serbs, and NATO is doing little to stop it."

Remembering 1389

Slavoljub Mitic stopped at Zivko Nacic's general store for a beer. Rain, sweeping across the wheat fields, chased him and other men under a corrugated tin roof. They sat, listened to thunder, joked about NATO cluster bombs and talked about 1389, when Serbian Prince Lazar battled the Turks on Kosovo's Field of Blackbirds.

Lazar's army was defeated and he was killed.

But every Serb child is taught the poem about the epic battle, the bravery, the religious devotion, and the myths that sprang from Kosovo. Mitic remembersin 1989 when Milosevic traveled to Kosovo and ignited his political career by extolling Serb nationalism and the virtues of the prince.

But Mitic said Milosevic is no Lazar.

"We need changes in Yugoslavia," Mitic said. "We need Milosevic out. He lost Bosnia. He lost Croatia. Now, he's lost Kosovo. He lost it all. It's over. . . . Kosovo is the Serbian soul. Milosevic will be remembered in history for losing it."

Two heavily armed NATO soldiers walked past. Mitic and the others watched them round the bend in the road. Some of the men worried that NATO is not protecting their village, and many fear attacks from ethnic Albanians if they go to harvest their wheat.

"We must do this harvest no matter what the fear," Rade Djorovic said. "My family has been here for centuries. I have never missed a harvest. Fear has never kept us out of the fields."


LOAD-DATE: October 25, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: The Kosovo Conflict
RELATED STORIES: Page 17A

199 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Sunday Mail (Queensland, Australia)


July 18, 1999, Sunday


SERB CIVIL WAR THREAT


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: JACK KELLEY


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 49


LENGTH: 340 words


Serb civil war threat

JACK KELLEY

SERBIA'S most powerful opposition leader has warned Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic that Serbs "are ready to spill their blood" if he does not resign.

"Civil war, chaos and bloodshed are just around the corner if his regime does not step down peacefully," Vuk Draskovic said. "I, with the people, am ready to act. We demand a new future, and Milosevic is not part of it." 

The ultimatum came amid a growing anti-Milosevic wave across the country this weekend. Opposition parties hope it will gain enough momentum for a march on the capital by the end of the month. Army reservists took to the streets in two towns on Friday demanding to be paid.

Thousands of people have signed anti-government petitions across the country and thousands more attended rallies calling for the Yugoslav president to step down.

Almost a month after NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia ended, the groundswell against the defiant Yugoslav president is building steadily.

In Kraljevo, 120km south of Belgrade, more than 10,000 protesters rallied to demand Milosevic's resignation.

Zoran Djindic, leader of the opposition Democratic Party, told the rally: "Milosevic has nowhere to run."

In Nis, south-west of the capital, hundreds of reservists occupied a square to demand pay for serving during the bombing, and decent treatment of military victims and their families.

Four more town councils in Serbia passed resolutions calling on Milosevic to resign, making a total of 11, but his allies have vowed to use force to stop protests. They have destroyed pro-democracy petitions, smashed tables where opposition leaders have collected signatures and arrested protest leaders.

"We will defend ourselves against the protesting moral scum," said Yugoslav Left spokesman Ivan Markovic. "We cannot let the traitors win."

Despite the threats, Mr Draskovic, who mobilised tens of thousands of Serbs for demonstrations against Milosevic in the winter of 1996-97, said he believed "the time is right" for a mass movement.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: SML


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


200 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Washington Post


August 8, 2000, Tuesday, Final Edition


WORLD; In Brief


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A18


LENGTH: 1316 words


 

ASIA

South Asian Flooding Kills Hundreds

PATNA, India--Floods caused by a monsoon deluge have killed hundreds of people and destroyed the homes of millions more in India, Bangladesh and Bhutan, officials said yesterday.

"We're still flying in the dark as far as the number of people homeless are concerned, but I think you're talking over 2 million," said Patrick Fuller, South Asia spokesman for the International Federation of Red Cross and Crescent Societies.

In India's Bihar state, the government said 20 people died, 1 million were displaced, 1,015 villages were inundated, 4,000 houses were destroyed and road and rail links were washed away.

Officials said thousands of marooned villagers in Bihar, one of India's poorest states, had refused to move to relief camps, fearing their farm animals and belongings would be stolen. 

(Reuters)

Philippines Ransom Payments Disclosed

MANILA--Muslim rebels who kidnapped Westerners and Asians have received $ 5.5 million in ransom payments, military chief Angelo Reyes said.

Reyes inadvertently disclosed the payments at a cabinet meeting led by President Joseph Estrada, who immediately cut the session short because of the presence of journalists. "We can talk about that privately, not in this forum," Estrada said.

The Philippines formally refuses to pay ransoms, and officials have never publicly confirmed that large amounts were paid to Abu Sayyaf, a small group of rebels fighting for an independent Muslim state in the southern Philippines.

In recent weeks, the group has freed a German and six Malaysians it seized in April at a Malaysian diving resort along with 14 others. The group also holds three French TV reporters and 12 Philippine members of a Christian evangelical group.

(Associated Press)

EUROPE

Milosevic Gets 2 More Challengers

BELGRADE--Formalizing a breach in opposition ranks, a coalition seeking to oust Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic in Sept. 24 elections nominated its own candidate, the third challenger to Milosevic thus far.

Most opposition parties in Serbia--Yugoslavia's dominant republic--endorsed Vojislav Kostunica, candidate of the small, center-right Democratic Party of Serbia. He has a reputation as a moderate nationalist and is widely respected for his decade-long opposition to the autocratic Milosevic.

Kostunica's nomination came a day after Yugoslavia's largest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, broke ranks with other anti-Milosevic groups and nominated Belgrade Mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic.

Earlier today, the ultranationalist Serbian Radical Party announced it had nominated Tomislav Nikolic.

(Associated Press)

THE AMERICAS

Children's Disappearances Investigated

GUATEMALA CITY--Guatemala's first report on the abduction and ultimate disappearance of hundreds of children during the country's 36-year civil war blames the country's armed forces for 92 percent of the incidents.

The 200-page study, by the human rights office of Guatemala's Roman Catholic archdiocese, interviewed parents and relatives of some of the more than 400 children it says disappeared. Most were lost in Guatemala's western highlands in the early 1980s, as leftist guerrillas fought army troops.

"This report aims to prevent such . . . pain and suffering from occurring again in Guatemala," the office coordinator, Bishop Mario Rios Montt, told reporters. Rios Montt's predecessor, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, was bludgeoned to death in 1998, the day after his office released a report blaming the army for the majority of wartime atrocities.

The new report said abductions were committed almost exclusively by the army, but in a few cases by pro-government paramilitary groups or leftist guerrillas. Other children became separated from their parents while fleeing combatants, it said.

(Reuters)

THE MIDDLE EAST

Iran's Hard-Liners Crack Down on Press

TEHRAN--Iran's supreme religious leader closed off legislative debate on a liberalized press law, while hard-line security forces arrested a reformist journalist and shut down a newspaper.

Ayatollah Ali Khamenei ordered a halt to debate on a bill proposed by President Mohammed Khatemi, a measure that would have replaced a restrictive press law installed by hard-liners shortly before reformists won control of the legislature in February elections.

Following the order, plainclothes police arrested journalist Ahmad Zeidabadi, apparently as a result of newspaper articles he published last year, his brother said. Also, authorities ordered the weekly paper Cheshmeh Ardebil in northwestern Iran to close for four months for "disturbing public opinion" and "insulting Islamic sanctities," the daily Abrar reported.

(Associated Press)

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They have nightmares, and some of them wet their beds. They regress to an infantile stage."

-- Clara Barona, UNICEF spokeswoman in Colombia, on the effects on children of Colombia's civil war


LOAD-DATE: August 08, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Washington Post


201 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


October 5, 1999, Tuesday


Assassin at the wheel: Draskovic


SOURCE: * AFP, AP


BYLINE: * Correspondents in Belgrade


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 430 words


SERB opposition leader Vuk Draskovic yesterday claimed a car crash he was involved in at the weekend was an assassination attempt.

The accident, which claimed the lives of four of his entourage, occurred as mass demonstrations against the regime of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic took place throughout Serbia for the 13th consecutive day, bringing tens of thousands of people out on to the streets.

Mr Draskovic, president of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), said the car in which he was travelling swerved off the road to avoid hitting a truck. 

The car his security team was travelling in hit the truck head-on.

"We are talking about an obvious assassination attempt, and with God's will everybody was killed but myself," Mr Draskovic said.

"Let those who carried it out reflect well on what will happen to them."

Mr Draskovic was slightly injured in the accident, which happened near Lazarevac, 40km south of Belgrade.

Killed in the accident were Mr Draskovic's security chief, Zvonko Osmajlic; two other members of the security team, Dragan Vusurevic and Vusur Rakocevic; and Mr Draskovic's brother-in-law Veselin Boskovic, an official in the Belgrade municipality. "The truck suddenly, without any reason ... switched to our side of the road and it was clear to me that it had intended to kill me," Mr Draskovic said.

Borivoje Borovic, a member of the SPO's directorate, said visibility was good, the road was straight and that the truck driver disappeared after the crash.

An investigating magistrate said the truck had been driving on the wrong side of the road at the time of the collision "for reasons yet unknown".

Meanwhile, amid daily signs of dissent on the streets of Yugoslavia, Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party and a central figure in the anti-Milosevic rallies, yesterday claimed Mr Milosevic planned to provoke violence at street protests to create a pretext for a crackdown on opponents.

"There are secret plans ... to stage an incident in which a number of policemen would be hurt, to put the blame on opposition, reshape public opinion and then move to arrest protest leaders, ban the rallies and introduce a form of emergency situation," Mr Djindjic said.

Mr Djindjic, who has always advocated peaceful protests, said he knew of the plan from insiders close to Mr Milosevic.

"I hope that people in the police and the army are alert to this ... Milosevic applied such tactics in (the wars) in Croatia, Bosnia, in Kosovo ... to provoke violence, push people into bloodshed and then play the peacemaker."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


202 of 348 DOCUMENTS




The Washington Post


March 13, 2003 Thursday  
Final Edition


Serbia's Pro-Western Premier Is Assassinated in Belgrade


BYLINE: Michael Dobbs, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 884 words


DATELINE: BRUSSELS March 12


Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic, chief organizer of the October 2000 democratic revolution that toppled Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, was shot and killed today by snipers as he approached the door of his government headquarters in Belgrade.

The Serbian government immediately declared a state of emergency, suspending all political activity in the Balkan republic of 10 million people and reintroducing rigid controls on the news media. Police officers and army troops began a massive hunt for Djindjic's killers, setting up roadblocks around the capital and halting all bus, rail and plane traffic out of the city.

Late in the day, the government said the killing was the work of a criminal gang whose leaders include Milorad Lukovic, the former head of an elite paramilitary police unit called the Red Berets. "The assassination of Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic represents an attempt by this group to stop the fight against organized crime that just started and for them to avoid their own arrest," the government said in a statement. It did not offer evidence to support that claim.  

Djindjic was one of Washington's closest allies in the region.

News media in Belgrade reported that two men were taken into custody. The murder plunged Serbia into a political crisis following 21/2 years of democratic rule and more than a half-century of authoritarianism, first under the Communists, then under Milosevic, a Communist-turned-Serbian nationalist.

Many Serbian observers said there was no obvious replacement for Djindjic. "He was the person who held everything together -- cutting deals, twisting arms, buying other parties out," said Ljiljana Smajlovic, a leading political commentator.

Djindjic and Vojislav Kostunica, his rival and collaborator in the movement that toppled Milosevic, dominated Serbian politics for the past two years. Kostunica, who succeeded Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia and stepped down earlier this month when the country was restructured into a looser federation called Serbia and Montenegro, remains a highly popular figure in Serbia.

The assassination bore the marks of a professional killing and a well-organized conspiracy.

Djindjic, using crutches because of a sports injury, was struck in the abdomen and back by two bullets from high-powered rifles as he walked the few steps from his armored automobile to a door at his headquarters. Police said multiple snipers apparently fired from the third floor of an abandoned building across the street. Another bullet hit Djindjic's car.

He was rushed to a hospital alive. But he died there at 1:30 p.m. Belgrade time, the government said.

Djindjic narrowly survived an apparent assassination attempt last month when a truck swerved into his convoy of cars. He blamed the incident on organized crime.

In just over two years as Serbian prime minister, Djindjic made powerful enemies, including ousted Communist and nationalist leaders, criminals and dissident factions in the secret police and army.

Djindjic was particularly detested by people close to the former, post-Communist government for giving in to intense Western pressure and extraditing Milosevic and several of his close associates to the U.N. war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

There is a long tradition of political assassinations in Serbia, which was the largest republic in Yugoslavia, a six-nation federation that disintegrated in bloody civil wars lasting through most of the 1990s. Gangland killings and political murders became common toward the end of Milosevic's long rule, as criminal groups vied for control over the economy and the government lashed out at political enemies. Such killings continued after Milosevic's fall.

Serbia's deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic, decried "a clear attempt by those who in the past have tried to stop Serbia's progress and democratization by assassinations to change the course of history and once again isolate Serbia."

President Stipe Mesic of Croatia, which broke away from Yugoslavia in 1991, described the murder as "an act of madness" that would slow Serbia's progress toward democracy.

Djindjic's willingness to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal, and his attempts to introduce market-oriented economic changes, made him a favorite of Western governments, including the United States.

In a statement today, President Bush said: "History will remember Prime Minister Djindjic for his strong leadership during Serbia's successful struggle to end the dictatorship of Slobodan Milosevic. . . . At the helm of the new government, Prime Minister Djindjic was committed to building a prosperous, democratic future for Serbia."

Djindjic led a 17-member coalition that had a tenuous majority in parliament following the splintering of the reform coalition that toppled Milosevic. He had earlier fallen out with Kostunica, his principal ally in the anti-Milosevic movement.

The emergency regulations, commentator Smajlovic said, mean Djindjic's allies will be able to rule by decree for a limited time. But the coalition of small parties is seen by analysts to lack political legitimacy, and would almost certainly be defeated in any election. Under Serbia's constitution, the acting president will nominate a successor to Djindjic, subject to parliament's approval.


LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2003 The Washington Post


203 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


July 5, 1999 Monday Final Edition


SERBIAN LEADER RETURNS FROM EXILE;
SAYS HE'LL RISK JAIL TO AVOID MORE CIVIL WAR


BYLINE: MARK FINEMAN, LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. C12


LENGTH: 462 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


In a direct challenge to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, Serbian opposition leader Zoran Djindjic returned to Belgrade yesterday from self-imposed exile, declaring he preferred the risk of prison to the prospect of civil war.

"I believe we must, as democrats, do all (we can) to avoid the risk of civil war in this country," the 46-year-old president of Serbia's Democratic Party told reporters and dozens of cheering supporters moments after he landed at Belgrade's airport on a flight from the neighbouring republic of Montenegro.

Djindjic, who said he left Serbia on May 10 amid death threats from paramilitary forces at the height of NATO's air war, added: "But I don't believe Milosevic can take the risk to arrest me and provoke protests around Serbia." 

The opposition leader's homecoming, after weeks of touring Europe to condemn Milosevic's regime and garner postwar support for opposition-ruled Serbian towns, appeared to have presented the Yugoslav president with a lose-lose situation.

For days, Belgrade's state-run media had stressed that Djindjic faced criminal charges if he returned, for draft-dodging and "failure to report a change of address" after he fled.

oThose charges carry prison terms ranging from two months to 20 years. Analysts here said a failure to arrest Djindjic would be seen by many as a sign of weakness by Milosevic's government.

But the arrest of a leader whose party is at the vanguard of nascent street protests in Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, would be viewed as a harsh crackdown on pro-democracy forces at a time when Milosevic and his nation are already isolated from European neighbours and the rest of the free world.

OUTNUMBERED

After Djindjic strode past the uniformed Serbian police officers who had deployed in strength for his arrival, the opposition leader gave credit for his unscathed return to the assembled reporters and camera operators, who far outnumbered the police.

Then he fired his first salvo against the Yugoslav president: "Most people know the reality. With Milosevic in power, Serbia hasn't a future."

Djindjic brushed aside the deep divisions among Serbia's major pro-democracy parties.

"The people are united," he insisted. "The change must be democratic, not radical and extreme. And the opposition and the Alliance for Change (anti-Milosevic coalition) are strong enough to take the direction for change."

Commenting on the rift between his party and the larger Serbian Renewal Movement of sometime opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, who has told his party members not to attend the Alliance for Change rallies that began last week, he said: "It's not up to me. It's up to Mr. Draskovic. ... I'm ready to forget the past. We have a lot to do in the future."


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo by Dragan Filipovic, The Associated Press; Serbian opposition leader Zoran Djindjic waves to supporters in this 1996 file photo during an anti-government protest in Belgrade. He returned to Serbia yesterday despite the threat of arrest.

204 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


April 28, 1999 Wednesday Final Edition


DRASKOVIC BACKTRACKS ON NATO FORCE


BYLINE: SPECTATOR WIRE SERVICES


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. C1


LENGTH: 538 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


A man once considered a mouthpiece for Slobodan Milosevic has suddenly upstaged the Yugoslav president by suggesting that NATO troops could play a role in Kosovo.

Deputy Premier Vuk Draskovic said Monday that Yugoslavia would accept a UN peacekeeping force for Kosovo that could include soldiers from NATO countries.

What's more, Draskovic said both Milosevic and Russian envoy Viktor Chernomyrdin shared the same view in his separate conversations with them. 

But yesterday, he pulled back. Asked by reporters if he and Milosevic specifically talked about whether such a force should be armed, he said: "We did not discuss this." That cast doubt on his assertion that Milosevic has accepted the concept of NATO troops in Kosovo.

Such a stance would mark a huge concession by Milosevic, who has steadily rejected the idea of any foreign armed forces in Kosovo, especially from "aggressor countries," his term for NATO members.

Draskovic would only say yesterday that Milosevic would accept a UN-sponsored force.

"I think President Milosevic is ready, and must be ready, to accept a Security Council resolution," he said. "Our obligation is to accept a UN Security Council resolution. They will decide the composition of the force."

Draskovic said nothing could be implemented until NATO stopped bombing and Yugoslav troops in Kosovo withdrew to the positions they held before the air strikes began over a month ago.

The U.S. and its allies continue to insist on a strong NATO-led force in Kosovo as part of any peace settlement.

But if Milosevic, Draskovic and Moscow are indeed of one mind, and Milosevic is using his deputy premier to unveil a new stand on Kosovo, then the two sides are closer than at any time since air strikes began March 24.

Still, Draskovic has a track record for unpredictability. His recent comments appear to be less a change in the thinking of the Yugoslav regime than an attempt to distance himself from Milosevic and position himself as a possible alternative to the Yugoslav president.

When he joined Milosevic's government in January, the flamboyant former opposition leader was accused of selling out by the anti-Milosevic movement.

After all, Draskovic was once beaten by Milosevic's police and played a key role in anti-government protests in 1996 and 1997.

For many, he turned into Milosevic's moderate voice once he joined the government.

After the start of the bombing campaign, Draskovic's language was pro-Serbian, but low-key compared to others in the Milosevic camp, who compared NATO to Nazis and U.S. President Bill Clinton to Adolf Hitler.

But he broke that mold on the weekend. In an interview with Studio B -- his party's television station -- the bearded firebrand suddenly condemned both the Yugoslav leadership and its propaganda campaign.

"Stop lying to the people in Serbia, and finally tell them the truth," he said. "The people should be told that NATO is not facing a breakdown, that Russia will not help Yugoslavia militarily, and that the world public opinion is against us."

In later interviews, he insisted he was not targeting Milosevic but criticizing hardline nationalists grouped around the other deputy prime minister, Vojislav Seselj.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo of VUK DRASKOVIC


Copyright 1999 Metroland Media Group Ltd


205 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE AUSTRALIAN


February 10, 1997, Monday


TUBE


BYLINE: Kevin Dickson


SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 18


LENGTH: 816 words


HITLER'S Henchmen (SBS, 8.30pm, 8pm SA) reaches its conclusion tonight with a profile of Karl Doenitz, Hitler's Admiral of the Fleet and successor. True to its high standard, this impeccably researched series finds both witnesses and historical footage showing that while Doenitz may be the least notorious of Hitler's main men, he was personally one of the most barbaric, the ultimate shadow minister, wrapped in servility and so desperate to infiltrate Hitler's circle of trustees that he drove his U-Boat fleet to ruthless victories merely to impress his Fuhrer.

And when he realised that Hitler was only impressed by victories on land, he stepped up his vicious U-Boat attacks.

Amid all the explosive footage of U-Boat bombings comes a shocking statistic: of 39,000 U-Boat sailors, 28,000 died. 

Doenitz is revealed to be a hard man, with a passion for weaponry, gadgetry and idolatry. As this excellent series ends, it leaves viewers with the impression of the Nazi party as a hellish boys club, each member pathetically in awe of a madman, and intentionally alerts the viewer to the facility with which Hitler was able to mobilise a nation under a banner of hate.

While it is definitely accurate to say that Bourbon Street in New Orleans is one of the ugliest strips of neonand liquor-drenched bars in the world, once a year its Mardi Gras festival transforms it into an ugly neon strip bursting at the seams with revelry, glitter and more excess than usual. Cutting Loose (SBS 11.05pm, 10.35pm SA) covers the weeks of meticulous preparation the city undergoes in the lead-up to the big event, spending time with spangly local low-lifes as they stitch, tease and thread their way to sub-Vegas glamour and glitz. Winner of the best cinematography and filmmakers trophy at The Sundance Film Festival, it captures another drunken, flashy global spectacle without making you wish you were there.

Foreign Correspondent (ABC, 9.30pm), Australia's most uncompromising and best researched current affairs show returns for its sixth season tonight, with George Negus (pictured) again filling the hot seat, and a typically strong round of global reporting. First off is a report from Indonesia on the spate of violent rioting that has besieged the country -3 per cent of the population are Chinese yet they control 75 per cent of the wealth, and most of the riot attacks have been on the Chinese. Eric Campbell infiltrates the Belgrade student movement to report on the anti-Milosevic revolution and finds a society once reviled as warmongers now potentially taking its first steps towards democracy. Finally, there's a delightful Postcard segment on a Melbourne tram driver who, upon seeing that Calcutta shared the same tramway system on a holiday, made it his work to salvage the Calcutta trams.

In its cliffhanger last season, Mad About You (Ten, 7.30pm) took the drastic step of leaving its maniacally monogamous twosome teetering on the edge of divorce (which in this couple-crazed comedy is the equivalent of the apocalypse).

Tonight the embattled enamorados have to sort out the fallout of infidelity (she only kissed a guy, for heck's sake), and they do so in a surprisingly dramatic and powerful park-bench argument scene.

During this scene, backed by a strong script, Helen Hunt (pictured) reveals considerable acting talent and again proves she is the show's linchpin.

Paul Reiser sticks to his limpid schmuck schtick (one of the show's main deterrents -he's horrible). Ed Asner appears as an amusingly crass father-inlaw, a role that inadvertently makes the point that Mad About You's greatest strength has always been its inventive casting and writing of the peripheral roles.

On exactly the same day, one year apart, the cities of Los Angeles and Kobe were hit by huge earthquakes of almost identical magnitude.

The difference between the two quakes was the death toll: The LA quake, with its epicentre located in Northbridge, north of the city, took 57 lives.

In Kobe, the quake struck the city centre, devastating the entire city and residential blocks, killing 5400 people. The Day the Earth Shook (SBS, 8.30pm, 8pm SA) brings home both the horror of the Kobe quake and the unbelievable good luck of its LA counterpart with scenes captured in Japan by security surveillance cameras in offices and convenience stores at the peak of the quake -desks literally slam from wall to wall as the earth heaves in every direction. Seismologists then use this video evidence to ascertain what type of construction fares better under quake conditions, extrapolating the secure movement of a potato chip display stand into safer interior furnishing for homes in quake zones. And since millions of dollars in seismic equipment failed to predict either earthquake, scientists are looking into natural detection devices, which seem to be implanted in every dog, bird and cat.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 1997 Nationwide News Pty Limited


206 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Toronto Star


November 10, 2011 Thursday


Back in the game


BYLINE: Haroon Siddiqui Toronto Star


SECTION: OPINION; Pg. A23


LENGTH: 763 words


Just before landing in Belgrade, I wonder what Canadians might think of when they think about Serbia - the homeland of tennis aces Novak Djokovic and Jelena Jankovic, of soccer star Nemanja Vidic of Manchester United, and of world champion basketball teams. Also the land where 250,000 civilians were ethnically cleansed in the 1990s, where Canadian peacekeepers went to keep a non-existent peace, where NATO mounted a 78-day air war in 1999, and where Slobodan Milosevic was eventually overthrown in 2000 and sent off to the war crimes tribunal at The Hague, after which President Boris Tadic, a moderate democrat, has turned the pariah state into a credible candidate for membership in the European Union.

A few days later, I watch Tadic welcome the annual congress of PEN International, the writers' group. He speaks extempore and well. Acknowledging the past, he says Serbia is trying to get along with the constituent parts of the former Yugoslavia that went their separate ways - Croatia, Slovenia, Macedonia, Bosnia and Montenegro. 

"What about Kosovo?" mutter some impolite writers, about the Serbian refusal to accept the state that declared independence in 2008. Tadic does not hear, or pretends not to.

Kosovo - the home of "sacred Serb sites," dating back to the Ottoman times - is a taboo topic. Even the seemingly apolitical Djokovic, known for clowning on the court, has strong views on the subject.

Tadic must pay lip service to nationalism and even subsidize the Serb enclave in northern Kosovo abutting Serbia. He also expresses rhetorical solidarity with the much larger Serbian enclave in Bosnia, called Republika Srpska.

But he must not inflame passions. That's the EU requirement for Serbia's possible membership, along with the demand, already fulfilled, of handing over war criminals.

A majority of Serbs, 53 per cent, want to join the EU (as per a poll taken before the current euro crisis). Nearly 60 per cent accept that Kosovo is lost. But there's still a constituency - conservative, Orthodox - that thinks of Russia, historic ally against the Ottomans, as a better alternative to Europe. This crowd includes young rednecks with tattoos of the cross and Saint Lazar, the 14th century prince of Serbia who waged the Battle of Kosovo against the Ottomans.

Politicians do not want to take on the nationalists, at least not until after the next election due in April.

"The past is so painful that people want to forget and get on with life," says Vida Ognjenovic. "But one must go back and dwell on it and learn the lessons that need to be learned." She is a historic figure - a playwright, drama professor and co-founder of the Democratic party that was in the vanguard of the anti-Milosevic movement.

In 1991, she was artistic director of the National Theatre in Belgrade when 50,000 protesters filled the square in front of the 19th century building. But there was a ban on public speaking. She invited the leaders of the march in and let them use the second floor balcony to address the crowd, using the theatre's sound system. She was promptly fired.

That was when leading members of the Orthodox Church and the world of academe supported Milosevic and his criminal gangs. They have had a lot to live down since.

Yet other intellectuals feel they were "misled and manipulated, and feel complicit, too," she says.

As for the majority population, it paid the price of world opprobrium and economic sanctions. The young left in droves. Some saw sports as a way out, most famously using empty, financially drained swimming pools for tennis.

The bruised national psyche is also shaped by the famous Serbian characteristic of inat (ee-nat), stubbornness to the point of being detrimental to one's own interest or, positively, forbearance against heavy odds, as in war or sports.

Conversations with Serbs - in Belgrade's bustling sidewalk cafes and in the countless bookstores that dot street corners and at literary festivals - reveal a conflicted people: Yes, something terrible happened but it happened because Croats, Bosnians and Kosovars were doing bad things to us. They, too, committed war crimes, yet we got punished more. And now the European Union is pushing us around, as a price of entry.

It's hard to work up sympathy for any of this, especially given the public reaction even this year to the arrest of war criminal Ratko Mladic, the butcher of Bosnia. He was hailed a hero, as had been Milosevic during his televised trial at The Hague.

Such is the milieu that Serbia's democrats must traverse. To their credit, they are traversing it well.

hsiddiqui@thestar.ca


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Tennis star Novak Djokovic represents the new face of Serbia as the country moves away from its troubled past. JACKY NAEGELEN/REUTERS


DOCUMENT-TYPE: COLUMN


PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER



Copyright 2011 Toronto Star Newspapers Limited


207 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


July 05, 1999, FINAL


Foe risks prison to battle Milosevic: Serbian says his arrest would provoke civil war


BYLINE: Mark Fineman


SECTION: News; A10


LENGTH: 476 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- In a direct challenge to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, Serbian opposition leader Zoran Djindjic returned from self-imposed exile yesterday, declaring that he preferred the risk of prison to the prospect of civil war.

''I believe we must, as democrats, do all (we can) to avoid the risk of civil war in this country,'' the 46-year-old president of Serbia's Democratic Party told reporters and dozens of cheering supporters moments after he landed at Belgrade's airport on a flight from the neighbouring republic of Montenegro.

Mr. Djindjic, who said he left Serbia on May 10 amid death threats from paramilitary forces at the height of NATO's air war, added: ''But I don't believe Milosevic can take the risk to arrest me and provoke protests around Serbia.'' 

The opposition leader's homecoming, after weeks of touring Europe to condemn Mr. Milosevic's regime and garner postwar support for opposition-ruled Serbian towns, appeared to have presented the Yugoslav president with a lose-lose situation.

For days, Belgrade's state-run media had stressed that Mr. Djindjic faced criminal charges if he returned: for draft-dodging and ''failure to report a change of address'' after he fled.

Those charges carry prison terms ranging from two months to 20 years, and analysts in Belgrade said a failure to arrest Mr. Djindjic would be seen by many as a sign of weakness on the part of Mr. Milosevic's government.

But the arrest of a leader whose party is at the vanguard of nascent street protests in Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, would be viewed as a harsh crackdown on pro-democracy forces at a time when Mr. Milosevic and his nation are already isolated from their European neighbours and the rest of the free world.

After Mr. Djindjic strode past the uniformed Serbian police officers who had deployed in strength for his arrival, the opposition leader gave credit for his unscathed return to the assembled reporters and camera operators, who far outnumbered the police.

Then he fired his first salvo against the Yugoslav president: ''Most people know the reality. With Milosevic in power, Serbia hasn't a future.''

Mr. Djindjic brushed aside the deep divisions among Serbia's major pro-democracy parties.

''The people are united,'' he insisted. ''The change must be democratic, not radical and extreme. And the opposition and the Alliance for Change (anti-Milosevic coalition) are strong enough to take the direction for change.''

Commenting on the rift between his party and the larger Serbian Renewal Movement of opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, who has told his party members not to attend the Alliance for Change rallies that began last week, he said: ''It's not up to me. It's up to Mr. Draskovic. ... I'm ready to forget the past. We have a lot to do in the future.''
