The New York Post


August 7, 1999, Saturday


DEFIANT MILOSEVIC: HELL, NO, I WON'T GO!


BYLINE: NILES LATHEM


SECTION: Metro; Pg. 010


LENGTH: 472 words


A defiant Yugoslav strongman Slobodan Milosevic signaled yesterday he won't step down from power and blamed efforts to force his resignation on NATO "aggression" and "corrupt" local pols.

Speaking out for the first time since mass protests against his regime erupted across Serbia a month ago, the embattled leader threw down the gauntlet against his foes, and other allies signaled a long and possibly violent struggle lies ahead between Milosevic and his internal opponents.

Meeting with a group of migr Serbs, Milosevic said NATO, "with the help of various corrupt politicians and political parties, is trying to undermine our stability from within and realize in this manner the aims it failed to do with 22,000 tons of bombs fired on our country." 

"It would be sad if the extended hand of the evil which NATO committed against our country was a hand of our own citizens," he said.

"I am certain that this will not happen, I am certain that patriotism and love for the homeland will prevail over treason," Milosevic added.

Even more ominous was a speech given by Serbia's Interior Minister Vlajko Stojiljkovic, who has been indicted by the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal along with Milosevic, warning that he might unleash his dreaded "MUP" - the same storm troopers who terrorized ethnic Albanians in Kosovo - on Serbian anti-government protesters.

If anti-Milosevic forces threaten to destabilize the state, Stojiljkovic warned "police will act in keeping with the constitution and law and take measures to protect all citizens and property as well as their right to a free and safe life and work."

The strong words from Milosevic and his allies come at a time when opposition to his regime is spreading in the wake of the 11-week NATO bombing campaign, which ruined Serbia's infrastructure and economy.

The Clinton administration and other NATO countries have been giving covert help to Serbian opposition groups and are saying publicly that there will be no wartime reconstruction aid to Serbia as long as Milosevic remains in power.

Pressure on the Serb leader is expected to increase in the next few weeks with plans by the government of Yugoslavian province Montenegro to break free of Serbia's dominance and plans for a major demonstration by the Serbian Orthodox Church and a coalition of opposition parties.

Balkan analysts see the latest developments as a sign that Milosevic is growing increasingly alarmed about the internal turmoil surrounding his 10-year rule and plans to fight back against his opponents.

"He's trying to derail this movement and to discredit the opposition. I think the fact that he had to make a statement himself indicates that he takes these demonstrations very seriously," said Kurt Basseuner of the Balkans Action Council, a Washington-based think tank.


LOAD-DATE: August 8, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 N.Y.P. Holdings, Inc. All rights reserved.


209 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Contra Costa Times (California)


September 30, 2000 Saturday FINAL EDITION


YUGOSLAVIAN GROUPS STRIKE TO FORCE MILOSEVIC'S HAND;
THE GOVERNMENT SAYS NO CANDIDATE WON A MAJORITY SO AN OCT. 8 RUNOFF IS NECESSARY


BYLINE: Katarina Kratovac


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A15


LENGTH: 821 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


Blocking roads and shutting down shops, movie theaters and coal mines, tens of thousands of Yugoslavs heeded opposition calls for a nationwide strike Friday to force President Slobodan Milosevic to step down.

As opposition leaders explained the campaign to 25,000 supporters in Belgrade's main square, students rallied in the country's south, shopkeepers closed down in the east and television workers cut off transmissions in the north.

The opposition called the protests to pressure Milosevic to admit that challenger Vojislav Kostunica won Sunday's presidential election.

Milosevic admits he finished second, but his government says no candidate won a majority so an Oct. 8 runoff is necessary. 

"Cease your work, come out and stay on the streets so that this country will find its path to (the) future," opposition leader Zoran Djindjic told the Belgrade crowd.

"Serbia must stop for us to unload Milosevic out of a seat he no longer has a right to."

Serbia and the smaller Montenegro make up Yugoslavia.

The actors guild declared a strike, and most theater and cinema owners said they would shut down.

Several roads were blocked in northern and southern parts of Serbia, and over 7,000 coal miners stopped work in Kolubara, 25 miles south of Belgrade.

Two protests, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening, attracted a total of 50,000 people to Belgrade's main Republic Square.

Police briefly blocked one of three main bridges over the Sava River, trying to prevent people and a column of about 100 taxi drivers from joining the evening protest in the capital.

Outside Belgrade, thousands of high school students shunned classes in Nis, Serbia's third-largest city, and spilled into the streets some jumping out of first-floor classroom windows in their haste to attend the protest.

Waving anti-Milosevic banners, they chanted: "Save Serbia and kill yourself, Slobodan," while taxi drivers blockaded adjoining streets.

"I know why you are not in school today," Mayor Zoran Zivkovic told the students in Nis. "You refuse to accept injustice!"

Walkouts joined by shopkeepers and company employees were staged in a dozen other cities and towns, including the opposition strongholds of Cacak and Kragujevac.

Southern Valjevo was completely blocked and thousands protested in Kraljevo. In Novi Sad, state television employees stopped work.

A main highway in western Serbia was blocked for one hour by about 60 cabbies as a warning.

Also Friday, Serbia's opposition lodged an official complaint with the Federal Election Commission, providing its tally showing Kostunica beat Milosevic, 51.34 percent to 36.22 percent, in Sunday's vote.

If the commission fails to respond to the complaint, the opposition plans to press the case in the country's constitutional court. The opposition said it would dispatch delegations to army headquarters, the Interior Ministry and Serbian state television with documents proving its election victory.

An opposition member of the commission, Nebojsa Bakarac, told reporters Milosevic falsified more than a hundred thousand votes from polling places that never opened in Albanian-populated towns in Kosovo and that there was proof of ballots "cast" by dead voters.

Another critic of Milosevic, Bernard Kouchner, the U.N. administrator of Kosovo, accused the Yugoslav president of manipulating votes cast in that southern Yugoslav province.

Kouchner said that although the Milosevic camp says 140,000 people voted in Kosovo, the maximum was no more than 45,000 and probably much fewer according to the 300 teams of U.N. observers counting voters Sunday.

"This man is a liar," Kouchner said of Milosevic. "We were there, And exactly for this particular reason to avoid manipulation in Kosovo."

Kostunica urged an independent recount of the ballots, appealing "especially to neighboring Greece" to help ease tensions caused by the differing election figures. "It is more than necessary to count the votes again and examine the entire balloting material," Kostunica wrote in a letter made available to Associated Press.

Greece, a NATO member with close cultural and religious ties to Serbia, has suggested the opposition consider the possibility of taking part in the runoff if international election observers are allowed.

Bakarac the commission's opposition member rejected Greece's initiative, saying the opposition would not bargain with Milosevic on a runoff: "The truth is the truth, and it's not negotiable."

U.S. Defense Secretary William Cohen has praised the growing anti-Milosevic movement, and noted, without giving specifics, that American forces were "prepared for contingencies."

Many foreign leaders, including President Clinton, have promised to lift sanctions if Kostunica's victory is respected.

Croatia on Friday added its voice to nations recognizing Kostunica's victory, calling it a "vote for democracy."


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP
Thousands rally in Nis, Yugoslavia, on Friday. The opposition called the protests to pressure Slobodan Milosevic to admit that Vojislav Kostunica won Sunday's presidential election. (AP)

210 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


July 10, 1999 Saturday  
Late Edition


Milosevic may go but blood will spill;
* SERBIA


BYLINE: GEOFF KITNEY Herald Correspondent and RORY CARROLL of The Guardian


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; International News; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 972 words


THE first stirrings of revolution in Serbia against President Slobodan Milosevic are raising hopes his brutal reign may be coming to an end. But few expect him to go quietly.

As Serbian democrats mobilise in the hope of a "velvet" revolution such as saw the peaceful transfer of power from Communist dictatorship to liberal democracy elsewhere in eastern Europe, there is growing concern Milosevic and his fanatical supporters will resist change with force, prompting yet more bloodshed.

The strength and the speed with which grassroots hostility to Milosevic is emerging in Serbia suggest he faces the real prospect of a mass uprising. But his 10-year rule of Yugoslavia has been characterised by a ferocious determination to cling to power. 

His disastrous military adventures in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo have greatly diminished his standing with his people. But Milosevic has built a formidable security apparatus that most observers believe will stay loyal.

In the Government-run southern Serbian town of Prokuplje on Thursday night, demonstrators cheered as they trampled over scaffolding originally erected as a platform for a cancelled pro-government counter-rally.

At one point the local chief of the ruling Socialist Party, Ratko Zecevic, fired into the air from the balcony of the party office as the building was surrounded by 5,000 protesters.

Police made no effort to intervene when scuffles broke out between an elderly Socialist Party official and several protesters. Two Milosevic loyalists on a shop roof unveiled a banner insulting opposition leaders just as they climbed their own platform.

They retreated under a shower of rocks. It was when they were chased back to the party office that the shooting occurred. A knot of 15 Milosevic supporters was jostled after trying to heckle speakers.

The rally in Prokuplje, a market town, was the third organised by the Alliance for Change, an umbrella group of 30 parties, who hope to create enough momentum over the northern summer to stage protests in the capital, Belgrade.

The first rally, held last week in Cacak, was disrupted by a bomb believed to have been detonated by Milosevic supporters. No-one was injured.

At Tuesday's second rally, in Uzice, electricity to the public address system was cut off.

The campaign of rolling protests in southern and central Serbia is attempting to exploit the disaffection of army and police reservists who have not been paid for war service in Kosovo.

The state-controlled media have continued to ignore the protests.

Before speaking at Prokuplje, Zoran Djindjic, one of the alliance leaders, travelled to the Gracanica monastery in Kosovo, an area with several Serb villages, to ask the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Pavle, to support the campaign to

oust Milosevic.

Mr Djindjic was given a hostile reception by local Serbs, who accused him of abandoning them without food or aid since the Yugoslav army withdrew from Kosovo last month. Some members of the crowd called him a thief who wanted to steal Milosevic's position and shouted at leaders of the Serbian Orthodox church in Kosovo, warning them not to interfere in politics.

The Serbs first attacked reporters and then invaded a news conference that Mr Djindjic and members of the alliance were holding.

In the city of Leskovac, another former Milosevic stronghold, protesters filled the streets on Thursday night for the fourth consecutive night, calling for Milosevic's resignation and free elections. They also attacked the home of the local party leader, Zivojin Stefanovic.

Western observers see the Leskovac demonstrations as important because they appear to have been the spontaneous action of local people. Most other recent protests were organised by opposition groups.

The spark for the demonstrations in Leskovac was the action of a 31-year-old television technician without any history of political activism.

Last Friday night Ivan Novkovic interrupted the televising of a basketball match to broadcast a recording of himself accusing Mr Stefanovic of abusing his authority, appointing cronies to head local companies and destroying the local economy.

Mr Novkovic was arrested and sentenced to 30 days' jail, but his action appears to have turned him into a local hero.

The incident created a scramble by opposition parties to try to tap into the anti- Milosevic sentiment in his own political stronghold.

But this has highlighted the great weakness of the campaign to oust Milosevic and why his position appears to be secure for the time being at least - the Serbian opposition remains divided and leaderless.

Foreign observers believe the first real test of whether the anti-Milosevic movement can combine into a serious threat will come when the man regarded as Serbia's most respected political figure returns to Yugoslavia.

Dragoslav Avramovic, a former governor of the central bank who has played a key role in the creation of the Alliance for Change, is regarded as having the best chance of bringing divided opposition parties together under single leadership. He is due to return next week after receiving medical treatment in Switzerland.

But in a newspaper interview he warned that street protests against Milosevic would not lead far without a strategy for replacing him.

He warned that because of the war crimes charges Milosevic faces, he would be unlikely to give in to demands for his resignation.

Mr Avramovic said the only way Milosevic might agree to stand aside would be if he were given some guarantee he would not end up before the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Prospects the Western alliance might agree to such a guarantee seem remote. Whether Serbia's opposition leaders would be inclined to offer Milosevic such protection is also doubtful.

That leaves him with a very strong motive for retaining power, and using whatever means he has to.


LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

211 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Washington Post


September 21, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition


WORLD In Brief


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A22


LENGTH: 928 words


 

EUROPE

Thousands Rally for Milosevic Opponent

BELGRADE--More than 150,000 opponents of President Slobodan Milosevic applauded his chief political rival yesterday in a preelection rally where the crowd eclipsed a simultaneous pro-Milosevic gathering by more than 10 to 1.

Thousands of supporters of opposition presidential candidate Vojislav Kostunica assembled in front of the parliament building in Belgrade in a boisterous display of anti-Milosevic sentiment before presidential and parliamentary elections Sunday.

Many chanted "He's finished," or "Save Serbia from this madhouse, Kostunica." Others displayed anti-Milosevic slogans and jeered loudly at any mention of the president's name. 

"There is a great chance and hope that after [Sunday's] elections, we will begin a new life in different Serbia," Kostunica told the joyful crowd, concluding his speech with: "May God help you to have enough courage . . . to win freedom! For Serbia!"

Milosevic labeled his opponents "rats and hyenas" while on a campaign stop in Montenegro, the smaller of Yugoslavia's two republics, where pro-Western leaders have urged residents to boycott what it considers an unfair vote.

In Belgrade, the president addressed about 10,000 supporters in a sports hall across the Sava River while Kostunica prepared to speak. Although the size of the hall limited the crowd, the turnout for the candidates' rallies echoed the results of recent polls.

Opinion surveys show Kostunica with a double-digit lead on Milosevic. There are fears, however, that Milosevic would not concede a loss and could try to stay in power by rigging the vote or imposing martial law.

(Associated Press)

Russia Has Day of Mourning for Sub Crew

MOSCOW--Following Russian Orthodox tradition, Russians marked the 40th day after the sinking of the nuclear submarine Kursk, mourning the deaths of its 118 sailors and officers.

Russian officials say most of the Kursk's crew was probably killed instantly when the submarine was shattered by an explosion on Aug. 12. But some of the sailors may have remained alive for hours or even days after the disaster, as the submarine lay on the floor of the Barents Sea, officials have said.

Memorial services were held across Russia. Priests chanted liturgies in a chapel on the military base of Vidyayevo, out of which the Kursk sailed on its last voyage. And families of the seamen packed churches in the city of Kursk, for which the submarine was named and from which many of the crew came.

(Associated Press)

ASIA

China Hails Senate Approval of Trade Deal

BEIJING--China cheered the U.S. Senate's approval of a trade deal as a potential new beginning for often tortured relations between the world's last major Communist government and the capitalist superpower.

"We hope the passage of the bill can become a new starting point and a chance to start anew," Foreign Ministry spokesman Sun Yuxi told reporters after the Senate approved permanent normal trade relations for China.

Sun called the overwhelming 83-15 Senate vote Tuesday "conducive to creating a long-term and stable environment for Sino-U.S. economic and trade cooperation."

The measure, approved by the House of Representatives on May 24 in a 237-197 vote, will take effect once China becomes a member of the World Trade Organization, expected within months.

(Reuters)

AFRICA

Burundi Cease-Fire Elusive at Summit

NAIROBI--A summit aimed at consolidating a fragile peace accord in Burundi ended in the Kenyan capital with no cease-fire accord but an appeal by mediators for all sides to cease hostilities.

Although mediator Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, had persuaded most of Burundi's political parties to sign a peace deal last month, the two main armed Hutu rebel movements were not involved in negotiations until yesterday's meeting.

A communique issued after the meeting--which included the presidents of Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania--called for all sides to sign a cease-fire within 30 days.

"The summit further called on them to declare immediate suspension of hostilities pending the conclusion of a cease-fire agreement," the communique said.

Fighting has actually intensified since the accord was signed, in a war that has cost 200,000 lives since 1993.

Mandela had hoped to bring the rebels into the peace process and persuade them to sign a cease-fire with the country's Tutsi-led army, but analysts had always said this would be difficult to achieve at this round of talks.

(Reuters)

THE AMERICAS

Canada Has Record Budget Surplus

TORONTO--Canada's Finance Minister Paul Martin announced a $ 12.3 billion budget surplus for the 1999-2000 budget year, the largest budget surplus in Canada's history.

Martin said that about $ 9 billion of the surplus for the year that ended March 31 would go to pay down Canada's national debt of $ 577 billion. Some opposition leaders have called for using the surplus to cut taxes.

Prime Minister Jean Chretien has indicated that some of the surplus would be used for improving health care in the provinces and for early childhood education. Last week, Chretien pledged to increase health-care payments to the provinces by $ 21.1 billion over the next five years.

(DeNeen L. Brown)

QUOTE OF THE DAY: "There is a sense that sanctions [against Iraq] are falling apart. We all feel, as a government and as a people, that it's about time for them to be lifted." -- Taleb Rifai, Jordan's minister of information. Page A21.


LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2000

212 of 348 DOCUMENTS



BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


March 12, 2006 Sunday


Milosevic's brother says funeral must take place in Serbia


LENGTH: 957 words


Text of report by Serbian TV on 12 March

[Announcer] Mira Markovic, Marko and Marija Milosevic have still not decided where Slobodan Milosevic is to be buried, although Russia is being mentioned most frequently. Borislav Milosevic, the brother of the former president of Serbia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, has told our TV that Slobodan Milosevic must be buried in our country as a great son of Serbia and Montenegro. The Socialist Party of Serbia [SPS] has asked the relevant bodies to allow the funeral to take place in Belgrade, with the family in attendance.

[Reporter Ivanka Maricic] The spouse of former President Slobodan Milosevic proposed yesterday that the body be transported to Russia so it could be buried there. Although there has been media speculation that Marija Milosevic, the daughter of the late former president, has asked that her father be buried in Montenegro, where she is living now, the Tanjug news agency has said that Marija backs her mother's proposal after all. It is not known what Marko Milosevic thinks about the funeral. Even though the SPS says that it is in contact with him, the public does not know his whereabouts. 

The brother of the late former president, Borislav Milosevic, has told our TV that Slobodan Milosevic must be buried in his own country. The last time he talked to him was on Thursday [9 March], when he did not complain about his treatment in Scheveningen.

[Borislav Milosevic on the phone, presumably in Moscow] He complained earlier that the headphones they had imposed on him - they took away his own in October - were causing hearing problems, buzzing in the head and vertigo. That is what he complained of earlier, while this poisoning you have mentioned, he did not complain about that to me now.

[Reporter] Tell me if you know anything about this - [Milosevic's lawyer] Mr Zdenko Tomanovic today presented a letter in The Hague which Slobodan had sent to [Russian Foreign Minister] Mr [Sergey] Lavrov. Did you know about this?

[Milosevic] I haven't read the letter, but I know about it. I was informed about it by the Foreign Ministry of the Russian Federation on Friday [10 March]. I found out that it had been handed to the Russian embassy in The Hague. It was handed on Friday. That letter was hand-written. I haven't read it, I have still not received it.

[Reporter] Are you travelling to The Hague? Who will take over the body? Have you decided anything?

[Milosevic] No, I am not going to The Hague. A group of Russian doctors will be going there, headed by Mr Leo Bokeria, director of the Bakulev scientific centre for cardio-vascular surgery.

[Reporter] Marija and Marko have not seen their father for almost five years, since he was taken to the Hague tribunal's detention unit. The arrest warrant for Marko issued by the court in Pozarevac [Milosevic's home town] was withdrawn in August 2005, following the withdrawal of charges of threatening and maltreating an activist of [the student anti-Milosevic movement] Otpor.

The last time Mira Markovic saw her husband was in October 2003 in The Hague. Since then she has not even been to Serbia. A trial against her opened in April 2005 on the basis of a bill of indictment on mediation in the unlawful allocation of flats from the Serbian government's housing fund. Since she failed to turn up in the courtroom of the Belgrade District Court, an arrest warrant was issued. The arrest warrant was re-issued in September 2005.

The SPS has demanded that the state create conditions for both the family and Serbia to part with Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade.

[SPS official Ivica Dacic speaking at presser] We are asking the State of Serbia to act in a dignified manner towards a man who used to be the president of the Republic of Serbia, president of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, and we are demanding of the people who are today at his post to take this into consideration and enable both his family and those who love and respect Slobodan Milosevic to bid farewell to him in a dignified manner here in Belgrade.

[Reporter] The Serbian Radical Party [SRS] has called on Serbian President Boris Tadic to pardon Milosevic's wife, so the former president of Serbia and Yugoslavia could be buried in the Alley of the Great [section of Belgrade's Novo Groblje cemetery in which prominent Yugoslav and Serbian political and cultural figures are buried] in Belgrade. They believe that the charges against Mira Markovic are absurd.

[SRS deputy chairman Tomislav Nikolic] If the funeral takes place in Moscow, the party's top leadership will go there. [SRS chairman and Hague indictee] Vojislav Seselj's wife will also be travelling there as the wife of his friend.

[Reporter] Serbian President Boris Tadic's office says that they have not received an official request for Mira Markovic to be pardoned. In case such a request arrives, we have learned unofficially that on the basis of his constitutional authorities the Serbian president will not pardon Mira Markovic. Our law envisages the possibility that detention, as a security measure for attendance of a trial, can be replaced by guaranty.

[Spokeswoman for the Belgrade Court of Investigation Ivana Ramic on the phone] Guaranty can be provided by the accused himself or someone else in his name, but it is necessary that the accused himself promise that he will not hide, that he will not flee, i.e. that he will not leave his residence without permission before the completion of the proceedings.

[Reporter] According to the provisions of our law on the termination of detention, it is necessary that the public prosecutor declare himself as well. If the detention is lifted, the arrest warrant will be withdrawn as well.

Source: RTS 1 TV, Belgrade, in Serbian 1830 gmt 12 Mar 06

213 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


October 6, 2000, Friday


VOJISLAV KOSTUNICA: CAN THIS GLOOMY MAN SAVE YUGOSLAVIA?


BYLINE: Timothy Garton Ash


SECTION: COMMENT; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 1331 words


 

VOJISLAV KOSTUNICA is one of the gloomiest men I know. This may be an advantage for a new president of whatever remains of Yugoslavia, if that is how he emerges from yesterday's heady scenes of revolution. A "new" Federal Republic of Yugoslavia will have a ruined economy, like Romania after 1989; a burden of guilt, like Germany after 1945; ubiquitous corruption, like Russia today; and unresolved ethnic -territorial issues, like, well, old Yugoslavia.

Who is the leader upon whom such a heavy burden may fall? A large, heavy man, grey-suited, quietly spoken, painstakingly analytical, Dr Vojislav Kostunica (pronounced Kosh-TOON-it-sa) talks more like an academic than a politician. Indeed, until 10 years ago, he was just that - a politically engage constitutional lawyer and political scientist. Now 56, he has only been an active party politician since the age of 45, when non-communist party politics became possible in Yugoslavia in 1989. 

The first time we met, in 1996-97 at the time of the last great anti- Milosevic demonstrations, he took me to an old-fashioned restaurant in central Belgrade and told me that he really believed in Yugoslavia. The original Yugoslavia, that is; the Serb-dominated unitary kingdom between the two world wars (his father was an officer in its royal army). It was, he said, or at least it should have been, an exercise in British-style nation-building under a constitutional monarchy. Look how the king had given his first son a Serb name, his second a Croatian one, and his third a Slovenian - rather as British monarchs deliberately call their heir the Prince of Wales.

Most of the other nationalities of former Yugoslavia would find that a very rose-tinted view. But no, he didn't believe in the restoration of the monarchy. Apart from anything else, he said, the pretender to the throne, Crown Prince Alexander, barely spoke Serbian. When they met, they had to talk in English - which Dr Kostunica speaks fluently. Now he believed in the need for "asymmetric federalism", as a solution for Kosovo, Montenegro and Vojvodina, and perhaps also for the Serb republic in Bosnia. And he explained to me at length about his plans for the " regionalisation" of Yugoslavia. At rather boring length, I must say. Vojislav Kostunica is a very serious man.

Solid. Consistent. Knowledgeable and capable of sophisticated rational argument. Principled, too. But hardly a bundle of fun. Short on charisma. Nor is he a great believer in the politics of the street. That time, he told me how he saw unhappy echoes of 1968 in the street demonstrators' cult of spontaneity, their belief in "the movement" as an end in itself. This is the man whose future, and with it the future of all south-eastern Europe, now depends on his ability to lead and channel a movement of mass protest and civil disobedience.

In late 1998, we talked in the office of his tiny party, the Democratic Party of Serbia. His spartan offices seemed virtually empty, as if a removals van was about to arrive. Under the harsh neon light, the talk was all of Kosovo, and how its future inside Serbia must be secured by constitutional, peaceful means. Ordinary, decent Serbians would be dismayed at what Milosevic was doing there, he said. In an election held under international supervision, Milosevic could be defeated. Fat chance, I thought.

A year later, after the war and the Nato bombing, which he criticised fiercely, the office seemed even more spartan and bare. Other opposition politicians clearly had plenty of money from somewhere - and Belgrade gossip would soon tell you from where - but not Serbia's Dr K. This time, he was furious with the United States, and with Britain. "Blair! Cook!" - he spat out the names with contempt. But, he went on, "I know they are not the West. Fortunately there is also Simon Jenkins (The Times columnist who criticised the Kosovo war), Henry Kissinger (whom he clearly took as another war critic), Noam Chomsky and Harold Pinter!"

So, as our papers say, a "moderate nationalist"? Well, what exactly is a "moderate nationalist"? Some old Yugoslav hands, shocked by his strong support for the Bosnian and Kosovo Serbs, say he's as bad as Milosevic. Some even say he's more deeply nationalist than the post-communist, opportunist Milosevic.

This is both true and completely false. It's true he's been more seriously and consistently concerned about the fate of the Serbian nation than Milosevic. That is one of the reasons he was purged from Belgrade University in 1974. In other, happier places and times he would be a conservative, romantic patriot, of the kind frequently encountered in the British Conservative party (and they have some pretty rose -tinted views of the national past, too). In this unhappy place and time, he has said and done things he should regret: being photographed holding an automatic weapon among Kosovo Serbs, for example, although he says the weapon was thrust upon him.

But I have no doubt that he is genuinely "moderate", and what matters is his moderation. The difference between him and Milosevic is that between day and night. This is not just because Kostunica is supported by a coalition of less nationalist democrats. It's because he is himself, in his whole style and intellectual formation, profoundly committed to civilised, peaceful, constitutional means. And one lesson of Europe's terrible 20th century is that the means you embrace are quite as important as the ends. Perhaps more important.

This is a man who is passionate about the rule of law. Who believes in elections, institutions, negotiations. He's also a man who, precisely because he is a Serbian patriot - or nationalist, if you will - sees that the only future for his country lies in a return to Europe.

Whether he can become a popular leader of a successful revolution, we shall see. He made a fine beginning at last Wednesday's post-election "victory rally". Addressing his "dear, brave fellow-citizens, free people", as they stood waving banners and rattles, he said: "We are fighting for democracy, and democracy is based on truth, not on lies." One might almost be listening to Vaclav Havel in Wenceslas Square in Prague, 1989.

Then Kostunica addressed a skilful message to rank-and-file members of Milosevic's Socialist Party: "we will not act as did your leaders: we will not hound people who have opposing opinions; we will not burst into other people's houses... we will not remove the property of the people from the country."

In the nine days since then he has placed himself, with whatever feelings, firmly and defiantly at the front of a growing movement of popular protest. On Tuesday, he observed: "I don't like the word revolution. But what is happening in Serbia today is a revolution - a peaceful, non-violent, wise, civilised, democratic revolution." On Wednesday, he was again cheered to the echo by striking coal miners at the strategically vital Kolubara mines, which have emerged as an epicentre of this revolution (a comparison can be made with the role of the Gdansk shipyard in the Polish revolution of 1980 - although there it was the workers who started it, and opposition leaders from the capital then joined them, whereas here it is the other way round). "President! President!" the miners shouted. As I write, late on Thursday afternoon, a massive demonstration of popular anger has engulfed Belgrade. Demonstrators have stormed the parliament and are reportedly attacking the state radio and television building. Who knows what will have happened by the time you read this?

Certainly, the rapids that Kostunica has to negotiate over the next few days are far more treacherous than those Vaclav Havel faced in 1989. But history makes unlikely heroes, and Serbia's Dr K may yet be one.

The author's eyewitness accounts of the revolutions of 1980 and 1989, 'The Polish Revolution: Solidarity and We The People', are both available in Penguin paperback


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: When Vojislav Kostunica addressed the crowds at a post-election rally, one could almost have been listening to Vaclav Havel in Prague, 1989; Srdjan Suki

214 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Daily Telegraph (Sydney, Australia)


October 5, 1999, Tuesday


Serbian protest leader in crash


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 24


LENGTH: 430 words


BELGRADE: Prominent Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic claimed to have been the victim of an assassination attempt yesterday, after being involved in a car crash in which four of his team died.

Mr Draskovic, president of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), told a television reporter the car crash was an "obvious assassination attempt".

The car in which Mr Draskovic was travelling swerved off the road to avoid hitting a truck. 

The car in which Mr Draskovic's security team was travelling hit the lorry head on, one of Mr Draskovic's advisers said.

"We are talking about an obvious assassination attempt, and with God's will everybody was killed but myself," Mr Draskovic said.

"Let those who carried it out reflect well on what will happen to them."

The assassination attempt claim came as mass demonstrations against the regime of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic took place throughout Serbia for the 13th consecutive day, bringing tens of thousands of people out on the streets.

Mr Draskovic was "slightly injured" in the accident, which happened near Lazarevac, 40km south of Belgrade, his party said in a statement.

Killed in the accident were Mr Draskovic's security chief, Zvonko Osmajlic, two other members of the security team, Dragan Vusurevic and Vusur Rakocevic, and Mr Draskovic's brother-in-law, Veselin Boskovic.

"The truck suddenly, without any reason ... switched to our side of the road and it was clear to me that it had intended to kill me," Mr Draskovic said.

Borivoje Borovic, a lawyer and member of the SPO's directorate, said the road was straight, and not slippery, and visibility was good.

"The truck driver disappeared," he added.

A Draskovic aide said the opposition leader's wife, Danica, was also slightly injured but Mr Borovic said she had been travelling in a third car which was not involved in the crash.

An investigating magistrate said the truck had been driving on the wrong side of the road at the time of the collision, "for reasons yet unknown".

At an anti-Milosevic rally organised by the opposition coalition Alliance for Change, a minute's silence was held in honour of the killed SPO officials.

The SPO does not participate in the alliance's daily protests aimed a ousting Mr Milosevic, due to a disagreement over strategy.

Meanwhile the mass protests continued, with police cordons restricting a march by some 15,000 people through the centre of Belgrade yesterday, directing the crowd back to a square where the demonstration had begun. There were no reports of violent incidents.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DTM


Copyright 1999 Nationwide News Pty Limited


215 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


DECEMBER 17, 1996 Tuesday SF EDITION


A DISPARATE DUO UNITE SERB OPPOSITION / THEY ARE EX-RIVALS. THEIR LINK IS A COMMITMENT TO / DEMOCRACY AND DISLIKE OF THE AUTHORITARIAN MILOSEVIC.


BYLINE: Inga Saffron, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A04


LENGTH: 1211 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


They have become simply Vuk and Zoran. One is Serbia's heart, the other its head.

Every day for almost a month, this odd couple of Serbian politics has marched side by side at the front of Belgrade's pro-democracy demonstrations, looking like socks that got mixed up in the wash - Vuk Draskovic, the wild-maned, aging hippie, and Zoran Djindjic, the clean-cut, Clintonesque pragmatist with the high-voltage smile.

Djindjic, 44, is a city boy steeped in the rigors of German philosophy; Draskovic, 50, is a shepherd's son raised on heroic Serbian ballads. One is an ivory-tower dissident, the darling of Belgrade intellectuals; the other a peasant nationalist who appeals to Serbs who keep icons and listen to folk music. Their only common link is a visceral dislike of Yugoslavia's communist system. 

Yet for all their political and personal differences, this temperamentally mismatched duo has managed to fuse the disparate forces of the Serbian opposition into a single wedge for democratic change, and to rattle the nine-year-old authoritarian regime of President Slobodan Milosevic.

"They have done something everyone thought was impossible," said Milan Protic, director of the Center for Serbian Studies. "They got people out on the streets and they've done a good job of keeping them there. I think this is the beginning of the end for Mr. Milosevic."

Whether the enthusiastic daily street marches alone will succeed in dislodging Milosevic is still anything but certain. Even so, the movement for change would never have begun if Draskovic and Djindjic - whose name sounds like "ginger" - had not teamed up.

As the leaders of different opposition parties, the two had been rivals who aspired to be president of Serbia. Then, this fall, in an effort to whittle away at Milosevic's hold on the federal parliament and local councils, they put aside their egos and squabbles to form a broad coalition with three other democratically oriented parties.

Calling themselves Zajedno, or Together, this alliance of convenience managed to win council majorities in 14 of 19 large cities. Djindjic was preparing to take over as mayor of Belgrade when Milosevic's courts annulled the results.

Draskovic and Djindjic immediately became the two most charismatic figures in the ensuing protests, even though they represent opposite trends in Serbian politics. They share only a commitment to the democratic rule of law and an intense dislike of Milosevic.

It was Draskovic, a bearded author of national epics, who first fired up Serbia's nationalist consciousness in the early '90s with his Serbian Renewal Movement. Born amid the rocky mountains of Herzegovina in Bosnia, where thousands of Serbs died at the hands of Croatian fascists in World War II, he gained a huge following by advocating a return to the traditions of Serbian and Orthodox culture.

Whenever he spoke, crowds would chant "Vuk, Vuk, Vuk" - a name that means "wolf" in Serbian. An admiring painter depicted him as Christ blessing his flock. When war again threatened the region, his ecstatic followers formed into paramilitary brigades. But to everyone's surprise, Draskovic renounced the force as a solution to the ethnic conflict.

"I'll never forget when Vuk called me in 1992 and said he wanted to join our antiwar demonstration," recalled Borka Pavicevic, copresident of the Belgrade Circle, a group of liberal intellectuals. "He lost some supporters when he did that."

Draskovic's popularity has waned over the last four years, perhaps reflecting a weariness with his passionate emphasis on all things Serbian and his penchant for rhetorical flourishes, a tendency that intellectuals here sometimes deride as "epic-ism." "I think he's a better man than a politician," said Pavicevic.

If Draskovic is criticized for his passionate excess, Serbian liberals sometimes complain that Djindjic seems to lack soul. Feminist writer Jasmina Tesanovic noted that while Draskovic was turning out best-selling, historical novels full of "blood, sweat and sperm," Djindjic was translating obscure philosophical tracts with titles like "Problems of Left Intellectuals."

But unlike Draskovic, Djindjic's commitment to democracy is unquestioned. As a student at Belgrade University, he defied the Communist authorities by starting a rival student union and publishing a free-thinking student newspaper. At a time when Yugoslav leader Marshal Tito was treated as infallible, Djindjic wrote an article criticizing a plan to build a costly memorial in his home village, recalled Dusan Velickovic, a college buddy of Djindjic's.

"It was very brave," Velickovic said. Djindjic was arrested and tried for the offense. After receiving a suspended sentence, he decided it was best to continue work on his doctorate in Germany. He was planning to become a philosophy professor there until the Berlin Wall fell, and the same democratic tendencies swept into Yugoslavia. He returned to Yugoslavia in 1989.

In the last few years, Draskovic has evolved into a real democrat, too. He embraces the Dayton peace accords more warmly than any politician in the former Yugoslavia, perhaps more warmly than Djindjic.

In a shift that shocked his most loyal supporters, Djindjic supported the cause of the Bosnian Serbs in 1994. At a time when NATO was bombing Serb positions to protect Muslim havens, Djindjic journeyed to Bosnian Serb headquarters in Pale for a day of skiing and feasting on roasted oxen with Bosnian Serb politicians. Today he opposes attempts to bring war-crimes charges against Radovan Karadzic and other Bosnian leaders; he even backed Karadzic's party in the local Bosnian elections, saying it was anti-Milosevic.

On the streets, demonstrators will sometimes say they prefer Djindjic or they prefer Draskovic, but far more often they will say they care for neither very much. "We're not here to support one or the other. We're here to support a principle," explained Jasminka Petrovic, a lawyer who joined a two-hour-long march through Belgrade this weekend.

Others, however, say they often wish for a candidate who combined Draskovic's moral fervor and Djindjic's organizing skills.

Until someone like that emerges, it's the younger, more urbane Djindjic who is increasingly seen as the right person to help Serbia become a modern, Western-style nation. "Djindjic is really the brains of the movement," said a liberal Belgrade analyst who asked not to be named. "He has a lot of smart, capable people in his party."

However successful the pair becomes, the analyst said, neither man is ready to govern just yet. Beyond their aversion to Milosevic, they have no clear program for reviving Serbia's wounded economy. Nor do they have supporters experienced in running a government.

The analyst said they would do better to seek the Serbian presidency next year, after Milosevic's term expires. Although he is constitutionally forbidden to seek a third term, many believe Milosevic will try to change the rules.

The best scenario is the one that seems just within the opposition's grasp: taking control of the city councils that the Zajedno won on Nov. 17.

"First," said the analyst, "Djindjic should learn to be mayor of Belgrade. Then he can run for president."


LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO;
PHOTO
Vuk Draskovic, 50, is a shepherd's son raised on heroic Serbian ballads. (Associated Press, DRAGAN FILIPOVIC)
Zoran Djindjic, 44, is a man of the city who is steeped in German philosophy. (Associated Press, DAVID BRAUCHLI)

216 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


September 28, 2000


Euphoric Serbs stage carnival to celebrate Milosevic defeat


BYLINE: By GILLIAN SANDFORD


SECTION: CITY EDITION; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 436 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


Euphoria filled Belgrade's Republic Square last night as a crowd of 200,000 jubilant Serbs celebrated the landslide presidential election victory of Dr Vojislav Kostunica.

A mix of mothers, fathers, pensioners and youngsters jammed Kolarceva Street and flocked towards the blaring music in the square.

They were waving flags. They carried balloons. They even carried babies' rattles. They were celebrating the end of the era of Mr Slobodan Milosevic. 

"We beat them like a baby beats its rattle," people said to each other, shaking the rattles.

From the stage the announcer gave the names of the local authorities in which the opposition had won: from Nis in the south to Novi Sad in the north, and in the central Serbian heartland of Cacak, Kraljevo and Kragujevac.

With the name of every city claimed by the opposition and every vote total, a massive cheer rang out from the square. Flares shot into the sky, and the sound of music echoed through the night.

The economist and anti-Milosevic activist, Mr Maladjan Dinkic, took the stage. "We've voted for Kostunica and now they have the last chance. They can choose to go easily. If not, only God can help them, because it is time," he declared.

There was so much jubilation in Belgrade - and in dozens of other cities across Serbia last night - that people said it seemed impossible for the defeated President Milosevic to do anything but step down.

With a massive 75 per cent turnout, the opposition swept to victory in the presidential, local and federal polls, according to opposition figures.

"I didn't have hope before. I didn't think there was a future, even two days ago. Talking about a future was like a fairytale before. Now there is light at the end of the tunnel," said Ms Milica Rajic.

When Dr Kostunica took to the stage there was a massive roar. "We have victory. And they have lost," he declared. "There is no dealing with them. We have support from the European Union. We have support from Russia. But the main thing is our own strength."

The next move by the regime will be clear today. But yesterday Belgrade was awash with rumours of collapse at the heart of the regime. Resignations and defections were being reported.

Some senior socialists were said to have left the country. Others have sounded out the opposition about their prospects if they abandon the party.

A youngster from the student resistance movement, Otpor, won a massive roar from the crowd when he declared: "In 1988 we promised resistance until victory and we are here. We said he is finished. And we are here." The crowd roared back: "Gotov je (he is finished)."


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times


217 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


December 23, 1993, Thursday, Final Edition


Milosevic Scores Again;
But Serbian Vote Gives Opposition a Foot in Door


John Pomfret, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A19


LENGTH: 1000 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22, 1993


With a substantial jump in the number of seats his party controls in parliament, Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic has proven once again that he is the most resilient ex-Communist leader in Eastern Europe.

But his apparent failure to win a sought-after parliamentary majority in balloting last Sunday will force him to work for the first time with opposition parties not under his direct control. Ivica Dacic, spokesman for Milosevic's Socialist Party, said today that it will talk with other parties about forming a new government, but declined to specify which ones.

Such a concession to pluralism is significant, observers said. Since its first multi-party elections in 1990, Serbia has essentially functioned as a one-party state with Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia firmly in control, backed by state-run TV and the biggest police force in Europe. Any cracks in this edifice, diplomats said, would constitute a victory for democracy even if opposition parties at this stage are as nationalistic as the president concerning Serbia's role in the Bosnian war. 

"First they need to introduce debate into the political equation. Once they do that, people will naturally begin to question nationalism," a Western diplomat said.

In addition, the necessity of day-to-day cooperation with the opposition could advance the prospects for peace in Bosnia and Croatia, where Serb forces supported by Milosevic have waged two wars and grabbed huge chunks of territory since 1991. By including political foes in decisions, the president will be able to blame them if the results fall short of the Serb dream that all Serbs in what used to be Yugoslavia will live in one state.

"The important thing to realize is that Milosevic is not a nationalist because he believes in it, he is a nationalist because it has given him power," said Srjdan Bogosavljevic, former director of the Federal Institute of Statistics. "He will drop nationalism if that means he'll stay in power longer, but to do that he needs someone to blame. That's where the opposition comes in."

The main question now, diplomats ask, is whether Bosnia's Muslims will view the election results as a setback for Milosevic and prolong the war to pressure him further before they agree to Bosnia's partition. Serbia is tottering under the weight of international sanctions, imposed by the United Nations in 1992 for Milosevic's support of Serb aggression in Bosnia and Croatia.

With 98.5 percent of the ballots counted, the Central Electoral Commission announced today that of the Serbian parliament's 250 seats, Milosevic's party would win 123, up from 101 in the last parliament, and a party of ethnic Albanians that backs the president would get two. Four opposition parties that ran anti-Milosevic campaigns are expected to win 120 seats. A party representing Hungarians from the northern province of Vojvodina won the remaining five. The commission ordered recounts in just 50 of the republic's 9,957 polling stations.

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, called the tally a "great victory," pointing out that 21 of the Socialists' seats came from the predominantly Albanian province of Kosovo, where more than 1 million Albanians, who want to secede from Serbia, boycotted the vote.

"Milosevic in the long term has got some problems," said Nenad Stefanovic, a political commentator. "Now he's got to work with the opposition, but this is a man who still believes in the one-party state, a man who thinks of a multi-party system as the source of all evil."

Stefanovic said he did not believe the opposition would be able to put aside the quarrels that kept it from uniting during the campaign and form a government, especially because one of the leading parties is led by ultranationalist Vojislav Seselj, a former Milosevic ally accused of being a war criminal. But Stefanovic also predicted that neither would Milosevic get the "stable parliament, free of obstructions," that he called for Sunday when he voted.

"Political instability is what we have to look forward to," Stefanovic said.

For example, Milosevic's party will be able to block the passage of an opposition-backed law challenging his control of Serbian state television, a move considered critical for democracy in Serbia. A study of the time the state network devoted to the campaign found it aired more than four hours of pro-Milosevic candidates compared with 4 minutes and 37 seconds for the top opposition group.

In a republic of 10 million where only 4 percent of the population reads newspapers or magazines, it is hard to overestimate the importance of television to Milosevic's government. More than a mechanism to back his party, television occupies a critical position in communicating his worldview to the Serbian people. It is a worldview that, according to Stefanovic, stresses xenophobia and taps into a sense among Serbs that they are the underdogs of history.

Stefanovic's independent news magazine, Vreme, was recently described in a state-run TV show as backed by "dark forces." A recent prime-time news broadcast employed the term "international plots" seven times.

While Milosevic will be able to kill democratizing legislation, Bogosavljevic said, the president will not be able to force through changes in either the Serbian constitution or that of the two-republic Yugoslav federation that he needs to cement his place in power.

The Serbian constitution limits a president to two consecutive 5-year terms, and Milosevic is in his second term. To get a third term, he would need a two-thirds vote of the Serbian parliament -- more votes than he will have -- to revise the constitution.

The presidency of Yugoslavia -- Serbia plus Montenegro -- is ceremonial. But if Milosevic decided to become federal president, he could make the office more powerful by revising the federal constitution. But to win a two-thirds vote of the federal parliament, he would have to call new federal elections.


LOAD-DATE: December 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: ANALYSIS, FOREIGN NEWS


Copyright 1993 The Washington Post


218 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


June 4, 1999


The two-minute Guardian;
News Photo Turner


SECTION: The Guardian Home Page; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 2355 words


Four of the five artists on this year's Turner Prize shortlist are either photographers or film-makers and the fifth uses video and snapshots in her work 7 Teacher boycott Head teachers voted unanimously to boycott Tony Blair's plans to link their pay with pupil performance 8 Art return An 85-year-old widow in Leicester whose father-in-law was forced by the Nazis to sell off his art collection could today see the return of a pounds 3.3 million Van Gogh 10 Menuhin memorial Yehudi Menuhin was honoured in Westminster Abbey yesterday at a memorial service 11 Mbeki's victory ANC won two thirds of the vote in S African elections 14 Pyramid power Egypt is hoping that the newly renovated Great Pyramid of Cheops will help restore the country's tourist trade 16 China clampdown Dissidents were rounded up on the eve of the Tiananmen Square massacre anniversary as Beijing called for friendly ties to US 17 Bid goes on Airtours is continuing with its pounds 800m bid for First Choice despite the launch of a monopolies inquiry 23 And finally The meerkats of the African bush, previously presumed to be models of selfless behaviour, turn out to be just like everybody else selfish, British scientists have learned 13 Peace poses big challenge to tyrant who thrived on war Yehudi Menuhin Page 11 Milosevic His medium term future is increasingly vulnerable War crimes Milosevic indictment non negotiable, tribunal says Quick Crossword G2 page 19 Main, Page 32 Ian Traynor in Cologne By suing for peace, President Slobodan Milosevic yesterday gained a fresh purchase on power, the sole driving force of the 57-year-old strongman who has teased and toyed with the West for eight years. 

The Yugoslav people have paid a terrible price for his ruthless ambition. But in his labyrinth of Belgrade bunkers, the president, the first sitting head of state to be charged with crimes against humanity, looks secure for a while longer.

'Removing him was never one of our stated objectives," said a senior western official at the European Union summit in Cologne yesterday as the Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari, arrived from Belgrade bearing the peace agreement.

Mr Milosevic's parents both committed suicide, suggesting to many analysts that he too has a death wish. But his survival instincts are acute and he appears to have averted the prospect of a Nato ground invasion which could have climaxed in his overthrow.

'Milosevic now has his back to the wall. He's just trying to save his skin. But he'll try to portray it as a defeat for Nato, a victory for justice and the United Nations," said Zoran Ivanovic, a veteran Serb opposition commentator.

Yesterday's capitulation to peace terms almost entirely dictated by Nato leaves Mr Milosevic enough scope to claim, to his own constituency at least, that he is a Balkan hero who stood up to a criminal bully and survived with dignity. His propaganda outlets and his political party were quick to interpret the surrender as a deal that saves Kosovo for Serbia, recognising that the province remains within Yugoslavia's 'territorial sovereignty" a defeat for Albanian separatist ambitions.

Time will tell whether that claim is justified. The history of Yugoslavia's dismemberment over the past decade suggests otherwise: that Kosovo will ultimately go the way of Slovenia, Croatia, Macedonia, and Bosnia-Herzegovina lost to the man who is the agent of the old federation's collapse.

But Mr Milosevic does not operate with a view to the long-term. His 10-year rule is an unbroken record of disaster and defeat, laced nonetheless with sweet tactical victories and the taunting and humiliating of opponents.

There are several elements to yesterday's deal which he will seek to exploit to his advantage. In the Yugoslav parliament only the neo-fascist Radicals of Vojislav Seselj abstained or voted against the deal.

Most crucially for Mr Milosevic, the proposed Russian contingent of up to 10,000 peacekeepers in Kosovo could serve as a guarantor of his continuation in power and could also be the agents of a de facto partition of Kosovo, though such notions were vehemently refuted by western leaders at the EU summit.

If the president's central concern is to cling to power, the post-war era will throw up three potential challenges to his medium-term prospects the mood in the military, the relationship with the small sister republic of Montenegro, and the capacity of a demoralised and divided opposition, which down the years has been vulnerable to co-option by the regime, to revive with western support and present a credible alternative.

Nato spokesmen have been quick to seize on the desertions and the mini -insurrections that have taken place within the Yugoslav military over the past month, but it remains notoriously difficult to gauge the degree to which disaffection among the army top brass could threaten Mr Milosevic's grip on power.

His decade in office has been punctuated by regular purges of the army high command and he has never favoured the military, starving it of funding, equipment and prestige in favour of building up his own praetorian guard of special interior ministry troops. In the event of a potential army revolt, the paramilitary loyalist police forces will have a key role to play in shoring him up.

The war has exposed the widening differences between Serbia and Montenegro, with Milo Djukanovic, the Montenegrin president, emerging as the cheerleader of the anti-Milosevic movement in Yugoslavia. Peace could aggravate those differences and feed Montenegrin separatism.

In Montenegro, too, sits the only Belgrade opposition leader to emerge from the disaster with his credibility intact. Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party and a former Belgrade mayor, defied the regime's insistence on patriotic unity in the face of 'Nato aggression" and fled to Montenegro to avoid Mr Milosevic's hitmen.

Other potential opposition leaders, such as Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement or potentially Mr Seselj of the Radicals, have burnt their boats and Mr Djindjic now looks likely to emerge as the pivotal figure, again supported by the west, in the attempt to find an alternative to Mr Milosevic.

'It's great that we're going to have peace,' said an opposition Serb analyst. 'But this also means that Milosevic stays. God knows what's going to happen in Belgrade next.' Officials of the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague yesterday insisted that the indictment against Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, could not be used as a bargaining chip to broker a peace deal.

The indictment cannot be removed, has no statute of limitations and will continue to oblige UN member states to arrest Mr Milosevic if he enters their territory, lawyers said. But there is no mention of it in yesterday's peace deal.

Finnish diplomats in Belgrade reported that one of Mr Milosevic's prime concerns in negotiating to end the Nato offensive was his own status and survival under the indictment, but the word from the tribunal was that no deal was possible.

Louise Arbour, the chief prosecutor, said in announcing the indictments last week that they could only be rescinded by a vote of the UN security council, the tribunal's parent body. For the council to do so, she said, would undermine the whole legal status of the tribunal. James Landale, a spokesman in The Hague, said yesterday: 'The indictment does not put any legal barrier in the way of negotiating with Mr Milosevic. That is a political decision for the people negotiating a settlement. But arrest warrants have been posted under chapter 7 of the UN Charter and no one is in any position to trade away the authority of the tribunal." Stephen Bates Comment & Analysis Analysis Price of peace Alex Brummer examines the way the burdens of war and peace in the Balkans are already driving down the wobbly euro 19 Comment End of the war? Guardian commentators Polly Toynbee and Martin Woollacott reflect on an apparent victory 19,20 Paul Oestreicher 'The murdered Kosovans cannot be brought back, nor those killed by Nato bombs' Letters 21 Plus Anthony Sampson - South Africa's future as the ANC triumphs 20 Leaders The war Milosevic's failure to accept a better deal offered in March has cost his country and his people a terrible price Tiananmen Square Ten years on, progress towards allowing political expression is still slow Asylum bill It must be changed 21 Obituaries Sir Christopher Cockerell, inventor of the hovercraft, aged 88 22 Polly Toynbee Page 19 G2 Murder, mystery, suspense The leader of America's atheists disappeared in 1995 at the same time as $ 500,000 went missing. Some thought she had run off, others that she had slipped away to die. Now the police believe she may have been Bridget Jones gets lucky In the next century there will be a shortage of women rather than men 4 Pashmina passion The must -have accessory for spring is about to hit the high street 10 Eyes wide open Picture profile of Nicole Kidman and Tom Cruise 12 Just one of the girls Dr Glenn Wilson analyses the appeal of Pauline Quirke in the guide daily 13 Milosevic has survived 10 years of disaster and defeat, but Kosovo may be one lost war too many Photograph: Emil Vas Nicole Kidman Page 12 Friday Review Caveman Singer and songwriter Nick Cave on why he is bringing Kylie Minogue, Sir Les Patterson and Nina Simone to the South Bank Human Traffic Peter Bradshaw gives the new movie about the British club scene three stars Forget Star Wars The Matrix is the innovative sci-fi move of the year and has made millions in the US Guerrillas present disarming problem The KLA Resurgent force may be reluctant to lay down weapons The Editor Gay marriage in Germany, Prince Charles on GM food, how to detoxify your body, and all George Lucas' media interviews - the best of the world's media edited for you Guardian Unlimited John Hooper in Morini and Owen Bowcott Having belatedly provided the Kosovo Liberation Army with limited close air support, Nato may now be faced with the difficult task of curtailing ethnic Albanian hopes of independence from Serbia and eventually disarming the resurgent guerrilla force.

Soon after news came through of the Belgrade parliament's vote, Serbian artillery close to the border between Kosovo and Albania fired a spectacular barrage that sent up great red plumes of dust around the KLA's positions on Mount Pastrik. The shelling underscored an uncomfortable fact for the guerrillas: that a peace plan which would see them disarmed is gaining ground at a moment when the Serbs appear to be weakened and under severe pressure.

Initial reaction from the leaders of Kosovo's Albanian community was one of guarded optimism.

'Militarily, it's better than Rambouillet, but politically it's weaker, because it does not have a referendum on independence,' said Baton Haxhiu, the chief editor of Koha Ditore, which is operating in exile in Macedonia.

'I don't believe the game is over until I see the Serb forces get out of Kosovo and Nato forces come in,' he added. 'Milosevic has violated scores of resolutions before, and he's always ready to lie.

'The peace plan makes no mention of the war crimes tribunal at The Hague. It was a big mistake of the international community to talk to a criminal. If he actually signed the document, it's a moral humiliation for many families in Kosovo'.

Blerim Shala, a member of the Kosovo delegation at Rambouillet, said: 'It was much better for Milosevic to accept Nato peacekeepers than have ground troops come in with the risk of Americans losing their lives. Then the pressure would have been on to try him.' Mr Shala saw a contradiction between the international trusteeship which the plan creates and Yugoslavia's continuing sovereignty. 'This is a problem, and there is also no referendum on independence,' he added.

Nato's position from the outset has been that the KLA should be disarmed as part of any settlement. Though driven from many of its strongholds within Kosovo, the KLA has grown in size. Nato intelligence sources recently put its strength at 17,000.

It will be difficult for the west to persuade the divided Albanian leadership that President Milosevic can be trusted to adhere to any deal, while at the same time convincing the Serbs that the rebel army has been disbanded.

Section eight of the peace plan refers to 'demilitarisation of the Kosovo Liberation Army' but sets no timetable. It also calls for an interim political agreement that would secure essential autonomy for Kosovo but respects the 'principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and other states in the region'.

Throughout the Kosovo crisis, Nato has attempted to keep at arm's length from the KLA. Many western European politicians view the organisation with suspicion, believing that its weaponry has been purchased with profits from the drug trade and that some of its soldiers may have tortured or murderd Serbian civilians.

But under the Rambouillet agreement - signed in March shortly before Nato launched its bombardment of Yugoslavia and the Serbs began their largest ethnic cleansing campaign - the KLA had already promised to disarm. That acceptance was crucial in isolating Mr Milosevic's regime and indirectly triggering Nato's onslaught.

The guerrillas have now acquired a substantial presence in north-eastern Albania, perhaps the most poorly communicated and lawless region of Europe.

It offers the KLA a stronghold from which it could hold out against the peacemakers' demands should its leaders choose to do so.

www.guardian.co.uk Ten years after Tiananmen Read John Gittings' eyewitness accounts of the 1989 Beijing massacre www.newsunlimited.co.uk World Cup Super Six Ball-by-ball coverage of Australia v India www.cricketunlimited.co.uk KLA troops: Rambouillet deal said they would be disarmed Guardian Newspapers Ltd, 119 Farringdon Road EC1R 3ER.

219 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


September 13, 2000 Wednesday Final Edition


Anti-Milosevic politicians prepare to lose: Opposition in lead as election nears, but few expect voters to have a say


SOURCE: New York Times


BYLINE: Steven Erlanger


SECTION: Insight; Pg. A9


LENGTH: 1038 words


DATELINE: Belgrade, Yugoslavia


Democracy is about choice, but in the Yugoslav version, which is now playing itself out with Slobodan Milosevic's future at stake, there are likely to be more choices than usual.

Milosevic, Yugoslavia's president, changed the constitution to make his office subject to direct election, and he has now called a vote nine months earlier than he had to.

So on Sept. 24, Yugoslavs will vote for a federal president, parliament and municipal officials in an election that will appear like most others, with voters getting to choose between the incumbent and his party, and an array of challengers.

But as election day approaches, a strong opposition candidate is doing better than Milosevic in the opinion polls, and this points up the uniqueness of Yugoslavia's system. Milosevic also gets to make a choice: whether to accept the choice of the people if it goes against him, or to manipulate the totals and declare victory regardless. 

And then the people will have another chance to choose, but not in the voting booths: will they accept Milosevic's choice, or will they come out onto the streets to defend their own choices, possibly against the arrayed power of the police and even the army.

This is a political netherworld, in which the forms and substance of both democracy and authoritarianism are clearly visible.

In an instructive way, they live side by side here, and both have their limits, depending on the stakes. But with Milosevic's own hat in the ring in a system he has manipulated like a master for 12 years, the real hopes of long-divided opposition leaders are coming up hard against the cynicism of those same challengers.

"This is a kind of authoritarianism that needs a form of democratic legitimation from time to time," said Vojislav Zanetic, a marketing consultant, playwright and columnist.

"This is a pseudo-democracy, in which the opposition is complicit," he said. "It's a kind of society that must fall apart slowly -- it can't be ripped apart in one day, in one election. We don't have a political crisis here or even an economic one -- we have a systemic crisis, a crisis of society and political will."

It is a form of parallel political universe. There is a campaign, with speeches and tours and open meetings. There are billboards and opinion polls and marketing experts. There are monitors ready to examine the voting and counting procedures, and Web sites devoted to the election and the campaign.

And even though the state media, especially television, are thoroughly and aggressively in the hands of Milosevic, there is a lively independent press, including local television and radio, that is both outspoken and combative in the face of government pressure and derision.

In general it has lined up dutifully in support of Milosevic's main rival, Vojislav Kostunica.

Yet among these opponents there is also a resigned conviction that Milosevic will steal as many votes as he needs to ensure not only victory, but victory in the first round -- since he needs an unquestionable victory to achieve his aims of re-legitimation.

And that adds a new quality of edge and risk to the options facing Milosevic. "For Milosevic, this election has turned into Russian roulette," one opposition leader said. "But for him to allow a second round would be suicide."

Can't Win Against Milo

But what of the people of Serbia; wouldn't they come out into the streets to defend the opposition or their own choice? Among the opposition, there are deep concerns that the Serbs, atomized and impoverished, will not.

"Frankly I'm not so optimistic," said Vuk Draskovic, the head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, who is living in Montenegro after two attacks on his life.

"All of us together are fighting a battle we cannot win. I'm quite sure Milosevic has right now in his pocket the result of the elections. What will happen after 24 September, when the opposition people face the crackdown on their hopes?"

Even Kostunica says that "people are fatalistic about the way they see these elections." Many of his own supporters in the polls, he said, "believe that Milosevic will win."

Kostunica plans to declare victory the night of the election, as his aides presume Milosevic will. In the case of massive election fraud, he hopes people will come out into the streets the way they did for months after Milosevic refused to acknowledge opposition victories in the 1996 local elections. But even Kostunica is not sure that they will.

Natasa Kandic, director of the Humanitarian Law Foundation here and a critic of Milosevic and Serb actions in Kosovo, said that Milosevic won't freely cede power even if everyone voted against him.

"What will happen, I don't know," she said. "It is, however, important that we do not sit at home on Sept. 24, but go outside and defend our votes."

But Kandic is facing troubles of her own, with the Yugoslav army threatening to bring her to court over articles she wrote criticizing the behaviour of Serbian forces in Kosovo. These threats to her are part of a skilful effort by the government to intimidate opposition leaders and their supporters, including the student movement, Otpor, or Resistance.

The message that the opposition hears is that the government will react with force, if necessary, against any revolution in the streets.

There are, in addition, mysterious events that create a chill, like the kidnapping two weeks ago of former Serbian President Ivan Stambolic, who was Milosevic's mentor.

In a swift party coup, Milosevic ousted him in 1987. Although there have been rumours -- which his wife denies -- that Stambolic was considering a run for the presidency, Milosevic and the government forcefully deny any role in the disappearance.

Zanetic, the marketing expert, thinks the government is better than the opposition at propaganda and political marketing, understanding that most Serbs get their information from television. "In politics here, it doesn't matter if you tell the truth or lie -- you must be clear," he said.

Which is why, if Milosevic claims victory, he is likely to also declare a landslide. And then one may better see where the new balance lies between democracy and authoritarianism.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: AP; Vojislav Kostunica, right, the top challenger of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic in the upcoming elections, leaves talks with Montenegrin officials on the weekend.
