220 of 348 DOCUMENTS




The Times (South Africa)


March 15, 2011 Tuesday


Wars in words


BYLINE: Andrew Donaldson


SECTION: OPINION & EDITORIAL


LENGTH: 475 words


IF YOU READ ONE THING THIS WEEK. . .
Fear Itself, by Andrew Rosenheim (Hutchinson) R185
AN ELEGANT thriller which focuses on an almost forgotten aspect of the Second World War: the pressure within the US to stay out of the conflict. Stephen Nessheim, a young agent in the fledgling FBI, is assigned to infiltrate the Bund, a group of expat Germans in America with pro-Nazi leanings, and to determine the extent of their influence over the Roosevelt administration. 


It's all pacy stuff, with an ear for the politics and intrigue of the era - and it will remind older local readers of the Ossewa Brandwag.
THE ISSUE
Advance notices for correspondent Kim Barker's The Taliban Shuffle: Strange Days in Afghanistan and Pakistan (Doubleday Books) have been on the enthusiastic side.
According to one critic, the book "is Scoop meets Dispatches remixed with a 21st century Bollywood soundtrack". Another praised her for her "dark, self-deprecating humour". Yet another advised: "Think PJ O'Rourke meets Paul Theroux." And even O'Rourke noted that Barker "breaks the journo code of silence and reveals a trade secret of the hacks who cover hellholes: The hell of the holes is that they're kind of fun." Which, of course, is the sort of thing the increasingly obnoxious O'Rourke would say about war.
But hopefully Barker's message - that Washington doesn't have a clue what's happening in the region - won't be lost in all the chuckles.
CRASH COURSE
There's a local aspect to Pulitzer and National Book Award winner Tina Rosenberg's new book, Join the Club: How Peer Pressure Can Transform the World (WW Norton & Co).
Basically, Rosenberg reiterates that we're such creatures of habit that often nothing will sway us from self-destructive behaviour. Crappy public health campaigns, for example, simply don't work. Think of any number of "official" initiatives to curb teen smoking, drug usage, alcoholism, and so on. Why do they fail? Peer pressure.
But Rosenberg cites a case where peer pressure did work - the Aids awareness LoveLife campaign which, she reveals, was modelled on a marketing strategy to relaunch Sprite in the townships. What worked for the fizzy drink worked for LoveLife, and it became one of the country's top brands; it was hip and it saved lives.
Rosenberg's other examples include Serbia's student-led anti-Milosevic movement, Indian rural health-worker initiatives, and how a youth programme for young British Muslims could be used in the war against terror.
In a sense, it's a guide to the use of peer pressure against the sort of peer pressure that bothered your mother so much.
THE BOTTOM LINE
"Hast seen the yellow duck?" - Moby-Duck: The True Story of 28 800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea and of the Beachcombers, Oceanographers, Environmentalists, and Fools, Including the Author, Who Went in Search of Them, by Donovan Hohn (Viking)


LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2011


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: The Times



Copyright 2011 AVUSA Media LTD
All Rights Reserved


221 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Irish Times


December 16, 2000


Serbian opposition poised for landslide victory
Slobodan Milosevic is an increasingly isolated figure in Belgrade, writes Gillian Sandford


SECTION: CITY EDITION; WORLD NEWS; Pg. 16


LENGTH: 470 words


The wife of toppled Yugoslav president Mr Slobodan Milosevic has branded the Hague tribunal the "gestapo" of the 20th century and blamed British Foreign Secretary Mr Robin Cook for an alleged NATO attempt to kill her daughter.

In a rare press appearance, Mrs Mirijana Markovic, the head of the Yugoslav Left party, which shared power with Milosevic's Socialists until the October uprising, said: "The Hague tribunal is the concentration camp and gas chamber of the 20th century."

She said she blamed herself for endangering her children with an open letter to British Foreign secretary Robin Cook after he alleged that they were out of the country during Nato bombing. Days after she had written that they were in Yugoslavia, a NATO missile struck the television station in Belgrade where her daughter Marija had been working. 

Ms Markovic's rare appearance was a bid to rally support for her party, which has virtually disintegrated in the last two months, before crucial elections in Serbia next Saturday.

In a rambling interview lasting more than 90 minutes, she said the left coalition of the former regime had "won the elections, but lost power" in the federal poll because the Montenegrin socialists had defected to the anti-Milosevic coalition.

But she said she was optimistic about the future of left-wing forces. Asked about money and property that the family had allegedly hidden away, she said. "My family didn't get rich at all. In general we are a family that doesn't have a feeling for material values."

Her appearance followed a few days after the first television interview by Mr Milosevic, who was re-elected president of the Socialists at a November party conference.

The couple's public interviews come as the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) coalition, which won a landslide victory in September's election, continued to show massive leads in all opinion polls.

The Strategic Marketing group estimated that DOS will gain three-quarters of the seats in the new Serbian parliament. It is in fact so certain of victory that it has announced that Mr Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party, will be prime minister and he has already named his cabinet.

"The key issue in these elections is ending the era of Milosevic," said Mr Miljenko Dereta of the non-government group Civic Initiatives. The new republic government will replace a temporary one formed after the October uprising in which each ministry has three ministers.

Mr Milosevic meanwhile is growing increasingly isolated and power is seeping from him. The Socialist party has fractured dramatically, with two rival groups already set up headed by former party officials.

Across Belgrade, posters of the youth resistance movement Otpor cover billboards. The slogan is "Overi" which means "finish the job".


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 The Irish Times

The New York Times


September 22, 1999, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


NEWS SUMMARY


SECTION: Section A; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk


LENGTH: 1221 words



INTERNATIONAL   A3-20
 
Toll in Taiwan Quake Continues to Rise
Rescuers worked to reach the thousands of people still trapped inside the rubble of toppled buildings and houses across Taiwan. More than 1,700 people were reported dead, at least 4,400 were injured and at least 30,000 homes were destroyed.   A1 


President Jiang Zemin of China offered condolences and aid.   A20
 
Clinton Appeals to U.N.
President Clinton, in a speech to the General Assembly, urged United Nations members to strengthen their collective capacity to intervene to prevent the kinds of mass killings and ethnic repression that ravaged Kosovo and East Timor.   A18
 
Hope faded that the Security Council would agree on a new approach to Iraq this week, with the United States and Russia still far apart on how to monitor Iraqi weapons programs and on when -- or if -- to begin lifting sanctions.   A18
 
More Troops Arrive in Timor
Military officials said the total of peacekeeping troops in East Timor had exceeded 2,000 and would reach 3,000 today.   A16
 
President B. J. Habibie appeared in Parliament to explain his decision to allow foreign troops in East Timor. He also urged legislators to ratify East Timor's resounding vote for independence next month.   A16
 
Summers Defends Russia Aid
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers vigorously defended the Administration's policy of supporting aid to Russia, but warned that the Russian central bank had to comply with safeguards to maintain American backing for assistance.   A3
 
Anti-Milosevic Rallies in Serbia
Tens of thousands attended rallies in several Serbian towns, hearing pleas to keep marching until President Slobodan Milosevic is gone.   A11
 
Israeli Leader Visits Berlin
Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, accompanied by survivors of a Nazi concentration camp, arrived in Berlin on the first state visit to the German capital since the Government moved there last month.   A3
 
World Briefing   A17
 
NATIONAL   A22-25
 
F.B.I. Director Opposed Clemency for 16 Militants
The F.B.I. "unequivocally opposed" President Clinton's offer of clemency to 16 Puerto Rican nationalists, asserting that the release of most of the prisoners would reinvigorate their terrorist movement, according to a letter prepared for the Bureau's Director, Louis J. Freeh. Mr. Freeh did not sign the letter, but senior law enforcement officials said it accurately reflected his position. Mr. Clinton provided his first full explanation in a letter to Congress.   A1
 
U.S. Prepares Tobacco Lawsuit
The Justice Department is set to file a civil suit against the tobacco industry, seeking to recover billions in health-related expenses that cigarette smoking has cost over the decades, a Government official said.   A1
 
Clinton Travels Assailed
Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho, the Senate's third-ranking Republican, issued a report on the cost of President Clinton's travels and accused the President of traveling overseas to an extent that was "almost abusive of the right and the privilege and the responsibility" of his office.   A24
 
A Ship the Navy Doesn't Want
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, has sought half a billion dollars to start building a $1.5 billion Navy vessel at a shipyard in Mississippi, his home state, but the Navy never sought to build the ship and, in any case, said only $295 million was needed to start the project.   A24
 
Medicare Prescription Changes
The Administration says in a report to be issued today that H.M.O.'s will stop providing free drug coverage to Medicare recipients next year. White House officials expressed alarm about the trend toward fewer benefits and higher prices.   A22
 
Approval for New Antibiotic
The F.D.A. approved Synercid to combat bacteria resistant to vancomycin, which has long been considered the antibiotic of last resort.   A22
 
Storm Sweeps Across Florida
Tropical Storm Harvey shifted course away from the Tampa Bay area and washed across Florida's southwestern Gulf Coast, the Everglades and South Florida.   A22
 
NEW YORK/REGION   B1-10
 
U.S. Proposes Expanding Disease Research Center
The Agriculture Department is seeking money to turn the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, a mile off Long Island, into a top-security laboratory where some of the most dangerous diseases known to man or beast can be studied.   A1
 
Divorce Court Scheme
Prosecutors said the top clerk of the Manhattan matrimonial court rushed through divorce cases for $10 and up, including cases in which husbands forged their wives' signatures to win uncontested divorces.   A1
 
Hospital to Pay $45 Million
Staten Island University Hospital agreed to reimburse the state Medicaid program $45 million for improper bills it submitted over a five-year period, and it will provide $39 million in free care for indigent patients in the next 20 years.   B1
 
Seat Belts and School Buses
The National Transportation Safety Board said better padding would protect school bus riders better than seat belts, which New York and New Jersey require on the buses.   B1
 
Mosquitoes in Greenwich
Mosquitoes carrying St. Louis encephalitis were found at a country club in Greenwich, Conn. Officials said outdoor activities would be restricted from 5 P.M. to dawn.   B1
 
Backing Bradley for President
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who is not seeking re-election next year, intends to endorse his former Senate colleague, Bill Bradley, for President tomorrow.   B4
 
EDUCATION   B11
 
SPORTS   D1-8
 
ARTS   E1-10
 
Schiele Subpoena Quashed
The State Court of Appeals set aside a subpoena that barred two Egon Schiele paintings looted by the Nazis from being returned to Austria.   E1
 
BUSINESS DAY   C1-26
 
Trade Deficit Still Growing
The Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit for July hit $25.2 billion, higher than the June imbalance of $24.6 billion. The dollar slipped against the yen, and stocks and bonds fell sharply, with the Dow losing 225 points, or 2.08 percent.   A1
 
Ford Labor Pact in Canada
Ford reached a tentative, three-year contract with the union representing its Canadian workers.   C1
 
Nasdaq Offering Reconsidered
The Nasdaq may not go public after all; instead, the market's board is expected to consider a plan in two weeks to sell a minority stake privately to substantial outsiders.   C1
 
Coast-to-Coast Cell Network
Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local phone company, and Vodafone Airtouch, Britain's largest wireless concern, will combine United States wireless operations to create the largest coast-to-coast network.   C1
 
Microsoft Trial Goes to Judge
Closing statements were delivered in the year-old Microsoft antitrust trial. The judge's ruling is expected around the end of the year.   C1

223 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)


September 29, 2002 Sunday


Kostunica's political life at stake today; Patience: 2 years after taking power many are growing impatient for change


BYLINE: KATARINA KRATOVAC


SECTION: Pg. a13


LENGTH: 492 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


Weary of Slobodan Milosevic's iron-handed reign and legacy of Balkan wars, Serbs eagerly embraced Vojislav Kostunica as the man who could topple their autocratic ruler and lead them out of economic hardship.

Kostunica fulfilled only the first of those desires.

A tumultuous two years later, Kostunica seeks re-election today by a Serbian electorate disillusioned with the slowness of reforms and the lack of improvement in daily life. 

Kostunica's own political career is at stake: His job as the federal president could end with constitutional changes intended to transform Yugoslavia into a loose union of its two republics, Serbia and Montenegro.

So 58-year-old Kostunica decided to run in Serbia's presidential race, boosted by popularity polls that show him in the lead. He is counting on his calm, commonsensical demeanor to keep him on top.

His past and his own brand of modest Serb nationalism may do it.

A somewhat colorless law school professor, Kostunica is a scholar of democracy who translated the Federalist Papers into Serbo-Croat. For his staunch anti-communism, he was kicked out of his job at Belgrade's university in 1974.

Kostunica found a niche at the Institute of Philosophy, where with time he became merely another academic critic of Milosevic. Then he turned to politics and in 1992 founded the Democratic Party of Serbia, which he has led ever since.

In 2000, the party joined an 18-member anti-Milosevic alliance that launched an election campaign which electrified Serbia and, despite Milosevic's manipulations, won the election of Sept. 24, 2000.

Married without children, Kostunica was known as a frugal, retiring man, and this added to his appeal, setting him in sharp contrast to Milosevic's aloof and authoritarian style.

With Milosevic out of power and under virtual house arrest, Kostunica settled into the role of Yugoslavia's president and Serbian nationalist who never quite forgave Western leaders for bombing Serbia. He steadfastly refused to extradite Milosevic to the U.N. tribunal at The Hague, Netherlands, on charges of war crimes and genocide.

That resistance led him to a head-on collision with Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic, his chief political rival.

Disregarding Kostunica's argument that delivering a Yugoslav national to The Hague court would be illegal, Djindjic engineered Milosevic's handover in June 2001.

That extradition marked a significant change in the once united pro-democracy movement and personal rivalries escalated. Now, Kostunica and Djindjic say they are no longer on speaking terms.

In today' elections, Serbia's ruling coalition and Djindjic are supporting another candidate, Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister Miroljub Labu, and promising "sweeping and fast changes."

"Some are in a great hurry," Kostunica said to a cheering campaign rally last week. ""You and I, meanwhile, know the best things come out of patience and hard work."


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP photo


Copyright 2002 Woodward Communications, Inc.


224 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


March 18, 1991


The game is up for a strongman now revealed as the real separatist: Serbia's President is paying dearly for his fit of pique


BYLINE: By IAN TRAYNOR in Belgrade


LENGTH: 816 words


 

IT WAS, said the Western envoy, like the spoilt child who upends the draughts board halfway through the game because he is losing and cries: 'I'm not playing any more.'

Thus, in a fit of pique after having been defeated in a democratic vote, not once but three times in four days, President Slobodan Milosevic withdrew Serbia from Yugoslavia's collective federal presidency.

The game is up in more ways than this. Mr Milosevic's decision to quit punctured two myths he was fond of fostering. Firstly, that it was he and his Serbian Socialist Party that sought to maintain the existence of Yugoslavia, while his rivals outside Serbia were intent on breaking up the union. 

'He's losing power in the federal institutions and in Serbia itself. As a result, it turns out that it is Milosevic who is the true separatist,' said one Croatian politician yesterday. That much was long suspected, but has come into sharp focus over the past week.

What is bad for Mr Milosevic is good for Yugoslavia. Certainly, as a result of the Serbian leader's weakening at the hands of the opposition, Yugoslavia is quietly and coolly fighting back. The army has stuck by the law of the land, abiding by the presidency decision to reject a military clampdown.

'If the army were to intervene now, I don't see how it could be anything but anti-Milosevic,' said a Western diplomat. 'He has shown clearly that it is he who is against the federation, the thing that the army is indoctrinated to protect.'

If Mr Milosevic could count on the support of the top brass he would not have needed to try to wreck the presidency, nor would he proclaim the need to beef up Serbia's own security forces as being so 'urgent'.

Ante Markovic, the federal Prime Minister, sidelined for months by the ethnic conflicts and subversion by the republics of his economic reforms, is sounding almost serenely confident and unflustered, issuing timely signals stressing that the federal government and federal Parliament will work as normal towards democratic and peaceful solutions.

Yugoslavia has entered its final agony, stated Mr Milosevic in his opening sentence on Saturday. Yesterday, the Markovic camp responded crisply that it is Mr Milosevic himself who is in the final throes of agony.

The Croats said that Mr Markovic's position had been immensely strengthened by the latest eruption of the crisis, while the Serbian leader's weakening was promising for the rest of Yugoslavia. Promising it may be, but it is also dangerous.

Mr Milosevic is now boxed into a corner. As he sees his power and appeal diminishing, he appears desperate and insecure. Many believe he will flinch from little to remain in power.

The main Serbian opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement, responded immediately to Saturday's declaration by stating it would not be an accomplice to the fanning of 'hatred, chaos, and paranoia' aimed at keeping Mr Milosevic in power.

But already Mr Milosevic is resorting to the same tactics that brought him to power, seeking to rally the masses to the nationalist flag and exploit Serbian hostility towards the Albanian majority in the southern province of Kosovo, which is under Serbian police rule.

Many expect he will try to provoke disturbances in Kosovo, or in the Sanjak area around the town of Novi Pazar, also in southern Serbia, where there is friction with the Muslim community. Trouble here could quickly spill over into neighbouring Bosnia, the scene of some of the worst atrocities of the civil war in the forties, and nowadays arguably the most ethnically confused and complex area in Europe, where the majority Muslims cohabit increasingly uneasily with large Serb and Croatian minorities.

The other myth that has been exploded over the past week by students on the streets of Belgrade is that Mr Milosevic represents all of Yugoslavia's nine million Serbs.

That claim was the basis for his intransigence in the stalemated negotiations among the six republics on the future of Yugoslavia. Mr Milosevic has never evinced any readiness or ability to negotiate. But with his sweeping presidential majority from last year, he could claim a mandate for that stubborness.

Deprived of that mandate by the growing opposition within Serbia, he has simply, by withdrawing Serbia from the presidency, foreclosed the forum for negotiations.

Much now hangs on what showing the Serbian opposition can muster at the demonstrations it has called for Wednesday, provided the peace is maintained in the meantime. If the opposition mushrooms, it could bring to the fore another Serbia that is flexibly and pragmatically for another Yugo-slavia.

The scenarios among the pundits here are at least as myriad as the nationalities in this country. But amid all the predictions of doom and bloodshed, there is a glimmer of light for the voices of sweet reason.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Guardian Newspapers Limited


225 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


September 26, 2000, Tuesday


'Free us from this asylum'


SOURCE: AFP, The Times


BYLINE: * A correspondent in Belgrade


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 29


LENGTH: 423 words


FROM the thousands of people gathered in central Belgrade on election night came cheers when the Opposition claimed gains and sharp whistles for results in favour of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

The cheers far outnumbered the whistles.

As soon as polling closed across Serbia and Montenegro yesterday, Opposition supporters filed into central Belgrade with an exuberance reflecting their hopes that, this time, Mr Milosevic would not escape the judgment from the streets. 

After midnight local time, there were 20,000 Opposition supporters filling the city's main axis, Terazije Avenue, letting off firecrackers and throwing cries of "victory" to the night sky in a party atmosphere.

Somewhere, a chant would gather force, calling for Vojislav Kostunica, the Opposition candidate who was allegedly on the verge of trouncing Mr Milosevic in the polls. "Free this country from the asylum it is locked in!" some yelled.

A moment of tension arrived when about 100 riot police were deployed to step between the burgeoning crowd and a few hundred pro-Milosevic demonstrators who had resolutely taken over the central place, Republic Square, with a state-sponsored concert.

"Go home. He [Milosevic] is finished," the opposition supporters cried, drowning out the singers.

"Go to Kosovo!" they yelled to the police, who were standing impassive in their armour, their batons in hand and their pistols holstered on their belts.

The minutes ticked by, and the cafes around the square started to take in their tables and chairs, fearing the worst. Then, shortly after midnight, the police and Mr Milosevic's supporters retreated, leaving the centre of Yugoslavia's capital to the massing, happy crowd.

The mood was celebratory, fuelled by a regular update yelled from the window of the opposition Democratic Party building on the avenue.

"Kill yourself and save Serbia, Slobodan!" was the chant, followed by a vocal demand for their new hero, Mr Kostunica.

Meanwhile, Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement -- the largest single opposition party in Serbia -- was awaiting the results in his summer villa at Budva in Montenegro, which, along with Serbia, forms the rump Yugoslav federation.

"After tomorrow, nothing will be the same in Serbia again," he said.

He is unable to return to Belgrade after an assassination attempt on June 15.

Although he is in exile, his wife, Dana, is waging war on Mira Markovic, Mr Milosevic's wife, through the pages of her anti-Milosevic newspaper.


LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 2000 Nationwide News Pty Limited


226 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


September 26, 2000, Tuesday


'Free us from this asylum'


SOURCE: AFP, The Times


BYLINE: * A correspondent in Belgrade


SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 29


LENGTH: 423 words


FROM the thousands of people gathered in central Belgrade on election night came cheers when the Opposition claimed gains and sharp whistles for results in favour of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

The cheers far outnumbered the whistles.

As soon as polling closed across Serbia and Montenegro yesterday, Opposition supporters filed into central Belgrade with an exuberance reflecting their hopes that, this time, Mr Milosevic would not escape the judgment from the streets. 

After midnight local time, there were 20,000 Opposition supporters filling the city's main axis, Terazije Avenue, letting off firecrackers and throwing cries of "victory" to the night sky in a party atmosphere.

Somewhere, a chant would gather force, calling for Vojislav Kostunica, the Opposition candidate who was allegedly on the verge of trouncing Mr Milosevic in the polls. "Free this country from the asylum it is locked in!" some yelled.

A moment of tension arrived when about 100 riot police were deployed to step between the burgeoning crowd and a few hundred pro-Milosevic demonstrators who had resolutely taken over the central place, Republic Square, with a state-sponsored concert.

"Go home. He [Milosevic] is finished," the opposition supporters cried, drowning out the singers.

"Go to Kosovo!" they yelled to the police, who were standing impassive in their armour, their batons in hand and their pistols holstered on their belts.

The minutes ticked by, and the cafes around the square started to take in their tables and chairs, fearing the worst. Then, shortly after midnight, the police and Mr Milosevic's supporters retreated, leaving the centre of Yugoslavia's capital to the massing, happy crowd.

The mood was celebratory, fuelled by a regular update yelled from the window of the opposition Democratic Party building on the avenue.

"Kill yourself and save Serbia, Slobodan!" was the chant, followed by a vocal demand for their new hero, Mr Kostunica.

He is unable to return to Belgrade after an assassination attempt on June 15.

Although he is in exile, his wife, Dana, is waging war on Mira Markovic, Mr Milosevic's wife, through the pages of her anti-Milosevic newspaper.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 2000 Nationwide News Pty Limited


227 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


January 7, 1997 Tuesday


Church's stand spurred by nationalism Religious, army leaders turned on Milosevic because he failed to feed their ambitions and not on account of his attacks on democracy, expert on region says.


BYLINE: BY BERNARD KAPLAN


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A13


LENGTH: 688 words


DATELINE: Paris


Hearst Newspapers

THE decision by church leaders and several army chiefs to distance themselves from Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic reflects the fact that opposition to him is spurred as much by extreme nationalism as by a desire for democracy, analysts say.

The Serbian Orthodox Church and the military chiefs of the former Yugoslav army strongly supported Mr. Milosevic when he launched the 1992 war to carve out a Greater Serbia from the territory of newly independent Bosnia. 

Now, according to historian Georges Castellan, a specialist on the region, church and army leaders blame Mr. Milosevic for selling out Bosnia's Serbs by agreeing to the 1995 Dayton peace agreement under pressure from the United States.

The church and the army "have withdrawn their support from Milosevic, not because he thwarted democratic elections in Serbia but because he proved ineffective in advancing Serbia's nationalist ambitions," Mr. Castellan said.

"For many years, the Orthodox Church and the military were staunch pillars of his autocratic rule. They've dropped him because he failed to create an enlarged Serbian state, not because they're in favour of democracy."

The church and the army waited for the regime to become vulnerable and, when it did, jumped in to weaken it further, Mr. Castellan added.

For the past six weeks, anti-Milosevic demonstrators have protested daily in the streets of Belgrade against the government's decision to annul municipal elections after a victory by opposition candidates in 14 of Serbia's 19 largest cities.

The struggle has been largely portrayed as a straight duel between pro-democracy forces in Serbia and Mr. Milosevic's neo-Communist regime. But some experts question whether it is as simple as that.

Bernard Orban, a specialist in the politics of the former Yugoslavia at France's National Research Council, said several opposition leaders have long-standing credentials as extreme nationalists.

"Vuk Draskovic [a key leader of the Belgrade protest] may proclaim his conversion to democracy," Mr. Orban said. "But during the Bosnian war, he adopted an ultranationalist position. He blamed Milosevic for not doing enough to destroy Bosnian independence. Even now, his speeches are filled with allusions to the inevitability of a Greater Serbia."

If Mr. Milosevic were ousted and Mr. Draskovic took power, it would mean "another war of Serbian expansionism sooner or later," Mr. Orban said.

He conceded the presence of genuine democrats among the organizers of the protest movement but emphasized that "they are not calling the shots. The nationalists are."

In its denunciation of Mr. Milosevic last week, the synod, or senior council, of the Serbian Orthodox Church accused him of "ignoring the will of the electorate" by cancelling the election results.

But most of the statement issued by the church's 33 bishops was devoted to a denunciation of the Serbian president for "trampling under foot our glorious and sad history."

The church leaders accused Mr. Milosevic "above all" of "betraying the lands of western Serbia" -- a reference to the loss of the territories of Krajina and Slavonia to Croatian troops late in the war.

Nationalist critics alleged that Mr. Milosevic stood aside and allowed these areas, seized by the Bosnian Serbs earlier, to be reoccupied by the Croats because he was already secretly contemplating a compromise peace.

The episode also provoked bitterness among military chiefs who have now let it be known they will not order their troops to defend the regime.

The religious leaders, according to Serbian-born political analyst Henry Bernic, "had been prepared to accept almost anything from the Milosevic regime -- even its refusal to return church property confiscated by the Communists -- as long as it championed Serbian nationalism.

"Throughout Serbia's history, the Orthodox Church has been a bastion -- often, the most extreme bastion -- of Serbian political ambitions," he said. "Nothing has changed."

Consequently, Mr. Bernic added: "The rest of the world would be wise to take much of what is occurring now in Serbia with considerable skepticism."


LOAD-DATE: December 5, 2006


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1997 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved


228 of 348 DOCUMENTS


San Jose Mercury News (California)


October 29, 2000 Sunday MORNING FINAL EDITION


HOPE AMID THE RUINS DESPITE NEW WOES, OPTIMISM IS HIGH THAT YUGOSLAVIA'S BLOODY NIGHTMARE HAS ENDED


BYLINE: JEFFREY FLEISHMAN, Knight Ridder


SECTION: GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 1AA


LENGTH: 1507 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


The snapshots of this nation are sobering: long lines for sugar and cooking oil, cash machines that dispense no cash, buses brittle from rust, a burned Parliament, a string of looted banks and the world's perception that Yugoslavs are imbued with a dangerous nationalism that still threatens the Balkans.

But the larger picture emerging after the defeat of former President Slobodan Milosevic is one of Yugoslavia purging its demons and moving toward reclaiming its place in Europe. There is joy. There is sometimes bewilderment. And there is the belief that the weird and bloody nightmare is over.

"I think people abroad now think we're a miracle," said Dragoljub Milinovic, a veterinary student at Belgrade University. "For 10 years we've lived the level of African nations. Now our optimism is greater than ever. We lived in a state of complete lies. Milosevic lied to us that we were living nicely. He was fooling us even when we knew the truth." 

If new president Vojislav Kostunica "manages to introduce real democracy here, then the image of us will change," said Biljana Radivojevic, a university biology student, who'd like to see the 400,000 young and educated people who fled Yugoslavia during Milosevic's regime to return. "We'll be open to other countries. Young people will be able to travel and show a different face of Serbia abroad. I hope we have that chance."

The task of resurrecting this country of 10 million is enormous. Kostunica is faced with a ruined economy, political mischief from the last of Milosevic's cronies, an independence-minded republic of Montenegro and a troubled province of Kosovo, where 35,000 NATO troops still prevent Yugoslavia from exerting its rule over 1.8 million ethnic Albanians and the province's rich natural resources.

Kostunica is intent on guiding his country back into the fold of the international community. He must balance between Serb suspicion of the West -- especially after last year's NATO bombing -- and the need to open Yugoslavia to world markets. Western diplomats say Kostunica must delicately mend a decade of acrimony and war between Yugoslavia's immediate neighbors -- Bosnia and Croatia.

The fate of Milosevic is a pressing international concern as the West insists that the former leader be turned over to The Hague for war crimes indictments. Most Serbs believe Milosevic should be tried in Yugoslav courts, not for mass killings and atrocities, but for wrecking what was once one ofeastern Europe's richest nations. Serbs express no desire to use Milosevic's downfall to examine this nation's complicity in four nationalist wars that killed 300,000 people, mostly civilians.

Kostunica told western diplomats that there is a "very real possibility Milosevic will be brought before a Serb court."

"The common people are opposed to the West and the Hague," said Boijan Djuric, a law student and member of the Belgrade's student resistance movement. "But Milosevic should be tried for all those war crimes in Bosnia and Kosovo. We are so embarrassed that that's the only way we can change" how the world thinks of Yugoslavia.

Re-writing the nationalist distortions in Yugoslav history books -- although talked about in this fledgling age of promise -- is expected to take some time. The Serbian spin on the Kosovo war, for example, emphasized "NATO aggression" but never mentioned the ethnic-cleansing and massacres sanctioned by the Milosevic regime.

Last week, Kostunica acknowledged on CBS's "60 Minutes II," that crimes had occurred during Milosevic's crackdown in Kosovo. It was the first time any Yugoslav leader accepted responsibility and expressed regret for any of the conflicts in the last decade in the Balkans.

Kosovo is expected to remain a NATO protectorate until Kostunica and ethnic Albanian leaders can negotiate autonomy or other solutions for the province.

"This society is not based on forgiveness. It's based on revenge," said Maria Babic, who runs youth camps to teach tolerance between different ethnic groups. "Forgiving in South Africa (over apartheid) was seen as a virtue, but here it's a weakness."

The events of October have stunned this country. Milosevic's downfall -- as 200,000 protesters massed in the streets and armed citizens seized government offices -- thrilled Serbs whose political opposition had been repeatedly crushed by the autocratic leader. Although the uprising appeared spontaneous, much of it was planned, especially the actions of gangs of armed men from the heartland town of Cacak, who rolled into Belgrade with a bulldozer, two truck loads of stones and a van filled with Molotov cocktails. With help from sympathetic police, they captured the Parliament and state TV.

Milosevic fled to his house in the suburbs, where he remains protected by guards. Western officials described Milosevic's regime as "decaying." The powerful state security police appear to have abandoned him, as have members of his socialist party.

The euphoria over the "revolution" vibrates daily across this country. The most popular CD features Milosevic on the cover and the satirical song, The Last Train for Serbia. Anti-Milosevic buttons are sold in the streets. The police are nearly invisible. Each day the tiny flags of other countries flap from BMWs and Mercedes as diplomats return to this capital. They bring good news, such as the announcement that the French automaker Peugeot will enter a partnership with Yugoslavia's Zastava car factory.

But these scenes are inter-cut with images of sugar lines, poverty and the crumpled buildings struck 20 months ago by NATO war planes. Yugoslavia's unemployment rate is 50 percent. The average monthly income is about $40. Pension checks are months late. The elderly routinely pick through dumpsters. Stories of government corruption are endless, such as the looting of $500,000 from the Bim Slavia meat plant by general manager Velibor Tomasevic, a buddy of Milosevic's wife, Mira.

At many businesses, workers have forcefully removed their bosses and seized company records. The executives are resorting to some serious last-minute house cleaning. "The management is trying to destroy documents, archives and all traces of their corruption," said retired Gen. Vuk Obradovic, a leader of a democratic political party.

The sting of the regime's criminality will be felt in coming months.

"I expect a lot of problems (in rebuilding the country) but the best of this is there is no more Milosevic," said Srboljub Antic, a member of G-17, a group of economists advising Kostunica's government. "We don't want to lie to the people . . . We are going to start a campaign soon to warn people of energy shortages over the winter."

"The biggest issue here is the economy," said Babic. "Whatever else the new government does won't matter unless people feel it in their wallets . . . They can't wipe out the black market because too many people rely on it now." The black market, which blossomed under economic sanctions, accounts for atleast 40 percent of the $13 billion gross domestic product, according to independent economists.

These days the bootleg CD sellers on Resavska Street are not a happy lot. Kostunica's government is attempting to stabilize the dinar. That has them in fits.

"Nobody knows the real rate of currency," said Marijan Stojkovic, leaning on a stack of black market CDs imported from Bulgaria. "Nobody is buying. There are no dinars on the streets. We just need a stabilized rate. I bought these CDs at 35 dinars to one German mark. Now the dinar is down to 22 and I'm losing money."

The European Union recently pledged $2 billion in aid. International sanctions, including oil and flight embargoes by the U.S., are being lifted. Italian and Greek firms -- who signed letters of intent during sanctions -- are planning to open businesses and offices across Yugoslavia.

But political analysts here say that Kostunica's relationship with the West will be risky. If Kostunica, a nationalist himself, appears to anger the Army or to drift too close to the West, diplomats say, it could incite Serb nationalism.

The new government is "carefully choosing its words about relationships with western countries," said Srdan Hofman, a composer and member of the Social Democrats, one of 18 parties supporting Kostunica.

Even in his weakened state Milosevic still casts a large shadow on this nation. His fate is ceaselessly debated. Anger over his regime grows. The turmoil he has caused for the last 13 years has set a harsh frame for the future. And, according to Kostunica's reformers, the fallen leader still has supporters who can stir trouble.

Vesna Hadjivokovac said the events of the last two weeks have made her numb. She is the epitome of the new Serb state of mind. She was an army spokeswoman during the Kosovo war. Today, she is a translator and analyst for the western media.

"My suffering is greater than yours," she recently told a colleague. "I have to explain a logic that doesn't exist."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: PICKING UP
THE PIECES
IN
YUGOSLAVIA
STILL FLUSH WITH THE SUCCESS OF THEIR POPULAR REVOLT AGAINST SLOBODAN MILOSEVIC, THE PEOPLE OF YUGOSLAVIA HAVE CONSIDERABLE WORK AHEAD OF THEM IN REBUILDING THEIR COUNTRY. EVEN WITH MILOSEVIC REMOVED FROM POWER, THE SPECTERS OF ECONOMIC DECAY AND NATIONALISM LOOM LARGE.

229 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Australian


March 14, 2003 Friday All-round Country Edition


Serb ruler wooed West


SOURCE: The Times


SECTION: FEATURES-TYPE- FEATUREOBITUARY-BIOG- ZORAN DJINDJIC; Pg. 12


LENGTH: 1235 words


Obituary

Zoran Djindjic

Prime Minister, Republic of Serbia. Born August 1, 1952. Died Belgrade, March 12, aged 50.

THE assassination of Zoran Djindjic threatens to plunge Serbia and the Balkans back into the appalling turmoil of the 1990s.

Although he was a controversial figure, Djindjic was widely recognised as his country's most dynamic politician. His death leaves no obvious successor at a time of great uncertainty and there are fears that the power vacuum in Serbia could undermine political stability elsewhere, especially in Kosovo. 

Arrogant and effective in equal measure, Djindjic also specialised in making enemies. His greatest opponents were among organised crime syndicates. For years he was accused of collaborating with the Surcin gang, one of the most powerful in Belgrade.

Djindjic always denied any association, but when the head of the Surcin gang recently fled the country and began to issue declarations from hiding, observers were alerted that various mafia groups had started to settle old scores.

Since becoming the Prime Minister of Serbia a little more than two years ago, Djindjic had been steadily introducing painful reforms that have won the plaudits of the European Union and the World Bank, but have not always endeared him to the public.

Djindjic never shook off the image of the gangster turned politician -- in contrast to his ally turned nemesis, Vojislav Kostunica, the former Yugoslav president. But three months ago Djindjic signalled that it was time to take on the gangs that plague Serbia. In the past month Serbian police have achieved some of their biggest successes in the fight against organised crime in the Balkans. Several factories producing drugs such as ecstasy for sale in western Europe were closed down.

Djindjic's death has implications that go beyond the struggle against organised crime. In recent months his Government had come under exceptional pressure from the US to hand over to the UN all remaining war crimes suspects thought to be on Serbian territory. In particular, Washington threatened to withdraw its aid program if it did not hand over by the end of June Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb commander.

Without Djindjic there is almost no chance that Belgrade will meet the deadline and so vital funds could be withheld just when the Serbian economy is desperate for help.

His murder does not affect the stability of Serbia alone; in the wider region it casts a long shadow over the unresolved issue of Kosovo's status.

Djindjic had made his name in the West as "the West's man" in post-Milosevic Yugoslavia. In many ways he resembled contemporaries such as Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and Gerhard Schroder, in that he seemed to be above all else a pragmatist who had no great visions but was prepared, like Bismarck, to float and steer upon the river of time.

But it was not always so and his political outlook evolved with the great changes that affected his country. To his supporters this was sensible and productive realism; to his opponents it was opportunism.

Djindjic was born in the Bosnian village of Bosanski Samac in 1952, the son of a Yugoslav army officer. He showed early political awareness when he tried to collect signatures protesting against a new law that made Marshal Tito president of Yugoslavia for life. Although punished for this indiscretion, he went on to complete a philosophy degree at Belgrade University, only to run foul of the authorities once again when, in 1974, with like-minded students from Croatia and Slovenia, he tried to found a non-communist student movement. For this he and his would-be colleagues were sentenced to one year's jail. On his release, Djindjic went to Germany to study at the University of Frankfurt when that institution was still associated with the student protest movement.

Back in Yugoslavia, Djindjic taught philosophy in the universities of Novi Sad and Belgrade. But within a few years he was fully engaged in politics.

As the final vestiges of the communist monopoly of power disappeared, Djindjic became one of the founders of the Democratic Party and two years later, in 1990, he became its chairman and in 1994 its president. He was elected to the Serbian parliament in 1990.

Djindjic then moved his supposedly centrist party closer to Serbian nationalism. In 1994, when the Bosnian Serbs were ordered by the Western powers to end the bombardment of Sarajevo, Djindjic showed, as he said, "solidarity with the Bosnian Serbs" by going to the Bosnian Serb capital, Pale, and partaking of a roasted ox with Radovan Karadzic. Djindjic also had occasional meetings with the notorious "Arkan", who led one of the groups of irregulars fighting in Bosnia.

Yet when Serbian nationalism was defeated in 1995, Djindjic sought a new tack, one that brought him into direct opposition to president Slobodan Milosevic. He played a key role in bringing about Zajedno (Together), an alliance of three anti-Milosevic parties. At the end of 1996 the alliance secured notable victories in local elections.

Though Milosevic initially tried to discount the elections, his hand was forced by widespread public protests and Western pressure, and in February 1997 Djindjic became the first non-communist mayor of Belgrade since 1945.

Djindjic performed another about-face and abandoned the more vociferous nationalists. In December 1996 he had told the German magazine Der Spiegel that he was "the horse that the West should back". After his removal from Belgrade Town Hall, he concentrated on gathering round him experts who could help reconstruct a Serbian economy battered by years of war and sanctions.

Only in the West, he argued, could the requisite expertise and capital be found. This did not mean that he condoned NATO action against Serbia in 1999, but once that had ended he pushed hard for Serbia's reintegration into the West. He became an even more determined opponent of Milosevic and played a significant role in his removal.

At the end of 2000 Djindjic was at the head of a new coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, which secured an easy victory in the parliamentary elections. He assumed office as Prime Minister of Serbia in January 2001.

As Prime Minister, Djindjic continued his pro-Western line but it was one that brought him into frequent conflict with the then president of Yugoslavia, Kostunica. Their differences were never greater than over the question of whether Milosevic should be extradited to face the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague. It was Djindjic who sanctioned Milosevic's extradition in June 2001. The following day an international donors' conference in Brussels offered Yugoslavia $US1.28billion in grants and loans.

Djindjic was universally recognised as a powerful intellect and an organiser of prodigious talents. But as with many politicians of his generation there was always doubt as to what, if any, were his core beliefs, and he never enjoyed the popular support accorded to his fellow intellectual and opponent, Kostunica.

In the Serbian presidential elections of 2002, Djindjic chose to back Miroslav Labus rather than run himself. Nevertheless, to many Serbs Djindjic remained what one British newspaper had called him after the fall of Milosevic: "the shadow kingmaker".

Djindjic is survived by his wife Ruzica, a lawyer, and by a son and a daughter.


LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


Copyright 2003 Nationwide News Pty Limited


230 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)


April 16, 1999, FINAL


Serbs united by NATO attacks


BYLINE: Patrick Bishop, The Telegraph


SECTION: World; D1 / FRONT


LENGTH: 516 words


DATELINE: LONDON


''This is a disaster for people like me,'' a Serb friend told me on the phone from Belgrade the other day. ''Now we are never going to get rid of him.''

It is just as well that NATO has not declared the removal of Slobodan Milosevic as a war aim. In keeping with Nietzsche's dictum, that which has not killed Milosevic has made him stronger. 

For the first time in his political career, he is enjoying the unconditional support of a majority of Serbs. Politicians who hate the Yugoslav president, as well as army malcontents who have been plotting his overthrow, have prudently decided to rally behind him or suspend their opposition.

Bourgeois intellectuals and the trendy young are finding that, beneath their European veneer, a Serb heart is beating. ''Only unity can save the Serbs'' runs the old slogan. Now, for once, Serbdom is unified -- thanks to NATO .

There is a strong streak of paranoia in the Serb psyche. As a result, many will find a perverse satisfaction in the bombing. Serbs are always being told by their leaders that the world is against them. Now they know it is true.

What they do not know is why NATO has gone to war with them. Viewed from outside Yugoslavia, it is hard to understand how Serb citizens can apparently condone the ethnic cleansing and murder that is being carried out on their behalf by Milosevic's forces in Kosovo.

That, of course, is not how the conflict has been presented. From the outset, the state-controlled media have portrayed it as struggle between the security forces and Albanian ''terrorists,'' who specialize in cowardly attacks on policemen and Serb civilians in their drive to break away from Yugoslavia and establish an independent state.

It was a picture that few bothered to challenge. Animosity toward the Albanians runs deep. Kosovo, with its Serb Orthodox foundations and battle site of the Field of Blackbirds (on which the Battle of Kosovo Polje was fought in 1389, when the Serb and Turkish armies met and the flower of Serbdom was slain) is genuinely dear to Serbs, though as an idea rather than a reality. Few visit, let alone choose to settle there.

When NATO bombs began to fall, the first reaction of many was astonishment. It was as if the U.S. decided to bombard Britain because it was unhappy with our treatment of the IRA. That feeling has now given way to a mood of resolution and stoicism, qualities that the Serbs have frequently demonstrated in their stormy history.

Now, almost everything that NATO does simply reinforces those feelings. A bomb fell on the town of Kragujevac, a bastion of the anti-Milosevic movement. More than 500 young men volunteered for the forces.

The raids on factories and infrastructure targets are failing to have the demoralizing effect for which the allies rashly hoped. If anything, they are reinforcing social solidarity.

NATO is facing a country that is more united than at any time since the break-up of the Yugoslav federation. The allies' psychological campaign against the Serb people appears to have been no more effective than the air campaign.


LOAD-DATE: April 16, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
