231 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


December 28, 1996


REPORT DAMNS SERB POLL FIX;
Milosevic faces stark choice after international mediators urge him to respect the will of the people


BYLINE: Julian Borger East Europe Correspondent


SECTION: THE GUARDIAN HOME PAGE; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

SERBIA'S protest movement scored an important victory yesterday when a team of international mediators unequivocally upheld opposition wins in local elections and called on President Slobodan Milosevic to respect the will of the people.

The judgment by the Organisation of Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), was greeted with jubilation in Belgrade by crowds of opposition supporters who have protested daily since the government refused to accept a string of defeats in major cities in municipal elections on November 17.

But the celebrations turned sour as night fell, when police clashed with protesters returning home from a rally. Witnesses said police attacked with truncheons after being jeered. At least one person was beaten unconscious, and two foreign television crews were attacked and had their cameras smashed. 

The OSCE findings are not legally binding but they present Mr Milosevic with a stark choice. If he accepts them, they could provide a face-saving way out of the deadlocked confrontation. If he ignores the judgment, he will make it clear that he would rather resume the role of international pariah than share even a token slice of power.

The former Spanish foreign minister, Felipe Gonzalez, who led an OSCE mission to Serbia last weekend, said the opposition Zajedno (Together) coalition had won local polls in 13 disputed cities and towns and in nine Belgrade municipalities.

Speaking at a press conference in Geneva, Mr Gonzalez said the Serbian courts annulled the results on the basis of arguments "that no democratic country could have accepted". His report recommended that the 53-nation OSCE issue an urgent call on the authorities "to implement the will of the citizens as expressed in the polls".

The Spanish mediator said he telephoned Mr Milosevic to inform him of the findings and asked for a response by early next week.

"There exists an extraordinary opportunity for the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to solve this concrete problem, to initiate real democracy in the country, and to reintegrate itself into the international community," said Mr Gonzalez.

An OSCE council meeting is expected in Vienna before the end of next week to consider Mr Milosevic's response. Diplomats say economic sanctions, lifted after last year's Bosnian peace agreement, could be reimposed if he refuses to compromise. Russia, however, has opposed the use of further international pressure.

In Belgrade, around 80,000 Zajedno supporters cheered and danced in the street after the ruling was announced. But coalition leaders said they expected the president to choose confrontation.

"We do not expect him to accept the findings of this commission, we expect further escalation, aggravation," said Zoran Djindjic, the head of the Democratic Party, one of Zajedno's main forces.

Mr Milosevic called in thousands of riot police on Thursday to manhandle marchers off the streets of Belgrade. Since then, the demonstrators have confined themselves to marching in circles, blowing trumpets and whistles and shouting anti-Milosevic slogans.

Blatant election-rigging by the government has already torpedoed the prospect of international financial sanctions being lifted.

But independent analysts have expressed concern that trade sanctions would not significantly weaken Mr Milosevic, who presides over an already devastated economy in a country where much of the population has fallen back on subsistence agriculture and supports the Serbian strongman out of a tradition of deference born of half a century of communism.


LOAD-DATE: December 28, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1996 Guardian Newspapers Limited


232 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


June 28, 1999, Monday


LIBERATION OF KOSOVO: PRIESTS DESERT THE NATIONALIST CAUSE;
 SERBIAN ORTHODOX CHURCH


BYLINE: Raymond Whitaker In Gracanica


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 1030 words


 

"THOSE PEOPLE who represent the war against Nato as another battle of Kosovo Polje are insulting our heritage as well as the Serbian Orthodox Church," said Father Sava Janjic. "In 1389 Prince Lazar carried the holy cross into battle; today, instead of the cross we have instruments of torture, and instead of the noble prince we have indicted war criminals."

Father Sava was speaking within the leafy precincts of the 14th-century monastery of Gracanica, a short distance south of Pristina, the provincial capital. It is one of the reasons why Kosovo is considered the seat of Serbian Orthodoxy: Gracanica and other monasteries are the oldest foundations in the faith. Today the head of Serbian Orthodoxy, Patriarch Pavle Ras- Prizren, will officiate at a solemn liturgy in the monastery to commemorate the 610th anniversary of the battle of Kosovo Polje (the Field of Blackbirds), which is seen by Serbs as the key to their national identity. For many others, however, the battle is significant because of its exploitation by Slobodan Milosevic, through which he enlisted the support of many in the Church. 

The Serbian Orthodox hierarchy did much to foster the tide of Serbian nationalism which Mr Milosevic later rode. In 1987 bishops decided to take the relics of Prince Lazar in procession from monastery to monastery, an event which attracted huge crowds and helped to re-establish the Church at the centre of the Serbs' sense of nationhood. In April the same year Mr Milosevic, then an obscure Communist Party official, gave the speech which was to make his career. At Kosovo Polje, the mainly Serb satellite town of Pristina named after the battle, he put himself at the head of Serbian nationalists who had been fighting the police, telling them: "Nobody should dare to beat you!"

Two years later, having risen to the verge of the Yugoslav presidency, Mr Milosevic came to Kosovo to commemorate the 600th anniversary of the battle. On 28 April 1989, amid scenes of adulation not seen since the death of Tito in 1980, he spoke to a crowd of a million people. Behind him on the podium was a row of Orthodox bishops. Reminded of this a decade later, Father Sava said: "The Orthodox Church does not have a unified political standpoint. There are a lot of deluded people in our number - probably many of them still support Milosevic."

But the Kosovo in which the 610th anniversary will be marked is very different from a year ago, let alone a decade ago. Yugoslav security forces have gone, and the Nato troops who replaced them are struggling to protect an ever -dwindling Serb minority from the revenge of the Albanian population. Yesterday the people of Belo Polje, a Serbian village near Pec, fled to the city's monastery after Albanians, said to be in Kosovo Liberation Army uniforms, burned and looted their homes. They also allegedly raped and murdered a mentally ill Serbian woman.

Yesterday too, Miodrag Zivic, a school porter at Laplje Selo village, only a mile or two from Gracanica, was buried after being beaten and shot four times by Albanians. British K-For troops took him to hospital, but he never regained consciousness.

Momcilo Trajkovic, the leader in Kosovo of the Serbian Resistance Movement, an anti-Milosevic party, was Zivic's cousin. In the heat outside the house where women were wailing over the body, he said: "This funeral is the result of Milosevic's policies, Albanian terrorism and the failings of the international community, but above all Milosevic." Events such as his cousin's death would weigh heavily at today's commemoration, but he added: "That ceremony, like this one, is a religious event, not a political one.

"Before the present situation the Church did allow itself to be used, but Patriarch Pavle and Bishop Artemije (head of the Church in Kosovo) tried to prevent it. Artemije spoke for the people of Kosovo. He was never a supporter of Milosevic."

At the monastery, Father Sava too was seeking to distance the Church from any of the anniversary's political connotations. "Each year we would commemorate the battle in a religious way, and other people would stage a march. The two were in parallel." But Patriarch Pavle also plans to speak at the monument to the battle at Gazimestan, just north of Kosovo Polje town, creating a potential security nightmare for K-For.

Father Sava's own credentials are not in doubt: during the war he sheltered dozens of Albanians from Serbian death squads at Decani monastery, south of Pec. But others point out that Patriarch Pavle did not come out against Mr Milosevic until after the war was over, and that it took another Serbian defeat - the Croatian seizure of Krajina in 1995, which sent 250,000 refugees into Serbia - to convince Bishop Artemije of the dangers of Serbian expansionism.

The bishop has spoken out courageously in the past year, calling for a ceasefire last summer when Serbian forces launched an offensive against the KLA. Two days after the Nato bombing campaign began, he condemned killing and looting in Kosovo, but his statement was ignored by Belgrade's media. No other condemnation of ethnic cleansing was heard from the Church; Patriarch Pavle said in Belgrade that Nato was "doomed to failure". Only after Nato forces had begun entering Kosovo did the Serbian Orthodox synod call for Mr Milosevic's resignation.

Last week, as Bishop Artemije and other Church leaders emerged from a meeting in Pristina with UN representatives, they were booed and hissed. The bishop fled to Gracanica from his seat in Prizren, in south-western Kosovo, after one priest was kidnapped, others threatened and Church buildings damaged.

The irony is that the 14th-century battle of Kosovo Polje was a defeat for Serbian expansionism: Prince Lazar fell fighting the forces of Islam, and Serbia did not regain control of Kosovo until early this century. If there is any modern parallel, it is probably here. The dream of a Greater Serbia, cheered on by most of the Orthodox clergy, has brought only disaster and defeat. As a result, the most holy places of the faith may once again be islands in an Islamic sea, for a long time to come.


LOAD-DATE: June 29, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Miobrang Zivic's family weep over his coffin(left). Ten years ago, President; Milosevic speech fatally reignited the Kosovo conflict Tom Pilston


Copyright 1999 Independent Print Ltd


233 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


JULY 4, 1999 Sunday D EDITION


SERB DISDAIN OF MILOSEVIC IS GROWING IN KOSOVO, ONE FARMER SAYS HIS LEADER HAS FINALLY LOST "THE SERBIAN SOUL."


BYLINE: Jeffrey Fleishman, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1269 words


DATELINE: LAPLJE SELO, Yugoslavia


The wheat is ready for harvest, but the combines are out of gas and Serb farmers are scared to work the fields. They sit in the shade of a cherry tree, cursing war and drinking homemade brandy until their wives collect them.

Just beyond them, NATO troops patrol narrow roads. Returning ethnic Albanian refugees seek revenge for years of Serb oppression. There seems no safe place. And the men are angry that the Kosovo land their families have farmed for centuries is suddenly in jeopardy.

The brandy stops flowing and words grow more bitter when someone mentions President Slobodan Milosevic. The Serb farmers of Laplje Selo, like increasing numbers of their countrymen, despise him. They blame Milosevic for plundering a country and twisting Serb nationalism into a sin that triggered NATO air strikes and saddled a bankrupt Yugoslavia with $40 billion worth of ruin. 

"A crook," says one farmer.

"Evil," says another.

Disdain for Milosevic is sweeping Yugoslavia. Elderly Serbs surviving on pensions of $22 a month marched against Milosevic last week in Belgrade. Tens of thousands of others - including underpaid soldiers - joined anti-Milosevic rallies in Cacak and other cities, demanding his resignation. The Serbian Orthodox Church has called for him to step down. Crown Prince Alexander, heir to Yugoslavia's exiled monarchy, described Milosevic as a "monster" who "must go, for the sake of Yugoslavia."

The surge of opposition is reminiscent of 1996, when students and intellectuals protested Milosevic's corrupt regime and militant nationalism that was tugging Yugoslavia further away from Europe.

Milosevic outlasted his detractors, dividing opposition leaders and strengthening his power. Some diplomats predict Milosevic will escape defeat again, but many Serbs say their president has shamed them for the last time.

"He's the traitor to Serb nationalism," said Momcilo Trajkovic, president of the Serbian Democratic Movement, a small opposition party founded by Trajkovic in his hometown.

"He ruined the Serbs," he said. "He betrayed our interests. He took us into war and he left us. He destroyed his own blood, and he has made the Serbs victims."

The notion of any collective culpability never comes up in conversation.

Laplje Selo's farmers say Milosevic did the most damage here, amid fields of loamy soils their families have tilled since the 14th century. The wellspring of Serb orthodox religion and tradition, Kosovo is now essentially a NATO protectorate.

In a stunning reversal of fortune, the Serbs, who once controlled Kosovo with paramilitary police, are increasingly vulnerable to ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the population.

The Serbs of Laplje Selo don't like the odds.

Across Kosovo, ethnic Albanians are looting and burning Serb homes. Serbs are winding up dead on roadsides. More than 80,000 of Kosovo's 200,000 Serbs have fled.

Most of Laplje Selo's 2,000 residents are staying put, though many farmers have sent their wives and children away until tensions ease. And a few village leaders, such as the baker, Stojan Nedeljkovic, are packing cars and tractors with furniture and clothes, just in case.

Remaining in the village is difficult, as farmers such as Zika Jovic can't sell summer squash and other vegetables because ethnic Albanians are boycotting Serb products.

"No one wants our cheese, bread or vegetables," said Jovic. "We have to give it to the cows to eat. I have to sell eggs to buy cigarettes, but now I can't even go to the market.

"We're scared. We're like prisoners. Milosevic promised so much. But we have nothing. There's not even room for us in Serbia if we leave Kosovo. The wars Milosevic started in Bosnia and Croatia have already flooded the country with Serb refugees."

Southwest of the Kosovo capital of Pristina, where the land flattens, Laplje Selo is marked by the silver domes of St. Sveta Petka church. The cemetery is wild with weeds and shiny with black granite markers, some bearing the names - as folklore has it - of those cursed to die young because their parents once sold land to Albanians.

Centuries ago, Serbs battled the Turks for this land. Then came the Germans. And last summer, 200 village men grabbed rifles and formed night patrols to protect 1,500 acres of wheat from guerrillas in the Kosovo Liberation Army. They feared the KLA might torch the fields.

Zika Jovic was one of the night watchmen.

Now, Jovic's eyes are bloodshot, his face half-shaved. He says 78 days of NATO bombing frayed his nerves. And he's worried that ethnic Albanians will burn and loot Laplje Selo as they seek vengeance for the bloody oppression and so-called ethnic cleansing wrought by Milosevic's forces.

It's ironic, he says, how quickly Serbs have become victims.

"Here I am thinking about fleeing my home, and there sits Milosevic still in power," said Jovic. "It's time to get rid of him. I don't really follow politics. I don't even care who's in power anymore. Even an Albanian would be fine with me. I just want my freedom. . . . I'm scared to leave this village."

Down the road at the village's cooperative farm office, the combines needed gasoline. War disrupted supplies, and farmers say Albanians are selling to Serbs at highly inflated prices.

Momcilo Trajkovic, the president of the Serbian Democratic Movement, said: "I feel the anger of Albanians. But now there is a tragedy against the Serbs, and NATO is doing little to stop it."

Slavoljub Mitic stopped at Zivko Nacic's general store for a beer. Rain, sweeping across the wheat fields, chased him and other men under a corrugated tin roof. They sat, listened to thunder, joked about NATO cluster bombs, and talked about 1389, when Serbian Prince Lazar battled the Turks on Kosovo's Field of Blackbirds.

Lazar's army was defeated, and he was killed.

But every Serb child is taught the poem about the epic battle, the bravery, the religious devotion, and the myths that sprang from Kosovo. Mitic remembers in 1989 when Milosevic traveled to Kosovo and ignited his political career by extolling Serb nationalism and the virtues of the prince.

But Mitic said Milosevic is no Lazar.

"We need changes in Yugoslavia," said Mitic. "We need Milosevic out. He lost Bosnia. He lost Croatia. Now, he's lost Kosovo. He lost it all. It's over. . . . Kosovo is the Serbian soul. Milosevic will be remembered in history for losing it."

Two heavily armed NATO soldiers walked past. Mitic and the others watched them round the bend in the road. Some of the men worried that NATO is not protecting their village, and many fear attacks from Albanians if they go to harvest their wheat.

"We must do this harvest no matter what the fear," said Rade Djorovic. "My family has been here for centuries. I have never missed a harvest. Fear has never kept us out of the fields."

Nearby, Jelica Petrovic, rose from a porch and strolled to the dusty shed where her nephew, Vladimir, makes tombstones.

She pointed to the tombstone of her cousin, Novica Petkovic. Born 1922. Died 1998. It sometimes takes a while, she said, before her nephew actually delivers the stone to the cemetery at St. Sveta Petka church. Novica, a farmer, died of natural causes before the NATO air strikes, the flood of Albanian refugees, and the mass graves dug by Serb paramilitary gangs.

Laplje Selo's most recent death was not peaceful.

Dragi Zivic, a school janitor, was shot by Albanians just beyond the thicket near the gas station.

"I guess we'll do his tombstone later," said Petrovic. "Milosevic got us into these problems."


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: MAP


Copyright 1999 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC 
All Rights Reserved


234 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 14, 1997, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Serbia's latest, civilized strife Fractured opposition struggles to define goal


BYLINE: David J. Lynch


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 1887 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia


BELGRADE, Serbia -- Every afternoon, thousands of protesters fill
the city center with a deafening, cacophonous roar of whistles,
horns, cow bells and chants.

Each night, promptly at the 7:30 start of the state TV news, people
bang pots and pans and honk car horns to drown out, at least symbolically,
government propaganda.

It's an extraordinary scene, this national catharsis, an unprecedented
venting of anger and disgust at the ruling regime. To American
eyes, these opposition tactics, full of passion and dreams, resemble
the democratic wave that washed across Eastern Europe after the
collapse of the Berlin Wall.

But Serbia is not Poland, where the Solidarity union waged a decade-long
battle against communists. Nor is it Romania, where the execution
of communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu bloodied the transition
to democracy.
 

Most analysts feel the danger of a violent crackdown by the Socialist
Party regime has passed. The army has declared its neutrality.
And if President Slobodan Milosevic were to order his battalions
of flak-jacketed riot police to use force, he would pay a stiff
price in world opinion -- and financial aid.

The international financing desperately needed to resuscitate
Serbia's wheezing economy would be out of reach, perhaps for good.

For now, this movement in Serbia is still a protest, not yet a
revolution.

In the 1970s movie Network, a deranged TV anchorman, fed
up with society's outrages, demands that viewers open their windows
and scream into the darkness: "I'm mad as hell and I'm not going
to take it anymore." Two decades later, all of Belgrade appears
to have heeded his call.

Mingling with the happy protesters, the noise is overwhelming.
The din overrides everything, making conversation -- even in shouts
-- all but impossible.

Actually, there are two parallel protests.

The political opposition attracts several thousand, mostly middle-class
Serbians for afternoon speeches by the leadership troika: Vuk
Draskovic, Zoran Djindic, and Vesna Pesic. In the evening, students
from the University of Belgrade take to the streets. In American
terms, it's as if 1960s Yippie leader Abbie Hoffman and Richard
Nixon's "Silent Majority" joined forces.

The two anti-government camps are allies but only to a point.
"We fight against the government, not for the opposition," says
Jelena Petrovic, 22, a student of molecular biology.

But if noise is one hallmark of the protests, humor is the students'
calling card. During one all-night protest, students took turns
reading to the police works of Greek philosophy. A cartoon on
a kind of "Democracy Wall" outside the student center shows
Arnold Schwarzenegger in full Terminator regalia under the legend:
"Hasta La Vista Communista!"

The students' presence in the streets is crucial. Milosevic has
attacked the political opposition as traitors and foreign spies.
And the coalition early on played into his hands by waving U.S.
and German flags at its rallies. It's more difficult to make such
charges against the students, many of whom are 18 or 19 years
old.

The enemy of the good

History hangs over everything here. The Balkans is a region of
long memories. Each June 28th, Serbs commemorate a battle fought
against Turk oppressors in 1389 -- a battle Serbs lost.

For a brief period at the beginning of this century, Serbia was
one of Europe's democracies. But in 1914 the moment passed. The
current generation has known only dictators.

From the end of World War II until 1980, Serbia was part of the
former Yugoslavia, which was ruled until his death by Marshal
Tito. Tito fashioned a home-grown communism, which took root in
a way that Soviet-imposed regimes never did elsewhere in eastern
Europe. Through force of personality, Tito held together a multiethnic
state of Serbs, Croats, Montenegrans and Bosnians, allowing the
people certain freedom so long as nationalist passions were in
check.

The Cold War's collapse unleashed democratic aspirations across
eastern Europe. But Milosevic, who took power in 1987, was able
to avoid the fate of leaders like East Germany's Eric Honecker,
exiled to South America, or Romania's Ceausescu, executed by opponents.
He stayed in office by channeling nationalist passions into a
genocidal war in Bosnia.

During the war, there were scattered protests. But by last November,
when balloting began in federal and local elections, the regime
had reason to feel secure. The Dayton accords, which ended the
war, secured for Milosevic greater international support. And
on Nov. 3, his ruling Socialist Party handily won federal elections.
It also seemed headed for a big win in the municipal elections
two weeks later.

But results in those elections were a shock. Normally, one-quarter
of voters participate in local elections. This time, more than
70% showed up, giving opposition parties control of 14 of the
country's 20 largest cities, including Belgrade, the capital.

Stunned officials reacted by invalidating opposition victories,
sending crowds of up to 200,000 into the streets.

Eight weeks later, the opposition has surprised itself. Never
before has an anti-Milosevic movement stayed in the streets for
so long. The last time, in 1992, the regime used tanks.

But the opposition remains weaker than it could be. Some potential
allies have offered as much criticism as support. Workers, intellectuals
and some democrats have held back.

Vojislav Kostunica, the head of the Democratic Party of Serbia,
complains the opposition is mistaken to rely so much on international
pressure. "For people who have not experienced democracy, it's
important that democracy grows in this country," he says. "If
it was somehow imported, it would not give people the right idea."

Even opposition leaders caution against optimistic predictions.
"What's happening on the streets can create the wrong impression,"
Djindjic told USA TODAY. "Milosevic has more than 50% (support).
We have something below 50%. Is now the moment to remove him or
just shake him a bit? I'm not sure."

Others are skeptical of the opposition leaders themselves, accusing
them of dabbling in nationalism when such beliefs were popular.
Pesic, head of the tiny Civic Alliance, a party of intellectuals,
is immune to such charges. But she has little influence. Draskovic,
an advocate of "Greater Serbia," and Djindic, who had close
ties to the Bosnian Serbs, are not listening.

Miladin Zivotic, one of Serbia's leading intellectuals and a longtime
foe of nationalism, leads a group called Belgrade Circle. A recent
morning found half a dozen people in his outer office, smoking
cigarettes and watching a small color television. Zivotic was
pessimistic about prospects for democracy.

Some of today's opponents "were completely involved in preparing
this war, creating this hate speech," he says.

The frail trade union movement also has been wary. Labor leaders
haven't forgotten that the opposition failed to support workers
against the state. Government harassment has whittled the independent
union's numbers to 135,000 from 300,000 five years ago. Branislav
Canak, union president, was fired from his job with state radio
for his union activities. Fearing the same for his members, he's
kept the union flags furled. "The average citizen can be beaten,"
he says from behind a desk piled high in papers. "Our members
lose their jobs."

On the border of disaster

Today's Serbian economy resembles one of its best known exports
to the United States, the notorious Yugo automobile. The government's
handling of elections sparked the protests. But equally important
in keeping people in the street in cold, snow and rain is the
erosion in living standards. "If you compare this way of living
and economy to Tito's era, then we were living in paradise,"
says Gordana Logar, a veteran journalist.

The war, economic sanctions by the west, and government cronyism
has crippled Serbia's economy. Employment in the steel industry,
which was 466,000 in 1991, is now 50,000. And the plants that
employ those lucky few often lack the energy or raw materials
to actually make anything. Unemployment, huge even before the
war, was made worse by international sanctions and a flood of
refugees unable to return home. Average salaries are around 100
dinars, or $ 25, a month.

Ljljana Raskovic, 36, lost her job after eight years. "The money
is gone. There are no jobs," she says. She motions toward her
two little girls, ages 6 and 8, as she tears up. "I'm coming
for the future of my kids, if nothing else."

Milosevic has tried to remedy economic problems the old-fashioned
way: by printing money. A hike in state pensions just before the
November election was funded this way, says Milan Potic, head
of the independent Center for Serbian Studies. That led to inflation.
In one day late last year, the dinar lost more than 25% of its
value against the German mark.

"I think Serbia is on the border of financial disaster," says
Carl Bildt, the chief international envoy in Bosnia.

And now, the really hard part

More than two months of protests have produced cracks in the regime.
The army and Serbian Orthodox Church have moved to the sidelines.
Milosevic's ruling party is reportedly divided on how to respond
to the protests. Even some riot police, waiting in their buses
one block from the protests, can be seen reading opposition newspapers.
Milosevic conceded that opponents won in Serbia's second-largest
city, Nis.

Yet Milosevic, though wounded, remains formidable. His aim appears
to be to end the student protest by meeting their demand to replace
two university officials, thus weakening the opposition. Few think
he will leave power.

His major weapon now is state radio and TV, which have alternately
ignored the opposition and branded it the work of foreign spies
and traitors.

For the opposition, taking control of the local governments it
won in November would be a mixed blessing. It would mean control
of local radio and television outlets, thus shattering the government's
monopoly on information. But opposition leaders would also be
saddled with the chores that bedevil municipal politicians from
Warsaw to Washington, D.C.: picking up the trash, keeping potholes
filled and boosting the economy. And they would have to tackle
them without money since an unfriendly federal government holds
the purse strings.

"I don't think it would be good for us to have a drastic change
of government," says Protic. "The best scenario would be a democratic
and gradual one."

That would make people like Miroslav Maric happy. The 19-year-old
student is part of a generation unfazed by the recent war. For
weeks, he's been more or less living on antibiotics and junk food
in a fourth-floor room in the university's philosophy department.
There, a half dozen students sit around a wooden table, eating
crackers and smoking. Political cartoons paper the walls.

"I believe I'm fighting once and for all for democracy here,"
he says. "I don't want any more armies on the street, or sanctions,
war, everything -- it's finally time to get some sense in our
lives."


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, color, Srdjan Ilic, AP; PHOTO, color, Darko Vojinovic, AP; PHOTO, b/w, Darko Vojinovic, AP


TYPE: Cover story


Copyright 1997 Gannett Company, Inc.


235 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury


June 8, 1993 Tuesday


BYLINE: BISHOP PATRICK


LENGTH: 885 words


President Milosevic: an authoritarian suddenly turned vicious.

Punchline of Serb chief is sour joke PATRICK BISHOP in Belgrade reports on a troubled week in Serbian politics.

WITHIN 24 hours of any political upheaval in Serbia a joke inspired by the event usually does the rounds of the bus queues and cafes in Belgrade.

Last week, following President Slobodan Milosevic's vicious crackdown on the opposition, there was stunned silence. For once, the thought processes of the leader defied the cynical analysis of the pavement philosophers. 

Since coming to prominence, Milosevic has been a jumble of contradictions. He has ridden to power on the back of two ideologies, communism and nationalism - and patently believes in neither.

More interesting, he seemed to be a natural authoritarian who could tolerate dissent.

Now the mask has slipped. In the space of 24 hours last week, he tipped the president of the rump Yugoslavia, Dobrica Cosic, out of office, unleashed the riot police to crush an anti-government demonstration and imprisoned the main Serbian opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, and his wife, Danica.

Why, wonders Belgrade's massive chattering class, should Slobo choose this moment to crack down?

On the international front, things have been going well for Milosevic, who has managed to rehabilitate himself with the West as a result of his backing for the Vance-Owen plan.

At home, despite the massive economic hardship stemming from sanctions and the war, there seemed little threat to his rule. President Cosic's hesitant, bet-hedging style of opposition hardly seemed to pose a serious challenge.

The charge advanced during the no-confidence debate in the federal parliament - that the 72-year-old author was plotting with the chief of the general staff to stage a coup - has been completely uncorroborated so far.

Apart from two strong statements by his fellow Serbian intellectuals and a pious protest from the Russian foreign ministry, Cosic's removal scarcely raised a peep from opposition circles. Cosic has been a figure of contempt since he accepted the presidency. His belated, and inaccurate, comparison of Milosevic with Hitler and Stalin after his downfall failed to attract any sympathy.

The demonstration that erupted in Belgrade the same day had no direct link with his fall.

It started after a member of the ultra-nationalist Serbian Radical Party beat up a member of the Serbian Renewal Movement when he dared to read out an embarrassing hymn of praise to Tito penned by the Radicals' leader, Vojislav Seselj, before he abandoned communism for chauvinism.

The demonstrators were voicing a general rage against the style of Milosevic's rule and the hopeless future his policies had landed them with. Even so, there were only 5000 of them; last year the opposition could muster at least 70,000.

The aftermath of the protest has exposed once again the feebleness of the anti-Milosevic camp.

The authorities' treatment of the Draskovics has been outrageous: they were seized in the party headquarters after the demo; both were beaten; they are being held virtually incommunicado in the central prison on charges of trying to overthrow the state.

The reaction of Draskovic's party has been to try to cool things down. They have instructed the provincial branches not to provoke the police by organising protests. The young, the middle-class, the urban intelligentsia who make up Draskovic's constituency appear equally cautious.

"Draskovic is too emotional," said one young supporter yesterday.

"He's too much of an intellectual, not enough of a politician." Despite the violence [a policeman was killed], the demonstration seemed strangely irrelevant. Young people lounged at the pavement cafes chatting as if nothing was happening as crowds of retreating protesters stumbled past, eyes and noses streaming from the tear gas.

Milosevic has virtually no contact with ordinary people. Confronted with individuals over whom he has no direct institutional control - like the deputation of students he met after a spate of anti-government demonstrations two years ago - he reportedly becomes agitated and incoherent.

Yet he is credited with an uncanny ability to sense public moods.

By smashing the essentially inconsequential Cosic and the romantic but ineffective Draskovic, he is signalling what most people had already accepted: that the opposition is merely an adornment to Serbia's political system, a bit of baroque cornicing to the bleak, authoritarian structure.

Until now it was a luxury he felt he could afford. But there are grim days ahead.

In the absence of a peace settlement in Bosnia and with no end in sight to Serbia's economic and diplomatic isolation, dissatisfaction with the regime is bound to deepen.

The Serbian opposition may be disorganised and incapable of shaking off its dissident mentality but it provides a focus for the resentment building up.

Milosevic's lesson in the past week to opposition leaders tempted to capitalise on those feelings is that the least they can expect is a broken head and a spell in jail if they do. The prospects for ordinary people thinking of following them are even grimmer.

It is no wonder that on the streets of Belgrade last week's events are no joking matter.

The Sunday Telegraph


LOAD-DATE: November 28, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: President Slobodan MilosevicMilosevicAP


JOURNAL-CODE: MER

236 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 19, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Yugoslav-Croat Game Produces No Goals and No Coup


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 929 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 18


A long-awaited, once-postponed and politically charged soccer match between Yugoslavia and Croatia passed off peacefully and rather anticlimactically tonight, finishing 0-0, much like the summer's demonstrations against the rule of the Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

But there was a taste for what might come at a major opposition rally planned for Thursday night in Belgrade when a transformer at the Red Star stadium blew a few minutes into the second half, and the lights went out. 

Suddenly chants aimed at Mr. Milosevic echoed around the stadium, with many of the 60,000 people there yelling, "Slobo leave!" and a popular, rhyming chant that goes in part, "Slobo, you've sold out Kosovo!"

The game was televised nationally, but those chants were not heard by viewers.

The wait for the generators to turn the lights back on stretched on for 40 minutes, and officials gave some consideration to replaying the whole game Thursday night. That led to immediate Balkan-style speculation that the Milosevic Government had intentionally blown the power to make sure that the game would conflict with the opposition rally.

But in an indication of the Government's nervousness about Thursday, state television news announced that the police had arrested a man from Cetinje with "an explosive device fitted with a timer," apparently intended to be set off during the rally in front of the Federal Parliament building. The police then warned, the announcer said, that others could be planning such attacks, and they advised people to be careful, especially regarding their children.

The broadcast seemed a patent effort to discourage people from attending the opposition rally, the first in Belgrade since the Kosovo war. But the opposition is divided, and its best orator, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, has decided not to attend -- at least as of today -- as has the former army chief of staff, Momcilo Perisic.

Another well-known opposition figure, Vesna Pesic of the Alliance for Change, who had also been expected to speak, instead traveled to Montenegro -- for safety, she said -- after prosecutors asked the police to investigate her on felony charges for seeming to urge the violent overthrow of Mr. Milosevic by citing "the Romanian example" -- an apparent reference to the 1989 uprising against the Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu.

In a telephone interview today, Ms. Pesic said the charge was ludicrous, but she left "because you never really know with them," meaning the Government. Asked if the much ballyhooed rally would be important now after so many defections, she said: "Only if the police or the regime starts a battle or an incident. It's now just one of the rallies."

Still, in the southern city of Nis today, Alliance leaders attracted more than 20,000 people to an anti-Milosevic rally. Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democracy Party, said Thursday's protest in Belgrade would bring the end of Mr. Milosevic closer. "Stage two of Milosevic's replacement begins in Serbia tomorrow," he said.

At the same time, Mr. Milosevic appeared to be moving to flummox the opposition again and to call their bluff, with a spokesman suggesting that new elections might be called soon. Ivica Dasic, the spokesman for Mr. Milosevic's party, said: "We believe that there are more important things on the nation's agenda than the elections, but if the opposition wants that, so be it. We are ready."

Mr. Draskovic favors new elections but the opposition generally has been wary, worried that the Government might manipulate the voting.

Opposition analysts and officials also say that they are not ready for elections and not sure they could win one now against Mr. Milosevic, especially in coalition with Vojislav Seselj, the Serbian extreme nationalist who is head of the Serbian Radicals.

On Tuesday, Mr. Seselj said that the Government was ready for new elections and the opposition only has to agree to them.

Ms. Pesic of the Alliance for Change, which does not include Mr. Draskovic, said her coalition probably would not boycott new elections, as it did in 1997. But she suggested that the Alliance would seek to turn the elections into "a referendum on Milosevic" by running a slate of non-partisan experts.

An opinion poll released today indicated that more than 70 percent of Serbs surveyed want a new Government and an end to the country's isolation. The poll of 1,000 people last week by the independent Partner Marketing Research Agency suggested that Mr. Milosevic and his allies could expect only 24 percent support if elections were held now. The various opposition parties and alliances would get around 40 percent, 18 percent would not vote and 11 percent were undecided.

But the margin of error was unclear, and private polling for the opposition parties has produced pessimism among their staff members about new elections.

In tonight's soccer match, a qualifying round for the European championship, the players, who are professionals, behaved sportingly toward each other. The game was originally scheduled for March 27, but was postponed because NATO had begun bombing Serbia on March 24.

The crowd was cheerfully venomous toward the Croatian team, drowning out the Croatian national anthem and shouting, over and over, "Kill the Ustashe," the Croatian fascists of World War II. They seemed more fervent against the Croats than against Mr. Milosevic.

There were dire predictions of what might happen should the Yugoslav side lose to the Croats, whom they had not played since 1991.
        

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: August 19, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


June 2, 2008 Monday


Zagreb daily slams Croatia's "submissiveness" toward Serbia, EU


LENGTH: 777 words


Text of report by Bosnian edition of Croatian daily Vecernji list, on 30 May

[Commentary by Milan Ivkosic in the column "Patriotic Nitpicking": "Divvying-up Croatia's Submissiveness"]

A cheeky fellow comes into your very own house, spits in your face, and you respond as follows: "We have good relations with Serbia, and the fact that Serbian politicians are employing extremist rhetoric and doing so primarily for their own internal purposes is their problem and not ours!"

That is how Mario Zubovic of the HDZ [Croatian Democratic Union], chairman of the Assembly's Foreign Policy Committee, responded to the accusation by Serbian Foreign Affairs Minister Vuk Jeremic, uttered in Zagreb at a meeting of the Adriatic-Ionian Initiative, that, in Operation Storm, Croatia had carried out the "ethnic cleansing" of more than four million Serbs [as published]. Together with the half-hearted reaction from the state leadership, that has been a typical occurrence in Croatian-Serbian relations for 10 years. It is one that can also be perceived in the name and surnames of the aforementioned pair: Vuk [wolf in Serbian and Croatian] has not abandoned his wolfish nature, and Zubovic, in Ivo Sanader's political ordainment, inherited from Ivica Racan and the SDP [Social Democratic Party], has been left toothless [zub means tooth in Serbian and Croatian]. 

That typicality was conceived in 2000, when Racan and Picula, in keeping with the policy and diktat of the EU, gave open support to "the democratization of Serbia" and the "toppling of Slobodan Milosevic." From the time he came to power in Belgrade, "democrat" Zoran Djindjic would be the symbol of a new, changed, anti-Milosevic, democratic Serbia to politicians and the media in Croatia. The real Djindjic would remain behind the opaque curtain of that myth. Only the cleaned-up face of that "civic politician" would be seen in public.

In the wake of some of his statements, some in Croatia would remember that the real Djindjic, but that would not to change the picture of him, so some of the politicians who would lead Serbia after he was killed would be compared to him, as to a political paragon.

It would thus be "forgotten" that Djindjic, and how, supported the leadership of "Krajina" in Croatia, that he regarded its right to secession to be tantamount to Croatia's and Slovenia's right to secede from Yugoslavia, that, during the time of the most violent attacks on Sarajevo, he was in Pale, where he prepared a banquet with an ox roast for war criminal Radovan Karadzic, that, in 1991, he supported the thesis that "republics' borders are not state borders," that, after the disappearance of "Krajina," he supported the annexation of Croatian Podunavlje [Danube basin] to Yugoslavia, that he proposed making Prevlaka a gift to Montenegro, that he ultimately criticized Milosevic not for his great-Serbia programme but for failing to accomplish it.

There were occasional reminders of that Djindjic here and there, such as when he reacted to Mesic's assessment that Serbia ought to pay Croatia 15 billion euros in damages with the statement that Croatia ought to pay Serbia perhaps as much as 150 billion euros in damages.

Thanks to the "new" Serbia of Djindjic and Djindjic's followers, a Croatian state visit to Belgrade and Mesic's notorious apology would ensue. When the European Union was getting ready to schedule the beginning of negotiations with Croatia, the same Vuk Draskovic who, as minister of foreign affairs, had arranged Sanader's visit to Serbia, rushed around all the major European metropolises so that those negotiations would be denied to us.

At the beginning of this year, with no provocation whatsoever, Serbian President Boris Tadic, in a discussion on Kosovo at the United Nations, accused Croatia of not being a lawful state. What, then, are Mesic's and Sanader's "good relations" with a Serbia in which the Chetnik movement has been officially rehabilitated and whose leaders continually wish us ill and work on effectuating it?

And what is the difference between Nikolic's and Tadic's Serbia, other than that Nikolic causes no surprise with his policies whereas Tadic sandbags you with his policies every now and then? Serbian politicians of the left and the right are aware of how submissive Croatia is to the European masters' governments of both the left and the right, and Jeremic's cheekiness at a European gathering in the middle of Zagreb is merely a sign that, in the future, Belgrade is going to try to come away with an even bigger portion of that submissiveness as shared booty with Brussels.

Source: Vecernji list (Bosnia-Hercegovina edition), Zagreb, in Croatian 30 May 08


LOAD-DATE: June 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript



Copyright 2008 British Broadcasting Corporation

238 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The New York Times


August 26, 2003 Tuesday  
Late Edition - Final


TELEVISION REVIEW;
The Bad Old Days of Yugoslavia's Fallen Dictator


BYLINE: By THOM SHANKER


SECTION: Section E; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7


LENGTH: 942 words


In the decade between Washington's two wars against Saddam Hussein, who was demonized by his adversaries as the butcher of Baghdad, the focus of Western foreign policy and the target of American military power was another cagey leader of a small country with strategic location.

Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, demonized by his adversaries as the butcher of the Balkans, guided a series of wars against the constituent republics of his fragmenting nation that impoverished the Serbian people.

But he was bold and shrewd, adept at advancing his agenda by riding lies through the gaps in a NATO alliance that had blocked the Soviet menace but that was unable or unwilling to halt bloodletting in one of the last corners of Europe to emerge from dictatorship.

"Yugoslavia: The Fall of Milosevic," a three-part documentary that will be rebroadcast tonight on the Discovery Times Channel, immediately establishes the significance of its protagonist as the first head of state to be brought before an international tribunal on charges of war crimes and genocide. 

The documentary was originally produced for the BBC, which showed it in January. Its respected executive producers, Norma Percy and Brian Lapping, have developed a method of intense interviews with key participants that has worked wonderfully well in documentaries like "The Second Russian Revolution" (1991), "The Death of Yugoslavia" (1995) and "The 50 Years War: Israel and the Arabs" (1998).

The three hours of "The Fall of Milosevic" describe the autumn of his political career in detail. The period includes the failed attempt at maintaining authoritarian control over Kosovo and its majority population of ethnic Albanians; NATO's air war, which did little to halt the Milosevic offensive until bombs fell on Belgrade, the Serbian capital; and the revolution from below in which the Serbian people finally voted him from power and then took it from him when he refused to go.

There is little examination of his Communist roots or of his blossoming as a leader of a tribal Serbian nationalism. There is scant description of the vicious, Medieval-style wars of siege and looting and rape elsewhere in the former Yugoslavia, even though it was the West's belated action to halt "ethnic cleansing" in Croatia and Bosnia that eventually shamed NATO into action over Kosovo. For Western capitals that sat idly by while Bosnia burned, "Never again" had arrived once more.

The series provides an invaluable summary of the complicated events that riveted world attention as the 1990's spilled into a new decade, and Ms. Percy, Mr. Lapping and their collaborators have gone to extraordinary lengths to capture the voices of every principal participant. Those interviewed include Presidents Bill Clinton, Jacques Chirac and Boris N. Yeltsin, Prime Minister Tony Blair, Kosovo's guerrillas and its nascent diplomats, the bulldozer driver who helped lead the Serbian people's seizure of the parliament in Belgrade and, of course, Mr. Milosevic himself.

The telescoping of history that is the documentarian's art reveals fascinating details that are difficult to judge as they are happening.

Members of the Kosovo Liberation Army, who hardly lived up to their early publicity as heroic Balkan Minutemen, revel in a cult of martyrdom. They perverted cease-fires to strike at Serbian forces, hoping for brutal counterattacks that would stoke Washington and Brussels.

How unexpected, though, to hear similar strategy from the intellectual leaders of the American-subsidized, anti-Milosevic political movement Otpor, which mobilized opposition candidates in Belgrade. Most of Otpor's foot soldiers were average citizens of Serbia dreaming, if not of democracy, then of an end to war and isolation, and their platform was nonviolent revolt. But among Otpor's leaders were those who also understood the cult of victimization. They, too, planned provocations and bragged that each violent arrest earned a thousand votes.

Armchair generals and a few at the Pentagon will no doubt take notes during an enlightening exchange on the air war. Mirjana Markovic, wife of Mr. Milosevic, describes how Belgrade's leaders viewedthe United States as spineless, NATO as a joke. The bombing, they were certain, would last one night, and the West would dab its forehead and fly home.

An American Air Force officer then recalls how his pilots pleaded for missions in the first three days of the war because they were certain that Serbia, as the neighborhood Balkan bully, would run at the first bloody nose.

Both, of course, were wrong. The air war lasted 78 days.

Parts 1 and 2 of the series, "Defiance" and "War," are well-made pieces of diplomatic and military history. Part 3, "Finished," is not only good history but good drama as well, the story of the election and people-power revolution that ultimately ousted Mr. Milosevic.

The documentary is eloquent in reminding viewers that it was not armed Kosovar guerrillas nor NATO diplomacy nor even the American military that bested the Serbian leader. It was the people of Serbia, the students and coal diggers and rock drummers and mothers who took to the ballot box and then to the streets.

"The Fall of Milosevic" is compelling history, even if the heroes of the Belgrade street protests are today locked in political inertia, failing to deliver the reform pledged when they rid the nation of Mr. Milosevic and packed him off to the Hague, to a jail cell and a war-crimes trial.

YUGOSLAVIA
The Fall of Milosevic

DISCOVERY TIMES, tonight at 8, Eastern and Pacific times; 7, Central time.

Brian Lapping and Norma Percy, executive producers; David Ash, international reversion producer.


URL: http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Slobodan Milosevic, on Belgrade posters, is being tried on charges of war crimes and genocide. (Photo by Associated Press)


DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2003 The New York Times Company


239 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


December 9, 1996, Monday, THREE STAR Edition


COURT RULINGS, PROTESTS PUSH SERBIA TOWARD CONFRONTATION; PROTESTERS CALL FOR RESISTANCE TO 'DICTATORSHIP'


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5A


LENGTH: 588 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


 

President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has elected to confront his opponents, who not only want to get back election victories but also to oust him.

It appeared that Milosevic's courts would deny the opposition its local election victories. Radomir Lazarevic, the chief of the Belgrade election commission, said the Supreme Court had rejected appeals that would have reinstated election victories in Belgrade. The court has yet to rule on overturned elections in other cities. 

About 100,000 demonstrators filled the streets of Belgrade on Sunday. Former French Culture Minister Jack Lang, a member of the European Parliament, told a cheering crowd: "The Serbs are fighting in the name of all peoples who resist dictatorship."

The opposition Democratic Party reported Sunday that eight protesters were arrested in the past two days, and one of them was badly beaten.

Protesters have been on the streets every day since the Nov. 17 elections were annulled by courts that Milosevic controls.

But instead of turning police officers loose on the demonstrators - as he has in the past - Milosevic appeared headed for a long struggle of tactics and politics. "What will prevail - the people's determination, or Milosevic's patience?" asked Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic Party.

A co-leader of the opposition coalition, Vuk Draskovic, said the choice for Serbs was simple: dignity or slavery. "We are not ready to be slaves!" he added.

"I am expecting tomorrow, the day after tomorrow, that Milosevic will use police, maybe even the army, but we will not stop," Draskovic said.

Daily protests in Serbia's second-largest city, Nis, also continued Sunday; the election results there also were overturned. The Fonet news agency said about 30,000 people - including students, taxi drivers, workers and farmers on their tractors - turned out.

Weeks Of Protests

The opposition had anticipated that Milosevic would try to calm three weeks of protests by giving back its election victory in Belgrade.

In Nov. 17 runoff local elections, the official electoral commission announced that a majority of the 110 seats on Belgrade's city council had been won by the opposition coalition, Together. But local courts annulled the results in Belgrade as well as opposition victories that had been announced elsewhere.

The opposition and the Belgrade election commission appealed to Serbia's Supreme Court, which had previously confirmed the lower courts' actions.

Djindjic said Milosevic apparently had realized that the protests wouldn't dissipate even if he gave in on the elections. "It became obvious that these protests would not stop if Belgrade was given back to us, and it's also obvious that this protest has defined itself as anti-Milosevic and anti-Communist."

Milan Komnenic, vice president of Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, said Supreme Court rulings couldn't change the protesters' motivation. "Our strength is in our determination."

Some independent unions have pledged to join the protests today.

So far, individual workers have taken part in the street marches, but organized labor has not.

Bosnian Follow-up Force

Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said Sunday that he would press for an early end to U.S. participation in NATO's planned follow-on peacekeeping force in Bosnia.

He called President Bill Clinton's decision to let U.S. soldiers stay for up to 18 months more a "big mistake." Kasich would have them home by spring.


LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


240 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


April 21, 1999, FINAL


Diplomatic feelers in the works?


BYLINE: Maj.-Gen. Lewis MacKenzie


SECTION: News; A9


LENGTH: 692 words


On this 29th day of NATO's war against Yugoslavia, it's worthwhile to look at what the situation is like on the ground throughout the region.

The forced departure of the ethnic Albanian community from Kosovo appears to be in its final stage. In the absence of reliable census figures, popular opinion puts Kosovo's prewar population at two million of which 10 per cent were alleged to be Serbs. Informed sources suggest that the overall figure was significantly less, but we will probably only know for sure when we count the refugees expelled from Kosovo. 

During the past year, about one million Albanians have been forced or convinced to leave the province, which means between 300,000 and 400,000 remain, and many of them are moving in the direction of Kosovo's borders with Macedonia and Albania.

The air campaign and Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's reaction to it has accelerated the removal of the Albanian population. This fact combined with Yugoslavia's paranoia regarding a NATO land invasion and the Serb army's desire to clear all civilians from Kosovo to enhance what they see as an inevitable defensive battle does not auger well for any Albanians remaining in Kosovo.

Yugoslavia's infrastructure and military complexes have suffered billions of dollars in damage. Oil refineries have been put out of commission, and fuel supplies stored in the open are targeted on a daily basis. Most bridges over the Danube are destroyed, the three in Belgrade being the exception. Electronic communications facilities of all types have been severely degraded and few transmission towers are standing. As far as civilian casualties are concerned, ''only'' 1,000 people have been killed or injured by the bombing campaign.

The Yugoslav army has suffered considerable damage in Kosovo. But considering the dearth of information from that area, it is impossible to gauge how much its operational effectiveness has been reduced. Considering the number of caves, tunnels and bunkers in Kosovo, it is probably safe to say the army is still an effective and formidable fighting force.

The situation is neighbouring Macedonia is highly unstable because of the massive influx of Albanian refugees. Macedonia's political situation is precarious at the best of times considering its ethnic mix. The presence of hundreds of thousands of refugees combined with Macedonia's 25-per-cent Albanian population is seen as a considerable threat by most of the remaining citizens. NATO's forces buildup of at least 12,000 is seen as an additional threat because of the potential for cross-border operations into Macedonia by Serb forces.

Albania, the poorest country in the region, is under immense pressure from its considerable share of the refugee exodus. Cross-border operations in remote border regions are commonplace, and NATO's movement of about 8,000 troops into the area along with Apache helicopters and multiple rocket launchers increase the potential for such attacks.

In 'neutral' Montenegro, there is much anticipation of a coup by the Yugoslavian army to displace a pro-western, anti-Milosevic government. Many Montenegrans are confused and upset that they are on NATO's target lists. Despite the fact that mostly military targets have been struck, many think the attacks are unjustified and unfair.

As far as Mr. Milosevic is concerned, there are no evident cracks in his intransigence. Diplomatic delegations parade through his office on a daily basis, but there have been no hints of even a minor breakthrough. Successful diplomacy is a secretive process, and the public will not be aware of any progress on that front until there is a major development.

The good news is that there appears to be an increased level of activities by senior Yugoslav officials. They seem to be preoccupied with what I can only assume are numerous diplomatic initiatives.

Let's hope one of them works.

Maj.-Gen. Lewis MacKenzie, now retired, commanded UN troops during the siege of Sarajevo in the Bosnian civil war of 1992. His column, A Soldier's View, will appear in the Citizen for the duration of Operation Allied Force.


LOAD-DATE: April 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 CanWest Interactive, a division of
CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved


241 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


February 16, 1998, Monday, Final Edition


Ominous Rumblings From The Balkans


Morton Abramowitz


SECTION: OP-ED; Pg. A27


LENGTH: 1045 words


 

The Clinton administration's rejuvenated Bosnia policy has scored major gains and offers real hope that the country can be kept together. But we and our allies continue to artificially separate what happens in Bosnia from what happens in Serbia. That was a disaster six years ago, and it could be a disaster again for Bosnia and the Dayton process. The issue in Serbia is increasingly the province of Kosovo, a part of Serbia but hardly only an internal Serbian problem.

Since Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic wiped away Kosovo's autonomy eight years ago, the Albanian population there has considered itself no longer part of Serbia and has acted that way. The Kosovo Albanians have elected their own "government" and maintained their own health and education systems. But Belgrade still rules -- and with a strong and oppressive hand. 

Every year for the past eight years, articles have been written that Kosovo is about to explode -- that mass violence and the expulsion of vast numbers of Albanians are approaching -- and that the West has to do something. So far Kosovo has been the dog that has not barked, despite the execrable situation that exists between the province's 1.8 million Albanians and the Belgrade regime.

Nevertheless, Kosovo steadily deteriorates. Serb repression increases, and violence in the province is rising. The Albanians agree that Western intervention is the answer for achieving independence, but more and more they disagree on tactics. The present majority headed by the elected "president," Ibrahim Rugova, pursues a non-provocation policy. Another, more amorphous school, believes Albanians must be more assertive in publicly demonstrating their opposition to Serbian rule if they are to get more from the West than sermons on nonviolence.

Most ominous has been the emergence of a little-known militant group called the Kosovo Liberation Front, which believes that violence is the only way to achieve Albanian political aims. The front is apparently well armed and is responsible for a number of recent violent incidents.

Nobody knows when Kosovo will "erupt." But it is clear that one day that will happen, and that day is drawing closer. The West knows it. Yet Western policy toward Kosovo can be described as hand-wringing -- i.e., rising rhetoric directed at Milosevic and much diplomatic to-ing and fro-ing, all signifying little. Washington's line-in-the-sand message to Belgrade, first by President Bush and repeated by President Clinton, not to use military force in Kosovo came when Serbia had no need to use force. At a time of real breakdown in Kosovo, that admonition may get lost in the sand.

Milosevic was a key factor in the Dayton agreement, and the United States has focused on Belgrade's role in Bosnia to make Dayton work. All high-level visits have been devoted to getting Milosevic's help with the Bosnian Serbs -- from forging a common automobile license plate in Bosnia to removing indicted war criminal Radovan Karadzic from power. The U.S. government believes Milosevic has been helpful to its efforts in Bosnia. As for Serbia, the United States did little to promote democracy, gave mostly ritualistic support to the anti-Milosevic movement of November 1996 and failed to beard him on Kosovo. In short, we seem afraid to do anything that might undermine Milosevic's ability to help implement Dayton.

Who rules in Serbia, and the role of the defense and security forces, is critical to Bosnia. The leadership in Belgrade still can do much to undermine Dayton, although it would face serious penalties. Equally, a major change in Kosovo -- large-scale violence, a massive outflow of Albanians, a change in borders -- could wreck Dayton by its impact on Serbia's leadership, on the Bosnian Serbs and on the region in general. The international management of such a disaster would be enormously difficult and costly.

There is also a longer-term factor here. The Balkans never will be stable if Serbia continues to decline and remains a pariah. Nor can Serbia ever become a democratic country or a normal state until it deals with Kosovo. Serbia's isolation again is generating an economic crisis. The country is close to running out of foreign currency.

Given the deep feelings on both sides, the Kosovo conundrum has no easy solution, which is probably another reason why the United States has not gotten involved. Any Serbian leader will have great difficulty finding a solution acceptable to Serbs and making it stick. Albanians, having sacrificed much, can be equally adamant. No solution can be delivered without outside help. Right now Milosevic is the only one in Serbia who might be able to work out some sort of agreement with the Albanians.

What is needed, nearly everyone agrees, is to start a serious negotiating process between the two parties. That will require the United States -- the only external power the two sides are prepared to accept -- to get deeply involved in generating such talks and participating in them. The parties themselves must be brought to some initial agreement. Almost certainly such an agreement must entail the end of an oppressive Serb regime in Kosovo, Albanian self-rule and no change in borders.

A negotiation on Kosovo will require massive U.S. diplomatic effort with no assurance of success. That means a serious capability to carry out such a major initiative, a capacity that has yet to be marshaled within the U.S. government. It means overcoming the fear that our getting deeply involved in Kosovo negotiations will make Belgrade more uncooperative in Bosnia. Real progress also requires raising the pressure on Milosevic yet offering tangible benefits to Serbia. The present Serbian economic crunch makes this an opportune time to try.

Kosovo threatens our massive investment in Bosnia and stability in the region. We will be courting folly if we continue to act as if Bosnia can be settled without substantial change in Serbia or without sustained U.S. effort in Kosovo. The past 10 years in the Balkans have shown the critical role of the West and the enormous cost of getting there too late.

The writer is a board member of the International Crisis Group and a Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.


LOAD-DATE: February 16, 1998


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Illustration, t. gibson


Copyright 1998 The Washington Post


242 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


August 10, 2000


Milosevic uses arrests to bolster election chances


BYLINE: Jonathan Steele


SECTION: Guardian Foreign Pages, Pg. 12


LENGTH: 531 words


 

The arrests of eight foreigners, including two Britons, on charges of espionage are designed to create a "sense of siege" and boost President Slobodan Milosevic's already strong chances in next month's elections, western officials fear.

"They are in effect hostages to his effort to present Yugoslavia as being under threat," a senior official said yesterday.

Ever since last year's war over Kosovo, western governments have pinned their hopes of removing Mr Milosevic on various scenarios, including an army coup and street demonstrations. When the Yugoslav strongman unexpectedly announced snap elections for next month, they banked on the central campaign issues being the future of the Serbian economy, Serbia's reintegration into the European fold, and how best to achieve political liberalisation. 

But Mr Milosevic is casting the election as a loyalty test, with his challengers portrayed as traitors. "This is a battle for the survival of the nation and the state. Slobodan Milosevic is the symbol of Yugoslavia, of heroic resistance to the aggressor, and of restoration and development. Our opponents are not an opposition to our party, but to their own people and the state," Gorica Gajevic, the secretary general of the Socialist party of Serbia, said last week.

Forced on to the back foot, the fractious Serbian opposition has accepted Mr Milosevic's gameplan and, in choosing Vojislav Kostunica as its standard-bearer in the elections, has appointed a nationalist rather than a liberaliser. As a result, western governments find themselves rooting for a man who strongly criticised Nato's Kosovo campaign and who refuses to meet officials from Nato countries.

Anti-western feeling is still high in Serbia and although many voters criticise Mr Milosevic they seem to accept his argument that Yugoslavia remains under siege.

Mr Milosevic's maverick ally, the ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj, yesterday pursued that line. He attacked Mr Kostunica as "Nato's candidate".

"Voice of America, Free Europe, Deutsche Welle and the BBC have all praised Kostunica over the past few days in Serbian language broadcasts," he said. Mr Kostunica had been more cunning than other opposition leaders at hiding his pro-Nato feelings but Serbs would never vote for "Nato candidates", he went on.

The charge is ironic since Mr Kostunica's nationalist credentials are clear. Before the Nato air strikes, he was photographed with Serbs in Kosovo brandishing a Kalashnikov rifle in resistance. He has described relations between foreigners and the Serbian state as "a game in which everything is given up in return for almost nothing, except symbolic concessions". He strongly opposes the Hague tribunal and criticises the war crimes indictment issued against Mr Milosevic.

This line of "moderate nationalism" may explain why Mr Kostunica came out well in a recent poll by the Belgrade-based Institute of Social Sciences. It found him leading Mr Milosevic by 42% to 28%.

But the poll was taken before the Serbian Renewal Movement, a leading opposition party, decided to put up its own candidate in a move which will split the anti- Milosevic front.


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


243 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Daily Telegraph (Sydney, Australia)


February 4, 1997, Tuesday


Serb tumult at flashpoint 


SECTION: FULLPAGE / WORLD; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 440 words


BELGRADE: The regime of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic today plunged deeper into crisis.

Western nations assailed a police attack on pro-democracy demonstrators and an opposition leader appealed for army intervention.

Police began clubbing demonstrators again today as more than 50,000 people marched through Belgrade. 

The previous day truncheon-wielding riot police set upon a crowd of unarmed protesters, injuring 80 of them.

Water cannons also were used to disperse the protesters.

Opposition leader Vuk Draskovic accused Mr Milosevic of running a regime of terror following yesterday's violence on the Brotherhood and Unity Bridge, the government's fiercest backlash yet to 11 straight weeks of street protests against Mr Milosevic.

As European countries and the Serbian Orthodox Church denounced the crackdown, Belgrade was tense again today.

About 1000 riot police with helmets, shields and tear gas fanned out to prevent a crowd of some 50,000 people assembled in Republic Square from staging a march along the city's main boulevard.

Mr Draskovic, addressing the crowd, appealed for calm and the group eventually started to disperse along a nearby pedestrian shopping street.

"We are going to overthrow violence with our nonviolence," the 50-year writer said.

He called for a general strike and a campaign of civil disobedience.

"Do not pay your taxes, electricity bills, nothing," he told the crowd.

Many of them tooted plastic whistles that provide the shrill battle-cry of the 11-week protest movement against eastern Europe's last communist-style regime.

Earlier in the day 30,000 students marched across the bridge that was the scene of yesterday's violence, but this time there were no police on hand.

At a press conference, Mr Draskovic said the Yugoslav army had to end its neutral stance in the crisis and intervene on behalf of the protesters.

Mr Draskovic and other opposition leaders have appealed for army support several times in the marathon showdown, the worst Mr Milosevic has faced since he came to power 10 years ago.

The army has so far insisted it would remain neutral.

But this was the first time Mr Draskovic appealed publicly for direct intervention from a force already said to be disgruntled over their pay.

"The army cannot sit around and calmly watch the crime which is being committed on the streets of Belgrade," Mr Draskovic said.

Speaking in English on yesterday's violence, he said: "Since last night, Slobodan Milosevic introduced openly a police terror in Serbia."

Police fire a water against anti-Milosevic demonstrators in Belgrade yesterday


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DTM


Copyright 1997 Nationwide News Pty Limited

The Daily Telegraph (Sydney, Australia)


February 4, 1997, Tuesday


80 injured in police attack 


SECTION: FULLPAGE / WORLD; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 439 words


BELGRADE: The regime of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic today plunged deeper into crisis.

Western nations denounced a police attack on pro-democracy demonstrators and an opposition leader appealed for army intervention.

Police began clubbing demonstrators again today as more than 50,000 people marched through Belgrade. 

The previous day truncheon-wielding riot police set upon a crowd of unarmed protesters, injuring 80.

Water cannons also were used to disperse the protesters.

Opposition leader Vuk Draskovic accused Mr Milosevic of running a regime of terror following yesterday's violence on the Brotherhood and Unity Bridge, the government's fiercest backlash yet to 11 straight weeks of street protests against Mr Milosevic.

As European countries and the Serbian Orthodox Church denounced the crackdown, Belgrade was tense again today.

About 1000 riot police with helmets, shields and tear gas fanned out to prevent a crowd of some 50,000 people assembled in Republic Square from staging a march along the city's main boulevard.

Mr Draskovic, addressing the crowd, appealed for calm and the group eventually started to disperse along a nearby pedestrian shopping street.

"We are going to overthrow violence with our nonviolence," the 50-year writer said.

He called for a general strike and a campaign of civil disobedience.

"Do not pay your taxes, electricity bills, nothing," he told the crowd.

Many of them tooted plastic whistles that provide the shrill battle-cry of the 11-week protest movement against eastern Europe's last communist-style regime.

Earlier in the day 30,000 students marched across the bridge that was the scene of yesterday's violence, but this time there were no police on hand.

At a press conference, Mr Draskovic said the Yugoslav army had to end its neutral stance in the crisis and intervene on behalf of the protesters.

Mr Draskovic and other opposition leaders have appealed for army support several times in the marathon showdown, the worst Mr Milosevic has faced since he came to power 10 years ago.

The army has so far insisted it would remain neutral.

Speaking in English on yesterday's violence, he said: "Since last night, Slobodan Milosevic introduced openly a police terror in Serbia."
