245 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


December 13, 1996, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Milosevic launches campaign to discredit opponents


BYLINE: TRACY WILKINSON; THE LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. B4


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


 

DECEPTION: While other hardliners call for a crackdown on demonstrators, Serbia's leader resorts to more subtle methods, like financial pressure, personal smears and the occasional beating of a well-known public figure or two.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- For the past eight days, some uninvited guests have been visiting Branislav Gojkovic's popular bookstore, Plato's.

The dreaded financial police -- inspectors who on a whim can fine a businessman thousands of dollars or shut him down altogether -- arrived soon after Gojkovic lent space and loudspeakers to students for their daily, high-decibel protests against President Slobodan Milosevic.

Since almost all business in Belgrade is conducted under murky circumstances, it seems clear to people here that Gojkovic was singled out not for his bookkeeping but for his support of the opposition. 

On Thursday, as students prepared to launch yet another rally outside Plato's, the owner apparently bowed to the pressure and took back his loudspeakers.

Despite tough talk from some government officials in favor of an all-out crackdown, Milosevic is pursuing a more insidious campaign to intimidate and discredit opponents who have been marching through city streets for 25 days to demand recognition for elections they won.

He has opted for: selective arrests and beatings; economic pressures and incentives; a media smear campaign; and the establishment of parallel, "loyal" organizations to detract from those in rebellion.

The threat of force is always there, of course -- on Thursday, scores of heavily armed riot police blocked thousands of students who attempted to march to Milosevic's home.

Whether the intimidation is physical, economic or psychological, a little goes a long way in a country yet to emerge from decades of communism, paranoia and apathy.

Two high-profile arrests have sent chills through the demonstration ranks. Gojko Baletic, a well-known actor, was seized by police after a rally on Wednesday, beaten unconscious and held incommunicado overnight.

That arrest followed last weekend's detention and torture of Dejan Bulatovic, a student who had demonstrated with a bigger-than-life effigy of Milosevic wearing prison stripes. Bulatovic, who had to receive emergency medical treatment, was finally allowed to see a lawyer this week but in the presence of prison guards. He whispered that police said they would kill him if he reported all of the brutal treatment to which he had been subjected, lawyer Ivan Sebek said.

The regime "is choosing people who are very visible," said Sebek, who is working on behalf of the opposition. "They are choosing people who are the examples to discourage others from joining. That is the message. They are trying to scare people."

Another method for discrediting the opposition is the use of the state-run media to conduct a smear campaign against the anti-Milosevic coalition known as Zajedno.

All television and most radio stations are controlled by Milosevic or his allies, and there are only a handful of independent or pro-opposition newspapers. The pro-Milosevic media has lumped opposition leaders with the most despised of Serbia's enemies, an undisguised effort to push all the right patriotic buttons and to split society along lines of deep loyalty.

Pro-government newspapers have especially focused on perceived support of the Zajedno movement by Albanian separatists. Albanians form the majority in Serbia's tense Kosovo region, an area that Serb nationalists cherish as the cradle of their civilization.

Economic pressure is applied in different ways. Besides unleashing the revenuers on Gojkovic's bookstore, Milosevic has also played the game from the other end -- by suddenly paying long overdue wages to workers and announcing cuts in electricity rates.

Resorting to a common technique under communism, the regime has also established parallel institutions to undercut those participating in demonstrations. A new "Independent Students Organization" appeared this week, holding news conferences. Posters suddenly appeared saying, "Study, yes! Politics, no!"

Reporters who went to the address given by the association as its office found no one there had ever heard of it.


LOAD-DATE: December 14, 1996


LENGTH: 708 words


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

246 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


August 19, 1999 Thursday Final Edition


MILOSEVIC OFFERS EARLY ELECTIONS


BYLINE: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. C6


LENGTH: 543 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party offered yesterday to hold early elections, one day before an anti-government rally was planned in the capital Belgrade.

The offer fell far short, however, of opposition demands that Milosevic step down and allow a transitional government before any elections.

On the eve of the Belgrade protest, 20,000 people rallied in the country's third-largest city, Nis, chanting: "Resignations, resignations!" Beta news agency said. 

"We believe that there are more important things on the nation's agenda than the elections but if the opposition wants that, so be it," Ivica Dacic, a spokesman for the Socialist party, said.

"We are ready."

Waves of anti-Milosevic protests began in Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia, after the 78-day NATO air campaign left the country badly damaged, impoverished, isolated and without control over the southern province Kosovo. The air campaign was launched to force Milosevic to accept a peace plan for the separatist province.

Similar rallies in the capital in 1996-97 pushed the Yugoslav president to make concessions to anti-government activists. Milosevic later took advantage of power struggles among coalition leaders to backpedal on all of the deals.

Opposition leaders have still been unable to forge a common front against Milosevic. A key opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, for example, will not attend today's rally. In the past, he has led the biggest protests against Milosevic.

In Washington, U.S. State Department spokesman James Rubin said officials have met with opposition leaders and have been encouraging them to maintain unity as a means of hastening the departure of Milosevic -- who has been indicted by a UN court for alleged war crimes in Kosovo.

"We believe that the people of Serbia and the people of the Balkans would be far, far better off if an indicted war criminal were no longer to be the president of Yugoslavia," Rubin said.

"We believe that this is a view that is increasingly taking hold in a number of parts of Yugoslav and Serbian society."

But yesterday, another prominent opposition leader fled Belgrade for Montenegro, Yugoslavia's rebellious province whose government opposes Milosevic.

Vesna Pesic, an official of the opposition Civic Alliance of Serbia, fled one day after Milosevic's prosecutor demanded an investigation against her for allegedly calling for violent toppling of his regime. She could have faced 20 years in prison if convicted of the charge.

Pesic, who was to have addressed the Belgrade rally today, said the prosecutor's statement was designed to intimidate people from attending the gathering.

The opposition has said it wants early elections but only if they are monitored by international observers. Dacic did not indicate the date of the early elections, or whether foreign monitoring would be allowed.

Elections are technically scheduled for 2001.

A prominent official of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, Milan Bozic, said yesterday his party would agree to early elections but only under international control.

Democratic party deputy chairwoman Ljiljana Lucic said the governing coalition's offer of early elections would be just another attempt at vote fraud.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo by The Associated Press; Some 20,000 supporters of the opposition umbrella group Alliance for Change demand the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic yesterday at a rally in Nis, 250 kilometres south of Belgrade.

247 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


March 10, 1992, Tuesday, UNAVAILABLE EDITION


War-weary Serbs protest 25,000 demand president quit over 'fratricide'


BYLINE: BY ALAN FERGUSON TORONTO STAR


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 495 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


War-weary Serbians prayed for their dead yesterday, but failed in an attempt to bring down the government that led them into their bloody conflict with Croatia.

Prayers for the souls of thousands of soldiers and civilians killed in the fighting were relayed by loudspeakers to a crowd estimated at around 25,000 gathered outside the chapel of Saint Sava cathedral.

At a sombre service inside the chapel, white-haired Patriarch Pavle, head of the Orthodox Church in Serbia, said, "Each drop of blood that has been shed was the blood of brothers and each killing was fratricide." 

The occasion was the first anniversary of anti-government demonstrations in Belgrade last March when two people died after troops and police opened fire on the crowd and tanks were sent into the streets.

Opposition parties marked the date with a rally demanding the resignation of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, one of the last surviving former Communist leaders in eastern Europe.

Vuk Draskovic, a charismatic poet who leads the Serbian Renewal Movement, called for a general strike, but set no date. Gesturing dramatically at the crowd, he also demanded the restoration of the Serbian monarchy, Crown Prince Alexander Karadjordevic lives in exile in London.

The lower-than-expected turnout for the rally was blamed by organizers on what they called a campaign of fear waged by the ruling Socialist party. In a statement last week, Borisav Jovic, a former Yugoslav president and close Milosevic ally, warned that Serbia "is not Romania" - a reference to the overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu after a popular uprising in 1989.

"The army, the police and the people are behind us," Jovic said, in what many Serbians interpreted as a thinly veiled threat to suppress with violence any attempt to disrupt order.

Nevertheless, there was a holiday atmosphere in Belgrade.

Milosevic, who was scheduled to go to Brussels for the resumption of a European Community-sponsored peace conference on Yugoslavia, stayed in the Serbian capital after he was reported to have suffered minor injuries in a car accident on Sunday.

The Serbian leader, who was re-elected by an overwhelming majority in 1990, has presided over a largely unpopular war and a disintegrating economy, but has so far shown an uncanny ability to survive.

He had appeared vulnerable last March when he was forced by popular opinion to release Draskovic from a brief spell in jail. Draskovic came directly from his cell to electrify an anti-government protest with his fiery oratory.

A year later, Draskovic appears to have lost momentum.

On the platform yesterday, Draskovic demanded the immediate resignation of Milosevic, accusing his government of falsely claiming to have won a war in which "so many died, so many were wounded and so many lost their homes - and all for nothing."

Draskovic was frequently interrupted by anti-Milosevic slogans chanted by demonstrators.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP PHOTO: Under a banner depicting opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, Serbs rally in Belgrade yesterday to denounce President Slobodan Milosevic.


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


248 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


March 10, 1992, Tuesday, AM


War-weary Serbs protest 25,000 demand president quit over 'fratricide'


BYLINE: By Alan Ferguson TORONTO STAR


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 497 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


 
   BELGRADE - War-weary Serbians prayed for their dead yesterday, but failed in an attempt to bring down the government that led them into their bloody conflict with Croatia.

Prayers for the souls of thousands of soldiers and civilians killed in the fighting were relayed by loudspeakers to a crowd estimated at around 25,000 gathered outside the chapel of Saint Sava cathedral.

At a sombre service inside the chapel, white-haired Patriarch Pavle, head of the Orthodox Church in Serbia, said, "Each drop of blood that has been shed was the blood of brothers and each killing was fratricide." 

The occasion was the first anniversary of anti-government demonstrations in Belgrade last March when two people died after troops and police opened fire on the crowd and tanks were sent into the streets.

Opposition parties marked the date with a rally demanding the resignation of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, one of the last surviving former Communist leaders in eastern Europe.

Vuk Draskovic, a charismatic poet who leads the Serbian Renewal Movement, called for a general strike, but set no date. Gesturing dramatically at the crowd, he also demanded the restoration of the Serbian monarchy, Crown Prince Alexander Karadjordevic lives in exile in London.

The lower-than-expected turnout for the rally was blamed by organizers on what they called a campaign of fear waged by the ruling Socialist party. In a statement last week, Borisav Jovic, a former Yugoslav president and close Milosevic ally, warned that Serbia "is not Romania" - a reference to the overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu after a popular uprising in 1989.

"The army, the police and the people are behind us," Jovic said, in what many Serbians interpreted as a thinly veiled threat to suppress with violence any attempt to disrupt order.

Nevertheless, there was a holiday atmosphere in Belgrade.

Milosevic, who was scheduled to go to Brussels for the resumption of a European Community-sponsored peace conference on Yugoslavia, stayed in the Serbian capital after he was reported to have suffered minor injuries in a car accident on Sunday.

The Serbian leader, who was re-elected by an overwhelming majority in 1990, has presided over a largely unpopular war and a disintegrating economy, but has so far shown an uncanny ability to survive.

He had appeared vulnerable last March when he was forced by popular opinion to release Draskovic from a brief spell in jail. Draskovic came directly from his cell to electrify an anti-government protest with his fiery oratory.

A year later, Draskovic appears to have lost momentum.

On the platform yesterday, Draskovic demanded the immediate resignation of Milosevic, accusing his government of falsely claiming to have won a war in which "so many died, so many were wounded and so many lost their homes - and all for nothing."

Draskovic was frequently interrupted by anti-Milosevic slogans chanted by demonstrators.


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP PHOTO: Under a banner depicting opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, Serbs rally in Belgrade yesterday to denounce President Slobodan Milosevic.Yugoslavia; demonstration; politics


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


249 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


October 6, 2000 Friday Final Edition


Media turns back on Milosevic; Protesters storm Yugoslav TV headquarters, state news agency switches allegiance


SOURCE: The Associated Press


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. C01


LENGTH: 546 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, YUGOSLAVIA


President Slobodan Milosevic's control over the Yugoslav media crumbled yesterday when the state news agency switched its allegiance and protesters took over state television, plowing into the broadcast headquarters with a bulldozer.

The bulldozer, apparently commandeered by demonstrators, broke through the walls of the TV building and demonstrators poured inside. Police fled out the back as some state TV employees joined the protesters. 

"Like all sane people in Serbia, we don't agree with this lunatic editorial policy," said Geno Juric, an assistant producer at the state TV operation.

Protesters said dozens of police at the state TV building joined crowds taking control there. Flames spilled from the first floor, burning part of the structure that had been one of Milosevic's propaganda mainstays.

The state Tanjug news agency -- another pillar of Milosevic's rule -- also announced it was changing sides and referred to Milosevic's rival, Vojislav Kostunica, as the "president-elect."

The opposition claims Kostunica won Sept. 24 presidential elections outright, and yesterday's massive Belgrade protests were sparked by Milosevic's attempts to cling to power.

"From this moment, Tanjug informs the Yugoslav public that it is with the people of this country and that it will report entirely on the basis of professional standards, truthfully and objectively," said a brief statement signed Journalists of the Free Tanjug and carried by the agency.

The announcement was only the latest sign that Milosevic had lost control of his crucial state media apparatus.

Earlier yesterday, more than 160 state television employees were fired for going on strike. Employees of the state newspaper Politika demanded that editorial policies be changed to include reports about the opposition, and several local branches of the official television stopped broadcasting programs from the Belgrade headquarters, opting for their own instead.

The fired state TV employees, mostly technical staff and editors of economic and culture programs, walked off to demand more objective reporting and the removal of managers and editors loyal to Milosevic.

"We demand that the editors and journalists ... who are still taking part in the biased reporting, to refuse obedience ... and join their colleagues who have already distanced themselves from such policies," some of the state television staff said in a letter carried by Beta news agency.

State television is the only TV broadcast seen throughout all of Serbia, and firm control over the broadcast and over several newspapers had been a main pillar of Milosevic's rule since 1987. Aware of television's importance for Milosevic, NATO bombed the TV headquarters in downtown Belgrade during last year's air war against Yugoslavia, killing 16 employees.

Because most people associate the state media with Milosevic, media outlets had become a symbol of his autocratic rule and probably the state institution most hated by the pro-democracy movement.

During major anti-Milosevic protests four years ago, the state television and Politika buildings were pelted with eggs and stones by furious demonstrators. For months, Serbs banged pots from balconies to drown out the sound of the main evening newscast.


LOAD-DATE: November 5, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Zeljko Jovanovic, Reuters; Opposition supporters stand outside the burning Serbian television building after clashes with riot police in Belgrade.; Photo: map


TYPE: News


Copyright 2000 Metroland Media Group Ltd


250 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


March 23, 1991


Yugoslavian leaders get together to try to resolve crisis in Serbia


BYLINE: By IAN TRAYNOR and BARNEY PETROVIC in Belgrade


LENGTH: 602 words


 

YUGOSLAVIA'S leaders pulled back from the brink yesterday and agreed to resume negotiations to find a way out of the crisis threatening to tear the country apart.

Following the tensest two weeks in the country's post-war history bringing army tanks, riot police, and tens of thousands of anti-communist protesters on to the streets of Belgrade and raising the spectre of a military takeover the presidents of the federation's six republics agreed to discuss the future.

A meeting on Thursday evening of the collective federal presidency the six republican presidents and the federal Prime Minister, Ante Markovic also discussed how to keep the economy functioning until the bickering republics decide on their relations. 

There was much talk, following the meeting, of rift-healing and tolerance. But despite the conciliatory signals, tension remains high, particularly in Serbia, the biggest republic under the diminishing control of its authoritarian President, Slobodan Milosevic, and his Socialist Party of former communists.

In this volatile climate, a week is a long time. Observers do not rule out a resumption of hostilities that could derail the dialogue. Thursday's meeting took place because Mr Milosevic went back on his dramatic statement last weekend declaring the collective federal presidency illegitimate, after he failed three times to get it to authorise a military crackdown.

Thwarted in his attempts to control the presidency, he then had to bow to its reconstitution. The Serbian parliament, dominated by Milosevic supporters, rejected the resignation of the Milosevic aide, Borisav Jovic, from the presidency, enabling him to retake his seat.

But the battering that the federal presidency has taken in the past week suggests that it will play a reduced role in the negotiations.

The Democratic League of Kosovo, the party supported by the vast majority of ethnic Albanians in the Serb-controlled southern province of Kosovo and arguably the biggest opposition party in Serbia, punctured the talk of reconciliation yesterday by demanding a voice at the negotiations.

It said talk of democratic bargaining over the future of Yugoslavia would remain meaningless as long as the country's third biggest ethnic group, the Albanians, were excluded.

It is inconceivable at present that Mr Milosevic would assent to allowing representative Albanian participation in the talks.

In Belgrade, meanwhile, dissidence is rumbling again amid signs that Mr Milosevic is going back on concessions he has been forced to make over the past 10 days.

The Serbian leader appears to be playing for time. While the Serbian interior minister, Radmilo Bogdanovic, offered to resign last week under pressure from the student protests, his resignation has not yet been accepted.

Despite concessions on media control such as the sacking of the director of Belgrade radio and television the widespread view is that the changes are cosmetic and that mainstream television and newspapers in Serbia continue to peddle pro-Milosevic propaganda.

In a statement yesterday, the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic, Mr Milosevic's biggest rival, claimed that the Serbian police were waging a campaign of 'coercion, threats and interrogation' against those who took part in the demonstrations that erupted in Belgrade two weeks ago.

Mr Draskovic has called for further anti-Milosevic protests next Wednesday, while student activists are busy in the centre of the city collecting thousands of signatures for a petition aimed at keeping up the pressure on Mr Milosevic.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Guardian Newspapers Limited


251 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


October 6, 2000, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Milosevic was the face of nation's nightmare


BYLINE: David J. Lynch


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17A


LENGTH: 1786 words


DATELINE: SVETI STEFAN, Yugoslavia


SVETI STEFAN, Yugoslavia -- After leading his nation to four humiliating
battlefield losses. After wrecking a once-prosperous economy.
And after turning a proud people into the isolated pariahs of
modern Europe.

Finally, Slobodan Milosevic may be gone.

A tumultuous day of protest capping a roller-coaster political
drama ended late Thursday with Yugoslavia's state-run media announcing
that it was with "the people" and proclaiming opposition leader
Vojislav Kostunica the country's elected president.
 

There was no official word on the whereabouts of Milosevic and
his powerful wife, Mira. And the possibility that the autocrat
was marshaling whatever forces remained loyal to him could not
be discounted.

But for the hundreds of thousands of people jamming the streets
of the capital, Belgrade, and promising to stay there through
the night, there was only a volcano of emotion, a euphoria that
sprang from more than a decade of suffering.

"I was living for this day," said a delirious Jovice Miric,
35, an auto mechanic in the Belgrade crowd that, with little official
resistance, took over the Parliament and the headquarters of the
state-run TV and radio stations. "I was prepared to give everything,
to give my life, to see Milosevic go."

It was a day that many in the battered remnant of the former Yugoslavia
had feared would never come.

And if, as dawn approached, Milosevic's political demise was not
assured, some warned that a very different vision also could not
be ruled out: the example of a hated Serbian king and his equally
unpopular queen, who were killed in a coup in 1903, their bodies
thrown from the palace window and mutilated.

Once the Cold War's non-aligned jewel of Eastern Europe, Yugoslavia
was a country that embraced six republics, reaching from the Hungarian
border in the north to Albania's "Cursed Mountains" in the south.

Today, it comprises just impoverished Serbia, where the average
monthly salary is just $ 48, and tiny Montenegro.

Milosevic was far from solely responsible for the agony of Yugoslavia,
which began in 1991. Short-sighted politicians in the other republics,
who pursued romantic 19th century ideas of nationalism at the
expense of peace and prosperity, were his co-conspirators.

But he was, and is, the man who personified the continuing Balkan
crisis.

For more than a decade, Milosevic was the "Zelig" of Europe's
worst trauma since the end of the Second World War, figuring in
every stage of the endless Balkans drama. Seen first as the pyromaniac
let loose in the Balkan tinderbox, by the time of the Dayton Agreement
ending the war in Bosnia in 1995, he appeared -- especially to
American policymakers -- as the region's indispensable peacemaker.
That portrait, if it was ever accurate, was thoroughly discredited
by the crisis and subsequent war over the separatist Serbian province
of Kosovo.

This day of apparent triumph, of course, came much too late for
the victims of almost a decade of Milosevic-inspired bloodletting.
Graves in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo are filled with the casualties
of the effort to replace the original Yugoslavia with a ring of
ethnically pure nation-states.

In the largest single massacre, more than 7,000 Bosnian Muslim
men were slaughtered at Srebrenica in July 1995. In the most geopolitically
potent, 45 people were shot down in the Kosovo village of Racak
in January 1999, killings that led directly to NATO's decision
to go to war over the rebel province.

Yet, Serbs, too, were victims of Milosevic's ill-conceived policies.
After his plan for a "Greater Serbia" collapsed, tens of thousands
of his ethnic kin were forced to flee lands in Croatia's Krajina
region, where Serbs had lived for centuries.

Roughly 100,000 other Serbs today live penned in NATO-patrolled
enclaves in Kosovo, surrounded by vengeance-minded Albanians and
abandoned by their president after a futile 78-day war with the
largest military alliance in the world.

The Serbs in Serbia itself, heirs to one of Europe's proudest
traditions of independence and valor, once lived in the most prosperous
country in Eastern Europe. Now Milosevic's successors are expected
to need two decades just to recover Serbia's 1989 standard of
living.

It's easy to forget, amid the seemingly unanimous popular condemnation
of Milosevic, how popular he once was. In the late 1980s, as communism
collapsed across Europe, Milosevic embraced a full-throated nationalism
that was in sync with a broad segment of Serbian society. By the
time the Berlin Wall fell, popular ditties celebrated his virtues:
"Slobodan, they call you freedom/You are loved by big and small."

His popularity soon waned. In 1991, he crushed an anti-war revolt
with tanks. Six years later, he compromised an unsteady opposition
movement called Zajedno ("Together") with partial concessions
and financial blandishments.

For much of his career, he was blessed with the right enemies.
His domestic opponents were a chronically quarrelsome bunch lacking
political savvy. Easy to smear as lackeys of foreign conspirators,
they seemed to prefer to hang separately rather than hang together.

Milosevic also notably enjoyed power thanks to the ballot -- not
the bullet. Elections in Yugoslavia and Serbia were rarely models
of Western democracy, but his parliamentary majorities depended
upon coalition partners, who could have backed other leaders,
and the ideological blindness of other potentially powerful opponents.

If the separatist ethnic Albanians of Kosovo, for example, had
swallowed their ideological objections and voted in Serbian elections
rather than boycotted them, Milosevic could have been peaceably
removed from power years ago. But the Albanians didn't, and they
later paid the price.

Never shy about using power, he was at the same time remarkably
sensitive to the appearance (if not the reality) of legality.
His government employed violence against those who disagreed with
it.

But Milosevic was not a totalitarian and, despite the jibes of
editorial writers and politicians, not a dictator in the mold
of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.

His secret police had 150,000 listening devices to monitor the
telephone conversations of opponents, according to an August report
of the Brussels-based International Crisis Group. Yet, anti-Milosevic
figures in Belgrade also were free to speak with foreign journalists,
who could quote them by name.

His was, after all, an odd government for late 20th and early
21st century Europe. The economy was largely state-controlled,
the official media produced a torrent of transparent propaganda,
and corruption was endemic.

Until Thursday, the question was: How long could this go on?

Now, it seems, we know.

Milosevic may be succeeded by a man few would ever have suggested
for the role.

A former law professor who emerged as the presidential candidate
of a united opposition only two months ago, Kostunica made an
unprecedented lengthy and unedited appearance on state-run television
Thursday night.

Official TV is now controlled by his coalition, and Kostunica,
speaking from the capital in his customary phlegmy baritone, used
the opportunity to introduce himself to a wider national audience.

"All those years, our life, day after day, hour after hour, was
too exciting. People now want some peace, and that's what I felt
during the campaign. That's what I saw in the eyes," he said.
"This vision of Serbia is going to get realized now. Democracy
is a healer. Tomorrow, this television will be open for those
who represent quite different attitudes. I promise that every
other voice in Serbia will be heard."

For Serbs and their neighbors, for Europe and the United States,
it appears that a new era lies ahead. It could start as soon as
today, when the opposition plans to convene the first parliamentary
session of the new Serbia.

The end of Milosevic would not mean the end of his country's troubles.
The economy is in ruins, the political culture has been debased,
and the country has yet to come to terms with its role in the
past decade of Balkans violence and hatred.

But Thursday was a good start.


The career of Milosevic

Events involving Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic:

December 1987: Takes over Communist Party in Serbia, dominant
republic of six-republic Yugoslav federation.

May 8, 1989: Is elected president of Serbia.

1989: Strips Serbia's southern Kosovo province of autonomy.

Dec. 9, 1990: Re-elected president of Serbia in first multiparty
elections.

March 1991: First big anti-Milosevic riots in Belgrade.

June 1991: Slovenia and Croatia declare independence.

July 1991: Yugoslav army withdraws from Slovenia after
brief war. Skirmishing in Croatia between ethnic Serbs and Croats
escalates into war, with Yugoslav troops backing Serbs.

Dec. 17, 1991: European Community says it will recognize
Croatia and Slovenia as independent states.

February 1992: U.N. Security Council sends 14,000 peacekeepers
to Croatia. Bosnia-Herzegovina declares independence; Bosnian
Serbs proclaim separate state; war erupts.

April 1992: Serbs besiege Sarajevo, Bosnia's capital, as
war intensifies. European Community and United States recognize
Bosnian independence.

May 1992: United Nations imposes sanctions on Yugoslavia,
now just Serbia and Montenegro, for fomenting war in Bosnia and
Croatia.

Nov. 21, 1995: Milosevic signs Dayton Peace Accord to end
war in Bosnia.

July 15, 1997: Milosevic inaugurated as Yugoslav president.

Jan. 15, 1999: 45 ethnic Albanians slain outside Racak
in Kosovo, spurring international peace efforts.

March 22, 1999: U.S. special envoy Richard Holbrooke warns
of airstrikes unless peace agreement signed; Milosevic refuses.

March 24: NATO begins bombing Serbia.

June 9, 1999: Yugoslav and Western generals sign accord
to end bombing, move Yugoslav troops out of Kosovo and allow refugees
to return home.

June 12, 1999: Peacekeepers take control of Kosovo.

May 27, 1999: U.N. tribunal indicts Milosevic for crimes
against humanity, holding him personally responsible for atrocities
in Kosovo.

Sept. 24, 2000: For first time, Yugoslavs vote directly
for Yugoslav president.

Sept. 25, 2000: Supporters of presidential challenger Vojislav
Kostunica declare victory.

Sept. 28, 2000: Milosevic announces runoff election Oct.
8; opposition threatens strike.

Sept. 29, 2000: Protesters block roads, close mines.

Oct. 5, 2000: Mobs rampage through Belgrade. Milosevic's
whereabouts unknown.


LOAD-DATE: October 06, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, b/w, Genevieve Lynn, USA TODAY, Source: CIA World Factbook 2000(Bar graph, Map, Chart); PHOTO, color, Nebojsa Parausic, AP(2); PHOTO, color, Marko Djurica, Reuters; PHOTO, b/w, Darko Vojinovic, AP; PHOTO, b/w, Srdjan Ilic, AP; Takeover: Waving the Serbian flag, Yugoslav opposition supporters scale the federal Parliament building Thursday. State TV and radio also came under opposition control. Fire and fury: A demonstrator raises the clenched-fist symbol of the student protest movement after clashes with police outside Parliament. Switches sides: A unit of secret service troops receives a warm greeting from demonstrators in downtown Belgrade after the soldiers decided to support the opposition. Kostunica: Democracy is a healer," opposition leader tells mourn. Milosevic: Once a revered nationalist, now reviled as an autocrat.

252 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


April 21, 1999, FINAL


Destruction, despair and, hopefully, diplomacy: The tally of refugees, casualties and ruined infrastructure has not lessened the chance for a wider war. Our best bet is secret talks are being held.


BYLINE: Lewis MacKenzie


SECTION: Editorial; A17


LENGTH: 720 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


BELGRADE - On this 29th day of NATO's war against Yugoslavia it might be worthwhile to look at what the current situation is like on the ground throughout the region.

The forced departure of the ethnic-Albanian community from Kosovo appears to be in its final stage. In the absence of reliable census figures, it is impossible for anyone to produce pre-war statistics for Kosovo.

However, popular opinion puts the population at two million, of which 10 per cent were alleged to be Serbs. Informed sources suggest that the overall figure was significantly less, but we will probably only know for sure when we count the number of refugees expelled from Kosovo. 

During the past year approximately one million Albanians have been forced or convinced to leave the province, which means there are somewhere around 300,000 to 400,000 left and a significant number of them are moving in the direction of Kosovo's borders with Macedonia and Albania.

The air campaign and Milosevic's reaction to it have without doubt accelerated the removal of the Albanian population. This fact combined with Yugoslavia's paranoia regarding a NATO land invasion and the desire of the Serb army to clear all civilians from Kosovo in order to enhance what they see as an inevitable defensive battle does not auger well for any Albanians remaining in Kosovo.

Billions of dollars worth of damage has been sustained by Yugoslavia infrastructure and military complexes. Oil refineries have been put out of commission and fuel supplies stored in the open are targeted on a daily basis.

The majority of bridges over the Danube are destroyed, the three in Belgrade being the exception. Electronic communications facilities of all types have been severely degraded and few transmission towers are left standing.

As far as civilian casualties are concerned, ''only'' 1,000 people have been killed or injured by the bombing campaign.

The Yugoslav army has suffered considerable damage in Kosovo but considering the dearth of information from that area it is impossible to gauge how much its operational effectiveness has been reduced. Considering the number of caves, tunnels and bunkers located in Kosovo, it is probably a safe deduction that the army is still an effective and formidable fighting force.

The situation in neighbouring Macedonia is highly unstable due to the massive influx of Albanian refugees. Macedonia's political situation is precarious at the best of times considering its ethnic mix.

The presence of hundreds of thousands of refugees combined with Macedonia's 25-per-cent Albanian population is seen as a considerable threat by most of the remaining citizens. The build-up of NATO forces numbering at least 12,000 is seen as an additional threat because of the potential for cross-border operations into Macedonia by Serb forces.

Albania, the poorest country in the region and only just recovering from a period of anarchy, is under immense pressure from its considerable share of the refugee exodus. Cross-border operations in remote border regions are commonplace and NATO's movement of approximately 8,000 troops into the area along with Apache helicopters and multiple rocket launchers increase the potential for such attacks.

In ''neutral'' Montenegro there is much anticipation of a coup by the Yugoslavian army to displace a pro-western, anti-Milosevic government. Many Montenegrans are confused and upset they are included on NATO's target lists. In spite of the fact that mostly military targets have been struck, many feel the attacks are unjustified and unfair.

As far as Milosevic is concerned, there are no evident cracks in his intransigence to date. Diplomatic delegations parade through his office on a daily basis but there have been no hints of even a minor breakthrough.

Successful diplomacy is a secretive process and the public will not be aware of any progress on that front until there is a major development.

The good news is that there appears to be an increased level of activities by senior Yugoslav officials. They seem to be preoccupied with what I can only assume are numerous diplomatic initiatives.

Let's hope one of them works.

Maj.-Gen. Lewis MacKenzie, now retired, commanded UN troops during the siege of Sarajevo in the Bosnian civil war of 1992.


LOAD-DATE: April 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

253 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


July 9, 1999 Friday Final Edition


SERB OPPONENTS FACE OFF;
CALLS FOR MILOSEVIC'S RESIGNATION GROW


BYLINE: STEVE CRAWSHAW, THE INDEPENDENT, LONDON


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. C5


LENGTH: 637 words


DATELINE: PROKUPLJE


Violent clashes between Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic loyalists and supporters of the democratic Serb opposition were narrowly averted last night when the ruling Serb Socialist Party apparently lost its nerve.

Party bosses had scheduled a demonstration at the same time and place as the anti-Milosevic opposition. Many expected violence -- one man was killed on the last occasion of such a deliberate double-booking. 

Yesterday however, the Socialists backed down in the face of growing anger.

They started to erect a stage for their rival meeting yesterday afternoon. But the hostility of the crowd was so strong that they finally gave up and left the pieces lying uselessly on the ground just a few metres from the stage that the opposition successfully erected.

During the demonstration, a local Socialist Party boss, Ratko Zecevic, fired gun shots from his office balcony, causing brief panic among the thousands who had gathered in the central square. However, the meeting went off peacefully.

Milosevic supporters unfurled a banner from a balcony demanding "Traitors Leave Toplica" (the region surrounding Prokuplje) but they were booed off the balcony.

It was the usually self-confident Milosevic supporters who seemed frightened. An old man inside the locked Socialist Party headquarters told The Independent that the demonstration was "absolute barbarism."

There were scuffles between supporters and opponents of the regime, but there were no injuries.

Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic Party, received a much warmer welcome in Prokuplje than he had at the hands of the Kosovo Serbs in Gracanica earlier in the day. He called for a peaceful solution to Serbia's problems, saying, "There are not so many Serbs that we can fight and kill each other."

All over the country, signs of resistance are multiplying -- though the protests have not yet reached critical mass.

DEMANDS

Resistance to the regime is taking different forms. In the industrial town of Nis down the road from Prokuplje, people lined up at trestle tables to sign demands for Milosevic's resignation.

The campaign is organized under the slogan, Many reasons -- but one demand: Resignation.

Each signatory gives not just their name but address and ID number. These serve to show not just that the signatories are real, but also that people are not afraid.

Most of the planned signing points in Nis were dismantled after the police threatened arrests. But outside a shopping mall in the city centre, organizers stayed put, daring the police to do their worst.

In other towns, the gathering of signatures was banned.

Vuk Draskovic's Serb Renewal Movement (SPO) -- formerly a pillar of the opposition -- has hesitated between supporting the protests and remaining loyal to Milosevic.

Draskovic has conspicuously avoided calling for the resignation of the Yugoslav leader.

Skepticism of politicians of all stripes runs deep in Serbia today. And tension remains high in the only other remaining Yugoslav republic, Montenegro.

The pro-western Montenegrin government fears proposals by Belgrade to form a federal police force, which could overrule Montenegro's own force. The Montenegrin interior ministry said such preparations were "yet another bid to destabilize the general situation in the republic."

During the NATO bombing, government buildings in the Montenegrin capital, Podgorica, were protected by armed police against a threatened coup by army units loyal to Belgrade.

Belgrade was publicly furious at Montenegro's refusal to offer support to Serbia.

The Serb media are split in their reporting of the current situation. The independent tabloid Blic devoted most of yesterday's front page to news about the opposition protest.

The pro-government Politika by contrast remained silent.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Metroland Media Group Ltd


254 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


August 11, 2000 Friday Final Edition


Milosevic uses arrests to boost election prospects


SOURCE: The Guardian; London


SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. C04


LENGTH: 526 words


Western officials fear that the arrests of eight foreigners, including two Canadians, on charges of espionage are designed to create a "sense of siege" and boost President Slobodan Milosevic's already strong chances in next month's elections.

"They are, in effect, hostages to his effort to present Yugoslavia as being under threat," a senior official said this week.

Ever since last year's war over Kosovo, western governments have pinned their hopes of removing Milosevic on various scenarios, including an army coup and street demonstrations. 

When the Yugoslav strongman unexpectedly announced snap elections for next month, they banked on the central campaign issues being the future of the Serbian economy, Serbia's reintegration into the European fold, and how best to achieve political liberalization.

But Milosevic is casting the election as a loyalty test, with his challengers portrayed as traitors.

"This is a battle for the survival of the nation and the state. Slobodan Milosevic is the symbol of Yugoslavia, of heroic resistance to the aggressor, and of restoration and development.

"Our opponents are not an opposition to our party, but to their own people and the state," Gorica Gajevic, the secretary general of the Socialist party of Serbia said last week.

Forced on to the defensive, the fractious Serbian opposition has accepted Milosevic's game plan and, in choosing Vojislav Kostunica as its standard-bearer in the elections, has appointed a nationalist rather than a liberalizer.

As a result, western governments find themselves rooting for a man who strongly criticized NATO's Kosovo campaign and who refuses to meet officials from NATO countries.

Anti-western feeling is still high in Serbia and although many voters criticize Milosevic they seem to accept his argument that Yugoslavia remains under siege. Milosevic's ally, the ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj, yesterday pursued that line. He attacked Kostunica as "NATO's candidate."

"On radio, Voice of America, Free Europe, Deutsche Welle and the BBC have all praised Kostunica over the past few days in Serbian language broadcasts," he said.

Kostunica had been more cunning than other opposition leaders at hiding his pro-NATO feelings but Serbs would never vote for "NATO candidates," he added.

The charge is ironic since Kostunica's nationalist credentials are clear. Before the NATO air strikes, he was photographed with Serbs in Kosovo brandishing a Kalashnikov rifle in resistance. He has described relations between foreigners and the Serbian state as "a game in which everything is given up in return for almost nothing, except symbolic concessions."

He strongly opposes the Hague Tribunal and criticizes the war crimes indictment issued against Milosevic.

This line of "moderate nationalism" may explain why Kostunica came out well in a recent poll by the Belgrade-based Institute of Social Sciences.

It found him leading Milosevic by 42 per cent to 28 per cent.

But the poll was taken before the Serbian Renewal Movement, a leading opposition party, decided to put up its own candidate in a move which will split the anti-Milosevic front.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: KNIGHT RIDDER; Vojislav Kostunica: good showing.


TYPE: News


Copyright 2000 Metroland Media Group Ltd


255 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 27, 1999, Monday, Late Edition - Final


Serbs Rally, Wearily Looking for Someone Else


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1527 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 26


Jelena Kovacevic, 25 years old, wants change so badly she is nearly in tears. She's afraid of the winter, afraid of her grandparents dying from lack of medicine, afraid of the future, afraid that she will never live in a Serbia in which she will want to bear a child.

A painter and graphic artist, she goes nightly to the opposition demonstrations in Novi Sad seeking the ouster of President Slobodan Milosevic, but she does not believe that they will succeed. 

"I go to the rallies because I want something good to happen in this country, so I can't stay at home," she said, twisting her fingers around her three earrings. "But I don't go because I support the opposition, either."

"People are so tired, tired of everything," she said. "Normally, I'm a person with a lot of energy, but I don't feel it now. I don't see the person in the opposition who can lead the Serbs."

Ms. Kovacevic's despair is widely shared among the tens of thousands, young and old, who have turned out for Serbia's first week of rallies to try to oust the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.

It is a despair shared, privately, by opposition officials and organizers, who are trying to swallow down their disappointment in their own people.

As many as 80,000 people across Serbia turned out last Tuesday, but the numbers since have, if anything, been shrinking. While the enthusiasm is palpable in Novi Sad, a 90-minute drive north of Belgrade, and numbers are back up to 30,000 in the capital now that demonstrators are asked to march instead of simply listen to speeches, they are down in other Serbian cities.

In a country of nearly 11 million people, the turnout is not even close to a politically definitive figure, let alone to the two million demonstrators that the Democratic Party leader, Zoran Djindjic, believes will be necessary to get the Milosevic Government to crack. And the behavior of the protesters is extraordinarily -- and undramatically -- polite.

"It's like Don Quixote against the windmills," said Vesna, who asked that her last name not be used because she works for an international organization. "However much we'd like to see Milosevic fall, to see him hanging with his wife from a lamppost in Terazije Square, like Mussolini, on the other hand" -- she paused, lifting up her arms, turning her palms toward her face -- "the power is still in his hands."

People are tired and afraid of losing what little is left to them, including their jobs, Vesna said. "From the end of the war until now, energy has been dissipated by the war, the bombing, the shortages of everything," she said. "And the opposition dissipates energy, too, with empty rallies, with their squabbling and their fight for supremacy."

The indisputable fact about the opposition is its division: Mr. Djindjic and the Alliance for Change, a coalition of smaller parties, have taken a path of daily rallies opposed by the largest, notionally opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic.

Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Djindjic, former allies in the Zajedno or Together coalition that led 88 days of opposition demonstrations in the winter of 1996-97, not so casually despise each other. Mr. Draskovic, who now controls Belgrade and its television station, Studio B, says that the Alliance strategy is all wrong, that street pressure will not bring down Mr. Milosevic but should be used to demand fair and early elections, even if Mr. Milosevic keeps his seat.

But Democratic Party officials and many rally goers believe that Mr. Draskovic simply wants to destroy Mr. Djindjic and become the sole leader of the opposition, and that his position is part of a deal with Mr. Milosevic to keep each other in power.

Vesna believes that Mr. Draskovic is hopelessly compromised by his desire to keep Belgrade, its money and privilege, and that he cannot be considered a member of the opposition at all.

"It really is true that the revolution eats its own children," she said. "Draskovic chooses not to join these rallies, and he is doing all he can to kill them." Studio B has taken a dismissive line toward the rallies, reporting them but underestimating turnout, much as state television has been doing.

"Vuk is a red bandit now," said Jovan Bandin, using a description commonly attached to Mr. Milosevic and his allies. Mr. Bandin, a portly, bearded businessman who says he will attend rallies until the end, said he liked Mr. Draskovic three years ago, "but he's Slobo's man now; he's doing everything he can to stop real change."

Mr. Bandin, who imports Timex watches and Herbalife, a nutritional supplement, says: "I have a house and cars. I don't need anything. But what I need I don't have, and that's freedom -- the freedom to live and travel."

But Mr. Bandin is also highly critical of the West's effort to drive Mr. Milosevic into a corner by indicting him for war crimes, giving him no option but to turn and fight for his position. "Without an exit, he won't go," he said, "not without a real battle."

Mina, 21, an economics student, has gone to the rallies without much real hope. Asked why, she said bitterly: "Milosevic has smashed my hopes. But the largest blame for that belongs to the opposition parties. They have no clear line. They just wait to see what Milosevic will give them, and everyone knows it."

But she conceded that the opposition has real problems of finances and lack of media access, too. For instance, cardboard masks of Mr. Milosevic's face with a red line through it, so popular at the first rally, had disappeared by the second day. The Alliance had money to print only 12,000, and they were gone.

With Mr. Draskovic's Studio B essentially unsympathetic to the rallies, it is difficult for Mr. Djindjic to answer the carefully honed criticisms of the state television that has been the mainstay of Mr. Milosevic's 12-year rule of Yugoslavia. Like all good propaganda, reports over the state news media play on real issues: there was a war here, NATO did bomb and take over Kosovo, and ordinary civilians died.

Within days of the start of the bombing, in March, Mr. Djindjic told The New York Times that the democratic opposition would be the first victim of NATO's war against Mr. Milosevic. And it remains very awkward for the political opposition to push for Western reforms and the ouster of Mr. Milosevic with the apparent support -- moral and financial -- of those who bombed for the same purpose.

At the same time, opposition officials say, NATO not only failed to finish off Mr. Milosevic, but also failed to protect the multiethnic character of Kosovo. By letting even innocent Serbs be driven from a province that remains a sovereign part of Yugoslavia, NATO has allowed Mr. Milosevic to justify fighting the war, however unwinnable, by stressing its consequences for Serbs.

Ms. Kovacevic, the Novi Sad artist, sees the opposition as part of the "collateral damage" of the NATO bombing war, caught between patriotism and its desire to push for Western-style democratic change. She has done a series of "collateral art" and distributed it on her web page (http://www.surf.to/jelena), including a graphic of Sisyphus, eternally trying to climb his mountain with a huge red Communist star still embedded in his back.

"The opposition had its chance to do something and failed everyone," she said. "And now, when it's the last chance to do something, when Milosevic is weaker, they're quarreling among themselves. You know people are afraid when they start to quarrel," she said. "People lose their faith and trust in them, and that's why the demonstrations have lost strength."

Ms. Kovacevic is trying without much success to pull money together to attend art school in America, but she also feels guilty about wanting to leave her family and friends before a winter that everyone knows will be difficult, with shortages of electricity and heat. But she doubts that winter will be a great ally to the opposition.

"It just adds to this collective depression," she said. "Imagine people in New York without enough electricity and heat, without confidence in the future, without knowing what will happen tomorrow to basic parts of life. Will there be medicine? Will my computer be dead without electricity? This uncertainty translates into apathy, not action."

She was 6 years old when Tito died in May 1980 after 35 years as the unquestioned leader of the old Communist Yugoslavia. "Everyone cried and I couldn't understand it," she said. "But since then I've lived in so many states, in so many Yugoslavias, each one smaller than the last, but for 10 years with the same leader -- that's the worst thing of all."

Many of her friends have joined the great exodus of young people from Yugoslavia, to live and work abroad. "They call or E-mail me and ask how am I," she said. "I can't answer -- things just get worse and worse. And when they talk about visiting, I tell them not to come."

Ms. Kovacevic toyed with her earrings again, finished a coffee and prepared to wander out to another rally. "After the war, I really thought Milosevic would be gone in a few days," she said. "But now he seems stronger."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Nightly anti-Milosevic demonstrations in Belgrade are drawing about 30,000 people, young and old. Women lit candles Saturday night for Slavko Curuvija, publisher of an opposition newspaper, who was slain April 11. (Liaison Agency for The New York Times)


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


256 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


October 26, 1999, Tuesday, Final Edition


Milosevic Foes Urge U.S. to End Sanctions; Measures Said to Help Yugoslav President


William Drozdiak, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A19


LENGTH: 693 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Oct. 25


 

Serbia's political opposition urged the United States today to ease economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, warning that such measures as an embargo on heating oil are harming ordinary citizens and helping to entrench President Slobodan Milosevic in power.

The appeal, delivered during two days of meetings in Budapest with U.S. special Balkans envoy James Dobbins, sought to persuade the United States that Western sanctions are allowing Milosevic to blame the outside world for the hardships faced by the 10 million people of Serbia--Yugoslavia's dominant republic.

France, Germany and other European Union countries support the idea of removing a ban on commercial air travel to and from Yugoslavia and restoring shipments of food, medical and fuel there--provided that "targeted sanctions" aimed at Milosevic and his associates are sustained. The number of people linked to the Yugoslav ruling clique who have been declared ineligible for visas to nearly all Western nations may soon be doubled to more than 600, increasing the pressure on those closest to Milosevic. 

But the Clinton administration has refused to go along with any softening of the sanctions. U.S. officials say they are convinced, given the personal rivalries among Serbian opposition leaders, that the only hope of ousting Milosevic may lie in a massive popular uprising caused by severe deprivation this winter.

"We don't really understand why the Americans are so insistent on these sanctions," said Milan Protic, a leader in the opposition bloc known as Alliance for Change. "There is a serious danger they will backfire by making it a lot easier for Milosevic to stay in power."

Serbian opposition groups want the immediate resumption of commercial air travel connections to Belgrade and basic humanitarian aid, especially fuel oil. They say unless people here receive urgent relief, Milosevic will continue to stir up public resentment against the West--especially now that Russia, despite its own economic difficulties, has started natural gas deliveries.

"The consistent position of all the opposition of Yugoslavia is that the sanctions really are not removing Milosevic," said Milan Panic, a former Yugoslav prime minister. "The humanitarian suffering of people cannot ever justify economic sanctions--Milosevic must be removed by some other means."

Panic said Yugoslavia also needs "massive assistance" to rebuild bridges across the Danube River that were destroyed last spring by a NATO bombing campaign aimed at forcing the Serb-led Yugoslav government to end a violent military campaign against the ethnic Albanian majority of Serbia's Kosovo province.

Serbian Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic, who has been staging nightly protest marches with the ostensible goal of forcing Milosevic to step down, said the time had come for a major change in Western strategy. He proposed that the West offer to lift sanctions as soon as free and fair elections are held in Yugoslavia, regardless of the winner.

"We all think this is now the right way to go," Djindjic said. "The opposition alliance is united behind this idea, and so are the major European allies. Only the United States is against it, because the Americans seem to think lifting sanctions would send the wrong message to Milosevic."

Djindjic is locked in a power struggle with Vuk Draskovic, the mercurial head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, for leadership of the opposition drive to bring down Milosevic. Draskovic has refused to join the protest rallies and declined to meet even separately with U.S. envoy Dobbins.

Both opposition leaders, however, insist that sanctions are hurting the cause of the anti-Milosevic effort and have expressed exasperation with the United States for its refusal to ease the economic punishment being inflicted on the population at large.

They argue that such steps are necessary to vindicate contacts with the West at a time when Milosevic is branding them traitors. In a recent speech, Milosevic railed against his rivals as those who "take their marching orders from NATO and are trying to finish the damage started by NATO bombs."


LOAD-DATE: October 26, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


257 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


July 2, 2001, Monday


My lessons in casual cruelty


BYLINE: Eve-Ann Prentice


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 957 words


 

Slobodan Milosevic faces war crimes charges tomorrow, but the scars of his brutal regime are still raw. Here three Times correspondents recall their own experiences of his wars

I owe my life to Milosevic

It is strange to think that I may owe my life to Slobodan Milosevic, a man more usually renowned as butcher than benefactor. The indicted war criminal, now awaiting judgment day in The Hague, intervened to ensure that his troops looked after me when I found myself on the wrong side of a Nato bombing raid during the Kosovo conflict. But the Yugoslav President was acting out of self-interest, not altruism; he wanted to ensure that I and four other western journalists lived to tell how we came under fire from our own side and how our driver was killed. 

Milosevic overruled a Yugoslav army officer who wanted to order us out of the relative safety of an army camp where we were taken during a lull in the bombing. Had we been forced to go, we would have faced an all-night aerial bombardment on a mountain also thick with snipers.

Goran Zdravkovic, the army doctor who helped me on that Sunday afternoon on May 30, 1999, later told me that his commanding officer had not wanted to help people from "aggressor" nations. Elsa Marujo, a TV reporter from Portugal, and I both had cut legs and had been badly shaken by the relentless bombing and the death of our driver.

"You were not fit to leave our camp," Zdravkovic told me after I met him again by chance in Belgrade two weeks after the Nato campaign ended. "I was having an argument with the commanding officer, who wanted you all sent back down the mountain, when the message came through. Milosevic personally radioed our camp and gave orders for us to look after you."

It seemed yet another example of the Yugoslav leader's far-reaching power, especially in the final years of his presidency. Like him or loathe him, few Serbs felt indifferent about him and his regime.

Until his overthrow last October, most Serbs lived in a state of anything from wariness to outright fear. Tension became especially palpable in the 16 months between the end of the Nato bombing campaign and last October's popular uprising.

A wave of anti-Milosevic rallies across Serbia in the summer and autumn of 1999 brought an upsurge in the number of armed police on the streets. While their presence roused many to indignation and anger, others were reduced to near panic.

Few people outside the opposition parties and groups would speak frankly unless sure that they were not overheard. I was once rebuffed by a Serb diplomat for moving to shake his hand in the street at a time when I was unpopular with the regime for having written something critical of the leadership. I had known the diplomat for years and he had often kissed my cheeks in typical Balkan fashion; I presumed that this time he was edgy about being seen to be too friendly.

A rise in politically motivated killings and disappearances also gave Belgrade a gangster-ridden feel during the death-throes of the old regime. Milosevic's old mentor, the former Yugoslav leader Ivan Stambolic, was kidnapped last summer and is believed to be dead; Vuk Draskovic, the founder of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, was involved in a road accident that is being investigated as a possible assassination attempt; and the paramilitary leader Arkan was gunned down by a hit squad in the capital's Inter-Continental Hotel early last year. The sound of gunfire became more than an isolated incident in the capital.

But Milosevic had supporters, especially outside Belgrade and among the working classes and the older generation, who saw communism as an antidote to the fascism of the Second World War. Rigidly state-controlled propaganda, and prices, were effective, while the Nato bombing rallied Serbs round their Government.

The final days of the Alliance campaign to force Milosevic's forces out of Kosovo were marked by especially fierce fighting on the ground and in the air. The narrow road where we were bombed was one of the last routes open to Serb forces moving between the front line along the Albanian border and the Kosovo capital, Pristina. Two Nato jets swooped out of the sky and pounded the road with five bombs for half an hour. One of the two cars in which we had been travelling was smashed into the roof of a road tunnel by the force of the first blast, killing the driver. The rest of us -an Italian, three Portuguese and I -were on foot near by and escaped with cuts and bruises.

While the bombing was still under way we could see no way to escape from the area, which was bordered by rock faces, a ravine and the newly bombed road, until the army doctor and a Serb soldier in two battered Yugo cars arrived to help us to their mountain camp. We were given food and medicine, and beds and army jackets as night fell. The next day the soldiers risked KLA sniper attacks to escort us to Pristina.

I wondered why these Yugoslav army troops should have been at such pains to help representatives of nations that were fighting them. Our propaganda value became clear when we were back in the Kosovo capital. News of western journalists caught in a bombing raid had flashed across the world. Nato had initially denied that it had taken action in that area, so the implication was that we may have been hit by Serbian shells. The Serbian press seized the chance to broadcast our own accounts of what had happened.

I have since become friends with the conscripted doctor and his family. Zdravkovic is a civilian again, working in a Belgrade hospital, while Milosevic ponders his new surroundings. The former President may be wondering if any miracle will come to his aid.


LOAD-DATE: July 2, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2001 Times Newspapers Limited


258 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


March 1, 1999, Monday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION


DIPLOMACY FAILS IN KOSOVO TALKS


BYLINE: Josef Rohlik


SECTION: EDITORIAL, Pg. D15, COMMENTARY COLUMN


LENGTH: 927 words


 

The script at Chateau Rambouillet, ultimately agreed on by the United States, its European NATO allies and Russia, is simple enough:

Yugoslavia - that is, Slobodan Milosevic and his Serbian government - will agree to have NATO troops stationed in Kosovo for three years. At the end, the Kosovars will regain limited autonomy, and the Kosovars will disarm and recognize the territorial integrity of Serbia, i.e. renounce their aspirations of independence, or unification with Albania.

If this script works, there will be universal happiness. Milosevic will keep his power and, as was contemptibly agreed at Rambouillet, nobody will be prosecuted for war crimes and crimes against humanity at the Yugoslav War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. The ethnic Albanians in Macedonia will get the message to keep quiet and not disturb yet another area of the Balkans. NATO troops will manage to do what the unarmed observers could not do - prevent the Serbian atrocities in Kosovo. And after three years, the political settlement will make the Serbs, the Montenegrins, and the Kosovars live happily ever after in the new Yugoslavia. 

This idyllic scenario makes a lot of theoretical sense. Political solutions are vastly preferable to the use of force. Kosovo is not a viable economic entity on its own. The NATO presence in Kosovo may embolden the democratic opposition to Milosevic and, maybe, lead to the overthrow of him, his orthodox Marxist wife and her advisers, who unseated the members of Milosevic's own marginally less hard-line circle.

There is a dangling carrot at the end of the long road. Ultimately, Yugoslavia will become a part of the unified Europe. After all, Slovenia, a constituent republic of the former Yugoslavia, is among the group of several European countries slated for membership in the European Union in the next round.

In the latter stages of the Rambouillet negotiations, the United States fully embraced this wishful political scenario. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told us that if the Kosovars fail to agree, nothing will be done. The president's national security adviser, Sandy Berger, told us on the "Newshour" with Jim Lehrer on Feb. 23 that "peacemaking is not for those who are in it only for a short run."

But this is not how the Rambouillet negotiations started. Their original purpose was to force Milosevic to stop the atrocities in Kosovo.

It may be remembered that for a few weeks prior to Rambouillet, the foreign policy establishment in the United States and in Europe started branding Milosevic as a villain, rather than as a partner in crisis management. Some commentators likened him to Saddam Hussein.

While this comparison was obvious with respect to war crimes in Bosnia and crimes against humanity in both Bosnia and Kosovo, it otherwise ignored the differences in the peculiar contexts of Iraq and the Balkans and, in particular, the fact that there has been opposition to Milosevic in Serbia, while there is no discernible alternative to Saddam's regime in Iraq.

In any event, the emergence of the anti-Milosevic sentiment seemed to signal the willingness of NATO members to move against Milosevic and his regime rather than to try to make yet another deal. In other words, one might have hoped that the policy goal to replace Saddam had a chance to be applied - with more probable success - to Milosevic and his regime.

Indeed, the only legitimacy of outside military intervention in Yugoslavia rests on the massive violations of human rights, on Milosevic's crimes against humanity. The international community has every right - many would say a duty - to safeguard basic human rights, whether or not political solutions are reached.

Why did the couple of hastily assembled representatives of the largely unorganized Kosovar movement refuse to sign the proposed settlement? Perhaps, they remembered that Irish patriot, Michael Collins, who in 1921 surprised the Irish people and signed in London the treaty dividing the Irish island. The Irish paid for Michael Collins' rationality with the ci vil war, Michael Collins paid for it with his life, and the settlement of the issue was finally reached in 1998.

Imposition of political settlements by outside powers rarely works. Our troops are still in Bosnia and will be there for a long time.

Last week's adjournment of the Rambouillet meeting is yet another victory for Milosevic. He did not come to Rambouillet. Despite Albright's admonition on hostilities, he is now free to resume massacring Kosovars and destroying their villages.

If that happens, will the Kosovo people be ready and able to signify their assent to their representatives, and send them back to Rambouillet to sign an agreement that will leave Milosevic once again at the helm in Yugoslavia? Should they have to live forever under an international protectorate?

With Milosevic in Belgrade, the three-year period and Kosovo's autonomy are a joke. Milosevic broke the Belgrade agreement brokered by Ambassador Richard Holbrooke in less than four months.

The United States should be involved, with broad international support, in responses to massive and continuous violations of human rights, particularly in an area, such as the Balkans, where the United States is already involved.

But when broad political solutions have demonstrably failed in the past, efforts to repeat them could degenerate into a farce. The current impasse at Rambouillet may result in placing the blame on the Kosovars, and otherwise leaving them at Milosevic's mercy.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC Graphic / Illustration - RANAN LURIE/Cartoonews International - (of a NATO airplane flying over two men, SERBS and ALBANIA)


Copyright 1999 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


259 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


July 07, 1999, EARLY


'Leave, Slobo, leave!' Serb protesters cry: Thousands rally in central town to demand Milosevic's ouster


BYLINE: Aleksandar Vasovic


SECTION: News; A10


LENGTH: 588 words


DATELINE: UZICE, Yugoslavia


UZICE, Yugoslavia -- Thousands of angry Serbs rallied in this central Serbian town yesterday to demand that President Slobodan Milosevic resign, and police in another Serb town clashed with a similar crowd of anti- government protesters.

''Leave, Slobo, leave!'' the crowd chanted, using Mr. Milosevic's nickname. They cheered the leaders of Serbia's democratic opposition, who organized the protest in Uzice, a town 200 kilometres southwest of Belgrade. 

''We must go to the end so that Serbia could have a new start. Every day ... we must be in all the streets and stay until he (Milosevic) leaves,'' Democratic party head Zoran Djindjic told the estimated 6,000 people who braved the sweltering heat.

The organizers from the Alliance for Change -- the leading umbrella group of Serbia's pro-democracy, anti-Milosevic parties -- ignored a police warning to call off the protest in downtown Uzice.

However, no substantial police presence was visible during the rally.

It was the latest of several protests in Serbian towns calling for the ouster of the autocratic president.

A few thousand people took to the streets in the southern Serbian town of Leskovac for the second day yesterday, demanding the resignation of a local governor loyal to Mr. Milosevic.

The protesters clashed with the police when they approached a police station where the activist who called for Monday's rally was being held.

Ivan Novkovic, an employee in a local TV station, became an instant celebrity when he interrupted the station's programming last week to call for a rally against the allegedly corrupt local governor.

After 20,000 people took to the streets Monday in Leskovac, he was sentenced to 30 days in jail.

Mr. Novkovic's individual outcry -- not organized by any opposition party -- was seen by some as a sign of the increasingly bold discontent with Mr. Milosevic for his hard-line policies that led to NATO air strikes and the virtual loss of Serbia's Kosovo province.

''Serbia has risen, free of fear. Leskovac is an example. Novkovic is better than Milosevic because he is a brave man,'' said Goran Svilanovic, an Alliance leader at the Uzice rally.

A local priest of the Serbian Orthodox Church also came to express support for the protest in Uzice.

In a break from tradition, the Church recently openly demanded Mr. Milosevic's resignation.

Another opposition activist, Velimir Ilic, called on the police and army to join the people's protest.

Mr. Ilic became a major dissident during the NATO bombing by blaming the government for the destruction.

But Milosevic loyalists have a long record of successfully outmanoeuvring Yugoslavia's often divided opposition.

Leaflets blasting the opposition as allies of NATO were thrown on the crowd in Uzice from a nearby skyscraper.

In another blow to Mr. Milosevic, Serbia's main opposition leader rebuffed the president's attempts to draw him into his coalition in order to boost support for his government.

Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement Party, said yesterday he would not join a government led by the pro-Milosevic premier, Momir Bulatovic.

He demanded a new government led by the pro-Western leader of Yugoslavia's smaller republic, Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic.

Also yesterday , the city council of Novi Sad, the second-largest city in Yugoslavia, which was heavily damaged during the 78-day NATO campaign, joined the chorus demanding Milosevic's resignation, the private Beta news agency reported.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Black & White Photo: Darko Vojinovic, The Associated Press / 'We must go to the end so that Serbia could have a new start. Every day ... we must be in all the streets and stay until he (Milosevic) leaves,' Democratic party head Zoran Djindic told protesters in Uzice.
