260 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


October 9, 2000, Monday


YUGOSLAVIA: MAYOR PLANNED STORMING OF PARLIAMENT WITH HIS FRIENDS AMONG POLICE DEFECTORS


BYLINE: Justin Huggler In Cacak, Serbia


SECTION: FOREIGN NEWS; Pg. 12


LENGTH: 696 words


 

THE EXTRAORDINARY events that brought about the fall of Slobodan Milosevic last week were planned with defectors from elite Serbian police units, the opposition mayor who led the storming of parliament said yesterday.

The apparently spontaneous capture of the Yugoslav Parliament and state television were the result of a carefully planned strategy, said Velja Ilijc, mayor of Cacak, an opposition stronghold.

Extraordinary scenes as riot police threw off their helmets and joined protesters were planned gestures designed to break police lines, he said.

As the mayor told the story of the Serbian revolution, one of his party aides sat and played with an unused AK47 round captured from hardline police who fired on Mr Ilijc and the other protesters. A bouquet of flowers on the mayor's desk bore the message: "Thank you for what you have done, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you." 

At 7.30am on Thursday, a huge column of protesters set off from Cacak for Belgrade, led by Mr Ilijc. Most were farmers and working men, but among them, said Mr Ilijc, were Yugoslav army paratroops and plainclothes police defectors. As they left, the mayor told them: "Victory or death."

They broke through five police blockades on the way to Belgrade, pushing into the ditch the trucks police had used to block roads. As they marched, they were joined by others from towns along the way. When the column reached Belgrade there were 10,000 of them. It was they who led the storming of Parliament and state television with a bulldozer they brought from Cacak. Their targets were carefully selected.Losing control of the media was a fatal blow to Mr Milosevic. "We were sick of watching state television," said Mr Ilijc, the image of a Serbian macho man lounging in the mayor's office in his tracksuit."We got fed up with living in Milosevic's Serbia. I planned it all with my buddies. It is Cacak's humble contribution."

The mayor says he co- ordinated Thursday's event with just four other people: two police officers from an elite unit based in Belgrade and two officers from Cacak. At 3.30pm, a time agreed in advance, the police defectors broke police lines, opening the protesters' path to Parliament.

The protest even had assistance from plainclothes police on the way to Belgrade, who tried to persuade police to abandon roadblocks. "I had trouble telling some people not to attack those officers," laughed the mayor. "I kept saying, 'Wait, they are going to come over to our side'."

The mayor insists that although it was his protesters who broke into Parliament they were not responsible for the fire started in the building.

As they forced their way into the building, he says he introduced some of them to the opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic. "I told him, 'You should thank these guys'," he said. He did not tell the opposition of his plan to storm Parliament, but said he did co-ordinate with the Otpor student resistance movement and fans of Belgrade's Red Star football team.

Mr Ilijc has long been a die-hard opposition figure. He fled Cacak to hide in mountains for 43 days during last year's Nato bombardment after he was accused of betraying his country by the Milosevic regime. When he returned he was greeted as a hero.

"We got sick of the way the opposition was going," he said. "It was useless. We'd march, criticise Milosevic and then everybody went home and he was still there. We decided, 'We are men, let's do it"."

He was unsure at first whether he could trust his police contacts. "The test was the miners' strike," he said. On Tuesday night, police tried to break an anti-Milosevic miners' strike at Kolubara. "My police contacts called me and said that they had been ordered to attack the miners," Mr Ilijc said. "They told me to get more people over there." The police attack failed.

He insists now is not the time for complacency. "Milosevic is still very dangerous," he said."It is sickening to see these politicians already squabbling over who will be Prime Minister and ministers. We didn't do it to become ministers and I warn them, if they don't get things right we will march on them as well."


LOAD-DATE: October 9, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Two Serb men in the suburbs of Belgrade celebrate, behind a grilled ox, Vojislav Kostunica's election win Predrag Milic/Reuters; The storming of the Yugoslav Parliament last week


Copyright 2000 Independent Print Ltd


261 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


September 27, 2000, Wednesday


Is this the man to topple Milosevic?


BYLINE: Eve Ann Prentice


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 1443 words


 

Serbia's opposition leader is a lawyer committed to peaceful resistance. Eve Ann Prentice reports

Vojislav Kostunica cuts an unlikely figure as hero and prospective saviour of Yugoslavia. While despairing Serbs and Western leaders looked the other way in search of a Balkan braveheart to rise up and cut the chains that have kept Slobodan Milosevic in power for the past decade, the quietly spoken rival for the presidency slipped under the ropes and, possibly, felled him at the ballot box.

Voting in Yugoslavia's presidential election could well run to a second round on October 8, but Milosevic looks mortally wounded after Sunday's vote. Even if he manages to hang on to power a little longer, his authority seems fatally undermined by Kostunica's strong showing. 

Soon after the end of the Nato bombing campaign last year, many war and sanctions-weary Serbs looked high and low for someone to lead them against the regime. The political options were bleak: the maverick fence-sitter Vuk Draskovic and his Serbian Renewal Movement on one hand, and the Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic on the other. Djindjic's error was to leave Belgrade at the height of the bombing - seen as an act of cowardice by ordinary Serbs who had no choice but to stay put.

To make matters worse, Djindjic and Draskovic proved repeatedly that they could not put personal differences aside and present a united opposition.

A series of opposition rallies around Serbia in the weeks that followed the Alliance campaign were little more than Sunday outings for the curious and a chance for the two opposition groups to squabble. The only exceptions came when protests were organised by two independent rebels: Ivan Novkovic, a renegade television weatherman in the southern town of Leskovac, and Bogoljub "Maki" Arsenijevic, an artist from the central town of Valjevo. However, while these two would-be revolutionaries galvanised people in their home towns, they were never serious contenders for the post of President.

During this time, Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history. It came when Milosevic decided to call early elections and Kostunica was chosen to head a multi-party democratic opposition. Whereas the West had been less than accurate in reading the Balkan mentality, Kostunica had read the runes well. He knew that many Serbs had become wary of firebrand politics and paramilitary adventurism. His message has been an almost Gandhi-esque appeal to peaceful resistance.

So who is the man who seems within inches of achieving what would have looked impossible even three months ago - levering Milosevic from power? And will he meet the West's expectations?

Vojislav Kostunica, a married man with no children, was nominated as the candidate of 18 parties and one trade union which form the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS). Born in Belgrade in 1944 to an old Belgrade family, he graduated from the Belgrade School of Law in 1966 and went on to obtain a master's degree in 1970 and doctorate in 1974.

In 1970 he was appointed assistant lecturer at the Belgrade School of Law, but expelled in 1974, during a political purge of Belgrade University, because of his opposition to communism.

From 1974 until 1981, he worked at the Institute of Social Sciences. He moved on to become director of the Institute for Philosophy and Social Theory. Until recently, his main claim to fame was as a bookish academic and author of papers on constitutional law, political theory and political philosophy. Kostunica has also worked as editor-in-chief of several specialised journals dedicated to law and philosophy, such as the Archive for Legal and Social Sciences, Philosophical Studies, Philosophy and Society and Theoria.

During the Eighties, while Milosevic was climbing the greasy pole to supreme power, Kostunica turned his legal skills to human rights and was especially active in the Board for the Freedom of Thought and Speech, where he was highly regarded. It was around this time that he became involved in politics, becoming a founder of the Democratic Party in 1989. He has been president of the separate Democratic Party of Serbia since it was founded in 1992 and was a member of the Serbian Parliament from 1990 until 1997 - when his party boycotted the elections due to the "lack of regular electoral conditions".

Western leaders, however, have been nonplussed. Although senior European Union, American and even Russian politicians have been swift to call on Milosevic to give way immediately and hand power to Kostunica, the lawyer has not always been flavour of the month, especially in Washington.

Kostunica has consistently proclaimed that he would not hand Milosevic over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and he was a vigorous critic of the Nato bombardment. This has been seized on by some as proof that he is no different from other war-zealous Balkan leaders. Kostunica has been described in some US state department background briefings as an old-fashioned Serb nationalist, a sort of "Seselj in coat-tails" - a reference to Milosevic's erstwhile ally, Vojislav Seselj, the ultra-nationalist leader of the Serbian Radical Party.

This is where East and West divide. Opponents of the Milosevic regime see nothing wrong in criticising the Alliance campaign - for the bombing affected nearly everyone. While they may be anti-Milosevic, they believe their political destiny should be decided from within.

"Kostunica is a good patriot. He is educated, a peaceful man and no threat to anyone," says Srdjan Stojanovic, an independent Serbian journalist who lives in London. "He is a calm, even boring speaker, but he insists on following legal procedures. That is what our country needs." Nikola Barovic, a noted Serbian human rights lawyer, agrees. "He is a very good lawyer and has a high regard for fair play. Because he is very strict and correct, I think he will do all he can to help keep things peaceful," he says.

And an expatriate Serb points out: "He is a politician of impeccable democratic credentials, keen intelligence and high personal integrity. He has not compromised himself either by making deals with Milosevic, unlike Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, or by being too subservient to the West like, say, Zoran Djindjic. His consistency and perseverance has finally paid off."

And what does Kostunica say? His actions and words in the next few days and weeks will be crucial. So far, he has tried to maintain calm on all sides.

"One encouraging thing is the conduct of the army and police, which was very appropriate - standing between two political options, and not between the so-called patriots and traitors," he said on Monday.

He then promised that, as soon he officially became president, he would start parliamentary talks on the relations between Serbia and Montenegro. Links between the two republics that make up Yugoslavia have been strained to near breaking point since the Nato bombardment when Montenegro intensified attempts to break loose of the federation. Many Serbs now fear civil war.

Asked how his alliance would react if final voting figures show that he has won but Milosevic fails to recognise the result, Kostunica said that he would defend his victory using all available democratic means.

"Protests and demonstrations are democratic methods of fighting for your rights. We will defend the will of the people in such a way as not to endanger the peace in the country, nor to challenge any reaction of the international community," he says.

But, as for handing Milosevic over to the Hague Tribunal, he is quick to point out that compulsory co-operation with this "so-called" court is not mentioned in Yugoslavia's constitution. "I think that the Hague Tribunal is not a legal, but a political instrument, and not one of the international community, but exclusively of the USA." he says.

"As for Slobodan Milosevic's safety during my presidency, it is regulated by our constitution. The part in which it is said that representatives of our country must take care of their citizens' safety, also refers to the safety of the former FRY President."

The would-be President also makes it clear that Yugoslavia must not become "anybody's protectorate" - seen by many as an allusion to the current status of Kosovo. People in Yugoslavia want to live in a state "that is not a vassal", he adds.

But the final word rests with the people of Serbia. "Please God, this time there is hope," says the wife of one human rights lawyer in Belgrade. "But then I turn my head and look back at the past ten years...."


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Times Newspapers Limited


262 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


September 24, 2000 Sunday Final Edition


Yugoslavia seethes with uncertainty: Seven million Serbs vote on Slobodan Milosevic's future


SOURCE: Southam Newspapers; Southam News


SECTION: Top Copy; Pg. A2


LENGTH: 517 words


DATELINE: Belgrade


Serbs go to the polls today to choose a president and a new parliament but the tension palpable on the streets of the Yugoslav capital in the hours leading up to the vote has revealed the nation's uncertainty about the election and future.

Yugoslavs appear to be wrestling with the question: "Are we about to elect a president, or descend into violence and war?"

"I'm scared a little bit," admitted Vukasin Petrovic, an activist with the Otpor (Resistance) movement, "because I can't predict what will happen in the next days. " 

Analysts and voters both say the elections are the most crucial Yugoslavia has faced in more than a decade.

About seven million Serb voters will pass judgment on the tumultuous 13-year regime of President Slobodan Milosevic, a Communist leader who won power in 1987 and rode successfully into the post-Communist era on a wave of nationalism and war.

Public opinion suggests Milosevic will lose the election to Vojislav Kostunica, a previously obscure academic who leads in the polls by six to 20 percentage points.

Kostunica, leader of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia alliance, is favoured to win in a fair fight. But the tension galvanizing Yugoslavia hinges on the widespread fear the Milosevic government will attempt to steal the election and defend the theft with the might of the Yugoslav Army and the federation's paramilitary police force.

Since opposition supporters are expected to take to the streets en masse if the government rigs the vote, many Serbs fear the election will end in tears.

"There will be blood," said Aleks Milutinovic, 33, a Belgrade journalist. "That's my prediction. The government will steal the election, the opposition will protest, and the police will crack down hard. Milosevic has shown a willingness to unleash his attack dogs at the first sign of protest."

But anything can happen. Here are some possibilities:

- Milosevic will win by stealing votes in Montenegro and Kosovo, declare victory, and use the armed forces to back him up. The likely result: protests and violence across Yugoslavia.

- Milosevic will lose, concede defeat, but invoke the nation's old constitution and remain in office until next summer. The likely result: protests by the outraged opposition. But if Milosevic is successful he will buy time to regroup and fortify his position.

- None of the four presidential candidates will win an outright majority, forcing a second round in October or November. Result: Milosevic gains time to plan a comeback. But opposition candidates could back Kostunica in a second round, burying Milosevic in an opposition landslide.

- Milosevic will lose the presidential elections, concede defeat, but steal local elections and retain power by controlling the parliament and cities.

Tensions in anti-Milosevic Montenegro have created fears there will be a post-election conflict in this independence-minded

Yugoslav republic.

Today, Serbs are grappling with all these sad scenarios.

"Everything depends on Milosevic," said Otpor's Petrovic, "and the state of his conscience and mind."


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: AP; Serbs carry ballot boxes and ballot papers into an electoral centre set up in a private home in the central Kosovo village of Lipljan on Saturday.


TYPE: News

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

The Ottawa Citizen


September 27, 2000, Wednesday, FINAL


Hope rests with unlikely hero: Considered a bookish academic until recently, Vojislav Kostunica has waited patiently for his moment in history. Eve Ann Prentice reports.


BYLINE: Eve Ann Prentice


SECTION: News; A9


LENGTH: 1326 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


BELGRADE - Vojislav Kostunica cuts an unlikely figure as hero and prospective saviour of Yugoslavia. While despairing Serbs and western leaders looked the other way in search of a Balkan braveheart to rise up and cut the chains that have kept Slobodan Milosevic in power for the past decade, the quiet-spoken rival for the presidency slipped under the ropes and, possibly, felled him at the ballot box.

Voting in Yugoslavia's presidential election now apparently will go to a second round on Oct. 8, but Mr. Milosevic looks mortally wounded. Even if he can hang on to power a little longer, his authority seems fatally undermined by Mr. Kostunica's strong showing.

Soon after the end of the NATO bombing campaign last year, many war and sanctions- weary Serbs looked high and low for someone to lead them against the regime. The political options were bleak: the maverick fence-sitter Vuk Draskovic and his Serbian Renewal Movement on one hand, and the Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic on the other. Mr. Djindjic's error was to leave Belgrade at the height of the bombing -- seen as an act of cowardice by Serbs who had no choice but to stay. 

To make matters worse, Mr. Djindjic and Mr. Draskovic proved repeatedly that they could not put personal differences aside and present a united opposition.

A series of opposition rallies around Serbia in the weeks that followed the Alliance campaign were little more than Sunday outings for the curious, and a chance for the two opposition groups to squabble.

Mr. Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history. It came when Mr. Milosevic decided to call early elections and Mr. Kostunica was chosen to head a multi-party democratic opposition. Whereas the West had been less than accurate in reading the Balkan mentality, Mr. Kostunica had read the runes well. He knew that many Serbs had become wary of firebrand politics and paramilitary adventurism. His message has been an almost Gandhi-esque appeal to peaceful resistance.

So who is the man who seems within inches of achieving what would have looked impossible even three months ago -- levering Mr. Milosevic from power? And will he meet the West's expectations?

Vojislav Kostunica, married with no children, was nominated as the candidate of 18 parties and one trade union that form the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS). Born in Belgrade in 1944 to an old Belgrade family, he graduated from the Belgrade School of Law in 1966 and obtained a master's degree in 1970 and a doctorate in 1974.

In 1970 he was appointed assistant lecturer at the Belgrade School of Law, but expelled in 1974, during a political purge of Belgrade University, because of his opposition to communism.

From 1974 until 1981, he worked at the Institute of Social Sciences. He moved on to become director of the Institute for Philosophy and Social Theory. Until recently, his main claim to fame was as a bookish academic and author of papers on constitutional law, political theory and political philosophy. Mr. Kostunica has also worked as editor-in-chief of several specialized journals dedicated to law and philosophy, such as the Archive for Legal and Social Sciences, Philosophical Studies, Philosophy and Society and Theoria.

During the 1980s, while Mr. Milosevic was climbing the greasy pole to supreme power, Mr. Kostunica turned his legal skills to human rights and was active in the Board for the Freedom of Thought and Speech. About this time, he became involved in politics -- he was a founder of the Democratic Party in 1989. He has been president of the separate Democratic Party of Serbia since it was founded in 1992, and was a member of the Serbian Parliament from 1990 until 1997 when his party boycotted the elections due to the ''lack of regular electoral conditions.''

Western leaders, however, have been nonplussed. Although senior European Union, American and even Russian politicians have been swift to call on Mr. Milosevic to hand power to Mr. Kostunica, the lawyer has not always been flavour of the month, especially in Washington.

He has consistently proclaimed that he would not hand Mr. Milosevic over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and he was a vigorous critic of the NATO bombardment. This has been seized on by some as proof that he is no different from other war-zealous Balkan leaders. Mr. Kostunica has been described in some U.S. State Department briefings as an old-fashioned Serb nationalist, a sort of ''Seselj in coattails,'' a reference to Mr. Milosevic's erstwhile ally, Vojislav Seselj, the ultra- nationalist leader of the Serbian Radical Party.

This is where East and West divide. Opponents of the Milosevic regime see nothing wrong in criticizing the Alliance campaign, for the bombing affected nearly everyone. While they may be anti-Milosevic, they believe their political destiny should be decided from within.

''Kostunica is a good patriot. He is educated, a peaceful man and no threat to anyone,'' says Srdjan Stojanovic, an independent Serbian journalist who lives in London. ''He is a calm, even boring speaker, but he insists on following legal procedures. That is what our country needs.''

Nikola Barovic, a noted Serbian human rights lawyer, says ''He is a very good lawyer and has a high regard for fair play. Because he is very strict and correct, I think he will do all he can to help keep things peaceful.''

An expatriate Serb calls him ''a politician of impeccable democratic credentials, keen intelligence and high personal integrity. He has not compromised himself either by making deals with Milosevic, unlike Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, or by being too subservient to the West like, say, Zoran Djindjic. His consistency and perseverance has finally paid off.''

So far, Mr. Kostunica has tried to maintain calm on all sides.

''One encouraging thing is the conduct of the army and police, which was very appropriate standing between two political options, and not between the so-called patriots and traitors,'' he said.

He then promised that, as soon as he officially becomes president, he will start parliamentary talks on the relations between Serbia and Montenegro. Links between the two republics that make up Yugoslavia have been strained to near breaking point since the NATO bombardment when Montenegro intensified attempts to break loose of the federation. Many Serbs now fear civil war.

Asked how his alliance would react if final voting figures show that he has won but Mr. Milosevic fails to recognize the result, Mr. Kostunica said he would defend his victory using all available democratic means.

''Protests and demonstrations are democratic methods of fighting for your rights. We will defend the will of the people in such a way as not to endanger the peace in the country, nor to challenge any reaction of the international community, '' he says.

But, as for handing Mr. Milosevic over to the Hague tribunal, he is quick to point out that compulsory co-operation with this ''so-called'' court is not mentioned in the constitution. ''I think that the Hague tribunal is not a legal, but a political instrument, and not one of the international community, but exclusively of the U.S.A.,'' he says.

''As for Slobodan Milosevic's safety during my presidency, it is regulated by our constitution. The part in which it is said that representatives of our country must take care of their citizens' safety, also refers to the safety of the former ... president.''

The would-be president also makes it clear that Yugoslavia must not become ''anybody's protectorate,'' seen by many as an allusion to the current status of Kosovo. People in Yugoslavia want to live in a state ''that is not a vassal.''

But the final word rests with the people of Serbia. ''Please God, this time there is hope,'' says the wife of one human rights lawyer in Belgrade. ''But then I turn my head and look back at the past 10 years.''


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: P Black & White Photo: Sasa Stankovic, Agence-France Presse / Vojislav Kostunica is considered by many to be a strong democrat as well as a nationalist. It seems unlikely that as president, he would hand over Slobodan Milosevic to the war crimes tribunal at The Hague, but rather would turn to the Yugoslav constitution to determine how the country's former strongman should be treated.

All Rights Reserved


264 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


April 8, 1999


Serbs waiting for their shot at Nato;
War to come: Defences biding their time, write Maggie O'Kane and Chris Bird from Belgrade


BYLINE: MAGGIE O'KANE AND CHRIS BIRD


SECTION: Guardian Home Pages; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 698 words


NATO'S hi-tech air war is unlikely to be enough to budge Yugoslavia's decidedly low-tech but well-trained armed forces from Kosovo.

The first two weeks of air strikes have been visually impressive: the sagging wrecks of the interior ministry buildings in Belgrade hit at the weekend were stark evidence that Nato means business. But while the hits are terrifying for the Serb people, the Yugoslav military machine that Nato aims to 'degrade' could sit out the air strikes for months.

Nato has yet to release hard evidence that it has seriously damaged Yugoslav air defences, especially its ageing Soviet-designed SAM-6 surface-to-air missiles, which are mobile and hard to track down. 'These are dangerous,' said Clifford Beale, editor of Jane's Defence Weekly. 'They can shoot and move.' He said Yugoslav air defence was far more integrated and concentrated than its Iraqi equivalent, and Serbian forces were adept at using apparently low-tech tricks to confound Nato's 'smart' weapons. 

One of these is the 'SAM-bush' luring in aircraft with a decoy radar and then locking in on it with a missile radar.

The Yugoslav army also has hundreds of shoulder-fired ground-to-air missiles and about 2,000 anti-aircraft guns which could give Nato's slower tank-busting jets and helicopters a hard time.

Ever since the first threat of Nato raids last October, the Yugoslav army and police units have been careful to move men, armour and material around. Ammunition has been brought out of store. Tanks and other weapons are parked in forests and draped with camouflage netting in fields and ravines to avoid detection by aircraft.

'Politically it's difficult for Milosevic right now as Nato is dropping everything on Serbia and Serbia doesn't appear to be really hitting back,' a political observer in Belgrade said. 'But the army is, as they say, waiting for Nato to come in 'low and slow'.'

A Serb military analyst who fought in the 1991-92 war with Croatia cast doubts on the effectiveness of the Nato air campaign. 'Other than long-term degradation of the army, this is not going to have a short-term impact certainly not in time to save the refugees. The Yugoslav army doesn't need barracks and sophisticated anti-aircraft defences to fight this war.'

'Serbian forces have cleansed most of the centres of the Kosovo Liberation Army's operational zones and have disrupted their core,' the political observer said. It would take months to train and equip a new force, however angry the ethnic Albanians expelled from the territory.

Western military officers with the international observer mission in Kosovo noticed, before their evacuation last month, extensive preparations of defences against a Nato attack from neighbouring Macedonia. They say that a strategic bridge and a tunnel have been mined by the Yugoslav army, ready to blow should Nato armour risk the narrow gorge of the Kacanik pass. The Shar mountains along the border would be territory relatively easy to defend, where tanks have only the most limited movement.

Western diplomats have made much of a reluctance of Serb men to obey the call -up. This was certainly the case before the air strikes. But much of sophisticated Belgraders' reluctance to fight has evapourated with the anger at Nato's attacks and with stiff new prison terms for draft-dodgers.

The length of the country, the more hardline Serbs of all ages can be seen in old reservist uniforms. All Serb men of fighting age in Kosovo are under arms and are highly motivated.

Mr Milosevic prepared for the showdown with Nato countries months in advance of air strikes when he purged the Serbian security forces of all senior dissenting voices. The purge continued last week with the sacking of the 2nd Army commander in Serbia's sister republic of Montenegro, where an anti -Milosevic government is trying to keep the territory out of the war. The new commander is a hardline Serb who commands more than 10,000 troops there.

As a result of the purges it is thought there is little chance of Serb army dissent. 'The army are fully behind Milosevic. They are in this trap together,' the political observer said.


LOAD-DATE: April 9, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 Guardian Newspapers Limited


265 of 348 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


December 7, 1996 Saturday  
Late Edition


Chill winds for Serbia's protesters


BYLINE: Christoher Henning


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; NEWS REVIEW; Pg. 32


LENGTH: 1566 words


For the past 17 days Belgrade's streets have been filled with anti-government demonstrators, but the forces ranged against them are gathering momentum - and all President Slobodan Milosovic has to do is bide his time. CHRISTOPHER HENNING reports.

HOW much power is there in an egg? Fifty or so grams of viscous liquid in a palm-size container, thrown by a protester a maximum of, say, 30 metres - what's the destructive force of that? It may annoy a riot policeman. It may break a window. Can it undermine a government? Serbia's opposition parties are hoping so, as they feel their way along the fine dividing line between protest and riot.

They have been protesting for 17 consecutive days against President Slobodan Milosevic for annulling elections that they had won. Protesting, note, not rioting. They make sure they throw nothing harder than eggs, so that if the police come and the riot sticks and tear gas come out, they can say they did not provoke the clampdown.

Eggs are one of their two weapons; outrage is the other. The two represent motivation plus restraint, the symbols of those holding the moral high ground. 

Against a lesser opponent those weapons might prevail. In Prague in 1989 an entrenched communist regime collapsed before crowds whose tactic was to stand in the snow in vast numbers holding lighted candles. But Milosevic is an opponent very different from the jaded apparatchiki of Communism in decline.

He is self-made. He created his own power base, and he stands on it still. He is not timid in the use of power: he has, by proxy, expanded Serb-controlled territory at the expense of his neighbours. He is dexterous: he has eluded all except the last attempt of Western Europe to thwart his ambitions. He took a backward step only when NATO (that is to say, the United States) became involved, and even it dealt with him as an equal and ceded him much of what he wanted. And he has no time for doubters: he has crushed dissent at home before, in 1991, with an iron fist.

Eggs aren't going to scare him.

SLOBODAN Milosevic is on the horns of a familiar dilemma. He must have Western investment to boost an economy run down after years of war, but he can't afford to allow in Western notions of human rights and democracy that may jeopardise his hold on power.

Milosevic came to power promising to restore pride to Serbs, and to create a single Serb State. His extreme nationalist policies were one of the central reasons Yugoslavia broke up as it did.

After four years of war, he may have gone some way to satisfying his countrymen's dreams of national aggrandisement - though that is debatable - but he has not made them prosper. When he came to power income per head was about $US2,000. These days it is about $US1,000. In places, unemployment reaches 50 per cent.

One of the final turning points in the Bosnian war was the Croatian offensive in Krajina, which took back Serb-held territory in north-western Bosnia and Croatia, and made refugees of about half a million Serbs who had lived in Croatia for centuries.

Serbia is now struggling with a gigantic resettlement task while its economy labours under Western sanctions and its own selfimposed limitations.

Democracy, in the form of elections, was the cause of his present troubles. On November 3, Serbians and Montenegrins went to the polls in elections for the lower house of the Yugoslav Federal Parliament. (Serbia and Montenegro are all that is left of the former Yugoslavia after it disintegrated in 1990.) Montenegrins also voted for a provincial assembly, and Serbians for local councils.

Milosevic had done his best to ensure a favourable result. He has complete control of Yugoslavian television, so there was no question of the opposition getting much of a run. But he had also changed the law before the poll to make it hard for small parties to win. Four parties promptly stymied that move by uniting to form Zajedno (Together).

And they had some wins. In the Federal Parliament they won just 22 seats out of 138, but at the local level they won Belgrade and 12 of the other 18 largest cities in Serbia. Those local election results were promptly overturned, and Zajedno called its supporters onto the streets. They have been there ever since.

The Yugoslavian Foreign Minister, Milan Milutinovic, in London for the Bosnian peace implementation conference, has played down reports of the demonstrations. "You said 100,000 people (were on the streets of Belgrade). That is not true. It is 10 times less," he said. "And in comparison with 2 million people in Belgrade, if you have 10 or 15 or 50,000 demonstrators on the streets, that does not mean that we have a mounting of the dangers."

Milutinovic may believe that; it is unlikely that as canny a politician as Milosevic does.

But why did he overturn the results in the first place? The opposition victories threaten to disturb the calm of Yugoslavia's centrally run economy, and the widespread networks of patronage by which it operates.

Yugoslavia is run by a left-wing post-communist coalition. The main party is Milosevic's Serbian Socialist Party (SPS), but a junior partner is the United Yugoslav Left (JUL) founded by his wife Mirjana, better known as Mira. The latter has little popular support, but its adherents wield increasing power within the bureaucracy.

Mihailo Markovic, a former senior SPS member, explained the strategic importance of the JUL: "They have seized control of the trade departments, so it means they have the final say in who gets import and export licences. Those are the key in such a closed economy."

Milosevic has much against him, not least the international community, but he has many things on his side - the police, which he has built up substantially, the media, which he rigidly controls, and to a lesser extent the army, although that has been

run down lately.

There are two other important factors. The first is the opposition itself. Zajedno is a coalition of very different interests. Zoran Djindjic, the long-haired, bearded leader of the Democratic Party who has been leading the street protests, would have been Belgrade's first non-communist mayor since World War II if the results had not been annulled.

Vuk Draskovic, the other leader, is head of the Serbian Renewal Movement. As its name suggests, this is a party of Serbian nationalism, and his rhetoric in the past has been every bit as extreme as that of his adversary, Milosevic. That doesn't mean they are allies by any means. Draskovic was arrested and jailed in the big protest movement against Milosevic in 1991.

The two haven't quarrelled yet, but without continuing success it is hard to see two such strong personalities maintaining their solidarity.

The other ally Milosevic has is the weather. General Winter has defeated two armies in Russia, and he may yet do the same to the enemies of Slobodan Milosevic. All it will take is time - something Milosevic has plenty of.

After all, he can't really afford to do anything against the demonstrators. He cannot afford to crack down on the opposition as he has in the past, for fear of outraging Western opinion. Although many sanctions against Serbia were lifted at the time of the Dayton agreement last year, some remain, and they are important. Serbia still has no access to the International Monetary Fund, and has been suspended from the Organisation of Security and Co-operation in Europe.

If Milosevic fell, who would replace him? According to Dr Spiros Economides of the London School of Economics, instability would be the result.

"The opposition party Zajedno, which is at the vanguard of the popular uprising, is not a very solid party. It's split between the various personalities," Economides said. "If Milosevic were to fall, some of the people who may replace him are no less nationalist than he is. Who would the West be dealing with?

"Peace in Bosnia is the main reason why the West has kept quiet about what is going on in Belgrade. They know he is feared enough by the Croats and Muslims for the peace to be kept."

BEFORE the election, Zajedno was accusing the West of propping up Milosevic. It claimed Western diplomats made high-profile visits to factories, which were broadcast in a way that presented the West as backing the Serbian regime. US diplomats denied any attempt to influence the outcome, and said they were neutral.

As the winter weather worsens and as Milosevic continues to let the protesters freeze, if they choose, in support of a principle, Zajedno is now looking to the West to help it bring Milosevic down.

If the US was ever prepared to prop up Milosevic in the interest of post-Dayton harmony, that appears no longer to be the case.

Washington has responded to Serbia's ban on an independent radio station, B92, by announcing it will use Voice of America to broadcast into Serbia itself. But these are not the good old days of the Cold War, when Radio Free Europe brought the message of freedom to the oppressed masses behind the Iron Curtain. Milosevic is a nationalist, and the Serbs, though they may be getting sick of Milosevic himself, are fiercely nationalistic.

The US, which has pretended to be even-handed in the Bosnian conflict while backing all the other sides against the Serbs, is a prime object for such paranoia. Milosevic won't be displeased that he will now have a large, loud bogeyman to point to as a scapegoat for problems that he has done the most to create.


LOAD-DATE: July 23, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: THREE ILLUS: Shell shock ... carrying nothing more deadly than candles and eggs, anti-Milosevic protesters march through the centre of Belgrade. Photographs by REUTERS Slobodan Milosevic ... iron fist.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Daily News (Sri Lanka)


March 11, 2013 Monday


HRW workers do make love to this employment


LENGTH: 2722 words


DATELINE: Sri Lanka


Sri Lanka, March 11 -- A close look at the barrage of Human Rights Watch (HRW) and the International Crisis Group (ICG) produced anti-Sri Lanka propaganda aimed at reinforcing the message of the British Channel 4 video falsehoods at the 22nd session of the UNHRC reveals much about the people and the techniques used in the global administration of the neocon generated 'pretend' human rights regime.

The HRW provided bogus information-based reports histrionically titled 'Human Rights Failings Detailed' and 'Rape of Tamil Detainees', and wrote letters to UNHRC member countries demanding an inquiry. They also wrote to the Commonwealth heads of governments demanding that the November 2013 CHOGM Meeting be moved from Sri Lanka.

Such coordinated moves are built on the same principles their multi-national corporations employ to 'alter perception' on consumer products that are proven to be harmful to human health as 'cool' life style choices. 

In this particular case, de-contextualised and distorted pictorial images of war and stories of abuse are presented in an arrogant, conspiratorial tone to psychologically influence the UNHRC member countries. The underlying objective is to keep Sri Lanka on the UNHRC agenda as a counterweight against the imminent Palestinian war crimes charges against Israel.

The extremely close tribal connections emanating from the common, let us say Phoenician, background of the people involved in the HRW fraud, with a sprinkling of other naive and cynically dollar seeking people, help read and understand their behaviour and activities.

The career history of almost every member of the HRW cabal shows a degree from a university such as Harvard, Georgetown or Johns Hopkins, previous UN involvement commonly in post - Pol Pot Cambodia and other countries of interest to them such as Indonesia, and remarkably long term occupancy of positions, often exceeding a decade, by those who hold management positions.

The members of the cabal keep on drifting between the US bureaucracy, UN agencies and the INGO circuit, donning human rights cloaks over their blood-stained suits.

The purpose here is to highlight the corrupt founding of the HRW and the tribal and incestuous relationships among the pompous and arrogant cabal that go on preaching to the world. Such information helps gain an understanding of the sinister coalescence between the neocon generated US foreign policy and the UNHRC operations following its recasting in 2006 to better suit the US agenda.

HRW is birth marked 'fraud'

HRW was founded in New York as Helsinki Watch in 1978 by Robert Bernstein, the owner of "Random House" publishers, as a Cold War instrument against the Soviet Union and the socialist bloc countries of Eastern Europe. From the very beginning, the charter of HRW has been to undermine nations by providing a web of "support" for pro-capitalist forces and political dissidents globally.

Billionaire George Soros soon took over HRW and linked it with his own personal subversive NGO, Open Society Institute(OSI) by appointing Helsinki Watch head Aryeh Neier, to head the OSI - From 1979, Soros distributed $3m annually to dissidents in the Soviet bloc countries including Poland's Solidarity movement, Charter 77 in Czechoslovakia and Andrei Sakharov in Russia. In 1984, he founded his first OSI branch in Hungary and pumped millions of dollars into opposition movements and media.

Ostensibly aimed at building up a "civil society", these initiatives were designed to weaken the existing political structures and pave the way for Eastern Europe's eventual colonisation by the neocon owned global capital. Soros now openly claims that he was responsible for the "Americanisation" of Eastern Europe.

Today, HRW has an annual budget of around $50 million and employs almost 300 operatives in 90 countries. They claim to publish around 100 reports and several hundred news releases each year.

In September 2010 HRW received a further 10-year, $100 million capital injection from Soros, with orders to increase its global presence by opening up advocacy offices in key regional capitals around the world with a view "to shape the foreign policies of the emerging powers". The structure they are going to adopt is the Transparency International's business model of employing more "researchers and advocates", to engage with government officials, journalists, and civil society - a model that defines "conspiracy" in the modern context.

HRW is a key instrument in implementing neocon global agenda

Hiding behind a facade of monitoring human rights "abuses" worldwide HRW works to reinforce the neocon global agenda and to justify US "humanitarian interventions" through pre-invasion propaganda aimed at demonising the respective national leaders and their administrations. Most recently they did this in Libya, and is currently at work against Syria.

The HRW board currently includes Morton Abramowitz, a founder neocon and Assistant Secretary of State for intelligence and research in the Ronald Reagan era, and a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations - Warren Zimmerman, US ambassador in Yugoslavia during the break-up, and Paul Goble, director of communications at the CIA-created, Soros-funded Radio Free Europe.

Other "independent" luminaries include warmongers like Zbigniew Brzezinski, Richard Allen, General Wesley Clark, and former congressman Stephen Solarz, described as "the Israel lobby's chief legislative tactician on Capitol Hill".

HRW carries out the functions of informational and propagandist support for USA and NATO projects to interfere in the internal affairs of foreign countries.

A book titled Human Rights Watch in Service to the War Party, (Edward S. Herman, David Peterson and George Szamuely, 2007), after examining HRW's role in supporting the breakup of Yugoslavia, concludes that - "HRW has... been an important contributor to human rights violations in the former Yugoslavia. HRW helped stir up passions in the demonization process from 1992 onward and actively and proudly contributed to preparing the ground for NATO's 'supreme international crime' in March 1999."

The Yugoslav people's stubborn resistance to US meddling expressed through their repeated election of Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist Party to government was broken through Soros' Open Society Institute funding, more than $100m between 1991-1999, to the coffers of the anti-Milosevic opposition, political parties, printing presses and "independent" media such as Radio B92.

Milosevic was finally toppled in 2000 in a coup d'etat financed and planned in Washington. He was carted before the Hague tribunal to face charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide, based on the largely uncorroborated anecdotal evidence of HRW. He was poisoned in jail before the case came to an end.

Soros claims that his financing of dissent in poorer countries is purely altruistic - asked about the havoc his currency speculation caused to Asian economies in the crash of 1997, Soros replied - "As a market participant, I don't need to be concerned with the consequences of my actions. It was only the courageous actions of leaders like Dr Mahathir Mohamed of Malaysia who blocked Soros 'pulling out' his speculative capital averted the crisis in some countries.

The fraudulent partisan behaviour of HRW becomes obvious through their silence on issues like the findings of the report, just a month ago, on the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child that it is "alarmed at reports of the death of hundreds of children as a result of attacks and air strikes by the US military forces in Afghanistan."

HRW's clear agenda of sanitising Israeli war crimes like the 2002 Jenin refugee camp massacre in the West Bank came to light with its attempt to tell the world that "no massacre had taken place in Jenin". The HRW was alone, and was against a mountain of evidence that suggested otherwise. Based on the HRW revision, the Bush administration demanded that the Palestinians condemned violence while calling Ariel Sharon 'a man of peace' and expressing sympathy for Israeli 'self-defense' measures.

In January this year, HRW sacked from its board the only honourable and genuine human rights campaigner they ever had, Richard Falk - he was told that his work with the UN on behalf of the Palestinians was "contrary to HRW policy". He was often critical of Israel.

The letter on Sri Lanka proves the links

The HRW letter to UNHRC council members demanded that they authorise an independent, international investigation into 'war crimes' committed during the final months of Sri Lanka's armed conflict.

The letter is another demonstration of the naked attempts to impose their own Phoenician cultural values and neocon economic model as the only path to human freedom and rights universally.

It is ironic that despite ample evidence pointing to the barbaric nature of their militaristic culture, they try to assume moral authority and credibility over the countries they target.

The letter was signed by Brad Adams, Asia Director of HRW and a woman named Julie de Rivero who holds the fancy designation, Geneva Advocacy Director. The careers and backgrounds of Brad Adams, who has occupied the position of 'Asia Director' since 2002, and Julie de Rivero of this shadowy cabal portrays the seamless manner in which the conspiracies between UN agencies and INGOs such as HRW merge.

Prior to joining the HRW in 2002, Adams, obviously an American of Phoenician extraction has worked for five years in Cambodia as a lawyer attached to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights(OHCHR), conducting human rights investigations, and drafting and revising legislation for judicial 'reform' of that country.

De Rivero, a dual Peruvian and British national, has 'coincidentally' worked with the OHCHR, also in Cambodia as the head of its 'protection team'. Prior to that, since 1996, she has worked at numerous UN positions including as an assistant to the UN special rapporteurs on the human rights of migrants, and on freedom of expression. She has then joined the NGO International Service for Human Rights to campaign for the creation of a 'protection mechanism' for human rights defenders. Now De Rivero works exclusively, based in Geneva, on 'advocacy' with the OHCHR on the work of the UNHRC. What this advocacy work means in Western jargon is 'having a chat over a Latte' at a trendy coffee shop with the career minded human rights worker currently handling the 'case' at the OHCHR, having an eye on the HRW or another such INGO as a possible employer at the end of 'her'(usually) UN contract.

A national government or their Geneva representation has not got the chance of 'a snowball in hell' in countering such 'advocacy'.

Charu Lata wants to teach us a lesson too

What is often not highlighted is that the arrogantly named HRW report "We Will Teach You A Lesson", though released under the HRW banner, has been the work, under contract, of an Indian and British dual national Charu Lata Hogg.

Charu currently works as an Associate Fellow, Asia Programme at Chatham House, the counterpart of the neocon cabal Council on Foreign Affairs in Britain. The report has been 'edited' by Phelim Kine, Deputy Asia Director at HRW. Phelim Kine is a Canadian, a China researcher in HRW's Asia Division. A former news wire bureau chief in Jakarta, he has worked as a 'journalist' for more than a decade in China, Indonesia, Cambodia, and Taiwan prior to joining HRW in 2007.

Charu Lata Hogg is in fact a former staffer, a South Asia Researcher, of HRW (2007 - 2009) who holds an MSc from the London School of Economics. Between 1990 and 2002 she has worked as a journalist in India and Sri Lanka for a number of media organisations including the BBC. She also works as a South Asia Analyst for a number of businesses including Janes Defence, and is a consultant to International Alert.

Hogg has left HRW to become Asia Manager of another NGO, Child Soldiers International, (CSI) in London, a registered charity with an annual income of over £ 825,000! CSI serves as an 'information resource centre' for related NGOs, child advocacy organisations, and international legislative bodies - it is up the NGO food chain.

They claim to contribute research reports to the United Nations Security Council, the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, and to the European Union. The CSI is a reincarnation of another NGO founded jointly in 1998 by Amnesty International, HRW, International Save the Children Alliance, World Vision International and other regional non-governmental organisations from Latin America, Africa and Asia.

The CSI Board of Trustees of six independent experts is Chaired by Demelza Hauser, former Programme Director (1993-2002), Asia and Pacific Region, Amnesty International. Hauser is also a Cambodia 'specialist' with stints in East Timor, Indonesia, the Solomon Islands and Afghanistan.

It is very likely that Charu Lata Hogg was hired for this task due to the difficulty the HRW would have in gaining access to people in Jaffna. Charu Lata is familiar with Sri Lanka, having been based there for her 'journalistic' work, and she probably came in as a tourist and operated 'under cover' in the North and the East to compile her methodologically extremely poor report. Attempts to find out her fee were unsuccessful.

Other examples of cross breeding between HRW, INGOs, US government and the UN

The pattern that emerges is that almost without exception, these INGO frauds recruit well trained operatives who have previously lived and 'worked' in the developing world under NGO, UN or journalist cover - those who are effective are employed for decades to 'heavy' the world in to submission.

James Ross, Legal and Policy Director at HRW, where he has worked since 2001, previously worked for Medecins sans Frontieres in the Netherlands, in Bosnia for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, and in Cambodia for the NGO International Human Rights Law Group. He is a graduate of Harvard Law School.

Joseph Saunders, Deputy Programme Director at HRW for the past 14 years was a corporate lawyer at Cleary, Gottlieb, Stein and Hamilton in New York. He has worked on Indonesia for more than 25 years.

Carroll Bogert, Deputy Executive Director for External Relations since 1998 spent more than a decade in international news reporting for Newsweek Magazine, in China, as bureau chief in Moscow.

Jan Egeland, Deputy Executive Director and the Director of its European Operations was the Executive Director of the Norwegian Institute of International Affairs and UN Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator from 2003 to 2006.

Chuck Lustig, Deputy Executive Director of Operations previously worked at ABC News, ultimately serving as director of foreign news. He negotiated with the North Korean government to allow ABC reporters access to the country.

Michele Alexander, Deputy Executive Director for Development and Global Initiatives was previously vice president for corporate support of CARE. While at CARE, she also worked on contract for USAID in Pakistan.

Iain Levine, programme director has field experience with NGOs including more than 10 years in Sudan and Mozambique and as Amnesty International's representative at the UN, and as UNICEF's chief of humanitarian policy and advocacy.

Meenakshi Ganguly, South Asia Director since 2004, was previously the South Asia correspondent for Time Magazine.

Tom Malinowski, Washington Director claims to be an expert in United States foreign policy, was previously special assistant to President Bill Clinton and senior director for foreign policy speech writing at the National Security Council. He was also a speech writer for Secretaries of State Warren Christopher and Madelene Albright.

Heather Barr the Afghanistan researcher in the Asia division managed the Afghanistan anti-corruption and criminal justice programmes of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime and the justice and human rights portfolio of the Afghanistan office of the UN Development Programme before joining HRW.

And they expect us to believe that there is no conspiracy! Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily News Sri Lanka. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com
