The New York Times


August 7, 1997, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Serbia's Last Ally in the Yugoslav Breakup Is Restive


BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 733 words


DATELINE: PODGORICA, Montenegro


From the secluded medieval fort of St. Stefan on the Adriatic Sea to the mountainous ancient capital of Cetinje, Montenegro was once independent. Annexed by Serbia in 1918, it went on to become an aquatic playground for the rich and famous, attracting valuable foreign currency to Tito's Yugoslavia.

Montenegrins have now become restless under the autocratic thumb of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. Montenegro and Serbia are all that remains of that fractured country, and Montenegrins are talking of regaining their pre-World War I independence. 

They have dreams of making Montenegro an international tax haven, or of turning the coastal waters, shrouded by palm and olive trees, into a tourist mecca again, a boat ride from crowded Italy.

The Liberal Alliance, a party dedicated to making Montenegro a separate country, is gathering strength, with its trademark green graffiti evident in the smallest village.

As usual in the Balkans, the intrigue surrounding the future of Montenegro is many-layered. But one thing became clear recently: the desire for a better deal from Serbia was out in the open. On July 28, for the first time, visiting politicians from Mr. Milosevic's Government were greeted with hostility, their cars kicked by protesters and pelted with eggs as the Montenegrin police stood by and watched.

A number of factors contribute to the unease, chief among them anger at the cost of the Yugoslav war. The Montenegrins willingly collaborated with the Serbs, contributing troops and leaders, including Radovan Karadzic, the wartime Bosnian Serb leader, who was born in Montenegro's northern mountains. The majority of Montenegrins are Orthodox Christians like the Serbs.

Now the economy is comatose, the few factories dying, the main steel mill kept running with scrap metal trucked over back roads from neighboring Albania.

Because Montenegro is part of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, it comes under the same constraints from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as Serbia. The United States has insisted that until Mr. Milosevic agrees to cooperate with the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and to turn over those like Dr. Karadzic who have been indicted, Yugoslavia cannot borrow from international financial institutions.

Several months ago the Montenegrin Prime Minister, Milo Djukanovic, an economist who favors market reforms, tried to convince the World Bank that Montenegro deserved credits on its own, despite the ban.

But his envoy in Washington, Ratko Knezevic, complained of being kept in the lobbies of international organizations only to be told that Montenegrins might be nice people but they kept bad company.

Recently Mr. Djukanovic, who controls the uniformed and secret police here, began publicly criticizing Mr. Milosevic. And he turned against Mr. Milosevic's political ally, President Momir Bulatovic of Montenegro.

The Prime Minister managed to oust Mr. Bulatovic from Montenegro's governing Democratic Party of Socialists, leaving the humiliated President to hold political meetings with his followers in rundown coffee shops. [On Aug. 6 Mr. Bulatovic's supporters voted to reinstate him, signaling a split in the party.]

Mr. Djukanovic is a long way from declaring an independent Montenegro. But he is pressing for more nearly equal standing with Serbia, even though Montenegro has only 600,000 people to Serbia's 10 million and is far smaller in territory and wealth.

Mr. Djukanovic does have a strong bargaining point. The Montenegrin port of Bar on the Adriatic is Serbia's only access to the sea. Without this outlet Serbia's exports would have to pass through less-than-friendly neighboring countries. But Montenegrins say the situation has hardly reached that point, and the Serbs know how to play hardball. Still, the demonstration against Mr. Milosevic's lieutenant was the first time that an anti-Milosevic rally was sanctioned here.

If Montenegro is to gain greater status in relation to Serbia, it must improve its economy. One way might be to restore the grandeur of once glamorous coastal resorts. Fashionable guests -- Jacqueline and Aristotle Onassis, Sylvester Stallone -- are now faded memories at St. Stefan's fort. The visitors these days are of a different variety.

"Our own and the Russian mafia," said the tour guide at the fort's frescoed Orthodox church.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Map of Montenegro shwing location of Podgorica: In Podgorica, Montenegrins are rethinking their ties to Serbia.


Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company


281 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


April 29, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BELGRADE;
Milosevic Abruptly Fires A High-Profile Maverick


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 5; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 885 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 28


A Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister who had threatened street demonstrations against the Government over press freedom went quietly this evening after being fired by fax.

The minister, Vuk Draskovic, the outspoken and liberal window-dressing for President Slobodan Milosevic's Government, was informed of his dismissal by Prime Minister Momir Bulatovic just 30 minutes before it was announced on Serbian state television, officials said. 

Mr. Bulatovic, a close ally of Mr. Milosevic, said Mr. Draskovic, a writer who turned to politics in the late 1980's and has always been something of a maverick, had been dismissed "because of his public statements against Government positions, and for damaging the Government's prestige."

American and NATO officials had interpreted Mr. Draskovic's stand as a sign of dissent born of the air war. But Mr. Draskovic is not an insider and there are few signs that the ruling circle around Mr. Milosevic and his wife is cracking.

In a brief news conference this evening, Mr. Draskovic issued no direct challenge to Mr. Milosevic. He said he supported the united fight of the Serbian people against NATO and would continue to urge a negotiated settlement for Kosovo, adding, "I hope Milosevic wants the same things I want."

In recent days the garrulous Mr. Draskovic had called on the Government to "stop lying" about the war and to negotiate a peace that would be monitored by armed United Nations troops.

But more threatening than these suggestions, senior Yugoslav officials and analysts said, were his repeated criticisms of the political parties of Mr. Milosevic and his influential wife, Mirjana Markovic. Mr. Draskovic said the couple had taken advantage of the war to further their own political aims.

"He stepped over some line with Milosevic," a senior Serbian journalist said tonight. Senior Draskovic aides were upset by the dismissal, having urged him in recent days to tone down his criticism and limit his interviews. "He got carried away with everyone slapping him on the back," one aide said.

In statements tonight on Studio B, the television station his Serbian Renewal Movement controls, Mr. Draskovic was supportive and careful.

"Now that my country is a victim of aggression," he said, "I am one of the millions of Serbs who are soldiers of their fatherland. We sometimes disagree about the ways and means of defending ourselves, but we are united and uncompromising in the decision to defend our territorial integrity. There is no crack here and there will not be one."

Serbian state television also announced tonight an agreement between Ibrahim Rugova, an ethnic Albanian leader in Kosovo, and Milan Milutinovic, Serbia's president, to work on a political settlement for Kosovo, a province in Serbia.

Mr. Rugova actually addressed the camera in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, speaking in Serbian and emphasizing "an atmosphere of mutual confidence." Mr. Rugova, whom NATO regards effectively as a prisoner and unable to speak freely, looked relaxed as he said: "The most important thing is this mutual trust that we have built and the world will salute."

He said he had "successfully cooperated" with Serbian officials, including Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Milutinovic, "and we shall continue until we create organs and institutions in Kosovo for all nationalities."

Previously Mr. Rugova could be seen but not heard, with his views being summarized, accurately or not, by an announcer.

In a joint statement, he and Mr. Milutinovic agreed to form a new, temporary government for the province; resume talks immediately on giving Kosovo "wide self-rule" within Serbia and Yugoslavia, and invite some foreigners "as guests" to attend the talks.

Mr. Draskovic, a leader of anti-Milosevic protests in 1996 and 97, had joined the Government in January, saying both that he wanted to strengthen it during a time of crisis over Kosovo and that he wanted to change it from within.

On Monday evening, Mr. Draskovic said that a military censor had taken over Studio B, an assertion denied by the military and later by the station itself, and that he would lead street demonstrations if military control continued.

He also complained bitterly about spending cuts for Belgrade city, which his party governs, while the Serbian Government faced few cuts.

Mr. Draskovic had earned most attention from the West for a statements that he thought Mr. Milosevic would permit an armed United Nations force in Kosovo after hostilities ended.

Other officials say the same, although the Government position remains that only unarmed civilian observers from non-NATO countries will be allowed into Kosovo -- nowhere close to the allies' demand that an armed "international security force," with NATO troops as its core, go in to give ethnic Albanians the confidence to return home.

Three ministers from Mr. Draskovic's party resigned in protest this evening. They were the Information Minister, Milan Komnenic; the Domestic Trade Minister, Slobodan Nenadovic, and Milan Bozic, a minister without portfolio who is also Deputy Mayor of Belgrade.

While Mr. Komnenic helped foreign journalists come to Yugoslavia to cover the war, the resignations will have little effect on the real power structure, which is controlled by Mr. Milosevic and his wife.
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic after his dismissal yesterday. (Agence France Presse)
      


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company

The Guelph Mercury (Ontario, Canada)


June 30, 2012 Saturday  
First Edition


TV sleuth adopted as Serbian hero;
Object of wartime escapism became political weapon


BYLINE: Soraya Roberts, Soraya Roberts is a Toronto writ


SECTION: ARTS; Pg. C6


LENGTH: 1300 words


Rob Stewart was a famous actor for 16 years before he realized it. He was an unemployed writer/director $6,000 in debt when he started going on auditions in his late 20s, hoping to land a role that might fund his other projects. In 1990, he tried out for a new show called Sweating Bullets, what he calls "a B-version Magnum, P.I." about a Don Juan detective named Nick Slaughter who solves local crimes in the fictional Florida beach town of Key Mariah.

Stewart, who couldn't afford a haircut at the time and had a "lion mane of hair," showed up in a tank top and jeans and had what he calls a "very bad audition."

"I accidentally went out drinking the night before," Stewart, now 50, says on the phone from the Calgary set of Heartland, a Canadian drama about life on a horse ranch. 

His tryout was so bad that when producer Peter Locke and writer/creator Sam Egan watched his tape, they almost immediately began fast forwarding. Then Locke's wife walked by and Stewart caught her eye. "That's your guy," she said.

After landing the job, the first thing Stewart did was ask for an advance to get a haircut. Locke said no. Instead, he pulled his new star's hair back in a ponytail and dressed him in a permanently unbuttoned Hawaiian shirt to show off his chest hair. Nick Slaughter was born.

Though Slaughter never failed to solve the crime - from petty theft to murder - and bed the dame, his approach was nowhere near as smooth as Tom Magnum's. Stewart hammed up the one-liners the show's writers served up each week, delivering them in a "lazy Canadian version of Groucho Marx." Bullets aired for three seasons in Canada and in the United States as part of CBS' Crimetime After Primetime.

And that would have been that. But in the summer of 1992, following Yugoslavia's breakup under Slobodan Milosevic, Bullets aired in Serbia and the series, known abroad as Tropical Heat, took on a second life. The UN had just imposed sanctions on Serbia, isolating the newly landlocked country and shrinking its economy. Robert Nemecek, the programming director for a then-new local television channel called TV Politika, was looking for a "positive, sunny, and colourful" series to buoy the spirits of Serbs who could no longer summer on the Croatian coast. He wanted Baywatch, the most popular beach-set series at the time, but it was too expensive. That's when Tropical Heat landed on his desk.

"First of all, it was the light entertainment needed for an audience bombarded with pictures of war," Nemecek said via email. "Second, it was Rob's face - he had the face of a Serbian!"

An embargo prohibited large companies from making new deals with Serbian programmers, but independent distributors had free rein. Between 1993 and 1997, Heat aired on three other channels besides TV Politika. Thanks to contracts signed before Yugoslavia's split, shows such as Twin Peaks and Beverly Hills 90210, along with pirated satellite series such as Melrose Place, The X-Files and L.A. Law, continued to air as well. But Tropical Heat was up to the competition. The series was a hit, and Stewart a star.

Milos Djuricic, an actor from Belgrade who recently co-starred with John Cusack in The Raven, was eight when Tropical Heat first aired in his native country. In the new documentary Slaughter Nick for President, which explores Tropical Heat's unlikely popularity in Serbia, Djuricic tells Stewart the show was one of the reasons he got into acting, "not because of very good production or very good acting, but [because] at that time I wanted to be in that paradise." The farthest he could travel in the '90s was his grandmother's village, but he didn't need a visa or a passport to get to Key Mariah.

For many Serbs, the appeal of the show was purely escapist. But eventually the series' second life took a strange turn: Nick Slaughter became a hero, of sorts, to the anti-Milosevic movement. On Nov. 17, 1996, mass protests broke out in the country in response to Milosevic's attempt to manipulate local elections.

The protests took place throughout Serbia, but were at their most concentrated in Belgrade where, in the suburb of Zarkovo, sometime in the mid-'90s, a young graffiti artist had written a rhyme that means, "Nick Slaughter, Zarkovo hails you." According to Marc Vespi, director of Slaughter Nick for President, this graffiti (which survives to this day) inspired student protesters with "the idea of running Nick Slaughter for president." Soon rhyming slogans started showing up on protesters' banners and badges.

"It was a kind of mock-campaign, the message of which was, even a fictitious TV detective would make a better president than Milosevic," said Vespi via email.

Djuricic, the actor, notes that humour was the protesters' weapon of choice during their three-month peaceful protest against Milosevic.

"That was the weapon the regime couldn't fight," he says in Slaughter Nick. "We knew that it was our joke and they didn't understand what our joke meant."

Timofejev Aleksandar, general manager and editor in chief of Belgrade's radio and TV broadcaster Studio B, covered the demonstrations as a young journalist for the independent radio station B92.

He says the Nick Slaughter slogans and numerous other "humorous" tactics were used to oppose the bleak conditions in which citizens were forced to protest.

"Those were demonstrations during the autumn and winter when it was very cold here in Belgrade - it was -10 or -20 degrees," Aleksandar says on the phone from Serbia.

In February 1997, Milosevic bowed to the opposition. That same year, Tropical Heat ended its run on Serbian television.

Locke's company went bankrupt in 2001, but Serbians never forgot Nick Slaughter.

In 2008, fans created a Facebook fan page, "Tropical Heat/Nick Slaughter," and its ranks eventually swelled to over 20,000 members, most of them Serbs.

Two months after the page was established, Nick Slaughter himself stumbled upon it. At the time, Stewart, again unemployed and living with his son and parents, had joined Facebook to communicate with his wife, a cinematographer working in Mexico.

One night he searched Tropical Heat to see if it was airing internationally and might send some residuals his way. That's when he landed on the fan site.

He wrote the administrator and got an email back detailing how Nick Slaughter became a Milosevic-era meme. "I'm famous in Serbia!" Stewart told his neighbour. Six months later, Stewart and his neighbour (filmmaker Marc Vespi) were on a plane to the Balkans.

Slaughter Nick for President, which had its world premiere at Toronto's North by Northeast festival earlier this month, documents their June 2009 trip to Belgrade and Novi Sad where they encountered what the local press called Slaughtermania.

Crowds of Hawaiian-shirted fans, front-page news coverage and autograph seekers of all ages with Tropical Heat DVDs greeted Stewart over the course of two weeks.

"Here, you're like some kind of god - anything is possible if Nick Slaughter is somewhere in it," one female fan tells Stewart in the film. As a baby, her father played her the Tropical Heat theme song, Anyway the Wind Blows, to quiet her cries.

In between documentary interviews, Stewart taped a suspect local TV ad for computer equipment, flashed his chest on a Serbian game show, planted a maple tree in Zarkovo (where "the first seed of the Nick for President phenomenon was planted," says Stewart in the film), and attended movie premieres and fashion shows.

But, for Stewart, the highlight of his visit was a performance at the To Be Punk Festival with Atheist Rap, a Serbian punk band that in 1998 released the song Slaughteru Nietzsche.

In the documentary, Stewart can be seen smiling broadly as the band sings: "You bring us a better tomorrow/ You make peace between nations and people/ Slaughter Nick, Serbia salutes you!"


LOAD-DATE: June 30, 2012


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

283 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)


October 2, 1997, Thursday


Mayor's sacking sparks Serb unrest


SOURCE: QNP


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 736 words


BELGRADE: Riot police yesterday attacked 20,000 opposition activists in the Serbian capital at a protest against the sudden dismissal of Mayor Zoran Djindjic.

Belgrade's first non-communist mayor for 50 years was sacked along with independent television executives in a sordid postscript to last year's uprisings against Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, during which up to 500,000 people staged daily demonstrations in the city.

The uprisings and international pressure forced Mr Milosevic to approve Mr Djindjic's appointment and divest his control over the Studio B television station.

Mr Milosevic's revenge was sudden yesterday. At a city council meeting, Mr Djindjic was voted out of office by 67 of the 68 deputies present. His own Democrats, and smaller parties, were not at the meeting. 

The assembly also replaced the Studio B management board, alleged to have shown bias towards Mr Djindjic.

The moves were a stunning consolidation of power by Mr Milosevic, his ultra-nationalist allies and Mr Djindjic's partner in the winter protests, Vuk Draskovic, who abandoned his former ally yesterday.

Members of Mr Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) yesterday voted with ultra-nationalists of the Radical Party led by Vojislav Seselj and Mr Milosevic's Socialists to oust the popular mayor.

The SPO was part of the Zajedno (Together) coalition which led the (northern) winter demonstrations, but the partnership fell apart over spring and summer, a victim chiefly of the bitter personal rivalry between Mr Draskovic and Mr Djindjic.

Their personal animosities boiled over when Mr Djindjic's Democrats refused to support Mr Draskovic in the presidential and parliamentary elections on September 21.

Mr Djindjic and other opposition leaders, convinced the SPO would do badly, boycotted both elections amid allegations of bad faith and cowardice between the former Zajedno partners.

Mr Draskovic came third in the presidential election with close to a million votes and the SPO won 45 seats in parliament.

Political sources said the results convinced Mr Draskovic he could gather enough strength to challenge Mr Milosevic and the radicals in future without partners like Mr Djindjic.

Yesterday they said Mr Draskovic had ambushed Mr Djindjic in a bid to establish himself as undisputed leader of Serbia's fragmented opposition.

Mr Djindjic said afterwards he would not contest the vote.

But he immediately urged demonstrators to revive their three-month campaign of street protests, which forced the Socialist-led government to recognise opposition victories in Belgrade and 13 other towns at elections last November.

Thousands answered the call, streaming into a central Belgrade square with the distinctive deafening whistles that characterised last winter's protests.

"We will defend Studio B," Mr Djindjic said, calling the station "the eyes of Belgrade".

The station had become a free media platform in opposition to the state media under Mr Djindjic, but, hours after he appeared on Studio B, it fell under the control of Mr Milosevic, who has switched from the Serbian presidency to become President of the Yugoslav Federation.

And it didn't take long for it to revert to its old habits.

The regular news bulletin made no mention of the police action swirling under its windows.

Mr Milosevic's swift actions sent a clear message to Yugoslavs that there was no alternative to the autocrat who has used a mixture of populism, nationalism, the army and police forces to become the only communist in eastern Europe to survive the upheavals of the past 10 years.

The unrest comes as Serbs prepare to vote on Sunday in the second round of republican presidential elections. These will be invalid unless more than 50 percent of the electorate turn out, an increasingly unlikely prospect.

The country risks a constitutional crisis if Mr Milosevic's nominee fails to get elected as tensions mount in Belgrade over Mr Djindjic's sacking.

The Yugoslav President's flank is also under attack from Montenegro, Serbia's only remaining partner in the federation, which is poised to elect an anti-Milosevic president and parliament on Sunday.

There is also trouble brewing in Kosovo province, where students from the repressed ethnic Albanian majority have said they want to start peaceful protests tomorrow for the right to hold classes on campus, instead of in private homes.

Reuter


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML

Moscow News (Russia)


March 21, 2001


DEJA VU IN THE BALKANS


BYLINE: Yelena Guskova D.Sc. (History), director of the Center for Current Balkan Crisis Studies


SECTION: ABROAD; No. 12


LENGTH: 1257 words


HIGHLIGHT:
NATO is faced with the dilemma:lose Macedonia or admit its own mistakes


 

In his address to the nation last Sunday, Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski said that the country was a victim to aggression from Kosovo, masterminded by Kosovo political leaders. Clashes between security forces and Albanian gunmen have been going on in the city of Tetovo, in the northwest of Macedonia, for almost a week now. On March 19, fighting broke out 400 to 500 meters away from the city center. A 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew was imposed. Thousands of residents fled from the city that has a predominantly Albanian population. Meanwhile, mobilization of Macedonian army reservists has begun. The armed forces have a strength of about 15,000 but it could be brought up to 120,000. Using the army against militants is a moot point since there is a large share of ethnic Albanians in the army. Great Britain said it had opened consultations with NATO allies on the situation in Macedonia and possible assistance to its authorities in fighting Albanian extremists. The rebels demanded that KFOR units deployed in Kosovo open up the border near the village of Djeneral Jankovic for refugees from Macedonia, otherwise threatening reprisals against the peacekeepers.

To understand the specifics of the ongoing developments in the Balkans, to predict their course and the possible level of tension, and to formulate an appropriate policy, it is vital to be aware of two things. 

First, what we are seeing now is yet another stage in the struggle by the Albanian people for "national liberation," this time around, however, with plans to involve in the process Albanians living in Macedonia and Montenegro, and to incorporate these lands into Albania. The radically minded Albanians in the province of Kosovo as part of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia began their separatist activities hot on the heels of World War II, and have been at it ever since, without a break. Unification with Albania has always been their main objective. The means and tactics have varied but the objective has remained immutable, regardless of the status of the province in Serbia, the amount of funds funneled into its development, or the level of interethnic relations within the federation. There were several stages in separatist activities: nationalist propaganda in the 1950s; demonstrations and acts of provocation in the 1960s; armed struggle in the 1970s; and an uprising in the early 1980s.

By the 1990s, Albanian extremists had achieved a good deal on their own: They had created a parallel system of regional administration and education, independent of Serbia; established close contacts with Albania; organized procurement, shipment, and storage of weapons both in Kosovo and in areas with an Albanian majority in Macedonia, Montenegro, and in the south of Serbia; on top of that, they had put in place volunteer training programs and created paramilitary formations. It was also critical to draw world public attention to the "Kosovo problem." They successfully coped with the task. In the late 1990s, Kosovo Albanians began a war for independence.

Second, their objective would never have been achieved (nor would their previous plans of Kosovo autonomy, incidentally) without assistance from the United States and NATO, and international organizations that by all intents and purposes supported Albanian extremists. In effect, they helped strengthen the Albanians' confidence that the latter would get assistance if they played on anti-Serb and anti-Milosevic sentiments in the West. And the extremists were not disappointed: All documents adopted by international organizations - the May 6, 1999 statement by the Group of Eight, the June 1999 Chernomyrdin-Ahtisaari-Milosevic accord, and UN Security Council Resolution 1244 - condemned not Albanian separatists but the Yugoslav army in Kosovo and Metohija, making demands that Yugoslav "military, police and paramilitary forces be pulled out of Kosovo," and defining stages for establishing sovereignty in the province: creation of a caretaker administration, to be followed by Kosovo local government bodies outside Serb jurisdiction, and the holding of elections without participation of republic or Union authorities.

The presence of NATO forces in Kosovo after June 1999 created what amounted to a greenhouse environment for Albanian extremism. NATO looked the other way as non-Albanians were being killed and Orthodox landmarks destroyed in Kosovo, effectively encouraging the creation of a monoethnic all-Albanian province. It will be recalled that the "peacekeepers" failed to disarm the so-called Kosovo Liberation Army and reduced the Serb territory by setting up a five-kilometer buffer zone on the side not of Kosovo but of Serbia, incorporating into it areas with Albanian-dominated population; that they sought to establish a local administration not bound by any obligations to the Federation or to Serbia, hastened to organize local elections, and opened Kosovo's border with Albania and Macedonia to free movement.

Choosing an opportune moment, the extremists organized an armed insurgency in Macedonia, in areas with a predominantly Albanian population, following the Kosovo scenario. It is wrong to see this as the work of a group of Albanians from Kosovo who invaded a neighboring territory. The extremist wing of the Albanian political spectrum has long been preparing for this turn, by creating political parties, proclaiming the republic of Illyrida, putting in place an underground education system, training armed units, and spreading nationalist propaganda among the republic's Albanians. It has to be stressed that the Albanian community in Macedonia is far from homogeneous. The bulk of that community is constituted by residents loyal to the authorities who would be reluctant to take up arms. Yet extremists are using intimidation tactics against them. Young Albanians readily respond to nationalist calls since they lack social safety nets, are largely unemployed, and have poor living standards.

Who will be able to put out the smoldering fire this time? Macedonia is pinning its hopes on NATO. After all, this is why NATO came to Kosovo and Macedonia in the first place. The alliance, however, will not get involved: Otherwise it will have, first, to recognize that its previous policy was a mistake and, second, to risk the lives of its servicemen. Maybe the Yugoslav or Macedonian army? The former has limited room for maneuver and is fully controlled by NATO while the latter has neither experience nor sufficient forces. What about UN? Considering that it ceded its peacekeeping functions to NATO of its own free will, this is not a viable option either. New resolutions will be adopted expressing "concern" while calls to all sides in the conflict will just fall on deaf ears. Therefore, the Albanians have indeed chosen a very opportune moment to act. Unless they are stopped, Macedonians and then Montenegrins will have to part with some of their territory while Europe will have to consider revising its borders and recognizing a new state: a Greater Albania.

Single-handed, separate actions will a priori be of no avail. It is only the concerted effort by all European structures and states that will be able to snuff out Albanian extremism. Only the absence of any support from the outside will force the Albanians to back down. Having said that, it is important to understand who stands to gain from keeping the Balkans in a perennial state of tension and what awaits Europe should it fail to act.


LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2001


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2001 Moscow News


285 of 348 DOCUMENTS


THE DAILY TELEGRAPH(LONDON)


March 13, 2003, Thursday


Zoran Djindjic Serbian premier who handed over Milosevic for war crimes trial and favoured western economic policies


SECTION: Pg. 31


LENGTH: 958 words


ZORAN DJINDJIC, who was assassinated yesterday aged 50, was the Serbian prime minister responsible for handing over the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic to stand trial for war crimes at The Hague.

He managed to link this to the promise of an international aid package of $1.2 billion, but even so Djindjic won small affection from his countrymen, who placed him 11th in a poll of politicians. The electorate was put off by his suave demeanour, mastery of the slick soundbite and liking for big cars and sharp suits; he was also a fitness fanatic.

His pragmatic belief in the need to embrace western economics earned him a half-admiring nickname of "The Manager"; but some labelled him "Little Slobo", saying that his authoritarianism contained some resemblances to the man he had sent to the International Court despite a constitutional ban on extraditing Serbian citizens. There was some truth in this. He once admitted that he and Milosevic were "ontologically opposed", then explained: "We all have a bit of Milosevic inside ourselves. We must pull him out by the roots." 

Djindjic's commitment to free market reforms as the first non-Communist prime minister for 55 years was painful enough for Serbs. When he sought to crack down on endemic corruption and organised crime, he stirred up further resentment, which led him to be consumed in the seething cauldron of Balkan politics.

The son of an officer in the Yugoslav People's Army, Zoran Djindjic was born in Bosanski Samac, Bosnia, on August 2 1952. He showed a rebellious streak early, being expelled from high school in Belgrade for helping to organise a protest against a law to make Marshal Tito president for life.

In 1974, he attracted official displeasure for attempting to form a non-Communist movement with students from Croatia and Slovenia at Belgrade University. After several months in jail he gained a degree in Philosophy and left for Germany, where he did a PhD and supported himself by selling textile machinery and making clothes.

On returning home he found the political fabric tearing apart, and became a founder member of the Democratic Party, along with Vojislav Kostunica, the present president of the much larger Serbia and the tiny, mountainous republic of Montenegro.

He was elected to the Serbian parliament in the free elections of 1990 and two years later, as he acrimoniously parted company with Kostunica, was elected his party's president. When the party took 12 per cent of the vote in the next elections there was talk about his being "Serbia's Kennedy"; Djindjic obligingly ditched his bohemian academic look, cut off his ponytail and donned sober suits and ties.

After the inconclusive election of 1993, Djindjic pursued talks with Milosevic on a non-partisan government of experts, prompting eminent members of Djindjic's party to resign, accusing him of a populist thirst for power at the expense of democracy. The talks collapsed and Milosevic found a Leftist coalition partner. In 1996, Djindjic formed a Zajedno (Together) reform bloc, which launched mass protests after Milosevic annulled Socialist losses in municipal elections. These lasted for 88 days in a row, despite periodic attacks by security police, before Milosevic recognised opposition victories in key Serbian towns.

Djindjic became mayor of Belgrade, but Milosevic sabotaged new reformist municipalities by starving them of funds. Riven by leadership squabbles, Zajedno fell apart in mid-1997 and Djindjic lost the mayoralty in September.

During Nato's 1999 air strikes on Yugoslavia, he fled to Serbia's sister republic, Montenegro, for fear of attack by Milosevic's agents. The state media seized on his departure to vilify him as a traitor and a coward.

But after the air strikes halted Milosevic's bloody repression of the Kosovo Albanians, Djindjic returned to ally the Democratic Party with 17 other parties and launched another crusade for democracy. A fresh campaign of marches, rallies and strikes fizzled out in the face of apathy and police intimidation.

But the brooding bitterness of a decade of economic decay and international isolation finally exploded in October 2000 when Milosevic refused to admit election defeat to Kostunica.

Djindjic had found his leadership of the party contested, and there were reports that he wanted to abandon politics. But after winning a confidence vote, he returned to the anti-Milosevic crusade, strengthening ties with reformist Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic.

When Serbia's divided opposition joined ranks in a last-ditch effort to oust Milosevic at the polls, Djindjic - with a modesty that surprised all - insisted on staying out of the spotlight and backed Kostunica.

On becoming prime minister in January 2001 Djindjic was confronted with the task of tempering the breakaway ambitions of ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo and also negotiating the dissolution of federal Yugoslavia into a loose union between Serbia and the tiny republic of Montenegro.

He feuded with Kostunica behind the scenes over the pace of reform, and angered his coalition partners by attempting to take control, through associates of mismanaged state enterprises, in the chaos after the uprising that ousted Milosevic. He also demanded summary sackings of police and state security chiefs and threatening to attack ethnic Albanian rebels in a post-war buffer zone along Kosovo's boundary with Serbia.

Djindjic, who spoke German and English, was the author of three books: Serbia Between East and West; Yugoslavia: the Partially Formed State and The Autam of Dialectics and Subjectivity and Violence.

He is survived by his wife, Ruzica, a lawyer, and their two children.
[PS]News: [ES]

End Column:


LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2003 Telegraph Group Limited


286 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


December 16, 1996, Monday, Final Edition


Serbia's Communism Shows Staying Power


John Pomfret, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1170 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Dec. 15


 

Seven years ago this winter, the capitals of Eastern Europe were filled with people tossing out Communist rulers and rushing headlong toward the West. Thousands massed to knock down the Berlin Wall, the symbol of a divided Europe. In Prague, hundreds of thousands packed Wenceslaus Square and ousted the Communist Party.

Now protesters are again jamming the streets of an East European capital. For the past four weeks, students and middle-class Serbs have marched through Belgrade's boulevards, in the most serious challenge to the last remaining Communist leader in Europe: Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic. 

Waves of protesting students tooting whistles and kazoos, and opposition leaders calling for democracy and the rule of law, recall the heady days of the Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia, Solidarity's victory in Poland and historic changes elsewhere. But the differences between the political crisis in Yugoslavia and the one that ended communism among its neighbors are numerous and vast. They lead Serb analysts and diplomats from the former Communist Bloc to conclude that the protests here have little chance of toppling Milosevic.

"These demonstrations open the door to democracy for Serbia," said one Eastern European diplomat who participated in a revolution in his country. "But the Serbs have a long way to go. Perhaps one year, perhaps five."

The Communist systems of other East European countries were imposed by Moscow, not home-grown as was Yugoslavia's. Established churches played a critical role in hastening democratic change in several other countries while in Yugoslavia the Orthodox Church has supported the regime. Massive industrial enterprises like the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk became lightning rods for political change in Poland, but Yugoslavia's economy is largely rural.

Perhaps most importantly, the people and economy of Yugoslavia have been damaged by five years of war. Milosevic is widely blamed for starting the conflicts in Bosnia and Croatia, dispatching Yugoslav forces to bombard the Croatian city of Vukovar, and grabbing 25 percent of Croatia and half of Bosnia.

A broad spectrum of Yugoslav society supported the war, which Milosevic has used as a way to co-opt, compromise and corrupt almost every segment of society. At one time or another, all of the opposition leaders have supported the war, or at least Serbian nationalist aims.

"This is a country where almost everyone has been compromised by the war except the people who left," said Jelena Volic, who represents a German foundation here. "When people marched in Eastern Europe in 1989 they had dignity. Here we have none."

Serbs from Serbia -- not just Croatia and Bosnia -- volunteered or were conscripted and sent to the front. Serbian paramilitary units, backed by Milosevic, pillaged and killed in Bosnia until the end of the war last year.

The conflict, Milosevic's role in bringing it about and Yugoslavia's guilt in supporting it are not spoken of in the marches. But like an amputated leg that continues to twitch, the war still exerts an enormous influence on the people in Belgrade's streets.

"Serbia was an aggressor in this war and we must start with that if we want to really embrace democracy," said Biljana Kovacevic-Vuco, a former judge on the Serbian supreme court and a representative of the Helsinki Committee for Human Rights. "This protest is a first step, but for real changes we must confront the issue of our responsibility for the war."

The war has had an enormously detrimental effect on Yugoslavia.

Psychologically, the Serbs appear to be a damaged people. Ultranationalism and blatant racism, used by Milosevic's state-run media during the conflict to whip up passions and encourage young men to volunteer, are now accepted coins of political discourse.

Because of the war effort and U.N. economic sanctions imposed on Milosevic's regime for his role in fomenting Bosnia's conflict, Yugoslavia tumbled from being the richest country in Eastern Europe to the third-poorest -- after Albania and its victim Bosnia. An estimated 300,000 people have emigrated from Yugoslavia since the war began, many of them students, going to Canada and the United States.

Other factors have added to the difficulties of Yugoslavia's people in toppling their Communist rulers.

First, Yugoslavia, alone among East European countries, had its own Communist revolution, led by dictator Josip Broz, known as Tito. Communism was not imposed on this country from Moscow, it was home-grown. Yugoslavia never belonged to Moscow's Warsaw Pact and Moscow's influence on Belgrade was much less than elsewhere in Eastern Europe.

So when Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev signaled unwillingness to suppress democratic changes in Eastern Europe in 1989, Yugoslavia's rulers were partially insulated from this shift.

There was also widespread support for Yugoslavia's version of communism among many people here. Backed by loans on favorable terms from Western financial institutions -- a present for keeping Moscow at arm's length -- Tito provided his people with the highest living standards in Eastern Europe. The Yugoslav passport was one of the best travel documents around.

"Throughout Eastern Europe and in other parts of the world, people treated us like kings," recalled Ilija Djukic, a former foreign minister of Yugoslavia and longtime diplomat. "It wasn't so easy for us to get rid of a collapsed system because it was our system," he added. "Communism for us wasn't an import. That wasn't the case in Hungary, Poland and the others."

Milosevic came to power in Yugoslavia in 1987 during the Gorbachev era. Calling his movement "the anti-bureaucratic revolution," Milosevic carefully packaged himself as both crusading reformer and nationalist. Soon he turned toward war.

"With him, we missed the democracy train in 1990," Djukic said. "Milosevic used the war as a pretext to stop further changes and to gradually re-create something we all thought of as the past: an autocratic system."

In Poland, East Germany and Czechoslovakia, the Catholic and Protestant churches played a critical role in pushing political change, but here the dominant Orthodox Church only bolstered Milosevic. Patriarch Pavle, the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, refused to meet with protesting students last week and issued statements dissociating himself from politics. During the war, the Serbian church routinely blessed Serb soldiers and paramilitary gunmen before they left for the front.

Protests in Belgrade are further hampered by the unwillingness or failure of Together, an opposition coalition of five parties, to widen its appeal. Since the protests started, the number of marchers has reached 100,000 only a few times. The marchers remain largely middle-class, well-educated and urban. Few workers participate in the movement. And students, who undertake parallel demonstrations each day, have refused to merge their marches into the coalition's.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, ap/sava radovanovic;ph,,ap/david brauchli, Anti-Milosevic students march with sparklers and horns in Belgrade. Opposition leader Zoran Djindjic waves as he leads thousands of Belgrade citizens through the city's streets in the fourth week of protests against the Socialist Party government of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic.


Copyright 1996 The Washington Post


287 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 6, 1999, Tuesday, Thursday, Final Edition


Milosevic Foes Appeal to West To Help Serbia; Aid Can Undercut Regime, Rivals Say


William Booth, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A09


LENGTH: 987 words


DATELINE: NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia


 

The most potent opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic has emerged not in Belgrade, the capital, but in provincial Serbian cities where dissident mayors and local officials say they can topple the Yugoslav leader. But they need help from the West, they say, and now.

They don't want guns. They want bridges. And transmitters, cement, transformers, ferries and, most important, oil and diesel fuel to keep their citizens from freezing next winter. 

"You Americans want to get rid of Milosevic? So do we," said Nenad Canak, a leader of the League of Social Democrats here in Novi Sad, a Danube River city 50 miles northwest of Belgrade. "You get me a bridge."

By this, Canak and other urban opposition leaders mean they need to show voters that the West does not hate them and that they do not need Milosevic to rebuild their bombed-out bridges and ruined economy, in which average salaries have plummeted to about $ 50 a month.

But the United States and other NATO nations have declared that, while they will provide humanitarian aid to Serbia--the dominant Yugoslav republic--they will not spend any money rebuilding its bomb-blasted infrastructure as long as Milosevic remains president of the Yugoslav federation, which also comprises Serbia's disaffected sister republic, Montenegro.

Canak, and the mayors of some of the largest cities in Serbia, say the West is missing an opportunity to challenge Milosevic. Seven years of sanctions did not work, but "strategic help" could, they say, and the West should find a way to funnel money directly to opposition-run cities--through humanitarian groups, Montenegrin banks or simply by sending materials.

"I'm thinking of something like a sister cities program," said Zoran Zivkovic, the mayor of Nis, another major Serbian city 120 miles southeast of Belgrade, capital of both Serbia and Yugoslavia. Zivkovic has a list of what he wants. At the top is 20,000 tons of heating oil. Without it, about a third of his city--90,000 residents who rely on "remote heat" from city steam plants--will have to do without. He estimates the heating oil would cost about $ 1 million.

Zivkovic said that since NATO spent about $ 50 million a day to bomb Serbia, "this is a reasonable request." He suggested that some U.S. or European city could donate it. It would be a lifesaver, Zivkovic says, and a powerful political tool.

Goran Matic, a government minister close to Milosevic, called the opposition scheme "pure stupidity" and an attempt by the West to blackmail Serbia with offers of aid if only the people would remove Milosevic. The opposition leaders are dreaming, he added, if they really believe the West will help them.

Just as in the United States, where local politicians can amass power and support by mending potholes, the opposition here wants to prove that the West supports those who question Milosevic. "We're not asking for help ousting him, that is our job," said Vuk Obradovic, a former Yugoslav army general and now leader of a small opposition party. "But we need to show the people something real, something they can see with their own eyes."

Ognjen Pribicevic, a strategist with the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, was more straightforward: "We can't rebuild the country with shovels and slogans. We need foreign money and investment. Lots of it. The longer we remain in a cage, the worse for us."

Milan S. Protic, an intellectual who also wants to see Milosevic removed, said city halls around Serbia have tremendous power. "These people made a difference under most difficult times, and they're going to win again," he said. "The West should show them a sign."

The NATO alliance and much of the Western media have often portrayed Serbia as united in antipathy toward the West. But most of its major cities--including Belgrade, Novi Sad, Nis, Cacak, Kraljevo and Kragujevac--are run by opposition parties that are calling for the resignation of Milosevic, creation of a transitional Yugoslav government and new elections. Mass rallies and other anti-Milosevic demonstrations have already taken place.

The pro-Milosevic Serbian president, Milan Milutinovic, was booed when he appeared in the town of Kursumlija last week. Over the weekend, about 500 army reservists blocked roads outside Raska, demanding back pay. And in Leskovac Sunday, a producer at the local TV station locked himself in the studio during the broadcast of the Yugoslav-German basketball game and urged the resignation of the district administrator, a member of Milosevic's Socialist Party. On Monday, thousands of chanting protesters took to the streets of Leskovac to support the technician.

Milosevic has been calling for national unity on reconstruction and is promising, for example, to rebuild a bombed Novi Sad bridge in the next 30 days. But Canak and his allies want to beat him to the punch--and snatch the credit. Forgoing the stiff rhetoric of some of his more academic colleagues, Canak sat one recent night at Novi Sad city hall, dreaming of his bridge. He said he was promised about $ 10 million--by "people in Vienna, and I can't say exactly who"--and a team of Austrian engineers to build a temporary bridge.

At a rally in Novi Sad Friday, Canak told several thousand protesters that the engineers were denied visas by the Milosevic government. The crowd hooted, whistled and chanted: "Dump Milosevic!"

The opposition mayors and leaders say they do not think their citizens would begrudge assistance from the countries routinely dubbed "the NATO aggressors" in state media. "All our cities were bombed, especially the cities where the opposition is greatest," said Zivkovic, the mayor of Nis. "Now, how do you explain to the people who voted for democratic reforms, who rallied against Milosevic, how do you explain that, well, the Western democracies bombed and killed you, and now they don't want to help you rebuild?"


LOAD-DATE: July 06, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Map, The Washington Post


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


288 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


July 16, 1999, FINAL


Arbour tells war crimes suspects to turn selves in: The most wanted suspect from the conflict, Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, still remains at large.


SECTION: News; A17


LENGTH: 762 words


DATELINE: SARAJEVO


SARAJEVO -- Chief Prosecutor of the UN war crimes tribunal Louise Arbour on Thursday called on all Bosnian war crimes suspects to surrender voluntarily or face arrest by NATO-led troops in Bosnia.

''Those who are publicly indicted will be well advised to surrender voluntarily,'' Arbour told reporters, after a meeting with the three members of Bosnia's inter- ethnic presidency.

If they failed to do so, Arbour said she was ''very confident that SFOR (the NATO-led Stabilization Force) will continue to discharge its mandate with the same openness that it has displayed in recent months.''

The peacekeepers have so far arrested 12 suspects in Bosnia. They detained earlier this month former Bosnian Serb deputy prime minister Radoslav Brdjanin, one of the highest-ranking officials to be indicted for war crimes. 

Brdjanin's name was on a ''sealed indictment'' accusing him of running notorious wartime camps for Muslim and Croat prisoners near the northwest Bosnian town of Prijedor.

The Hague-based tribunal has issued 26 indictments against 89 individuals suspected of war crimes, in addition to an unknown number of ''sealed indictments'' kept secret to avoid alerting suspects.

''I will be calling on SFOR to complete these arrests and particularly with respect to sealed indictments,'' Arbour said.

The most wanted war crimes suspects from the Bosnian war, former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his military commander Ratko Mladic, remain at large.

Arbour, making a three-day visit to Bosnia as part of a wider Balkans tour, also called on Bosnian authorities to hand over war crimes suspects.

''I have called on many occasions and I continue to call on the government of this country to discharge its obligations and to secure arrest of all remaining indictees,'' she said.

Arbour said Thursday's decision by the tribunal's appeals chamber to declare the Bosnian war an international conflict was a ''progress for international humanitarian law.''

The ruling means that the 1949 Geneva Conventions, intended to protect civilians in wartime, can be applied to the conflict.

It was a part of a complex decision that overturned the acquittal in 1997 of a former Bosnian Serb police reservist on charges that he murdered five Muslims and Croats.

In May the tribunal indicted Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic for alleged war crimes in Kosovo, along with four other top Yugoslav officials.

Milosevic continued to draw public opposition Thursday. In the central Serbian town of Kragujevac, thousands of people turned out on Thursday for the first of two rival protest rallies to hear speakers call for a united front against him.

About 8,000 gathered in a central square where leaders of the Alliance for Change denounced Milosevic and appealed for an end to damaging opposition splits.

On Saturday, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) led by Vuk Draskovic will make its protest debut in the town, an industrial centre badly hit by NATO's 11-week bombing campaign against Yugoslavia over Kosovo.

The two groups have been bitterly divided since they parted ways after huge street protests in 1996 that forced Milosevic to acknowledge their victories in local elections.

Now both say they are trying to push Milosevic out of office, but their continuing split is a major handicap.

''I am telling my friend Vuk that his place was here among us today,'' Velimir Ilic, the mayor of the nearby town of Cacak who moved to the Alliance from Draskovic's party, told the crowd.

''There can be no separate rallies, there can be only one rally against them . . . I call on the SPO, the mailed fist of Serbia, to assume the helm of the Alliance for Change.''

Vuk Obradovic, Socialist Yugoslavia's youngest general and now leader of an Alliance party, also appealed to Draskovic.

''I invite my namesake to join us. We must abandon all petty party interests and join a united front fighting for a new Serbia.''

Democratic party chief Zoran Djindjic, whose personal rivalry with Draskovic is at the heart of the split, did not refer to him directly but said this was no time for politicking.

''There can be no party political gathering now . . . this is a social revolution of a people deprived of their rights.''

Some people in the crowd seemed more interested in the fact the demonstrations were anti-Milosevic than in who was running them. They planned to turn out on Saturday too.

''It doesn't matter who organizes the rally, so long as it's not the ruling party,'' said Tomislav, a 25-year-old farmer.


LOAD-DATE: July 16, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
