289 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


AUGUST 8, 2000 Tuesday SF EDITION


NEWS IN BRIEF


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A02


LENGTH: 933 words


In the Nation

N.Y. police commissioner reportedly will quit New York Police Commissioner Howard Safir, who has presided over a department beset by racial incidents at the same time that crime has dropped dramatically, will leave the NYPD next month, police sources with direct knowledge of Safir's plans confirmed yesterday. They said he was expected to announce the move today. A Safir spokeswoman did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Pentagon delays report on missile defense

A Pentagon assessment of how and when to move forward with a national missile-defense system will take longer than planned, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said yesterday. As a result, Cohen is unlikely to recommend a course of action to President Clinton until early September, officials said. 

Clinton signs bill on oceans, coastal resources

At a Coast Guard station on the shores of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., President Clinton signed bipartisan legislation yesterday aimed at protecting the nation's oceans and coastal resources. The measure sets up a commission to spend 18 months studying how to promote better use of U.S. beaches and coasts, restore fisheries and marine mammals, strengthen coastal economies, and expand undersea exploration.

Seafood is called top cause of food poisoning

Seafood is the biggest cause of food poisoning in the United States, having caused 237 outbreaks since 1990, a consumer group said yesterday. Eggs are second, having caused 170 outbreaks, mostly of salmonella, said the Center for Science in the Public Interest. The group suggested that the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention maintain a database on all food-poisoning outbreaks.

Cisneros quits TV network to develop housing

Former Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros has resigned as president of the Spanish-language television network Univision to form a company dedicated to developing housing. Univision, which Cisneros headed since 1997, said Cisneros was leaving to create American CityVista, which will be based in San Antonio and will develop residential communities in the central areas of selected cities.

Small earthquake hits northeastern Ohio

A small earthquake shook northeastern Ohio on Sunday in an area where seismic activity is rare, the U.S. Geological Survey said yesterday. It measured 2.8 and caused no damage or injuries, authorities said. It was felt in an area halfway between Cleveland and Columbus near Pennsylvania's border.

Newseum to move to Pennsylvania Avenue

The Newseum, a museum focused on the news media, will relocate to Washington's Pennsylvania Avenue, "America's Main Street," where it will be within walking distance of some of the nation's most popular monuments on the National Mall, officials announced yesterday. Officials said they envisioned a 300,000-square-foot facility, more than four times the exhibit space of the Newseum's current home in Arlington, Va. The new site could open by June 2003.

In the World

S. Korea's Kim ousts almost half of cabinet

South Korean President Kim Dae Jung replaced almost half of his cabinet yesterday, including the finance minister, after criticism over the pace of economic reform. Taking over as finance minister is Jin Nyum, South Korea's chief budget planner for two years. Kim made changes in eight of the 19 cabinet posts. Most of the replaced ministers held economic jobs and were responsible for implementing reforms drawn up at the start of the Asian financial crisis of 1997.

Iran arrests journalist, closes newspaper

Iran's hard-liners arrested a liberal journalist and shut down a reformist newspaper yesterday, a day after the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, halted debate on legislation to ease a restrictive press law. Journalist Ahmad Zeidabadi was arrested, and the weekly Cheshmeh Ardebil in northwestern Iran was ordered closed for four months.

3d opposition candidate to challenge Milosevic

A coalition opposed to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic yesterday nominated its presidential candidate for next month's elections. Most of Serbia's opposition parties endorsed Vojislav Kostunica of the center-right Serbian Democratic Party. On Sunday, the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party, nominated Belgrade Mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic for president. The anti-Milosevic votes will be sliced further by the ultranationalist Serbian Radical Party's announcement yesterday that it had picked its own candidate, Tomislav Nikolic.

U.S. seeks sanctions against Afghanistan

The Clinton administration said yesterday that it was discussing with other U.N. Security Council members the possibility of imposing an arms embargo against Afghanistan. This and other punitive measures are being contemplated after the Taliban government's refusal to hand over suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said. Bin Laden, a Saudi exile, is wanted in the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa two years ago.

Bomb kills 3 suspected separatists in Spain

Three suspected members of the Basque separatist group ETA were killed yesterday when a bomb tore apart their car in Bilbao as they headed for a possible attack, Spanish officials said. The ETA has been blamed for seven killings and 17 attacks since it ended a cease-fire in December.

Ruling on Pinochet's immunity is due today

Chile's Supreme Court will deliver a formal ruling today on whether former President Augusto Pinochet can keep his immunity from prosecution, which is blocking bids to put him on trial for alleged abuses.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC 
All Rights Reserved


290 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


April 29, 1997, Tuesday, Final Edition


The Policeman Who Knew Too Much?; Murder of Belgrade's Top Cop Has Fingers Pointing in Many Directions, Including High Up


Jonathan C. Randal, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A10


LENGTH: 805 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


 

A masked gunman entered a Belgrade restaurant at half-past midnight on April 11 and fired six bullets into Serbia's top police official before disappearing into a getaway car.

The murder of Radovan Stojicic, deputy interior minister for public security, has remained unsolved, like so many before it. But speculation about who pulled the trigger and why has led to some uncomfortable questions for Serbia. The slaying of the boss of Serbia's 80,000 uniformed police -- a central pillar of President Slobodan Milosevic's decade-long rule -- underscored as never before the government's ties with criminals and war-profiteering businessmen. 

In Belgrade's gossipy political world, rumors variously laid Stojicic's death at the door of disgruntled underworld figures, jealous army officers and fellow policemen, senior members of the ruling Socialists -- and even Milosevic himself. Some insisted Stojicic was killed by high-ranking anti-Milosevic Socialists determined to clean up the regime. Others were sure the president wanted to be rid of a man who knew too much.

Retired police inspector Mladen Lojovic remarked that Stojicic's murder and other assassinations have served to "rewrite history" by "removing embarrassing witnesses of quite a lot of events of the dark 1990s."

Rarely mentioned were more logical foes: ethnic Albanians in Serbia's turbulent Kosovo province, Croats and Bosnian Muslims. Over the past eight years, they all had ample reason to seek revenge for the violence Stojicic and his special paramilitary police units visited upon them.

The regime gave Stojicic a funeral worthy of a national hero, but a reminder of his past excesses resurfaced at graveside. Photographed just behind the president, his son Marko and daughter Marija at the Belgrade cemetery plot reserved for the nation's most respected citizens was Zeljko Raznatovic, a convicted prewar bank robber.

Better known as Arkan, Raznatovic personifies the government's use of violent convicted criminals in ethnic purges in Bosnia and Croatia from 1991 to 1995 to achieve Milosevic's now-abandoned war aim of creating a Greater Serbia. During Serbia's undeclared wars with its neighbors, Arkan's Tigers -- and other paramilitary outfits recruited among released convicts promised pardons -- were coordinated by Stojicic and his special police units.

Those links soon encompassed looting, then expanded to smuggling of gasoline and other strategic materials to circumvent wartime sanctions imposed by the United Nations from 1992 to 1996 to punish Belgrade for its role in the Bosnian conflict.

In the coded signs that often pass for information in Belgrade, the absence at the funeral of senior army officers and of the president's powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, was deemed significant. Leaders of the armed forces were known to dislike Stojicic, who last year introduced military ranks in the uniformed police -- with himself as a general -- to rub in his success in creating a paramilitary police organization challenging the army for funds, weapons and prestige.

Politically, his brand of radical Serb nationalism was increasingly out of favor, especially with the president's wife and militants of her Marxist Yugoslav United Left party.

Nor was Stojicic universally popular within the police. The rival state security police run by Jovica Stanisic, also a deputy interior minister, resented his powers and unlimited access to Milosevic, according to press reports.

When the killer opened fire from less than five feet with a German-made MP5 submachine gun, under the table, media reports said, was a briefcase containing 750,000 German marks in cash -- about $ 440,000. But veteran crime reporter Jovan Dulovic said police investigators assigned to the case reported they found no money when they arrived at the restaurant within 15 minutes of the shooting.

The possible existence of so much cash, the absence of a bodyguard and the presence at the table of customs inspector Milos Kurdulija have fueled speculation that the two men were involved in a smuggling deal payoff.

Similar allegations have long circulated. Opposition journalist Milovan Brkic landed in the hospital after he wrote an article last October alleging that Stojicic was involved in lucrative drug and car-theft operations with a prominent Belgrade gangster.

Brkic said two of the gangster's men visited his Serbia's Word, a weekly published by Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, produced what they said were state security identity cards and took him to their headquarters near the Belgrade airport.

He was tortured for five hours, he said, and owes his life to intervention by the president's son, whom the gangsters telephoned asking for permission to cut off his fingers as a prelude to more serious bodily harm.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Illustration, vreme magazine, The gangland-style murder of Serbia's top police official inspired this cartoon showing President Slobodan Milosevic working under Serbia's national emblem, a two-headed eagle, modified by the addition of cigars and fedoras to the eagle heads, and a submachine gun -- to suggest his government is tied to criminals.


Copyright 1997 The Washington Post


291 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Sunday Herald


July 4, 1999


Rumblings of resistance


BYLINE: Milenko Vasovoc And David Pratt


SECTION: Pg. 14


LENGTH: 2316 words


 

The war is over, but Milosevic faces a new state of emergency. Milenko Vasovic, in Belgrade, and David Pratt report

Surrounded on all sides by resentful ethnic Albanians and KLA soldiers, you might think that those struggling to live in the tiny Serb enclaves of Kosovo would have other things on their mind than the fate of Slobodan Milosevic. Yet even here, as in parts of Serbia itself, dissent against the Belgrade regime is brewing.

"At this moment we are in a catastrophic political state, and have no friends in the world - the government is nothing more than a mafia," Jana Dedic, a teacher, complained as she packed a few meagre belongings into her car in readiness for a hasty departure should life in the Kosovo town of Orahovich become too dangerous to stay.

Across the country, in ethnic enclaves, rural communities and industrialised cities, there are signs that Yugoslavs no longer believe the bombast of their president. With the fledgling opposition as yet scattered, disorganised and divided, it is too early to talk of Milosevic's imminent downfall. But resistance is beginning to surface and mobilise. 

"Down with Milosevic Where is the money? Where are the bridges? Where is fuel? Where is electricity?" read the main banner at a rally in the bomb -shattered city of Novi Sad on Friday. Earlier in the week, demonstrations in the city centre of Cacak drew thousands of people in an enthusiastic opposition gathering - the first since the end of the war.

Serbian police prevented a few busloads of demonstrators, and some international journalists, from reaching the rally. Local members of opposition parties also received warnings or were detained for "informative talks" in an effort to get them to call off the protest. Despite this harassment, activists with the coalition Alliance for Change mounted the first open display of opposition since the end of the war.

Making his first public appearance since going into hiding during the war, Cacak Mayor Velimir Ilic addressed the chanting rally and waded into the crowd to shake hands and greet supporters. He was joined on the platform by Social Democrat leader Vuk Obradovic, Civic Alliance of Serbia (GSS) leader Goran Svilanovic, Mayor Zoran Zivkovic of Nis and civic activists from Cacak as well as Kraljevo. "For freedom, for Cacak," read posters plastered around the town.

Cacak has been a focus of opposition since its first anti-Milosevic demonstrations in 1992. In the 1996 local elections, opposition politicians from the Democratic Party of Zoran Djindjic, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) of Vuk Draskovic and others gained seats and took overall control.

But it was in the midst of the heaviest Nato bombing that Cacak secured its reputation as an opposition stronghold by organising anti-regime demonstrations despite the state of war. On May 18, local activists organised a citizens' parliament, which held three days of protests attended by thousands of people. After such meetings were banned, opposition-oriented gatherings continued in panel discussions and other private meetings.

"The citizens' parliament was formed so the people of Cacak could speak openly about everything that is happening to us," explains Verica Barac, a municipal attorney associated with the parliament. "We wanted the voice of reason to be heard, to fight for the last man, and not to the last man. But it seems the regime wants as many people as possible to die."

During the bombing, euphoric nationalism swept Serbia - including officially sponsored rallies in Cacak "against the Nato aggressor". The municipal assembly, dominated by opposition parties, and Mayor Ilic of the New Serbia party, sought to explain to citizens that such "patriotic protests" were staged by local representatives of the ruling Socialist Party of Serbia and its communist partner, the Yugoslav United Left.

Thus while air raid sirens wailed, and soldiers' bodies were returned from Kosovo, citizens of Cacak condemned such patriotic defiance. Yet with the media blockade, they had little impact. Even the local private TV station, Galaksija 32, lent itself out as the official parties' mouthpiece.

In these circumstances, the initial aims of the citizens' parliament were formally apolitical. The focus was on ending the war and saving people's lives. A modest industrial town of 80,000, Cacak lies 100 miles south of Belgrade. The destruction of its economy contributed to the feeling among jobless residents that the patriotic fervour pumped out by the regime and its loyal media cannot offer them a real future. With desperate young soldiers returning from Kosovo, people in Cacak were also under no illusion that the war against Nato could be won.

The regime responded with ham-fisted attempts to stifle dissent in Cacak. The first to be attacked was Ilic, the assembly speaker. Based on statements he made to Radio Free Europe, he wasaccused of revealing military targets. The authorities tried to arrest him, but Ilic slipped into hiding, where he remained until now.

Trumped-up charges were also brought against leading members of the citizens' parliament for holding unregistered gatherings during a state of war. "The situation in the town is extremely repressive," says Dr Svetlana Eric, who was also charged. "Only in Cacak were people arrested because of their opinion.''

Within the town, the political initiatives appear to have widespread support. "Serbia is shrinking year by year and its citizens are ever poorer," says Milisav Kovacevic, an unemployed factory worker. "I am left without a job, and what do I get in return? Bogus patriotism from people who managed to get rich on other people's misery." He thinks the Cacak initiatives suggest people realise they have to take responsibility for Serbia's future. "Sooner or later the regime will have to answer before its own people," he says.

The question is whether Cacak's citizens' parliament and other activities can emerge as a serious new political force. In these terms at least, such protests suggest a hot summer and a hotter autumn for the hitherto uncontested Milosevic, who may have been cornered. The moment the state of war with Nato was lifted, calls for his resignation multiplied. Many came from pre-conflict critics who have now been joined in the call for change by the influential Serbian Orthodox Church.

But after enthusiastically backing Milosevic's campaign for a Greater Serbia for the past decade, the church is finding it difficult to reinvent itself. The on-going Serb exodus from Kosovo is in many respects as much a defeat for the church as for Milosevic. With more than 50,000 Serbs on the move, the church itself is coming under pressure in what it used to call its holy land.

In an attempt to salvage something from the Kosovo debacle, the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Pavle, rushed to Pec, home of the Serbian Patriarchate during Ottoman rule, as soon as the Nato bombing ended. He urged Serbs and Montenegrins to remain there, but most chose to flee the town - which had been cleansed of its Albanian inhabitants in April - rather than wait for the return of their former neighbours. As a result, the current anti -Milosevic feeling inside the Serbian Orthodox Church does not reflect victory of universal principles over the national interest, but bitterness over Milosevic's failure and "betrayal of Serbdom".

Milosevic is also losing the support of older allies who first helped him into power, then kept him there through years of crushing UN sanctions and a string of disastrous military defeats that have turned hundreds of thousands of Serbs into refugees.

Dejan Medakovic, president of the Serbian Academy of Arts and Sciences (SANU), has called for a change, as has Dobrica Cosic, who co-authored the notorious 1986 SANU memorandum which paved the ideological way for Milosevic's Greater Serbia project. Cosic, later the first President of rump Yugoslavia and now a respected newspaper columnist, has urged Milosevic to step down and "make way for necessary change".

Cosic was roughly divested of his presidency after parting political company with Milosevic over a 1993 peace plan for Bosnia. Years of this kind of ruthlessness are bringing droves of former allies turned foes into the open.

"We were solving the Kosovo question together with the Albanians," says former Serbian President Ivan Stambolic, once one of Milosevic's closest friends but ejected from politics by his machinations in 1987. "Others just cut through it with a sword," he told Radio Free Europe. "The bloody saga has come full circle during the past 12 years and is now closed."

There have been critics before, and threats to Milosevic's authority, but the difference this time is the sense of public anger that permeates the air. There is a feeling that someone should be called to account for all the lives claimed, homes destroyed, businesses smashed and wars lost over the past few years.

Only the criminal community and the political elite have escaped the economic crisis that afflicts the country. More than half the workforce is without jobs, and those in work have to survive on an average monthly wage of about £30. Pensioners who have only just received their February payments must live on even less. Hospitals are short of medicines to treat the estimated 10,000 people injured by Nato's bombs, while managers of the bombed -out electricity grid reckon that a freezing winter beckons. Families who once got by dabbling in the black market have found even that avenue is no longer as lucrative.

Army reservists in the towns of Kragujevac, Kraljevo, Trstenik and Vrbas, just back from Kosovo, protested violently when they discovered they could not get their pay for their time under fire. Many families had gone without money while their breadwinners were called up. Mothers, sisters and girlfriends in many disgruntled industrial centres like Cacak bitterly resent the way their menfolk - in disproportionate numbers to their sophisticated metropolitan counterparts in Belgrade - were packed off to such a pointless war. Even some regular soldiers have not been paid for months at a time, adding to the Yugoslav Army's palpable sense of fury that so many have died in the name of a cause which was so clearly unwinnable from the outset.

For the second day running yesterday, reservists - some armed and drunk - blocked roads in southern Serbia demanding payment for service in Kosovo. Similar protests in central and eastern Serbia a week ago raised political tensions in the country sharply, until the government handed out money to demonstrators.

The unanswered question remains: who among Milosevic's own party will step forward to challenge him for its leadership? No obvious candidate from the ranks of the ruling Socialist Party (SPS) has yet emerged.

The Serbian opposition continues to warn Milosevic's SPS allies that they are facing their "last chance" to disassociate themselves from their leader, who has been indicted for war crimes committed in Kosovo by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague. Meanwhile, petitions calling for Milosevic's resignation have begun to circulate throughout Serbia. Under the constitution, 100,000 signatures will force the Yugoslav parliament to consider ousting him.

The Sumadija Coalition is leading the petition drive in Kragujevac in association with the opposition Civic Alliance of Serbia (GSS). In Novi Sad, Serbia's second largest city, three groups are now gathered under the banner of the Alliance of Democratic Parties. Zoran Djindjic's Democratic Party, the strongest opposition party, has also joined the drive.

The Yugoslav parliament, which contains deputies from both Serbia and Montenegro, appoints the Yugoslav president and Milosevic may reasonably expect his party and its usual allies - the Yugoslav Left (JUL), which is headed by his wife Mirjana, and the ultra-nationalist Serbian Radical Party (SRS) - to resist any motion brought to the house by the petitioners. The Montenegrin half of the house is loyal to Federal Prime Minister Momir Bulatovic, who is in turn loyal to Milosevic.

If he is to survive, Milosevic must now resist efforts to change this political balance. In the first instance, he has to stop any bid to call an early election in Serbia, which he would almost certainly lose. Secondly, he has to prevent Montenegro from implementing an earlier decision to change the composition of the Montenegrin contingent in the Yugoslav parliament, replacing the existing members with deputies loyal to Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic, all ready to vote against Milosevic.

In addition to the Serbian opposition, both Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), which has been in and out of government, and Vojislav Seselj's SRS now advocate early elections. But as Democratic Party vice-president Slobodan Vuksanovic points out, early elections will only count if they are fairly held under an election law that meets Council of Europe standards and are conducted under the eye of a free media.

Things could still thus get much worse before they get better. The other prospect for Serbia is that Milosevic may declare a formal state of emergency. In such an event, all hope of elections would be suspended.

No one in Serbia has an answer to the question of how to force an early vote and tip Milosevic out of power in truly democratic fashion. Thus Milosevic remains in power, still controlling the security forces, the media and the political scene. In that sense then, Serbia is further from a peaceful transition by popular vote than it is from the unpredictable consequences of a state of emergency.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1999


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Mayor Velimir Ilic comes out of hiding to greet the people of Cacak, a town 100 miles south of Belgrade that has been a focus of opposition to the government since 1992 Photograph: Srdjan Ilic/AP;The Democratic Party, led by Zoran Djindjic, left, could now pose a real threat to Slobodan Milosevic's regime


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1999 Scottish Media Newspapers Limited


292 of 348 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 14, 2000, Saturday, 0 South Pinellas Edition


Yugoslavia awakens from nightmare


SOURCE: Knight-Ridder Newspapers


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 2A


LENGTH: 1422 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


 

The snapshots of this nation are sobering: long lines for sugar and cooking oil, cash machines that dispense no cash, buses brittle from rust, a burned Parliament, a string of looted banks and the world's perception that Yugoslavs are imbued with a dangerous nationalism that still threatens the Balkans.

But the larger picture emerging after the defeat of former President Slobodan Milosevic is one of Yugoslavia purging its demons and moving toward reclaiming its place in Europe. There is joy. There is sometimes bewilderment. And there is the belief that the weird and bloody nightmare is over.

"I think people abroad now think we're a miracle," said Dragoljub Milinovic, a veterinary student at Belgrade University. "For 10 years we've lived the level of African nations. Now our optimism is greater than ever. We lived in a state of complete lies. Milosevic lied to us that we were living nicely. He was fooling us even when we knew the truth." 

If new president Vojislav Kostunica "manages to introduce real democracy here, then the image of us will change," said Biljana Radivojevic, a university biology student, who would like to see the 400,000 young and educated people who fled Yugoslavia during Milosevic's regime to return. "We'll be open to other countries. Young people will be able to travel and show a different face of Serbia abroad. I hope we have that chance."

The task of resurrecting this country of 10-million is enormous. Kostunica is faced with a ruined economy, political mischief from the last of Milosevic's cronies, an independence-minded republic of Montenegro and a troubled province of Kosovo, where 35,000 NATO troops still prevent Yugoslavia from exerting its rule over 1.8-million ethnic Albanians and the province's rich natural resources.

Kostunica is intent on guiding his country back into the fold of the international community. He must balance between Serb suspicion of the West - especially after last year's NATO bombing - and the need to open Yugoslavia to world markets. Western diplomats say Kostunica must delicately mend a decade of acrimony and war between Yugoslavia's immediate neighbors - Bosnia and Croatia.

The fate of Milosevic is a pressing international concern as the West insists that the former leader be turned over to The Hague for war crimes indictments. Most Serbs think Milosevic should be tried in Yugoslav courts, not for mass killings and atrocities, but for wrecking what was once one of eastern Europe's richest nations. Serbs express no desire to use Milosevic's downfall to examine this nation's complicity in four nationalist wars that killed 300,000 people, mostly civilians.

Kostunica told western diplomats that there is a "very real possibility Milosevic will be brought before a Serb court."

"The common people are opposed to the West and the Hague," said Boijan Djuric, a law student and member of the Belgrade's student resistance movement. "But Milosevic should be tried for all those war crimes in Bosnia and Kosovo. We are so embarrassed that that's the only way we can change" how the world thinks of Yugoslavia.

Re-writing the nationalist distortions in Yugoslav history books - although talked about in this fledgling age of promise - is expected to take some time. The Serbian spin on the Kosovo war, for example, emphasized "NATO aggression" but never mentioned the ethnic-cleansing and massacres sanctioned by the Milosevic regime. Kosovo is expected to remain a NATO protectorate until Kostunica and ethnic Albanian leaders can negotiate autonomy or other solutions for the province.

"This society is not based on forgiveness. It's based on revenge," said Maria Babic, who runs youth camps to teach tolerance between different ethnic groups. "Forgiving in South Africa over apartheid was seen as a virtue, but here it's a weakness."

The swift events of the past 10 days have stunned this country. Milosevic's downfall on Oct. 5 - as 200,000 protesters massed in the streets and armed citizens seized government offices - thrilled Serbs whose political opposition had been repeatedly crushed by the autocratic leader. Although the uprising appeared spontaneous, much of it was planned, especially the actions of gangs of armed men from the heartland town of Cacak, who rolled into Belgrade with a bulldozer, two truck loads of stones and a van filled with Molotov cocktails. With help from sympathetic police, they captured the Parliament and state TV.

Milosevic fled to his house in the suburbs, where he remains protected by guards. Western officials described Milosevic's regime as "decaying." The powerful state security police appear to have abandoned him. Members of his socialist party are defecting, including the entire municipal council in Zitorodja.

The euphoria over the "revolution" vibrates daily across this country. The most popular CD features Milosevic on the cover and the satirical song, The Last Train for Serbia. Anti-Milosevic buttons are sold in the streets. The police are nearly invisible. Each day the tiny flags of other countries flap from BMWs and Mercedes as diplomats return to this capital. They bring good news, such as the announcement that the French automaker Peugeot will enter a partnership with Yugoslavia's Zastava car factory.

But these scenes are inter-cut with images of sugar lines, poverty and the crumpled buildings struck 20 months ago by NATO war planes. Yugoslavia's unemployment rate is 50 percent. The average monthly income is about $ 40. Pension checks are months late. The elderly routinely pick through dumpsters. Stories of government corruption are endless, such as the looting of $ 500,000 from the Bim Slavia meat plant by general manager Velibor Tomasevic, a buddy of Milosevic's wife, Mira.

At many businesses, workers have forcefully removed their bosses and seized company records. The executives are resorting to some serious last-minute house cleaning. "The management is trying to destroy documents, archives and all traces of their corruption," said retired Gen. Vuk Obradovic, a leader of a democratic political party.

The sting of the regime's criminality will be felt in coming months.

"We don't want to lie to the people . . . We are going to start a campaign soon to warn people of energy shortages over the winter," said Srboljub Antic, a member of G-17, a group of economists advising Kostunica's government.

"The biggest issue here is the economy," said Babic. "Whatever else the new government does won't matter unless people feel it in their wallets . . . They can't wipe out the black market because too many people rely on it now." The black market, which blossomed under economic sanctions, accounts for at least 40 percent of the $ 13-billion gross domestic product, according to independent economists.

The European Union last week pledged $ 2-billion in aid. International sanctions, including oil and flight embargoes by the U.S., are being lifted. Italian and Greek firms that signed letters of intent during sanctions are planning to open businesses and offices across Yugoslavia.

But political analysts here say that Kostunica's relationship with the West will be risky. Milosevic's socialist party daily attacks Kostunica's coalition as "traitors and spies" of NATO and the West. The Yugoslav Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic, who has close ties to Milosevic and despises NATO, is threatening Kostunica not to meddle with the military leadership. If Kostunica, a nationalist himself, appears to anger the Army or to drift too close to the West, diplomats say, it could incite Serb nationalism.

The new government is "carefully choosing its words about relationships with western countries," said Srdan Hofman, a composer and member of the Social Democrats, one of 18 parties supporting Kostunica.

But even in his weakened state, Milosevic still casts the largest specter on this nation. His fate is ceaselessly debated. Anger over his regime grows. The turmoil he caused for the past 13 years has set a harsh frame for the future. And, according to Kostunica's reformers, the fallen leader still has supporters who can stir trouble.

Vesna Hadjivokovac said the events of the past two weeks have made her numb. She is the epitome of the new Serb state of mind. She was an army spokesperson during the Kosovo war. Today, she is a translator and analyst for the western media.

"My suffering is greater than yours," she recently told a colleague. "I have to explain a logic that doesn't exist."


LOAD-DATE: October 14, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO, Associated Press; A man fills his fuel tank from a plastic soft-drink bottle in downtown Belgrade on Thursday.


Copyright 2000 Times Publishing Company


293 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Edmonton Journal (Alberta)


September 27, 2000 Wednesday Final Edition


Is this the man to topple Milosevic?: Opposition leader is a Serbian lawyer who believes in peaceful resistance


SOURCE: Times of London


BYLINE: Eve Ann Prentice


SECTION: Insight; Pg. A13


LENGTH: 1070 words


DATELINE: Belgrade


Vojislav Kostunica cuts an unlikely figure as hero and prospective saviour of Yugoslavia.

While despairing Serbs and Western leaders looked the other way in search of a Balkan braveheart to rise up and cut the chains that have kept Slobodan Milosevic in power for the past decade, the quietly spoken rival for the presidency slipped under the ropes and, possibly, felled him at the ballot box.

Voting in Yugoslavia's presidential election is now slated to run to a second round on Oct. 8, but Milosevic looks mortally wounded after Sunday's vote.

Even if he manages to hang on to power a little longer, his authority seems fatally undermined by Kostunica's strong showing. 

Soon after the end of the NATO bombing campaign last year, many war- and sanctions-weary Serbs looked high and low for someone to lead them against the regime.

The political options were bleak: the maverick fence-sitter Vuk Draskovic and his Serbian Renewal Movement on one hand, and the Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic on the other. Djindjic's error was to leave Belgrade at the height of the bombing, seen as an act of cowardice by ordinary Serbs who had no choice but to stay put.

To make matters worse, Djindjic and Draskovic proved repeatedly that they could not put personal differences aside and present a united opposition.

A series of opposition rallies around Serbia in the weeks that followed the Alliance campaign were little more than Sunday outings for the curious and a chance for the two opposition groups to squabble.

During this time, Kostunica waited quietly for his moment in history. It came when Milosevic decided to call early elections and Kostunica was chosen to head a multi-party democratic opposition.

Whereas the West had been less than accurate in reading the Balkan mentality, Kostunica had read the runes well. He knew that many Serbs had become wary of firebrand politics and paramilitary adventurism. His message has been an almost Gandhi-esque appeal to peaceful resistance.

So who is the man who seems within inches of achieving what would have looked impossible even three months ago, levering Milosevic from power?

And will he meet the West's expectations?

Vojislav Kostunica, a married man with no children, was nominated as the candidate of 18 parties and one trade union which form the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS).

Born in Belgrade in 1944 to an old Belgrade family, he graduated from the Belgrade School of Law in 1966 and went on to obtain a master's degree in 1970 and doctorate in 1974.

In 1970 he was appointed assistant lecturer at the Belgrade School of Law, but was expelled in 1974, during a political purge of Belgrade University, because of his opposition to communism.

From 1974 until 1981, he worked at the Institute of Social Sciences. He moved on to become director of the Institute for Philosophy and Social Theory.

Until recently, his main claim to fame was as a bookish academic and author of papers on constitutional law, political theory and political philosophy.

Kostunica has also worked as editor-in-chief of several specialized journals dedicated to law and philosophy.

During the 1980s, while Milosevic was climbing the greasy pole to supreme power, Kostunica turned his legal skills to human rights and was especially active in the Board for the Freedom of Thought and Speech, where he was highly regarded.

It was around this time that he became involved in politics, becoming a founder of the Democratic Party in 1989. He has been president of the separate Democratic Party of Serbia since it was founded in 1992 and was a member of the Serbian Parliament from 1990 until 1997 when his party boycotted the elections due to the "lack of regular electoral conditions."

Western leaders, however, have been nonplussed. Although senior European Union, American and even Russian politicians have been swift to call on Milosevic to give way immediately and hand power to Kostunica, the lawyer has not always been flavour of the month, especially in Washington.

Kostunica has consistently proclaimed that he would not hand Milosevic over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and he was a vigorous critic of the NATO bombardment. This has been seized on by some as proof that he is no different from other war-zealous Balkan leaders.

Kostunica has been described in some U.S. state department background briefings as an old-fashioned Serb nationalist, a sort of "Seselj in coattails" a reference to Milosevic's erstwhile ally, Vojislav Seselj, the ultra-nationalist leader of the Serbian Radical Party.

This is where East and West divide. Opponents of the Milosevic regime see nothing wrong in criticizing the Alliance campaign, as the NATO bombing affected nearly everyone. While they may be anti-Milosevic, they believe their political destiny should be decided from within.

"Kostunica is a good patriot. He is educated, a peaceful man and no threat to anyone," says Srdjan Stojanovic, an independent Serbian journalist who lives in London. "He is a calm, even boring speaker, but he insists on following legal procedures. That is what our country needs."

And what does Kostunica say? His actions and words in the next few days and weeks will be crucial. So far, he has tried to maintain calm on all sides.

"One encouraging thing is the conduct of the army and police, which was very appropriate standing between two political options, and not between the so-called patriots and traitors," he said on Monday.

He then promised that, as soon as he officially became president, he would start parliamentary talks on the relations between Serbia and Montenegro. Links between the two republics that make up Yugoslavia have been strained to near-breaking point since the NATO bombardment when Montenegro intensified attempts to break loose of the federation.

Many Serbs now fear civil war.

Asked how his alliance would react if final voting figures show that he has won but Milosevic fails to recognize the result, Kostunica said that he would defend his victory using all available democratic means.

"Protests and demonstrations are democratic methods of fighting for your rights. We will defend the will of the people in such a way as not to endanger the peace in the country, nor to challenge any reaction of the international community," he says.

But the final word rests with the people of Serbia.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: AP; Vojislav Kostunica, presidential candidate of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, talks to journalists after voting Sunday. After the first round of voting, many feel he has delivered a knockout blow to Slobodan Milosevic.


TYPE: News

CanWest Global Communications Corp.
