294 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


October 6, 2000, Friday


Police and priests join workers' revolt


BYLINE: Misha Glenny


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 837 words


 

THOUSANDS of Serbs were on the streets of Belgrade last night in an astonishing display of people power which swept President Milosevic from office.

Protesters set fire to the parliament building, took over national state television, and ransacked the Belgrade headquarters of Mr Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia. Two people were reported to have died and more than 100 were injured.

The opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, addressed the crowd on the steps of the parliament building. He said: "We are living the last twitches of Milosevic's regime. Democracy has happened in Serbia. Communism is falling. It is just a matter of hours. We are staying here till the very end and I am staying with you." 

Mr Kostunica held an emergency session of a new Yugoslav parliament and later gave an address on Serbian state television in which he was presented as the "new Yugoslav President". He outlined his democratic vision for Yugoslavia and called for a return of "normality".

Mr Milosevic's precise whereabouts were unclear.Zoran Djindjic, a Serb opposition leader, said on state television last night that Mr Milosevic and his closest associates were in the eastern Serbian town of Bor, close to the Romanian and Bulgarian borders, and that he might be preparing a counter -attack.

War crimes investigators said that they were trying to arrest him. Special forces from Britain, America and France are known to be operating in the Balkans and were on alert for any possible capture of the toppled President.

As Mr Kostunica prepared to address both chambers of parliament, he called on world leaders to lift sanctions on the country, saying: "What we are doing today is history, but history is created by these people. We do not need Moscow and Washington, we are ready to liberate Serbia by ourselves." He issued a call for "peace" among citizens of Serbia and its neighbours.

World leaders welcomed the collapse of the Milosevic regime and pledged to support the demonstators. Tony Blair said that Britain was ready to begin a new chapter and forget past differences with the people of Serbia.

President Clinton said: "I think the people are trying to get their country back and we support democracy and the will of the Serbian people. The United States stands with people everywhere who are fighting for their freedom."

He ruled out American military intervention as inappropriate, even in the event of violent repression of the anti-Milosevic mass demonstrations. He also pledged to move quickly to lift sanctions on Yugoslavia once democracy was restored there. In Paris the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, said that the European Union was also ready to heed lift sanctions.

President Putin returned to Moscow from a visit to India. He would not say if he had offered Mr Milosevic safe haven. He said that violence could have "grave consequences," and that if it was not checked it would spread beyond Yugoslavia.

Milo Djukanovic, President of Montenegro, which is part of the Yugoslav Federation and which had boycotted the presidential election, said the last bastion of dictatorship in Europe had fallen.

Two people were reported killed in the protests. One girl was said to have died when she was run over by a bulldozer in front of the parliament building and three other people were injured by gunfire. About 100 people sustained other injuries.

On the streets last night the demonstrators had no doubts that they had won. From first light they had been pouring into Belgrade - miners, farmers, students - from every corner of the country. By mid-morning the crowd, already said to be 300,000 strong, began to converge on the parliament building. At first riot police stood their ground, firing teargas at those who forced their way towards the entrance. Protesters waving Serbian and opposition party flags nevertheless strode on. As the 3pm deadline set by the opposition for Mr Milosevic to stand down passed, those at the front of the crowd stormed past terrified security guards.

Police fled, some of them tearing off their helmets and joining the protest as those inside hurled portraits of Mr Milosevic through windows and set fire to the main lobby. Some used a stolen bulldozer to smash their way into the parliament as police fled through back exits where they coule be seen discarding their uniforms. Protesters appeared on balconies waving flags to the crowds below.

A group headed for the nearby state television headquarters. Within an hour, screens across the country went blank. Journalists working for the Yugoslav state news agency Tanjug also said that they were now "with the people of this country".

Orthodox priests last night joined protesters, many of them carrying Serbian flags. Police began to pull down their barricades at the Kolubara mine, near Belgrade. where strikers had given the crucial boost to the opposition movement.It had taken 12 hours for a mass act of civil disobedience to topple a Government.


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Times Newspapers Limited


295 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 8, 1999, Sunday, Final Edition


Serbs Move Church Toward Bully Pulpit; Patriarch Invited to Opposition Rally


William Branigin, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A26


LENGTH: 940 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


 

He is an unassuming man, barely five feet tall, with a long gray beard and collar-length white hair. Shunning the trappings of office, he rides around Belgrade in the crowded Russian-built trolleys that ply the streets and relishes mingling with ordinary people.

But the spry 84-year-old, who was born Gojko Stojicevic but now is known as Pavle, patriarch of the Serbian Orthodox Church, is becoming an increasingly important player in the struggle unfolding in Yugoslavia over the fate of President Slobodan Milosevic and the governance of the country. As pressure mounts on Milosevic to quit, many Serbs want the church to take a more active role. 

Opposition groups have asked the church to sponsor a transitional "government of experts" to run the country until elections are held, in the event that Milosevic is persuaded to step down. The patriarch has been invited to speak at a demonstration in Belgrade on Aug. 19 to rally popular support for the plan.

The church has already called for Milosevic to resign and is expected to back the proposed transitional government of technocrats and others who are not politicians, church officials said. Serbian Orthodox churches in the United States and other countries plan to hold prayer gatherings on Aug. 19 in solidarity with the rally. But Pavle so far has been noncommittal about his participation.

In an apparent effort to sidetrack the proposed transition plan, Yugoslav Prime Minister Momir Bulatovic, a staunch ally of Milosevic, has said he will reshuffle the cabinet and offer posts to opposition party members. There were no immediate takers.

Adding to the pressure, Montenegro has demanded a radical loosening of relations with Serbia in the Yugoslav federation, in effect seeking its dissolution.

The church weighed in strongly against Milosevic in June when its Holy Synod sharply denounced his policy in Kosovo and demanded that he give way to a "government of national salvation." Allies of Milosevic responded by calling Pavle and other church leaders traitors.

In the Serbian town of Valjevo, a top church official addressed a recent opposition rally for the first time since the current resignation drive started. In his speech, Bishop Artemije, who heads the Serbian Orthodox Church in Kosovo, took issue with a rally organizer's remark that Milosevic should be sent to the rebellious province.

"Don't send him to Kosovo, for God's sake," the bishop said. "Send him to The Hague." Milosevic is wanted there by an international tribunal for war crimes against Kosovo's ethnic Albanian population.

For his part, Patriarch Pavle "wants to be above political parties," said Dusan Batakovic, a historian and church adviser. "He will not issue more anti-Milosevic statements for fear there could be a civil war."

In a sermon last week at Belgrade's St. Marko Church, Pavle walked a fine line between Serbian responsibility for atrocities in Kosovo and the Serbs' historical sense of victimization. He denounced recent killings of Serbian residents of the province by vengeful ethnic Albanians and attacks on more than 30 Serbian churches.

"What little of our nation that is left down in Kosovo is getting killed," Pavle said. "These people were killed only for what they are, not for what they did."

Wearing a golden crown and holding a staff in one hand and a cross in the other as he spoke in the packed church, Pavle concluded: "We have to face the just judgment of God to see whether we have used the gifts that were given to us by God for good or evil, whether we were torturers and villains or we defended the just cause. Now in peace and unity, we should seek justice and salvation."

He made the remarks after a ceremony commemorating Serbs killed by Croatian forces during a mass expulsion from Croatia's Kraijina region in 1995. A church bulletin, which listed the names of victims, said 1,791 were killed or missing, including 997 civilians.

The ceremony illustrated some of the strains pulling Serbian society in different directions over Kosovo, a province containing 1,300 churches and monasteries and regarded as a cradle of the Serbian Orthodox faith. While many Serbs profess to have been shocked by the atrocities committed by forces loyal to Milosevic, others now revile him for having "lost" Kosovo.

Among the congregants were Serbs with a strong streak of nationalism, a sentiment that seems to be shared by some church officials. One worshiper carried a large black flag emblazoned with a skull and crossbones and the words, "Faith in God. Freedom or Death." A white-haired man in a military officer's uniform said he was a member of the Chetnik movement, a nationalist group that has fought for Serbian causes throughout the life of the Yugoslav federation.

A former priest, Zarko Gavrilovic, a staunch anti-communist who once urged the patriarch to excommunicate Milosevic, rejected the accounts of atrocities and said he felt betrayed by the recent U.S.-led NATO bombing campaign against Yugoslavia. "Until this bombing, I thought America was the leading Christian democratic country in the world," he said. "But now when one mentions America, I get a bitter taste in my mouth."

In an earlier ceremony at St. Marko Church, Milan Popovic, a 63-year-old former electrical engineer, said, "I know that Serbs committed some terrible crimes in Kosovo, but I doubt that many others here know."

Like many here, he said he now feels oppressed by Milosevic, but he holds out little hope that the church or the opposition can do much about it.

"I don't see a way out of the situation," Popovic said.


LOAD-DATE: August 08, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


296 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


December 2, 2004


Comment & Analysis: Bitter lemons: Six questions to the critics of Ukraine's orange revolution


BYLINE: Timothy Garton Ash


SECTION: Guardian Leader Pages, Pg. 25


LENGTH: 1308 words


 

Why are so many west Europeans being such lemons about Ukraine's orange revolution? Every day brings a new example of some feeble, back-handed or downright hostile reaction.

Yesterday, it was Simon Jenkins in the Times describing the crowds in Kiev as a "mob". (Dictionary definition: "a riotous or disorderly crowd of people; rabble".) Last week, it was Jonathan Steele in these pages, responding to my enthusiastic column about the Kiev events with such arguments as this: "Nor is there much evidence to imagine that, were he (the opposition candidate, Viktor Yushchenko) the incumbent president facing a severe challenge, he would not have tried to falsify the poll." Unpick that contorted hypothetical if you can.

In between, we have two representatives of a pressure group with a highly dubious track record, Mark Almond and John Laughland, informing us that somewhere behind or among the demonstrators were, respectively, agents of George Soros and Ukrainian, anti-semitic neo-Nazis. In the Berlin Tagesspiegel, I read a comparison of the opposition's tactics with those of Lenin in 1918; in Italy's La Repubblica, a commentary suggesting that Warsaw and Vilnius are trying to foist on the European Union a policy of destabilising the region. And so it goes on. 

For 25 years, I have heard these same old arguments against supporting the democratic oppositions in eastern Europe. Those oppositions, we are told, threaten European "stability". Behind or beside them are nasty nationalists and/or the CIA. We must respect the legitimate security interests of Moscow (an argument originally used to justify the continued existence of the Berlin Wall). A ghastly Pandora's box will be opened by . . . . . . . (fill this space with: Poland's Solidarnosc, Charter 77, the Leipzig demonstrators - sorry, mob - in 1989, anti-Milosevic students in Belgrade, Georgian rose revolutionaries, or now Ukrainians).

Oh yes, and tu quoque : someone else is just as bad, so a plague on both their houses. "Vladimir Putin," writes Simon Jenkins, "obliterated his opponents in Russia's last presidential election without a peep from the west." Well, exactly. But what follows from that is that we should have criticised Putin's election-rigging more strongly, not that we shouldn't criticise election-rigging in Ukraine.

Behind all these contorted reservations, we hear an inner voice which says, in effect, "Why won't all these bloody, semi-barbarian, east Europeans leave us alone, to go on living happily ever after in our right, tight, little west European (or merely British) paradise?" And, quite often, "Why are those bloody Americans stirring them up to disturb us?" For this is not a simple left-right divide. It's a divide between, on the one side, central and east Europeans inside the EU, together with Americans of left and right, and, on the other, west Europeans of both left and right. Not all west Europeans, to be sure. In fact, the EU has spoken out remarkably clearly on the election fraud, through its Dutch presidency and Spanish foreign minister. But many west Europeans.

Before I address some questions to the Reluctant West European, let me first acknowledge a few obvious home truths. This is a very dangerous situation. There is a real possibility of violence (a little has already happened in the east of the country), and of a painful split between Ukraine's more Russian-oriented east and the more western-oriented west. We must keep talking to Moscow as well as Kiev. And there is no such thing as the immaculate victim. The Bosnians in besieged Sarajevo were not immaculate victims, nor even were the Czechs in Charter 77. In Ukraine, a country with a tortured history of oppression (remember Stalin's deliberate famine, the "harvest of sorrow" in which around 14.5 million Ukrainians died), division and occupation, of evils done to and returned with interest by Ukrainians, that is especially true.

Ukraine has an appalling level of corruption, involving those on the opposition as well as the government side. Members or supporters of both do have connections to a mob, in its other sense, meaning mafia. What follows an opposition victory will be messy, disappointing to most of those young orange supporters in Kiev's Independence Square, and sometimes unsavoury, as in all post-communist countries. None of this means they don't have the right to try, if their candidate wins a new monitored election which is as free and fair as is possible in such circumstances.

Now my six questions to the Reluctant West European:

1. Can't you see the wood for the trees?

You point out some bad trees, but here's the shape of the wood: An election was stolen. Most of the orange revolutionaries want their country to enjoy more of the freedoms, rights and opportunities that we in western Europe enjoy, rather than being tied back closer to an increasingly authoritarian Russia. Wouldn't that be a good thing, for them and for us?

2. Do you think Ukrainians don't deserve democracy?

Please examine your attitude and see if it doesn't reflect some deep-seated prejudices of west Europeans towards the continent's other half, typecast for centuries as distant, exotic, mysterious, dark etc. A good test is to substitute, say, "Spaniards" or "French" for "Ukrainians" in any statement, and see how it reads.

3. Are you reluctant to support the orange movement just because the Americans do?

Put thus starkly, most people would say no. But some of the west European unease undoubtedly comes from the fact that American pro-democracy organisations have actively supported the Ukrainian opposition, and Washington does have a geostrategic agenda involving the expansion of Nato, military bases across central Asia etc. Yet the knee-jerk leftist or Euro-Gaullist reaction - "if the Americans are for it there must be something wrong with it" - is silly. Please consider the Ukrainian case on its own merits, not through an American or anti-American prism.

4. Why is Russia entitled to a sphere of influence, including Ukraine, if the United States is not entitled to a sphere of influence, including Nicaragua?

The truth is, neither Moscow nor Washington is entitled to such a sphere. There are hard realities of economic, military and political power with which the smaller, weaker neighbours of great powers have to deal. In the case of Ukraine, this is further complicated by the cultural and ethnic identification of many eastern Ukrainians with Russia. But these are constraints with which Ukraine must deal itself, as a sovereign state. The country of Yalta (a town in the Ukrainian Crimea) should not be subjected to a new Yalta.

5. Would you rather have George Bush or Vladimir Putin?

Preferably neither. Given the choice between Bush and Putin, I choose Marilyn Monroe. But it's incredible that so many west Europeans, including Chancellor Schroder of Germany, seem to prefer as their partner an ex-KGB officer currently reimposing authoritarian rule in Russia over a man who, for all his faults, has just been re-elected in a free and fair election in one of the world's great democracies.

6. If you don't like the Americans taking the lead in Ukraine, why don't we?

To some extent we already are. At the negotiating tables in Kiev yesterday, there was Javier Solana from Brussels, the Polish and Lithuanian presidents, and a senior Russian official, but not, so far as I know, any senior American. And that's right. This is a version of our European model of peaceful revolution, with the aim of rejoining Europe, not America. Now it's up to us to support it, with all the peaceful means at our disposal. These include saying that, in our interest as well as theirs, a democratic Ukraine deserves a place in the European Union. Agreed?

www.freeworldweb.net


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 2004


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2004 Guardian Newspapers Limited


297 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


July 7, 1999, Wednesday


THOUSANDS RALLY FOR MILOSEVIC'S RESIGNATION


BYLINE: Alex Todorvic In Uzice


SECTION: Pg. 9


LENGTH: 738 words


 

THOUSANDS of angry Serbs rallied in the central Serbian town of Uzice yesterday to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic, who was branded by opposition leaders as a "false prophet".

"Leave, Slobo, leave!" the crowd chanted in sweltering heat as they greeted Zoran Djindjic of the Democratic Party and other activists of the Alliance for Change, the leading umbrella group of Serbia's pro-democracy, anti-Milosevic parties.

"We must go on to the end so that Serbia can have a new start. Ever day we must be every street and stay there until he (Milosevic) leaves," Mr Djindjic told the crowd. "We are not here to celebrate victories, but to see how to survive the defeat (by NATO). 

"In the coming months we will turn to civil disobedience, and with the help of (Serb Orthodox) Patriarch Pavle, will establish a transitional government," Mr Djindjic said to a raucous wave of applause and cheers.

Civil disobedience would begin in towns controlled by the opposition, he said. Church bells would toll to call people to the streets. "The police can arrest individuals, but they cannot arrest us all," he said.

Mr Djindjic was the keynote speaker at the "Now or Never" rally, the second large protest organised by the alliance.

No substantial police presence was visible at the demonstration. Mr Djindjic returned on Sunday to Serbia where a warrant for his arrest was issued last month for evading military conscription. He fled to Montenegro at the beginning of the conflict after state television accused him of being a traitor.

As the rally opened, students showered the square with leaflets portraying a clenched fist with the slogan "Resist".

Every mention of the Milosevic family was followed by whistling and shouts of "Red bandits" and "stand up, Serbia".

The mayor of Cacak, Velimir Ilic, the other speaker sought for arrest by the army, was greeted with chants of his nickname, "Velyo".

"They (the Milosevics) have brought the greatest shame and misfortune in history upon our country," he said. "They persecute people who fight for truth and democracy. As a Serb, I'm ashamed that such people exist. We must drive them out."

Raising his voice, he said the Milosevic family should be put on a reservation to be examined by scientists as the last living examples of Bolshevism in Europe. Milan St Protic, a historian, told the crowd that Serbs had followed a false prophet: "For the first time in hundreds of years, we've been shamed.

And this anti-Christ government is responsible."

Local police banned the meeting 45 minutes before it was scheduled to begin.

Electricity for the public address system was cut off, but local citizens hurriedly brought a generator to the scene and restored power.

"When all those who protect Milosevic go home tonight, let them think about how much this government will cost their children," Mr Djindjic said as the rally drew to a close.

Elsewhere, a few thousand people took to the streets in the southern Serbian town of Leskovac, demanding the resignation of a local governor loyal to Mr Milosevic. The protesters clashed with police when they approached a police station to demand the release of an activist jailed there for organising a rally on Monday.

Ivan Novkovic, an employee at a local TV station, became an instant celebrity when he interrupted the station's programme last week to urge people to rally against the allegedly corrupt local official.

Mr Novkovic was yesterday jailed for 30 days for disturbing the peace.

In Novi Sad, the second-largest Yugoslav city to come under bombardment during the NATO air campaign, the city council joined the chorus demanding Mr Milosevic's resignation.

In Belgrade, in another blow to Mr Milosevic, Serbia's main opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, said that under no circumstances would he join a coalition government led by the pro-Milosevic premier, Momir Bulatovic.

Mr Draskovic, who has so far refused to join the Alliance, said that Mr Bulatovic must resign to make way for a transition government. The new premier, he said, should come from a pro-Western party led by the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic - an avowed opponent of Mr Milosevic.

Mr Milosevic has been trying to lure Mr Draskovic, leader the Serbian Renewal Movement Party, into the government in order to create a broad alliance and sideline other opposition leaders.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


298 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


December 1, 2000


FREEDOM SONGS: In Serbia, western pop is bitterly known as 'Nato music' and folk songs have been a vital tool in the struggle against Milosevic. Robin Denselow reports on a land where pop and politics do mix


BYLINE: Robin Denselow


SECTION: Guardian Friday Pages, Pg. 10


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

It is early evening on Saturday October 7, two days after the storming of the federal parliament in Belgrade. In the coal mining town of Lazarevac, 30 miles south of the Serbian capital, the entire population seems to be making its way to a triumphant free concert that marks Slobodan Milosevic's departure. A small wooden stage has been erected between the traffic lights across the main road, next to the small hotel and cluster of bars that mark the centre of town. An incongruous blend of old Queen anthems, local folk music and Irish dance tunes blare from the speakers as the crowd wait for their new heroes to arrive.

First comes the strike committee of miners who have defied the Milosevic police and paramilitaries by closing down the vast open-cast pits that scar the countryside. Arms held aloft in triumph, they are greeted by a middle-aged man in a black sweatshirt.

This is Djordje Balasevic, Serbia's most celebrated singer. During the Milosevic era, he was censored, exiled, and under constant fear of arrest, but his songs became a rallying cry for students, miners and all Serb voters who clamoured for change. 

This, he says, is his first concert in "free Serbia", and he congratulates the miners and townspeople for making it possible. Then he eases into a solo ballad before bringing on his band of guitars, bass, keyboards and saxophone, for a gloriously emotional show. They start with a protest song, Ne Lomite Mi Bagrenje ("Don't Harm My Acacia Trees"), an allegorical tale which has been interpreted as an attack on Milosevic and has, says Balasevic, become a song of "good versus evil, of youth and suffering, and all those people who have had to leave Serbia". Then they sing Slobodane, written eight years ago but not recorded until 1998, in time to become an anthem for the student protest movement. The title indicates that the first part of Milosevic's first name means "free" and the second part "no". Hence "no freedom".

Balasevic's songs have the sturdy melodies of good country ballads, mixed with a dash of blues. The crowd know all the words, and sing them back at him across the square. He's a fine raconteur, mixing the music with long, rambling stories. One ridicules Milosevic's TV appearance the previous evening, and his claim that he was stepping down to "spend more time with my grandson".

Milosevic's downfall was partly a cultural revolution, fought out in songs from both sides of the political spectrum. In Britain, the idea that political pop can be hazardous seems far-fetched, but there is a depressing history of political singers being persecuted because of their work. Balasevic follows in the footsteps of Pete Seeger, banned by the US in the 1950s during the HUAC anti-communist witch-hunts; Victor Heredia, banned by the military junta in Argentina; Fela Kuti, whose club was attacked by the Nigerian army; and Victor Jara, killed in the Santiago massacres during the Pinochet coup.

Milosevic also used terror against his opponents, and Balasevic says he felt threatened by the militias and secret police. A "rock'n'roll child", influenced by "Pink Floyd, the Beatles and electric guitars", he had already established a popular following across the Balkans by the time Milosevic came to power. Then his livelihood was taken away from him. For a decade, his songs were never played on state television - a situation only rectified after the storming of the Federal parliament. When Balasevic's wife rushed in to tell him that he was back on the air, he was astonished. "I could hardly recognise myself," he says, "because all the recordings they had of me were so old."

During the Milosevic years he retreated to the house where he was born, up in the northern town of Novi Sad (a target for the Nato bombs that destroyed the bridges across the Danube). "I didn't dare leave the house for two months," he says. "I'd been threatened with arrest as a deserter because I refused to fight in Croatia - I have fans and friends there."

He spent his time writing four books, which were printed privately and sold from the house, along with cassettes of his songs, and in the later years he was able to give a few low-key concerts, but was never allowed to promote himself or book any large-scale venues. For much of the time he lived as a refugee, across the border in Slovenia, but then began touring, as "I could go anywhere except my home in Serbia". He travelled across the Balkans, and sang to the Serb communities in Australia and Britain. He kept writing songs, and even managed to keep recording. His last album, Deveste (The 1990s), was the story of a lost decade. The title track dealt, he said, "with just how great the 1960s were, and how things have been getting worse in Serbia ever since". Recorded secretly in Belgrade and in Slovenia, the CDs were smuggled back across the border. Smuggling became something of a national pastime in Serbia; criminal gangs and border police were all involved. There were, said Balasevic, "so many corrupt police officers, there was no real problem getting my CDs back here".

Over the past two years, his songs have found a new audience in the student supporters of the Serbian resistance. As the elections approached, they organised rock concerts to encourage the anti-Milosevic vote, and plastered Belgrade with their slogan Gotob Je! (He's Finished!). Pirate CDs helped to inspire the students, much to the fury of the authorities.

One of the best of those CDs, Gotob Je!, features a ripped election poster of Milosevic on the front cover. Four of the 16 songs on the compilation are by Balasevic, including Slobodane and Zveti Slobodno ("To Live Freely"), a song from the Deveste album which had become a firm favourite with student activists and others opposed to Milosevic. "I'd been waiting to sing it live for over a year," says Balasevic, "and when I did eventually get to sing it for the first time, it was alongside Kostunica at a rally in Belgrade, in front of an audience of half a million people. The students had been using the song, it had been played on B92 (the independent radio station closed last year by the authorities but now back in business) and everyone knew the words."

Young Serbs want to tell visitors that their country is not full of Slobodan-supporting murderers and monsters, and that the image built up in the west during the Bosnia and Kosovo conflicts is one-sided. Belgrade is keen to present the image of a modern European city, and English visitors are likely to be quizzed about the Nato bombing campaign ("how could you do that to us when so many were against Milosevic?"), then asked about English football and western pop. This is now referred to, somewhat bitterly, as "Nato music", but B92 seemed to be playing a solid diet of Pulp last month. The bootleg CDs of the anti-Milosevic campaign have proved that home-made Serbian pop is a force to be reckoned with, and can be witty, original and brave.

But that was just one side of the political pop equation. Balasevic complains that, "far too many of my colleagues simply went along with Milosevic, so they could appear on TV and travel as they wished. If more of us had come together during Croatia and Bosnia we could have done something."

Then there were the musicians seen as advocates of the Serb nationalism that led Milosevic to his bloody military adventures. Throughout the late 1990s, the musical pin-up in Serbia was Ceca Raznatovic, known as Ceca. Unlike Balasevic, she was constantly on Serbian TV. It was Ceca, says Balasevic, who "provided the soundtrack for the Milosevic movie".

Ceca's powerful voice and declamatory, theatrical style mixes the Middle Eastern/ Turkish-sounding influences of southern Serbia with wailing fuzzed guitars and heavy synthesised riffs. Her image is equally brash. For her latest CD, Ceca 2000, she poses in skimpy purple plastic, and blue bondage bra and pants. Nothing dangerously political in that, one might think, but what makes the ruling queen of Serbian "turbo-folk" so special is that she's the widow of Zelko Raznatovic, better known as Arkan. And Arkan was the most notorious and feared of all the gang-leaders and warlords who emerged during the Milosevic era. In January this year Arkan was gunned down in Belgrade, discovered by his wife in a pool of blood. He was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital. A group of men accused of Arkan's murder, including an off-duty policeman, are now on trial in Belgrade.

Balasevic is scathing about her musical standing: "She's a folk singer from the south of Serbia, and folk music was used to boost Serb nationalism. When people get drunk they sing about knives and war. It's primitive music and it was always on TV. Turbo-folk was a kind of terror music, but if it's on TV all the time you get used to it. Now I hope we can forget it."

The overthrow of Milosevic has transformed the country's cultural scene. While the one-time queen of Serbian pop attends a murder trial, the singer who suffered the most under Milosevic finds that his life has changed for the better. He can give concerts in his homeland, and is being feted as an international celebrity. In his years in exile in Slovenia he accepted an offer from the United Nations to become UN "goodwill ambassador" for south-east Europe. Last month he flew to New York to take part in a celebrity bash. Recovering from the failure of the Middle East peace talks, Kofi Annan surrounded himself with a motley crew of 40 goodwill superstars, ranging from Mohammed Ali to Geri Halliwell, Susan Sarandon, Michael Douglas, Mia Farrow, Youssou N'Dour and Seamus Heaney. "I was treated like a hero," says a delighted Balasevic.

Back in Serbia, he is preparing a victory concert in the capital. "For years I had managed to give an annual show in Belgrade, but I had no media support, so two years ago I said I wouldn't play another major concert in the city until Milosevic had gone. At that point I had played 99 concerts in Belgrade, and I wanted the 100th show to be really special." The Belgrade victory concert will take place on Monday in the National Theatre in Belgrade.

But are the dangerous times really over? Before leaving Belgrade, I browse through booths of smuggled CDs along the main pedestrian walkway, Knez Mihajlova. Copies of Ceca 2000 are selling well alongside Balasevic and the anti-Milosevic compilations. I'm not sure they're home and dry.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Guardian Newspapers Limited


299 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


April 25, 1999, Sunday, Home Edition


NATO can still fight war with words;
Before the airstrikes, we should have bombarded the Yugoslav population with information.


BYLINE: Tom Teepen, Cox News Service


SOURCE: AJC


SECTION: Perspective; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 521 words


The smartest idea so far in all the back-and-forth and busy second- guessing over NATO's war against Serbia comes from former U.S. Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia.

Which is not surprising. Even a couple of years distant from office, the longtime Democratic chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee is still crackling smart about military policy and the tricky places where that blends with foreign policy. 

Nunn is making the point in interviews that in dicey situations like the one in the Balkans, where civil war and ethnic hatred mix, U.S. military and civilian planners first need to unleash not their bombs and missiles, but an aggressive information campaign.

Our failure to make it clear to Serbian civilians just what horrors Slobodan Milosevic was committing in their name in Kosovo and the reasonable compromises NATO was pressing for has made the NATO attack seem arbitrary and merely abusive to most Serbians. The effect has been clear in interviews as even longtime anti-Milosevic Serbs angrily take up with the man they were working just weeks ago to be rid of.

NATO's efforts to catch up now, with the bombs dropping, have obvious credibility problems. The field has been ceded to the manipulative, hypernationalist government-controlled media of Serbia.

The democracies, Nunn says, need what he calls ''a new set of tools'' --- in effect, information warfare --- as a potential first resort.

The basic idea is hardly new. Allied planes dropped propaganda leaflets in World War I. Something far more sophisticated is called for now.

Voice of America and other established means for getting the word out should be targeted to specific policy purposes, Nunn says. Even if that failed to deter an authoritarian regime like Milosevic's, the civilian readiness to see a nasty conflict through would be softened.

The military, too, needs an upfront ability to press an information campaign itself --- much of its current limited capacity is in the reserves -- - and, if hostilities start, should take out opposition media, Nunn says. The nation's information war ''capacities are not well inserted into doctrine.'' The need is ''to get them into the minds of policy-makers'' as part of any war plan.

Nunn sees NATO's failure first to make its case compellingly as having a potentially disastrous side effect in U.S.-Russian relations. Russian anti- American sentiment is running stronger now, he says, than during the Cold War. Then, the Soviet government was pushing the people to be anti-American; now the Russian people are pushing their government to be anti-American.

Unless that can be fixed --- perhaps by involving Russia in a solution, though Nunn says that could be a ''migraine headache'' --- populist anti- Americanism could bring Communists and nationalists to power in Russia's December elections.

NATO and the United States, Nunn says, have ''good motives, the instincts are humanitarian.'' Those instincts and motives will have a harder time prevailing when they are lost on the very people for whom they are intended.


Tom Teepen's column appears Sundays and Tuesdays.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo
Silenced: NATO struck Serbian state television headquarters in Belgrade early Friday, knocking Yugoslavia's main station off the air./ Associated Press
Graphic
ETHNIC AND CIVIL WARS WORLDWIDE
Kosovo is currently the most publicized conflict, but ethnic hatreds, civil wars and oppression are all too common phenomena. Here are many of the world's conflicts.
Nation
Conflict / Death toll / Clinton administration action
Sundan
16-year civil war, pitting fundamentalist Arab Islamists of northern Sudan against black Christians and animists in the south / Estimated 1.9 million since 1983 / $ 1 billion in food relief
Tibet
Ever since China seized Tibet in 1949, human rights groups have reported torture, killings and religious suppression./ Estimates range as high as 1.2 million / In 1994, " delinked" trade matters from Beijing's record on human rights; in 1997, appointed a special coordinator for Tibetan issues
Rwanda
Extremists among Hutu majority in 1994 launched genocide against Tutsi minority./ 800,000, perhaps 1 million / Pentagon provided massive humanitarian aid
Anglola
25- year civil war. Formerly U.S.-backed Jonas Savimbi, refusing to accept elections, battles central government./ 1 million over 25 years; 300,000 since 1992 / U.S. diplomats, along with officials from Portugal and Russia, monitor the ailing 1994 peace agreement.
Somalia
Ouster of dictator in 1991 unleashed a civil war that still rages./ About 300,000 in the ensuing famine in 1992 and 1993; more since then / Intervened from late 1992 to late 1994 with 25,000 troops; 30 troops died, including 18 in a bloody Mogadishu firefight
Liberia
Seven-year civil war with ethnic overtones / As many as 250,000; 700,000 displaced / Helped finance 10-nation peacekeeping force; spent $ 7.5 million to help ensure a fair 1997 election
Bosnia and Herzegovina
Move for Bosnian independence in 1991 aroused opposition from Serbs whose forces "ethnically cleansed" Serb areas of Muslims and Croats./ More than 200,000; hundreds of thousands displaced / Economic embargo bombing and intervention by 20,000 U.S. troops; 6,000 U.S. troops remain
Indonesia
East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that Indonesia invaded and annexed in 1975, fights for independence./ As many as 200,000 Supports international peacekeeping or observer force and a "peace and stability council" for fractious region
Algeria
Seven-year civil war of militant Islamic groups against secularist military government / Between 65,000 and 80,000 / Participated in 1998 U.N. fact-finding trip; offered to send observers for a new election
Sri Lanka
Since 1983, secessionist Tamil guerrillas have waged a war against the Sinhalese Sri Lankan majority./ 56,000 / Regarding the Tamil Tigers as terrorists; helping train anti-terrorist squads for the Sri Lankan government
Chechnya
21-month war between Russian forces and separatist Muslims ended in cease-fire in 1996./ 40,000 / President Clinton letter to Boris Yeltsin saying conflict could not be settled militarily
Turkey
15-year military and terrorist effort by Kurdish separatists to establish autonomy in southeast Turkey / 37,000 / Military aid to Turkey, a NATO ally; helped Turkey track and arrest Abdullah Ocalan, leader of Kurdish separatist movement
Nagorno-Karabakh
Muslim Azerbaijan and Christian Armenia fought a five-year war over this ethnically Armenian enclave in about 20 percent of Azerbaijan. A cease-fire was reached in 1994./ 35,000; hundreds of thousands of refugees / Diplomatic efforts, with France and Russia, to draw up a peace agreement; $ 12.5 million in humanitarian aid
Kashmir
Some Kashmiri rebels want independence from India; some want association with Pakistan./ 25,000 in past nine years / Offers of mediation if both sides request it
Democratic Republic of Congo
Two-year civil war, largely a fallout from Rwandan civil war and collapse of 30-year rule of Mobutu Sese Seko, in what was called Zaire / As many as 10,000 in past year / Active diplomacy working toward cease-fire, including the appointment of a special envoy to African Great Lakes region
Eritrea
Fierce border dispute between Eritrea and Ethiopia / 10,000 in recent months / Active but unnoticed diplomacy, including brokering an agreement by both sides not to use air power and sending a special envoy to the region
Sierra Leone
Civil war, with rural rebels trying to depose elected urban government/ 3,000 since January / Supports a multinational military force to keep elected government in power
Northern Ireland
30 years of sectarian violence between Catholics and Protestants / 3,200 over 30 years / Extensive multiyear involvement, including special ambassadors, participation in peace talks and personal intervention by President Clinton
Kosovo
Albanian Kosovars seek independence after 10 years of suppression by Serbian government./ 2,000 in past year; 250,000 displaced / Diplomatic pressure culminating in NATO airstrikes
Haiti
Civil strife and political assassinations began in 1991 when military elite overthrew elected president. Tens of thousands of people fled to Florida in boats. / Hundreds / 20,000 troops intervened in 1994; no U. S. combat deaths; 500 U.S. troops remain
 
Map of the world locates the countries mentioned above.
Source: National Journal / DALE E. DODSON / Staff


Copyright 1999 The Atlanta Constitution


300 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


June 3, 1998, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


A 3-front attack on a Balkan boss: Slobodan Milosevic's grip on power in the Yugoslav federation is weakening. Fighting in Kosovo province, agitation in Montenegroor student and civic unrest could break it, a Vancouver Balkan-watcher observes. And th


BYLINE: LENARD COHEN; SPECIAL TO THE SUN


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A17


LENGTH: 1573 words


 

Slobodan Milosevic has clung to power in Yugoslavia for more than a decade, thanks to his tight control of the media, the police and the dwindling assets of a deteriorated economy.

But the erosion of Milosevic's position has recently accelerated and his efforts at political survival have assumed the character of a three-front war.

[1] A power struggle with politically non-conformist Montenegro. This small republic of less than 700,000 people makes up, with Serbia, the two-unit, 10-million-strong Yugoslav federation.

[2] An undeclared war with the independence-seeking Albanians in Serbia's southern province of Kosovo

[3] A confrontation with students and faculty at Belgrade University who have found a new pretext to resume anti-regime protests. 

Now, the most serious current threat to Milosevic comes from Montenegrin voters' decision late last year to elect a vocal anti-Milosevic reformer, 36-year-old Milo Djukanovic, as president of their republic. Djukanovic and his Montenegrin reform team not only advocate pluralist democracy, multiculturalism and economic "marketization," but they are also harshly critical of the isolationist and neo-communist policies of the regime in Belgrade. They refuse to support Milosevic's effort to expand the power of Yugoslavia's federal presidency.

Because Djukanovic was previously associated with the Milosevic ruling power structure, he serves as a magnet for both disenchanted regime officials who secretly yearn for an orderly end to authoritarian rule and also for opposition elements who have vainly sought a fresh leader with a coherent reform program. Milosevic has not taken the Montenegrin challenge lightly.

For example, hoping to constrain the Montenegrin reformers, and also to tip the scales in last Sunday's legislative elections, Milosevic arranged the removal of Yugoslavia's federal prime minister, a Montenegrin who had declined taking strong measures against Djukanovic after the latter's electoral victory in 1997. He also named as his successor Djukanovic's chief political rival, Momir Bulatovic, a former president of Montenegro and a Belgrade loyalist.

Preliminary results from the election indicate a decisive victory for Djukanovic's coalition (taking 51 per cent of the vote, compared with 34 per cent for the anti-reformers), thereby raising the political temperature considerably. Milosevic and Bulatovic may now attempt to covertly destabilize Montenegro to create a pretext for Belgrade to impose some kind of martial law.

This approach would add insult to injury and could provoke Montenegrin secession from the federation, which might lead to civil war. Though most Montenegrins view their community as a branch of the Serbian ethnic family, they deeply resent the manipulation of their republic by Belgrade politicians.

Montenegrin resistance to Belgrade has been reinforced by Milosevic's strategy in Kosovo where, since late February, violence has escalated between Serb security forces and local Albanians. Djukanovic does not support the demand for independence by Kosovo Albanians or the call in some quarters for the creation of a third "Kosovo Republic" within Yugoslavia, which would be three times the size of Montenegro in population.

But the Montenegrin president blames Milosevic for precipitating an armed struggle by Albanians in Kosovo and favours international mediation of the Kosovo problem - a position rejected by Milosevic and a large majority of Serbs.

Even without the Montenegrin problem, the Kosovo crisis has become extremely serious for Milosevic. Because large numbers of Kosovo's roughly two million Albanians are now disenchanted with the non-violent strategy of their leaders, the Albanian guerrilla movement in the province (the Kosovo Liberation Army) is rapidly growing stronger in terms of both size and equipment. Fighting between the Yugoslav army and Albanian guerrilla forces has already claimed the life of more than 200 civilians.

The flow of arms into Kosovo from neighbouring Albania, where the government is not in control of the northern portion of the country, has also stimulated Kosovo's radicalization. Last week, NATO ministers took some limited measures to help Albania and Macedonia protect their border zones to avert spillover from the Kosovo conflict.

Many members of the international community want to head off the danger of a general Balkan conflagration. And they are uncomfortable with the idea of assisting Kosovo's secession from Yugoslavia. But there remains mixed feelings about indirectly assisting Milosevic by depriving the Kosovo Albanians entirely of any outside military assistance.

Diplomatic efforts to avoid a violent secessionist scenario have also been intensified.

After some arm twisting in Belgrade by American envoy Richard Holbrooke, talks have begun between Serbian officials and Kosovo's Albanian political leaders - a kind of simulated dialogue or a - dialogue about dialogue."

Few believe, however, that Milosevic, who has recently brought ultra-nationalist leaders of the Serb Radical Party into the Serbian government, will rush to grant substantial autonomy to Kosovo. Indeed, playing the anti-Albanian card is a conventional method used by Milosevic to drum up popular support.

But international pressure and the exigencies of the anti-Serb guerrilla struggle in Kosovo may force Milosevic, who personally cares little for Kosovo, to make a deal Albanians perceive as favourable. Should he do so, he will undoubtedly face new and equally disruptive resistance from radical nationalists in Serbia. Ironically, Milosevic began his political ascent by mobilizing Serbian grievances over Kosovo; he now finds that issue haunting his political survival.

(Violence in Kosovo has erupted again. The latest Associated Press dispatch from the Balkans reports that hundreds of villagers fled across the border to Albania Tuesday to escape heavy fighting between Serb security forces and rebels.)

Milosevic is also battling on a third front closer to home. His autocratic tactics have managed to resuscitate the anti-regime ardour of Belgrade students and intelligentsia. During the winter of 1996/97, demonstrations forced Milosevic to reverse his annulment of the opposition's electoral victories.

The unity of the opposition was soon shattered, however, after its leaders began squabbling. A number of new student organizations then retreated to the universities where their leaders debated Serbia's predicament. But only weeks ago, after the government prepared a bill to limit university self-government, raise student fees and tighten admission requirements, the regime provided new impetus for student political mobilization.

Initially, protests at Belgrade University remained small, but the government has now formally adopted the restrictive legislation it promised, and that action may provide a new outlet for the considerable youth and urban dissatisfaction that exists in Yugoslavia. The 1996/97 demonstrations turned into a cathartic "carnival" and with a few exceptions the police and army remained loyal to the regime.

But Milosevic's front lines are now more extended, his foes (especially the Albanians and reformist Montenegrins) have become far more dangerous, and his allies rather less reliable.

If Milosevic is increasingly desperate, he still holds an ace in the hole. Namely, for the moment there seems to be no political figure who can take his place, and also effectively ensure Yugoslavia's relative political stability. Thus, the fractious opposition lacks a strong leader, and Djukanovic, for all of his popularity, remains a regional figure.

Milosevic also continues to prop up and carefully control radical nationalist figures to show the international community that should the current regime be pushed out, things might even get worse. While there is widespread aversion in the international community to doing business with Milosevic, such sentiment is overshadowed by the anxiety that any chaotic power shift in Belgrade might violently destabilize Southeastern Europe. The disruption of the enormous international investment in Bosnia's reconstruction is of particular concern.

Still, while Milosevic can't easily be counted out, a scenario similar to recent events in Indonesia is no longer far-fetched. The problems of the regime in Belgrade have significantly multiplied. Yugoslavia's economy continues its downward slide with its accompanying societal criminalization and violence (including the assassination of Milosevic cronies).

Should an anti-Milosevic group from within the existing oligarchy join forces with elements of the weakened but still lethal armed forces, Milosevic will find it difficult to politically survive.

Significant escalation of fighting in Kosovo, serious strife connected with obstreperous Montenegro or a resumption of student and civic unrest could become triggers for such a rapid and dramatic change in power. It has been credibly rumoured that in 1992, at the request of then Yugoslav president Dobrica Cosic, Milosevic had agreed to gracefully resign office, only to back out of the deal at the last moment.

Stubborn, dedicated solely to the pursuit of power for its own sake and fearing possible international retribution for his wartime policies in Bosnia, Milosevic is highly unlikely to slip quietly into retirement.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1998


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH



GRAPHIC: Photo: (Slobodan) Milosevic
Photo: Files, Vancouver Sun / WHY EARLY RETIREMENT IS UNLIKELY: Milosevic fears international retribution for his wartime policies in Bosnia. In April Albanians, dressed as UN soldiers,paraded in The Hague an effigy of the Serb leader to publicize their demand for a war crimes trial for Milosevic.

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

301 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


September 25, 2000, Monday, Edition 1


MILOSEVIC MAY FACE RUNOFF MILOSEVIC OPPONENT CLAIMING VICTORY


BYLINE: Olivia Ward


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 849 words


 

PETER VUJANIC/REUTERS

But Yugoslav leader insists he's ahead in vote plagued by irregularities

EUROPEAN BUREAU

PODGORICA, Yugoslavia - President Slobodan Milosevic and his opponents were locked in a bitter election race after Yugoslavs turned out in large numbers in chaotic voting yesterday.

Yugoslavia's once struggling opposition claimed victory and urged Milosevic to peacefully quit power after 13 years of hardline rule.

Milosevic, however, showed no signs of conceding defeat. His spokesperson, Nikola Sainovic, said early today he doubted there would even be a need for the Oct. 8 run-off vote - required if no candidate gets more than 50 per cent - because "our candidate is leading." 

As both supporters and opponents of the Yugoslav leader claimed they were ahead in the presidential vote, the state election commission closed up for the night.

With official results not expected until tomorrow, rival Serbian political parties were issuing their own results based on a partial count.

Supporters of main opponent Vojislav Kostunica, a 56-year-old Belgrade lawyer backed by a coalition of 19 opposition factions, said he was leading with 57 per cent to 33 per cent for Milosevic based on returns from 45 per cent of 10, 000 polling stations.

"According to our count, the first-round victory is certain," Kostunica said early today. "Dawn is coming to Serbia. I'm excited."

"There is no doubt that we overwhelmingly won on all levels," said opposition campaign manager Zoran Djindjic, who gave Kostunica 49.6 per cent of the vote to Milosevic's 36.8 per cent, with 310,909 votes counted.

Meanwhile, Milosevic's Socialist party claimed that Milosevic was leading Kostunica by 44 to 41 per cent with more than 940,000 votes counted.

However, the ultra-nationalist Radical Party, once a member of Milosevic's coalition but now estranged, put Kostunica ahead with 53.53 per cent to Milosevic's 37.91 per cent with 1,937,734 votes counted at 4,358 polling stations.

The party admitted its own candidate, one of three others in the race, was defeated.

In Belgrade, thousands of opposition supporters declared victory in a central square near the site of a rock concert held to celebrate a win for Milosevic. Armed riot police kept the two sides apart, and there were reports of clashes between police and opposition demonstrators on a nearby bridge.

Yugoslavs hoping for change after a decade of despair had turned out for yesterday's vote, which poll watchers said was marked by widespread irregularities.

In Serbia, 7.8 million people were eligible to vote for a federal president and parliament and for municipal politicians. Montenegro had 444,000 registered to vote, along with 100,000 Serbs from Kosovo.

The Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a private group that monitored voting, reported a turnout of 74.6 per cent in Serbia.

Milosevic altered the Yugoslav constitution to give him the chance to extend his term another four years, with the possibility of running for a further term. Montenegro, the smaller partner in the Yugoslav federation, declared the changes invalid, and vowed to boycott the elections, which its liberal government rejected.

Election monitors from the Democratic Opposition of Serbia coalition supporting Kostunica complained yesterday of lack of access at some polls, and condemned the voting rules. Observers in Belgrade complained they were kicked by police, and in Zitorade, central Serbia, there were reports soldiers were issued with ballots pre-marked for Milosevic.

Vote-rigging was predicted by many analysts, but most were holding their breath for the next developments.

"It's only an illusion that Milosevic will leave power," warned Miodrag Vukovic, an adviser to Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic. "Those who think so forget who he is."

The coming days will indicate more clearly which way Milosevic will move, as results are announced by an electoral commission made up largely of his supporters.

Opposition members say much depends, too, on how many people will take to the streets if Kostunica is declared the loser in a fraudulent poll.

Since the enormous anti-Milosevic demonstrations of 1996 and 1997, those who hoped for a democratic transition were disillusioned by the fracturing of the opposition, which led to the Serbian strongman's triumph.

Milosevic, surviving through force and guile, took control of most of the Serbian media, and harassed and intimidated any who defied him.

Meanwhile, attempts at revving up public anger failed as factional opposition leaders squabbled. The tide turned when Kostunica became coalition leader.

Milosevic's opponents know they must turn out in great strength to prevent the notoriously brutal leader from crushing the new movement, if he tries to hang on to power after a dubious win.

Some analysts predict Milosevic might allow Kostunica victory, but block him from making any important reforms through control over parliament.

With files from Reuters


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2000


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: STREET ANGER:
An opposition supporter kicks a poster of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic as polls close in Belgrade yesterday. Both sides were soon claiming victory.


Copyright 2000 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


302 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


December 23, 2000 Saturday FINAL EDITION


Last call for Milosevic: Today's election in Serbia is seen as one final chance for voters to once and for all rid Yugoslavia of Slobodan Milosevic.


BYLINE: Scott Taylor


SECTION: WORLD, Pg. B1 / Front Scott Taylor


LENGTH: 1670 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE


BELGRADE - For the second time in three months, Serbians are headed to the polls today to determine their nation's destiny.

Posters across Serbia proclaim, "One more step to the finish line!" in an effort to encourage voters to once and for all rid Yugoslavia of Slobodan Milosevic and his Socialist party.

Although the dramatic October uprising forced Mr. Milosevic to accept defeat and concede his federal Yugoslav presidency to Vojislav Kostunica, Mr. Milosevic's socialists remained in control of the Serbian republic parliament. Today's election is seen as a crucial hurdle for Mr. Kostunica if his fledgling coalition government -- Democratic Opposition Party of Serbia (DOS) -- is to consolidate its power base.

What remains of Yugoslavia at the federal level are the republics of Serbia and Montenegro. With economic ties between the two already partially severed and Montenegro's separatist president, Milo Djukanovic, threatening a referendum on independence, Mr. Kostunica's umbrella level of government could be ousted. 

With so much at stake, DOS is trying to once again capitalize on the tremendous wave of anti-Milosevic Serb sentiment that swept Mr. Kostunica to power.

The party's election slogans encourage voters to "clean out" the rot of socialism. Since taking office 12 weeks ago, Mr. Kostunica and his coalition cabinet have embarked on a whirlwind campaign of domestic housecleaning and international bridge-building. But despite the tremendous efforts, Mr. Kostunica conceded this week that the situation he inherited was even worse than expected.

"In some cases, we knew what we were getting into, in other cases, they were either far more complex -- or complete surprises," he said.

Of particular concern is the worsening situation with Montenegro's possible secession.

"We had been led to believe that Milosevic was the major obstacle to a successful union, but it appears that the problem goes much deeper," said Mr. Kostunica.

Even among Serbians, the prospect of breaking ties with Montenegro has become a growing popular sentiment.

Adding to the domestic pressures has been the recent increase of violence, which has spilled out of Kosovo and into southern Serbia. With Albanian terrorists escalating their activities and seizing control of several Serb villages in the de-militarized zone, relations between Yugoslavia and NATO are once again being tested.

Until now, the Serbian military has respected the UN Technical Agreement and it has not yet deployed heavy weapons into the five-kilometre buffer zone.

However, Yugoslavia is stepping up its demands for the UN Security Council to take stronger action. Without a serious UN effort to curtail the Albanian occupation, Mr. Kostunica has made it clear that Serbian forces are prepared to "cleanse the region of terrorists."

NATO spokesmen have repeatedly claimed they will not tolerate any Serbian military action in the demilitarized zone.

Such a potential showdown with NATO would jeopardize the flow of vital foreign aid that has been propping up the bankrupt Yugoslav treasury.

Throughout the election campaign, Mr. Milosevic's Socialists and the right-wing Radical party have described this developing situation as "NATO blackmail." Both Vojislav Seselj -- the Radical party leader, and Mr. Milosevic, have played to the voters' sense of patriotic pride -- urging Serbs to reject the "blood money" offered as foreign aid and thereby retain their independence.

Such sentimental appeals have in the past kept Mr. Milosevic in power, even as Yugoslavia disintegrated. However, the polls here would indicate that Serbians are wearying of hard-core nationalism.

"Of course we recognize that with foreign investment, we will lose some control," said Vladimir Krajnovic, a 38-year-old Belgrade-based economist. "However, if such a sacrifice means having a job and a future for my children, then I'm willing to give this up.

"After 10 years of oppressive sanctions, costly civil wars in Bosnia and Croatia and last year's devastating bombing campaign, many Yugoslavs are anxious for any sign of a possible economic recovery."

In Belgrade, there are some tell-tale signs of a renewal. A new pay phone system -- which has been in total disrepair for the past decade -- has been installed on downtown streets.

Independent banks are opening across Serbia and, with the "inner wall" of sanctions lifted, the free-falling dinar has been stabilized, although at one-third of its 1999 value.

Unfortunately, by freezing the dinar and removing the Socialists' subsidies on many staple products, the new DOS policies have led to severe inflation in the marketplace.

As prices have soared, Mr. Milosevic has stepped up his attacks on the DOS party's platform. His election advertisements remind voters of the cost disparity and the Socialist party slogan reads: "It's not too late to avoid disaster!" But rather than stirring up nostalgic yearnings, most Belgraders find the ads amusing.

"It is true that the official prices were lower, but there were never any such products in the stores," said Zoran Suvakovic, a senior editor with the Politika newspaper. "It may cost us four times as much now, but at least we can actually purchase what we can no longer afford."

Almost overnight, the black market economy that had unofficially kept Yugoslavia functioning and created criminal activity has been shut down. Under Mr. Kostunica's DOS regime, the police have been prosecuting many former Socialist officials. The most prominent arrest was that of Mihalj Kertes, the former chief customs administrator. His arrest has led to rampant speculation that Mr. Milosevic himself may soon face criminal charges.

Virtually all of the major public appointments have already been purged of Socialists and replaced by members of either DOS or its G-17 founders.

Managing Yugoslavia's power company is a vital and challenging task, particularly as winter threatens to overload the battered power grid. Last year's NATO bombing only further reduced an already aged electrical production system. When coupled with summer's drought, which reduced the Danube hydroelectric capacity by 50 per cent, Serbia will fall well short of its minimum domestic requirement.

"We are already importing the maximum power and producing the maximum power," said Mr. Simovic. "When the cold weather hits, there will definitely be regular blackouts."

The temporary reprieve from power outages and inclement weather has served to prolong the euphoric mood of hope that Mr. Kostunica ignited with the Oct. 5 uprising.

For many Serbs, their new president has acquired an almost "divine" status, reflected in his approval ratings -- currently sitting at an almost impossible 91 per cent. His repeatedly strong stand against U.S. interests, particularly last month's unprecedented public snubbing of U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, has elevated Mr. Kostunica to hero status.

The DOS has tried to capitalize on this popularity and convert it into votes for Zoran Djindic, the party's prime ministerial candidate in today's election. But Mr. Djindic's leadership is viewed by many Serbs as a potential liability to DOS. By having been long associated with the Serbian Democratic Movement, Mr. Djindic is distrusted by most Serbs. The many compromises and coalition agreements he made with Mr. Milosevic have led voters to question his true values.

"We don't fully trust him, but he is the candidate for our party," said Vesna Jukic, a DOS political organizer. "We will just have to hold our noses when we vote and tell ourselves that we're doing it for Kostunica."

While it is considered highly unlikely that Mr. Milosevic could achieve a majority government, none of the polls has ruled the Socialists out of finishing second.

In September elections, when Mr. Milosevic was defeated, he was still able to get more than 1.8 million presidential votes, roughly 40 per cent of the electorate. These results, though, came through the control of the State Radio Television Service, as well as government newspapers. Since then, these outlets have switched their loyalties.

In protest, Mr. Milosevic filed a formal complaint against "a prejudicial media" with the Organization for Security and Co-operation of Europe, which is monitoring the election. It found that Mr. Milosevic had not been granted equal and objective coverage of his party's platform. However, under the complex Serbian electoral system, Mr. Milosevic stands to gain simply through the preponderance of candidates.

On today's ballots there will be eight lists for voters to choose from various coalitions that comprise 209 different political parties and movements. Even Zeljko Raznatovic -- "Arkan," the infamous Tiger warlord -- has a political party entered on the ballots, despite the fact he was murdered last January.

Many of the splinter groups will fail to garner the minimum five per cent of the overall vote required to retain official status, and their share of the votes will be transferred proportionately to the major parties.

Potential voter apathy due to political burnout could yet prove to be the spoiler in Mr. Kostunica's quest to consolidate control.

"For many Serbs, they want to believe that they already made their choice twice: First at the ballot box on Sept. 24 and then in the streets on Oct. 5," said Vesna Jukic. "All DOS is asking for is for them to take that one more step."

Under the existing system, the 250 parliamentary seats are not selected to represent an individual riding, but are selected after each party's vote percentage determines its number of successful candidates. Although early results will be available within hours, it is not expected that a final election result will be confirmed until Monday. In the unlikely event that DOS fails to achieve the required 51 per cent majority, the possibility exists that yet another compromise government coalition will have to be formed.


LOAD-DATE: December 23, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Color Photo: Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica faces off, today against former president Slobodan Milosevic as Serbians head, to the polls for the second time in three months.; Color Photo:, (Slobodan Milosevic) ; Color Photo: Reuters ; A Yugoslav soldier, observes the area around the southern Serbian town of Bujanovac,, some 370 kilometres south of Belgrade earlier this week. Without a, serious UN effort to curtail the Albanian occupation in southern, Serbia, Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica has made it clear that, Serbian forces are prepared to 'cleanse the region of terrorists.'


TYPE: Column


Copyright 2000 CanWest Interactive, a division of
CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved


303 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 27, 1999, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Summit in Sarajevo targets stability in the Balkans U.S. goal: Don't 'lose the peace'


BYLINE: Barbara Slavin


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A


LENGTH: 944 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON -- Western leaders will gather Friday in Sarajevo,
a symbol of Balkan destruction and rebirth, to launch an effort
to stabilize the region and make the Kosovo war Europe's last.

"We must help put the last pieces of the puzzle in place in southeast
Europe," national security adviser Samuel Berger told a Washington
audience Monday. "We won the war, but it will be a hollow victory
if we lose the peace."

Despite the sweeping rhetoric and earlier talk of spending billions,
no price tag for Balkan reconstruction will be announced, officials
said.
 

Concern is growing that reconstruction will be hampered by excluding
the central piece of the puzzle: Serbia, which is still ruled
by Slobodan Milosevic who presided over the bloody breakup of
Yugoslavia.

Balkan leaders also worry that emergency aid for Kosovo, a province
of Serbia that is now an international protectorate, will take
precedence over the rest of the Balkans indefinitely.

"I'm very concerned with the sounds I hear," said Philip Dimitrov,
Bulgaria's ambassador to the United States. "We are trying to
achieve a safe and prosperous neighborhood. You cannot expect
good behavior in a slum."

International financial institutions are still assessing the regional
impact of the 78-day air war for Kosovo. The war disrupted trade,
transit, tourism and investment for six nations surrounding Yugoslavia,
now made up only of Serbia and Montenegro. All six are former
communist states struggling to build market economies.

Albania, the poorest country in Europe, and Macedonia, the least
developed former Yugoslav republic, were hardest hit. Bosnia,
Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria also suffered.

This year, the six countries face a cumulative gap between imports
and exports of $ 1 billion, according to the World Bank, and 3%-4%
reductions in economic growth.

Some support for these countries has already been pledged, but
a donor conference Wednesday in Brussels, Belgium, will focus
only on Kosovo. Berger announced Monday that the United States
was prepared to contribute up to $ 500 million to help the province
rebuild.

As for the rest of Serbia, Berger said the United States would
not provide "a penny for reconstruction so long as a war criminal
rules in Belgrade."

Other U.S. officials say Friday's summit might announce programs
to support dissident Serb groups and cities. The European Union
has proposed restoring energy and water supplies to anti-Milosevic
towns, but the United States is cool to the idea.

Before the war, Serbia was a major trading partner for Bosnia
and Macedonia and the main transit route for other regional trade.

The Yugoslav capital, Belgrade, is "geographically a natural
strategic point on the road, rail and power axis" of southeastern
Europe, said the Center for European Policy Studies, a Brussels
think tank.

Two road projects in the works before the war skirt Serbia. "Corridor
eight" runs east-west from the Black Sea through Bulgaria and
Macedonia to the Albanian port of Durres on the Adriatic. "Corridor
four" is to connect Greece, Bulgaria and Romania.

But shipping routes along the Danube remain blocked by debris
from Serb bridges, oil refineries and factories destroyed by NATO
bombs.

"Serbia is the key to the economic future of southeastern Europe,"
said Rory O'Sullivan, the World Bank's outgoing resident representative
in Bosnia and newly appointed special representative for southeast
Europe. "No one will feel comfortable until Serbia comes back
into the fold."

Milosevic, indicted for war crimes in Kosovo, is the only Balkan
leader excluded from the Sarajevo summit. Friday's gathering is
expected to attract 30 heads of state and will be the largest
in Sarajevo.

"The whole process means a lot to the people here," O'Sullivan
said in a telephone interview from Sarajevo. "It affects their
psyches in an extraordinary way."

U.S. and European officials say they are determined that the meeting
will be more than window dressing.

"Our objective is to make it as concrete as possible," said
Juergen Chrobog, the German ambassador to Washington.

Germany, the dominant power in the heart of Europe, proposed the
so-called "Stability Pact" that Friday's summit will launch.
A former German industrialist and chief of staff to Chancellor
Gerhard Schroeder, Bodo Hombach, has been put in charge.

Modeled after the U.S.-financed Marshall Plan, which brought prosperity
to Western Europe after World War II, the pact is a largely European
initiative meant to groom the Balkan nations for eventual membership
in the European Union.

Sullivan said the initial emphasis will be on "issues that can
be fixed with political will and bring rapid benefits."

Among them: freer trade and movement of people among the Balkan
nations and shared electrical power.

Donor conferences are scheduled in the fall. Reliance on such
gatherings worries Balkan leaders. After meeting with Secretary
of State Madeleine Albright last month in his rundown capital,
Skopje, Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov told reporters that
donor conferences are an "inefficient" means of raising cash.

"Democratization is just as important as money," German Foreign
Minister Joschka Fischer said last month in Cologne, Germany,
when the Stability Pact was signed by foreign ministers from 31
nations. "Without democratization, the money will just go into
the wrong hands."

Balkan officials say economic growth is the best support young
democracies can have. "We are looking for investment, not handouts,"
Dimitrov said.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, B/W, Genevieve Lynn, USA TODAY (Map); PHOTO, B/W, Ivan Dobricic, AFP; No reconstruction funds for Serbia: Serb men fish from a bridge in Ostruznica. It was destroyed during NATO airstrikes.


Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


304 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 18, 1999, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


FILM;
A Serb With a Prophetic Intuition for His Country


BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 


SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 


LENGTH: 1611 words


DATELINE: PARIS


IT is not an easy time for a Serbian filmmaker to be releasing a new movie in the United States, even for a veteran director like Goran Paskaljevic, who has long opposed Slobodan Milosevic's regime, who has expressed his shame over the atrocities committed by Serbian forces in Bosnia and Kosovo, who has been denounced as a traitor by the official press in Belgrade. For all that, he remains a Serb, and, as such, he is expected to throw light on the collective madness that has gripped a good many of his fellow Serbs of late.

As it happens, this was his objective when he began shooting "Cabaret Balkan," his 11th feature film, in Belgrade in the early spring of 1998. It was still a year before NATO launched its aerial war against Yugoslavia in the name of saving Kosovo, but Mr. Paskaljevic was already convinced that President Milosevic was leading his nation to disaster. His movie is about people, not politics, but nonetheless about people driven to violence and despair by politics. The film's original title -- "The Powder Keg" -- said it all. 

"Many critics now say the film was prophetic, but it was normal to me that the powder keg would explode in the end," Mr. Paskaljevic said over coffee in the small apartment in Paris that he and his French wife, Christine, have just occupied. "I believe it is an honest testimony of the dark and tragic atmosphere in Belgrade at the time."

The movie, which opens in New York on Friday, was renamed for the United States because Kevin Costner had registered the title "The Powder Keg." But "Cabaret Balkan" also serves it well, hinting at the dark humor and macabre theatricality of the Serbian dance of death that Mr. Paskaljevic portrays. The film, which won the International Critics Prize for Best Film at the 1998 Venice Film Festival, has already been released in much of Western Europe and, more surprisingly, also in Belgrade and Sarajevo, where it drew enthusiastic crowds.

The screenplay, written by Mr. Paskaljevic and Dejan Dukovski, is an adaptation of Mr. Dukovksi's play "The Powder Keg," which was well received in Belgrade in the mid-1990's. But while the play presents a series of short stories set in Skopje, Macedonia, the movie takes place in Belgrade in the course of one night, linking the different tales in the style of "La Ronde" and setting them against the political background of a Serbia sliding into poverty, ostracized by the world and paralyzed by its own myths.

The sinister mood is set by the slurred opening words of the master of ceremonies at Cabaret Balkan, who addresses the camera as if speaking for Serbia to the world: "Why do you laugh at me? Do you think I am funny? Do you think I am a freak? That I'm different from you? Is that why you have come? It doesn't matter. You're welcome." Welcome, he adds with a thin smile, because he has plans to upset you.
