The stories that follow are indeed disturbing, each one ending in an act of violence, a violence that seems darkly logical in a context in which tension, frustration and distrust are feeding feelings of victimization and a desire for revenge. A taxi driver recognizes a policeman, now crippled by an accident, and sets out to repay a beating that the policeman once gave him. Two old friends, sparring in a boxing ring to keep fit, begin confessing how they have betrayed each other, until one of them explodes. A young man hijacks a bus and berates some passengers for their passivity. Another young man is mistaken for a gasoline thief and is chased by a lynch mob.

"I try to show that the victim and the executioner nearly become the same," said Mr. Paskaljevic, whose last movie, the 1996 English-language "Someone Else's America," was every bit as sentimental as "Cabaret Balkan" is menacing. "That's our tragic problem. Most of the Serbian population feel like a victim, which is wrong. But it is a very strong feeling."

A stockily built man of 52 with thinning long hair and, on this occasion, a three-day stubble, Mr. Paskaljevic likes to think of himself as an optimist, but he concedes that this is his most somber movie.

"I cannot express hope in the film artificially," he said. "Hollywood movies always express hope at the end of the story, but it is not like that in life. But I do find some hope in some of the characters, in their humanity, even in their tragic circumstances. Little gestures. For example, the political scene is the bus scene. The guy is nice to the old people; he lets them off the bus. He's nice to the young people, who are kissing each other and don't care. But he tries to shake up the middle classes and says, 'You need another war to wake up and become rebels.' "

Now, after another war has brought Serbia its fourth defeat in a decade, Mr. Paskaljevic is more upbeat. He is encouraged by the anti-Milosevic demonstrations that are beginning to take place in many Serbian towns, and he believes that the return of university students to classes in September may accelerate the demise of the regime. But he also hopes that the West will support the opposition more than it did during the 100-day protest movement that shook Serbia in the winter of 1995.

"They didn't help because, for the American administration, Milosevic was the strongman of the Balkans who had signed Dayton," he said, referring to the agreement that ended the four-year conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina. "It's always easier to deal with dictators than democracy."

Reared in Marshall Tito's Yugoslavia and trained in the Prague film school known as FAMU, Mr. Paskaljevic has himself had ample experience of dictatorship. While he made his home in Belgrade, his films were frequently invited to the Berlin, Venice and Cannes film festivals, with his deadpan comedy "Special Treatment" winning a Golden Globe nomination for best foreign film in 1980. It also earned him a two-year ban on making films in Yugoslavia.

"The film was an allegory about a dictator, and I was asked by The Hollywood Reporter whom I meant," the director recalled with a laugh. "I said, Stalin. And they asked, Tito? And I said, yes, Tito also. After that, I couldn't get work in Yugoslavia."

In 1982, he made his first English-language film, "Twilight Time," starring Karl Malden as an old man bringing up his two grandchildren. Four more films followed before he worked again in English in 1995 in "Someone Else's America," starring Tom Conti and Miki Manojlovic (who is also in "Cabaret Balkan"). Reviewing this film in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that the two actors infused the movie "with enough soulfulness to lend a crude modern fairy tale about immigrants pursuing the American dream a heartwarming sweetness."

Returning home from filming that movie in Brooklyn, however, Mr. Paskaljevic felt the need to address the crisis in Serbia. He obtained a small grant from the Ministry of Culture to make "The Powder Keg." But his hopes of supposedly guaranteed financial help from Serbian state television evaporated once he presented the final screenplay. Still, with the film's $1.2 million budget eventually covered by co-producers in France, Greece, Turkey and Macedonia, he was able to present it at last year's Venice Film Festival.

When Mr. Paskaljevic told an Italian newspaper that "the totalitarian and intolerant regime of Milosevic" was destroying Serbia, however, he was promptly accused of "infantile treason" by the pro-government Serbian newspaper, Politika, which also noted suggestively that other infamous intellectual traitors had been executed or had committed suicide. The Serbian authorities then refused to distribute the film, but the director found an independent theater in Belgrade that was willing to show it. And it caught on through word of mouth.

"Already 250,000 people have been to see the movie in Belgrade," he said. "Young people treated it like a cult film. My idea was to shock people, to punch them. But many young people came out laughing and saying, 'Listen, the reality is much worse than your film.' "

Mr. Paskaljevic was particularly pleased by the movie's reception in Sarajevo, even though, at a post-screening press conference, a Bosnian journalist asked the director and his actors to state what each had done during the siege of Sarajevo.

"I said, 'Listen, I will answer,' " he recalled. ' "First of all, you have no right to ask that because I am not on trial here. I came with good will, and I am very proud to be a Serb. But I have to tell you that I am ashamed of what we did in Sarajevo, and I came to apologize for that. I didn't do it, but somebody did it in my name.' "

Today, Mr. Paskaljevic says he is no less ashamed of what Serbia has just done in Kosovo, but he also wants to look to the future.

"It's very important that Serbia wake up and say we are also responsible for what is happening to us," he said. "We must be aware of what is happening in Kosovo; we have to face the facts and look to the future. Our tragic mistake is that we are always looking to the past. We have to cut ourselves off from our myths of the past and see where we are today and what is going to be our place tomorrow. We can only do this through democracy."

For his next movie, though, Mr. Paskaljevic plans to leave the Balkans far behind.

"I cannot make another film in Yugoslavia now," he said. "Even if I could find the financing, I would repeat myself, it would be 'Powder Keg II.' I need a pause, I need distance. So I'm going to shoot on location in Mexico. Mexico will enable me to meet a different world. Then I'll go back to Yugoslavia and make another film."

And by then, he hopes, it will also be a different Yugoslavia.
  

http://www.nytimes.com


NAME: Goran Paskaljevic


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Goran Paskaljevic, above, the director of "Cabaret Balkan." At right, a scene from the film, about people driven to violence and despair by politics. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times); (Paramount Classics)(pg. 9); Nikola Ristanovski is a cabaret artist in Goran Paskaljevic's "Cabaret Balkan," which opens Friday. (Paramount Classics)(pg. 12)


TYPE: Biography


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


305 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


September 22, 1991, Sunday, Final Edition


Serb Leader's Gains in Yugoslav Crisis May Be Short-Lived


Michael Dobbs, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1


LENGTH: 1173 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Sept. 21, 1991


At first glance, Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic appears to be the big victor of the Yugoslav crisis. By laying the foundations for a Greater Serbia, Eastern Europe's last hard-line Communist leader is riding higher than ever in the opinion of his fellow Serbs and has virtually crushed a once-formidable domestic opposition movement.

On paper, everything seems to be going Milosevic's way. The Yugoslav army, the most powerful military force in the Balkans, is rapidly turning into a Serbian army. Forces loyal to the Serbian leader have grabbed large areas of neighboring Croatia and are poised to make similar territorial gains in Bosnia. As Yugoslavia disintegrates into its component parts, Milosevic has emerged as the strongest leader of the region's strongest state. 

Over the long term, however, his political position does not look nearly as strong as it does now. The Greater Serbia that is being built on the ruins of Yugoslavia includes millions of non-Serbs: Croats, Albanians and possibly Slavic Muslims, if the war is extended to Bosnia. After everything that has happened over the past few months, it is unlikely these minorities will ever again accept rule from Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital.

"Milosevic is not a man of vision. He is a day-to-day survivor," said Milos Vasic, an editor on the Belgrade weekly Vreme, one of the few Serbian media outlets not under the control of the Milosevic regime. "The Greater Serbia that he is trying to create will be undefendable and unsustainable."

At home, Milosevic has distracted the attention of most Serbs from their growing economic problems, including a 20 percent drop in industrial production since the beginning of the war. In the present atmosphere of jingoistic nationalism, many Serbs seem prepared to accept a decline in living standards for the sake of their country. But economic grievances are likely to resurface once the war is over.

"The moment Milosevic stops his territorial campaign, he will face social unrest in Serbia. He knows that, which is one reason why it is impossible for him to stop," said Dragan Veselinov, a political scientist who heads the Serbian Peasants' Party, one of several small opposition parties. "As long as he continues his war policy, he is able to neutralize the opposition by suggesting we are traitors."

He and other opposition leaders trace the war with Croatia to the anti-Communist demonstrations that swept Belgrade in early March. Milosevic used the army to disperse the demonstrators, a move that severely damaged his popular legitimacy and his reputation as a "defender of the Serbs." For a few days, it seemed Milosevic might go the way of other Communist leaders in Eastern Europe. But by the end of March, the tense standoff between Serbs and Croats in border areas of Croatia had exploded into fighting. Serbia blamed the Croats for the border incidents, but opposition politicians and independent journalists here say they are convinced they were exploited by Milosevic to repair his domestic image.

A former banker and Communist apparatchik, Milosevic, 49, has used nationalism as a political weapon since coming to power in Serbia in 1987. He established himself as Serbian leader by absorbing the republic's two autonomous regions: the predominantly ethnic-Albanian Kosovo province in the south and Vojvodina in the north, home to many ethnic Hungarians. These first moves toward creating a Greater Serbia were enormously popular among Serbs, who felt their nation had not received adequate recognition in post-World War II Yugoslavia.

The second stage of Milosevic's campaign to unite Serbs into a single state has also proved highly popular here. The rights of the Serbian minority living in Croatia have long been a sensitive subject for a nation with a vivid collective memory of atrocities committed by the puppet Nazi state of Croatia during World War II. Older Belgrade residents can recall hundreds of bodies of Serbs floating down the Sava River from the direction of Croatia. When a nationalist regime came to power in Zagreb last year, many Serbs feared history would repeat itself.

The mistrust of Croatia is so deeply etched into the Serbian national psyche that even Milosevic's most ardent political opponents have had to take it into account. It has now become a political commonplace in Belgrade that the post-World War II borders between Serbia and Croatia are unjust and must be corrected.

"Croatia lost the war, but it won the peace. It even gained territories. Croatia did not pay any penalty for what it did to Serbia. This must be put right," said Vuk Draskovic, leader of the opposition Serbian Renewal Party, which brought tens of thousands of anti-Milosevic demonstrators out into the streets of Belgrade in March.

The anti-Croat fervor has been whipped up by the Serbian media, which, except for Vreme and the former Communist Party daily Borba, are firmly under Milosevic's control. Serbian newspapers routinely refer to the Croatian national guard as "Ustashi," the pejorative term used to describe Croatian Nazis in World War II. News bulletins routinely lead with reports of Croatian attacks on Serbian or federal troops.

Although Belgrade is little more than 100 miles from the fiercest fighting in eastern Croatia, there are few outward signs of war here. Sidewalk cafes are crowded. Stores and movie theaters are full. On the surface, the Serbian capital seems a prosperous and relaxed city.

Private conversations, however, are dominated by the war. The mobilization of thousands of young men to join the army this week has clearly touched a sensitive national chord, even though it is not a subject of public discussion.

There have been reports of scattered mutinies in military barracks around Serbia and widespread draft evasion. An officer responsible for mobilizing reservists said that, on a typical night, he had been able to deliver only 15 out of 120 summonses to report for military duty.

"Time is running out for the Yugoslav army," said Vreme editor Vasic. "The response to mobilization has been getting poorer and poorer. They lack conscripts. Nobody wants to go to this war."

As of now, Serbia and its ally Montenegro are the only republics where the federal army is still respected as an institution.

For the moment, the army and the Serbian territorial forces clearly have the upper hand in the war. As long as Serbia continues to accumulate territory, Milosevic's position seems secure. But Serbian opposition leaders insist that the political tide will turn as soon as there is any reversal on the ground.

"It's impossible to defeat Milosevic in Serbia. All our internal problems have been dissolved in the war," said Zoran Djingic, leader of the Democratic Party. "Milosevic, like Napoleon, will be defeated on the battlefield. The army in Croatia will come back to Serbia and they will overthrow Milosevic. I don't think he can succeed in the long term. The only question is how long it will take to defeat him."


NAME: SLOBODAN MILOSEVIC


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, CROATIAN MILITIAMAN, ABOVE, USES DAMAGED BUILDING FOR COVER WHILE TAKING AIM DURING BATTLE AGAINST SERBS. AP


TYPE: ANALYSIS, FOREIGN NEWS, BIOGRAPHY


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


306 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Scotsman


August 26, 1999, Thursday


YUGOSLAV OPPOSITION AGREES TO DISAGREE AS MILOSEVIC PLAYS FOR TIME


BYLINE: Conal Urquhart


SECTION: Pg. 11


LENGTH: 1201 words


 

THE pavement cafes are full of well-dressed people enjoying the last of the summer sun amid the bustle of what could easily be a western European capital city. It is hard to imagine that a few months ago Belgrade was the bombing target of a massive air force and is predicted to be the focus of a fierce political struggle in the coming weeks.

Already there is a slight chill in the air, auguring the arrival of the bitter Balkan winter, and beneath the facade of normality the potential for hardship is great. Yesterday, the director of the state-owned electricity company warned that bomb damage to the electricity supply system means some major Serbian cities will be without central heating this winter.

The toll of ten years of conflict and international sanctions is also evident. A newspaper report revealed that Serbs are the lowest paid in the former Yugoslavia. The average Slovenian worker earns 13 times more than his Serbian counterpart, who gets around GBP 30 per month. Much of this hardship has been spared Belgrade by a government which fears the wrath of a city which is home to one-eighth of the Serbian population. 

Bratislav Grubacic, the editor of Belgrade's English-language news service, said protest fatigue and relative prosperity has meant that the torch of opposition has passed from the capital to the provinces. "In Belgrade you don't see much on the surface.

The authorities deliberately try to ensure normality because they are afraid of Belgrade.

Also, people here are tired of ten years of war and demonstrations so it is harder to feel the tension.

"Something happened recently in Serbian politics. The Serbian provinces became much more clear in their opposition to the government than Belgrade itself. Basically, they suffered much more during the Kosovo war. They became much poorer than Belgrade, where you can still find second jobs. More people were mobilised and more of their sons were killed. There was very little mobilisation in Belgrade."

The government of Slobodan Milosevic was obviously as concerned about body bags as Bill Clinton, and sought to spread the human cost of the Kosovo conflict outside of the capital.

But still the opposition, galvanised by the war and Serbia's economic problems, has forced the government to offer early elections as a means of dividing its opponents.

Last week, members of the ruling coalition said they would be prepared to hold elections two years early if the opposition groups wanted them.

Yesterday a spokeswoman for Milosevic's party, the Socialist Party of Serbia (SDS), said elections could be held on 7 November. Although there are regular elections in Yugoslavia, it is difficult to describe them as democratic. The media is mostly state-controlled; only Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), and President Milosevic have access to television.

Secondly, there is a strong identification between the ruling party and the state, which mirrors the former communist system where the state and party were indistinguishable.

"It is difficult to see how the elections can be normal and democratic. It is just a way of defusing tension and saying to the people, 'Why go to demonstrate when you can vote' and 'Elections or civil war?'" said Mr Grubacic.

Mr Draskovic, the leader of the largest opposition party, which also runs Belgrade city council, has abandoned the tactics of street demonstrations which made him famous in 1996 and added his voice to government calls for elections.

This has raised doubts about the once fiery rabble-rouser's commitment to the opposition.

Mr Grubacic said: "Draskovic is selling out his brave opposition adventures since 1991. He has grown older and has lost interest in street risings against the authorities. Now he is more interested in business and a good life. He was always regarded as someone emotional, charismatic and unpredictable - now he is predictable. Whenever there is a need to mess up the opposition, Draskovic will do it to help Milosevic. Maybe they are not directly connected but I don't know."

If Mr Draskovic is unwilling to oppose Mr Milosevic, then the Alliance for Change, a coalition headed by Zoran Djindjic, does not have the power. Last week, an opinion poll showed the alliance was rising in popularity and would poll almost 15 per cent of the vote. This put it behind the SPO with 18.1 per cent and above the SDS, which would gain 13.7

per cent. But Mr Milosevic's ruling coalition - which includes the extreme nationalist Serbian Radical Party and the Yugoslav Left party led by his wife - would gain 24 per cent of the vote, leaving it the single biggest grouping while the opposition remains split.

"The Alliance for Change cannot mount an effective challenge to the government by itself and we do not know if Draskovic wants to do it. All the alliance can do is catch the wave of dissatisfaction and ride it. They have no access to the media so they cannot bring people on the streets," says Mr Grubacic.

"People distrust and have been disappointed by the opposition. The rule of the SPO in Belgrade has been tinged with corruption and Djindjic is seen as ineffective. The demonstration last week was not led by the opposition, it was simply people going out on the streets because they are fed up with Milosevic, not because they endorse the opposition leaders."

The best example of disillusionment with the established opposition is a protest in the southern Serbian town of Leskovac, where an unknown television station technician appealed for a demonstration after the withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from Kosovo.

More than 20,000 people, a third of the town's population, went on the streets. After recognised opposition politicians arrived, the number of protesters on the streets fell to 2,000. Commentators believe there is little prospect of a new leader arising from any of the anti-Milosevic groups. Milo Djukanovic, the president of Montenegro, has shown no desire to play a role in Serbia and General Momcilo Perisic, a former chief of staff of the Yugoslav army, is seen as a useful asset for the opposition but not a potential leader.

Despite the inability of the Serbian opposition parties to express the people's discontent, many Serbs, even some inside the SDS, believe Mr Milosevic must resign. SDS members realise they can no longer govern with Mr Milosevic at their head. But he still retains a strong hold on the party.

Mr Grubacic said: "I do not know when Milosevic will fall from power - as soon as possible, I hope. What I do know is that his model for governing has expired. Now he does not have a single idea about what to do apart from disrupt the opposition and buy some time.

"You never know when problems will happen that could put pressure on the government. It could be sparked by some stupid thing or some arrogant action by the authorities. Then who knows what will pull the trigger. He will scare people with the threat of civil war and people are afraid of that.

"It will take some time until people are desperate enough to accept that price. This is the criteria under which Milosevic will fall."


LOAD-DATE: September 10, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: PAPER


Copyright 1999 The Scotsman Publications Ltd.


307 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


June 16, 1999, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE RUSSIANS;
Muscovites Savor a Caper After Being Down So Long


BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES


SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 857 words


DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 15


As a military operation, it was insignificant. But as a symbol, there is no more potent metaphor for Russia's regard of the West than the image last weekend of 200 Russian soldiers seizing a Kosovo airfield, and then lining up armored personnel carriers to keep NATO troops out.

Kremlin officials offered a strategic explanation for the move, involving the need to acquire bargaining chips in talks on Kosovo's future and to establish Moscow once and for all as a player in the peace process. 

But most Russians were uninterested in the diplomacy. For them, it was a moment to savor, a rare act of one-upmanship by a faded power against a military that once viewed them with fear and awe. But it was a chance to say vicariously what they increasingly feel: that they are fed up with the overbearing West in general, and the United States in particular.

It is not easy for most Westerners to understand. But 78 days of war in Yugoslavia, a country a thousand miles removed from Moscow and no special soulmate of Russia in any case, seems to have convinced many Russians that the West is their enemy.

"All the anti-Western attitudes that were accumulating in the society resulted in this explosion when the war began," Igor Bunin, a historian and director of Moscow's Center for Political Technology, said in an interview. In focus groups involving scores of Moscow residents, he said, "many respondents said at the time that the bombs were not falling on Yugoslavia, but on their own heads."

The feeling is not universal. Some polls show Russian opinion of the United States and the West has softened somewhat since the war's peak. But even Russian newspapers, which viewed last weekend's operation in Kosovo as a diplomatic and public-relations debacle, called it "dashing" and lightning-fast.

One noted with satisfaction that Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott's airplane had been forced to perform a midair U-turn and to return to Moscow when news of the troop movement surfaced -- just deserts, because former Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov had been forced to abandon a Washington trip in midair when the bombing began in March.

If Russia's pleasure at such slight victories seems out of place, one need only listen to politicians and military leaders to realize the depths of their anger at the West's supposed efforts to feed on Russian weakness.

In anonymous remarks this weekend, Russian military officials repeatedly talked of ending their humiliation by American and NATO forces, which bombed Yugoslavia with impunity. Ordinary Muscovites frequently express the conviction that NATO and the West have Russia in their gunsights, and that the Yugoslavia war was merely a test run for a larger conflict.

Much of their reasoning is no secret. In the former Soviet Union, average people suffered, but could still take pride in military and scientific achievements. Democratic Russia promised affluence, peace and full membership in the club of Western nations, which many Russians had admired for decades.

But none of it has come about. Russia's foundering transition to capitalism was plotted largely by American academics and business leaders and carried out by pro-Western politicians; some now see it as a Western plot to impoverish the nation. Except for honorary memberships in organizations like the Group of Seven leading industrial nations and NATO's so-called Partnership for Peace, Moscow has largely been shut out of Western decision making.

NATO itself has proven far more of a sticking point than many Westerners realized. The West rebuffed Russia's early proposals to move toward full membership in the alliance. When the United States and Europe first announced plans to admit new members to NATO from Central Europe, Russian leaders immediately complained that they were being encircled by a potentially hostile military force -- fears that NATO tried to allay by giving Russia an advisory seat in the organization.

"The decision to enlarge NATO could not be understood by anybody in Russia because Russians know very well how weak Russia is today," said Sergei Rogov, who heads the Government's Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada. "On the other hand, Russians felt that we ended the cold war and started to behave nicely by dissolving the Warsaw Pact, withdrawing troops, cutting arms. And thus the very maintenance of NATO was seen as strange."

Mr. Rogov argued that the West consistently underestimated the Russian public's suspicion of NATO's expansion. That raised the prospect an anti-Western explosion should NATO became involved in a European crisis, he said.

And Mr. Bunin, of the Moscow center, said Yugoslavia provided the spark. The problem, he said, was not that Russians saw Yugoslavia or its President, Slobodan Milosevic, as allies or martyrs; the problem was rather that the Russians had no opinions about them.

"There was no anti-Milosevic propaganda in Russia," he said. "Nobody looked at Milosevic as a new Hitler or as the person who is seen in the West. And so the NATO and U.S. attack looked to us as completely unprovoked, as the step toward world hegemony."  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: June 16, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


308 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New Zealand Herald


October 6, 2001 Saturday


Conflict without the fighting


SECTION: NEWS; General


LENGTH: 1145 words


The timing seems singularly ironic - or utterly appropriate, depending on your point of view. Barely a fortnight after the terrorist atrocities in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania, an American breezes through town hawking a book and a television series that celebrate and promote what sounds like an oxymoron: non-violent conflict.

But Jack DuVall is painting on a canvas far broader than a fortnight. The executive producer of the two-part documentary and the co-author of the weighty book called A Force More Powerful remarks that this is the last place on Earth to be offered the chance to see what he's devoted much of the past five years of his life to. 

The two-part film, which screens on Sky's Sundance Channel this month (the companion book, sparsely available in hardback now, will be published in paperback in December), was screened on American public television almost a year ago and is a survey of the 20th century's great non-violent struggles for freedom.

The project was undertaken at the millennium's end, he says, to ensure that we would remember our recent history not just as a series of bloody insurrections and armed conflicts.

"We were concerned that at the end of the century there would be all these media records of the wars and revolutions and there would not also be a look back at other kinds of conflicts."

His choice of words is careful. DuVall, who is fond of the term "non-violent weapons", is anything other than a peacenik and he resists the yoking together of the terms "conflict" and "resolution" because he's keen to distinguish non-violence from inaction.

"We're not necessarily talking about resolution," he says, "but we're saying that when conflict cannot be resolved it needs to be carried on in a non-violent fashion. So we begin to shift the phenomenon of conflict away from the uninformed choice of violence."

They are sobering words for a world staring down the barrel of a US-led response to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. But human history is littered with evidence of the failure of violent conflict. When force prevails it gives the illusion of victory, DuVall suggests, but it fails because the very idea that force prevails is an oxymoron.

Both book and film derived from the academic work of Peter Ackerman, whose book Strategic Non-Violent Conflict: The Dynamics of People Power in the Twentieth Century grew out of scholarly research that began in the 1970s.

They amount to a comprehensive survey of the great non-violent movements of the century. Among events he documents with detail and precision, but in an easily digestible style, are Mahatma Gandhi's campaign for self-rule in India, which began with his historic and symbolic defiance of the hated salt laws; the Danes' resistance to occupying Nazi forces, which resulted in the escape to Sweden of almost all Danish Jews; the black occupation of segregated diners in Nashville, Tennessee, in 1960; the 1980 shipyard strikes in Gdansk, Poland, which history would come to see as the first crack in the pedestal of totalitarian communist rule in Europe; and the spectacularly successful 1985 boycotts by black shoppers of white-owned stores in South Africa's Eastern Cape Province.

But at all points, the writers are keen to underline the idea of non-violent struggle as a form of conflict. The Rev James Lawson, a student of Gandhi's methods who inspired three Nashville sit-ins, is quoted as urging that non-violent resistance needs to be organised and orchestrated with military precision.

"It needs fierce discipline," he says, "training and strategies; it does not happen spontaneously."

DuVall, who worked in US Air Force counter-intelligence during the Vietnam War and later was a speechwriter for presidential contenders, including Gary Hart and Walter Mondale, is at pains to emphasise the practicality of non-violence.

Its great proponents, he says, "came to that choice because they had - or thought they had - no other choice available. It doesn't have to be a principled decision - though that is not to say that no valid principle can attach to it."

In the shadow of the atrocities of September 11 and to a West aching for revenge, the idea of non-violence may ring a little hollow. "Try telling that to Osama bin Laden," some may say.

But DuVall says that, in geopolitical terms, the major powers have taken too little note of the effectiveness of non-violent struggle in eroding the power base of terrorist regimes.

"Gandhi didn't bomb the Houses of Parliament," DuVall says. "He went after the Raj's basis of support in his homeland. The same lesson may be drawn from what happened in [the former] Yugoslavia.

"In the book we quote at some length a number from the democratic Opposition in Serbia who say, 'If you had just given us the help that we were asking for in 1993 and 1994 we might have prevented what happened in Bosnia'.

"The Americans believe that Nato bombing 'softened up' Milosevic. But I don't think you'd find a Serbian who agrees with that. If anything, it hardened his grip on power. When, finally, in 2000, US agencies channelled help to non-violent anti-Milosevic forces inside Serbia, they brought him down."

Like many whose analysis runs counter to the prevailing ideology, DuVall seems a little like a voice in the wilderness. The networks in the US shunned his show, though it aired on PBS, which can be received on every set in the country. Here, TVNZ turned the documentary down and it will screen on a channel that only Sky digital subscribers see.

He sees the decisions, though, less as a rejection than as "a kneejerk assumption that they knew what this was about, that their model for non-violence was the saintly Gandhi giving an inspiring speech and everyone saying, 'I will lay my body down to get run over.'

"This is not someone sitting around pleading for morally correct behaviour. We are showing real conflicts in which people are fighting and contending and getting hurt and sometimes losing their lives because they had a passionate cause, but had found it possible to engage in conflict in another way."

He believes the media generally "actively neglect" non-violent struggle (until the baton-waving police move in and it gets violent) because it does not always or necessarily generate dramatic and striking images.

But for all that - and despite the events in America - he feels optimistic. "This latest wholesale act of terrorism - although this may not be apparent right at the moment - will necessarily anathematise the use of violence," he says. "Other strategies will have to be reconsidered and taken up."

* A Force More Powerful screens on the Sundance Channel on October 21 and 28. The book (hardback $81.95, paperback $54.95) is published by St Martin's Press, whose New Zealand representative is Pan Macmillan.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2001 The New Zealand Herald. All Rights Reserved.


309 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


October 8, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


SHOWDOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA: THE DIPLOMACY;
Down the Years, a Slippery Foe Frustrated the U.S.


BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ


SECTION: Section 1; Page 17; Column 1; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 1595 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7


In the mid-1990's, when the United States was trying to end the war in Bosnia and then enforce the peace, Washington's contacts with Slobodan Milosevic were frequent, volatile and very much in person.

Often, after a shouting match over policy with American diplomats in his palace in Belgrade, Mr. Milosevic would signal a servant to open the doors to a large dining room, where a meal of several courses awaited and where the conversation could be, according to participants, jocular and cordial. 

Relations with Mr. Milosevic at that period were never warm, but were at the height of a roller-coaster ride that coursed over a decade from a lack of attention during a Bush presidency distracted first by the fall of Communism elsewhere, and then by fighting Saddam Hussein, to outright war last year under President Clinton. Now, finally, Washington is celebrating the downfall of a man who for years delighted in defying, befuddling and belittling his far more powerful foes.

As the Clinton administration tries to temper its pleasure, senior officials are looking back at an opponent -- the last of the major East European strongmen -- who has caused as many internal debates and as much anguish in Washington as any other.

Some of the skirmishes were between the secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, who with her Czechoslovak origins and childhood memories of Belgrade holds a special kinship to the Balkans and Eastern Europe, and the ambassador to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke, a forceful diplomat who did the unpalatable deal with Mr. Milosevic to end the war in Bosnia.

From the beginning, these kinds of diplomatic differences marked Washington's relations with Yugoslavia. In 1990 and 1991, the ambassador to Yugoslavia, Warren Zimmerman, felt that the Bush administration, distracted by the Persian Gulf war, made too little effort, too late, to stop the brewing conflict in Yugoslavia.

Secretary of State James A. Baker said in 1991 that the United States did "not have a dog in that fight," that Washington's national interest was not centered on the Balkans and that it was unwise to commit American troops there.

In 1992, while running for the presidency, Mr. Clinton seemed to suggest that he would do more to confront Mr. Milosevic and the Bosnian Serbs, who were besieging Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, and conducting the worst killing in Europe since World War II.

Once in power, the Clinton administration wanted little to do with the conflict, which it regarded as Europe's business and which it believed could be contained by United Nations sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia in 1992. In Congressional testimony, Secretary of State Warren Christopher called the killing in Bosnia "a problem from hell."

In a tentative foray into the Balkans in 1993, Mr. Christopher, who never seemed persuaded by what he was trying to sell, went to Europe to persuade the allies to agree to a "lift and strike" policy. This called for the lifting of an arms embargo that had been placed on all of former Yugoslavia -- thus giving the well-armed Serbs an automatic advantage over the outgunned Bosnian Muslims -- and the launching of strategic NATO airstrikes at Bosnian Serb targets.

The British and French, who had troops in Bosnia as part of a United Nations force, objected strongly to airstrikes, and the Clinton White House backed off.

By 1995, with the killing in Bosnia under way for three years and unpunished, the Clinton administration looked for a way to end the conflict.

The engagement with Mr. Milosevic turned from sporadic contact to full-fledged diplomatic involvement.

First, though, the administration had to make a critical decision. Should it deal with Mr. Milosevic, the mastermind of the war, or with his surrogates, the Bosnian Serbs, led by Radovan Karadzic?

To decide that question, a diplomat with an uncanny skill for dealing with ugly regimes, Robert Frasure, was dispatched to Belgrade, where he held lengthy talks and had many meals with Mr. Milosevic. Mr. Frasure, who had negotiated with the Marxist dictator of Ethiopia, Mengistu Haile Mariam, who eventually fled his country, and then with the ruling white regime in South Africa, which ultimately collapsed, recommended dealing directly with the boss of the Balkans, Mr. Milosevic.

Mr. Frasure was one of four Americans killed when their armored personnel carrier drove over a mountainside in Bosnia as Mr. Holbrooke, Gen. Wesley K. Clark and other officials took a perilous road into Sarajevo because Bosnian Serb guns made it too dangerous to fly. Mr. Holbrooke then began a dizzying flurry of talks, meeting Mr. Milosevic as NATO launched its first sustained airstrikes against Bosnian Serb targets in September 1995. The negotiations culminated in the Dayton accords, reached at an Ohio air base that November and signed in Paris in December 1995.

Critics charged that the administration became too close to Mr. Milosevic, treating him as part of the solution to the war, rather than part of the problem.

At the time, there were arguments within the administration about whether sanctions against Mr. Milosevic should be eased. As ambassador to the United Nations, Dr. Albright was strongly opposed, as was Vice President Al Gore's top foreign policy adviser, Leon Fuerth.

During this period all kinds of American officials visited Mr. Milosevic, including senators and House members, who would be shown on Serbian television -- lending, for Mr. Milosevic's purposes, authenticity to his reign.

After the Dayton deal, which resulted in the dispatch of more than 30,000 peacekeeping troops to Bosnia, Mr. Holbrooke, and then the assistant secretary for European affairs, John Kornblum, continued to visit Belgrade. Their purpose was to persuade Mr. Milosevic to get his acolytes in the Serbian part of Bosnia to live up to their commitments at Dayton, including allowing Muslims hounded out of their homes to return.

On one occasion, however, Mr. Milosevic delivered. In mid-1996, at Mr. Holbrooke's request, he engineered Dr. Karadzic's removal from office.

By early 1998 Mr. Milosevic, as many feared, began to stir again, this time in the Serbian province of Kosovo, where a large Albanian majority began an armed rebellion against years of repression by the Yugoslav Army and Serbian police. Again, as in Bosnia, Mr. Milosevic's forces committed massacres and drove out thousands of Albanian families.

In October 1998, Mr. Holbrooke returned to Belgrade to reason with the strongman. The upshot, after more than 10 days of argument and the threat of NATO bombing, was an agreement that allowed outside, unarmed monitors into Kosovo to observe a truce between the Serbian forces and the growing Kosovo Liberation Army.

A massacre by Serbs in the Albanian village of Racak in January 1999 decisively broke the truce. By then Dr. Albright had decided that only force could bring Mr. Milosevic, now in charge of a diminished and isolated Serbia, under control. She argued strenuously at the White House for building a NATO consensus that if Mr. Milosevic did not agree to a NATO peacekeeping force in Kosovo he would be punished with airstrikes.

She had also concluded that Yugoslavia, where she had walked the streets as a child when her father was the Czechoslovak ambassador to Belgrade, could not be a normal country with Mr. Milosevic at the helm. (Her only encounter with Mr. Milosevic -- in May 1997 in Belgrade as part of a tour of the Balkans as Secretary of State -- was, according to aides, confrontational and blunt.)

With the war in Kosovo over, Mr. Milosevic remained in power, though indicted for war crimes by the international tribunal in The Hague.

Dr. Albright made no secret of her desire to see him go. She argued that the Serbs, and Europe, needed and deserved better.

When Mr. Milosevic announced in July that he was holding direct elections for the presidency on Sept. 24, Washington had already prepared some ground by financing civic groups and independent media opposed to his regime. This support was rapidly fortified and an anti-Milosevic operation, intended to keep in contact with the opposition movement, was established under the American ambassador, William Montgomery, in Budapest.

But the administration had to be careful. The opposition presidential candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, was fiercely independent and critical of American policy in Kosovo and Bosnia. In the end, the sweeping anti-Milosevic election result and the strength of the sentiment on the streets of Belgrade late this week were the work of the people.

For Mr. Holbrooke, Mr. Milosevic was "the arsonist of south-central Europe."

"As long as he was in power, you couldn't deal with the problems there," he said. "Now he has gone, the real problems will emerge but at least you can deal with them."

Mr. Holbrooke, who has dealt with Mr. Milosevic more than any other American official, cautioned that Mr. Milosevic's quick decision to stay on in political life would be "vastly complicating."

For Dr. Albright, the show of people power was a moment of vindication. She learned of Mr. Milosevic's collapse as she flew toward Washington after a disheartening round of Middle East talks.

She was asked how his departure ranked among her moments in office. "This is something very personal to me," she said, standing in the aisle of the secretary of state's plane. "I have always felt very strongly that the Serbian people were terrific. They had gotten a lousy deal by being ruled by Milosevic."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: October 8, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Richard Holbrooke, left, urged Slobodan Milosevic to accept a Kosovo accord in Belgrade in March 1999. (Reuters); For Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, a moment of vindication. (Associated Press)


Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company


310 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 2, 1999, Friday, FIRST EDITION


Milosevic's foes see 'our moment,' but can't see eye to eye


BYLINE: Jack Kelley


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10A


LENGTH: 933 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Several hundred retired government workers,
carrying placards equating President Slobodan Milosevic with Nazi
leader Adolf Hitler, called for the Yugoslav leader's ouster Thursday
in a march past government buildings still scarred from NATO airstrikes.

"Wake up, Serbia! Slobo out!" shouted the retired workers, who
were once among Milosevic's strongest supporters. Others stuffed
a mock ballot box with slips of paper to show their desire to
vote against Milosevic, whose term expires in 2001.

At the same time, several dozen university students and army reservists
who fought in Kosovo plastered stickers and signs reading "Milosevic:
Get out!" along the city's main pedestrian street. Police immediately
ripped down the stickers and chased off the demonstrators.
 

The protests, rare in the Yugoslav capital in recent years, came
only days after the first large public protest against Milosevic
and his Communist regime since the end of 11 weeks of NATO airstrikes
on Yugoslavia. Tuesday, nearly 10,000 people, waving Serbian flags
and chanting "Resignation," gathered in the southern city of
Cacak to demand Milosevic's ouster.

At least 20 other protests are planned for this summer, opposition
leaders said Thursday. Among them: Tuesday in the Yugoslav city
of Uzice, southwest of Belgrade; July 8 in Prokuplje, southeast
of Belgrade; and July 16 in Kraljevo, south of Belgrade.

"We have two aims: Milosevic's resignation and early, free and
fair elections," says Vladen Batic, head of an umbrella opposition
group called Alliance for Change. "We want this regime to go
in a peaceful, democratic way. We'll go from town to town, from
house to house, from man to man and light the torch of democracy
in Serbia."

Many Yugoslavs say Milosevic's political problems help the effort
to oust him. The Yugoslav leader, they note, has:

-- Allowed NATO peacekeepers to assume control of the sacred
Serbian province of Kosovo.

-- Been indicted as an international war criminal.

-- Been denounced by the Serbian Orthodox Church for the country's
lack of democracy.

-- Sparked the political and economic isolation of Yugoslavia.

-- Presided over an increasingly deteriorating economy.

"This is our moment. Now is the time for change," says Cedomir
Radoskovic, executive director of the Civic Alliance for Serbia,
an opposition group.

But few here expect the badly divided opposition to capitalize
on growing public discontent. "We're racked with problems,"
says Miroslav Filipovic, vice president of Civic Alliance. "It
all comes down to pride and ego. Yes, ego. Everyone wants to lead,
and no one wants to follow."

Divisions are so great that many opposition groups refuse to talk
to one another; their leaders won't appear in the same room. Others
openly criticize one another in the media and discourage attendance
at rival groups' rallies.

The last three attempts to oust Milosevic -- in 1991, 1993 and
1996 -- failed because of such lack of unity. These deep divisions
once again offer Milosevic his best hope for political survival,
at least in the near term, analysts say.

"Milosevic couldn't ask for a better opposition to suit his purposes,"
says Branislav Vujinovic, head of the Belgrade Chamber of Commerce.
"Nothing will be accomplished and nothing will be changed if
these people don't stop fighting. Every one of them appears to
put his own agenda ahead of the good of the nation."

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Party, for example,
is the only opposition leader with a sizable following. Polls
shows that 15% of Yugoslavia's 11 million people would vote for
him as the next president, second only to Milosevic, with 21%.

The tall, bearded writer, widely criticized for his healthy ego,
denounces the anti-Milosevic protests held earlier this week.

"This is not the time for change," Draskovic, 52, said in an
interview. "When the time has come, I will announce it. There
is no point participating in these pointless street rallies. I
am not ready."

Draskovic says he has every reason to refuse to cooperate with
his "selfish, egocentric" opposition colleagues.

In 1996 and 1997, Draskovic led three months of protests that
came close to toppling the Milosevic regime. He then decided to
run for president of Serbia, one of the two republics that make
up Yugoslavia. But Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic
Party, encouraged residents to boycott the election, and Draskovic
placed third in the balloting.

Seeking revenge, Draskovic joined with Milosevic's Socialist Party
of Serbia to oust Djindjic as mayor of Belgrade. Draskovic then
joined the Yugoslav government, dominated by Milosevic supporters,
before he was expelled earlier this year. "I will not be duped
again by the selfish (opposition) people," Draskovic says.

But other opposition groups have banded together under the Alliance
for Change and say they will pursue Milosevic's ouster regardless
of Draskovic.

"We don't need Vuk. We're stronger than him. He thinks of himself
as a king," Filipovic says. "We have a growing popularity. We
are a force. We have real power."

But U.S. officials in the Balkans who recently met with nine opposition
leaders in the Yugoslav republic of Montenegro aren't so sure.
They privately criticize the opposition movement, calling it weak
and pitiful. They expect Milosevic to survive the latest protests
and possibly invite Draskovic to rejoin the government to keep
the opposition divided.


LOAD-DATE: July 02, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, Ivan Milutinovic, Reuters; Turning against Milosevic: Retirees sign a petition demanding the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic during a protest Thursday in Belgrade.


Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


311 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


June 26, 1999, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BELGRADE;
Opposition's Egos Get in Way Of United Push to Oust Milosevic


BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 


SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 1180 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, June 25


For opposition politicians in Yugoslavia, this should be showtime.

Slobodan Milosevic has lost his fourth war in a row and surrendered the sacred Serbian homeland of Kosovo to heavily-armed foreigners. He has been indicted as a war criminal, the Swiss say they are swooping down on his supposed bank accounts and the United States has offered $5 million to anyone who helps to nab him. A third of Yugoslavia is out of work, incomes are down 40 percent this year and, according to a credible poll by a private firm this week, 70 percent of Serbs blame Mr. Milosevic for the whole sorry mess. 

Yet, as has been the case for nearly a decade, the opposition seems incapable of seizing the day. United in their eagerness to dump a dictator and end Serbia's isolation as an international pariah, opposition leaders remain hobbled by their competing egos. "Mr. Milosevic could not choose a better opposition because, if it repeats its unforgivable mistakes, he will be in power forever," grumbled Slobodan Vuksanovic, vice president of the Democratic Party, one of a cluster of pro-Western parties here. "We have an ego problem."

Exhibit A in the disunity of the Serbian opposition and the primacy of ego is Vuk Draskovic, the only figure with a sizable national following, his own television station and the populist razzle-dazzle to lure a large number of Serbs into the streets.

Mr. Draskovic's haughty disdain for a fractured opposition movement that desperately needs his charisma, his television station and his political machine helps explain why democracy in Serbia has been so much more elusive than in the rest of post-Communist Eastern Europe.

Tall, bearded and prone to self-dramatizing soliloquy, Mr. Draskovic, 52, a former best-selling author of blood-soaked nationalist novels, is not humble about his political gifts.

"I am the king of the streets," Mr. Draskovic said in an interview today at the headquarters of his Serbian Renewal Party. "I know better than anyone in the world what could be the real moment for demonstrations to bring down Mr. Milosevic. This is not the time."

The leaders of nearly every other opposition party in Yugoslavia disagree on the question of timing. They have joined to form the Alliance for Change and announced that on Tuesday they will begin a series of mass protests around Serbia to demand Mr. Milosevic's resignation and free elections under the supervision of European monitors.

"We must harness the anger of the Serbian people," said Vladan Batic, coordinator of the alliance. "After Kosovo, everything is different. People finally understand that political changes are necessary."

Mr. Draskovic, who also senses that the loss of Kosovo will prove to be a mortal blow to Mr. Milosevic's rule, said he wishes the alliance luck but does not feel like associating with "small political parties."

"I am not ready to waste time in closed rooms discussing stupid things," Mr. Draskovic said.

As much as other opposition leaders may resent Mr. Draskovic's uppity tone, they tend to agree that without him and his party, which has a proven record of being able to turn out tens of thousands of protesters against Mr. Milosevic for weeks on end, it will be difficult to sustain pressure on the Yugoslav President.

"Vuk won't call us and we don't want to call him, and Mr. Milosevic is rubbing his hands together in delight," conceded Mr. Vuksanovic, a prominent leader in the alliance.

Mr. Draskovic's hubris is a result of strong recent poll numbers for his party, his surprisingly successful cameo performance as a Government minister during the 10-week Kosovo war and a new go-it-alone strategy cooked up by his advisers.

Those advisers say Mr. Draskovic was betrayed by other opposition leaders in 1996-97, when he helped lead three months of protest rallies in Belgrade that came tantalizingly close to toppling Mr. Milosevic. They vow that he will not be duped again.

During the last big round of protests, Mr. Draskovic complained that he was undermined by Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democratic Party and the other big fish in the opposition sea. In the fall of 1997, Mr. Djindjic encouraged opposition parties to boycott an election when Mr. Draskovic ran for president of Serbia. The boycott contributed to Mr. Draskovic's dismal third-place showing in the vote.

Never again will he trust Mr. Djindjic or other "very selfish" opposition leaders, Mr. Draskovic said, as he painted a dark scenario of what he believes would happen if he were to participate in an opposition alliance before an election.

"Immediately before elections, they will start to quarrel, to accuse each other, to blackmail each other, and Milosevic would see a way to manipulate them," said Mr. Draskovic. "He would use smoke, coffee, whiskey and be very, very satisfied by the stupid ambitions of the opposition. No. I am not a part of it. I tried for nine years to unify them without any success. O.K. That's it."

Mr. Draskovic, who has been severely beaten and imprisoned in anti-Milosevic protests, stunned many in Serbia in January when he accepted the Serbian leader's invitation to join the Yugoslav Government as a Deputy Prime Minister.

During the war, he attracted attention by condemning the NATO bombing of civilian targets in Serbia as brutal and inhuman. He demanded that the foreign press be allowed to operate inside Serbia and distanced himself from Mr. Milosevic, accusing his Government of lying to the Serbian people about who was winning the war in Kosovo. In late April, he was dismissed, but not before he had shown himself as a strongly nationalist yet sane alternative to Mr. Milosevic's policies.

"I prevented many stupid things from happening during the war," Mr. Draskovic boasted today. "I risked my life. I did my obligations. I did it by staying in Serbia."

Many of Mr. Draskovic's critics here believe that the real reason he is reluctant to take on the Milosevic Government is that he does not want to lose his political trump card, Studio B television. The station, a real alternative to state-controlled television, is run by Belgrade City Hall, which is run by a coalition of Mr. Draskovic's party and the ruling Socialists.

"If Vuk pushes too hard, he could lose the support of the Socialists," said one analyst here. "He could lose Studio B and then he would be in the same position as everybody else in the opposition."

Asked about that, Mr. Draskovic was indignant.

"It is a total lie," he said.

Perhaps the most vexing complication in the political evolution of Mr. Draskovic is what exactly he believes in. He has been a somewhat promiscuous populist during the last decade, alternating between fist-pounding nationalism and rather sophisticated sensitivity to the rights of ethnic minorities.

As with many politicians in Serbia, it is difficult to discern how much nationalism colors his commitment to democracy and human rights. Mr. Draskovic said there is no confusion at all. "My nationalism was always healthy Western nationalism," he said.

  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: June 26, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


312 of 348 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 2, 1999, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Milosevic's foes see 'our moment,' but can't see eye to eye


BYLINE: Jack Kelley


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10A


LENGTH: 933 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia


BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Several hundred retired government workers,
carrying placards equating President Slobodan Milosevic with Nazi
leader Adolf Hitler, called for the Yugoslav leader's ouster Thursday
in a march past government buildings still scarred from NATO airstrikes.

"Wake up, Serbia! Slobo out!" shouted the retired workers, who
were once among Milosevic's strongest supporters. Others stuffed
a mock ballot box with slips of paper to show their desire to
vote against Milosevic, whose term expires in 2001.

At the same time, several dozen university students and army reservists
who fought in Kosovo plastered stickers and signs reading "Milosevic:
Get out!" along the city's main pedestrian street.
 

Police immediately ripped down the stickers and chased off the
demonstrators.

The protests, rare in the Yugoslav capital in recent years, came
only days after the first large demonstration against Milosevic
and his Communist regime since the end of 11 weeks of NATO airstrikes
on Yugoslavia.

Tuesday, nearly 10,000 people, waving Serb flags and chanting
"Resignation," gathered in the southern city of Cacak to demand
Milosevic's ouster.

At least 20 other protests are planned for this summer, opposition
leaders said Thursday. Among them: Tuesday in the Yugoslav city
of Uzice, southwest of Belgrade; July 8 in Prokuplje, southeast
of Belgrade; and July 16 in Kraljevo, south of Belgrade.

"We have two aims: Milosevic's resignation and early, free and
fair elections," says Vladen Batic, head of an umbrella opposition
group called Alliance for Change. "We want this regime to go
in a peaceful, democratic way. We'll go from town to town, from
house to house, from man to man and light the torch of democracy
in Serbia."

Many Yugoslavs say Milosevic's political problems help the effort
to oust him. The Yugoslav leader, they note, has:

-- Allowed NATO peacekeepers to assume control of the sacred
Serb province of Kosovo.

-- Been indicted as an international war criminal.

-- Been denounced by the Serbian Orthodox Church for Serbia's
lack of democracy.

-- Sparked the political and economic isolation of Yugoslavia.

-- Presided over an increasingly deteriorating economy.

"This is our moment. Now is the time for change," says Cedomir
Radoskovic, executive director of the Civic Alliance for Serbia,
an opposition group.

But few here expect the badly divided opposition to capitalize
on growing public discontent. "We're racked with problems,"
says Miroslav Filipovic, vice president of Civic Alliance. "It
all comes down to pride and ego. Yes, ego. Everyone wants to lead,
and no one wants to follow."

Divisions are so great that many opposition groups refuse to talk
to one another; their leaders won't appear in the same room. Others
openly criticize one another in the media and discourage attendance
at rival groups' rallies.

The last three attempts to oust Milosevic -- in 1991, 1993 and
1996 -- failed because of such lack of unity. These deep divisions
once again offer Milosevic his best hope for political survival,
at least in the near term, analysts say.

"Milosevic couldn't ask for a better opposition to suit his purposes,"
says Branislav Vujinovic, head of the Belgrade Chamber of Commerce.
"Nothing will be accomplished and nothing will be changed if
these people don't stop fighting. Every one of them appears to
put his own agenda ahead of the good of the nation."

Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Party, for example,
is the only opposition leader with a sizable following. Polls
show that 15% of Yugoslavia's 11 million people would vote for
him as the next president, second only to Milosevic, with 21%.

The tall, bearded writer, widely criticized for his healthy ego,
denounces the anti-Milosevic protests held earlier this week.

"This is not the time for change," Draskovic, 52, said in an
interview. "When the time has come, I will announce it. There
is no point participating in these pointless street rallies. I
am not ready."

Draskovic says he has every reason to refuse to cooperate with
his "selfish, egocentric" opposition colleagues.

In 1996 and 1997, Draskovic led three months of protests that
came close to toppling the Milosevic regime. He then decided to
run for president of Serbia, one of the two republics that make
up Yugoslavia. But Zoran Djindjic, leader of the opposition Democratic
Party, encouraged residents to boycott the election, and Draskovic
placed third in the balloting.

Seeking revenge, Draskovic joined with Milosevic's Socialist Party
of Serbia to oust Djindjic as mayor of Belgrade. Draskovic then
joined the Yugoslav government, dominated by Milosevic supporters,
before he was expelled earlier this year. "I will not be duped
again by the selfish (opposition) people," Draskovic says.

But other opposition groups have banded together under the Alliance
for Change and say they will pursue Milosevic's ouster regardless
of Draskovic.

"We don't need Vuk. We're stronger than him. He thinks of himself
as a king," Filipovic says. "We have a growing popularity. We
are a force. We have real power."

But U.S. officials in the Balkans who recently met with nine opposition
leaders in the Yugoslav republic of Montenegro aren't so sure.
They privately criticize the opposition movement, calling it weak
and pitiful. They expect Milosevic to survive the latest protests
and possibly invite Draskovic to rejoin the government to keep
the opposition divided.



LOAD-DATE: July 02, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, Ivan Milutinovic, Reuters; Turning against Milosevic: Retirees sign a petition demanding the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic during a protest Thursday in Belgrade.


Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


313 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The New York Times


November 3, 2013 Sunday  
Late Edition - Final


Srdja Popovic, 76, Champion of Rights


BYLINE: By WILLIAM YARDLEY


SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Obituary; Pg. 30


LENGTH: 947 words


Srdja Popovic, a Serbian lawyer and celebrated human rights advocate who pressed for reform and free speech for five decades, first under Communist rule in the former Yugoslavia and later under the strongman Slobodan Milosevic and his successors, died on Tuesday in Belgrade. He was 76.

His death was confirmed by his family's law firm, Popovic, Popovic, Samardzija & Popovic, which was founded by his father, Miodrag, in 1933. 

Mr. Popovic's principal work was representing commercial clients, many of them international. But in the late 1960s he began a side career defending writers, artists and political dissidents who dared to criticize Communist Yugoslavia. By the mid-1970s he had become one of the accused -- and something of an international cause célèbre because of it.

In March 1976, Mr. Popovic was sentenced to a year in prison for ''maliciously spreading false information and causing public disorder,'' the Communist authorities declared. His supposed crime was agreeing with the views of a client, a dissident and poet named Dragoljub S. Ignjatovic.

The charges stemmed from courtroom arguments that Mr. Popovic had made two years earlier, when he tried to introduce evidence supporting Mr. Ignjatovic's claim that Yugoslavia's economic policies were failing.

Less than two weeks after Mr. Popovic was sentenced, and after international human rights and legal groups had publicized his case, a group of 106 prominent American lawyers signed a petition asking President Josip Broz Tito of Yugoslavia to free him.

The signers included Ramsey Clark, the attorney general under President Lyndon B. Johnson; Telford Taylor, a lead prosecutor at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials after World War II; and Cyrus R. Vance, the president of the New York City Bar Association, who would be named secretary of state by President Jimmy Carter the next year.

An appeals court suspended Mr. Popovic's sentence in late May, though it banned him from practicing law for a year.

Mr. Popovic (his full name is pronounced SIR-ja POE-pa-vich) went on to represent more dissidents. In 1984, he was asked to defend many of the so-called Belgrade Six, a group of Yugoslavs charged with holding meetings for the purpose of ''abolishing the existing government.''

The dubiousness of the charges -- the meetings were public and had gone on for years -- and the Yugoslav authorities' treatment of Mr. Popovic drew international attention. As he was preparing his case, prosecutors listed him as a potential witness, disqualifying him under Yugoslav law from serving as a defense lawyer.

After Yugoslavia splintered and Mr. Milosevic rose to power in the late 1980s advocating Serbian nationalism, Mr. Popovic was among the first to speak out against him. A magazine he started in 1990 -- its title, Vreme, means ''time'' in Serbian -- became a leading anti-Milosevic voice.

''When Milosevic 'cleansed' the media, we suddenly got a lot of reporters,'' Mr. Popovic said in a 2011 interview with a Slovenian weekly. ''This was an excellent opportunity to do something.''

He left Yugoslavia the next year to live in the United States, in part because of the political climate under Mr. Milosevic. Later, as the Bosnian war expanded, he accused many Serbs, even opponents of Mr. Milosevic, of allowing Serbian nationalism to blind them to their complicity in widespread brutality.

''The people are sunk in their passivity because they know they are guilty,'' he told The New York Times in 1997. ''They know the lies they took in -- they know they triumphed when Sarajevo was bombed. As a nation they have lost all self-respect.''

He returned to Belgrade in 2000, after Mr. Milosevic was ousted.

In recent years, he represented the family of the former Serbian prime minister Zoran Djindjic, who was assassinated in 2003. Mr. Djindjic, a reformer who sought alliances with Europe, allowed for Mr. Milosevic and others to be extradited to The Hague to face war-crimes charges. Mr. Popovic argued that the assassination was essentially a coup attempt by nationalist supporters that involved far more than the 12 members of the secret police and organized crime who were convicted in the killing in 2007.

Mr. Popovic was born on Feb. 24, 1937, in Belgrade. His name sometimes appears with the middle initial M., a Serbian custom that signifies the first letter of his father's first name. He received his law degree from the University of Belgrade in 1961.

His survivors include his wife and four children. He is not related to a prominent younger man of the same name who was among the leaders of Otpor, a student group whose demonstrations helped lead to the ouster of Mr. Milosevic in 2000.

In the 1970s, Mr. Popovic was a founding partner of the World Association of Lawyers, which focused on international legal issues. In the 1980s he was part of a prominent group of lawyers who tried to end the death penalty in Yugoslavia, where executions were carried out by firing squad. In the early '90s he was president of the European Movement in Serbia, which supports integration with the European Union.

Mr. Popovic represented a wide range of clients, not just those whose political views he might share. He represented people accused of war crimes and political leaders who supported brutal violence. In the shifting and often confusing alliances and divisions of Balkan politics, he said one constant should be the right of everyone to an honest justice system.

''My father had an idealistic understanding that a lawyer is most needed for those who have many enemies, and those are political prisoners,'' he once said. ''Against them are the media, the state, the court, the prosecution, and sometimes even their family.''


URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/03/world/europe/srdja-popovic-76-champion-of-rights-dies.html


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2013


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Srdja Popovic began defending writers and dissidents in Yugoslavia in the 1960s. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MARKO CVETKOVIC/ESQUIRE SERBIA)


DOCUMENT-TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company


314 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


October 24, 1999, Sunday, Final Edition


Serbs Fear Milosevic Will Never Leave; Yugoslav Leader Could Turn Crippled Economy, Country's Isolation to His Advantage


William Drozdiak, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A31


LENGTH: 1355 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Oct. 23


 

He has lost four wars in the past decade and seen his dream of a Greater Serbia shrivel as it became a pariah state. He has presided over the collapse of the economy and watched his army retreat from the nation's most hallowed plot of ground.

Yet more than four months after Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic bowed to NATO demands and pulled his troops out of Kosovo, the world's only indicted war criminal to be running a country remains safely ensconced in his hilltop palace outside Belgrade, where he continues to shape the destiny of Europe's most volatile region.

As Serbia's 10 million citizens approach what promises to be an agonizing winter, the likelihood of a bloody political confrontation seems greater than at any time since the 1996 street marches protesting the outcome of local elections nearly toppled Milosevic. Yet interviews with more than a dozen prominent politicians, economists, writers and academics reflect mounting fears that Milosevic may again turn his people's adversity to his advantage and sustain his reign indefinitely beyond the 10 years he has already served. 

At a glance, the Yugoslav leader's situation would appear untenable. He is isolated by the West, key domestic allies have abandoned him and support for his Socialist Party is deteriorating rapidly. The economy is in a shambles and sources of government funds used to ensure loyalty have all but dried up. Army officers are reported to be dismayed by what they view as a political capitulation, rather than a military defeat, in the Kosovo war.

During the opening this month of a newly rebuilt railway station in Leskovac, Milosevic acknowledged for the first time that living standards were dropping. "Nobody has to tell us that we are going through difficult times that may get worse," he said. The biting effect of economic sanctions, especially targeted measures such as the ban on 308 Milosevic allies from traveling to 28 countries, have eroded support for the Yugoslav leader even among those considered to be his cronies.

"The fact that Milosevic is going public much more often than in the past is a sign that he is nervous," said Ivan Vejvoda, executive director of the Fund for an Open Society Yugoslavia, backed by U.S. financier George Soros. "He knows that a solid majority of the people are now against him and he no longer has the resources, let alone the backing of the West, to prop up his position."

The Yugoslav army is another source of anxiety for Milosevic, who has never enjoyed good relations with what Momcilo Perisic, a former armed forces chief of staff, calls "the last democratic institution left in the country." Military sources say there have been six foiled coup attempts against the president since 1989, and he has regularly removed top generals to prevent any of them from becoming too ambitious.

"Milosevic has changed a lot in the past few months," says Bratislav Grubacic, a Belgrade editor who maintains close ties with the government and the opposition. "He has grown much more temperamental and does not like to hear bad news. He used to listen to other viewpoints, but now he gives monologues and is surrounded by yes men. Most of all, it kills him that none of those famous Western statesmen come to visit him anymore."

But Milosevic's foes, at home and abroad, have learned to their chagrin not to make premature predictions about his downfall. He maintains absolute control over the police, the banks and the electronic media. He exercises an authoritarian rule that helps him deflate dissent and confuse his opponents. Most of all, he manipulates his political rivals with ruthless guile, leaving many opponents in despair over Serbia's prospects of evolving into a mature democracy.

"Milosevic has used every war--with Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and now Kosovo--to consolidate his power," said Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party and a leader of the opposition alliance. "Whenever he feels weak, he provokes a crisis and seizes upon it as an opportunity to secure even greater control."

For Djindjic and other foes of the government, the Kosovo war ended in the worst possible way. The southern province, revered as the soul of the Serbian nation for more than six centuries, was severed from the homeland and placed under an international protectorate. The refugee burden has grown to staggering proportions, with 700,000 homeless Serbs seeking shelter. Relations with the republic of Montenegro, which along with Serbia forms what is left of the Yugoslav federation, were strained to the breaking point.

Damage from the war and international sanctions has nearly ruined the economy, accelerating an exodus of Serbia's best and brightest that has seen 300,000 educated professionals flee the country in the past 10 years. Facing the truth about the brutal deportation of Kosovo Albanians has plunged many Serbs into a state of moral depression, making them feel, as one writer says, "like the Nazis of the Nineties." And worst of all, Milosevic still retains his grip on power--with no promise that he will soon let go.

"People here feel doubly betrayed, by Milosevic and by the West," said Svetozar Cvetkovic, a well-known actor and theater director. "He tricked us into believing life would get better when it only got worse. And the West made us believe they would destroy Milosevic and his war machine, but instead they bombed the cities and people that have been trying to get rid of him."

Much of the antipathy toward the West evident during the war, as demonstrators ridiculed NATO bombs by wearing mock targets, has subsided. But so has much of the energy that motivated anti-Milosevic protesters to take to the streets last month for nightly demonstrations to persuade the government to call early elections.

Instead, Milosevic has sought to demoralize his opposition by exploiting the rivalry between his two principal challengers, Djindjic and Vuk Draskovic, the head of the Serbian Renewal Movement. Ever since 1996, when protests erupted after Milosevic tried to block an opposition victory in local elections, Djindjic and Draskovic have fought for control of Belgrade city hall and tried to undermine each other's political fortunes.

Early this month, Draskovic was injured in a traffic accident that killed his brother-in-law and three bodyguards after a huge truck veered into their caravan on an open highway. When the truck could not be traced by authorities and the driver escaped, Draskovic accused the government of trying to assassinate him because of fears that his popularity was becoming a direct challenge to Milosevic.

Not to be outdone, Djindjic this week accused Milosevic and his powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, of ordering security forces to plot his own assassination. He said police were taking pictures of his residence and scrutinizing the weapons of his bodyguards in preparation for an attack on his life. "This kind of organized terrorism shows how nervous Milosevic is getting," Djindjic said. "The only way to stop it is by bringing it to the attention of the people."

Far from outraging the public, the rival assassination claims by Djindjic and Draskovic seem only to have deepened their animosity and held the two up to greater ridicule. During the war, both men found their reputations sullied. Draskovic's position of deputy prime minister held him open to charges of collaborating with Milosevic, while Djindjic was called a coward after fleeing Belgrade for the relative safety of Montenegro.

"Why would anybody want to kill these guys?" said Vojislav Seselj, the ultranationalist leader of the Serbian Radical Party that is allied with Milosevic. "We should be offering to provide for their protection. They are the ideal opposition because they will never be capable of coming to power."

A protester carries a newspaper with headline "Changes" at one of the recent daily demonstrations in the Serbian capital against Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic. Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic maintains his position, despite economic crisis and loss of key allies.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1999 The Washington Post


315 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 25, 1999, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


Serbian Protesters Install Their Own Government


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 


SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 


LENGTH: 882 words


DATELINE: NOVI SAD, Serbia, Sept. 23
