330 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


March 29, 1999, Monday, Late Edition - Final


CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN BELGRADE -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops;
Support for Homeland Up as Sirens Wail and News Is Censored


BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER


SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk


LENGTH: 1721 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 28


Slobodan Milosevic, defiant as ever and proud of his nation's resistance to NATO's air attacks, staged an eerie celebration today -- a rock concert in the center of Belgrade to show solidarity with the soldiers facing down the allied assaults.

Few of the thousands of Serbs who attended were unaware that this was also the 10th anniversary of the day when Mr. Milosevic stripped broad autonomy from Kosovo, just after his security forces had killed some 30 ethnic Albanian protesters in Pristina, Kosovo's capital. 

Today, the Serbian security forces are sweeping through Kosovo, driving tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians into panicked flight and provoking what Western officials described as the worst refugee crisis that Europe has seen in 50 years.

In Belgrade, given strict censorship rules and the patriotic fever of wartime, few Serbs seemed to know much about events in Kosovo, or the Western reaction. They poured their scorn on the Americans, rejoicing in what Serbian television persistently called the shooting down of an F-117A stealth jet, and rallied around their nation -- and, by extension, its leader, Mr. Milosevic -- in a way not seen here in years.

The rock concert organized to celebrate the holiday known as "the day of Serbia's statehood" bore an ironic resemblance to similar concerts held by anti-Milosevic demonstrators during the mass pro-democracy demonstrations of 1996-97 in Belgrade.

The same bands played today to some of the same people, by their own account, symbolizing the unifying effect that air strikes have had on the general population. "Forget who is supporting whom, this is no time for divisions," said one of the leading singers at the rally, Dejan Cukic.

Many of the thousands at the afternoon rally -- called "Songs Keep Us Alive and United" -- wore small placards on their chests displaying a black target. One placard referred to the downing of the stealth aircraft, and read: "F-117A. Sorry, we didn't know that you are invisible." Another redefined NATO as "New American Terrorist Organization," while others compared President Clinton to Hitler, whose air force bombed Belgrade in 1941.

During much of the rally, Belgrade was under an air raid alert. The first bombs fell today at about 4 A.M., and then again at 8 A.M., with their detonations preceding any air raid sirens. Air raid warnings continued to howl after dark. Tonight, however, in contrast to Friday and Saturday night, when the city was plunged into darkness, most of Belgrade's street lights stayed on.

Mr. Milosevic held a meeting of his Cabinet and military leaders and issued a statement praising the army and the citizenry. The two were linked "by strong unity, a high patriotic conscience and determination to endure in the just struggle against the criminal aggressors," the statement said. "Our citizens are demonstrating high personal responsibility and a high degree of mutual solidarity."

There was no reference to increasingly blunt Western charges that Mr. Milosevic's armed forces and police units are engaged in widespread atrocities in Kosovo.

Western reporters with no access to Kosovo were largely reduced to interviewing the ethnic Albanian refugees pouring across its borders, a situation reminiscent of Cambodia in the mid-1970s, when the victorious Khmer Rouge emptied the cities and reporters had to piece together the scale of atrocities from the refugees who straggled into Thailand.

On Serbian state television's evening news, the Serbian Minister for Refugees, Bratislava Morina, whose late husband was a Kosovo Albanian Communist, suggested that ethnic Albanians were fleeing NATO bombs, not the Serbian military. "If NATO wants these people to return to their homes, it should stop this aggression immediately," she said.

Still, the official Tanjug news agency did announce that NATO planes attacked before and after sunrise, targeting the air force base in the Belgrade suburb of Batajnica for the fourth consecutive day. Two other explosions cracked windows at Belgrade's main civilian airport, Surcin, 15 miles from the city center. Other missiles fell near Cacak, the site of a huge military factory in central Serbia, Tanjug said. In Kosovo, four bombs hit an army barracks outside Prizren, the agency said. There was no report of any casualties. To date, the Yugoslav media has talked of dozens killed in the air raids.

At the rally, words of general patriotism came from noted performers like Mr. Cukic and Momcilo Bagajic, known as Bajaga, who said, "We should defend ourselves." Mr. Bagajic is known not to be a rabid nationalist, and he has played in other parts of the former Yugoslavia, like Slovenia.

He wrote a hugely popular and moving song about the Yugoslav civil wars, largely initiated by Mr. Milosevic, that says, "My friends are pearls scattered all over the world." Ironically, the Government is now playing the song often on state television as a backdrop to patriotic pictures of the Yugoslav armed forces.

One member of the Children of Bad Musicians, a popular group, told the crowd, "I used to play sax, but since that sex maniac plays it, I don't touch it anymore."

Olga, a 43-year-old economist wearing a fur vest and Italian shoes, said she never went to the air raid shelters because she could not bring her English setter, Loli. She is no fan of Mr. Milosevic, she said, but war is no time for divisions. "I was in all the demonstrations for democracy," she said, "but now I have to be in favor of defending my homeland."

In an interview, Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democratic Party and an organizer of the pro-democracy demonstrations, noted the irony. "The bombs have marginalized any dissenters here, and there's little we democrats can do to affect the situation," he said. "The same is also true of those democrats and moderates among the ethnic Albanians," he noted.

Washington has spent more on one day's bombs than it ever spent helping the democracy movement in Yugoslavia, Mr. Djindjic said bitterly. "Milosevic could be far more easily eliminated through the development of democracy here than through air strikes," he said. "Every crisis strengthens him. The only players that matter now are Milosevic, the Kosovo Liberation Army and the Americans."

The consequences of the air strikes are "this radicalized and pauperized Serbia and a destabilized Montenegro," whose independence Washington wants to encourage under President Milo Djukanovic, Mr. Djindjic said. Yugoslavia consists of Serbia and Montenegro, and Mr. Djukanovic is a former protege of Mr. Milosevic who in the last year has turned against the Yugoslav President. "Now Djukanovic is compromised by the bombs, and there is more anti-American feeling in the entire region," Mr. Djindjic said.

There are Yugoslav military and police depots and headquarters in Montenegro, and NATO has bombed them freely, despite a statement by Mr. Djukanovic that Montenegro would stay neutral in any fight between NATO and Serbia.

Mr. Djindjic and Mr. Djukanovic are close, and Mr. Djukanovic told him the day the bombs started dropping that no one in the American Government ever telephoned to explain the situation or to warn him, Mr. Djindjic said. "Ordinary people in Montenegro will now say that Djukanovic based his entire policy on America, but we're getting bombed just as badly as Milosevic," Mr. Djindjic said. "This will make it much more difficult for Montenegro to secede."

The evening news gave a hint of a Russian initiative to solve this crisis, announcing that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Mr. Milosevic had exchanged letters. But the Yugoslav Ambassador to Moscow, Mr. Milosevic's brother, Borislav, said he could not confirm that the two Presidents would meet, and there was no indication that a Russian delegation, which arrived tonight and includes former Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar, would get anywhere with its own peace initiative. France said it was pressing the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, to seek a diplomatic solution. Russia is a traditional backer of Serbia.

For the first time today, the Yugoslav Government organized a junket for some 70 foreign journalists here -- dominated by non-NATO countries like Japan -- to the site where the F-117A crashed, in Budjanovci, 30 miles northwest of Belgrade. Reporters, in two buses, were only allowed to see the remains of a wing while local villagers danced with evident joy at this small triumph of their hugely outgunned military.

A young boy wearing a knitted cap with the logo of the Chicago Bulls stood on the American Air Force star painted on the wing, while the assembled cameramen scrambled for angles. The boy had a toy pistol in one hand while he tried to make the Serbian victory sign with the other.

The evening news said that, in addition to the wartime censorship that now applies to media, new wartime banking rules were established to fund the military, and that profiteering would be punished severely. In the newspaper Glas Javnosti today, there was a story about the arrest of the first "war profiteers" in the city of Nis, a man and his son who owned a gas station and were hoarding 3,171 liters of gasoline, 5,300 liters of diesel fuel and 1,000 liters of oil. Gasoline is nearly unavailable now except on the black market, where the price has now reached almost 10 German marks a liter, many times its price a week ago.

On the back page, however, there was a story about the opening of the yearly automobile show at the Belgrade Fair, featuring a photograph of the new Volkswagen Beetle.

Also today, Dragoslav Rancic, a senior contributing editor of the weekly magazine Nin, and his editor, Stevan Niksic, were released from police custody. They were arrested early on Saturday for offending censorship regulations with an article about Mr. Milosevic's negotiating style. Friends said they had not been beaten by the police.

No Belgrade newspaper published a word about their arrest, a sharp contrast to the solidarity local journalists displayed when Veran Matic, the chief editor of the banned radio station B92, was detained for eight hours last Wednesday. But on Wednesday night, the first NATO bombs fell on Belgrade, and, as one local journalist said bitterly, "media solidarity is evidently another casualty."
  

http://www.nytimes.com


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Children played yesterday around a big target symbol with the message "This is Belgrade" placed in front of the United States culture center. A boy carrying his belongings left an air raid shelter in Belgrade yesterday after the latest wave of NATO air strikes on Yugoslavia. (Photographs by Agence France-Presse)(pg. A12)      


Copyright 1999 The New York Times Company


331 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


January 09, 1997, Thursday, Final Edition


Reform or Repression? Milosevic Hesitates


Michael Dobbs, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A23


LENGTH: 1144 words


DATELINE: BELGRADE, Jan. 8


 

Shortly after the eruption of Serbia's present political crisis, a cartoon appeared in a local newspaper that summed up the critical choice facing Europe's last old-style communist boss. The drawing showed Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic standing at a fork in the road. A signpost offered him a choice of two directions: "Europe" and "Romania."

The newspaper readers understood "Europe" as shorthand for the introduction of the rule of law, radical economic reform and an end to the international isolation that resulted from Serbia's involvement in the 3 1/2-year war in neighboring Bosnia. "Romania," by contrast, was the code word for a full-blooded communist dictatorship cut off from the outside world and condemned to a future of economic penury. 

It has been 50 days since protests erupted in Belgrade over the alleged theft of local elections by the Milosevic government. Seemingly oblivious to the political turmoil all around him, the Serbian strongman has been hesitating in front of the imaginary signpost, either unwilling or unable to take an irrevocable step in one direction or another. In the view of most political analysts, time is now running out for him to make a decision.

"We are living on a knife edge," said Ivan Stambolic, a former Serbian president and political mentor to Milosevic who was forced out of office in 1987 after his protege embraced the cause of Serb nationalism. "Neither side wants to resort to violence, but the situation is so tense that a single incident could spark a general conflagration."

Milosevic's problem, and the best explanation for his hesitation, is that either course leads to likely political oblivion. The experience of Eastern Europe has shown that any communist leader who introduces democracy and radical economic reform is almost certain to be booted out of office in the next election. If he resorted to the Romanian variant, he might succeed in holding on to power a little longer, but could eventually suffer the fate of Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed by his own army on Dec. 25, 1989.

Over the past weeks, Milosevic has alternated between repression and reconciliation, and today was no exception. This afternoon, riot police were out on the streets of Belgrade to enforce a ban on marches by anti-Milosevic demonstrators. This evening, however, the Serbian government made a significant concession to the opposition coalition known as Together by acknowledging an election defeat in the southern city of Nis.

One of the most striking things about the present crisis has been Milosevic's own silence. His last big public appearance was on Dec. 24, when he addressed a rally of his supporters in Belgrade. A week later, he gave a three-minute televised address to mark New Year's Eve.

Over the past month, Milosevic has withdrawn into self-imposed seclusion, refusing to meet with Western diplomats or the more liberal wing of the ruling coalition. Instead, he has surrounded himself with political cronies and appears to be relying heavily for advice on his wife, Mirjana Markovic, a hard-boiled Marxist ideologist and founder of the hard-line Yugoslav United Left party.

"In essence, he rules alone," said a former political ally who recently fell out with Milosevic. "He has created a kind of virtual reality for himself. If something does not fit into his plan, he thinks there is something wrong with reality and that it is simply necessary to change the person who was unable to carry out his orders."

This source compared Serbian politics to Indonesian shadow-puppet plays: "You can see the figures, but the real play is taking place in the shadows. There are two parallel systems of government, one of which is public and has no power. The other government exists in secret, and has all the power but no responsibility."

Western diplomats and Serbian officials alike worry that there is practically no one in Milosevic's inner entourage who is prepared to tell him the truth. According to these accounts, one of the few people in Belgrade who is ready to speak frankly with the Serbian leader is the U.S. charge d'affaires, Richard Miles. Milosevic, however, has refused to meet with Miles or any other Western ambassador for the past month.

"He is mad at the Americans because he thinks that they have cheated him," said a pro-Milosevic politician, noting that the United States had relied on Milosevic to push through the 1995 Dayton peace agreement on Bosnia. "The hard-liners are playing on this anger."

According to this source, Milosevic initially appeared willing to accept the loss of Belgrade and other cities in the Nov. 17 elections. In private conversations, he predicted that the opposition would rapidly demonstrate its political incompetence and be unable to deal with the huge problems of running a big city. "They have a plane, but they don't have a pilot," the Serbian president remarked scornfully.

Something happened during the next two days, however, to make Milosevic change his mind about the wisdom of surrendering control over Serbia's big cities. It is widely assumed that his wife and other hard-liners in her party, a member of Serbia's ruling coalition, persuaded Milosevic not to risk allowing the opposition to gain such a prominent political platform for its views.

In the past, Milosevic has shown himself to be an extraordinarily agile politician, capable of some stunning U-turns. An orthodox communist until 1987, he helped to plunge Yugoslavia into war by transforming himself virtually overnight into the advocate of a Greater Serbia that would incorporate Serb-populated areas of Croatia and Bosnia. In 1993, he switched course once again and denounced his former Bosnian Serb allies for "suicidal" nationalism.

According to associates, Milosevic frequently takes a long time to make up his mind, weighing all the options before him. On this occasion, however, his penchant for procrastination is turning into a liability. The longer he waits, the stronger the opposition becomes and the more concessions he will have to make to negotiate a solution to the crisis. Time is against him.

"The only thing that Milosevic is concerned about is power, and that power is being eroded day by day," said Miodrag Perisic, a leader of the Democratic Party, which belongs to the Together coalition.

What started out as a relatively manageable protest against stolen elections has now mushroomed into a full-fledged democracy movement. Opposition leaders have made clear that they will not be satisfied with partial concessions, such as control of the Nis city government. The minimum political price for ending the street demonstrations is full access to the media and a level playing field for Serbia's presidential and parliamentary elections, which are scheduled later this year.


LOAD-DATE: January 09, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1997 The Washington Post


332 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Herald-Sun (Durham, NC)


June 12, 2000 Monday  
FINAL Edition


News in brief


BYLINE: - FROM WIRE REPORTS


SECTION: INSIDE FRONT; Pg. A3


LENGTH: 1703 words


NATIONAL

Republicans plan to push Medicare drug proposal

WASHINGTON - House Republicans will flesh out their proposal for Medicare drug benefits this week and try to push it through two House committees in three days, despite fierce objections from many Democrats.

Republicans said Sunday that they would combine their drug plan with a proposal to give more money to health maintenance organizations - perhaps $4 billion over five years - in hopes of halting the exodus of HMOs from Medicare.

In the last two years, HMOs pulling out of Medicare have disrupted insurance arrangements for more than 700,000 elderly people, and many more health plans are expected to withdraw this year. 

Under the Republican proposal, the government would subsidize private insurance to cover pharmaceutical costs for Medicare beneficiaries. Such insurance, covering only drug costs, is now unavailable, and insurance companies say they do not intend to sell it, but the Republicans have set aside up to $40 billion over the next five years to buy it.

A summary of the House Republican plan says the government would guarantee access to drug coverage if private insurers did not offer it.

Burton: Clinton, Gore, Reno will be prosecuted

WASHINGTON - The chief Republican congressional investigator of political fund raising in 1996 said he is likely to refer President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and Attorney General Janet Reno for prosecution after a new president takes office next year.

Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., said Sunday it appears Reno obstructed justice by refusing several times to request special prosecutors to investigate Clinton and Gore for money-raising irregularities during their campaign four years ago.

Clinton and Gore knew they were breaking the law concerning illegal campaign contributions, Burton said, but "I can't give you the specifics of it right now."

Clinton's chief of staff, John Podesta, said Burton's main intent is to inflict political damage on Gore in his run for the presidency.

Anti-smog formula helps hike gas prices

CAMARILLO, Calif. - Gasoline prices climbed 8.82 cents a gallon in the past three weeks as a new kind of reformulated gas made its way to the pumps, giving some cities an average price of more than $2 a gallon.

High crude oil prices, rising demand and new anti-smog regulations affecting 17 metropolitan areas pushed the nationwide average cost to $1.6723 a gallon Friday, analyst Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. That compares to the May 19 Lundberg Survey of 10,000 stations nationwide that found a national average of $1.5841.

Metropolitan areas with some of the worst air pollution in the nation were required by June 1 to start using a new kind of gas that is designed to preserve air quality.

Lundberg predicted gasoline prices might drop slightly in coming weeks, especially if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decides to increase production this month. But the price won't come near last year's weighted average on June 11 of $1.19.

AMA urges doctors to boost membership

CHICAGO - The American Medical Association is asking doctors to become salespeople to boost its flagging membership.

While it remains America's largest group of doctors, only about a third of the nation's 800,000-plus physicians, medical residents and medical students belong.

Membership, now at 293,695, is down about 2 percent from the end of last year, Dr. E. Ratcliffe Anderson Jr., the AMA's executive vice president, told delegates attending the first day of the annual AMA meeting Sunday.

Membership woes are "the thousand-pound gorilla in the living room," said Anderson, who urged doctors to pressure their colleagues and recruit non-members.

CIA, FBI decide Iranian defector is imposter

WASHINGTON - The CIA and FBI reportedly have concluded that an Iranian defector who claims to be a former intelligence official and terrorist mastermind is an impostor.

The defector claimed to have masterminded the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, and the 1996 attack against a U.S. military installation in Saudi Arabia. Two Libyans are now on trial for the Pan Am bombing.

A U.S. intelligence official quoted anonymously in The Washington Post on Sunday said the CIA and FBI concluded the defector lied during interviews with intelligence officials and lacked basic knowledge of Iran's intelligence apparatus.

U.S. officials have doubted the defector's credibility since he first told his story on "60 Minutes" on CBS June 4. Iran vehemently denied the defector's claims.

INTERNATIONAL

Milosevic's allies say West sullied Montenegro vote

PODGORICA, Yugoslavia - Allies of President Slobodan Milosevic accused the West of using financial aid to buy votes in Montenegro's local elections, which were held Sunday in two cities and were seen as a referendum on the republic's pro-Western policies.

Voting reportedly went smoothly in the Montenegrin capital, Podgorica, and the coastal town of Herceg Novi. After the polls closed, however, police had to separate pro-and anti-Milosevic groups in Podgorica as tensions rose.

First returns were not expected before early today. However, anti-Milosevic groups, confident of victory in Podgorica, drove in convoys throughout the city, honking horns in celebration.

Although the elections were for local posts, the two towns account for one-third of the republic's registered voters. As a result, Sunday's elections provided the first electoral test for supporters of Montenegro's pro-Western President Milo Djukanovic, who took office in 1998.

Israelis, Palestinians leave for treaty talks

JERUSALEM - Israeli and Palestinian negotiators left Sunday for peace treaty talks in Washington, despite the uncertainty cast over the Middle East by Syrian President Hafez Assad's death.

The Palestinians for the first time can expect Israel's undivided attention, since a resumption of Israeli-Syrian talks in the near future is very unlikely. Assad's successor, apparently his son Bashar, will need time to consolidate his rule.

When talks on both tracks were proceeding simultaneously last winter, the Palestinians were worried that Israel would play one Arab partner against the other to extract concessions on both.

Israeli Justice Minister Yossi Beilin said Sunday that Assad's death could give Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat more freedom in the negotiations. In the past, Assad has been sharply critical of Arafat for negotiating a separate peace with Israel. Several Palestinian groups opposed to peace with Israel are based in Syria.

Reformers get posts in Iran's parliament

TEHRAN, Iran - A one-time hard-liner and veteran revolutionary who now favors democratic reforms was elected Sunday as the speaker of Iran's first reformist-dominated parliament in more than 20 years.

Mehdi Karrubi was elected unopposed in a compromise between hard-liners and moderates who said they wanted to avoid further tension at a time when the two factions are locked in a power struggle.

Two leading reformers, including Mohammad-Reza Khatami, brother of the liberal president, were elected deputy speakers of the 290-seat Majlis, or parliament, during a session broadcast live on state-run Tehran radio. Nine other deputies elected to parliamentary offices also are top allies of President Mohammad Khatami.

The Majlis speaker is the third most powerful person after the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and the president.

Petroleum meeting draws protesters

CALGARY, Alberta - Waving posters and colorful papier-mYch, puppets, hundreds of protesters demonstrated against global energy policies Sunday at the start of the five-day World Petroleum Congress.

The congress, comprising more than 2,500 delegates from 87 countries representing the oil industry, was the latest target of anti-globalization groups who protested the World Trade Organization and the Organization of American States in recent months.

The demonstrators called for developing renewable energy sources such as wind power and solar power while reducing reliance on pollution-causing fossil fuels.

Fearful of street clashes that hindered a WTO meeting in Seattle in December, police imposed stringent security measures. Six-foot-high green fencing created a security zone around a six-block area that surrounding the convention site. Officers armed with riot gear, including pepper spray, batons and bulletproof vests, patrolled the perimeter.

Haitians cast ballots in local, legislative races

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti - Haitians voted Sunday in local and legislative elections in the southern Grand'-Anse District, where voting was postponed on May 21 because of technical problems and political disputes.

There was no violence during the vote, election office president Benoit Guerrier said, despite long lines caused when some stations opened late. Results were expected later this week, with a run-off round scheduled for June 25.

Voter turnout appeared to be good, an indication that residents were ignoring opposition parties who had called for a boycott. Those parties have complained that the May 21 vote was tainted to favor the Lavalas Family Party of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

Two upper-house and 11 lower-house seats were up for election. Eighteen mayoral commissions and hundreds of urban and rural councils were also on the ballot.

Zimbabwe leader raps U.N. on vote monitoring

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's president accused the United Nations of trying to hijack international monitoring of his country's parliamentary elections, which many doubted could be free and fair amid rampant political violence, a newspaper reported Sunday.

The United Nations overstepped its welcome in trying to coordinate election monitoring, President Robert Mugabe complained to a state newspaper, a week after U.N. observers pulled out of the country's election monitoring operations.

Many questioned whether Zimbabwe was even capable of holding fair elections. At least 31 people have been killed in political violence since February. The main opposition Movement for Democratic Change announced Sunday that another organizer had died after being tortured by ruling party supporters.

The June 24-25 election poses the biggest challenge to Mugabe since he led the nation to independence from Britain in 1980.


LOAD-DATE: August 19, 2004


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2000 The Durham Herald Co.


333 of 348 DOCUMENTS


San Jose Mercury News (California)


March 29, 1999 Monday MORNING FINAL EDITION


AIR RAIDS EXPAND 'RACE AGAINST TIME':NATO INTENSIFIES ATTACKS ON SERB TARGETS AS IT PUTS FOCUS ON STOPPING THE 'GENOCIDE' OF ETHNIC ALBANIANS.


BYLINE: STEVEN THOMMA AND RICHARD PARKER, Mercury News Washington, Bureau


SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 1527 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Under growing pressure to stop large-scale Serb atrocities against ethnic Albanians, NATO forces on Sunday intensified air attacks on Yugoslavia, but rejected calls to invade with ground troops.

As the alliance launched its fifth day of airstrikes against Serb military targets throughout Yugoslavia, it stepped up attacks on targets in and around Kosovo, the province where Serb forces are believed to be escalating a bloody campaign against ethnic Albanian civilians.

Sunday evening's attacks involved several dozen jet fighters from Italy and at least a pair of B-52 bombers based in England. The targets included an expanding list of military bunkers, ammunition dumps and fuel depots used by Yugoslav troops in and around Kosovo.

Air-raid sirens sounded in downtown Belgrade at least four times between 4 p.m. and early Sunday evening. Each time, cruise missiles landed on sites that couldn't be identified immediately. 

Earlier Sunday, at least three cruise missiles plowed into a Yugoslav air base near Batajnica. It was the fourth straight day that the base, one of the largest in Yugoslavia, had been hit by a cruise missile attack.

'Genocide is starting'

Calling the expanding air assault a "race against time," NATO spokesman Jamie Shea said: "We are on the brink of a major humanitarian disaster in Kosovo, the likes of which Europe has not seen since the closing stages of World War II."

"Genocide is starting," German Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping said in a television interview with station ZDF.

Thousands of ethnic Albanians fleeing "ethnic cleansing" in Kosovo choked highways Sunday into neighboring Macedonia and Albania, where relief workers scrambled to provide the refugees with basic aid.

Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said as many as 18,000 Serb soldiers are massing for an offensive against the Kosovo Albanians. Pentagon officials said the Yugoslav troops would be attacked when spotted by U.S. jets.

"There are terrible reports about men and women, men being separated from women and children, then . . . being taken off and executed, villages being torched, people arriving across the border with no shoes, and literally told to leave their villages," Albright said on CBS's "Face the Nation."

After days of pointing to increasing atrocities as justification for the decision to attack, U.S. officials Sunday shifted tactics as they found themselves insisting the airstrikes did not cause the increased bloodshed.

Albright said Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic "was planning to do this anyway. It is just simply an upside-down argument to think that NATO or we have made this get worse."

Defense Secretary William Cohen said Sunday that the air campaign would not be deterred by the downing Saturday of a F-117A stealth fighter near the Yugoslav capital of Belgrade. Serb authorities boasted that they shot down the plane, the first NATO aircraft to have been downed in the conflict. But U.S. officials said Sunday they had not yet determined conclusively whether the plane was shot down or crashed for some other reason.

President Clinton said after a meeting with his national security advisers at the White House on Sunday that he was relieved the American pilot was rescued. He reminded Americans again that "this military operation entails real risks."

But he added that "the continued brutality and repression of the Serb forces further underscores the need for NATO to persevere" and said he strongly supports the decision to expand the airstrikes.

"We're looking at an expanded set of targets, and we're going to go more intensively after some targets," said NATO Commander Gen. Wesley Clark, a U.S. Army general.

"We're entering a phase which is more focused on trying to stop the humanitarian catastrophe which is taking place on the ground," said NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana from his headquarters in Brussels, Belgium.

Pope John Paul II used his Palm Sunday address in Rome to urge a peaceful solution.

"It is never too late to meet and negotiate," he said.

Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic told Russian television that his government is ready to return to peace talks if NATO stops bombing.

"You cannot talk under bombs. There can be no agreement under bombs," he said. But he did not indicate Yugoslavia would accept the peace agreement already signed by the ethnic Albanians.

While NATO warplanes and missiles Sunday were aimed at some ground troops and even more military targets like headquarters and command bunkers, they were still trying to find and destroy Yugoslavia's sophisticated air-defense system. Serb forces have frustrated NATO officials by rarely using their surface-to-air missiles and thus not exposing them to likely destruction by NATO forces.

NATO needs to take out the air defenses to clear the way for the slower and lower-flying planes like the A-10 Warthog that will ultimately be needed to effectively attack the 300 or so Serb tanks used to shell ethnic Albanianvillages and to support the ground troops that are suspected of storming through the countryside and committing atrocities.

Yugoslavia's Tanjug state news agency reported that on Sunday night seven missiles hit near Pristina, close enough to break windows at the central hotel that houses the Serbian Media Center. It also said two explosions shook the northern Serbian town of Sombor.

The missiles that rained on Pristina targeted Mount Veternik to the southwest and suburban Ajvalija, where a large army barracks is located, Tanjug said.

The agency also said that up to 20 missiles had hit the region of Gnjilane, 22 miles southeast of Pristina. Initial reports said at least three people had been wounded.

Ground troops needed?

The failure so far to deter Serb aggression against the ethnic Albanians raised fresh questions Sunday about whether the bombing can stop the Serbs or whether NATO ultimately would be forced to invade or arm the ethnic Albanian resistance movement, the Kosovo Liberation Army.

"I don't know myself of any war . . . that's been won totally by air power," said Sen. Richard Shelby, R-Ala., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

"We have to exercise every option," said Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. "We have to do whatever it takes. All of us would grieve at the loss of a single American. But when you go into these things, the primary purpose cannot be the safety of your forces. It has to be the achievement of your strategic and tactical goals."

Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger echoed that, saying, "We have to take whatever measures are necessary, even, reluctantly, introducing ground forces if that is the only way to accomplish it."

Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., a supporter of the NATO assault, agreed that airstrikes alone would not stop the "ethnic cleansing."

"Clearly you can't stop the kind of slaughter and terrorism on the ground without some contradictory opposing force on the ground," he said.

But Lieberman said he opposes a NATO or American invasion, preferring instead that the alliance supply arms to the Kosovo Albanians and let them fight for themselves.

U.S. and NATO officials ruled out any use of alliance soldiers or arms on the ground.

"We have no intention of sending ground forces," said White House national security adviser Samuel "Sandy" Berger. "We will continue this campaign as long as it is necessary, until the job is finished."

Gen. Henry Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on CNN that it would take "hundreds of thousands of ground troops over a rather protracted period of time and in a very dangerous situation" to invade Yugoslavia and forcefully stop Serb repression of ethnic Albanians.

Clinton and NATO have committed to deploying troops in Kosovo to enforce a peace agreement if the Serbs sign it, and NATO officials appeared less rigid in ruling out the use of ground troops at some time in the future.

"I don't know how things are going to evolve, but at this point troops will not be deployed on the ground," Solana said.

Belgrade rock concert

Meanwhile, a defiant Milosevic staged a rock concert in the center of Belgrade on Sunday to show solidarity with the soldiers facing down the allied assaults.

Sunday was also the 10th anniversary of the day Milosevic stripped broad autonomy from Kosovo, just after his security forces had killed some 30 ethnic Albanian protesters in Pristina, Kosovo's capital.

In Belgrade, given strict censorship rules and the patriotic fever of wartime, few Serbs seemed to know much about the events in Kosovo or Western reaction to them.

The concert organized to celebrate the holiday known as "the day of Serbia's statehood" bore an ironic resemblance to similar concerts held by anti-Milosevic demonstrators during the mass pro-democracy demonstrations of 1996-97 in Belgrade.

The same bands played Sunday to some of the same people, by their ownaccount symbolizing the unifying effect that airstrikes have had on the general population. "Forget who is supporting whom, this is no time for divisions," said one of the lead singers at the rally, Dejan Cukic.


LOAD-DATE: October 25, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: ATTACK ON YUGOSLAVIA
RELATED STORIES: pages 1A, and 8A-11A Mark Milstein in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, and Mercury News wire services contributed to this report.

MAP: MERCURY NEWS

A Belgrade resident removes the remains of her window after a round of airstrikes by NATO, which is intensifying attacks.
[990329 FR 9A]
PHOTO: ASSOCIATED PRESS
U.S. Sgt. Steven Courtemenche guards the site where a Yugoslav MiG-29 warplane was shot down in Bosnia.

334 of 348 DOCUMENTS



The Express


June 23, 2007 Saturday  
U.K. 1st Edition


SO IF HE DIDN'T KILL JILL DANDO WHO DID?;
Barry George could walk free for the murder of the TV star after doubts about evidence against him. We reveal why the disturbed loner could have been jailed for a crime committed by a Serbian hitman


BYLINE: by Julie Carpenter


SECTION: NEWS; 40


LENGTH: 1778 words


THIS week in his cell at the maximum security Whitemoor prison, Barry George was given the news he'd been waiting years to hear.

The Criminal Cases Review Commission announced he had won the right to a fresh appeal against his conviction for the murder of Jill Dando. A spokesman added there was a "real possibility" he could walk free.

The 42-year-old was at the centre of the largest criminal investigation since the hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper when he was given a life sentence in 2001 for the murder of TV's golden girl. It was a crime which sickened the nation and put the police under enormous pressure to find the culprit. Yet, as his lawyers will claim at the new hearing, expected in the autumn, there is not enough evidence to support George's conviction - and more than reasonable doubt to quash the verdict. 

He is, says his lawyer Jeremy Moore, "obviously very pleased and hopeful. The prison isn't equipped to deal with his condition, with the psychological difficulties he has as a result of brain damage caused by epilepsy. He has been finding it very difficult to cope with life inside." Soon he may not have to. The Commission ruled that too much emphasis was placed on the only piece of forensic evidence which linked George to the murder. This concerns a microscopic speck of firearms discharge residue found deep in George's coat pocket. It was crucial to the prosecution's case and described as "compelling evidence of guilt" at his trial. The jury heard a scientist confirm it was clearly a firearms deposit and matched traces in Dando's hair and clothes.

But explaining the new ruling, Commission chairman Graham Zellick argues it could have come from anywhere. "Whereas considerable weight was placed on it at the trial, our conclusion is that it cannot bear that weight, if it can bear any weight at all, " he says.

The Court of Appeal will now decide whether this renders George's conviction unsafe, in which case it will be overturned. It will then decide if there should be a new trial - although legal experts think this unlikely.

"There was a paucity of the evidence in the first place, " says Moore. "A very weak prosecution case was held together by this forensic evidence. Without that, the rest of the case does not stand up to scrutiny." Jill Dando, who was to marry her fiancé Alan Farthing, was walking back to her house in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, on the morning of Monday, April 26, 1999, when she met her assassin. She was ordered to kneel on the path outside her home and he fired a single gunshot into her head.

IT TOOK police 13 months to arrest George, who lived alone in a rundown, dingy flat 500 yards from Dando's home. On one level, he certainly fitted the profile. He was a lonely and disturbed misfit who inhabited a fantasy world, believing he was a cousin of Freddie Mercury and even adopting the rocker's original surname of Bulsara.

He had stalked dozens of women, had a conviction for attempted rape and received a three-month suspended jail sentence for indecent assault.

He also had an "interest" in guns and was once arrested after being discovered in the grounds of Kensington Palace dressed in combat fatigues, carrying a knife, a rope and a letter to Princess Diana.

In the Dando case, there was no witness, no murder weapon and no motive but three witnesses claimed to have seen a man who looked like George around her house on the day of the murder. A single fibre on the coat Dando was wearing when she was shot matched fibres on a pair of George's trousers - something which was insufficient to prove they had definitely been in contact but, according to the prosecution, "is nonetheless consistent with such contact having occurred".

The case also relied on George's reputation as a stalker and his celebrity obsession - the fact that he had written notes on Britt Ekland and Suzanne Dando and photocards of Anthea Turner and Emma Freud. George had also lied about his movements to police and tried to create a false alibi.

However, the prosecution case hinged on the speck of firearms residue. Its credibility is not only undermined by the suggestion that police searching George's flat were armed when they entered it. There is also the possibility that it could have been contaminated by being left in an unsealed room full of police evidence.

A major BBC Panorama programme in autumn last year quoted firearms expert Professor Marco Morin, who believes the single particle may not even have come from a gun.

Scott Lomax, author of Justice For Jill: How The Wrong Man Was Jailed For The Murder Of Jill Dando, agrees. "One of the things I discovered was that the alleged particle could have originated from a firework, " says Lomax. "George's best friend told me he used to collect fireworks and put them in his pocket. At trial, they were so obsessed with the idea of contamination from the labs where the jacket was examined that they didn't explore fully any other possibilities." The Panorama programme additionally coaxed revealing comments from one of the jurors. George was convicted by a 10-1 majority and Janet Herbert was the dissenting voice. She told the BBC: "I just felt shocked that on that little evidence anybody could be locked away. It might have been him, don't get me wrong, but you have to reach a verdict on the evidence." The issue of the firearms residue is the only ground on which the case has been referred back to the Court of Appeal (George lost his first appeal in 2002 based on a different premise) but George's lawyer says he is "entitled to apply for leave to put forward additional grounds".

There are two other main areas on which the defence would concentrate - George's mental state and the lack of a credible witness. George had suffered a mild form of brain damage and was in the bottom one per cent of the population in a psychological test of life skills. His uncle Michael Bourke argues that his nephew possesses neither the mental nor physical ability to carry out the crime.

"Barry is not the brightest.

This was a killing carried out with such efficiency. Barry is the sort of person who would have panicked or tried to hide if he had committed the crime, but people at the advice centre he visited that day said he arrived completely calm." Whoever the killer is had the foresight to press the gun against Dando's temple, making it virtually silent - significantly, a next-door neighbour heard a cry but no gunshot - and guarding against any blood spraying on his clothing.

Also, the murder weapon - never found - was a replica firearm, a short automatic smooth barrelled 9mm which had been specially modified. Much had been made of George's gun obsession but his experience was less than technical and it is unlikely he would have had the necessary skills.

"This is the guy who could not even put a new lamp on his bike, " says former Met commander John O'Connor.

George also suffers from a personality disorder, according to Lomax: "One of the allegations at the trial was that he reacted out of all proportion for an innocent man but the jury were never made aware that George suffers from Histrionic Personality Disorder and sufferers react in dramatic ways to news." Aside from his mental disabilities, there is also a question mark over credible witnesses. Twelve people went to ID parades but eight failed to pick out George. Of the remainder, three had what is termed "qualified identification" and the one who immediately picked him out - Susan Mayes - merely said he was in Dando's street at 7am on the day of the killing whereas the shooting took place at about 11.30. She also identified George 18 months after the murder.

George's attempts to create a false alibi could also be explained by the fact he had been questioned about the Rachel Nickell murder on Wimbledon Common in 1992, despite being innocent, and he was afraid he could be a suspect again.

There is also no evidence that George had any obsession with Dando. Police found 736 newspapers in his flat of which eight had reference to her - but none were highlighted or cut out. There were hundreds of photos of women that George had stalked but none was the Crimewatch presenter. There remain a disturbing number of question marks in the case against George. "He has spent seven extremely difficult years in custody for a conviction which we believe that, in the fullness of time, will be seen as one of the gravest miscarriages of justice of recent years, " says his lawyer.

But if Barry George didn't kill Jill Dando, who did? Various conspiracy theories have been put forward, one being that she was targeted by a particular crime boss due to her work presenting Crimewatch, but the strongest theory is that she was assassinated by a Serbian hitman.

PERHAPS this is not so farfetched given the political situation of the time. Britain was at war with Serbia and had started bombing military targets in Kosovo in March 1999 and civilian targets from April. Tony Blair said this was necessary to put an end to the "Serb killing machine" but Serbian dictator Slobodan Milosevic reacted with his customary brutal revenge, ordering Kosovar Albanians to leave or be shot.

Three weeks before she died, Jill Dando fronted the Kosovo Crisis Appeal on national television, thereby becoming the public face of the anti-Milosevic cause.

Three days before her death, Nato bombed a TV station in Belgrade, killing 16 journalists, including a young make-up artist for the RTS station in Belgrade called Jelica Munitlak. She was a favourite of Milosevic who always did his make-up when he came to the station and the pair had established a friendship. It is claimed the dictator ordered his twisted warlord Arkan to arrange for Dando's assassination as retaliation.

While Milosevic didn't have the might for a full-scale bomb attack, Israeli intelligence services had already warned Nato that two-man Serb teams were attacking "targets of opportunity". Jill Dando was one of the highest profile presenters of the time and had become a target through the Kosovan appeal.

The day she was killed was also the day the funerals of the 16 Serbians who had died took place.

During George's trial, defence barrister Michael Mansfield QC revealed there were five or six calls to the BBC linking Dando's murder with the Serbian incident. "Your government and in particular your prime minister, Blair, butchered 16 young people, " said one. "He butchered, we butcher back." It was also the opinion of a former high ranking MI5 spy, David Phillips, who had a deep understanding of assassination techniques used by Eastern European countries, and who expressed his views in writing to the police officer in charge of the investigation.


LOAD-DATE: August 29, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: OBSESSION?George didn't have any photos of Jill Dando
INNOCENT MAN? Barry George was convicted on flimsy forensic evidence


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2007 XPRESS - Al Nisr Media FZ LLC

All Rights Reserved


335 of 348 DOCUMENTS




The Washington Post


February 10, 2002 Sunday  
Final Edition


In Love and War;
They found each other, then his country started bombing hers, and things got complicated


BYLINE: Chuck Staresinic


SECTION: MAGAZINE; Pg. W24


LENGTH: 4526 words


Hours later, it would occur to my brother that the police had probably watched him from the moment he left the apartment. There would have been one to watch the building (a man pretending to work on his car, perhaps -- he'd seen that ruse before) and another to trail him at a distance.

It was a quiet morning, and Mike was not thinking about being abducted. He sipped from a green ceramic mug as he walked. The sight of him drinking coffee while walking past a sidewalk cafe confused many people in Belgrade. Coffee should be drunk while sitting at a table, they told him. One cup required approximately 30 minutes.

Mike loved this sort of attention. But it was necessary to fit in at times. He found it rather serendipitous that the Belgrade telephone directory included a few other Staresinics. He took to introducing himself as "Meeko," and he spoke our surname as if our grandparents had never left the village in nearby Slovenia -- "starRUSHinitch," instead of the Americanized pronunciation, which rhymes with "arsenic."  

As usual, he took one of several indirect routes to the office flat. A man who passes the same place at the same time on two consecutive mornings is a man on his way to work, and Mike could not appear to be a man with a job. This is why he never referred to the rented flat as "the office," which is exactly what it was. It was October 2000 and he had no permission to work in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia. Had he requested permission, he would have been escorted to the nearest border and expelled, or worse.

On paper, he was a resident alien -- an American married to a Serb. In truth, he was on the payroll of Freedom House, a nonprofit organization based in Washington. He administered grants to local activist groups, independent media organizations and human rights advocates who wanted to create a more civil and democratic society.

Mike did not want to ever be in possession of anything that would incriminate him. The money came from elsewhere and he sure as hell didn't deliver it. He considered every piece of paper, every e-mail, every communique. Could it be used as evidence? On this particular day, he was going to the flat to organize the only sort of receipts he dared keep. They were for mundane things like gasoline, hotel rooms, fax paper, copy paper and toner.

Mike's wife, Nevena, was in bed when he slipped out of the apartment. It was just as well. She couldn't have done anything to protect him and she needed her rest. She was six months pregnant, and exhausted from the march through Belgrade the day before where she joined the thousands demanding that Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic acknowledge his electoral defeat. Friends and strangers, shocked to see her standing -- distended belly to belly -- with riot police, had said she ought to be at home, or at least in the rear of the demonstration.

She was probably still asleep when Mike, several blocks away, heard the mug shatter. He didn't see it hit the ground. Three of them had rushed him from behind. He yelled for the police, hoping to attract witnesses. He cursed loudly and swung his fists until he was forced to the ground. One of his assailants breathed halting English into his ear, "We are the police." They switched back to their own language and demanded to know if he spoke Serbian. He pretended not to understand. He was handcuffed, jerked to his feet, silenced with a meaty hand across his mouth, and pushed to the end of a narrow stone passageway. His eyeglasses had come off in the scuffle, but he made out a passerby in a tight green dress and heels, watching from the corners of her eyes. When the hand was removed to help him into the car, he seized his chance. "Call my wife!" He shouted his telephone number in Serbian as they shoved him into the back and slammed the door.

Getting arrested was bad, but getting arrested without witnesses was exponentially worse. Sometimes people just disappeared. One officer said, "I thought you didn't speak Serbian," and punched him in the head. The officer in the front passenger seat cursed and pounded the dash. "Jesus Christ! I can't believe he yelled his phone number!" He glared at Mike, then spat words into a mobile telephone. "He called out his wife's telephone number! What do we do now?" Mike wondered if Nevena would get word of this. They'd been so vigilant lately, calling each other every few hours. People they were close to were getting arrested and harassed. Maybe she'd grow suspicious and walk to the flat. Maybe she'd attempt to retrace his steps only to find spilled coffee and a broken mug.

A Marriage of Inconvenience

Mutual friends had arranged for Mike Staresinic to meet Nevena Antonijevic in a Belgrade cafe more than two years earlier, in 1998. She thought he was the most un-European man she'd ever seen. He wore a T-shirt that read "Budapest" tucked into green shorts with running shoes and white socks. He wasn't tall or fat, but there was a broadness in his shoulders that seemed to extend all the way to his ankles. He had a handsome, roundish face and thin lips that curled into a nice little smile. His flat brown hair was parted on one side and combed over to the other, exactly the way our father had styled it back in the '70s.

Nevena, whose name sounds like "heaven" but with an extra syllable, was very cosmopolitan. Her hair was recently bleached blond and she'd spent a lot of time on her makeup that day. Her blue eyes were sultry beneath a strong Balkan brow. She was learning to speak English, and when Mike greeted her in broken Serbian, she coolly assured him, "We can talk on English." She had changed outfits three times for this meeting, finally settling on a light, summery shirt with bluejeans and white high heels. It was casual but sexy. Yet she had the feeling he wasn't really looking at her.

The truth was that Mike had misplaced his eyeglasses. The woman across from him was a colorful blur with a pleasant scent. He loved listening to her voice. He smiled while she searched for words. She could butcher his language all she wanted.

Nevena was a bit unclear about his occupation. He gave her his business card, and she went home to puzzle over what a "grants procurement administrator" might be. The dictionary said procure was "to get and make available for promiscuous sexual intercourse."

Mike had told her that he worked for an American firm named Ronco, out of the American Cultural Center, which was true. He said Ronco supported the U.S. Agency for International Development by purchasing computers, fax machines and office supplies. That was the same thing he told the police. He couldn't tell her that Ronco administered USAID grants to Serbian opposition groups. Things were tense, and even Nevena, who was wholeheartedly against Milosevic and his Socialist Party of Serbia, was not immune to their nationalist rhetoric, which said that Serbs didn't need the Americans or anyone else to help them run their country.

In her own life, Nevena was fiercely independent. In 1998, she wasn't confronting the riot police, but neither was she toeing the party line. She bought antiques and old paintings, and she sold them out of her apartment. She bought apartments, too, lived in them while she spruced them up, then resold or rented them out. She made enough money to feel independent of the socialist system she despised. The last thing she wanted was to be a civil servant. They lined up at the bank every Friday to cash their paychecks, as if spending the workday in line hid the fact that they weren't productive and weren't expected to be.

Before long, she was meeting Mike regularly for coffee and drinks. He was different from most people she knew, and not only because he told jokes in two languages. He talked about the future as if it were something that people created for themselves. The more time she spent with him, the more she realized that everyone around her treated the future as if it were something that was coming to crush them.

She was startled when he suddenly became critical of Serbs for accepting their powerless condition. Nevena didn't have the English to say that they had tried for years to change things. Anyone who spoke up was attacked, and Milosevic did what he wanted to anyway. How could she tell him what she barely admitted to herself? Her hopes had been dashed for so long that she'd practically given up and stopped caring.

When Mike told her that he was being transferred to Banja Luka, in Bosnia, she was surprised by how much the news saddened her. "It's too far," she said. He told her it was only half an hour by plane, and he would pay for her to come every weekend. But Nevena felt like her life was returning to the way it had been before. Soon she'd again be like every other Serb in Belgrade, depressed and cynical.

Mike called from Banja Luka and pressed her to visit. Missing him terribly, she went. The war in Bosnia was long over, but when she drove there, she felt like she'd been ambushed. As a rainy nightfall overtook her, she came upon vast landscapes of rubble, and the sickening realization that these had been towns and villages. For three years, Croatia and Serbia had tried to rip Bosnia in half and share the spoils. Living in Belgrade, she'd been largely in the dark. She'd tuned out what little real news got through. It wasn't her war, she told herself. She couldn't change anything, and she had her own affairs to worry about.

Now she saw charred beams, heaps of bricks, sticks of furniture, and a solitary plaster wall marred by bullets. The destruction stretched to the horizon on all sides. She shouted and wailed and drove through her tears.

Dating grew even more complicated in February 1999, when Mike left Ronco and took a job with Freedom House in Sarajevo. Belgrade and Sarajevo are about as close geographically as Washington and Philadelphia, but in terms of goodwill they were more like Tel Aviv and Baghdad in 1999. There were no flights between the cities. Sarajevo is the capital of Bosnia, after all, and the terror its residents had suffered at the hands of Serb soldiers was still a recent memory. There was a bus from Belgrade, but Serb drivers refused to go through Croat-Muslim territory and took a tortuously indirect route. To make matters worse, NATO, led by the United States, was threatening to bomb Serbia for its aggression in Kosovo, so it wasn't a good time for an American to visit Belgrade.

Mike felt like they were trying to weather a storm in a rickety lifeboat. If they could just keep bailing until the storm broke, they would survive. If they could stay together until he found a job in Belgrade, they would have a chance at a normal relationship.

They talked on the phone every night. He tried to focus on how they felt about each other, and how good it would be to be together again. But Nevena couldn't help talking politics. She felt that Serbs had been wronged by the world, and by NATO in particular. Mike held his tongue. He believed in peaceful solutions as a general rule, but he thought NATO should have bombed Serbia months ago.

On March 24, 1999, Nevena came home from her English class at 7:30 in the evening. Mike called from Sarajevo to warn her. The NATO bombing was beginning. She refused to believe it until the sirens began -- loud, terrifying and unceasing. She rushed through the apartment, dutifully preparing to evacuate. Then she realized there was nowhere to go. She sat down on her sofa in the dark and listened to the sirens wail.

When Nevena left Belgrade about four weeks later, she felt like she was abandoning her home, her family and her friends. But she recognized that she and Mike had to spend time together or give up completely. She boarded the bus to Sarajevo and suffered the next 12 hours on the war-weary back roads of Bosnia beside a woman with motion sickness.

Nevena stayed for almost a month, despite their frequent arguments over the bombing and the occasional discomfort that went along with being a Serb in Sarajevo. At times she looked at Mike and thought they had a future together if only the world were not so crazy. Other times she couldn't stand the sight of him, like when he agreed with her that NATO shouldn't bomb Serbia's bridges and suggested that they bomb Serbia's soldiers instead. She wanted to go home.

He said this was no time to break up. But what was he supposed to do? Insist that his girlfriend stay in Sarajevo until his country finished bombing hers? He respected her devotion to the place where she was born, even though it was taking her away from him. Standing on line to board the bus, she couldn't look at him. He pulled her out of line and embraced her. Then she boarded without looking back and he waved until the bus disappeared.

The last bomb fell on June 10, 1999, after 78 days, with Milosevic still firmly in power. Mike drove to Belgrade while the ashes were still fresh. He was scared, knowing he could be arrested or attacked by an anti-American mob, but he couldn't stay away. Belgrade was like a patient waking up from radical treatment to find that the cancer remained. But Nevena allowed herself some hope for the future. If her country could survive the bombing, it could survive anything. And she was glad to see Mike.

He stayed one extra day on business, meeting with the Serbian activists he knew from his days with Ronco. Back in Sarajevo, he told Freedom House that the Serbian opposition in Belgrade was frightened, isolated and uncertain about the future. For all these groups knew, they didn't have a friend in the world. He said that Belgrade was the one place in the Balkans where he could be most effective. Freedom House agreed, but everyone knew it was a dangerous assignment. The only Americans seen recently in Serbia had been prisoners of war and their negotiators. In 1998, Yugoslavia's deputy prime minister had told the nation that anyone working for an international aid organization deserved to be taken to the butcher and cut to pieces.

The next time Mike visited Belgrade, he went with Nevena to the Ministry of the Interior. On the third floor, there was a sign in English that read, "Department of Strangers." There, an officer named Boris poked away at the keys of a manual typewriter. There are two ways to get residency, Boris said. You must register for Serbian language courses at the university or get married to a Serb. Mike said, "I'm sick to death of learning languages."

On the street outside, they talked about marriage as if they were considering purchasing a car. There was no denying it would enable them to spend more time together. They both wondered if there was enough love between them, but they were sick of being apart.

Despite the pretense of pragmatism, they grew excited over the following weeks. They were married in October 1999. The air was warm and the trees still held fast to their leaves. Mike and Nevena were aglow that morning, and not only because of rakija, the perfectly clear, wickedly strong and quintessentially Balkan plum brandy made and sold like moonshine. She wore a sleek white dress that stopped above her knees and black leather boots that stopped just below. Her blond hair swept her shoulders. He wore a navy suit, white shirt and yellow tie. She'd talked him into a more European hairstyle -- so short there was no combing it to the side. They were married before two seated bureaucrats. When Mike informed the bookkeeper that Nevena did not wish to take the name Staresinic, she tugged at his sleeve and whispered, "Meeko! I've changed my mind."

Don't Ask, Don't Tell

Mike and Nevena's commitment to each other required an extraordinary measure of trust. She knew what his job was, and that it was dangerous, but he didn't give her details. She didn't ask.

By November 1999, the word was out that Freedom House had money for "elections related grant activity" and that Mike Staresinic was the local contact. Around the same time, the police picked up a man named Slobodan Djinovic for questioning. He was one of the most important figures in the Serbian resistance movement. An officer scrolled through the names in Djinovic's mobile telephone and said, "Who's Staresinic?"

"Some guy I play basketball with," Djinovic lied.

Freedom House funded more than 40 proposals from Serbian opposition groups for around half a million dollars. They were not the sole or even the largest source of American support for the Serbian democracy movement. USAID had a bigger budget and more American personnel working out of Hungary. But no other aid organization had anyone so immersed in the movement. 

Mike had 3,000 German marks stashed in the apartment to pay for his emergency evacuation. He could get to Romania, Bulgaria or Bosnia within a few hours and cross the border like any traveler.

Nevena had several ovarian cysts removed that winter, and the doctor told her that if she wanted children, she should think about starting soon. Mike and Nevena were both surprised by how quickly they conceived. They talked about having the child in the United States, but Nevena refused to concede that the country of her birth might not be a safe place to have a baby. Besides, Milosevic had suddenly announced that the presidential election would be held in October, less than three months away. They couldn't leave now. She became an activist.

In early September 2000, Nevena was pulled over by the police for displaying a resistance sign in her car window. She got out of the car and challenged the officers. It was her car, she asserted. She could do what she wanted. They took the sign from her window and ripped it to pieces.

The senior officer said they'd let her go, but only because she was pregnant. No, she countered, if I committed a crime then arrest me. One officer pulled Nevena aside and said if they are telling you to go, then get out of here.

She drove a few blocks away and stopped the car. She was still shaking with fear and anger. She walked around to the back of the car and pulled out a fresh sign: a clenched white fist on a black background and the single word "Otpor!" Resistance! She taped it to the window.

Ten days before the election Mike was feeling extremely insecure. Freedom House was suggesting that he might want to get out. Local activists were getting arrested. Serbs who worked for aid organizations were fleeing the country. There was a meeting scheduled for that evening: Someone was returning Freedom House's grant money. The reasons weren't clear to Mike. It bugged him all day. Nobody returned grant money.

An hour before the meeting, it dawned on him there was only one possible reason for someone to schedule a time and place to put Freedom House money into his hands. He was being set up. He went straight to the flat, ran up one flight of stairs and let himself in. It was dark and muggy, but he left the lights off, windows shut and blinds drawn. They'd probably come straight there when he didn't show up for the meeting. He had to get out of town. Maybe for good. There were 120 proposals in two stacks. Why had he held on to this stuff?

He started tearing. Sweat streamed down his face. He'd never figured out how to find a paper shredder without attracting attention. He started mixing the shreds into two different trash bags. He urinated in the bags, poured in dish soap and beer, saving some to drink himself. It took more than an hour, and near the end he was certain there would be a fist pounding on the door at any moment.

He left the bags in two different dumpsters. He walked a few blocks, turning corners and slipping down a narrow alley. He switched taxis to avoid being followed, then arrived at Nevena's sister's house, where he laid low for a few days until he and Nevena flew to Montenegro together. Nevena returned on a surprisingly quiet Sunday to vote. Mike shrugged off the danger and followed on Friday.

By this time, entire towns in the Serbian provinces had been shut down in anti-Milosevic demonstrations. In Belgrade, protesters filled the streets daily. At times the city was jubilant. The people in the streets knew Milosevic had lost. They only had to make him admit it.

Nevena demonstrated every day, and never considered leaving Belgrade for the safety of the child she carried. "It's boiling here," she said, as if that were the most wonderful thing.

Birth of a Nation

On Wednesday, October 4, Nevena slept off the previous day's march. When she finally emerged from the bedroom, the coffeepot was cold. Mike and his green mug were gone. By noon, she could already hear the music and the voices coming from the square through her kitchen window. She ate a little lunch and went to join the protesters gathering in the square. People sang and waved banners as they marched. Whenever someone shouted Slobo's name, an inarticulate roar of defiance rose up and the buildings seemed to shake.

From far across the square, she saw a few men on the balcony of Mike's office flat. Immediately, she was concerned. She pulled out her mobile and called him. No answer.

Inside the flat, Mike stood sullenly and listened to the crowd outside. His arms were twisted painfully in front of him and locked into position with handcuffs. Clearly the police had known about the flat for some time. They had taken him here to look for evidence of anti-government activity. Ludicrous. Most of the country was involved in anti-government activity. All they had to do was look out the window.

Mike had already been strip-searched at the station. Standard humiliation, but he knew this was serious trouble. He estimated his chances of successfully rushing the balcony and vaulting the rail into the crowded street below. He wasn't sure he could get past the guys on the balcony. Even if he did, there would still be the danger of getting shot on the way down or breaking both ankles when he hit the pavement.

One of the police officers looked at him and said, "Mike, you might be the last victim of communism in Yugoslavia."

Nevena had an appointment with her doctor at 4 to check on the progress of her pregnancy. One moment she was singing for the president to kill himself. The next she was stroking her belly with one hand and talking to her baby.

The doctor said she and the baby were in perfect health. She had only been home 10 minutes when the doorbell rang. "Who is it?" she called.

"Mike." But the voice was wrong. So flat.

She opened the door. There must have been 12 officers with him. She looked to him for an explanation, but it was clear he was not allowed to speak. They all came inside and an officer told her they would be searching the apartment. He asked, "Do you know what Freedom House is?"

She didn't even look at Mike. She knew what she was supposed to say. "No." But she cried immediately, and they did not ask her any more questions.

They conducted a painstaking search. They confiscated two computers, dozens of rolls of exposed film, two cameras, and the German marks Mike had set aside for emergency evacuation. One officer videotaped the entire search and Mike imagined it airing as propaganda on state TV -- American imperialists attempted to steal the election, but President Milosevic has successfully defended Serbia's independence!

The officers were cautious around Nevena. She was a Serb after all, and pregnant. She asked them to promise they wouldn't hurt him. Please don't hit him, she repeated. But she had to be herself, and when they discovered Mike's homemade replica of an opposition poster, she asked the officers, "Do you know why Milosevic is yellow in that picture?" They did not. "Because he's dead. And only you don't know it."

Mike had never seen her so strong. He'd never realized how much he needed her and trusted her. She'd never realized how devoted to him she was. They allowed her to fix a sandwich and a tall glass of rakija for him. After he ate, she sat on his lap with officers so close on either side that they could all hear one another breathe. She was never so proud of him. Her makeup was running down her cheeks when they embraced and said goodbye. He whispered to her, "Call the world."

She started with the office of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia next door. She told them Mike Staresinic was being arrested and they must send someone outside immediately to witness. She grabbed her little camera, ran to the balcony and snapped a picture as they led him away. At the sight of the flash, two officers instantly pounded back up the stairs. One officer snatched the camera from her hands and yelled that she should show more respect after they'd treated her so carefully. Hours later, Mike was alone in a sparse and windowless interrogation room. He lifted his head from the table when an officer opened the door and said, "Hey! Let's go!"

"Where?"

"You are leaving Serbia."

He didn't believe them. It must have been past 10 in the evening. There was one enforcer in back with him, and another in front with the driver. They took Brotherhood and Unity Highway out of town, past the spot where Nevena had stared down the police only the day before. Mike thought it would be smart to leave as much DNA evidence in the car as possible. He pulled off pieces of fingernail and wiped his sweat on the upholstery. Their headlights cut through a black and featureless countryside between Belgrade and Croatia, and the driver made a call. "Yes," he said, "we'll be there in 20 minutes."

They got out of the car and brought Mike to the edge of the darkness, then told him to walk. The Croatian border was 300 yards away along a deserted road. Before turning his back, Mike offered his hand to the officer in charge and looked him in the eye for a moment. "For correct work," he said in Serbian, "thank you." "In other words," Mike would tell me later, "thanks for not leaving me in a ditch." When Nevena received Mike's call from Croatia, she couldn't believe it. She made him hang up and call back, and when he did she shouted for joy.

On October 5, 2000, the people took over Belgrade's parliament building while my brother watched on television from a hotel on the Croatian border. The next day, Slobodan Milosevic would admit he had lost the election and resign. After all Mike had been through, he was glad to be gone from Serbia. It would be a long time before his nerves returned to normal, but he felt a measure of safety for the first time in months.

Yet it was strange to be so far away when the streets of Belgrade erupted into spontaneous celebration. He'd imagined the moment so many times, but he never thought he'd be alone when it happened. They'd stamped his passport in red, "Banned from entry to the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia for five years." It would take weeks to get a new passport and visa. In the meantime, Mike and Nevena would spend their first wedding anniversary apart. Her doctor forbade her to travel, and Mike was not able to return to Belgrade until late November. But that was soon enough.

On January 6, 2001, a boy named Isaac Mateja Staresinic was born to loving parents in a liberated Belgrade.

Chuck Staresinic is a graduate student of creative writing at the University of Pittsburgh.</body>


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2002 The Washington Post
