BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


May 18, 2007 Friday


News agency profiles ministers in new Serbian government


LENGTH: 3055 words


Text of report in English by Serbian news agency Beta's Beta Week service

Serbia's new government has a total 25 spots, including one prime minister and one deputy prime ministerial position. Below with give brief biographies of the new cabinet's members:

VOJISLAV KOSTUNICA - Prime minister and leader of the Democratic Party of Serbia. Born in Belgrade on March 24, 1944. Kostunica was also prime minister of the previous cabinet. He was elected FR Yugoslav President in elections in 2000 in which he defeated Slobodan Milosevic (Kostunica's full biography is available in this edition of Beta Week).

BOZIDAR DJELIC - Deputy prime minister for European integrations (Democratic Party). Was the minister of finance in late premier Zoran Djindjic's cabinet. Ran as the Democratic Party's candidate for prime minister in the past election.

Djelic was born in Belgrade on April 1, 1965. He graduated from the Paris Institute of Political Sciences and earned a masters degree in economics from the Paris School of Social Sciences, a masters degree in business administration from the US Harvard Business School and J.F.K. School of State Administration. 

Djelic joined the Serbian government from the position of French Credit-Agricole bank director for South East Europe. Djelic joined the Democratic Party in December 2004. He is a member of the party's steering commission and political council.

He speaks fluent English and French, understands Russian, German and Polish. Djelic is divorced, with two daughters.

DRAGAN JOCIC - Minister of interior affairs (Democratic Party of Serbia). Jocic was interior minister in the former cabinet. He was born in Belgrade on Sept. 7, 1960.

Jocic graduated from the School of Law and worked as an attorney for some time. He was elected MP twice and headed parliament's security board for two years.

He is an original member of the Democratic Party of Serbia. Jocic was a member and president of the party's executive board. He was promoted to vice president in June 2003.

He is married.

MIRKO CVETKOVIC - Minister of finance (Democratic Party). Born in Zajecar in 1950. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Economics, from which he also received a PhD.

Cvetkovic worked for the Institute of Mining, the Economics Institute and as a consultant for CES MECON. He was an economics consultant at the Institute of Mining between 1998-2001, his last job before being appointed minister of the economy and privatization. Cvetkovic also worked as director of the Privatization Agency (2003/2004), followed by a stint as special adviser to CEO Intercon Consulting/CESMecon.

Speaks English. Is married with two children.

DRAGAN SUTANOVAC - Minister of defence (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade in July 1968, where he earned a degree in hydro energy from the School of Mechanical Engineering. Sutanovac also holds a Law Enforcement Diploma, a Security Issues and Oversight Diploma, and a diploma from the esteemed US-German Marshal Centre for Security Studies in Garmisch-Partenkirchen.

Sutanovac was a special adviser and then assistant minister at the federal ministry of interior affairs. He was elected republican MP three times and served as a councilman in the Belgrade city assembly twice. Was president and deputy president of Serbian parliament's security and defence board.

Sutanovac is a member of the Democratic Party. He was a member of the party's presidency. In February2006, Sutanovac was promoted to vice president.

Speaks English. Married, has two sons.

VUK JEREMIC - Foreign Minister (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade on July 3, 1975. Took a graduate degree in theoretical physics from Cambridge University. Earned a masters degree instate administration from Harvard University.

Worked as a financial analyst for Deutche Bank, followed by Dresdner Kleiwort Benson Bank, and Astra Zeneca Pharmaceuticals in London. Was one of the founders and a financial manager for the Organization of International Serbian Students.

Jeremic was an aide to the FR Yugoslav minister of telecommunications (from 2000) and an aide to the defence minister of Serbia-Montenegro (2003). He also was appointed aide for international relations and head of the Serbian president's foreign political team in July 2004.

Jeremic is a member of the Democratic Party and president of the party's board for international relations and a member of the Democratic Party's steering commission (February 2006).

Speaks English and German. Is married.

DUSAN PETROVIC - Minister of justice (Democratic Party). Born in Sabac on Sept. 8, 1966. Graduated from law school in Belgrade and practiced law until2000 when he was appointed president of the Sabac municipality and a delegate in FR Yugoslavia's parliament.

Is an original member of the Democratic Party. Served as president of the Democratic Party's Sabac chapter. Has been a member of the party's presidency since 2000 and delegate in Serbia's parliament since 2003. Was deputy speaker of Serbia's parliament. Petrovic was appointed whip of the party's caucus in March 2004.

Petrovic is married, with one child.

SLOBODAN MILOSAVLJEVIC - Minister of agriculture (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade on Nov. 19, 1965. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Economics. Holds a masters degree and PhD in macroeconomics and management.

Worked as a researcher for the Belgrade Institute for Market Research, and director of the Centre for Conjectural Research and Macroeconomic Analysis (since 1996). Was minister of trade, tourism and services in the Serbian government, and president of the Serbian chamber of commerce (appointed in 2004).

Speaks English. Is married, with two children.

ALEKSANDRA SMILJANIC - Minister of telecommunications and IT society (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade on June 12, 1970. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Electrical Engineering. Holds a masters degree and PhD in electrical engineering from Princeton University.

Employed as an assistant professor at the Belgrade School of Electrical Engineering and an affiliate professor at the New York Polytechnic University and Stony Brook University in New York. Is currently running a project under the auspices of the Ministry of Science and Environmental Protection called "Implementation of Internet Router Controllers." Smiljanic also worked for AT&T as a researcher between 1999-2004.

Authored numerous works presented at conferences and published by magazines. She holds seven US patents, and two patent applications, which have also been patented in Europe, Japan and China. She is editor of the OSA Journal on Optical Networking(since 2003), and IEEE Communication Letters journal (since 2005).

Smiljanic speaks English.

RASIM LJAJIC - Minister of labour and social politics (Democratic Party/Social Democratic Party). Born in Novi Pazar on Jan. 28, 1964. Graduated from the Sarajevo School of Medicine.

Took up politics in 1990 when he was appointed secretary general of the Sandzak Party of Democratic Action. Ljajic has been president of the Sandzak Coalition, now known as the Sandz ak Democratic Party, since 1994.

Ljajic was minister of national and ethnic communities in the FR Yugoslav government, and the Serbia-Montenegro minister of human and minority rights (elected in 2003). Appointed Vice president, and then president of the government coordinating body for the Presevo, Bujanovac and Medvedja municipalities, and vice president of the Coordinating Centre for Kosovo and Metohija(August 2001).

He is president of the National Council for Cooperating with the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia and coordinator of the government's Action Plan for cooperating with the ICTY (July 2006).

Speaks English and Russian. Married, with two children.

MILAN MARKOVIC - Minister of state administration and local self-administration (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade on Sept. 7, 1970. Graduated from law school, specialty is anti-terrorism.

Markovic joined the Democratic Party in 1996. He led the party's youth, was president of the Belgrade party chapter's executive board, vice president of the party's Belgrade city board, a member of the Democratic Party's steering commission, and is currently (2006) a member of its executive board.

Markovic was also president of the Belgrade Palilula municipal assembly. He is an MP (since 2001) and was deputy speaker of Serbia's parliament (2003/2007). He is a visiting teacher at different universities where he lectures on security and partakes in research projects.

He speaks English.

RADOMIR NAUMOV - Minister of religion (Democratic Party of Serbia). Born in Coka on May12, 1946. Holds a degree from the Belgrade School of Electrical Engineering.

Worked for 35 years at the Nikola Tesla Electrotechnical Institute. Was GM of the institute for nine years. He also taught at the Bor Technical School and served as an MP in Serbia's parliament.

Was minister of mining and energy in Prime Minister Kostunica's previous cabinet. Is an original member of the Democratic Party of Serbia's steering commission. Was president of the Democratic Party of Serbia's Belgrade chapter for five years.

Naumov speaks English and German. He is married, with two children and reputed to be deeply religious.

SASA DRAGIN - Minister of ecology (Democratic Party). Was born in Sombor on June 10, 1972. Graduated from the Novi Sad School of Agriculture and earned a PhD in the molecular engineering of domestic animals. Is an assistant teacher of animal physiology and an associate teacher of physiology.

Dragin worked for different US animal genetic engineering laboratories, and for the Slovakian Institute of Animal Production in Nitra. He was appointed Vojvodina deputy secretary of agriculture, water and forestry in 2005.

Dragin speaks English and understands Slovakian and German. He is married.

VOJISLAV BRAJOVIC - Minister of culture (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade on May 11, 1949. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Drama Studies. Brajovic is one of Serbia's best known actors.

Became a permanent member of the Yugoslav Drama Theatre in 1969. Brajovic acts in other theatres as well. Appeared in over 30 movies. Featured in numerous TV series. Holds almost every relevant acting award including three Sterija awards.

Speaks English. Is married, father of two.

MILICA CUBRILO - Minister of the Diaspora (Democratic Party). Born in Carthage, Tunis, in 1969.Holds a degree in law from the department of public law, Paris University -Panteon Asas (1992). Picked up a masters degree in law and anthropology at the Sorbonne in Paris in 1993.

Worked as a reporter and correspondent for the Balkans for the French media between 2001-2003 (Le Figaro, Radio Frans Internacional, Tan and Poan). Worked as a reporter for Le Figaro in Paris from 2000-2 001.

Cubrilo was director of the Tourist Organization of Serbia from 2003-2006. She is a coordinator for the Global Congress of the International Press Institute, which will be held in Belgrade in June 2008.

She speaks both French and English, understands Italian and Spanish.

ALEKSANDAR POPOVIC - Minister of energy (Democratic Party of Serbia). Born in Belgrade, on Oct. 20, 1971. Holds a degree in chemistry from the Belgrade University. Earned a masters degree in the United States and a doctoral degree in Belgrade.

Popovic served twice as an MP in Serbia's parliament. He was minister of science and environmental protection in the previous cabinet headed by Prime Minister Kostunica. He is also an original member of the Democratic Party of Serbia and a vice president.

Speaks English. He is married and has one child.

PREDRAG BUBALO - Minister of trade (Democratic Party of Serbia). Born in Vladicin Han on Oct. 14, 1954. Graduated from law school in Novi Sad, where he also earned his masters degree and PhD.

Worked in the Kikinda foundry on foreign accounts. Also worked as an engineering executive. Bubalo's work took him to Iran, Tanzania, Algeria and India. He also headed the foundry's branch office in Bejing for six years, starting 1994. He was appointed GM of the foundry in 2002.

Bubalo was minister of international economic relations in Prime Minister Kostunica's previous cabinet. He was also minister of the economy and privatization since October 2004. Bubalo joined the Democratic Party of Serbia in 2002.

He is married, and has two children.

ZORAN LONCAR - Minister of education (Democratic Party of Serbia). Born in Novi Sad inNovember, 1965. Graduated from the Novi Sad school of law from which he also received a PhD in administrative law.

Was minister of state administration and local self-administration in the previous cabinet. Joined the Democratic Party of Serbia in 2000. He is a member of the party's steering commission and president of the party's board for justice and state administration.

He speaks English and French. Loncar is married, two children.

SLOBODAN SAMARDZIC - Minister of Kosovo and Metohija (Democratic Party of Serbia). Born in Belgrade, March 23, 1953. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Political Sciences. His 1987 doctoral dissertation was called "The Democracy of the World."

Samardzic served as editor of Radio Belgrade's science and political programme from 1982-1984. He was initially a science adviser for the International Workers' Movement Institute only to be promoted to science assistant. He also worked as a higher science associate with the Institute for European Studies.

Samardzic is a regular teacher at the Belgrade School of Political Sciences, where he teaches European Relations and the EU and heads the school's post-graduate European studies programme. He served as a political aide to former FR Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica, and remained Kostunica's aide when Kostunica became prime minister.

Samardzic heads the government's Commission for the Decentralization of Kosovo and is a member of Belgrade's negotiating team on Kosovo's future status.

He speaks English and German, is married, with three children.

VELIMIR ILIC - Minister of infrastructure (New Serbia). Born in Cacak on May 28, 1951. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Technology. He took a masters degree from the Cacak Technical School.

Ilic was an entrepreneur for nearly 20 years, until he was elected speaker of the Cacak municipal assembly in December 1996. He joined the Serbian Renewal Movement in 1990. Ilic became president of the New Serbia party in March 1998. He was a federal MP in FR Yugoslavia and president of the Cacak municipality twice. Ilic was ministe r of capital investment in Kostunica's previous cabinet.

Ilic is married, with five children.

MLADJAN DINKIC - Minister of the economy and regional development (G17 Plus). Born in Belgrade on Dec. 20, 1964. Graduated from the Belgrade School of Economics, where he became an assistant teacher in 1990. He earned his masters degree there, three years later.

Dinkic one of the founders of the group of independent economists (G17) and was initially the group's coordinator. Dinkic served as the National Bank of Yugoslavia's governor from November 2000 to July 2003.

When the G17 Plus association turned into a party in December 2002, he was appointed vice president and a member of the party's presidency. He took the helm of the party's Belgrade chapter in April 2006. Dinkic became party leader in September 2006 after Miroljub Labus resigned as president.

Dinkic was minister of finance in prime minister Kostunica's government up to October 2006, whenG17 withdrew from the cabinet in protest over its failure to resume negotiations with the EU.

Dinkic speaks English. He is married.

TOMICA MILOSAVLJEVIC - Minister of health (G17 Plus). Born in Krusevac on Dec. 24, 1955. Graduated from the Belgrade Medical School in 1979, and later received a masters degree and PhD. Specializes in internal medicine, gastrology. Milosavljevic is a associate professor and member of the Medical School's council of deans.

Milosavljevic was minister of health in premier Zoran Djindjic's government (June 2002), Zoran Zivkovic's government and, most recently, in Prime Minister Vojislav Kostunica's cabinet. He left the cabinet on Oct. 1, 2006, along with G17 Plus's other members.

Milosavljevic served on G17 Plus's project council, the association of independent economists. He is currently a vice president in the party.

He speaks English and Russian. Milosavljevic is married and the father of three children.

SNEZANA MARKOVIC-SAMARDZIC - Minister of youth and sports (G17 Plus). Born in Belgrade on March 10, 1966. Is a professor of Yugoslav and world literature.

Did different jobs at the Norwegian Embassy in Belgrade from 1993-2001. She was also assistant director of the directorate for neighbouring states with the FR Yugoslav foreign ministry and an aide in Serbia-Montenegro's Embassy in Oslo. She later became an aide at the Directorate for Europe.

Her most recent job was assistant minister of defence.

She speaks English and Norwegian, and understands Russian. She is married and has two children.

ANA PESIKAN - Minister of science (G17 Plus). Pesikan was born in Feketic, on July 24, 1959. She took a degree in psychology from the Belgrade School of Philosophy. She also holds a PhD.

Pesikan was an associate on and hosted Belgrade TV's educational programme, and later worked on a series of projects in the area of psychology. She teaches at the Diplomatic Academy, and the School of Chemistry and School of Philosophy's doctoral programme. She also works for the Institute of Psychology with the Belgrade School of Philosophy.

She speaks English and is married.

DRAGAN DJILAS - Minister without portfolio (Democratic Party). Born in Belgrade, on Feb. 22, 1967. Graduated from the School of Mechanical Engineering, aviation. Worked as a journalist for Radio Index and was one of Radio B92's founders. He later led the station's news programme.

As student president, Djilas led anti-Milosevic student demonstrations in 1991 and 1992. He joined the Democratic Party in 2004. He was a member of the party's executive commission and steering commission, and is currently president of its Belgrade chapter and a member of the party's presidency.

Djilas was appointed director of the president's people's office in October 2004.

He is a coowner of Direct Media, a leading media company in the former Yugoslavia.

He speaks English, is married and has two children.

Source: Beta Week, Belgrade, in English 0000 gmt 17 May 07


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript



Copyright 2007 British Broadcasting Corporation

337 of 348 DOCUMENTS




The Washington Post


October 23, 2011 Sunday  
Every Edition


Revolutionaries


BYLINE: David Montgomery


SECTION: SUNDAY ARTS; Pg. E01


LENGTH: 2313 words


DATELINE: IN NEW YORK


The revolution will not be led. But it will be mentored. Â¶ We're in a conference room at New York University with about four dozen slightly starstruck activists, artists, students and professors. A couple young people fromhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/occupy-wall-street-nypd-to-look-into-officers-use-of-pepper-spray-on-protestors/2011/09/28/gIQAm3S04K_blog.htmlhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/wall-street-protesters-hope-to-plant-seeds-of-a-national-cause/2011/10/03/gIQAiBmKJL_story.htmlOccupy Wall Street have temporarily left the occupation to be here. A leader of the frolicsome 1990s student uprising against Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevicis present. Â¶ The Yes Labis in session - presided over by the Yes Men, the dynamic prankster art duo who specialize in impersonating corporate lackeys and fooling journalists. Â¶ Stripped of their spoofy personas and pinstripe suits from the Salvation Army on Fourth Avenue, the Yes Men are winsomely sheepish. Jacques Servin, 48, is unshaven in an untucked button-down shirt. Igor Vamos, 43, wears a T-shirt from a Tunisian graffiti artist that says, in Arabic, "Need My History." Â¶ Never mind the slogan of their 2009 documentary, "The Yes Men Fix the World" - "Sometimes it takes a lie to expose the truth."  

Today the Yes Men promise to tell the truth. Expose merry tricks of satiric political activism. Invite us behind the scenes of the street theater.

And something more: On their latest and craziest mission of all, the Yes Men propose to catch the new creative spark of revolution - from Tunisia to Wall Street to Washington - and coach it into bigger headlines and better buzz. Like radical Johnny Appleseeds, their goal is to sow the land with scores of activists schooled in how to practice what Servin calls "using humor to attack the powerful."

"We'll first do a full group brainstorm for Occupy Wall Street and come up with a list of actions they can do to enjoy themselves and keep themselves busy," Servin tells the lab participants.

Folks around the table riff on possible slogans and stunts. The occupiers seem to like what they hear, and take notes.

"There's a danger of over-thinking," Servin counsels. "It's more important to do something and enjoy it and have fun and meet people and get the word out there by any stupid means possible. And just do it."

He speaks from experience. Famous in left-wing activist circles, the Yes Men periodically break into mainstream consciousness with comic book hero flair - the Yes Men strike again!

Punk the Establishment

In their most celebrated stunt, in 2004, Servin was interviewed on BBC World posing as a spokesman for Dow Chemical. He announced that Dow would take responsibility for the deadly 1984 Bhopal chemical spill and pay $12 billion to survivors. Dow was forced to respond it would do no such thing.

In 2009, the Yes Men and environmentalists staged a press conferencein the name of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce at the National Press Club in Washington. Servin announced that the chamber had suddenly decided to support tough climate change legislation.

In this way, the Yes Men take credit for sparking hundreds of newspaper and television stories over the last decade on issues that the Yes Men say would not have received as much coverage if not for the media catnip of their stunts.

Critics say the Yes Men are merely con artists and publicity hounds. The chamber filed a lawsuit accusing them of "commercial identity theft masquerading as social activism." They've never been criminally charged for a stunt.

The art world gingerly embraces them, and the progressive activist community hails them for re-energizing the anti-corporate, pro-powerless causes.

"We crave Yes Men-style activism," says Justin Wedes, 25, a part-time public high school teacher in New York, who works with Occupy Wall Street and who was advised by the Yes Men this past spring when his group, US Uncut, perpetrated the hoax claiming General Electric would return a $3.2 billion tax refund. "There's a certain sense of frustration and powerlessness in protest actions today. You don't feel like you're reaching anyone." (GE says it received no refund but paid lower taxes because of business losses.)

Yes Men on campus

Now, after a career of infiltrating institutions and videotaping the results, the Yes Men have gained admittance to the ivory tower without any subterfuge at all. Servin is stepping into the real role of "visiting associate arts professor" in the performance studies department at NYU.

Today's seven-hour workshop is the opening session of the Yes Lab, a weekly extracurricular practicum where activists will hatch Yes Men-inspired protest stunts, and then go out and do them. The theme for the first batch of actions in the coming months will be the problem of income disparity.

Servin and Vamos have been professors before. Servin taught at Parsons the New School for Design, and Vamos is on the art faculty of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Next semester at NYU, Servin will teach a graduate seminar on revolution and an undergraduate course on "the design principles for activism."

What's novel is the Yes Lab, which formalizes and institutionalizes theirmentoring of young activists.It's just one notable new example of seasoned left-wing activists systematically trying to propagate a creative, arts-inflected style of subversion. Several groups, including the Yes Men, are collaborating on"Beautiful Trouble: Toolbox for the Next Revolution,"a printed manual and Web site .

The Yes Lab is housed at the NYU-supported Hemispheric Institute of Performance and Politics, a consortium of universities in Latin and North America exploring the crossroads of art, activism and scholarship. Servin is also curating a weekly lecture serieson "creative activism."

NYU administrators draw a distinction between Servin's academic perch as a professor and the edgier pursuits of the Yes Lab. The Yes Lab is not in the university curriculum, is not supported with tuition money and is open to pretty much anyone inside or outside the university. The lab is chartered as a non-profit to raise its own funds.

"People can choose to participate in the Yes Lab but it's nobody's job or obligation or course work to participate," says Diana Taylor, founding director of the institute.

'Who are you really, sir?'

Servin and Vamos each had grandfathers who were killed in the Holocaust - family histories, they say, that form a root of their mistrust of authority and sensitivity to what they consider official propaganda.

Servin grew up in Tucson; Vamos near Albany, N.Y. They met in the mid-1990s at the behest of mutual friends after each had gained underground notoriety for a stunt:

Working as a computer game programmer, Servin buried rogue code in the SimCopter game so that scantily clad men would suddenly appear and start kissing wildly. Thousands of doctored games were shipped; Servin was fired. Vamos and some cohorts switched the vocal packages of talking Barbies with those of talking G.I. Joe dolls, and put them back on store shelves, leading to a rash of confused children being interviewed on television. Their Barbies said things such as "Vengeance is mine." The G.I. Joes said, "It's so much fun to shop with you." In interviews at the time, Vamos and his cohorts said the prank was a critique of gender stereotyping and violence inherent in toys.

Servin and Vamos created a techno activist art project that made it into the Whitney Biennial in 2000, using invented corporate-style Web sites and press releases to proclaim the existence of a secret network of pranksters embedded across corporate America. The Yes Men were born when, after further experiments with fake Web sites, they were surprised that some journalists and officials took the Web sites seriously, clicked on "contact," and sought interview subjects and speakers. The Yes Men obliged these requests.

Their real names sound like aliases, so as the Yes Men they devised the more "normal" monikers Andy Bichlbaum (Servin) and Mike Bonanno (Vamos).

The 2004 romp on BBC http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A34057-2004Dec3.htmlprompted the world media to put the debate over corporate responsibility in the news on the 20th anniversary of the disaster at a Union Carbide pesticide plant that killed thousands. (Carbide had paid $470 million to the Indian government. Dow later acquired Carbide. The Bhopal site remains contaminated and survivors say they are sick.)

The BBC declined to comment for this story; Dow did not respond to several requests for comment.

Over the years, the Yes Men have talked gibberish on behalf of the World Trade Organization; distributed candles they said were prototypes made by Exxon to recycle the body fat of victims of climate change; and demonstrated the bogus SurvivaBall spherical body suit they said was created by Halliburton to allow a person to withstand any disaster.

During the fake 2009 Chamber of Commerce news conference - attended by real reporters, including one from The Washington Post - Servin posed as the fictional spokesman "Hingo Sembra." A real chamber official burst into the room and created a scene that guaranteed widespread, snickering media coverage.

"This is a fraudulent press activity and a stunt," said the real chamber official, Eric Wohlschlegel.

"Who are you really, sir?" asked Sembra/Servin.

"I work there, and you do not look familiar to me at all," Wohlschlegel said.

"You can't barge in here and interrupt our press conference," Sembra/Servin said.

"This is a fraud! He's lying!" Wohlschlegel said.

The chamber declined to comment for this story. In a brief supporting the 2009 lawsuit, still pending in U.S. District Court in Washington, the chamber's lawyers wrote: "Jacques Servin and Igor Vamos are con artists who have operated under many aliases to perpetrate their schemes. They characterize their business as 'identity correction' - posing as other persons for the purpose of misrepresenting their positions to the public. This is just another way to say 'identity theft.'"

The Yes Men's pro bono legal team, including the Electronic Frontier Foundation, responded that the stunt was constitutionally protected parody and political speech.

Critics sometimes see the humor but not the point.

"Candles made from human bodies? It was grotesque; at least it was funny. But there again, what's the point?" says Marlo Lewis Jr., senior fellow on energy and environmental policy at the free-market-advocatingCompetitive Enterprise Institute, who has a cameo in "The Yes Men Fix the World." "They're pretty good at self-promotion. How have they advanced public understanding of any issue?"

Despite their reliance on deception, Servin and Vamos say they never allow a lie to linger. The Dow, Chamber and GE hoaxes were revealed in less than an hour. The point, they say, is never the lie; the point is the momentary disoriented pause when - they hope - reporters and the public will ask, What if the lie were true?

"It's keeping the ideas alive that things can be different, and that there's something dramatically wrong with the world," Servin says. "So that when change is possible, those ideas are there. And now is a time when change is really possible."

Young activists see them as role models.

"They make me feel like any of these big issues will be able to be fixed with a positive outlook and a creative approach," says Jessica Assaf, 21, a senior at NYU majoring in public health and social activism, who worked with the Yes Men on a recent project to place official-looking stickers on water fountains in New York saying, "This water is most likely safe," as part of an anti-fracking campaign.

Last month Servin gave a guest-artist lecture at the Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore, where he urged the students: "Figure out how you really might want to change the world, and don't worry about the [art] gallery."

With BFF's like these . . .

Back in the Yes Lab, Servin gives a brief illustrated tour of the history of political pranktivism, from Abbie Hoffman throwing money in the New York Stock Exchange to Iraq Veterans Against the Warperforming a mock "patrol"through downtownD.C.

Ivan Marovic, a former leader of the Otpor anti-Milosevic youth movement in Serbia, discusses the role of art and humor in creating "dilemma actions," where no matter how the authorities react, they look ridiculous or worse.

The lab participants divide into working groups to focus on issues within the theme of income disparity, including corporate tax avoidance, military spending and immigration. The working groups report back with possible stunts, which the larger group critiques.

(We can't be more specific because all Yes Lab participants must agree not to reveal details of specific actions, and a reporter is allowed to attend under the same ground rules.)

One Occupy Wall Street-related action that went public Oct. 17 invites activists to become"best friends forever"- via phone, e-mail or personal visits - with some of the "1% who have wrecked the economy," accompanied by a list of corporate chieftains to befriend.

The inner workings of a good stunt are subtler than they might appear. "The idea," the Yes Men explain in their tip sheet, "is to make funny stuff that asecondaryaudience (viewing the video of the action, or reading your press releases) will enjoy and understand, but that will not clobber theprimaryaudience over the head so that they chase you into the parking lot. (That happened to us once.)"

Homework for the next session is to crank out 80 percent of the plan of each project.

For the Yes Men, this work is not academic.

"The whole thing is meant to be a machine for action," Vamos says. "People are participating in actions, and that's how they learn. If an action doesn't come from it, then it's traditional school."

montgomery@washpost.com


LOAD-DATE: October 23, 2011


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


DISTRIBUTION: Every Zone


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2011 The Washington Post
All Rights Reserved


338 of 348 DOCUMENTS


The Times (London)


March 11, 2000, Saturday


The beaten generation


BYLINE: Janine di Giovanni


SECTION: Features


LENGTH: 3813 words


 

When the Nato bombing campaign ended, there was little for the young people of Serbia to celebrate. Having endured 12 years of Milosevic's reign, a decade of wars, economic meltdown and international pariah status, they found themselves with no money, no prospects and nowhere to go. Janine di Giovanni meets the lost youth of Belgrade

Ilooked everywhere, but Aleksandra was gone. At the apartment she despised - a twelfth-floor communist-style block in Yugoslavia's New Belgrade - the phone rang into dead space. The mobile that she carried with her like a spare limb was disconnected: a voice in Serbo-Croat sternly informed me the person had abandoned the number. The crowded coffee bar that blasted Puff Daddy was strangely quiet without her: the bartender said he hadn't seen her for weeks. Maria, a mutual friend, wasn't surprised. "If she had a chance to get out of Belgrade, she would have taken it," she said. "She probably got a visa and jumped in the first car and drove to Hungary. Maybe she got a break." 

Aleks needed a lucky break. When I met her in the summer of last year she was 22, an archaeology student who had abandoned her studies during the Nato war because her thesis - the restoration of Orthodox churches in Kosovo - became obsolete. The bombing campaign against her city had just ended, but she and her friends weren't celebrating. Instead, the end of the war signalled something more terrifying to them: a black hole of a future, with no prospects and no dreams. They had no money. They had no visas to travel - being Serbs, it was impossible to get a visa to enter any civilised country (the Serbs' only friends are the Iraqis, Libyans and Chinese) and even if they could wangle one, they needed the money to get to Hungary.

The war in Kosovo forced most Western countries to close their embassies in Belgrade. Now they can't even bury themselves in studies. Most classes in their universities have been halted since the war: those that have re-started are hopelessly overcrowded. And with university professors earning about $ 100 a month, it makes more sense for them to become black marketeers and sell illegal gasoline in plastic Coke bottles or Bulgarian cigarettes on street corners. If you have links to the Government, you can make thousands, so why earn an honest living? "I really feel for these kids," says Stasa Babic, a professor of philosophy at Belgrade University. "They have no prospects. They really are a lost generation."

Last June, a few days after the Yugoslav federal parliament voted to lift the official state of war, a Belgrade-based economic think tank called G-17 published the cheerful news that in 40 years time, the economy would be back to its 1989 pre-war state. In 1999, the GDP was 44.4 per cent lower than 1998 because of the war, and the damage caused by Nato was estimated at Pounds 17.4 million. This news was published in Blic, one of the few newspapers that doesn't toe the government line. That day, Ana, Aleksandra's best friend, read the news out loud and dropped her head in her hands in despair. She said that according to her grandmother, it took Belgrade 30 years to get back on its feet after the Second World War. "I don't want to wait 30 years to have a normal life," she said. And for the moment these kids - the Milosevic generation - do not have normal lives. In a sense, they are the American equivalent of slackers. They don't quite see the point of wasting their time planning for the future or trying to work hard. The only role models they have, the only people doing well in Belgrade, are gangsters with thick necks and bimbo girlfriends.

Aleks's friends seem to spend most of their time in coffee bars, inventing elaborate visions of escape or working as translators for the few foreigners who come to Belgrade. The only one with a job is Ivan, who desperately wants to finish his degree, but has to work to support his family after his father was killed by a hit-and-run driver on the highway to Montenegro. Ivan drags himself off to a job at a graphic-design firm for $ 100 a month. Even Aleks's brother, Dragan, who is 18 and has every reason to look forward to life, seems to move through his days with an air of resigned defeat: he pores over Will Smith MTV videos and talks endlessly of going to America to play professional basketball. "I can't make it here," he says. "Only the children of the political elite manage to get ahead."

"This is what I call 'Futureless in Belgrade'," Aleksandra once told me. "Something like Sleepless in Seattle, but without the jokes."

Far worse than their immediate future is the terrible lingering sense of failure left over from the loss of four wars. This generation, now in their twenties, who have survived the 12-year reign of Slobodan Milosevic, have known nothing but a decade of economic meltdown, losses, dead soldiers, sanctions, anti-Milosevic demonstrations and gloom. And, politically, they are confused. While they don't actively oppose the current regime - very few of the ones I meet are out marching on the streets to topple Milosevic - they try to question exactly what has happened to their country, but get caught up in their own Serb victimisation: "The world is against us."

In 1990, when Tito died and the first of Yugoslavia's wars began - the one against Slovenian succession - the country was just poised to move closer to the West. As young teenagers, they had a tantalising taste of modern society, and then, suddenly and terribly, it was snatched from them. Now they don't know what to believe. Did Serb soldiers commit atrocities in Kosovo? Aleks didn't want to think about it because her own young friends were forced to serve in the province during the war. One came back so shell-shocked by what he saw that he had a breakdown and is now in hospital. "I don't want to think of my people doing things like that," she said. "It can't be possible. A lot of it is propaganda."

There are three viable options for the Milosevic generation: to join the criminal underworld where one at least can earn a decent living; to live in gloom; or to emigrate. Since 1990, estimates of the number of university-trained young people who have fled the city range from about 100,000 to 300,000 - a major brain drain. In 1991, only about 622,000 people in a population of 10 million had more than a secondary-school education. All those talented engineers, mathematicians and scientists, as well as writers, actors and artists, are high-tailing it to Germany, to France, to any country that will take them. "Emigration is always hanging over my head," said Aleksandra sombrely. She counted off the number of lucky friends who got away: one, two, three, four, five... "No, it's too depressing. Everyone's gone away."

Shortly before the Solidarity movement in Poland, Rolling Stone reporter P.J. O'Rourke went to Warsaw to observe the lives of young Poles. He came to this conclusion: "Living in Poland," he wrote, "is like living with your parents. Forever."

It's the same thing with Belgrade - in fact, most Serbs between the ages of 18 and 30 do live with their parents. Before the wars began, Belgrade was the coolest place in the former Yugoslavia - in fact, in most of Eastern Europe. Czechs, Hungarians, Russians and Romanians drifted to the White City on the Danube because of its intellectual ambience: it was a bit like Paris in the Twenties. Film-makers like Goran Paskaljevic (The Powder Keg) and Srdjan Dragojevic (Pretty Villages, Pretty Flames) hung out at the National Theatre. Writers like Vladimir Arsenijevic (In the Hold) wrote about young Serbs and their loves and lives. Musicians, artists, dancers, intellectuals and free-thinkers migrated to the excellent restaurants - Serbs love their food - and all-night clubs.

All that has changed. Now it is cool to be a gangster, not a thinker, and the city is divided neatly in two: those who have money - which means it probably came from some dodgy place and therefore they are probably connected to the Milosevic regime - and those who do not. Those who do not, still struggle to get on with life, but it is a struggle. They are a lost generation, but without champagne cocktails and glamour.

Still, they try. "This is what we do: we come home after work, if we work, and then take a nap," says Marija, who is studying international law, but who lost a year because she fled to Montenegro when the bombing started. "Then we eat dinner and go out around midnight. Everyone stays out until six or seven and then goes to breakfast, then goes to work..."

"No one goes to work," interrupts her friend Ilisa. "No one has any work."

"Yeah, that's right, I forgot," Marija says.

It seems like there isn't a problem at first glance. Then when you talk to people, you realise thereis a common thread: nearly everyone spends all the money they have on bars and clubs; no one is getting married or having children and no one is talk-ing about what they want to do when they grow up. There's no flash "I want to work in the city" or "I want to be the next Richard Branson" talk. There's just the constant thud of music, drugs coming from Albania and Turkey, and lots of drink to ease the pain.

Katerina, who is 19, meets me in The Sports Cafe which has re-opened after being closed for several weeks by "the financial police". "Don't ask why," she says. She tells me that she is in her first year at university, studying graphic engineering, but doesn't see the point of going to classes. "Now they hold them in old cinemas downtown because there are so many people," she says. "We share seats and have to write with our notebooks on our knees. A lot of refugees from Kosovo are there. The Government is embarrassed, so they let them in without taking exams." A jumped-up version of the Verve's Bitter Sweet Symphony blares out of the speakers and Katerina silently mouths the words. She looks thoughtful.

"Since the bombing," she says, studying the menu of bad American-style food, none of which she can afford, "my life is going down. My father is a printer. He works two jobs, so I never see him. My mother works as a music teacher and not many people want music lessons any more. But the worst thing is psychological. Since the bombing, nothing surprises me any more. I'm ready for anything. My country is sinking, but since we've touched bottom, where else is there to go?" She says that she will go the first chance she has: once she has money, once she can scam a visa. At the moment, her mother gives her DM50 (Pounds 15) a month to live on while she is studying: a pair of imported shoes costs DM100, a cup of tea in a cafe DM1. It is this kind of stagnation that is forcing her to think about leaving and never coming back. "My parents taught me not to be emotionally connected to anything that cannot survive," she says.

The answer to all this angst is to numb the pain. Katerina doesn't have a boyfriend ("What's the point? No one is getting married any more") so she goes out every night with friends to places where she can order one drink and linger a long time. Men pay DM1.5 to enter the clubs; women get in free and they can usually get someone to buy them a glass of vodka for DM2.5.

At 2 o'clock in the morning, Reseva (the name means monastery), a club in Central Belgrade, is heaving with sweaty bodies swaying to the Pan Band doing a cover of Born to be Wild. Everyone may be out of work, but the beer and tequila slammers are flowing and there is so much smoke from imitation Marlboros that tears run down my cheeks. Beautiful girls with long blonde hair and tattoos on their bare shoulders are gyrating; guys in surfer T-shirts and Levi's roll joints and pass them around. It could be fraternity night at an American campus, or a club in the West End, but when you scratch the surface, you see kids who are terrified of the future. "What future?" screams Elizabetta - who was studying computers in "her old life" before the war - over the din. It surprises me that she knows all the words to the Doors' LA Woman, and My Sharona by the Knack. "Why shouldn't I?" she says defensively. "What do you think I did in high school? Listened to the Doors, just like you did."

At 26, like many young Serbs, Elizabetta is tall and heart-stoppingly beautiful. But she is scarred, and in ten days I saw her laugh only once, at the cinema. As a Serb resident of Sarajevo, she was evacuated by her parents with her little brother in 1992. She expected to be gone for a week; instead she found herself in exile. As a result of the four lost wars, there are nearly half a million internally displaced people - Serbs who originally lived in Bosnia, Croatia or Kosovo - now scattered throughout the country. It is fair to say that the refugees are treated like second-class citizens - they are living proof of the failed wars, and an embarrassment to the Government.

Elizabetta carries a card in her wallet which defines her as a non-resident of Belgrade, even though she is a Serb. It is a constant reminder that she is a refugee: but while she should feel she is among her own people, she never does. When I ask her why she doesn't go home, she looks startled: "To what?" she says. "There's nothing left in Sarajevo - hardly any Serbs; most of my friends are gone; my house is gone."

She is spending most of her energy trying to get a visa to go to Italy, where her best friend is living. "I could take the train," she says, "cross Croatia, cross Slovenia... and vroom! I'd be somewhere sunny and warm. Somewhere with a life." Until then, she fantasises: she spends most of her time going to the cinema to see American romantic comedies at the Dom Omladine (House of Youth) on Friday nights, a cavernous place with hard-backed seats and a room packed with pool tables.

Her dream is not of finishing her degree and getting a job, but of bumping into Joseph Fiennes. For a young woman who was always first in her class, studying is not a way out. She gave up going to Belgrade University Faculty of Maths because there are ten computers for 800 students. The computers are loaded with software seven years old. The unheated hallways are packed with sniffling students elbowing each other to get a seat for a lecture.

As in the old communist days, they queue up and wait with grim resignation. Everything is crowded in Belgrade: the police station where refugees like Elizabetta must come once a month to register; the shops which sell cheap Chinese clothes or stolen Italian goods which have been smuggled in by stewardesses on JAT Airlines; the corner stores that run out of bread by 8am; and, of course, the life force of the city, the bars.

It is clear how little work gets done by the number of people whiling away the hours in cafes and bars during the day. In Stupidca, attached to the National Theatre where Closer is showing starring Branka Katic, a young Serb who also starred in the BBC drama Warriors, writers, directors and theatre people hang out for hours over espressos, discussing the script they are going to write, the project they are trying to get off the ground, or the Berlin or Cannes film festivals that they can't get visas to attend.

The walls are lined with photographs of a naked blonde teenager, a Claudia Schiffer lookalike who works at a bar down the street. Her pouting face, bare bottom and adolescent breasts stare down at us. "She comes here a lot," says one of the directors, staring at a photo of the teenager with her hands down her trousers in a faux-masturbation pose. "Doesn't she feel uncomfortable when she comes in here and everyone sees her naked?" I ask. Someone called Alex, a former theatre manager now working for French television, sighs. "She thinks maybe some model agent from outside will see them and take her away and make her a star."

The truth is a model scout could never get a visa to get into Belgrade, and it is doubtful that the pretty teenager will ever get out of here. The most she can hope for is to use her beauty to lure either one of the few foreigners who come to Belgrade to take her away, or attract a gangster boyfriend. The latter is the easiest, as Belgrade is ripe with thugs carrying the three Bs - beeper, Beretta and babes. Their girlfriends, often as young as 15 or 16, are known as "sponsor girls", which is something like being a geisha girl in Japan but without the charm and cultural history. They are middle-class high-school girls happy to trade their beautiful bodies for a bit of comfort from a skinhead thug.

But there are rewards. You can play tennis at a club. You get to go to expensive restaurants sucn as Villa, Frans, Mali Porto or Soho Bar, and carry stylish little silver Nokia phones. In the summer, you go swimming in the sea off the Montenegrin coast. Even under sanctions, life isn't too bad for a sponsor girl. That is, until they are replaced by someone younger. The sad truth is, you don't get ahead, you don't get rich by being hard-working in Belgrade. And everyone knows it. Says Katerina: "Maybe sponsor girls aren't so stupid. Someone takes care of them."

"Wanna go shopping?" Angela asks. Angela is 24 and wealthy. She grew up abroad, is fluent in several languages and her parents have money stashed outside Yugoslavia. She has a car, a patent-leather wallet from Prada in Rome, and the option to get out of the country whenever she wants. Don't ask how. Shopping in Belgrade is not like shopping anywhere else in the world. First, Angela makes a few calls on her mobile (bill paid for by daddy). Then we meet on a downtown corner and drive to the old part of town. "My friend just got four Prada bags," she says mysteriously. "How?" No reply. She turns the radio up in the car and we park and enter a walled house. We knock, an armed guard nods and lets us in. A smiling blonde in tight trousers and red lipstick invites us into her sitting room which has racks of one-off extremely expensive designer clothes: Armani, Alberta Ferretti, Marni, Ungaro, plus a few fur coats. Men's suits and shoes are piled in her bedroom. Where it all comes from, one can only guess.

Angela tries on a Moschino gown and decides she doesn't like it. Maybe a MaxMara cashmere overcoat in black? "Check back next week," says the woman, disappointed that we didn't fork over hundreds of marks. "I've got new stuff coming from Milan."

Next stop is a lingerie boutique run out of a thug's home. Boxes upon boxes of the gaspingly expensive Italian lingerie, La Perla (average cost for a bra in England, Pounds 125; average cost here on the black market, Pounds 20), are arranged in his spare bedroom. Frantic girls change in the bathroom alongside his bottles of cheap aftershave and dirty towels; he sits behind a desk and takes the hard cash - marks only. I don't see his gun, but I know he has one. He must have close to Pounds 1 million worth of underwear in his spare bedroom.

"Let's hit the bars," Angela says, looking at her watch. It's about 5pm - time for a reviving cocktail before the nap that will allow us to continue on into the night. We go to KGB, one of the hippest rendezvous in Belgrade, where Nina, 25, is coming off a double shift at the state-run radio station where she works as a DJ. Her eyes are ringed with black circles: her hands shake with exhaustion as she lights a cigarette. She does shifts five times a week and gets DM80 a month. She orders a beer and tells me how much life sucks. "A good lipstick costs DM20. A CD costs DM23," she says. "I can't afford that, and I've been working for the station for five years. And I still live with my parents. Your life is supposed to improve as you get older. Mine just seems to get harder." She was 14 when the wars started. She remembers because her family had a house in Dubrovnik where they went every summer. "One day, we just stopped going and Dubrovnik ceased to exist for me."

Nina and her friends have inherited a Serb sense of victimisation - the ingrained certainty that the world is against them. But in many ways, she has a point. "Young people here are lost in space," she says. "Everyone wants to get out of here. Everyone wants to leave and never come back. The only reason I stay is because of the graves of my ancestors." Also, she adds, who would take her? "When you show your passport, and people know you're a Serb, people resent and hate you... the world hates us. And here, the truth about the world is blocked - the censorship is so strong that we never know what is real and what are lies."

Her boyfriend, Dan, is one of the most popular rock stars in Serbia. He worships Brian Eno and Bono, both of whom have shown great interest in Yugoslavia. Dan's lived for years in America and England, but his songs focus on love and general Nirvana-like angst, Serb-style, rather than Bob Dylan-style politics. This is deliberate. Dan says part of the problem is that the youth of Serbia "don't know the language of rebellion. It's not like punk in England, where a generation rose up and protested - here, young people are still sleeping. They feel, but they don't know how to show it. They're angry, but they don't know how to use their power. It's a question of time when this (Milosevic) regime topples, but they aren't doing anything valuable to help shift things. They're lost."

Nina and Dan marched in the winter 1996 anti-Milosevic demonstrations. Then, everyone felt there was a chance to topple Milosevic. Now, the bombing campaign appears to have made him stronger than ever, uniting the Serbs with their victimisation. Neither Dan nor Tina attended any of the political opposition's recent demonstrations, which, because of poor attendance, have been reduced to Saturday marches. "In 1996, all the clever people were on the streets trying to change the world," says Dan. "Now they are all sleeping. They lost hope."

"These politicians have got to go," agrees Nina. But she says she won't support the Milosevic political opposition, the Alliance for Change. "I have enough troubles," she says. "And, besides, I worked every day and every night of the bombing. We're too busy surviving to try to overthrow a government."

After ten days in Belgrade, I discover what happened to my friend Aleksandra. In the space of about a month, she met a foreigner, got married and got out of Yugoslavia. I always knew she had something special. I used to think that had she not been born in Yugoslavia in 1977, she would have been bound for great things. The marriage shocked me. When I first heard the news, my stomach sank. What happened to all of her dreams of graduate school, of work, of travel? Then I thought of her sad, hungover face when she described being "Futureless in Belgrade". Maybe it's not the best move, getting married at 22, but at least she got away.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 2000 Times Newspapers Limited


339 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Copyright (c) 1995 Cornell International Law Journal
Cornell International Law Journal


Spring, 1995


28 Cornell Int'l L.J. 701


LENGTH: 3240 words


SYMPOSIUM: Peacekeeping, Peacemaking, & Peacebuilding: The Role of the United Nations in Global Conflict: Peacekeeping in Operation: A Conflict Study of Bosnia: The Predicament of Peacekeeping in Bosnia


NAME: Tibor Varady *


BIO:


* Pro-Rector, Director of the Legal Studies Department, and Professor of Law, Central European University; S.J.D., Harvard Law School, 1970; LL.M., Harvard Law School, 1968; LL.M., Belgrade University Faculty of Law, 1967; Law Graduate, Belgrade University Faculty of Law, 1962. From July 1992 to March 1993, the author served as the Minister of Justice of Yugoslavia (in the Government of Milan Panic).


LEXISNEXIS SUMMARY:
 ... As some earlier speakers did, I would also like to start with semantics about peacekeeping, peacemaking, and peacebuilding. ... It began with peacekeeping and then moved towards peacemaking. ... The international community began to address the conflict first with peacekeeping, hoping that this would later yield peacemaking. ... Then, there were no-fly zones (which actually functioned as fly-watch zones), the threat of airstrikes, and finally, NATO. ... Sarajevo used to have a sizable Jewish community, originating mostly from Spain. ... Tragic events of the past gradually lost their significance, and the prospect of living together was very much enhanced by multiculturalism and acceptance of distinct ethnic, religious, and linguistic identities. ... Even though events are moving towards ethnic separation, they have not even reached a half-way point. Recognizing the concept of ethnic separation is not just acquiescence in a status quo, it is an instigation of a continued cruel march towards the gruesome objective. ... One should also ask what message will be sent to the former Soviet Union and to other areas experiencing ethnic tensions if the international community concludes that the only solution to ethnic differences is ethnic purity, ethnic partition and the changing of borders. ...  


TEXT:
 [*701] 

I. Keeping Peace - and Authority
 
Thank you for giving me this opportunity to speak. As some earlier speakers did, I would also like to start with semantics about peacekeeping, peacemaking, and peacebuilding. I do not subscribe to the idea of an overarching notion of peacekeeping that would extend even to operations such as the Gulf War. Furthermore, I am fairly certain that peacekeeping units would not be happy with this perception either, because they often have explained their action or inaction in terms of limitations inherent in the concept of peacekeeping. I think that their explanations are entitled to some respect.

I was somewhat puzzled with the sequence of this conference's topics. It began with peacekeeping and then moved towards peacemaking. While logic cannot offer much support to this sequence, it is precisely the order that was attempted in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The international community began to address the conflict first with peacekeeping, hoping that this would later yield peacemaking. It may seem rather easy to demonstrate the logical inconsistency of this progression, but a closer examination of the concepts of peacekeeping and peacemaking reveals that things are not so simple. These concepts are interlocking notions which involve different levels of reality.

The role of peacekeeping, like many other roles in the former Yugoslavia, was a transfunctional one. Peacekeeping forces in Bosnia, and in the former Yugoslavia in general, were always called "peacekeeping," but they were clearly awaited as peacemaking forces. This was not merely wishful thinking on the part of Bosnians or other aggrieved residents of the former Yugoslavia. The problem was how to make peace, and the mission was heralded as a solution to the problem. There was a tremendous pressure to do something to stop the war, the atrocities, and ethnic cleansing, and the United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR) was a response to this pressure. Political leaders in various countries explained to their voters that UNPROFOR was the means by which something would finally be  [*702] done, and it was clearly understood that making peace was what UNPROFOR would attempt to do.

When the peacekeepers arrived, it became obvious that their mandate, their equipment, and their logistic support seriously restricted them. Still, they had one asset which seemed to proffer them some chance of success. This asset was their prestige, their authority. It was the first time in Eastern Europe that such a move was made. The "international community" stepped in, and I think that it was not a completely foolish expectation to believe that the arrival of U.N. troops would keep some ambitions at bay and possibly check aggression.

Bringing into play authority in Bosnia was not a completely new gambit. This has been the general approach towards events in Yugoslavia. When the various Carrington plans were offered, the authority of the European Community (E.C.) stood behind them. This authority lent credibility to the E.C. position taken in the August 27, 1991 Brussels Declaration stating that its members would never accept the politics of fait accompli. All of the E.C. plans were accepted by Slovenia, Macedonia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, and Croatia. These plans were all rejected by Serbia and Montenegro with the exception of one which Montenegro accepted and only Serbia rejected.

At that time, the authority behind both the threats and incentives was very sparingly used. Involvement was growing, yet the avoidance of involvement remained a cherished political value. At that time, no economic or other sanction had been mentioned; there were only suggestions that those who accepted the plan would fare better economically. These suggestions had some credibility given the economic stature of the European Community.

In 1991, it was still unthinkable to mention military threat or protection. The E.C.'s very cautious and gradual use of authority actually resulted in a corruption of authority of some magnitude. Prestige was spent just up to the level where it was neither sufficient nor workable. After the first and succeeding plans were rejected, more powerful components of authority were brought into play. Time and again, the European Community, the United Nations, and the United States were ready to pay yesterday's price for a solution, but never the actual cost.

When military threats were finally used, they were followed up very sparingly. First, there were rumors that the Sixth Fleet would come to the Adriatic. Then, there were no-fly zones (which actually functioned as fly-watch zones), the threat of airstrikes, and finally, NATO. While it cannot be proven, I am quite convinced that a threat of economic sanctions in 1991 would have been effective. A clear promise of considerable economic aid might also have yielded a solution. At that time, however, such a solution appeared too radical. Later, sanctions were announced and introduced, but always at a time when they were no match for the stampede of new developments. The international community's and its key institutions' authority was devalued step by step as stronger and stronger  [*703] promises and threats were made but were never strong enough to do the job.

NATO was the last fragment of authority brought into play. According to a Bosnian Serb paper of July 1995, NATO was defeated by the Bosnian Serb Army. No matter how absurd this sounds, I think that there is some truth to this assertion. It was, of course, a limited showdown, but this is no excuse. If you compare the results in terms of casualties, NATO lost more people in the confrontation than the Bosnian Serbs lost. As far as material losses are concerned, NATO lost, among other things, several planes (Harriers around Gorazde, another plane in the area of Banja Luka, and two Predator spy-planes), while Bosnian Serbs suffered no equivalent losses from the NATO attacks.

One can hardly contest that NATO has been a clear loser in terms of moral loss and damage to credibility. Not only were none of NATO's aims achieved, but NATO failed to even frustrate or forestall the aims of Karadzic and Mladic. Thus, the Bosnian Serbs' claim that they handed NATO a military defeat is not completely nonsensical. It is well known that NATO committed only a limited force and that it was hindered by a complicated chain of command. But the chain of command, chain of motivation, and deployment of adequate forces are decisive elements in each confrontation. Thus, the question has arisen whether, within the given political environment, NATO is capable of committing adequate forces and whether it is capable of persisting in its efforts with an adequate chain of command.

The erosion of the authority of the international community's principal agents has continued. The irrationality of Milosevic's and Karadzic's actions have often been mentioned, although it can be argued that they behaved quite rationally in pursuing their own obsessions and interests, and in not bowing to the unrealized threats of NATO. After the fall of Srebrenica and Zepa, two safe havens designated by the Security Council, a new term was established in the international media: Srebrenica, Zepa, Gorazde, Sarajevo and Bihac became "so-called safe havens." The next step in this direction may be the conversion of the Security Council into the "so-called Security Council."

Many are questioning whether peacekeeping efforts have actually accomplished anything. There are, of course, comprehensive reports, some of which were mentioned and cited during this conference, but I would like to relate to you some of my personal impressions. From talking to many people from the region, including friends and former students from Sarajevo, I can only say that the signals are contradictory. It has been said that the peacekeepers failed to keep peace because there was no peace to keep and the authority invested was never sufficient to create peace. I agree. Nevertheless, the United Nations did try to mitigate the tragedy and did achieve some positive results, an accomplishment which must not be underestimated.

How much of the success was attributable to UNPROFOR, the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR), or the International  [*704] Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is difficult to determine and probably not too important to establish. In spite of this limited success, practically all warring factions have a negative picture of U.N. involvement. Recurring accusations emerge in stories about bribery and black-marketeering in which U.N. personnel play the main role. While I cannot confirm these reports, I can confirm that I heard them from many people and from all sides of the conflict.

It is not easy to find neutral observers among the residents of Bosnia. However, some evidence which can be said to come from neutral sources may be cited. During the last several months, I had a chance to speak with some leaders of two very small groups who are in a truly impartial position. In July of last year, I attended a meeting in Geneva of intellectuals from all over the former Yugoslavia, organized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). One of the participants was a man who represented the Jewish community from Sarajevo. Some months later, in Budapest, I met the lady president of the Hungarian community of Sarajevo. Jews and Hungarians are both completely outside the ethnic dividing lines and ethnic strife in Bosnia. Sarajevo used to have a sizable Jewish community, originating mostly from Spain. It also had a small Hungarian community from the time of the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy, but most Hungarians came to Sarajevo from the ranks of the Hungarian minority in Yugoslavia. Some came to study, while others found jobs or established families. Both communities had several thousand members each, but both have dwindled down to only several hundred members.

Their two stories were quite similar. A central point of agreement was that Sarajevo's inhabitants have been facing severe restrictions imposed by three actors: the Serbian blockade (the cruellest actor), the Bosnian government itself, and UNPROFOR. One question I asked these representatives was whether they wanted to leave Sarajevo (They actually had a choice, since I met one of them in Geneva and the other in Budapest). Both stated that they had no desire to leave.

The president of Sarajevo's Hungarian community, whom I met in December 1994, is a professor of veterinary medicine. Her husband is Moslem and a professor of biochemistry. She said that many things had improved. For example, unlike the year before, her eight-year-old son now attends school without being exposed to a great danger of sniper attacks. At the same time, however, she explained that her son's school, had no windows, even in December. There was no glass to replace them. Wooden or tin windows would not suffice, since they would not let in daylight, and there was no electricity. So they had no windows. She also told me that sitting was very difficult since the chairs only had their metal frames (the wooden part was used for heating). She described these conditions as some sort of improvement, and she attributed it partially to the fact that UNPROFOR made getting to school somewhat safer.

The final point made by both my Jewish and my Hungarian acquaintances was quite striking. They stated that the strongest reason for the  [*705] peacekeepers' continued presence was the fact that when there are U.N. peacekeepers present, the press is also there. This presence of the press imposes some restraint on the perpetrators of atrocities.

II. What Peace To Keep?
 
The ethnic landscape of the former Yugoslavia is improbably complex. A Serbian political leader (Vuk Draskovic) compared Yugoslavia's ethnic distribution to the design of a leopard skin. Throughout the course of history this ethnic diversity has often been a source of richness, but no less often a source of conflict. In my opinion, the present confrontation is not between Serbs, Croats, Moslem-Slavs, Albanians, Hungarians, and others, but between those who believe in the possibility and the sense of living together and those whose beliefs are built on the assumption that separation is the only solution.

The fact that these two ideas are expressed openly and explicitly is new. In Tito's Yugoslavia, the only legitimate concept was that of "Brotherhood and Unity," and all other alternative concepts were suppressed (and oppressed). This clearly less-than-democratic imposition of "Brotherhood and Unity" did not mean that below the layers of official politics the opposing concept of "unquenchable historic hatred" remained the only reality. As a matter of fact, life in common had become a reality, and the relevance of history had faded. Tragic events of the past gradually lost their significance, and the prospect of living together was very much enhanced by multiculturalism and acceptance of distinct ethnic, religious, and linguistic identities. Having lived there, my impression is that the bulk of the present conglomerate of hatred is new hatred generated by escalation within the last ten years.

This escalation became possible because of a power vacuum in a space which was suddenly left without authority. Disintegrating communist power opened the gates for the disintegration (or at best reorganization). In federal multiethnic states this power vacuum created a heightened level of societal danger. Constraints, those of the communist party and those of civilization as well, were significantly loosened. Political power, economic power, sovereignty, and national identities lost their bases so that everything was up for grabs. At the same time, the end of state-socialism triggered the end of a long-established international order, and the new situation resulted in confusing responses from international institutions. This is the climate in which ethnic separation established itself as an option within Europe and in which ethnic separation is gaining a resigned but growing international recognition.

I would like to object to the option of ethnic separation, not only on moral grounds or on the basis of norms of civilization (which would be too easy), but on practical grounds as well. I am convinced that both ethical and practical considerations lead to the conclusion that the best way to keep peace in Bosnia and in the former Yugoslavia is through the establishment of a multiethnic and multicultural society.  [*706] 

Even though events are moving towards ethnic separation, they have not even reached a half-way point. Recognizing the concept of ethnic separation is not just acquiescence in a status quo, it is an instigation of a continued cruel march towards the gruesome objective. Also, one must not forget that inter-ethnic marriages in Bosnia-Herzegovina constitute more than twenty percent of all marriages.

In reviewing the practical considerations, one would also have to question whether all Serbs or all Croats could live harmoniously in one state, if such a state came into being. I submit that the cultural dissimilarities and differences in mentality between, for example, Krajina Serbs or Bosnian Serbs on the one hand and Vojvodina Serbs on the other hand, are much larger than the differences between the Vojvodina Serbs and the Vojvodina Hungarians, or the Vojvodina Slovaks. One should also ask what message will be sent to the former Soviet Union and to other areas experiencing ethnic tensions if the international community concludes that the only solution to ethnic differences is ethnic purity, ethnic partition and the changing of borders.

Of course, leaders of nationalistic factions base their legitimacy on the concept that living together is impossible, a concept which stems from the claimed existence of an "unquenchable historic hatred." This theory is questionable even in these nationalistic leaders' most immediate environment. General Mladic's wife is a Macedonian. Karadzic's vice president, Koljevic, has a brother who decided to stay in Bosnian-held Sarajevo and share its suffering. One can see from the phonebook of Sarajevo that, judging by their surnames, most telephone subscribers by the name of Karadzic are Moslems. Few people know that in those areas of Sarajevo which were bombarded by Karadzic and Mladic, there is still a sizeable Serbian population. Some of the Serbs hold important positions in the city administration and in the Bosnian Army as well. A delegation of Bosnian Serbs living in the territory held by the Bosnian government visited Belgrade during the Spring of 1995. They were received very warmly by the anti-war Serbian opposition.

This leads me to my next point, which is that there is an anti-war and anti-Milosevic Serbian opposition. There was and still is a peace movement. Several hundred thousand citizens of Serbia refused the draft, refused to join the civil war, and are still subject to criminal punishment. Nationalist leaders claim, of course, that all their ethnic brethren are with them, and this assumption is readily accepted by those international actors who feel that it would be too much trouble to oppose the realpolitik of ethnic partition. Note also that in December 1992, Milan Panic ran against Milosevic on a platform of multicultural coexistence. He argued for the recognition of Bosnia and Croatia and against the use of ethnicity as an organizing principle. As a consequence, Panic was labelled as a traitor by the Serbian government-controlled media, but he still received about thirty-five percent of the votes. Moreover, these were predominantly Serbian votes because the Albanians boycotted the election and the  [*707] Hungarian minority constitutes less than five percent of the Serbian population (other minorities are even smaller).

Of course, a lot of damage already has been done. Sometimes, reality moves towards negative stereotypes. In recent years, some members of ethnic factions have started acting in exactly the same way in which they were depicted earlier by the rival faction's propaganda. But this is not the whole reality of the former Yugoslavia. All ties have not been broken. There are many examples of bravery reaching beyond ethnic lines, and there are still many people who refuse to judge their neighbors by ethnic criteria. This remaining domain of multiculturalism is what has to be kept, and this is the only foundation on which peace may be built.

A Postscript from September 1995
 
After this essay was written in September 1995, the international community discharged a response which cannot be labelled as sparing, or just-less-than-adequate. Bosnian Serb positions were heavily bombarded by NATO. Realities and attitudes have changed since, and chances for a settlement appear to be genuine. I still believe, however, that the price for the creation of such a chance would have been much lower a year or two earlier. A timely investment of adequate authority would have spared thousands of lives and would have prevented immense devastations.

I still also believe that thrift and the desire for speed should not legitimate ethnic partition because peace cannot be reestablished within the former Yugoslavia without giving multiculturalism a chance.


Legal Topics:

For related research and practice materials, see the following legal topics:
GovernmentsFederal GovernmentDomestic SecurityInternational LawSovereign States & IndividualsHuman RightsGeneral Overview


340 of 348 DOCUMENTS


Copyright (c) 2000 Cornell International Law Journal
Cornell International Law Journal


2000


33 Cornell Int'l L.J. 67


LENGTH: 28580 words


ARTICLE: Information Intervention: Bosnia, the Dayton Accords, and the Seizure of Broadcasting Transmitters


NAME: Monroe E. Price *


BIO:


* Joseph and Sadie Danciger Professor of Law, Howard M. Squadron Program in Law, Media and Society, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law; co-director, Programme in Comparative Media Law and Policy, University of Oxford. This study was written while I was a Fellow of the Media Studies Center in New York. Stacy Sullivan, who had been a reporter in Bosnia-Herzegovina, contributed very substantially to the work due both to her experience and her excellence as a writer. Joseph Perkovich, Eric Blinderman, and Kevin Deborde provided significant research support.


LEXISNEXIS SUMMARY:
 ... Regardless of the content of the broadcasts, they were successful in stirring up hatred against Muslims and Croats. ... These programs would be broadcast on television stations across Bosnia-Herzegovina, helping to improve content and to avoid piracy. ... Characteristically, SRT Pale refused to soften its editorial content. ... The new system would include "codes of conduct for program content," modeled on "the established practices in Western European democracies and in North America." ... It could prohibit rebroadcast of an "offending programme or its content" and temporarily withdraw a license for access to the transmission system. ... Is advocacy of imminent lawless action in a troubled area enough to justify an information intervention? Is the use of fighting words enough to justify an information intervention? When do these types of speech pose a "clear and present danger" to the international community such that an information intervention is justified? Must all information interventions be "narrowly-tailored" and "content neutral" to fit within the discourse of international information intervention?
